title: 'Prison was holiday camp compared to forced labour', court hears
text: Patrick Joseph Connors, 59, Patrick Dean Connors, 39, William Connors, 36, and Lee Carbis, 34, deny several offences. They allegedly kept Michael Hughes, 46, and another man, 41, in "appalling conditions" at an industrial unit in Goole, East Yorkshire. Leeds Crown Court heard how Mr Hughes was allegedly "routinely beaten", forced to work 16-hour days, given only scraps of food and was doused in freezing cold water. In a video interview played to the jury, Mr Hughes said he had to sleep on a "filthy" piece of cardboard in a container. He claimed he was so hungry that he ate raw fish out of a bin, and at one point begged his captors to kill him, saying: "I can't do this, I can't take it any more." The court heard how Mr Hughes managed to escape and raise the alarm after 12 months of captivity. The jury was also shown a video of the other alleged victim, who was so malnourished and weak that he was only able to crawl on his hands and knees. Prosecutor Robert Smith QC said the defendants had treated their victims "like animals" and had "exploited their vulnerability". The defendants claim the two men were willing participants in a legitimate "work placement" scheme. Patrick Joseph Connors told the jury that Mr Hughes was "free to come and go as he pleased" and that he had never been assaulted. He said he had allowed Mr Hughes to sleep in the container because he had nowhere else to go. Patrick Dean Connors claimed that the other alleged victim had been "lazy" and had refused to work. He said he had given the man food and money and had even offered to help him find accommodation. The trial continues.

title: Delhi rape: PM promises to pursue panel recommendations
text: Manmohan Singh wrote to the panel's head, ex-chief justice JS Verma, saying the report would be taken up promptly. The brutal gang rape and murder of a 23-year-old woman on a bus in Delhi in December has sparked outrage in India and around the world. The case has reignited a debate about the safety of women in India and the need for tougher laws against sexual violence. The Verma Commission was set up in response to the public outcry over the Delhi rape case. The commission was tasked with examining the issue of sexual violence in India and making recommendations on how to prevent and respond to such crimes. The commission's report, which was released on 23 January, made a number of recommendations, including: Faster trials for rape cases Longer sentences for convicted rapists The establishment of special courts to deal with sexual violence cases The creation of a national registry of sexual offenders The provision of free legal aid to victims of sexual violence The government has welcomed the commission's report and has pledged to implement its recommendations. However, some activists have expressed concern that the government will not take sufficient action to address the issue of sexual violence in India. The Verma Commission's report is a significant step towards addressing the issue of sexual violence in India. However, it is important to remember that the report is only a first step. The government must now take action to implement the commission's recommendations. Only then will India be able to make progress towards becoming a safer place for women. In addition to the Verma Commission's recommendations, there are a number of other things that can be done to address the issue of sexual violence in India. These include: Education: It is important to educate people about sexual violence, including what it is, how to prevent it, and how to respond to it. Awareness: It is also important to raise awareness about the issue of sexual violence. This can be done through public service announcements, media campaigns, and social media. Support: Victims of sexual violence need support and assistance. This can include medical care, counseling, and legal aid. Prevention: It is also important to work to prevent sexual violence from happening in the first place. This can be done by creating safe environments, empowering women, and holding perpetrators accountable. By working together, we can create a safer future for women in India.

title: Bath and Bristol streets exceed EU pollution levels
text: Data from Bath and North East Somerset and Bristol City Council showed nitrogen dioxide levels were more than twice the EU limit in some roads. Bristol City Council said reducing the amount of traffic to just essential journeys was one of many ways to improve air quality. "We are legally required to meet EU limits on air quality, and we have a number of measures in place to help us do this," a spokesperson said. "These include encouraging people to use public transport, walk or cycle instead of driving, and working with businesses to reduce their emissions." Bath and North East Somerset Council said it was working on a number of initiatives to tackle air pollution, including promoting electric vehicles and installing electric vehicle charging points. "We are also working with local schools and businesses to encourage them to reduce their emissions," a spokesperson said. "We recognize that air pollution is a serious issue, and we are committed to doing everything we can to improve air quality in Bath and North East Somerset." Air pollution is a major public health issue, and it is estimated to cause around 40,000 premature deaths in the UK each year. Nitrogen dioxide is a pollutant that is particularly harmful to respiratory health, and it can cause a range of problems, including asthma, bronchitis, and lung cancer. The EU has set a limit for nitrogen dioxide of 40 micrograms per cubic meter of air (µg/m³). However, data from Bath and North East Somerset and Bristol City Council showed that nitrogen dioxide levels were more than twice this limit in some roads. For example, on the A4 in Bath, nitrogen dioxide levels were as high as 88 µg/m³, and on the M32 in Bristol, levels were as high as 82 µg/m³. These high levels of air pollution are a serious concern, and it is clear that more needs to be done to improve air quality in Bath and Bristol. One way to reduce air pollution is to reduce the amount of traffic on the roads. This can be done by encouraging people to use public transport, walk, or cycle instead of driving. Another way to reduce air pollution is to promote electric vehicles. Electric vehicles do not produce any emissions, so they are much better for air quality than petrol or diesel vehicles. Bath and Bristol councils are both working on a number of initiatives to tackle air pollution, but more needs to be done. The government needs to provide more funding for local councils to invest in public transport and electric vehicle charging points.

title: Poland profile - Overview
text: There have been periods of independence as well as periods of domination by other countries. Several million people, half of them Jews, died in the Holocaust perpetrated by Nazi Germany during World War Two. After the war, most of Poland's eastern territories were annexed by the Soviet Union, while its western border was shifted westwards into what had been Germany. The country became a Soviet satellite state, the Polish People's Republic. In 1980, the Solidarity trade union was founded, leading to a period of social and political upheaval. In 1989, Solidarity won elections, leading to the collapse of the communist government and the establishment of a democratic republic. Poland joined NATO in 1999 and the European Union in 2004. It is now a developed country with a free market economy. Political system Poland is a parliamentary republic. The president is elected by popular vote for a five-year term. The prime minister is appointed by the president and approved by parliament. The parliament consists of a lower house (Sejm) and an upper house (Senate). Economy Poland has a developed market economy. The country's main industries include agriculture, manufacturing, mining, and tourism. Poland is also a major exporter of coal, steel, and dairy products. Demographics Poland has a population of about 38 million people. The vast majority of the population is ethnically Polish. There are also significant minorities of Ukrainians, Belarusians, Germans, and Russians. Religion The majority of Poles are Roman Catholic. There are also significant minorities of Eastern Orthodox, Protestant, and Jewish people. Culture Poland has a rich cultural heritage. The country is home to many famous composers, writers, and artists. Polish cuisine is also known for its hearty and flavorful dishes. Sport Poland is a sporting nation. The country has produced many Olympic champions, particularly in track and field and weightlifting. Football is the most popular sport in Poland, and the national team has qualified for several major tournaments. Foreign policy Poland is a member of the European Union and NATO. The country has close ties with its neighbors, particularly Germany and France. Poland is also a strong supporter of Ukraine in its conflict with Russia. Challenges Poland faces a number of challenges, including: Economic inequality Corruption Environmental pollution The aging population The government is working to address these challenges, but they will continue to be a major concern for the country in the years to come.

title: Three teenagers arrive in Fiji after Pacific ordeal
text: The boys, from the Tokelau Islands, a New Zealand-administered territory in the South Pacific, had been given up for dead. However, on September 15, the boys were spotted by a passing fishing boat about 1,500 kilometers (932 miles) from their home island. They were taken to the Fijian island of Ono-i-Lau, where they were given medical attention. The boys, aged 15, 14, and 13, told rescuers that they had survived by eating fish and drinking rainwater. They said they had also used a sail to catch rainwater. The boys' families were overjoyed to learn that they were alive. They said they had never given up hope that their sons would be found. The boys' survival is a testament to their resilience and determination. It is also a reminder of the dangers that people face when they venture out into the open ocean. The Tokelau Islands are a group of three atolls located in the South Pacific Ocean. The islands are home to about 1,500 people. The islands are a New Zealand-administered territory. The boys' ordeal began when they set off in a small boat on September 5 to go fishing. They were planning to fish for a few hours and then return home. However, the weather conditions worsened, and the boys lost their way. The boys drifted for days, with no food or water. They eventually spotted a passing fishing boat and were rescued. The boys' rescue is a reminder of the importance of being prepared when venturing out into the open ocean. It is also a reminder of the importance of never giving up hope.

title: Climate change to drive 'massive' investment shift
text: Larry Fink, who runs BlackRock, said the shift will happen "sooner than most anticipate". His company has announced "sustainable" versions of its products and pledged that "climate change" would be a core investment conviction. "We are on the edge of a fundamental reshaping of finance," Fink wrote in his annual letter to shareholders. "The evidence on climate risk is compelling investors to reassess core assumptions about modern finance." The value of assets that explicitly target environmental, social and governance (ESG) factors doubled to $40 trillion last year, according to investment research firm Morningstar. So far, much of the investment has been in equity markets, with a focus on renewable energy stocks. But Fink believes this is just the start. "We are entering a 'new era of investing'," he said. "The next 1,000 unicorns won't be search engines or social media companies, they'll be sustainable, scalable innovators – startups that help the world decarbonize and create a more sustainable future." Fink's comments come as the world grapples with the escalating climate crisis. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has warned that global emissions must be cut by 45% by 2030 to limit global warming to 1.5C above pre-industrial levels. To achieve this, the world will need to invest trillions of dollars in clean energy, energy efficiency, and other climate-friendly technologies. According to the International Energy Agency (IEA), the global energy sector will need to invest around $5 trillion per year over the next decade to achieve net zero emissions by 2050. The shift towards sustainable investing is being driven by a number of factors, including growing awareness of the climate crisis, regulatory changes, and changing consumer preferences. Investors are increasingly realizing that climate change poses a major financial risk. According to the Bank of England, climate change could cause global GDP to decline by up to 10% by 2050. Governments are also introducing new regulations to encourage sustainable investing. In the UK, the government has introduced a new requirement for large pension funds to report on their climate-related risks and opportunities. Consumers are also increasingly demanding products and services from companies that are committed to sustainability. According to a recent survey by Nielsen, 66% of global consumers are willing to pay more for products and services from sustainable brands. The shift towards sustainable investing is a major challenge, but it is also a major opportunity. By investing in companies that are helping to solve the climate crisis, investors can generate long-term financial returns and help to create a more sustainable future.

title: Teenagers risk missing out on savings pots
text: By Kevin Peachey Personal finance reporter These funds were set up by the Labour government in 2005 to encourage parents to save for their children and to promote financial awareness. They began with an automatic contribution from the government of £250, which was doubled for the most disadvantaged families, and additional payments can also be made by parents and family members. Now known as Child Trust Funds (CTFs), they were initially very popular. In its first 12 months of operation almost one million CTFs were opened, and 13 years on around 6.3 million CTFs have been opened across the UK.  However, campaigners say that take-up started to decline following the introduction of a lower contribution rate, set at £50, by the Conservative government in 2011. There are also concerns that parents are not saving into them as much as they could. The average total amount saved in a CTF is just under £1,000 - well below the £1,865 total maximum government contribution. Last year, the Post Office found that 43% of the Child Trust Funds it looks after still only had the original £250 government contribution and there was no additional money added.  A further 22% had less than £500 in total. The Children's Investment Fund Foundation (CIFF) is concerned that this means rising numbers of young people could be missing out on a substantial financial boost when they reach 18, the age at which they gain access to their CTF. "The potential long-term loss is significant," says CIFF. "If a typical child was to start saving £6 a week into their CTF, by the time they were 18 they could have accumulated £6,500, assuming a 3% average return. "Even if they saved just £1 a week they could still end up with £1,300 at 18." Some banks and building societies have also questioned the future of the CTF, with several stopping offering the product in recent years. Campaigners say the government needs to improve awareness of CTFs, and encourage more families to save into them and a number of banks have urged ministers to simplify the Child Trust Fund system to make it more accessible for poor families. Last year the government announced it was investing £2.5bn in CTFs over the next decade, enabling automatic contributions to increase from £250 to £500 for some children, but CIFF says this is not enough. "We'd like to see the government ringfence CTFs so that they are not used to pay for other savings products or benefits," says CIFF. "We also want to see the addition of a universal contribution, of say £50 a year, regardless of a family's income or savings history." The government says it is keeping CTFs under review and will "continue to make sure that all children, regardless of their background, have the best start in life".

title: Coronavirus: Climate action cannot be another Covid victim - PM
text: Coronavirus: Climate action cannot be another Covid victim - PM _By Justin Rowlatt_ _Chief environment correspondent_ The prime minister will tell a meeting hosted by UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres that climate action cannot be allowed to become another victim of the coronavirus pandemic. Boris Johnson, who co-chairs the event with Mr Guterres, will say that "climate and Covid are two sides of the same coin", and that they both threaten both our health and prosperity. He will argue that the pandemic has shown that it is possible to take collective action to tackle a global problem, and that the same approach is now needed to tackle the threat of climate change. "We need to act with the same urgency and ambition that we have brought to the fight against coronavirus," he will say. "Climate change is an even greater threat to humanity than Covid, and it will require an even greater collective effort to overcome it." The prime minister's speech comes ahead of the UN Climate Change Conference (COP26), which is due to be held in Glasgow in November. The conference is seen as a crucial opportunity to accelerate global action on climate change, and to increase the ambition of countries' emissions reduction targets. However, the pandemic has cast doubt over whether the conference will be able to take place as planned, and there are concerns that it could be postponed or even canceled. In his speech, the prime minister will stress the importance of holding the conference as scheduled, and will say that it is "more important than ever" to show that the world is committed to tackling climate change. "COP26 must be a success," he will say. "It is our best chance to put the world on a path to a more sustainable future." The prime minister's speech will be welcomed by environmental campaigners, who have been calling for the government to show more leadership on climate change. However, they are likely to be disappointed that he did not use his speech to announce any new policies or measures to tackle the climate crisis. The prime minister's speech comes as the UK prepares to host the G7 summit in Cornwall next month. The summit will bring together leaders from the world's seven largest economies, and is expected to focus on a range of issues, including climate change. The prime minister is expected to use the summit to press other countries to increase their ambition on climate change, and to commit to more ambitious emissions reduction targets.

title: Anonymous backs new encrypted social network site

title: Southeastern customers face worsening services
text: Tom Edwards Transport correspondent, London @BBCTomEdwards on Twitter If you thought your commute was bad now, it will get worse for the next five years. That's the message hidden in the small print of new plans to overhaul Southeastern. The franchise, which runs trains from London through Kent and East Sussex, was taken over by the government in 2021 amid complaints of poor performance. It's now being run by the Department for Transport (DfT), which has said it will pump in millions of pounds to improve the service. But documents seen by the BBC show that despite this investment, passengers can expect a reduction in services compared with before the pandemic. By summer 2024, Southeastern plans to run 92.5% of pre-pandemic services. That will rise to 95% by summer 2025 and 97.5% by summer 2026. It is not until summer 2027 that the full pre-pandemic service will be restored. And that's on the assumption that all goes to plan. The DfT has warned that these targets could be missed if there are any delays in the delivery of new trains, or if strike action continues to disrupt services. Southeastern has been hit hard by industrial action, with RMT union members striking over pay and working conditions. The union says that Southeastern is among the worst-performing train operators in the country. Southeastern has defended its performance, saying that it is running more trains than at any time since the pandemic began. But it is clear that passengers are not happy. In a recent survey by consumer group Which?, Southeastern was rated the worst train operator in the UK. Passengers complained of overcrowding, delays and cancellations. The DfT says it is "working closely" with Southeastern to improve performance. But it is clear that passengers will have to be patient. It could be five years before they see a full restoration of pre-pandemic services.

title: RHI inquiry: Call for review of special adviser role
text: The special adviser to the then-Enterprise Minister Jonathan Bell who was tasked with managing the botched Renewable Heat Incentive (RHI) scheme is to be recalled to the inquiry examining the project. David Sterling's witness statements to the Renewable Heat Incentive (RHI) inquiry were published on Wednesday. He is due to give evidence again on Thursday. The inquiry has been told that, in 2015, Mr Sterling asked for a cap to be imposed on the scheme - but was told by Mr Bell to "do nothing". The inquiry is investigating the running and collapse of the RHI scheme, which left Stormont with an estimated £490m overspend. It is examining whether there was any cover-up or obstruction of justice. Inquiry chairman Sir Patrick Coghlin has written to Mr Bell asking him to provide a fuller explanation of his account of a key meeting in March 2015. Sinn Féin's Máirtín Ó Muilleoir described the inquiry's latest findings as "a bombshell". "The evidence suggests that the special adviser, Mr Sterling, raised concerns about how much the RHI scheme was going to cost against the budget and was told to do nothing," the North Antrim MLA said. "It is more proof that this was a scheme that was doomed to fail from the get-go." In a statement to the inquiry, Mr Sterling said that, during the meeting in March 2015, he had asked Mr Bell whether there should be a cap on the amount of money available to the RHI scheme. He said that Mr Bell had responded: "I need you to do nothing." Mr Sterling said that the department's permanent secretary Andrew McCormick had then intervened and told Mr Bell that he should reconsider his position. Mr Sterling said that Mr Bell had then said: "OK, I will reconsider this over the weekend." However, in his witness statement to the inquiry, Mr Bell said that he had not understood Mr Sterling to be making a request for a cap. He said that he had thought Mr Sterling was asking for guidance on how to respond to a question from the media about whether there could be a cap. Mr Bell said that he had not told Mr Sterling to do nothing. "I fully understood the importance of having regard to public expenditure," he said. "I am not so foolish as to just say, 'Do nothing'. "I would never have said that because I understood the constraints on public expenditure." Sir Patrick wrote to Mr Bell, saying that his account of the meeting "lacks any semblance of credibility". "Your evidence about not understanding Mr Sterling to be making a request for a cap raises even more serious issues about your honesty and reliability as a witness," he wrote. "You must appreciate that the inquiry expects witnesses to give a full, frank and truthful account of the events in question." Sir Patrick said that he believed that Mr Sterling's account of the meeting was "more likely to be the truth".

title: Video 'shows hunt law breached'
text: By David Miller BBC Scotland environment correspondent Campaigners claim the ban on hunting with dogs is routinely being flouted. Hunt supporters insist they take great care to respect the law. Footage obtained by the League Against Cruel Sports appears to show foxes being chased and killed by hounds in the Borders, Scotland. The Scottish government said it takes allegations of illegal hunting "very seriously" and is "committed to ensuring compliance" with the law. The Hunting Act 2004 banned the hunting of wild mammals with dogs in England and Wales, and the Protection of Wild Mammals (Scotland) Act 2002 had a similar effect north of the border, although some exemptions were made for pest control, game bird management and hunting deer. The Scottish government's guidance states that hounds must be under "close control" at all times and landowners must make "all reasonable endeavours to prevent the dogs from pursuing or killing a wild mammal", while the game bird exemption only applies during the legal season for game birds. However, campaigners from the League Against Cruel Sports (LACS) say they have documented examples of hunts flouting these rules in the past year. A spokesman said: "Our investigations have exposed numerous serious incidents of illegal fox hunting and deer hunting. "The evidence we have gathered includes foxes being chased and killed by hounds after a hunt saboteur witnessed the dogs being released and also deer being chased down a public road in full view of members of the public." LACS is calling on the Scottish government to take "urgent action" to tackle the problem, including increasing penalties for those caught breaking the law and providing more support for enforcement officers. However, the Scottish Gamekeepers Association (SGA) said it was "confident that the vast majority of shooting estates in Scotland are operating within the law". A spokesman said: "SGA members take their legal responsibilities very seriously and are committed to operating within the letter and spirit of the law. "We do not condone any form of illegal hunting and we urge anyone with evidence of such activity to report it to the relevant authorities." The Scottish government said it was "aware of the concerns raised by the LACS" and was "working closely with Police Scotland to investigate any allegations of illegal hunting". A spokesman said: "We take allegations of illegal hunting very seriously and are committed to ensuring compliance with the law. "We are also working with stakeholders to improve understanding of the law and to encourage responsible behavior."

title: Theresa May 'not considering election' on walking break, says No 10
text: But - stand down everyone - Number 10 has insisted the prime minister is not considering calling a general election. Mrs May famously decided to call a snap election in 2017, with her Conservative Party losing their majority in the House of Commons. Her spokesman told reporters: "The prime minister is not considering calling a general election." The denial comes as the prime minister takes a break in the Swiss Alps with her husband, Philip. The couple are staying in a luxury chalet in the mountain resort of Klosters, where they have been pictured walking in the snow. The prime minister's decision to go on holiday has been criticised by some, who say she should be focusing on Brexit negotiations. But her spokesman said: "The prime minister is entitled to take a break. She has been working hard over the past few months, and she needs some time to rest and recharge." It is not clear how long the prime minister will be on holiday for, but she is expected to return to work next week. Her decision to rule out a general election will come as a relief to many Conservative MPs. Many Tory MPs fear that a general election would result in the party losing even more seats, and potentially even handing power to the Labour Party. A general election is not due until 2022, but there has been speculation that the prime minister could call one earlier if she is able to secure a good deal on Brexit. However, with the Brexit negotiations still ongoing, it is not clear when or if such a deal will be reached. Meanwhile, the prime minister's decision to rule out a general election has been welcomed by the Labour Party. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said: "Theresa May's decision not to call a general election shows that she is running scared of the people. "She knows that if she called an election, she would lose. The people have lost confidence in her and her government." The Liberal Democrats have also welcomed the prime minister's decision. Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable said: "Theresa May is right to rule out a general election. The country needs stability, not more chaos. "We need to focus on getting a good deal on Brexit, and on building a fairer and more prosperous society."

title: Endangered species: Gunshot detection technology deployed
text: By Cristina Criddle, Technology reporter  New technology has been developed by international conservation charity the Zoological Society of London (ZSL) and Google Cloud. The technology detects gunshots in real time, through machine learning algorithms. It uses audio recordings from smartphones left in the field by rangers, scientists, and community patrollers. When a gunshot is detected, the system immediately sends an alert to the user's phone, enabling a rapid response to poaching incidents. The system was developed using a dataset of over 100,000 gunshot and non-gunshot audio recordings, collected by ZSL and the University of Oxford's Wildlife Conservation Research Unit. The system also includes a web interface that allows users to view gunshot detections on a map, manage their devices, and access information on poaching incidents. The technology has been deployed in several countries, including Nepal, Gabon, and the Democratic Republic of the Congo. In Nepal, the system has been used to detect poaching incidents in Chitwan National Park, home to the world's largest population of one-horned rhinos. In Gabon, the system has been used to monitor poaching in Loango National Park, home to a diverse range of endangered species, including elephants, gorillas, and chimpanzees. The technology is part of ZSL's EDGE of Existence programme, which focuses on protecting threatened and endangered species. Dr. Amy Hinsley, ZSL's EDGE of Existence programme manager, said: "We are excited about the potential of this technology to help us protect endangered species from poaching. The system can detect gunshots in real time, enabling rangers to respond quickly and effectively to poaching incidents." Dr. David Maxwell, Google Cloud's director of product management for artificial intelligence, said: "We are proud to partner with ZSL on this important project. Our machine learning expertise and cloud computing platform have enabled us to develop a system that can detect gunshots in real time, providing rangers with the tools they need to protect endangered species." The deployment of this technology is a significant step forward in the fight against poaching. It provides rangers and conservationists with a powerful tool to detect and deter poaching incidents, helping to protect the world's most endangered species.

title: Carrie Fisher given 'amazing' send-off in Star Wars: The Last Jedi
text: The London-born actor said he shares "many scenes" with the late actress in Star Wars: The Last Jedi and that the sci-fi franchise "keeps her alive". Fisher, who played the iconic Princess Leia in the original Star Wars trilogy, died in December 2016 at the age of 60. "I think it's an amazing send-off for her," Ahmed told BBC Breakfast. "She's very much alive in the film." Ahmed said that Fisher was "a very special person" and that he was "honoured" to have worked with her. "She was so funny and so intelligent," he said. "She was a real force of nature." Ahmed also said that he believes Fisher's legacy will live on through her work in the Star Wars franchise. "She's one of the most iconic characters in cinema history," he said. "She's inspired generations of fans." The Last Jedi, which is the eighth instalment in the Star Wars saga, is released in cinemas on 15 December. The film also stars Mark Hamill, Daisy Ridley, John Boyega and Oscar Isaac. In the film, Fisher reprises her role as Princess Leia, who is now a general in the Resistance. Ahmed plays Bodhi Rook, a pilot who defects from the First Order to join the Resistance. Ahmed said that he is "very excited" for fans to see The Last Jedi. "It's a really great film," he said. "It's got everything you could want from a Star Wars movie: action, adventure, humour and heart." Ahmed also said that he hopes The Last Jedi will be a fitting tribute to Fisher. "I think it's going to be a really special experience for fans," he said. "It's a chance to say goodbye to Carrie and to celebrate her legacy."

title: Coronavirus: Paris restrictions to stay as France reopens
text: Edouard Philippe said the country was "cut in two" in terms of the rate of infections. Restrictions will remain in the capital and north-eastern regions. It comes as France prepares to relax its nationwide lockdown on 11 May. Mr Philippe told the French parliament that there remained "territorial disparities" in the battle against the virus. "In some territories, the virus is practically under control and in others it's still circulating very actively," he said. He said that restrictions in the Paris region would stay in place for now, along with several other regions including Grand Est, Mayotte, Ile-de-France, and Burgundy-Franche-Comte. However, local authorities will be given more freedom to relax some measures if they wish. From 11 May, the rest of France will be able to start easing restrictions, such as reopening shops that are less than 400 sq m, and allowing people to travel within 100km of their home. Parks are to reopen and people will be allowed to exercise without a time limit, but beaches will remain shut. Bars, restaurants, museums and cinemas will stay closed, but libraries will reopen. People will not be obliged to have special permission to go out, as is currently the case, but they will still need to fill out a form giving a reason for their movements. The prime minister said he understood that Parisians would be disappointed, but he said there was "no choice". "We couldn't take the risk of having a new outbreak of the epidemic after 11 May," he said. "That would be a disaster." The decision comes after a slow but steady reduction in the number of Covid-19 cases in France. On Saturday, 19 May, there were 104 new deaths, the lowest daily toll since 20 March. The number of people being treated in intensive care units continues to fall.

title: RBS chief hopes to make Ulster Bank decision by end of summer
text: By John Campbell BBC News NI Economics & Business Editor Ross McEwen said "all options" were still being considered for what has been the worst performing part of the group, which had also suffered from bad loans. "We'll have a decision and announcement by the end of the summer," he added. There had been speculation that RBS might sell Ulster Bank or close it down, but Mr McEwen said: "We are not considering closing Ulster Bank. "We've got a strong balance sheet now and a strong capital position, so we're not considering closing it. "We're also committed to Northern Ireland and committed to supporting our customers and our colleagues in Northern Ireland." Mr McEwen said the bank had "made good progress" over the past three years, but that the situation was "still challenging". The bank's financial performance had improved in 2018, with a reported operating profit of £384m, but that still lagged behind most of the group's other operations. Ulster Bank has been hit by a number of factors, including the economic downturn in Northern Ireland following the financial crisis, bad debts and Brexit uncertainty. Mr McEwen said the bank was "well positioned" to meet the challenges and that it had "a number of initiatives" in place to improve performance. He said the bank was "working closely" with the UK government and the Northern Ireland Executive to support businesses and consumers. "We're also working with customers who are facing financial difficulties," he added. "We're providing a range of support measures, including repayment holidays, interest-free overdrafts and debt consolidation loans. "We're also working with businesses to help them grow and create jobs." Mr McEwen said the bank was "confident" about the future of Ulster Bank. "We've got a strong team in Northern Ireland, we've got a strong customer base and we've got a strong commitment to the region," he added. "We're confident that we can continue to play a vital role in the Northern Ireland economy."

title: Pakistan Taliban chief Mullah Fazlullah targeted by US strike in Afghanistan
text: Fazlullah's men shot the schoolgirl Malala Yousafzai in Pakistan in 2012. He was also behind the 2014 massacre in the Pakistani city of Peshawar that killed more than 130 schoolchildren. He became the TTP's leader after his predecessor Hakimullah Mehsud was killed in a US drone strike in 2013. Fazlullah was born in 1974 in the Swat Valley in northwestern Pakistan. He received religious training in a madrassa, a religious school, and became known for his fiery speeches against the Pakistani government. He joined the TTP in 2007 and quickly rose through the ranks. Under Fazlullah's leadership, the TTP became increasingly violent. The group carried out a number of suicide bombings and assassinations, and it also imposed a strict interpretation of Islamic law in the areas it controlled. Fazlullah was also accused of ordering the beheading of 23 Pakistani soldiers in 2012. In 2014, the Pakistani military launched an operation to clear the TTP from the Swat Valley. The operation was largely successful, and Fazlullah was forced to flee to Afghanistan. He continued to lead the TTP from exile, but his influence has diminished in recent years. Fazlullah was targeted by a US drone strike in Afghanistan on June 13, 2018. The strike killed Fazlullah and several other TTP members. The US government said that Fazlullah was a "terrorist leader" and that his death "will disrupt the TTP's ability to plan and carry out attacks against innocent civilians." The Pakistani government welcomed the news of Fazlullah's death. Prime Minister Shahid Khaqan Abbasi said that Fazlullah was "a brutal terrorist" who "had caused immense pain and suffering to the people of Pakistan." The TTP has not yet named a successor to Fazlullah. The group is likely to face a period of instability following his death, but it is too early to say whether this will lead to a decline in violence.

title: New Aberdeen FC stadium could be derailed even if approved
text: The stadium and training facilities would be at Kingsford, near Westhill. Although the final decision is a matter for Aberdeen councillors, Aberdeenshire Council will have to agree to a controlled parking zone. The zone would mean drivers would have to pay to park near the stadium on match days, with the money raised going towards transport infrastructure in the area. However, Aberdeenshire Council's infrastructure services committee voted against the plans at a meeting on Thursday. They argued that the council should not be responsible for funding transport infrastructure for a private development. The committee's decision does not mean the plans for the new stadium are dead. However, it does mean that Aberdeen FC will have to find another way to fund the transport infrastructure. One option would be for the club to pay for it themselves. However, this would likely be a significant cost. Another option would be for Aberdeen FC to work with the Scottish government or other partners to find funding. However, this could also be a lengthy and difficult process. The decision by Aberdeenshire Council's infrastructure services committee is a setback for Aberdeen FC's plans for a new stadium. However, it is not necessarily the end of the road. The club will now have to explore other options for funding the transport infrastructure. If they can find a way to do this, the new stadium could still be built. In a statement, Aberdeen FC said they were "disappointed" by the committee's decision. "We believe that the proposed new stadium would be a major asset for the north-east of Scotland," the club said. "We will now consider our options and continue to work with all relevant stakeholders to try to find a way forward." The Scottish government said it was aware of the decision by Aberdeenshire Council's infrastructure services committee. "We are committed to working with Aberdeen FC and other partners to explore all options for delivering a new stadium for the club," a Scottish government spokesperson said.

title: Canada's immigration website crashes during US vote
text: Officials have confirmed that the cause was a higher than normal level of traffic. It has been suggested this may have been related to the US vote, as many Americans were reportedly looking into the possibility of emigrating to Canada. The website has since been restored, but the incident has raised questions about Canada's immigration system. Some critics have argued that the system is not equipped to handle the increasing number of people who are looking to come to Canada. In recent years, Canada has seen a significant increase in the number of people who are applying for permanent residency. In 2019, over 340,000 people applied for permanent residency, up from 250,000 in 2015. The increase in applications has been attributed to a number of factors, including the country's strong economy, its high quality of life, and its welcoming immigration policies. However, the influx of applications has also put a strain on the immigration system. The government has taken steps to address the issue, including increasing the number of staff who process applications and investing in new technology. However, the website crash suggests that more needs to be done. Some experts have called for the government to adopt a more streamlined application process. Others have suggested that the government should increase the number of visas that are available to skilled workers. The government has said that it is committed to making the immigration system more efficient and responsive. However, it is clear that more needs to be done to address the challenges that the system is facing. The website crash is a reminder of the challenges that Canada faces as it tries to manage the increasing number of people who are looking to come to the country. The government will need to find ways to improve the immigration system if it wants to continue to attract the best and brightest from around the world.

title: Grave of 'George III's granddaughter' restored in Carmarthen
text: Experts say Caroline Prytherch and her sister were related to the former king due to his links with Hannah Lightfoot during his time as Prince of Wales. The previously lost family grave of Ms Prytherch at St David's Church, Carmarthen, has been restored. Local historian Robert Evans, who has been researching the family history for more than 10 years, said the two sisters were related to King George III through an illegitimate son born to his brother, Prince William Henry. "Hannah Lightfoot was his mistress, but she was not accepted at court. She was pregnant at the time, and the child was taken away from her," Mr Evans explained. The child, William, was brought up by the Prytherch sisters' grandmother in Carmarthen. "This was considered a left-handed marriage at the time and there is some evidence to suggest that it was accepted," he added. The sisters' mother, Lettice Thomas, was a relation of the Prytherch sisters' grandmother, so the link to the royal family goes through both sides. Mr Evans said that the two sisters lived in Carmarthen all their lives and were well-respected members of the community. "They were known for their kindness and generosity, and they were always willing to help those in need," he added. The sisters never married, and they died within a few months of each other in 1872. They were buried in the churchyard at St David's Church. Over time, their grave became overgrown and neglected. However, thanks to a grant from the Heritage Lottery Fund, it has now been restored. The grave has been cleaned and repaired, and a new headstone has been erected. The headstone bears the sisters' names and dates of death, as well as the inscription: "Descendants of William Henry, Duke of Gloucester, brother of King George III".

title: Solar subsidy 'to be protected'
text: By Bob Howard Reporter, Money Box The feed-in tariff scheme was launched last April. It promised a typical household earnings of £800 a year for generating electricity from renewable sources such as solar panels, or small wind turbines. But there are fears that the scheme could be scaled back, or even scrapped, as part of the government's spending review. Solar power advocates have condemned the proposal, saying it would damage the UK's nascent solar industry. The Energy and Climate Change Secretary, Chris Huhne, has said that no decisions have been made, but he has admitted that the feed-in tariff scheme is "expensive". The government has already announced that it will cut spending on other renewable energy schemes, such as the Renewables Obligation. This has led to fears that the government is not committed to supporting renewable energy. However, the government has said that it remains committed to meeting its targets for renewable energy. The UK has a target of generating 15% of its electricity from renewable sources by 2020. The feed-in tariff scheme is one of the key policies that the government is using to meet this target. The scheme has been successful in encouraging people to install solar panels. In the first year of the scheme, over 100,000 solar panels were installed. This is more than double the number that were installed in the previous year. However, the solar industry is still in its early stages. The cost of solar panels has fallen in recent years, but they are still more expensive than traditional forms of electricity generation. The feed-in tariff scheme helps to make solar power more affordable. But if the scheme is scaled back, or scrapped, it could make it more difficult for the solar industry to grow. The government is due to announce its decision on the future of the feed-in tariff scheme in the autumn.

title: Great Yarmouth school sets up food bank to help families
text: North Denes Primary in Great Yarmouth has started collecting food donations to distribute to families. Head teacher Debbie Whiting said she has noticed an increase in the number of pupils coming to school hungry in the past year. "We have seen a real increase in the number of children coming to school hungry, and we know that this is having a negative impact on their learning," she said. "We want to do everything we can to support our families and pupils, and we believe that this food bank will make a real difference." The food bank will be open every Wednesday from 9am to 11am during term time. Families can come to the school and collect a bag of food, which will include essential items such as pasta, rice, tinned goods, and cereal. The school has already received a number of donations from local businesses and organizations, but they are still appealing for more support. "We are so grateful for the donations we have received so far, but we still need more to ensure that we can continue to support our families," said Mrs. Whiting. "Any donation, no matter how small, will make a difference." The food bank is the latest in a number of initiatives that the school has launched to support families. The school also has a breakfast club, which provides free breakfasts to pupils every morning. "We know that many of our families are struggling to make ends meet, and we want to do everything we can to help," said Mrs. Whiting. "We believe that every child deserves to have a fair chance in life, and we are committed to doing everything we can to support our pupils and their families." If you would like to donate to the food bank, please contact North Denes Primary School on 01493 843429.

title: Melania Trump: Donald Trump and I are fine
text: In an interview with ABC News, she said media speculation about her marriage was not "pleasant". Asked if she loves President Donald Trump, she said: "Yes, we are fine." He denies having had extra-marital affairs. Porn-star Stormy Daniels claims that she slept with Trump in 2006 and received $130,000 from his personal lawyer in 2016 to keep quiet about it. Trump's former lawyer Michael Cohen has admitted making the payment to Daniels but denies that Trump knew about it. In a 2018 interview with Fox News, Trump said: "I never had an affair with Stormy Daniels." In a 2019 interview with the New York Times, Daniels said: "I was surprised by the amount [of money] because it was a big number. But I knew I was hush money because I was told to sign a non-disclosure agreement. And I knew the only reason somebody would want me to sign a non-disclosure agreement is because they were trying to hide something." In a 2019 interview with ABC News, former White House aide Omarosa Manigault Newman said that she heard Trump having a phone conversation with Cohen about Daniels. "I heard the president talking to Michael Cohen about Stormy Daniels," Manigault Newman said. "I remember that conversation very well." Trump has denied having had any conversations with Cohen about Daniels. The allegations of an affair with Daniels are just one of a number of scandals that have dogged Trump's presidency. He has also been accused of sexual assault by multiple women, and has been criticized for his handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite the scandals, Trump remains popular with his base of supporters. He has already announced that he will run for re-election in 2024.

title: Bet365: UK's best-paid boss sees pay rise to £265m
text: The firm's accounts show compensation, for the firm's "highest paid director" rising to £265m including dividends. That was £48m higher than the total she received in the previous 12 months. The payout will reignite the debate about excessive pay at the top of British companies. The compensation for "highest paid director" for the year ending 27 March 2022, was £497m, which included £328m in dividend payments. The company declined to comment on the increase in the chief executive's pay. However, the payout emerged as the gambling giant announced revenues had risen by 2% to a record high of £2.98bn for the year to the end of March. It reported a pre-tax profit of £923.6m, also up 2%. The online betting and gaming company, founded by Denise Coates and her father Peter in a portable cabin in Stoke-on-Trent in 2000, now employs more than 5,000 people in the UK, and revenues have grown exponentially in recent years. In 2019, the company announced plans to create 2,000 new jobs at its new Festival Park campus in Staffordshire. The large pay rises come despite the company facing increased regulatory scrutiny, having recently agreed to pay £17m to settle a money laundering case brought by the Gambling Commission. Denise Coates is the daughter of Peter Coates, who founded the Provincial Racing betting shop chain in 1974. Denise Coates became managing director of the family business in 1995, and transformed it into an online betting giant, which is now the world's largest online gambling company. She is known for her philanthropy, having donated millions of pounds to charities and good causes. In 2020, she was awarded a CBE for services to the community in Stoke-on-Trent and Staffordshire.

title: India Kolkata flyover collapse: At least 20 dead
text: More are feared trapped under the concrete and steel bridge, and rescue efforts are continuing all night. Images show residents using their bare hands to shift twisted metal and rubble, as emergency workers use cutting equipment to free those trapped. The cause of the collapse is not yet known, but the Indian Express newspaper reports that some witnesses said they had heard a loud bang before the bridge fell, while others said they had seen cracks appearing in the structure. The collapsed bridge is part of a major flyover that was built to ease traffic congestion in the city. It was inaugurated in 2013 and had been inspected by the authorities just last month. The collapse has raised questions about the safety of other flyovers in the city, many of which are in a state of disrepair. The government has ordered an inquiry into the collapse and has promised to take action against those responsible. The collapse has caused widespread anger and grief in Kolkata. Many people have taken to social media to express their condolences to the victims and their families. One Twitter user wrote: "This is a tragedy that should never have happened. The government must be held accountable for this." Another wrote: "My thoughts are with the victims and their families. This is a terrible loss for Kolkata."

title: 'Unsolvable' exam question leaves Chinese students flummoxed
text: Primary school students at a school in the Chinese district of Shunqing were faced with this question on a paper: "If a ship had 26 sheep and 10 goats on board, how old is the ship's captain?" The confusing question prompted frustrated parents to take to social media to vent their anger and has since gone viral. One parent, surnamed Li, said: "I don't have an answer myself." Another, surnamed Wang, queried: "Is this question relevant to the syllabus?" Other users said they felt sorry for the children who were left flummoxed by the question. One user said: "This is just to torture the kids." Another added: "The person who came up with this question needs to go back to school." The question has since been removed from the paper and an investigation has been launched into how it came to be included in the first place. In a statement, the Shunqing District Education Bureau said: "We have taken this matter very seriously and are conducting a thorough investigation. We will take appropriate action once the investigation is complete." The incident has sparked a debate about the quality of education in China. Some parents have called for stricter controls on the content of exams, while others have said that schools need to focus more on developing students' critical thinking skills. One expert, Professor Zhang Minxuan of Beijing Normal University, said: "This question is a typical example of the kind of rote learning that is still prevalent in Chinese schools. Students are expected to memorize facts and figures, rather than to think for themselves." He added: "We need to move away from this kind of teaching and learning and focus more on developing students' critical thinking skills. This means teaching them how to analyse information, solve problems, and make decisions." The Shunqing District Education Bureau has said that it will take steps to improve the quality of education in the district. It has also said that it will provide more support to teachers and parents. The incident has also prompted calls for a national review of exam content. One member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, a top advisory body, has called for a "thorough review" of all school exams. He said: "We need to make sure that exams are testing students' knowledge and skills, not just their ability to memorize facts." The debate about the quality of education in China is likely to continue. However, the Shunqing District Education Bureau has said that it is committed to improving the quality of education in the district and is taking steps to address the concerns of parents.

title: New markets for Welsh firms after Brexit, says PM
text: The Conservative leader said she wanted the "best possible deal" for Wales and the whole of the UK. Meanwhile, Mrs May confirmed that she had written to the European Council president, Donald Tusk, to trigger Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty, formally beginning the process of exiting the EU. "The Government will deliver on the democratic decision of the British people and will bring certainty and clarity to the UK's future outside the EU," she said. "We want to build an economy that works for everyone, where young people have the chance to succeed and where public services can be protected." The UK will now enter a two-year period of negotiations with the EU, during which time it will need to secure a deal on the terms of its exit, including trade, immigration and security. The government has said that it wants to achieve a "deep and special partnership" with the EU, but it is unclear what this will entail. Businesses and organisations in Wales have welcomed the prospect of new markets outside the EU, but have also expressed concerns about the potential impact of Brexit on the Welsh economy. The Welsh government has said that it will work to ensure that Wales benefits from the opportunities that Brexit presents. "We will work with the UK government to secure the best possible deal for Wales," said First Minister Carwyn Jones. "We will also work to ensure that Wales is well-placed to take advantage of the opportunities that Brexit presents." The UK's decision to leave the EU has been met with mixed reactions in Wales. Some people believe that it will be a positive move that will allow the UK to regain control of its borders and laws. Others are concerned about the potential economic impact of Brexit and the loss of access to the single market. The UK government has said that it will work to ensure that the UK leaves the EU in a orderly and stable manner. It has also said that it will work to protect the rights of EU citizens living in the UK. The UK's exit from the EU is a complex and challenging process. It is unclear what the final outcome will be, but it is likely to have a significant impact on Wales and the rest of the UK.

title: South Africa parliament chaos as Malema MPs heckle Zuma
text: The Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF), led by Julius Malema, repeatedly interrupted Mr Zuma, demanding answers over a spending scandal. The speaker of parliament, Baleka Mbete, repeatedly warned the EFF MPs but they continued to heckle the president. At one point, Mr Zuma was forced to stop speaking as the EFF MPs chanted "Zuma must go!" and "Pay back the money!" Some of the EFF MPs even held up signs that read "Zuma thief" and "Zuma must fall." The chaos in parliament continued for several minutes before the speaker was forced to adjourn the session. The EFF MPs then marched out of the chamber, chanting slogans and waving their fists. The spending scandal that the EFF MPs were referring to relates to the use of taxpayers' money to upgrade Mr Zuma's private home in Nkandla in KwaZulu-Natal. The Public Protector, Thuli Madonsela, found that Mr Zuma had benefited unduly from the upgrades, which cost the state more than 200 million rand ($15 million). Mr Zuma has denied any wrongdoing, but the scandal has damaged his reputation and led to calls for his resignation. The EFF has been one of the most vocal critics of Mr Zuma and has repeatedly called for him to step down. The chaos in parliament is the latest in a series of incidents that have highlighted the growing tensions between the ANC and the EFF. The EFF is a relatively new party, but it has quickly become one of the most popular opposition parties in South Africa. The EFF is known for its radical policies and its confrontational style of politics. The ANC has accused the EFF of being disruptive and disrespectful, but the EFF has defended its tactics, saying that they are necessary to hold the government to account. The chaos in parliament is likely to further strain relations between the two parties. It is unclear what the long-term consequences of the chaos in parliament will be. However, it is clear that the incident has damaged the reputation of both the ANC and the EFF. It is also clear that the tensions between the two parties are likely to continue to grow in the coming months and years.

title: Stolen dogs: Carmarthenshire and Briton Ferry raids 'uncover 80'
text: The dogs and puppies are said to be worth tens of thousands of pounds, Dyfed-Powys and South Wales (SWP) police forces said. Pet owners have been warned to be vigilant after two raids in Wales uncovered 80 stolen dogs and puppies. The animals were taken from Carmarthenshire and Briton Ferry, near Neath. Officers said they were alerted to the thefts by a concerned member of the public who reported seeing suspicious activity. A team of officers was assembled and raided two addresses, one in Carmarthenshire and the other in Briton Ferry. Inside, they discovered 80 dogs and puppies of various breeds, including French bulldogs, pugs, and German shepherds. The animals were found crammed into small cages and pens, and many were in poor health. Some of the dogs had been microchipped, but many had not. Police said the dogs were stolen to order and were believed to be worth tens of thousands of pounds. "These animals are often sold for large sums of money, and the trade in stolen dogs is a lucrative one," said a spokesperson for Dyfed-Powys Police. "We are urging pet owners to be vigilant and to take steps to ensure their animals are safe." Police are asking anyone who has had a dog stolen to contact them. They are also appealing for information about anyone who may have been involved in the thefts. "We are determined to bring those responsible to justice and to return these animals to their rightful owners," the spokesperson said. The raids are part of an ongoing investigation into the theft of dogs in Wales. In recent months, there have been a number of reports of dogs being stolen from homes and gardens. Police believe the thefts are being carried out by organized gangs who are targeting specific breeds of dogs. Pet owners are advised to take the following steps to protect their dogs from being stolen: - Keep your dog on a lead when in public places. - Don't leave your dog unattended in a car or in the garden. - Ensure your dog is microchipped and that the details are up to date. - Report any suspicious activity to the police.

title: Government automatically enrols firms in case of no-deal Brexit
text: The move will enable UK firms to continue to trade with EU member states after the UK leaves the EU. The government has said it will automatically enrol firms in the scheme if they do not do so themselves. The announcement was made by Brexit Secretary David Davis, who said it was "essential" that businesses were prepared for a no-deal Brexit. "We want to do everything we can to support businesses and ensure that they have the tools and information they need to continue trading with the EU," he said. "This scheme will help businesses to get the support they need to trade seamlessly with the EU after we leave." The scheme will be open to all UK businesses, regardless of size or sector. Businesses will need to provide some basic information about their business, such as their name, address and contact details. They will also need to declare whether they export to the EU or import from the EU. Businesses that are already registered for the scheme will not need to do anything further. The government has said it will provide further details about the scheme in due course. The announcement has been welcomed by businesses. The British Chambers of Commerce said it was "essential" that businesses were given support to prepare for a no-deal Brexit. "This scheme will help businesses to get the support they need to trade seamlessly with the EU after we leave," said BCC Director General Adam Marshall. "We urge all businesses to take advantage of this scheme and to start preparing for a no-deal Brexit." The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) also welcomed the announcement. "This scheme will help businesses to get the support they need to trade seamlessly with the EU after we leave," said CBI Director General Carolyn Fairbairn. "We urge all businesses to take advantage of this scheme and to start preparing for a no-deal Brexit." The government's announcement comes after it was reported that a number of businesses were not prepared for a no-deal Brexit. A survey by the Institute of Directors found that only 20% of businesses had taken steps to prepare for a no-deal Brexit. The survey also found that businesses were concerned about the impact of a no-deal Brexit on their ability to trade with the EU.

title: Mosul Iraq battle: IS accused of shooting civilians
text: The UN says 12 civilians were shot dead on 11 November when they tried to stop militants launching rockets from the roofs of the homes in the Bakir area. Militants allegedly killed 27 others suspected of collaborating with Iraqi forces. The latest allegations of atrocities add to the mounting evidence of the brutality of IS's three-year reign over Mosul. The group's crimes have included mass executions, public torture and rape. Human Rights Watch has accused it of committing "war crimes, crimes against humanity, and possibly genocide" in Iraq. Mosul's civilian population has borne the brunt of the fighting. The UN estimates that at least 1,000 civilians have been killed and 10,000 injured since the offensive began in October. The Iraqi government and its US-led coalition partners have been accused of causing civilian casualties with airstrikes and shelling. However, IS has also been blamed for using civilians as human shields and booby-trapping buildings. The humanitarian situation in Mosul is dire. The city's water and electricity supplies are limited and food is scarce. Thousands of people have been displaced from their homes. The UN's humanitarian coordinator for Iraq, Lise Grande, has called for safe passage for civilians who want to leave Mosul. She said the UN and its partners were "ready to scale up our response and provide life-saving assistance to all those in need". The Iraqi government has said it is committed to minimizing civilian casualties in Mosul. However, it has also vowed to defeat IS at all costs. This suggests that the battle for Mosul could continue for some time, and that the civilian population will continue to suffer. The liberation of Mosul would be a major victory for the Iraqi government and its US-led coalition partners. However, it would also be a Pyrrhic victory if it came at the cost of thousands of civilian lives. The international community must do everything it can to ensure that the civilians of Mosul are protected. The UN must continue to provide humanitarian assistance, and the Iraqi government and its coalition partners must do everything they can to minimize civilian casualties.

title: Male employees want flexible work too
text: By Mary-Ann Russon Business Reporter, BBC News In the past, pressure for the opportunity to work part-time or flexibly has usually come from women. But increasingly, men also want to strike a better work-life balance. For years, the UK government and many individual employers have been encouraging more women into the workplace. Policies such as shared parental leave and flexible working were designed to make it easier for women to return to their jobs after having children. However, as flexible working becomes increasingly common, men are beginning to take advantage of these opportunities too. A recent study by the Institute for Fiscal Studies found that the number of men working flexibly in the UK has increased by 50% in the past decade. The study also found that flexible working is associated with a range of positive outcomes for both men and women, including: Increased job satisfaction Improved work-life balance Reduced stress levels Increased productivity There are a number of reasons why men are increasingly interested in flexible working. One reason is that men are increasingly taking on more childcare responsibilities. In the past, childcare was often seen as a woman's responsibility, but that is changing. Nowadays, many men are happy to share the childcare with their partners. Another reason why men are interested in flexible working is that they want to spend more time with their families. In the past, men were often expected to work long hours and put their careers first. However, that is no longer the case. Many men now want to have a more balanced life, where they can spend time with their families as well as their work. The rise of flexible working is good news for both men and women. It allows people to work in a way that suits them, and it can help to create a more balanced and fulfilling life. However, there are still some challenges to overcome. One challenge is that flexible working is not always seen as acceptable for men. Some people still believe that men should be the main breadwinners and that they should not be taking time off work to care for their families. Another challenge is that flexible working can be difficult to implement in some workplaces. For example, it can be difficult to arrange flexible working for employees who work in customer-facing roles. Despite these challenges, the trend towards flexible working is likely to continue. As more and more people realize the benefits of flexible working, it will become increasingly accepted and implemented in workplaces.

title: £5.6m Newbridge Memo makeover gets under way
text: Scaffolding is set to go up at the Grade II listed Newbridge Memorial Hall, known as the Memo, in Caerphilly county. It follows an eight-year fundraising campaign by the hall's trustees. Built in 1923 to commemorate the fallen of the First World War, the Memo has fallen into disrepair in recent years. The £5.6m restoration project will not only ensure the building's future but also revitalise the surrounding area. The makeover includes a new glazed atrium entrance, a lift to provide disabled access, modern toilet facilities, and a new bar and kitchen. A new extension will also be built to house a new community centre, classrooms, meeting rooms, and an office space. The project is being funded by the National Lottery Heritage Fund, Caerphilly County Borough Council, the Welsh government, and the Garfield Weston Foundation. Work is expected to be completed by the end of 2024. Once complete, the Memo will once again be a thriving community hub, offering a wide range of activities and events for local people. It will also provide a much-needed space for community groups, businesses, and individuals to meet, socialise, and learn. The Memo's trustees are delighted to see work finally getting under way. "This is a momentous day for the Memo," said chairman John Edmunds. "We have been working towards this for many years, and we are so grateful to everyone who has supported us. "The Memo is a vital part of our community, and we are excited to see it restored to its former glory." The Memo's restoration is part of a wider regeneration project for Newbridge. The village has been awarded £1.5m from the Welsh government's Town Centre Regeneration Fund. The money will be used to improve the village's public realm, including new pavements, streetlighting, and seating. A new community garden will also be created. The regeneration project is expected to be completed by the end of 2023.

title: Coronavirus funeral restrictions: 'Other families shouldn't have to go through this'
text: Iolo Cheung BBC News Only 12 people were allowed to attend Bernard Lawrence's funeral last week. His granddaughter Ffion Evans said it was frustrating as many other Covid measures have been eased. The Welsh Government has said it appreciated how difficult it was for people to say goodbye to their loved ones with the current restrictions. But it said the limit on funeral numbers was still necessary to help prevent the spread of the virus. "We know that this is a difficult time for people who are grieving the loss of a loved one, and we want to offer our deepest sympathies," a Welsh Government spokesperson said. "We are keeping the situation under review and will make changes to the regulations as soon as it is safe to do so." Ffion Evans said her grandfather, who died aged 87, was a "kind and loving man" who will be greatly missed by his family and friends. She said the family had to make the difficult decision to limit the number of people who could attend his funeral due to the current restrictions. "It was really frustrating because so many other things have been lifted now," she said. "I understand that they're trying to keep people safe, but it was still hard to have to tell people they couldn't come." Ffion said the family were able to live-stream the funeral so that other people could watch it online. "It was nice to be able to share it with other people who couldn't be there," she said. "But it's not the same as being able to hug them and to be together in person." The Welsh Government has said it is working with faith groups and funeral directors to develop guidance on how to hold funerals safely during the pandemic. It said it would continue to keep the situation under review and would make changes to the regulations as soon as it was safe to do so.

title: Fallen Yosemite climbers were 'very experienced'
text: Jason Wells, 46, and Tim Klein, 42, had climbed together for decades, including in the California park. Officials are investigating how they both fell over 1,000ft (300m) from the granite rock. The climbers were about 2,000ft up El Capitan - almost two thirds of the way to the summit - when they fell. They had been preparing to abseil back down. Yosemite National Park spokeswoman Jamie Richards said the pair were "very experienced climbers" who knew the route well. They fell just after 11:00 local time on Saturday (18:00 GMT) while on the Salathé Wall route. Witnesses saw two bodies on the ground at the base of the cliff. Search and rescue teams recovered the bodies but officials have not yet said how the climbers fell. Park spokeswoman Jamie Richards said the pair reached the summit of El Capitan on Friday, and were preparing to rappel down when they fell. "They were descending from the top of El Capitan when something happened and caused both climbers to fall," she said. "Our hearts go out to their families and loved ones." The park service is investigating the accident and said it will release more information when it is available. El Capitan is one of the most popular climbing destinations in the world, and is known for its sheer granite walls. The Salathé Wall route is considered one of the most challenging on El Capitan, and requires climbers to ascend over 3,000ft of rock. In May, three climbers were killed in an avalanche on the mountain. Yosemite National Park is home to some of the world's most famous rock climbing routes, and attracts climbers from all over the world. However, the park also has a history of climbing accidents. In 2017, a British climber fell to his death while attempting to free-climb El Capitan. Despite the risks, climbers continue to flock to Yosemite to challenge themselves on its iconic rock formations.

title: Tinder to introduce in-app background checks
text: By Cody Godwin BBC News, San Francisco Later this year, Tinder will allow users to view public records information of perspective dates using their name or mobile number. The feature, called "Background Check," will be powered by Garbo, a non-profit organization that searches public records for potentially harmful information. Tinder says it will be the first social media company to offer such a service. The announcement comes as Tinder faces increasing scrutiny over its safety record. In recent years, the app has been linked to several high-profile cases of violence and abuse. In 2019, a woman was murdered by a man she met on Tinder. Tinder has since implemented several safety features, including a "panic button" that allows users to call for help if they feel unsafe. However, the company has been criticized for not doing enough to protect its users. The new background check feature is designed to address these concerns. It will allow users to see if a potential date has any criminal convictions, restraining orders, or other public records that could indicate a risk of harm. Tinder says that users will have the option to opt out of the background check feature. However, the company hopes that most users will choose to use it, as it could help to make the app safer. "We believe that this new feature will help to make Tinder a safer place for our users," said Tinder CEO Elie Seidman. "We want to give our users the tools they need to make informed decisions about who they're matching with." The background check feature is still in development and is expected to launch later this year. Here are some additional details about the feature: The background check will be powered by Garbo, a non-profit organization that searches public records for potentially harmful information. Users will have the option to opt out of the background check feature. The background check will be free to use. The background check will only include information that is available in public records. The background check will not include any information that is protected by law, such as medical records or financial information.

title: Green screens and social distancing - TV industry publishes guidelines to resume filming
text: The measures form part of a back-to-work blueprint issued by the UK's biggest broadcasters on Monday. They have been adopted by the BBC, ITV, Channel 4, Sky, ViacomCBS, WarnerMedia and NBCUniversal. The guidance is based on expert advice from Public Health England and has been developed in consultation with members of the British Film Commission and Pact, the UK's trade association for the creative industries. It includes measures to ensure that filming can take place safely in a variety of locations, including studios, outside broadcasts and on location. Key measures include: Social distancing: All cast and crew members must maintain a distance of at least 2 metres from each other at all times. This may mean using green screens or other techniques to create the illusion of close proximity. Hygiene: All cast and crew members must wash their hands regularly and wear personal protective equipment (PPE) when appropriate. The use of hand sanitiser will be mandatory on set. Testing: Cast and crew members may be required to undergo regular COVID-19 testing. This will help to identify and isolate any individuals who may be infected with the virus. The guidance also includes specific measures for different types of filming, such as: Studio filming: Studio filming will be limited to a maximum of 50 people on set at any one time. All cast and crew members will be required to wear face masks and maintain social distancing. Outside broadcasts: Outside broadcasts will be limited to a maximum of 25 people on set at any one time. All cast and crew members will be required to wear face masks and maintain social distancing. Location filming: Location filming will be limited to a maximum of 10 people on set at any one time. All cast and crew members will be required to wear face masks and maintain social distancing. The guidance is a living document and will be updated as necessary in line with the latest government advice. It is hoped that the measures will allow the TV industry to resume filming safely and minimise the risk of COVID-19 transmission.
