title: MoT changes come into force in Northern Ireland
text: Under the new rules, more than 20 extra checks will be carried out on vehicles. The checks relate mostly to safety-critical items, such as tyres, brakes, lights, steering and suspension. The changes have been brought in to improve road safety and reduce the number of people killed or seriously injured in road traffic collisions. The new rules mean that drivers of all vehicles, including cars, vans, motorbikes and buses, will need to have their vehicles tested more frequently. Cars and small vans will need to be tested every two years, instead of every three years. Larger vehicles, such as buses and lorries, will need to be tested every year. The new rules also mean that the tests will be more comprehensive. More than 20 extra checks will be carried out on each vehicle, including: Checking the tread depth of tyres Checking the condition of brakes Checking the condition of lights Checking the condition of steering and suspension Checking for any leaks or damage to the vehicle The changes have been welcomed by road safety campaigners, who say they will help to reduce the number of people killed or seriously injured in road traffic collisions. However, some garage owners have expressed concern about the increased workload that the new rules will create. They say that they may have to increase their prices to cover the cost of the extra tests. The Department for Infrastructure has said that it will be working with the garage industry to ensure that the new rules are implemented smoothly. It is important to note that the new rules only apply to vehicles that are registered in Northern Ireland. Vehicles that are registered in other parts of the UK will not need to be tested more frequently. If you are unsure whether your vehicle needs to be tested, you can check the MOT checker on the Department for Infrastructure website. The new MOT rules are just one of a number of measures that the Department for Infrastructure is taking to improve road safety in Northern Ireland. Other measures include: Investing in new road safety infrastructure, such as road signs and traffic lights Educating drivers about the dangers of speeding, drink-driving and other risky behaviours Enforcing the law against dangerous drivers The Department for Infrastructure is committed to making Northern Ireland's roads safer for everyone.

title: Salisbury city best performing in GB shop vacancy table
text: Salisbury city best performing in GB shop vacancy table Its vacancy rate of 7.7% is the lowest in the country, says the Local Data Company report, with Cambridge (8.5%) and Chesterfield (8.7%) completing the top three. The research also found that the number of empty shops across Great Britain fell by 3.6% in the first half of the year, with 11,619 fewer units now vacant. The Local Data Company said this was "the first sustained period of decline in shop vacancy rates since 2015". Matthew Hopkinson, director at Local Data Company, said: "The decline in the overall vacancy rate is encouraging news for the UK's retail sector. "While there are still challenges ahead, the fact that vacancy rates are falling is a positive sign that the sector is starting to recover from the impact of the pandemic." The report also found that the number of new store openings increased by 11.6% in the first half of the year, with 1,976 new stores opening. This was the highest number of new store openings since the Local Data Company began tracking the data in 2015. Hopkinson said: "The increase in the number of new store openings is another positive sign for the retail sector. "It suggests that retailers are starting to gain confidence in the future and are investing in new stores." The report also found that the number of vacant shops in shopping centres fell by 4.8% in the first half of the year, with 3,581 fewer units now vacant. This was the first time that the number of vacant shops in shopping centres had fallen since 2015. Hopkinson said: "The decline in the number of vacant shops in shopping centres is particularly encouraging. "It suggests that shopping centres are starting to recover from the impact of the pandemic and are becoming more attractive to retailers."

title: BCP Council leader Vikki Slade ousted in second confidence vote loss
text: Lib Dem Vikki Slade failed to win support over a Tory motion stating "a high level of public frustration and mistrust" in her administration. She had led Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole (BCP) Council since May 2019, under the Unity Alliance. A coalition of Labour, Independent and Green councillors voted with the Conservatives, leaving the Lib Dems and two Independent councillors supporting Vikki Slade. The motion was triggered by a string of public rows that have made national headlines, including an investigation into the deputy leader Cllr Philip Broadhead who was accused of sexual harassment. Cllr Slade was also criticized over a council tax increase, and the collapse of a suspended pier project, which the leader had strongly supported. The vote was the second time the Conservative group had put forward a motion of no confidence in Vikki Slade. In January, only the Conservative councillors supported the motion, with Labour, Green and Independent councillors abstaining, and Lib Dems voting against it. In a statement Vikki Slade said: "I am disappointed with the outcome of tonight's vote and believe that it is a huge loss for local democracy. "I am deeply saddened that councillors have chosen to put party politics before the best interests of the residents of BCP. "Throughout my time as leader I have always put the needs of residents first and worked tirelessly to deliver the best possible services in an extremely challenging financial environment." The council said it would now begin the process of electing a new leader. The Unity Alliance was formed by the Lib Dems, the Conservatives, and two Independent councillors, in May 2019. The agreement was intended to give the Lib Dems control of the council, while giving the Conservatives a greater influence than they would have had in opposition. However, the coalition has been dogged by rows, with the Conservatives and Lib Dems clashing over a number of issues. The Tories had already withdrawn from the alliance in 2022, leaving the Lib Dems in a minority administration. A full council meeting will be held on 15 March to determine a new leader of the council.

title: Kent MPs lobbied to support Thames estuary airport
text: Sittingbourne and Sheppey's Gordon Henderson, Dartford's Gareth Johnson and Gravesham's Adam Holloway, all Tories, have met Daniel Moylan. "It didn't change my mind. I still oppose an airport on the Isle of Grain," said Mr Henderson. Mr Johnson, who represents the constituency where the airport would be built, said: "I support an airport on the Isle of Grain, but only if it is brought forward with the backing of the local community." Mr Holloway said: "I believe an airport on the Isle of Grain could bring many benefits to north Kent, but it is important that the local community is consulted and their views are taken into account." The MPs' meeting with Moylan came after a leaked letter revealed that the aviation industry lobby group had offered to provide them with "research and other materials" to help them make their case for an airport. The letter, from Moylan to Tory MP Mark Francois, said: "We would be delighted to provide you with any research and other materials you may need to help you make your case." The offer was made after Francois had written to Moylan asking for help in persuading the government to support an airport on the Isle of Grain. The Department for Transport said it was "not considering" an airport on the Isle of Grain. An airport on the Isle of Grain has been proposed for decades, but it has always been met with strong local opposition. A public inquiry into the proposal in 2003 concluded that an airport would have a "significant adverse impact" on the environment and local communities. The Isle of Grain is a peninsula on the south bank of the River Thames, between the towns of Gravesend and Sheerness. It is home to a number of oil refineries and other industrial facilities. An airport on the Isle of Grain would be close to the proposed site of the Lower Thames Crossing, a new bridge and tunnel that would link Kent with Essex. The government has said it is committed to building the Lower Thames Crossing, but it has not yet confirmed when the project will be completed.

title: Unilever: Ice cream in, personal hygiene out in lockdown
text: The firm said ice cream sales leapt 26% in the three months to June, but demand for shampoo and deodorant fell. It said it had seen strong "growth in home consumption of foods, ice cream and tea" during lockdown. But hair salons and barbers being closed meant customers bought less shampoo, hair conditioner and hair spray. And with people spending more time at home, it said, they were using less deodorant. Unilever's sales overall fell by 1.6% between April and June, as sales of its beauty and personal care products dropped by 7.2%. However, sales of its food and refreshments products rose by 4.6%. The Anglo-Dutch company, which also owns brands including Dove soap, Ben & Jerry's ice cream and Marmite spread, said it had seen "encouraging" signs of recovery in China, where the coronavirus pandemic began.  But it said the outlook in other markets was "highly uncertain" due to the potential for further lockdowns. "Covid-19 continues to have a significant impact on people's lives and livelihoods, and this is reflected in our first half results," said chief executive Alan Jope.  "In response, we have accelerated our plans to simplify our business by making portfolio choices that enhance our focus on fewer, bigger brands and markets where we can deliver superior returns. We are also continuing to invest in our long-term growth priorities, such as digitalisation, e-commerce and sustainability." Unilever, which has its headquarters in London and Rotterdam, said it had raised its prices in order to offset a 4% rise in the cost of its raw materials. The company, the world's second largest consumer goods maker, has been reviewing its business in recent months. In March it announced plans to sell off its tea business, which includes the PG Tips and Lipton brands, in order to focus on faster growing areas. Unilever's shares have fallen by about 10% over the past year.

title: Nick Grimshaw's Radio 1 debut impresses critics
text: The Telegraph's Michael Hogan was impressed by Grimshaw's "youthful energy and enthusiasm for new music". The Guardian's Elisabeth Mahoney said Grimshaw made a confident debut. It was "a very promising, refreshing start that politely suggested the over-30s might like to shove off and go and die". The Independent's Andy Gill was less enthusiastic, describing the show as "a bit of a curate's egg" and saying that Grimshaw's "flippancy and over-familiarity" were off-putting. However, he did praise Grimshaw's "decent taste in music". Overall, the critics were divided in their opinions of Grimshaw's debut. However, the general consensus was that he had made a promising start and that he had the potential to be a successful radio presenter. In the weeks and months that followed, Grimshaw quickly established himself as a popular figure on Radio 1. He was praised for his engaging personality, his knowledge of music, and his ability to connect with his audience. Grimshaw's show became one of the most popular on the station, and he quickly became one of the most recognizable faces in British broadcasting. Grimshaw's success on Radio 1 was not without its critics. Some accused him of being too "mainstream" and of not playing enough alternative music. However, Grimshaw remained unfazed by these criticisms. He continued to play the music that he loved and to connect with his audience in his own unique way. In 2018, Grimshaw announced that he would be leaving Radio 1 after six years. He said that he wanted to "try something different" and that he was "excited for the future". Grimshaw's departure from Radio 1 was met with sadness by many of his fans. However, they wished him well in his future endeavors. Grimshaw's legacy at Radio 1 is one of success and innovation. He was one of the most popular and influential presenters in the station's history. He helped to shape the sound of Radio 1 and to connect with a new generation of listeners. Grimshaw's departure from Radio 1 marks the end of an era, but his impact on the station will be felt for many years to come.

title: Lancashire County Council election: Tories gain control
text: The authority had been under no overall control, with Labour the biggest party by four councillors. Nationally, the UK Independence Party (UKIP) suffered huge losses, but they did manage to gain the Padiham and Burnley West ward on. UKIP's gain was Labour's loss, with sitting Labour councillor Christine Fogarty losing her seat to UKIP's Paul Parker by 67 votes. Mr Parker was joined by UKIP's Alan Hosker, who saw off competition from four other candidates with 60% of the vote. Elsewhere in Burnley, the three sitting Conservative councillors in the Daneshouse with Stoneyholme ward all retained their seats. In Pendle, victory for the Conservatives in the Vivary Bridge ward means Labour have lost control of the council. The Tories gained the seat from Labour by the narrowest of margins - just four votes - after recounts. Nigel Eden, Paul McKenna and Graham Roach took the seats for the Conservatives. It's the first time the Conservatives have taken overall control of Pendle since it was created out of the local government reorganisation in 1974. For Labour, it's the first time since 1987 that they have not controlled the council. In Hyndburn, Labour maintained control despite losing Rishton ward to the Conservatives. However, Labour's losses did mean the party's majority was reduced from 16 to eight. In Rossendale, Labour managed to gain a seat from the Conservatives in the Eden ward, meaning they retained control of the council with 21 councillors. Liberal Democrats held onto all three of their seats in the Lancaster City Council elections. In Wyre, the Conservatives gained two seats from Labour and one from the Liberal Democrats. The Tories now control the council with 18 councillors to Labour's 12. Overall, the results were a mixed bag for the Conservatives, who made gains in some areas but lost ground in others. However, the party's victory in Pendle will be seen as a major achievement, and it will be interesting to see how they use their new-found power.

title: Concern at mortality rates at two Lanarkshire hospitals
text: Monklands and Wishaw General Hospitals recorded higher rates than the national average during the last quarter. Healthcare Improvement Scotland (HIS) will now investigate both, following an interim report which raised concerns. The report highlighted the higher-than-expected mortality rates at both hospitals. Monklands Hospital had a higher rate of deaths than expected for the third quarter of 2022/23, while Wishaw General Hospital had a higher rate for the second and third quarters. NHS Lanarkshire has welcomed the investigation and said it is committed to working with HIS to improve patient care. The health board said: "We welcome the Healthcare Improvement Scotland review into mortality rates at Monklands and Wishaw hospitals. We are committed to working with HIS to improve patient care and ensure that our hospitals are providing the best possible service." HIS said it will now carry out a full investigation into the mortality rates at both hospitals. The investigation will look at a range of factors, including the quality of care provided, staffing levels, and the availability of resources. HIS said: "We are aware of the concerns that have been raised about mortality rates at Monklands and Wishaw hospitals. We have therefore decided to carry out a full investigation into the matter. "The investigation will look at a range of factors, including the quality of care provided, staffing levels, and the availability of resources. We will work closely with NHS Lanarkshire to ensure that the investigation is thorough and that any necessary improvements are made." The investigation is expected to take several months to complete. HIS will publish a report of its findings once the investigation is complete.

title: UK plans £3m no-deal medicine transport
text: UK plans £3m no-deal medicine transport By Howard Mustoe & Joe Miller Business reporter It wants to hire an "express freight service" to transport medicines, blood and transplant tissue. But experts have warned that the deadline of 1 September set for the contract is "unachievable". The Department of Health and Social Care (DHSC) said the new service would help ensure "critical medicines" would be available in the event of a no-deal Brexit. The UK is due to leave the EU on 31 October, but it is not yet clear what will happen to trade between the two sides after that date. If the UK leaves the EU without a deal, it could lead to delays at the border, which could affect the supply of medicines. The DHSC said the new express freight service would be used to transport medicines, blood and transplant tissue from suppliers in the EU to the UK. The service would be used in addition to the existing arrangements for transporting medicines, which include air and sea freight. The DHSC said it was "working closely with the pharmaceutical industry and hauliers to ensure that we have the capacity and capability to deliver medicines to patients in all circumstances." However, experts have warned that the deadline of 1 September set for the contract is "unachievable". John Kearney, the chief executive of the British International Freight Association, said it would be "impossible" to get a new express freight service up and running by 1 September. He said: "The logistics industry is already stretched to capacity, and there is no spare capacity available to set up a new service by that date." The DHSC said it was "confident" that it would be able to award the contract by 1 September. A spokesperson for the department said: "We are working closely with the pharmaceutical industry and hauliers to ensure that we have the capacity and capability to deliver medicines to patients in all circumstances."

title: Russia halts Lithuania dairy imports in trade row
text: Russia has halted all imports of Lithuanian dairy produce in a widening trade row between the two countries. Russia's consumer watchdog said the levels of yeast and mould in Lithuanian dairy produce were unacceptable. Lithuania is already involved in a bitter dispute with Russia over the cost of gas imports from Russia's Gazprom energy giant. The Russian consumer watchdog Rospotrebnadzor said its inspections of Lithuanian dairy products found "unacceptable levels of yeast and mould". The watchdog said it had banned imports of all Lithuanian dairy products with immediate effect. Lithuanian officials have rejected the allegations, saying that their dairy products meet all EU safety standards. The Lithuanian government has accused Russia of using the dairy ban as a political tool to pressure Lithuania into accepting higher gas prices. The dairy ban is the latest in a series of trade disputes between Russia and Lithuania. In recent months, Russia has also banned imports of Lithuanian fruit, vegetables, and meat. The trade disputes between Russia and Lithuania are part of a wider pattern of tensions between Russia and the European Union. Russia has been accused of using trade bans and other economic measures to pressure EU countries into supporting its policies. The EU has condemned the Russian trade bans, saying they are illegal and unjustified. The EU has also imposed its own sanctions on Russia in response to the annexation of Crimea and the conflict in eastern Ukraine. The trade disputes between Russia and Lithuania are likely to continue in the coming months. Russia has said that it will not lift the dairy ban until Lithuania agrees to accept higher gas prices. Lithuania has said that it will not accept higher gas prices and that it will continue to challenge the Russian trade bans in the courts.

title: Coronavirus: London key workers to star on cover of British Vogue
text: London key workers to star on cover of British Vogue A London Overground train driver, an east London midwife and a King's Cross supermarket worker will all feature on July's front page. Photographer Jamie Hawkesworth captured the trio, who were nominated by the public. The coverline reads: "Salute to our NHS and key workers - They've done their duty and they deserve a medal." The initiative was the brainchild of British Vogue editor-in-chief Edward Enninful. He said: "This cover is a celebration of those key workers - both celebrated and unsung - who have kept our country going during this pandemic. It is a moment in history and a moment for unity and gratitude." One of the cover stars is Atul Kochhar, a King's Cross supermarket worker. He said: "I was surprised and very honoured to be asked. It was a pleasure and a privilege to represent key workers on the cover of such a prestigious magazine. I would like to say a big thank you to the NHS, the government and everyone who has helped us during this difficult time." Another cover star is Marianne Eger, a London Overground train driver. She said: "I was so excited to be involved in this project. It's a real honour to represent key workers and to be part of something so special. I hope it will help to raise awareness of the importance of key workers and the work they do." The third cover star is Liz Johnson, an east London midwife. She said: "I am so proud and honored to represent key workers on the cover of British Vogue. It's a huge privilege to be part of such an inspiring project and to be able to share the stories of key workers with the world. I hope it will help to raise awareness of the importance of key workers and the work they do." The July issue of British Vogue is on sale from Friday 3 July.

title: British Steel in talks with government to avert collapse
text: Sources close to owners Greybull Capital say its future will be discussed at "ministerial level". British Steel has admitted it needs further financial support from the government to help it address high energy costs and a downturn in its markets. It employs 3,400 people in the UK, mostly in Scunthorpe in Lincolnshire and Teesside, after it was bought out of liquidation in 2016. The government has declined to comment on the prospect of a bailout. The firm is one of the UK's largest steelmakers. It is reportedly losing about £1m a day and will run out of cash by the end of the month unless it can agree on a support package from the government. Government support would be likely to be in the form of loans rather than equity. The steel industry has been hit hard by a combination of factors including: The war in Ukraine and sanctions on Russia, which have led to a surge in gas prices and uncertainty about supply. Falling demand from construction and manufacturing as a result of the economic downturn. Increased competition from China, which has led to a global glut of steel. The UK government has already provided the company with a £30m loan and a £100m guarantee on commercial loans. It is understood that the company is asking for a further £300m to help it through the current crisis. The government is thought to be reluctant to provide further support without guarantees that the company has a long-term future, and that taxpayers' money will be protected. The company is currently carrying out a strategic review of its operations, and it is understood that it is considering selling off some of its assets. Any deal to sell the company would likely need the approval of the government, which has a "golden share" in the company that gives it the right to veto any sale. The government has said that it is committed to supporting the steel industry, but it is also mindful of the need to protect taxpayers' money.

title: Lagarde warns UK of pain ahead as Brexit approaches
text: Kamal AhmedEconomics editor@bbckamalon Twitter Christine Lagarde told the BBC the Brexit process would be complicated. She said that although the UK economy had some strengths, it was not as well placed as it could have been to go through with the process. "I think the UK has certainly strengths and it has weaknesses also, and I think it's important to recognise that the position in which the UK economy is today is not as strong as it could have been," she said. "Having said that, it has some strengths that should enable it to go through with the process in a satisfactory manner, but there will be pain and there will be a slowdown and there will be some adjustments that the UK economy will have to go through." Her comments come as the UK government prepares to start the process of negotiating its exit from the European Union. The government has said that it wants to leave the single market and the customs union, and to negotiate a free trade agreement with the EU. However, there is uncertainty about what kind of deal the UK will be able to negotiate, and how long the process will take. Ms Lagarde said that the UK economy was not as well prepared for Brexit as it could have been, and that there would be some pain ahead. She also said that the UK government should be "as transparent as possible" about the potential impact of Brexit on the economy. "I think it's important for the UK government to be as transparent as possible about the potential impact of Brexit on the UK economy, and to be honest with the British people about what the challenges will be," she said. The UK government has said that it is committed to transparency, and that it will provide regular updates on the progress of the Brexit negotiations. However, it has also said that it will not be able to provide all of the information that businesses and the public may want, because some of the details of the negotiations will need to be kept confidential.

title: US 'may free Israel spy Jonathan Pollard'
text: A US official told the New York Times that no decisions had been made, but confirmed there had been discussions. Pollard, who was granted Israeli citizenship in 1995, is serving a life sentence for passing thousands of classified military and diplomatic documents to Israel in the 1980s. He was arrested in 1985 and has been in prison ever since. In 2015, the Obama administration commuted Pollard's sentence by five years, making him eligible for parole in November 2018. However, the Trump administration has not yet made a decision on whether to release him. Pollard's case has been the subject of much debate over the years. Some argue that he is a traitor who deserves to remain in prison, while others believe that he has already served his time and should be released. Pollard's supporters, including many members of the Israeli government, have argued that he was treated unfairly and should be released on humanitarian grounds. They point out that he has already served 30 years in prison, which is more than any other American convicted of spying for an ally. Pollard's opponents, including some former US intelligence officials, argue that he is a danger to national security and should never be released. They say that he betrayed his country by providing Israel with highly classified information that could have been used to harm the United States. The decision of whether or not to release Pollard is ultimately up to President Trump. He has not yet indicated what he will do, but he has said that he is aware of the case and is considering all of his options. If Trump decides to release Pollard, it would be a significant diplomatic gesture to Israel. It would also be a controversial decision, as Pollard is a convicted spy who has caused significant damage to the United States. The decision of whether or not to release Pollard is a complex one with no easy answers. It is a decision that will have a significant impact on US-Israeli relations, as well as on Pollard's own life.

title: Government says sorry to women 'ignored' by doctors
text: Government says sorry to women 'ignored' by doctors By Zoe Kleinman Reporter, BBC News Nadine Dorries was giving a statement in Parliament, on the Cumberlege review, published on Wednesday. The review, which had heard from about 700 women, focused on vaginal mesh to treat incontinence, a problem that mainly affects middle-aged and older women. Vaginal mesh is a synthetic material that is used to treat incontinence and prolapse - in which organs slip down because supporting tissues have weakened. It has been used in more than 100,000 operations in the UK. But the review found that many women had been given mesh implants without fully understanding the risks. Some said they had been pressured into having it and not told about alternatives. Many also complained that their concerns about pain and complications after surgery were ignored by doctors. "I want to acknowledge today that on too many occasions the experiences of these women were missed, ignored, or dismissed," Ms Dorries said. "I want to say sorry to each and every one of them." She said the government would now set up a new body to implement the review's recommendations, including a compensation scheme for those who had suffered complications from mesh implants. The review also looked at other types of surgery for incontinence and prolapse. It found that up to a quarter of women who have these operations experience serious complications. The government has promised to invest £50m in research into new treatments for incontinence and prolapse. The Cumberlege review was commissioned by the government in 2020. It was led by Baroness Cumberlege, a crossbench peer who has previously chaired inquiries into other medical scandals. In her report, Baroness Cumberlege said that the mesh scandal was "the result of a collective failure of the system". She said that women had been "failed by the healthcare system, by manufacturers, and by regulators". She called for a change in the way that mesh is used in the NHS. She said that it should only be used as a last resort, after other treatments have failed. The government has said that it will accept all of the review's recommendations.

title: Donegal crash: Mullan family funeral hears there are 'no words and no answers'
text: By Keiron Tourish BBC News NI John Mullan, 49, his six-year-old daughter Amelia, and 14-year-old stepson Tomas died in the crash. Their mother, Geraldine Mullan, managed to escape and raise the alarm. She told their funeral in County Donegal that her "world fell apart" when she was told what had happened. "There are just no words and no answers. Only an unimaginable pain," she said. "How do you try to make sense of the senseless, know that you will never see the faces of the people you love ever again? How do you come to terms with the fact that you were meant to be with them but, by a twist of fate, you got out alive?" Mrs Mullan said she wanted to thank the emergency services who had responded so quickly to the crash. "Our hearts ache for what you witnessed and the trauma that you must have suffered that night," she said. "But we also want to say thank you. You showed great compassion and dignity." She also thanked the local community for their support. "Your kindness has helped us to cope with the unbearable," she said. "You have shown us that, even in the darkest of times, there is still so much love and humanity in the world." The funeral was also attended by President Michael D Higgins and Prime Minister Micheál Martin. In his homily, Bishop Alan McGuckian said that the Mullan family had been "robbed of their future". "They were a loving family, who were full of life," he said. "Their deaths have left a huge void in the hearts of their family and friends." Bishop McGuckian said that it was important to remember the good times that the Mullan family had shared. "Let us not dwell on the sadness of their passing, but on the joy that they brought into our lives," he said. "Let us celebrate their lives and the love that they shared." The funeral was followed by a burial at St Mary's Cemetery in Dunfanaghy.

text: The University of Wolverhampton and Keele University in Staffordshire both said teaching would continue online. title: Cladding: MPs fail in bid to change fire safety payment rules
text: The Fire Safety Bill - to strengthen regulations following the Grenfell Tower fire - comes after financial help was granted to install better cladding. But flat owners say the rules around who pays are unfair, as more than half a million leaseholders may have to pay tens of thousands of pounds to fix potentially unsafe buildings. In the wake of the Grenfell Tower fire, which claimed the lives of 72 people in 2017, the government pledged to improve building safety standards. As part of this, the Building Safety Fund was created to help pay for the removal and replacement of dangerous cladding on high-rise buildings.  However, leaseholders, who own their flats but not the freehold of the building, have argued that they should not be responsible for the costs of replacing unsafe cladding. They say that the responsibility should lie with developers and building owners, who were responsible for installing the unsafe cladding in the first place. The Fire Safety Bill, which is currently going through Parliament, would have introduced a new levy on developers to help pay for the costs of cladding replacement. However, MPs voted against an amendment to the Bill that would have required developers to pay for all the costs of cladding replacement. This means that leaseholders could still be liable for significant costs. Leaseholders have expressed their disappointment at the MPs' decision. They say that they are being unfairly penalized for the mistakes of developers and building owners. They are calling on the government to introduce a fairer system that would protect leaseholders from the costs of cladding replacement. The government has said that it is committed to protecting leaseholders and that it will continue to work on finding a solution to the cladding crisis. However, it is clear that the issue is far from resolved and that leaseholders could still be facing significant costs for cladding replacement. The Fire Safety Bill is expected to become law later this year. It will introduce a number of new measures to improve building safety, including: A new Building Safety Regulator to oversee the safety of high-rise buildings New requirements for developers to provide information about the fire safety of their buildings New powers for local authorities to take action against unsafe buildings The government hopes that these measures will help to prevent another tragedy like the Grenfell Tower fire. However, the issue of cladding replacement remains unresolved and could continue to be a major source of concern for leaseholders.

title: Manchester attack: Veil of quiet respect descends over city
text: By Tom Mullen BBC News Online Tuesday's proud show of solidarity and defiance at a vigil in Albert Square appears to have given way to a sense of deep sadness, with dozens of people pausing to read the many messages left in St Ann's Square. There are flowers, candles and soft toys as well as messages of condolence and support, with some people quietly crying as they read what has been written. A veil of quiet respect has descended over the city centre, with even the trams pausing briefly as they pass the floral tributes which have been left near the scene of the attack. The city's main shopping centre, the Arndale Centre, reopened on Tuesday and, while there were fewer people than usual, those who were there said they felt safe. "It's nice to be back in the city centre, but it's very strange to think that something so awful happened here," said Kelly Williams, 30, a healthcare worker. "I think people are still in shock, but we're determined to show that we won't be beaten by terrorism. We're a strong city and we'll get through this together." Police officers are patrolling the city centre in large numbers and there is a heavy security presence around the main train stations and shopping areas. But despite the increased security, there is a sense of calm and defiance among the people of Manchester. "We're not going to let the terrorists win," said John Smith, 40, a computer programmer. "We're going to continue to live our lives and we're going to show the world that Manchester is a strong and resilient city." The attack has had a profound impact on the people of Manchester, but it has also brought them together. In the wake of the tragedy, people have been offering each other support and comfort. There have been spontaneous acts of kindness, such as people offering free hugs to strangers in the city centre. And there have been countless messages of support from around the world, which have been shared on social media and displayed in public places. The people of Manchester are determined to show that they will not be defeated by terrorism. They are a strong and resilient city and they will get through this together.

title: BT signs 5G deal with Ericsson to help ditch Huawei
text: BT signs 5G deal with Ericsson to help ditch Huawei By Leo Kelion Technology desk editor BT said in time it expected 50% of all its 5G traffic to be transmitted via the Swedish company's kit. The move will let it ditch Huawei, the Chinese company that provides much of the UK's 4G and 5G equipment. The government has ordered telecoms operators to remove all Huawei equipment from their networks by 2027. BT has said it needed "multiple vendors" to ensure its network remained competitive. It explained that the Ericsson deal would deliver a "significant" number of new 5G sites. "This deal means we can accelerate the rollout of our 5G network using the latest kit from a trusted and high-quality vendor," said Howard Watson, BT's chief technology officer. "Ericsson's state-of-the-art kit will deliver significant benefits." But the deal may not solve all BT's technology headaches. For example, it still relies on Huawei for its broadband network kit. And BT will have to balance its relationship with Ericsson with those of its other suppliers, especially Nokia and Samsung. BT owns the UK's largest mobile phone network, EE. Two years ago, BT struck a major deal with Nokia to replace Huawei equipment in the core of its 5G network. But unlike Huawei, Ericsson also has an established radio access network (RAN) hardware business. The RAN is the part of the network that connects mobile phone masts to the core network and the internet. The Huawei ban and other issues had been expected to delay BT's 5G rollout plans. But Mr Watson said the deal with Ericsson would "accelerate" its 5G deployment. In a separate statement, Ericsson said it was "delighted to strengthen our long-standing partnership with BT".

title: Chevron: Indigenous Ecuadoreans seek higher damages
text: By Irene Caselli BBC News, Ecuador A triumphant atmosphere might have been expected as they gathered for a news conference in Quito, given the favourable verdict finally reached in a case that had been grinding through the Ecuadorian and US legal systems for 28 years. But for the four Indigenous leaders, representing more than 30,000 Ecuadorean Amazonians, the moment was bittersweet. "We never thought it would take so long, so many of our friends died waiting for this verdict. They gave their lives in the struggle," said Pablo Fajardo, speaking on behalf of his community, and a member of the Cofan people. The landmark decision by Ecuador's highest court at the end of February found Chevron, the US oil giant, responsible for massive contamination in the Amazon, which included dumping billions of gallons of toxic waste into rivers, contaminating the drinking water and killing wildlife. The court upheld a lower court ruling that ordered Chevron to pay $9.5bn (£7bn) in damages - one of the biggest environmental fines in history. Chevron has always denied the allegations and said it will fight the verdict. It says the clean-up was carried out by state-owned oil company Petroecuador, with which it worked in partnership. The Indigenous communities say the environmental disaster has had a devastating impact on their lives. They have suffered serious health problems, including cancer, and contamination of their water supplies has deprived them of their main source of food. "Our children are fishing in a polluted river... and eating fish that have mercury," said Fajardo. "We feel so much sadness. We have lost everything due to Chevron," he said. The communities want more money from Chevron to help them to overcome the damage that has been done. "The verdict is a first step towards justice, but it should not end there. Chevron must repair the damage it has done and compensate the communities who have suffered," said Fajardo. The communities are also calling on the Ecuadorian government to step up its efforts to clean up the contamination. "The government must play its part. We need a clean-up plan. We need compensation for the damage to our health and environment," said Fajardo. The case has been closely watched by environmental groups around the world and is seen as a test case for the accountability of oil giants for the environmental damage they cause. The Indigenous communities say they hope the verdict will inspire other communities in the Amazon who are fighting similar battles against oil companies. "We are a symbol of resistance. We have shown that it is possible to fight against these powerful companies and win," said Fajardo.

title: China morning round-up: Illegal workers
text: Shanghai Daily says Vice-Minister of Public Security Yang Huanning told the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress on Wednesday that the crackdown was aimed at curbing "smuggling, theft, robbery and other crimes". Police caught 105,274 illegal workers and 5,670 employers between January and August 2023, and imposed fines totalling 260 million yuan ($37m; £30m), he said. The Global Times said the crackdown was not new and that the authorities had been "vowing to ensure 'dynamic zero-Covid' and social stability". It said the police operation involved "coordinated efforts" requiring "multiple city-level departments". The crackdown is part of a wider drive by the Chinese government to clamp down on illegal activities and maintain social order. In recent months, the authorities have also launched crackdowns on online scams, telecommunications fraud and food safety violations. The Chinese government has long been concerned about the issue of illegal workers, who are often paid less than the minimum wage and lack basic labour protections. In 2019, the government introduced a new law aimed at cracking down on the illegal employment of foreign workers. The crackdown on illegal workers is likely to continue in the coming months as the Chinese government seeks to strengthen its control over the labour market and maintain social stability. The move has been welcomed by some, who say it will help to protect the rights of workers and ensure that businesses are operating fairly. However, others have expressed concern that the crackdown could lead to discrimination against migrant workers and make it more difficult for them to find work. The crackdown is also likely to have a significant impact on the Chinese economy. Illegal workers make up a significant portion of the workforce in many sectors, such as construction and manufacturing. The crackdown could lead to labour shortages and higher labour costs, which could in turn lead to higher prices for goods and services. The crackdown on illegal workers is a complex issue with both positive and negative consequences. It is important to weigh the benefits and risks of the crackdown before making a judgment about its overall impact.

title: 'I'm gay and I was sexually assaulted by a woman'
text: By Shiona McCallum Newsbeat reporter He says he "didn't feel under threat" by his attacker, Cheryl Cottrell, because she was a woman. The film-maker, who is gay, has been struggling with post traumatic stress disorder and suicidal thoughts since. "I didn't feel like I was under threat from her because I knew women can't physically overpower men," he says. "But it doesn't change the fact that I was sexually assaulted. I still felt like a victim." He says the culture surrounding male victims of sexual violence makes it hard for them to come forward and speak out about their experiences. "There's a lot of stigma around men being victims of sexual assault," he says. "There's this idea that men are supposed to be strong and powerful, and that if they're assaulted then they're not a 'real man'. "This needs to change. Men need to be able to come forward and talk about their experiences without feeling ashamed or embarrassed." He hopes that by speaking out about his experience, he can help to break down the stigma surrounding male victims of sexual violence. "I want people to understand that sexual assault can happen to anyone, regardless of their gender," he says. "I want men to know that they're not alone, and that if they've been assaulted, they should come forward and seek help." If you or someone you know has been affected by sexual violence, the following organizations can provide support: - The National Sexual Violence Resource Center: 1-800-656-HOPE - RAINN: 1-800-656-HOPE - The National Domestic Violence Hotline: 1-800-799-SAFE - The National Center for Victims of Crime: 1-855-484-2846

title: Brexit: Giant lorry park branded 'concrete monstrosity'
text: Construction work on a site off the M20 near Ashford began earlier this month. One resident labelled the plans "sneaky", stating she had not been told about them. The Department for Transport said "commercial sensitivities made it impossible to engage with local residents" before work started. The site is one of three disused airfields, along with Manston in Kent and Stanford in Essex, being transformed into lorry parks for Operation Brock, which is intended to reduce disruption at the Port of Dover in the event of cross-Channel disruption. But Dover MP Natalie Elphicke and Ashford MP Damian Green have raised concerns about the impact on the local area following complaints from residents. The MPs said the airfields were "completely the wrong locations" for the lorry parks and called on the government to reconsider. The government said the sites were chosen for their "good access to motorways" and other nearby infrastructure. However, residents in Sevington, a village on the outskirts of Ashford, have expressed anger at the lack of consultation over the plans. "It's like a concrete monstrosity," said one resident, who asked not to be named. "It's going to ruin our village." Another resident said he had not been told about the plans until work started. "I'm really concerned about the impact it's going to have on the environment," he said. "We've got a lot of wildlife around here and this is just going to destroy it." The Department for Transport said it had been "engaging with local residents and businesses throughout the planning and development process". "We understand that some residents may have concerns about the impact of the lorry park on their local area," a spokesperson said. "We are committed to working with the local community to address these concerns and minimize any disruption." But residents say they have not been given enough information about the plans. "We've been completely ignored," said one resident. "The government hasn't even bothered to tell us what's going on." The government has said the lorry parks will be temporary and will only be used when necessary to ease congestion at the Port of Dover. However, residents fear that the parks will become permanent fixtures and that their villages will be blighted by noise, pollution, and traffic.

text: However, the broadcaster has not announced any further details, such as the location of the villa. title: Preston GP struck off over 'dishonest' food poisoning claims
text: A tribunal found the actions of Dr Zuber Bux, who practised in the Preston area in Lancashire, were "misleading, dishonest and financially motivated". The panel also proved he failed to declare his wife Sehana Bux, who helped run his clinics, as a director of his company. The tribunal heard evidence that Dr Bux had claimed to be a travel health expert and recommended unnecessary vaccinations to around 1,300 patients. He also provided letters to patients claiming they had food poisoning, which they could use to claim compensation from travel companies. The tribunal chairman, Dr Nigel Murray, said: "The repeated, dishonest claims made by Dr Zuber Bux were rooted in financial gain. He sought to portray himself as an expert in travel health, when in fact he had no such expertise. "His actions were a betrayal of the trust placed in him by his patients and brought the medical profession into disrepute." Dr Bux qualified as a doctor in Pakistan in 1987 and moved to the UK in 1990. He worked as a GP in the Preston area for many years and was the medical director of two clinics, Travel Clinic UK and Bux Medical Centre. In 2016, the General Medical Council (GMC) began an investigation into Dr Bux's conduct after receiving a number of complaints from patients. The investigation found that Dr Bux had been making false claims about his qualifications and experience, and that he had been providing patients with unnecessary vaccinations. Dr Bux was suspended from practising medicine in 2017 and the GMC referred his case to a tribunal. The tribunal heard evidence from a number of witnesses, including patients who had been treated by Dr Bux. The tribunal found that Dr Bux had breached a number of GMC rules, including those relating to honesty, integrity and financial probity. The tribunal also found that he had failed to declare his wife as a director of his company, which was a breach of company law. The tribunal's decision to strike Dr Bux off the medical register means that he will no longer be able to practise medicine in the UK.

title: Teletubbies creator 'sad' about show's remake
text: Wood, 77, told Radio Times she is not a fan of the trend for remaking old shows such as Dangermouse. "I think we've got to move on," she argued. "There's still room for new ideas." Wood created Teletubbies with her husband, Andrew Davenport, and it first aired on BBC Two in 1997. title: Depression: 'Second biggest cause of disability' in world
text: By Helen Briggs BBC News The disease must be treated as a global public health priority, experts report in the journal PLOS Medicine. The study compared clinical depression with more than 200 other health conditions and found that it is the second leading cause of disability worldwide and the top cause in several countries including the UK, US and Australia. The researchers estimated that more than 300 million people globally are living with depression, and it could cost the world economy more than $1 trillion (£750 bn) a year. That's in lost productivity, as well as direct healthcare costs. The study, funded by the World Health Organization, also found that depression is more disabling than many other chronic conditions, including diabetes, heart disease, and cancer. Lead researcher Professor Alize Ferrari of the University of Queensland in Australia said: "Our findings show that mental disorders, and in particular depression, are not only common, but they cause more suffering and disability than most other conditions." "This means that depression should be one of the main health challenges that governments and health systems address for their populations worldwide." The researchers hope the study will help convince governments and health organisations to invest more resources in mental health. "Depression can be treated, but too often does not get the attention it deserves," said Prof Ferrari. "We need to reduce the stigma associated with depression so people can come forward and seek help to manage their illness." She said mental health services should be available and affordable for all. "We need to move depression from the margins to the mainstream of health." The study was based on data from 188 countries and analysed information from the World Health Organization's Global Burden of Disease Study, which includes information on 301 health conditions and their impact on population health. The researchers calculated the disability caused by depression using a measure called years lived with disability (YLDs). YLDs measure the number of years lived with a health condition, weighted to reflect the severity of the condition. The researchers found that people with depression had an average of 8.9 YLDs, which is more than the number of YLDs for diabetes (5.3), heart disease (4.7), and cancer (3.7). The study also found that the number of YLDs for depression has increased by more than 50% since 1990. The researchers say this is due to a number of factors, including population growth, ageing, and changes in lifestyle. They also say that the increase in YLDs for depression may be due to better diagnosis and reporting of the condition. However, they say that more research is needed to understand the reasons for the increase.

title: Pound rises on Brexit 'progress' report
text: Sterling rose nearly 1% against the US currency and 0.5% against the euro after the reports on Bloomberg News. However, the pound later gave up some of its gains after London Mayor Sadiq Khan warned that the UK capital's financial services industry could lose up to 100,000 jobs if the UK leaves the EU without a deal. The reports from Brussels suggested that the EU and the UK were close to agreeing on a withdrawal deal, but that there were still some "significant obstacles" to overcome. The reports also suggested that the UK government was preparing to offer a "significant financial incentive" to the EU to help secure a deal. The pound has been volatile in recent weeks as investors try to assess the likelihood of a no-deal Brexit. Sterling fell to a 28-month low against the US dollar in August, but has since recovered some of its losses. The UK is due to leave the EU on 29 March 2019. If the UK leaves without a deal, it will mean that there will be no transition period and businesses will have to adapt to new trading arrangements overnight. This could lead to disruption to trade and a fall in the value of the pound. The EU has said that it is willing to grant the UK a transition period, but only if the UK agrees to pay a "divorce bill" of up to £40bn. The UK government has said that it is willing to pay a "reasonable" divorce bill, but has not yet agreed to the EU's figure. The negotiations between the UK and the EU are ongoing and it is unclear whether the two sides will be able to reach a deal before the UK leaves the EU. If the UK does leave without a deal, it could have a significant impact on the UK economy and the value of the pound.

title: Europe-wide police operation busts horsemeat racket
text: Police in Spain made 65 arrests for crimes including animal abuse, forgery, money laundering and racketeering. Horses in Portugal and Spain deemed unfit for consumption were slaughtered and their meat passed off as beef, police said. Europol, the EU's police agency, said the meat was sold in at least 25 countries across Europe, including the UK, France, Italy and Portugal. Some of it found its way into products destined for children, including burgers and lasagne. The operation began in February 2022, when Spanish police discovered horses being slaughtered in conditions that breached regulations. They found signs of ill-treatment, including animals with open wounds and broken bones. Police also discovered that the horses had been given drugs to make them appear younger and healthier. The meat was then sold to slaughterhouses and meat traders, who passed it off as beef. As well as the arrests in Spain, police in Portugal, France, Italy and the UK made a further 10 arrests. Europol said the operation had dismantled a "major criminal network" involved in the horsemeat racket. The operation is the latest in a series of investigations into the horsemeat trade in Europe. In 2013, a major scandal broke out when it was revealed that horsemeat had been found in products sold in supermarkets across Europe. The scandal led to a number of changes in the way that horsemeat is regulated in Europe. However, the latest operation suggests that the trade in horsemeat is still a problem. In a statement, Europol said the operation had "demonstrated the importance of cooperation between law enforcement agencies across Europe". "This investigation has shown that the illegal horsemeat trade is a serious issue that poses a risk to public health and animal welfare," the statement said. "Europol will continue to work with its partners to tackle this problem and bring those responsible to justice."

title: London minicab drivers demand more Covid-19 protection
text: London's 110,000 minicab drivers are allowed to work if they are providing essential journeys. The United Private Hire Drivers Association said TFL should urgently advise drivers how to minimise the risk. "We are asking TfL to consult with minicab drivers and provide guidance on how to operate safely during the current pandemic," a spokesman for the association said. "We are urging the mayor of London and TfL to work with us to protect drivers and passengers." TfL said it had not received any reports of minicab drivers contracting Covid-19. "We are working closely with the minicab industry to ensure that drivers are operating safely and in accordance with the latest government advice," a TfL spokesman said. "We have produced guidance for drivers on how to minimise the risk of infection and provided them with advice on how to clean their vehicles." The spokesman said TfL was also working with minicab operators to ensure that they were providing drivers with the necessary safety equipment. "We will continue to monitor the situation and take any further action that is necessary to protect drivers and passengers," the spokesman said. Some minicab drivers have said they are concerned about the risk of contracting Covid-19 from passengers. "I am worried about getting the virus from passengers," said one minicab driver, who asked not to be named. "I am doing everything I can to protect myself, but I am still worried." Another minicab driver said he had stopped working because he was worried about the risk of contracting the virus. "I am not prepared to risk my health," he said. "I know that I am providing an essential service, but I am not going to put my life on the line." The United Private Hire Drivers Association said it was working with TfL to provide drivers with the necessary safety equipment and guidance. "We are doing everything we can to protect our drivers," the spokesman said. "We are urging the mayor of London and TfL to work with us to protect drivers and passengers."
