title: Commons pays tribute to miners in Gleision tragedy
text: Shadow Welsh Secretary and Neath MP Peter Hain said lessons could be learned from the Gleision tragedy for the future of mines safety and rescue. He also said during Welsh Questions that the appeal fund set up for the families affected by the disaster could not be closed due to the ongoing trauma suffered by the families. The fund has now reached £143,000 and there are plans for a permanent memorial to the victims. Mr Hain said: "There are lessons to be learned from what happened at Gleision, both in terms of mine safety and in terms of the rescue services." "We need to make sure that we have the best possible safety standards in place at all mines, and that we have the resources in place to respond quickly and effectively to any emergency." "The families of the Gleision victims have suffered a terrible tragedy, and they deserve to have the best possible support from the government and from the community." "The appeal fund has been a great success, and I would like to thank everyone who has donated so far. The money raised will help to provide much-needed support to the families, and it will also help to fund a permanent memorial to the victims." Welsh Secretary Stephen Crabb said that the government was committed to improving mine safety and to providing support to the families of the victims of the Gleision tragedy. He said: "The government is committed to improving mine safety and to providing support to the families of the victims of the Gleision tragedy." "We have already taken a number of steps to improve mine safety, including introducing new regulations and increasing the number of inspectors." "We are also working with the mining industry to develop new technologies and practices to improve safety." "The government is also committed to providing support to the families of the victims of the Gleision tragedy." "We have already provided financial assistance to the families, and we are working with them to develop a long-term support package." "The government will continue to work with the mining industry and with the families of the victims to improve mine safety and to provide support to those who have been affected by the Gleision tragedy."

title: Sheffield shooting: Drive-by gunman guilty of attempted murder
text: The boy suffered serious leg injuries when Stephen Dunford, 25, opened fire on a group of people in Northern Avenue, Sheffield, from a passing car. He was later recorded in jail bragging about the attack, saying he had "burst" his victim's kneecap and that he "deserved it" for disrespectful comments made in the past. Dunford, of no fixed address, was found guilty of attempted murder by a jury at Sheffield Crown Court on Friday after a trial lasting almost four weeks. He will be sentenced on 29 March. The court heard how Dunford had been driving a black Audi A3 when he pulled up alongside a group of people in the street at about 18:00 GMT on 23 July last year. He wound down the window and fired four shots from a handgun towards the group. One of the bullets hit the boy in the leg, causing serious injuries. He was taken to hospital where he underwent surgery. Dunford fled the scene but was later arrested by police. When interviewed, he denied being involved in the shooting, but his DNA was found on the gun and in the car. The jury heard that Dunford had been friends with the victim's family but had fallen out with them after an argument. He had made threats to harm the victim in the past. In a statement released after the verdict, the victim's family said: "We are relieved that Stephen Dunford has been found guilty of attempted murder. This has been a very difficult time for us, but we are grateful to the police and the jury for their hard work in bringing him to justice. "We hope that this verdict will send a clear message that gun crime will not be tolerated in our society." Detective Sergeant Matt Turner, who led the investigation, said: "This was a cowardly and reckless attack on a group of innocent people. Dunford is a dangerous individual who has no regard for human life. "I would like to thank the jury for their careful consideration of the evidence and for reaching the right verdict. I hope that this verdict will provide some comfort to the victim and his family."

title: A killer's compulsion undimmed by time
text: By Graeme Ogston BBC Scotland Tayside and Central reporter Sobs from the public seats from those whose lives he had changed forever, the passion in the Crown's closing speech, and the almost emotionless delivery of his own defence - there were many layers to the Ian Brady sentencing hearing. It was the culmination of years of patient and determined work by detectives, lawyers and forensic experts. The evil and the banality had co-existed in Brady throughout his life and both were present in court. His voice devoid of any emotion as he addressed the judge, Brady described himself as a "political prisoner" and accused the authorities of a "witch hunt". He made the bizarre claim that the Moors murders were somehow linked to his republican activities in Glasgow. It was clear though that the evidence against him was overwhelming. The description of his offending as "grotesque and wicked beyond belief" was not an exaggeration. The Crown narrative, illustrated by chilling black and white photographs, charted the manipulative grooming of vulnerable young victims, their torture, sexual abuse and murder. Brady maintained his innocence but the evidence against him was overwhelming. He and Myra Hindley lured five children to their deaths in the 1960s. Pauline Reade, John Kilbride, Keith Bennett, Lesley Ann Downey and Edward Evans were subjected to unimaginable horrors before being murdered. In 1985, Brady was convicted of the murders of John Kilbride, Lesley Ann Downey and Edward Evans and jailed for life. Hindley was jailed for life in 1966 for her part in the murders of Edward Evans and Lesley Ann Downey. She died in prison in 2002. Brady's bid to overturn his convictions in 2001 failed and he had been held at the high-security Ashworth Hospital on Merseyside since 1985. He died in May 2017 at the age of 79. The judge who sentenced Brady to life in prison described him as "wicked beyond belief". In his closing speech, the prosecutor said that Brady's crimes were "so heinous that they beggar belief". He said that Brady was a "sadistic and calculating killer" who had shown no remorse for his crimes. Brady's crimes shocked the nation and continue to haunt those who were affected by them. His death brought an end to a chapter in British criminal history, but the pain and suffering he inflicted will never be forgotten.

title: Labour's prosperity pledges for election campaign
text: Improved school standards, new NHS treatments and 100,000 apprenticeships were among six election pledges for prosperity unveiled by Carwyn Jones. He also promised free childcare and help for older people selling homes to pay for care. Announcing Welsh Labour's manifesto launch, Mr Jones said he was "proud" of the party's record. "We have always been the party of aspiration and opportunity, and we can be so again," he said. "This election is a choice between a Labour government that will work with people to create a more prosperous Wales or a Conservative government that will take us back to the failed policies of the past." Mr Jones said Labour would invest £1bn in schools to raise standards and make Wales "a world leader in education." He said: "We know that the key to our future prosperity lies in our young people." "This investment will help them fulfil their potential and give them the best possible start in life." Labour would also introduce a new 10-year NHS cancer plan, providing more treatments and support for patients. Mr Jones said: "Cancer is a terrible disease that affects so many people." "We want to give people the best possible chance of beating it, and this plan will help us to do that." The party would also create 100,000 apprenticeships, with a focus on new technologies and skills. Mr Jones said: "We need to make sure that our young people have the skills they need to compete in the modern economy." "These apprenticeships will give them the chance to earn and learn, and to build a successful future for themselves." Labour would also introduce free childcare for all three and four-year-olds, regardless of their family income. Mr Jones said: "Childcare is a huge expense for many families, and it can make it difficult for parents to work." "We want to make it easier for parents to balance their work and family life, and to give our children the best possible start in life." Finally, Labour would introduce a scheme to help older people sell their homes to pay for care. Mr Jones said: "We know that many older people are struggling to pay for care, and that can put a real strain on their finances." "This scheme would give them the option to sell their home, and to receive a lump sum that they can use to pay for their care."

title: Ulster Bank apologises as thousands unable to access money
text: It apologised for Monday evening's problems and said it would compensate anyone left out of pocket. Customers said they could not use cash machines, debit cards or access online or telephone banking. Up to 750,000 customers from RBS, Natwest, and Ulster Bank were affected by a digital banking outage that started at about 18:00 BST. Some had also reported problems accessing their accounts on Tuesday. In a statement, Ulster Bank said: "We're very sorry for the problems experienced by our customers yesterday evening and this morning. "We know how frustrating it is when you can't access your money when you need it. "We are working hard to resolve the issue as quickly as possible and we would like to reassure our customers that their money is safe." The bank said it would provide an update later on Tuesday. The outage comes at a time when many people are feeling financially stretched due to the rising cost of living. Sarah Coles, senior personal finance analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown, said: "This is the worst possible time for a banking outage. "People are already struggling to make ends meet, and not being able to access their cash or pay for things online will cause a lot of anxiety." She urged customers to contact the bank if they have been left out of pocket as a result of the outage. "The bank has promised to compensate customers, so don't be afraid to ask for what you're owed," she said. The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) said it was aware of the problems and was in contact with the banks affected. A spokesperson said: "We are aware of the issues that customers of Ulster Bank, Natwest and RBS are experiencing. "We are in contact with the banks and are monitoring the situation closely. "We expect the banks to keep their customers informed and to resolve the issue as quickly as possible."

title: Indonesia crash: Sriwijaya Air plane's flight data recorder retrieved
text: The flight data recorder was brought ashore, but the teams are still trying to locate the cockpit voice recorder. The authorities hope that data from the black boxes can give vital clues as to what caused the plane to crash into the Java Sea with 62 people on board. "The KNKT (the Indonesian Transportation Safety Committee) divers managed to locate the FDR at around 16:40 local time (09:40 GMT) at a depth of 23 metres," said Angkasa Pura II president director Muhammad Awaluddin. "The FDR has been successfully lifted to the surface and is currently being transported to the KNKT office in Jakarta." The FDR records flight data including speed, altitude, heading and engine performance. It is housed in a protective casing designed to withstand impact and fire. The cockpit voice recorder, which records all conversations and sounds in the cockpit, is still missing. It is located at the rear of the aircraft, which broke up on impact. The search for the missing black box is continuing, with the help of sonar equipment and underwater drones. The Sriwijaya Air plane crashed shortly after take-off from Jakarta on Saturday. The cause of the crash is still unknown. The plane's wreckage was found in the Java Sea, about 20km (12 miles) from the coast of Jakarta. The search and rescue operation has been hampered by bad weather and strong currents. The victims' families are waiting for news of their loved ones, and for answers about what caused the crash. The Indonesian government has promised a full investigation into the crash.

title: Victims' Code criticised by watchdog
text: Victims' Code criticised by watchdog Parliamentary Ombudsman Dame Julie Mellor said an investigation of complaints had exposed a lack of understanding. It came as ministers unveiled plans to revamp the code, which tells people what to expect from police, courts and other agencies after they have been a victim of crime. The code was introduced in April last year. Dame Julie was asked to look into it after receiving a high volume of complaints. Her report, published on Wednesday, found that complainants often did not understand the code and were not given enough information by agencies at the outset. She said victims were often forced to chase up agencies to find out about their case and that some agencies had a "narrow and minimalist" approach to the code. Dame Julie said: "I am concerned that the Victims' Code is not currently providing all victims with the information and support they have a right to expect. "The code must be made easier to understand and agencies must be given clearer guidance on how to implement it effectively. "I hope that my recommendations will help to improve the experience of victims and ensure that they are treated with the respect and compassion they deserve." Dame Julie made a number of recommendations, including: The code should be simplified and made easier to understand Agencies should provide more information to victims at the outset Agencies should be given clearer guidance on how to implement the code There should be an independent body to monitor the implementation of the code Justice Minister Sir Oliver Heald said the government was "committed to improving the experience of victims". He said: "We will carefully consider the ombudsman's recommendations and will set out our response in due course." The Victims' Code is a statutory code of practice that sets out the minimum standards of service that victims of crime should expect from criminal justice agencies. It was introduced in April 2015 and replaced the previous Code of Practice for Victims of Crime. The code covers a range of issues, including: Information and support for victims The right to make a victim personal statement The right to be kept informed about the progress of their case The right to attend court hearings The right to compensation

title: 'Affluence is factor' in tests, says 11-plus council
text: Affluence is factor' in tests, says 11-plus council By Hannah Richardson BBC News education reporter Buckinghamshire County Council's comments came in response to a school wanting to use 11-plus results to decide who gets priority on new places. The council's response said that the test "is an imperfect measure of ability" and that "it is well known that family income and wealth are closely linked with attainment at 11". This would mean that "the pupils who would most benefit from a grammar school education would be less likely to secure a place". Former education secretary Justine Greening said the claims were "a deeply depressing indictment of the current system". She said: "It's a further indication that the system is failing too many children from disadvantaged backgrounds." But a spokesman for the Grammar Schools Heads Association said there was no evidence the 11-plus "works against pupils from poorer backgrounds". He said: "In fact, there is evidence to suggest the opposite, that grammar schools help to close the attainment gap." The National Education Union believes the focus should be on improving results for all pupils, rather than creating a two-tier system. Joint general secretary Kevin Courtney said: "The NEU's position is that we do not support selective education. "We would prefer to see all schools supported and funded to improve the academic achievement of the whole school community." The debate over grammar schools has been reignited by the government's plans to open new ones. The government says that grammar schools will help to raise standards for all pupils, but critics argue that they will lead to a more segregated and unequal education system. The 11-plus is a test that is taken by children in England at the age of 11. The results of the test are used to decide which children will go to grammar schools, which are selective schools that are often seen as being the best schools in the country. The test is controversial, with some people arguing that it is unfair and that it discriminates against children from disadvantaged backgrounds.

title: Wood Group wins £100m Nexen North Sea contract
text: Under the agreement, Wood Group PSN (WGPSN) will continue to deliver operations, maintenance and technical support across Nexen's offshore assets. They include the Buzzard, Scott and Golden Eagle platforms. More than 900 offshore and onshore roles will transfer to Wood Group under the deal. Craig Shanahan, UK managing director of WGPSN, said: "This award strengthens our long-standing relationship with Nexen and demonstrates the strength of our integrated service offering. "The contract will see us continue to support Nexen's operations in the UK North Sea through the provision of our core integrated services." Nexen is a wholly owned subsidiary of CNOOC. It has been operating in the UK North Sea since 1976 and operates 20 platforms and four FPSOs in the region. The contract award comes just weeks after Wood Group announced it had secured a £200m contract with Royal Dutch Shell to provide operations and maintenance services for its Shearwater platform in the central North Sea. Wood Group has been providing services to Nexen in the UK North Sea since 2006. The new contract will extend this relationship for a further five years. The contract is a significant win for Wood Group, which has been facing challenges in recent years due to the downturn in the oil and gas industry. The company has been cutting costs and selling off non-core assets in order to improve its financial performance. The Nexen contract will provide Wood Group with a much-needed boost and help to secure the future of the company's UK operations.

title: Milk cuts campaign launched by Scottish farmers
text: It comes after Robert Wiseman, Britain's biggest fresh milk company, said it would reduce the farm-gate milk price by 1.7p a litre from 1 August. Wiseman blamed the "increasing pressure" of cheaper imported milk, with the UK seeing record levels of dairy imports in recent months. The Scottish government said it was "deeply concerned" about Wiseman's decision, and that it would "stand up for Scotland's dairy industry". "Dairy farmers are facing a significant challenge at present, with rising costs and volatile milk prices," said Rural Economy Secretary Fergus Ewing. "The Scottish government will continue to work closely with the industry to find solutions." The NFU Scotland said Wiseman's decision was a "kick in the teeth" for dairy farmers. "Dairy farmers are already operating on wafer-thin margins, and this price cut will make it even harder for them to make a living," said NFU Scotland President Andrew McCornick. "We urge Wiseman to reconsider this decision." The Scottish Milk Campaign is calling on consumers to buy Scottish milk and dairy products in a bid to support the industry. "Scottish milk is some of the best in the world, and we need to do everything we can to support our dairy farmers," said campaign coordinator Jean Lamont. "By buying Scottish milk, you can help to protect one of Scotland's most iconic industries." The campaign is also calling on the Scottish government to do more to support the dairy industry. "The Scottish government needs to step up and provide more support for our dairy farmers," said Lamont. "They could provide financial assistance, or they could introduce measures to make it easier for farmers to sell their milk at a fair price." The Scottish Milk Campaign is a coalition of organizations including the NFU Scotland, the Scottish Dairy Trade Association, and the Scottish Government.

title: Children in care 'let down for too long', says David Cameron
text: Writing in the Sunday Times, the PM promised "zero tolerance" of state failure around social care and a new covenant for those leaving care. New laws will encourage the permanent adoption of children, even if they have a history of challenging behaviour. The article was prompted by the publication of a report from the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse, which found that thousands of children were abused while in care. The inquiry concluded that the state had "failed" these children and that there was a "culture of denial" about the extent of the abuse. Cameron's article was welcomed by some campaigners, but others said it did not go far enough. The National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NSPCC) said the government needed to do more to ensure that all children in care are safe and that those who have been abused are properly supported. The NSPCC's chief executive, Peter Wanless, said: "We welcome the prime minister's commitment to 'zero tolerance' of state failure in childcare. However, we believe that the government needs to go further and commit to a national inquiry into the sexual abuse of children in care." The government has said that it will consider the inquiry's recommendations carefully. However, it is not yet clear what specific measures the government will take to improve the care of children in care. The Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Abuse was set up in 2014 to investigate child sexual abuse in England and Wales over the past 60 years. The inquiry has heard evidence from more than 7,000 victims and witnesses. The inquiry's report found that there was a "culture of denial" about the extent of child sexual abuse in care. The report also found that the state had "failed" to protect children from abuse and that there were "systemic failures" in the care system. The government has apologized for the state's failures to protect children in care. However, campaigners say that the government needs to do more to ensure that all children in care are safe and that those who have been abused are properly supported.

title: Rickmansworth man Davey Everson jailed for Millie-Rose Burdett murder
text: Davey Everson, 23, had been convicted of the murder of three-month-old Millie-Rose Burdett, who died in hospital on 11 January 2019. A judge at the Old Bailey said he must serve a minimum of 13 years and six months before being considered for release. The court heard that Everson had been in a relationship with Millie-Rose's mother, Nalini Thakor, and had been looking after the baby at their home in Rickmansworth, Hertfordshire, when she suffered a fatal head injury. Everson initially claimed that Millie-Rose had fallen off a bed, but a post-mortem examination found that she had died from blunt force trauma to the head. Everson was arrested and charged with murder in January 2019. During the trial, the jury heard that Everson had been violent towards Thakor in the past and had threatened to kill her. He had also been seen shaking Millie-Rose on a number of occasions. In his sentencing remarks, Judge Mark Lucraft QC said that Everson had shown "no remorse" for his actions and had been "utterly selfish". He said that the baby had been "vulnerable and defenceless" and that Everson had "taken her life in a moment of anger". "This was a cruel and senseless killing of a defenceless baby," Judge Lucraft said. "You have shown no remorse for your actions and you have been utterly selfish. You deserve to spend a long time in prison." Everson's sentence was welcomed by Millie-Rose's family. In a statement, they said: "We are relieved that justice has been done and that Davey Everson has been sentenced to a substantial term of imprisonment. We hope that this will send a message that violence against children will not be tolerated." The case of Millie-Rose Burdett's murder has shocked the community of Rickmansworth. Local residents have expressed their anger and sadness at the death of such a young child. A vigil was held in her memory in the town centre in January 2019. The case has also raised awareness of the issue of violence against children. The NSPCC has said that it is "horrified" by the death of Millie-Rose and has called for more to be done to protect children from harm.

title: Coronavirus: Lockdown 'could boost wild flowers'
text: Plantlife has been urging councils for years to cut grass less often. It also wants them to delay cutting until flowers have had chance to seed. The charity says it has seen signs of a change in the management of roadside verges during lockdown. On the M1 near Sheffield, a verge has been left to grow. Plantlife said that this was now a spectacular display of wildflowers. It wants to see verges like this retained on the motorway network as part of the "nature recovery network" that the government has proposed. Councils around the country have reported a surge in the number of calls they have received about people spotting wildlife in their areas. This is likely to be because people are spending more time in their local parks and green spaces during lockdown. In one park in Burnley, Lancashire, people have been surprised by the appearance of purple orchids, foxgloves and birdsfoot trefoil. A council spokesman said that the wildflowers had benefited from the reduction in the number of dog walkers and the fact that the grass had not been cut. “The wildflowers are a real joy to see,” he said. “They are a reminder of the importance of protecting our green spaces.” Plantlife is calling for a change in the way that we manage our green spaces. It wants to see a move away from the intensive mowing of verges and parks. This would allow wildflowers to flourish and create a more diverse habitat for wildlife. The charity is also urging people to plant wildflowers in their gardens. This would help to create a network of habitats for pollinators and other insects. “We need to change the way we think about wildflowers,” said Plantlife’s chief executive, Ian Dunn. “They are not just weeds. They are a vital part of our ecosystem.” The lockdown has given us a glimpse of what our green spaces could be like if we managed them differently. Let’s hope that we can learn from this experience and create a more sustainable future for our wildlife.

title: Newspaper headlines: 'Midsummer's dream' and '118 days until freedom'
text: By BBC NewsStaff "Four steps to freedom," the i declares; "118 days until freedom" is the the Daily Telegraph's headline, while the Daily Express echoes the prime minister's "One more heave" exhortation to push past the final, toughest stage of lockdown. The Times agrees, urging readers to "prepare for the final push" with a "sense of optimism and anticipation". It also carries an interview with Professor Stephen Powis, the national medical director for NHS England, who warns that the Delta variant is accounting for two-thirds of cases. Despite this, he is quoted as saying "we have every reason to be confident" that the vaccines are still effective. The Guardian warns that "new Covid cases hit five-month high", suggesting the recovery is "fragile". It also reports on the situation in Northern Ireland, where almost two-thirds of the population have had both vaccine doses. The region is to lift all remaining restrictions on July 1. The Daily Mail's headline is "Midsummer's dream", in reference to the hottest day of the year so far. It also reports on the surge in Covid cases, noting that "one in 90 Brits now has the virus". The Sun leads with the story of a group of eight men who were rescued after they got into difficulty while swimming in the sea off the Kent coast. The paper describes it as a "close call" and says the men were "lucky to be alive". The Daily Mirror has a similar story, reporting on the rescue of a family who were trapped on a sandbank. The paper says the family "could have drowned" if they had not been rescued by the RNLI. The Daily Star has a more light-hearted take on the heatwave, with the headline "Boob fryday". The paper features a picture of a topless woman sunbathing on a beach. The Independent leads with the story of the Grenfell Tower inquiry, which is due to publish its findings this week. The paper says the inquiry will "expose the failures" that led to the fire in which 72 people died.

title: Merseyside Police arrest footage reveals 'nothing short of an assault'
text: The video appears to show Nathan De Asha, owner of the Prophecy Performance Centre gym in Liverpool, being kicked while held for alleged Covid breaches. Vinny Tomlinson, De Asha's lawyer, has slammed the force's actions, calling it "nothing short of an assault." The footage, obtained by the BBC, shows De Asha being held on the ground by three officers while a fourth appears to kick him. De Asha can be heard screaming in pain. The incident took place on December 1, 2020, after police raided the gym for alleged Covid breaches. De Asha was arrested along with several others. Merseyside Police said in a statement that they were "aware of the video footage and are reviewing it." They added that they "take all allegations of misconduct seriously and will investigate them thoroughly." Tomlinson, speaking to the BBC, said that the footage was "shocking" and that it showed "a clear and blatant assault." He said that De Asha had been left with "significant injuries" and that he was considering legal action against the police. "This is a disgrace," Tomlinson said. "It's an absolute disgrace. This is what we've come to in this country? Where the police can just go around and assault people with impunity? It's not good enough." De Asha, speaking to the BBC, said that he had been "terrified" during the incident. He said that he had been doing nothing wrong and that he had been "completely compliant" with the police. "I was just trying to protect my business and my staff," De Asha said. "I didn't do anything wrong. I was just trying to do the right thing." The incident has sparked outrage among many people, including Labour MP for Liverpool Wavertree, Paula Barker. Barker said that the footage was "deeply disturbing" and that it "raises serious questions about the use of force by the police." "I am deeply concerned by the footage that I have seen," Barker said. "It is clear that Mr De Asha was the victim of an excessive use of force. I have written to the Chief Constable of Merseyside Police to demand an urgent investigation into this incident." The incident is the latest in a series of allegations of excessive force by Merseyside Police. In 2020, the force was criticized for its handling of a protest against the Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Bill. Several protesters were injured during the incident, including a woman who was knocked unconscious. Merseyside Police has defended its use of force on both occasions, saying that it was necessary to maintain public order. However, the incidents have raised concerns about the force's use of force and its accountability.

title: Moira Stuart to join Classic FM
text: She has been at the BBC for over 40 years, having briefly left in 2007 over what was perceived as an ageism row. But Moira Stuart has now joined Classic FM, where she will present a new weekend show. The former BBC Newsreader will host the show on Saturday evenings from 7pm to 10pm, playing her favourite classical music and sharing her thoughts on the pieces. Stuart said: "I am so excited to be joining Classic FM. It is a station I have long admired, and I am thrilled to be able to share my passion for classical music with its listeners." "I have always loved classical music," she added. "It has the power to move me in a way that no other music can. I am looking forward to sharing my favourite pieces with listeners and exploring the wonderful world of classical music together." Classic FM's Managing Editor, Sam Jackson, said: "We are delighted to welcome Moira Stuart to the Classic FM family. She is a broadcasting icon, and her passion for classical music is infectious." "Her new show will be a must-listen for classical music lovers, and I am sure that listeners will enjoy her insights and her unique take on the music." Stuart's departure from the BBC came after she was taken off the main evening news bulletins and replaced by younger presenters. At the time, she said she felt "discriminated against" because of her age. However, she later returned to the BBC to present a number of documentaries and specials. In recent years, Stuart has also been a vocal critic of the BBC's decision to axe its free TV licences for over-75s. She has said that the decision is "unfair" and will have a "devastating" impact on many elderly people. Stuart's new show on Classic FM will be her first regular presenting role since she left the BBC. It is set to launch on Saturday 4th September.

title: Jim Broadbent and Brenda Blethyn adapt Raymond Briggs book for BBC
text: The film will tell the autobiographical story of the couple's life through four decades of marriage from the late 1920s to the early 1970s. Broadbent and Blethyn will be joined by a host of other well-known actors, including Penelope Wilton and David Haig. Raymond Briggs is one of Britain's most celebrated and beloved children's authors and illustrators. His books, such as The Snowman, Fungus the Bogeyman, and When the Wind Blows, have sold millions of copies around the world. Broadbent and Blethyn have been married for over 30 years and have starred in several films together, including Mike Leigh's Vera Drake and Richard Curtis's Love Actually. They are both highly respected actors with a wealth of experience. The BBC adaptation of Time for Lights Out will be a major event for British television. It is a unique and ambitious project that will bring one of Raymond Briggs' most personal and moving stories to life. The film is expected to air on BBC One later this year. In an interview with the BBC, Broadbent said: "This is a very special project for us. We are both huge fans of Raymond Briggs and his work, and we are so grateful to have the opportunity to bring his story to life." Blethyn added: "Time for Lights Out is a beautiful and poignant story about love, loss, and family. We are so excited to be a part of it." The BBC's adaptation of Time for Lights Out is sure to be a must-see for fans of Raymond Briggs, Broadbent, and Blethyn. It is a film that will stay with you long after the credits have rolled.

title: Scot back in police custody in India over fresh claims
text: Jagtar Singh Johal, 30, has been in custody for a fortnight. He appeared in court early on Friday and was sent to prison until 30 November. However, he was returned to court to face new allegations. Police in the northern Indian state of Punjab have arrested him over the murders of two Hindu men. Mr Johal denies the allegations and says he has been "framed" by police. His lawyer, Jaspal Singh Manjinder, said his client was "very concerned" about the new charges. "We are going to file for bail, but the courts are closed for Diwali," he said. "We are also going to challenge the charges." Mr Johal, an engineer from Dumbarton, was arrested on 4 November while visiting his family in Punjab. He was initially charged with sedition and terrorism offences, but police have now added murder to the charges. Mr Johal's family and supporters say he is a human rights activist who has been targeted by police because of his work. They have called for his immediate release. The Indian government has said that Mr Johal is a terrorist who has been involved in violence in Punjab. The British government has said it is "concerned" about Mr Johal's case and has called for a fair trial. The case has sparked protests in the UK and India. On Thursday, around 100 people gathered outside the Indian High Commission in London to demand Mr Johal's release. Mr Johal's arrest has also been condemned by human rights groups. Amnesty International has said that his arrest is "arbitrary" and that he should be released immediately. Human Rights Watch has said that the charges against Mr Johal are "baseless" and that he is being held in "inhumane conditions".

title: Russians fly orphan bear to new life
text: By News from Elsewhere...as found by BBC Monitoring Villagers in the far eastern Kamchatka Peninsula found the starving 10-month-old roaming their freezing streets last month, crying out for food. Locals tried to care for the animal, which they named Venza, but realised he needed specialist treatment. A local resident contacted the Kamchatka animal welfare group Wild Rescue Centre and founder Viktoria Ignatieva travelled 120km (75 miles) from the regional capital Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky to collect the bear. She told the BBC's Russian service that at first she didn't want to get involved. "We don't work with bears," she said. "But then I heard his screams." Viktoria said Venza was very weak and was having trouble feeding because his teeth had not fully developed. He was dehydrated, malnourished and had wounds on his paws. She was able to find a sponsor who would pay for the bear's flight to Moscow, where he could receive specialist care at the Wildlife Rehabilitation Centre. She then had to wait for several days for permission from the authorities to transport the bear. Viktoria took the opportunity to buy baby food and a bottle with a small teat, which the bear accepted immediately. "It was difficult to feed him, he was too weak," she said. "After a few hours he was already sleeping on his tummy and dreaming." Venza's welfare flight was part of a joint initiative from the Wild Rescue Centre and Russian airline S7. The flight attendant monitored Venza throughout the journey, stroking his head and giving him baby food. Venza is now recovering at the Moscow wildlife centre, where he is being introduced to berries and vegetables. The centre's director, Vladimir Burdachevsky, described him as "very sweet". "It's sad that he lost his mother," he said. "But he is in good hands and we will do everything we can to prepare him for life in the wild." Venza is expected to stay at the centre for up to a year. He will then be released into a protected area in the Russian Far East. Viktoria said: "We're already thinking about his life in the wild. He has to be ready to live alone. He will be under the supervision of the Kamchatka Natural Resources Ministry, using a GPS tracker." She added: "It's the first time in Russia that an orphaned bear cub has been rescued and we hope it sends out the message that we should all care about the wild animals who share this planet with us."

title: Are farmers getting the mental health support they need?
text: But a charity which helps farmers and rural families in Northern Ireland says there's been a 25% increase in the number of farmers calling them. Rural Support chief executive Colleen Scullion said in recent months farmers have been increasingly squeezed financially, with rising costs of machinery, fertiliser and feed. "They've never seen those figures before. They've never had to make such difficult decisions on a daily basis," she said. "In turn, it's giving them a lot of stress. It's giving them a lot of sleepless nights." Colleen Scullion says rising costs of machinery, fertiliser and feed are putting farmers under a lot of stress The charity has a 24/7 helpline and offers counselling for farmers and their families. Colleen Scullion said they are hearing from more farmers with mental health issues than ever before. "We would be concerned that, you know, this winter will be particularly difficult for the farming community," she added. "And it's really important that we continue to raise awareness. It's OK to talk about mental health. "It's important that farmers realise that they're not alone and that there is help out there if they need it." The Ulster Farmers' Union (UFU) is also urging farmers to seek help if they're struggling with their mental health. UFU president Victor Chestnutt said: "Farming can be a very isolating job. You can be working long hours on your own, and it can be difficult to talk about your problems. "But it's important to remember that you're not alone. There are people out there who can help." The UFU has a range of support services available to farmers, including a counselling service and a helpline. Victor Chestnutt said: "We would encourage any farmer who is struggling with their mental health to reach out for help. "There is no shame in asking for help. It's a sign of strength, not weakness." If you're a farmer and you're struggling with your mental health, there is help available. You can contact Rural Support on 0845 600 0123 or visit their website at www.ruralsupport.org.uk. You can also contact the Ulster Farmers' Union on 028 9037 0222 or visit their website at www.ufuni.org.

title: Coronavirus: Extra testing in Pendle to stop virus spread
text: The area in east Lancashire was second highest for new cases in England last week, according to public health stats. "There has been a concerning increase in the number of Covid-19 cases in recent weeks," said Dr Sakthi Karunanithi, the county council's director of public health. "This is a worrying development and we are working closely with our partners to do everything we can to bring this situation under control." Pendle Council said the rise in cases was likely due to a number of factors, including an increase in social mixing and the emergence of new variants of the virus. "We know that this is a difficult time for everyone," said Councillor Mohammed Iqbal, leader of Pendle Council. "But it is vital that we all follow the rules and do everything we can to stop the spread of this virus." As part of the increased testing in Pendle, the council has opened a new walk-in testing centre at the Marsden Hall Leisure Centre in Nelson. "The extra testing will help us to identify more cases quickly, and to isolate them quickly," said Dr Karunanithi. "This will help to break the transmission chain and to help us to get the virus under control." In addition to the increased testing, the council is also urging people to follow the national lockdown rules, which include staying at home, only meeting one other person from outside your household, and wearing face masks in public places. "We know that the lockdown restrictions are tough, but they are essential to help us to control the spread of the virus," said Councillor Iqbal. "We all have a responsibility to do our part to protect our communities." The council is also working with schools and businesses in the area to ensure that they are following the rules and to provide them with support. "We are all in this together," said Dr Karunanithi. "By working together, we can help to stop the spread of this virus and get back to normal."

title: Norman Baker: EU would slow down 'legal highs' fight
text: By Justin Parkinson Political reporter, BBC News The Liberal Democrat told a parliamentary committee the UK was already in a "stronger position" than most states, as it had flexibility to act act quickly. The coalition has banned more than 50 so-called legal highs since coming to power in 2010, with a further 10 substances set to be added to the list by the end of the year. But Mr Baker said the UK could do more and that he was "disappointed" the EU had blocked plans for a European-wide ban on psychoactive substances. "I think we'd be in a stronger position as a country if we weren't part of that process," he said. "We could go ahead with what we were planning and ban these things more quickly than we are able to at the moment." The European Commission, the EU's executive arm, has said it is not convinced that a ban is the best way to tackle the problem. It has instead proposed a "balanced" approach which would include monitoring the market, providing information and support to users, and encouraging research. The commission's position has been backed by some experts, who argue that a ban could simply drive the market underground and make it more difficult to control. But Mr Baker said he was not convinced by these arguments. "I think the evidence suggests that a ban can be effective in reducing the availability of these substances," he said. "And I think it's important to send a clear message that these substances are not acceptable." The Home Office has said it is "disappointed" by the EU's decision, but that it will continue to work with other countries to tackle the problem. The government has also said it will continue to ban new psychoactive substances as they emerge. In the meantime, Mr Baker said he would be looking at ways to "speed up" the process of banning these substances. "I think we need to be more proactive in this area," he said. "We need to be doing everything we can to protect people from these dangerous substances."

title: British Legion calls for more research into Gulf War illnesses
text: Over 33,000 former soldiers are thought to suffer from illnesses related to their service such as chronic headaches, fatigue and memory problems. The charity said too little was known about the condition and called for more research into the link between the illnesses and the drugs they were taking. The British Legion said the government had not done enough to investigate the illnesses and called for a public inquiry. The charity's director of welfare, Ian Blackford, said: "We believe that the government has not done enough to investigate these illnesses and we are calling for a public inquiry. "We need to know what caused these illnesses and what can be done to help those who are suffering. We also need to ensure that lessons are learned so that this does not happen again." The Ministry of Defence said it was committed to supporting veterans who have served their country and that it was working with the British Legion to improve understanding of Gulf War illnesses. A spokesperson said: "We are committed to supporting veterans who have served their country and we are working with the British Legion to improve understanding of Gulf War illnesses. "We have invested in research into the condition and we are working to ensure that veterans have access to the best possible care." The British Legion's call for a public inquiry comes after a number of high-profile cases of veterans suffering from Gulf War illnesses. In 2019, the BBC reported on the case of Corporal Diane Allen, who died from a rare form of cancer after serving in the Gulf War. Allen's family believe that her cancer was caused by her exposure to depleted uranium, which is used in armor-piercing shells. The Ministry of Defence has denied any link between depleted uranium and Gulf War illnesses. The British Legion's call for a public inquiry is likely to be met with resistance from the government. The government has previously said that there is no evidence to support the claim that Gulf War illnesses are caused by exposure to depleted uranium.

title: Dale Farm eviction: 'Show of force designed to shock'
text: By Julian Sturdy BBC East The police, the travellers were told, would only be there to maintain the peace and prevent criminality. But, they said, they had broken no laws. So why, they asked, were there 4,000 police officers, many in riot gear, backed up by water cannon and a helicopter? "We're not moving and we don't know why they're here," said Kathleen McCarthy, who along with her husband John has lived at Dale Farm for 20 years. "We feel let down. We are being treated like animals." The community living on the Dale Farm site, just off the A12 in Essex, felt they had been given reassurances that they would not face immediate eviction. But on Wednesday, 19 October, the police moved in. Travellers have long complained that they face prejudice and discrimination, but they say the way they have been treated at Dale Farm is unprecedented. "We are not criminals," said Mary Sheridan, who came to Dale Farm with her family eight years ago. "We have done nothing wrong." The travellers say they are simply trying to live a traditional way of life. "We're not asking for much," said Kathleen McCarthy. "We don't want to be millionaires. We just want to live a quiet life." But the authorities say that the Dale Farm site is illegal and that the travellers have ignored repeated court orders to leave. The eviction, which is expected to take several days, is the largest of its kind in British history. The police have said that they are using "proportionate and necessary force" to ensure that the eviction is carried out safely and without violence. But the travellers say that the police are using excessive force. "They're treating us like we're animals," said Mary Sheridan. "They're trying to scare us into leaving." The travellers have vowed to stay put. "We're not going to give up without a fight," said Kathleen McCarthy. "We're going to make them drag us out." The eviction of Dale Farm is a complex and controversial issue. The travellers say they are being unfairly targeted, while the authorities say they are simply enforcing the law. The outcome of the eviction will have far-reaching implications for the future of traveller communities in the UK.

title: Venezuela ex-prosecutor: I have proof of Maduro corruption
text: Luisa Ortega also accused two party leaders and the new prosecutor. Ms Ortega, who fled Venezuela last week after she was sacked and her husband was jailed, claimed that Maduro had created a network of corruption and extortion to line his own pockets. She said he had set up "frontmen and strawmen" who had made "millions of dollars" from overcharging the state for government contracts and then laundering the money through foreign banks. She said she had already spoken to the ICC's chief prosecutor, Fatou Bensouda, and that she was "confident" that the court would open an investigation. The Venezuelan government has dismissed Ortega's allegations as "baseless" and "politically motivated." Maduro has accused her of being a "traitor" and a "criminal" who is trying to destabilize the country. Ortega's allegations are likely to further damage Maduro's already fragile credibility. He has been under increasing pressure from both within and outside Venezuela to step down, and his approval ratings have plummeted in recent months. If the ICC does open an investigation into Maduro, it would be a major blow to his presidency and could lead to his eventual downfall. The ICC is a court of last resort that investigates and prosecutes individuals for genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, and the crime of aggression. Ortega's allegations are likely to be welcomed by the Venezuelan opposition, which has been calling for Maduro to step down for months. The opposition has been struggling to regain momentum in recent months, but Ortega's allegations could give them a new lease of life. The Venezuelan government has accused Ortega of being part of a "coup attempt" and has said that she will be arrested if she returns to the country. However, Ortega has said that she is not afraid of being arrested and that she will continue to fight for justice in Venezuela.

title: Tesla's Elon Musk may be in contempt over tweet
text: His comments came after the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) asked the courts to hold him in contempt for violating a settlement aimed at limiting his social media comments. The rule, agreed to by Musk in 2018, requires him to have his tweets pre-approved by a lawyer if they contain information that could affect Tesla's stock price. Musk's defiance is the latest in a series of clashes with the SEC, which has accused him of repeatedly misleading investors. In 2018, Musk tweeted that he had secured funding to take Tesla private, causing the company's stock price to spike. The SEC subsequently charged Musk with fraud, and he settled with the agency without admitting or denying wrongdoing. As part of the settlement, Musk agreed to step down as Tesla's chairman for three years and pay a $20 million fine. He also agreed to have his tweets pre-approved by a lawyer if they contained information that could affect Tesla's stock price. However, Musk has repeatedly violated the agreement, tweeting about Tesla's production goals, financial performance, and other topics without seeking pre-approval. In September 2022, he tweeted that Tesla would sell "about 50%" more cars in 2023 than it did in 2022. The SEC has accused Musk of misleading investors with this tweet, as Tesla's production and delivery numbers have fallen short of his projections. Musk's latest comments come as the SEC is investigating whether he violated the settlement again by tweeting about Tesla's planned stock split. On April 5, 2023, Musk tweeted that Tesla would split its stock in a 3-for-1 ratio. The SEC is now investigating whether Musk had proper approval for this tweet, as it could have affected Tesla's stock price. If the SEC finds that Musk violated the settlement, he could face a range of penalties, including fines, imprisonment, or being barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company. The SEC could also seek to appoint a monitor to oversee Musk's compliance with the settlement. Musk's defiance of the SEC is a sign of his growing frustration with the agency. He has repeatedly accused the SEC of overreach and has said that he does not believe that he needs to comply with its rules. Musk's behavior is likely to further strain his relationship with the SEC and could lead to more legal challenges.

title: Dundee University to tackle hepatitis in Tayside drug users
text: Working alongside NHS Tayside, researchers hope to reduce the number of hepatitis C infections by targeting drug users at an early stage. Hepatitis C is a blood-borne virus which can cause serious liver damage.  The new project at Dundee University will involve running two screening clinics in the city, offering testing to drug users who are not already receiving treatment. The study team will also carry out focus groups and interviews with drug users to understand their knowledge, attitudes and behaviours related to hepatitis C. This work will help researchers to develop more effective ways to engage with and support this population. Hepatitis C is a major public health concern in Tayside, with an estimated 1,200 people living with the condition. The virus is spread through contact with infected blood, and can be transmitted through injecting drug use, sharing needles and equipment, or having unprotected sex with an infected person. Around 20% of people with hepatitis C will go on to develop serious liver damage, including cirrhosis and liver cancer. There is no vaccine for hepatitis C, but treatment can be very effective in preventing the development of serious liver disease. Professor Chris Newman, who is leading the study, said: "Hepatitis C is a serious condition, but it is one that can be prevented and treated. We know that drug users are at high risk of infection, but many of them are not aware of their status. This project will allow us to reach out to this population and offer them testing and support." The study is funded by the Medical Research Council and will run for three years. The research team hope that the findings will help to inform future public health policy and improve the care of drug users in Tayside. In addition to the screening clinics, the research team will also be working with local drug services to raise awareness of hepatitis C and to promote testing. They will also be developing new educational resources for drug users and healthcare professionals. The project is part of a wider effort by NHS Tayside to tackle hepatitis C in the region. The health board has already introduced a number of measures to improve testing and treatment for hepatitis C, including offering free testing to all drug users and providing access to new antiviral treatments.

title: The heartbreak of watching the slow death of ash trees
text: At primary school I remember learning how to identify trees by their leaves or bark. The one I was most interested in spotting was the ash, with its distinctive black bark and diamond-shaped leaves. It was the tree we built dens in, climbed to the highest branches, and swung from on long ropes tied to low-hanging limbs. As an adult, I was lucky enough to spend much of my childhood in the countryside, where towering ash trees were everywhere. I would play in woodland, surrounded by their elegant trunks, and marvel at their ability to soar so high into the sky. The ash was a symbol of strength and resilience, a constant in my life. But over the past few years, I have watched with increasing sadness as ash trees have fallen victim to a devastating disease called ash dieback. Caused by a fungus spread by wind and insects, it has decimated ash populations across Europe since it was first identified in the UK in 2012. The fungus infects the leaves of ash trees, causing them to turn brown and die back. In the early stages, the tree may only lose a few leaves, but as the disease progresses, it will spread throughout the canopy, eventually leading to the tree's death. I have seen firsthand the devastation that ash dieback can cause. In one woodland near my home, I have watched as row after row of ash trees have been felled, leaving behind a barren landscape. The once-vibrant green canopy is now a patchwork of brown and grey, and the sound of birdsong has been replaced by an eerie silence. It is not just the loss of the trees themselves that is so heartbreaking. Ash trees are home to a wide variety of wildlife, including insects, birds, and mammals. The loss of these trees will have a ripple effect throughout the ecosystem, affecting everything from the food chain to the water cycle. I know that there is no easy solution to ash dieback. The fungus is highly contagious, and there is no known cure. However, there is still hope. Scientists are working on developing resistant ash trees, and there are a number of things we can do to slow the spread of the disease. We can avoid moving infected plant material, clean our shoes and equipment after visiting infected areas, and plant new ash trees in areas where they are less likely to be exposed to the fungus. By working together, we can help to protect our ash trees and ensure that they continue to be a part of our landscape for many years to come.

title: Criminal injury compensation cuts to be reconsidered
text: The Ministry of Justice (MoJ) had wanted to restrict payments from the Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme to those suffering serious injuries. But an MoJ spokesman said: "We recognise the strong feelings about this issue and we want to reassure people that no decisions have been made. We are committed to supporting victims of crime and are looking carefully at all the evidence before making any decisions." The MoJ's original proposals would have meant that only those who had suffered a "serious physical or mental injury" would be eligible for compensation. This would have excluded people who had suffered less serious injuries, such as broken bones or bruising. The proposals were met with widespread criticism from victims' groups and lawyers. They argued that the changes would have left many victims of crime without adequate support. The Victims' Commissioner for England and Wales, Dame Vera Baird, said: "These proposals are a betrayal of victims of crime. They would deny compensation to thousands of people who have suffered real harm." The Law Society, which represents solicitors, said: "The government's proposals are a retrograde step. They would leave many victims of crime without the financial support they need to rebuild their lives." The government's decision to reconsider the proposals is a welcome victory for victims' groups. However, it is important to note that no decisions have been made and the MoJ could still decide to implement the changes in the future. In the meantime, victims of crime are advised to continue to apply for compensation under the current scheme. The scheme is open to anyone who has been physically or mentally injured as a result of a crime. To apply for compensation, victims must complete a claim form and submit it to the Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority (CICA). The CICA will then assess the claim and decide whether to award compensation. The amount of compensation awarded will depend on the severity of the injuries suffered. The maximum amount of compensation that can be awarded is £500,000. Victims of crime can also claim for loss of earnings, medical expenses, and other expenses. The CICA can also provide support services, such as counselling and therapy.

title: Harry Uzoka death: Three guilty of killing London model
text: George Koh, 24, stabbed fellow model Harry Uzoka in the heart after he went to settle the dispute, accompanied by two friends on 11 January last year. Koh, Jonathan Okigbo, 25, and Merse Dikanda, 25, were unanimously found guilty of murder at the Old Bailey on Friday. Uzoka, 25, was killed in Shepherd's Bush, west London, after he intervened in a row between Okigbo and his girlfriend, Blessing Douglas. The court heard that Uzoka and Koh had been friends, but they had fallen out after Koh allegedly made unwanted advances towards Douglas. On the night of the murder, Uzoka went to the flat where the row was taking place with two friends, Elliott Johnson and Adrian Harper. Koh, Okigbo and Dikanda were outside the flat when Uzoka and his friends arrived. A fight broke out, and Koh stabbed Uzoka in the chest. Uzoka was taken to hospital, but he died a short time later. Koh, Okigbo and Dikanda all denied murder, claiming they acted in self-defence. However, the jury rejected their claims and found them guilty of murder. Detective Chief Inspector Jim Eastwood, who led the investigation, said: "This was a senseless and tragic death of a young man who had his whole life ahead of him. "Harry Uzoka was a popular and well-respected member of the community, and his death has been a huge loss to his family and friends. "The defendants have shown no remorse for their actions, and they deserve to spend a long time in prison." Uzoka's family said in a statement: "Harry was a kind and loving son, brother and friend. He was taken from us far too soon, and we will never get over his loss. "We want to thank the police and the CPS for their hard work in bringing the defendants to justice. "We hope that this verdict will bring some closure to our family and friends, and that Harry's memory will live on."

title: Foster carers' concern for children's welfare with cuts
text: Nationwide Association of Fostering Providers (NAFP) said the Welsh government consortium which buys their services is looking to renegotiate their contracts. "The situation in Wales is that we have got the local authorities, that is the commissioners, who have got contracts with the NAFP membership and their concern is that the local authorities will turn around and say 'You've got to take a cut in your fees'," he said. "And the providers will say 'we can't afford that because we're already making a loss'. And that's where we are at the moment. "It's early days but there are concerns about the way forward." The Welsh government said it was committed to supporting foster carers and that it would work with the NAFP to ensure that they are fairly rewarded. "We are aware of the concerns raised by the NAFP and we will be working with them to ensure that foster carers are fairly rewarded for the important work they do," a Welsh government spokesperson said. "We are committed to supporting foster carers and we will continue to work with the NAFP to ensure that they have the resources they need to provide a high quality service." The NAFP has called for a review of the way foster care is funded in Wales. "We believe that the current system is not sustainable and that it is putting the welfare of children at risk," Mr Sutton said. "We are calling for a review of the way foster care is funded in Wales and we are calling for a fairer deal for foster carers." The Welsh government said it would consider the NAFP's request for a review. "We will consider the NAFP's request for a review of the way foster care is funded in Wales," the Welsh government spokesperson said. "We are committed to ensuring that foster carers are fairly rewarded for the important work they do and we will continue to work with the NAFP to ensure that they have the resources they need to provide a high quality service."

text: Forty-nine people in four boats were met by Border Force and brought to England, while a further two boats were dealt with by French authorities. A Border Force cutter escorted the vessel to Dover, where the people on board were taken into the care of the Home Office. title: UK 'needs more bureaucrats for Brexit', says ex-diplomat
text: Sir Simon Fraser was a trade negotiator in Europe and permanent under-secretary at the Foreign Office until July 2015. "I don't think we can avoid an increase in bureaucracy," he said, "because there are more regulations that we will have to manage ourselves in the future that were previously managed at EU level." The UK will need to recruit thousands more bureaucrats to manage Brexit, according to a former diplomat. Sir Simon Fraser said the UK will need to "scale up" its civil service to handle the extra workload created by leaving the EU. The UK is currently negotiating its exit from the EU, and the government has said it will leave the single market and customs union. This will mean that the UK will have to create its own regulations for a range of areas, including trade, immigration, and environmental protection. Fraser said the UK will need to increase the size of its civil service to manage the extra workload. He said the UK will need to recruit "thousands" of new bureaucrats, and that the government should start recruiting now. "I think we need to start planning for this now," he said. "We need to start recruiting and training people now." The government has said it is committed to reducing the size of the civil service, and has set a target of cutting 91,000 jobs by 2020. However, Fraser said the government will need to make an exception for Brexit. "I think the government will have to make an exception for Brexit," he said. "This is a one-off event, and we need to make sure that we have the resources in place to manage it." The government has not said how many new bureaucrats it will need to recruit for Brexit. However, the Institute for Government has estimated that the UK will need to recruit between 10,000 and 20,000 new civil servants. The government has said it is committed to increasing the diversity of the civil service, and that it will make sure that the new bureaucrats it recruits are representative of the UK population. "We need to make sure that we have a civil service that is representative of the UK population," a government spokesperson said. The government is expected to announce its plans for recruiting new bureaucrats for Brexit in the coming months.

title: Easyjet wants more women in the cockpit
text: By Rebecca Marston Business reporter, BBC News The Amy Johnson initiative, named after the first female pilot to fly solo from the UK to Australia, prompted 1,200 applications from women - a quarter of the total. The airline wants to address the gender imbalance in the industry. Currently, only 5% of the world's commercial airline pilots are women. EasyJet has set a target of recruiting 200 female pilots by 2020. Johan Lundgren, chief executive of easyJet, said: "We have a problem with gender diversity in our industry... "We want to inspire the next generation of female pilots." The airline has also launched its own programme to help women from under-represented backgrounds break into the industry. The scheme, called 'Women in the Cockpit', will provide mentoring, networking opportunities and financial support to women who want to become pilots. EasyJet's initiatives are part of a wider effort by the aviation industry to address the gender imbalance. In 2016, the International Air Transport Association (IATA) launched its 25by2025 campaign, which aims to increase the number of women in the air transport industry by 25% by 2025. The campaign has been endorsed by a number of airlines, including British Airways, Lufthansa and Delta Air Lines. Despite these efforts, the number of women in the aviation industry remains low. According to IATA, women make up only 2% of airline pilots and 3% of airline engineers. There are a number of reasons for the gender imbalance in the aviation industry. One reason is that women are under-represented in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields. Another reason is that the aviation industry has a long history of being a male-dominated environment. However, there is a growing recognition that the aviation industry needs to change. The industry is losing out on talent by not attracting more women. A more diverse workforce would also lead to a more balanced and inclusive workplace. title: Ashya King 'not receiving chemotherapy'
text: By David Fenton Health correspondent, BBC South Today His father said he did not need it as the tumour was now "in remission". But a leading UK cancer expert has said, without chemotherapy, children's chances of survival could be reduced. Ashya King, five, was diagnosed with a brain tumour in September 2013. He and his family travelled to Prague for proton beam therapy - a form of radiotherapy - amid a dispute over his treatment with Southampton Children's Hospital. Following the therapy, his father Brett said the tumour was in remission and Ashya would not undergo any further chemotherapy. But Professor Karol Sikora, an independent cancer expert, said not continuing chemotherapy risked a "significant" reduction in Ashya's chance of survival. "We do know that for a brain tumour of this type, the risk of relapse is high - about 60 to 70%," he said. "Therefore without chemotherapy the risk of dying is significantly increased. "If the family interrupt the treatment, I would think that his chances of survival will be reduced because the most effective treatment for this type of cancer is chemotherapy." However Ashya's father has defended his decision. Brett King said his son "did not need" chemotherapy and said: "The tumour is in remission. It's gone." He said the family's decision to refuse chemotherapy was based on "all the information available". "There are various treatments for this particular tumour, some of which include chemotherapy and some of which don't," he said. "All these treatments come with their own toxicities and risks. This treatment has been going on for quite a long time. Ashya's had over six months of treatment. Our family are looking forward to it being over." Ashya was treated with chemotherapy in Southampton before he left the UK. Professor Sikora said the hospital would have "sound reasons" for recommending chemotherapy. "It's difficult to understand why they have changed their mind," he said. "I think they've been given a lot of incorrect information on the internet... about the potential side-effects of chemotherapy and the benefits of proton beam therapy." A spokesman for Southampton Children's Hospital said: "We have a duty of care to all our patients and will therefore continue to take the necessary steps to ensure Ashya receives all the treatment recommended by his doctors."

title: Google v Oracle: Supreme Court declares Google's code copying fair
text: Oracle, another tech titan, had sued Google in 2010 for copyright infringement over what it said was copied computer code. Android is now used in an estimated 70% of the world's smartphones, so even a small percentage of licensing fees would have amounted to billions of dollars. The Supreme Court decision was a victory for Google, but it could have implications for other copyright cases involving software and technology. It could also make it harder for companies to sue each other for copyright infringement. The court's decision was based on a fair use doctrine, which allows for the limited use of copyrighted material without permission from the copyright holder. The court found that Google's use of Oracle's code was a fair use because it was transformative, meaning that it created a new and different work that did not compete with Oracle's original work. The court also found that Google's use of Oracle's code was not commercial, even though Android is a commercial product. The court said that Google did not use Oracle's code to make a profit, but rather to create a new and innovative operating system. The Supreme Court's decision is a significant victory for Google and other companies that use copyrighted material in their products. It could make it easier for companies to defend themselves against copyright infringement lawsuits, and it could also lead to more innovation in the technology industry. However, the decision is also likely to be controversial. Some copyright holders may argue that it makes it too easy for companies to use their work without permission. The decision could also lead to more litigation, as companies try to determine what uses of copyrighted material are fair and what uses are not. Despite the potential for controversy, the Supreme Court's decision is a significant development in copyright law. It could have a major impact on the way that companies use copyrighted material in their products, and it could also lead to more innovation in the technology industry.
