title: Sri Lankan rights campaigner Jayalath Jayawardena dies
text: By Charles Haviland BBC News, Colombo He had a recent history of heart disease. Dr Jayawardena was a stalwart of the main opposition United National Party. He became well-known for his staunch defence of basic freedoms under both Mr Rajapaksa's presidency and its successor, led by Maithripala Sirisena. Mr Sirisena appointed Dr Jayawardena to head the Human Rights Commission, a role he had held since 2016. However, the government faced criticism for alleged inaction on human rights, and the commission was accused of failing to investigate properly allegations of abuse. In an interview with the BBC in 2018, Dr Jayawardena said: "The government has appointed me. I'm not accountable to any political party. People can criticise me as much as they want. I have a job to do." He also argued that Sri Lanka's human rights record had "vastly improved" since the end of the war. "The Rajapaksa regime considered any form of dissent as terrorism - and cracked down heavily. There's been a complete change when you compare that to what happened in the past," he said. However, he continued to criticise what he saw as a lack of accountability for war crimes committed during the final stages of the conflict. In 2019, he said that Sri Lanka was not cooperating fully with an international investigation into alleged human rights abuses during the war. Dr Jayawardena was born in Colombo in 1947 and studied in the UK at Oxford University. He worked as an academic and a human rights lawyer before entering politics. He joined the United National Party in 1994 and was elected to parliament two years later. He held several ministerial posts in the governments of President Chandrika Kumaratunga and Ranil Wickremesinghe. Dr Jayawardena was a strong advocate for a negotiated settlement to the Sri Lankan civil war, which ended in 2009. He also played a key role in the drafting of the country's new constitution, which was passed in 2017. News of Dr Jayawardena's death has been met with an outpouring of grief from across the political spectrum. President Gotabaya Rajapaksa said in a statement that Dr Jayawardena had served the country with "dedication and commitment". Opposition leader Sajith Premadasa said Dr Jayawardena was a "true champion of human rights". The UN Resident Coordinator in Sri Lanka, Hanaa Singer-Hamdy, said Dr Jayawardena was "an advocate for human dignity and rights". "His principled leadership will be deeply missed," she said.

title: Alexander Vindman, witness 'bullied by Trump', quits US military
text: Lt Col Alexander Vindman was the victim of a "campaign of bullying, intimidation and retaliation" by the president, his lawyer said. Lt Col Vindman's "concern" over a phone call between Mr Trump and Ukraine's president led to his removal from his White House role last year and he quit the US military on Wednesday. In a statement his lawyer said he had been subjected to "false attacks" and "innuendo" since he testified to Congress about the call. He said Lt Col Vindman had "honourably served this country" and was "forced out because he was inconvenient to the president". The White House has denied the claims. Lt Col Vindman, who was born in Ukraine, was a key witness in the impeachment inquiry into Mr Trump. He testified that he had been concerned about the president's request that Ukraine investigate his political rival, Joe Biden. After his testimony, Mr Trump called Lt Col Vindman a "Never Trumper" and suggested he had dual loyalties. Lt Col Vindman's lawyer said the president's attacks had taken a toll on his client. "Lt Col Vindman has been the subject of relentless, unfounded attacks by the President of the United States," he said. "These attacks have caused significant harm to his career and reputation, and have created a hostile work environment for him." He said Lt Col Vindman had "honourably served this country" and was "forced out because he was inconvenient to the president". The White House has denied the claims. Lt Col Vindman's resignation comes as Mr Trump is facing a new impeachment inquiry, this time over allegations that he pressured Ukraine to investigate Mr Biden. Lt Col Vindman's lawyer said his client's resignation was a "sad reminder" that "patriotism and loyalty are not rewarded in this administration".

title: Birmingham stabbings: Family tribute to Jacob Billington
text: Mr Billington was attacked in Irving Street in the early hours of Sunday while he was out with old school friends, police said. He was rushed to hospital but died a short time later. His family spoke of their devastation in a statement released through West Midlands Police. They said: "We are all absolutely devastated by Jacob's death. He was a loving son, brother, grandson and friend and his life has been cruelly cut short. "He was out with his friends enjoying himself when he was attacked. We cannot understand why anyone would want to harm him. "Jacob was a gentle and kind-hearted young man who had his whole life ahead of him. He will be deeply missed by all who knew him." A 23-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder and remains in police custody. Detective Inspector Laura Harrison, from West Midlands Police's homicide unit, said: "This was a senseless and tragic attack on a young man who was simply enjoying a night out with his friends. "Our thoughts are with Jacob's family and friends at this difficult time. We are determined to find out who is responsible for his death and bring them to justice." Anyone with information is asked to contact West Midlands Police via Live Chat at www.west-midlands.police.uk, via 101, or Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111. Knife crime has been a major issue in Birmingham in recent years. In 2021, there were 12 fatal stabbings in the city, the highest number in a decade. The West Midlands Police and Crime Commissioner, Simon Foster, has said that tackling knife crime is a "top priority" for the force. He said: "Knife crime is a scourge on our communities and we are determined to do everything we can to tackle it. "We are working closely with the police, schools and community groups to raise awareness of the dangers of knife crime and to provide support to those who are at risk of being involved in it." The government has also pledged to take action on knife crime. In 2021, the Home Secretary, Priti Patel, announced a £30 million fund to tackle knife crime in six cities, including Birmingham. The fund will be used to provide support for young people who are at risk of being involved in knife crime, and to provide more resources for the police to tackle knife crime.

title: Slovakian 'slave' trafficked to Burnley for marriage
text: The Romany victim's account of being handled as a "human slave" read like "something from a 19th century novel by Dickens", Preston Crown Court heard. She described being trafficked from Slovakia to the UK at the age of 20, under the false promise of a job as a cleaner. Upon arriving in Burnley, she was forced into a sham marriage with a local man, who then subjected her to years of violence and exploitation. The victim testified that she was treated like a "possession," with her movements and communication strictly controlled. She was forced to clean the house, cook the meals, and perform sexual acts on demand. Any attempts to resist were met with severe beatings and threats of violence. "I was like a prisoner in my own home," she told the court. "I couldn't go anywhere or speak to anyone without his permission. I was terrified of him." The victim's ordeal only ended when she managed to escape and seek help from the police. Her trafficker, a 37-year-old man from Burnley, was subsequently arrested and charged with modern slavery, rape, and false imprisonment. Prosecutor Lisa Worsley told the court that the case highlighted the "hidden and insidious" nature of modern slavery in the UK. She said that victims are often isolated and vulnerable, and may be reluctant to come forward for fear of reprisals. "This case is a reminder that slavery is not just something that happens in far-off countries," she said. "It can happen anywhere, even in our own communities." The victim's testimony has had a profound impact on the jury, who have heard harrowing details of her suffering. The trial is ongoing, and the defendant denies all charges.

title: UK to Zuckerberg: Show us you're sincere about regulation
text: Rory Cellan-Jones Technology correspondent @BBCRoryCJon Twitter But now the UK's information commissioner has asked him to take action to show he means what he says. Elizabeth Denham has told Facebook to drop its appeal against the £500,000 ($655,000) fine she imposed for failing to protect the data of people who used the This is My Digital Life app. She said the public would struggle to trust Facebook's commitment to privacy and transparency if it continued to challenge the fine. "The ICO [Information Commissioner's Office] wants to see Facebook put its words into action. There needs to be a meaningful shift in Facebook's privacy and data protection practices so that people are empowered and protected," she said. "To create that shift, we expect Facebook to drop its appeal with immediate effect and start engaging meaningfully to bring its practices in line with the law." So far, Facebook has given no indication that it intends to drop its appeal. In fact, it issued a statement suggesting that it was even less willing to change its privacy policies. The company said that while it shared the ICO's goal to protect people's data, it had "fundamentally disagreed with the ICO's approach" to the case. "We believe the ICO's investigation and decision in this case was flawed, and we intend to appeal," it said. "We appreciate the ICO's recognition that protecting privacy and data is important and share that goal, but we believe the ICO's investigation and decision in this case was flawed and we intend to appeal." If it does lose the appeal, the company could face a fine of up to 4% of its global turnover - or about £1.5bn. But there are many people who question whether even this would be enough to force the company to change its ways. "Facebook is an unstoppable juggernaut that is out of control and Mark Zuckerberg will do nothing to change that, no matter how much money he is fined," said Julian McQuillan, a security researcher who is now chief executive of security firm Tenable. "He has made it very clear that Facebook's mission is to connect people and he will not be deterred from that, because he believes that he is doing something good for the world."

title: Danielle McLaughlin 'raped and strangled' - post mortem
text: Danielle McLaughlin, from County Donegal, was found dead in a field close to tourist resorts in Canacona on Tuesday morning. The 28-year-old had travelled to India in February. Her post mortem concluded that brain damage and asphyxia caused her death. A man arrested on Wednesday in connection with the murder of McLaughlin has admitted to having sex with her but denied killing her, his lawyer said. Vikat Bhagat was arrested in the coastal state of Goa after police said that DNA evidence linked him to the crime. McLaughlin's body was found with multiple injuries, including a head wound, and DNA samples were taken from her body. Police said that Bhagat's DNA matched samples taken from her body. Bhagat's lawyer, Amit Palyekar, said that his client admitted to having sex with McLaughlin but denied killing her. He said that Bhagat had been drinking heavily on the night of the murder and could not remember what happened. "He has admitted to having consensual sex with the girl," Palyekar said. "He does not remember what happened after that because he was heavily drunk." Palyekar said that Bhagat had been cooperating with police and had given them a DNA sample. He said that his client was "innocent until proven guilty" and that he would fight the charges against him. The murder of McLaughlin has shocked the local community in Goa and has raised concerns about the safety of foreign tourists in the state. Goa is a popular tourist destination, known for its beaches and nightlife. McLaughlin's family has said that they are "devastated" by her death and have called for justice. They have said that they want the person responsible for her murder to be brought to justice. The Irish government has said that it is "deeply concerned" about the murder of McLaughlin and has called on the Indian government to investigate the case thoroughly. The British government has also said that it is "shocked and saddened" by the murder and has offered its condolences to McLaughlin's family.

title: UK fracking: Shale gas starts flowing, Cuadrilla says
text: Operations began at the Lancashire site in October for the first time since 2011 when it was suspended because of earth tremors. Cuadrilla said that the gas that was produced will be flared off on site rather than sold commercially. The firm said this was "to ensure both operational efficiency and to provide technical information". It said the gas was expected to flow for about four weeks. Cuadrilla is the only company to have fracked in the UK, but was forced to suspend its operations in 2011 and 2019 after seismic activity was recorded. Fracking - a technique to extract gas or oil from underground - has been a source of controversy in the UK, with many environmental groups opposed to the process. Critics say it can cause environmental damage, including water contamination and air pollution. They also argue that it is not a sustainable source of energy because it contributes to climate change. The government has said fracking will only be allowed if it can be done safely, but has not ruled out supporting the industry in the future. Cuadrilla has always maintained that fracking is safe and can be done without causing environmental harm. The company said in a statement that it was "delighted" to have started producing gas from the Lancashire site. "This is a significant milestone for Cuadrilla and for the UK shale gas industry," the statement said. "We are now focused on continuing to operate safely and efficiently, and on providing valuable technical information that will help to inform the wider debate about shale gas in the UK." Anti-fracking campaigners have vowed to continue to oppose the industry. Friends of the Earth energy campaigner Danny Gross said: "This is a dangerous and unnecessary step backwards. Fracking is a dirty and risky technique that has no place in the UK. "The government must now abandon its support for fracking and focus on investing in clean, renewable energy sources."

title: Tax power restrictions 'starting point' for debate, says Cameron
text: UK ministers want to hold a referendum on allowing the Welsh government to vary income tax rates. Each income tax band could only be moved at the same time and by the same amount. For example, if the basic rate of income tax in Wales is 10%, the government could increase or decrease it by 1%, 2%, or any other single figure - but not by different amounts for different bands. Under the plans, the Welsh government would not be able to set a different threshold at which people start paying income tax. Many people have said they would support the move if it was put to a referendum. Plaid Cymru, the Welsh nationalist party, said it would support a referendum on giving the Welsh government the power to set income tax. Liz Saville Roberts, Plaid Cymru's leader in Westminster, said: "I think the people of Wales are grown up and have shown in recent referendums that they are capable of taking big decisions." The Welsh Conservatives have also said they would support the move. Andrew RT Davies, the leader of the Welsh Conservatives, said: "This is something that we have been calling for for a long time. We believe that the people of Wales should have the power to set their own taxes." However, some people have said they are concerned about the impact that the move could have on the UK's economy. The UK Treasury has said that it is concerned about the impact that the move could have on the UK's single market. A Treasury spokesman said: "We are concerned about the potential impact on the UK's single market, and on the competitiveness of the UK economy." The Welsh government has said that it is confident that the move would not have a negative impact on the UK economy. A Welsh government spokesman said: "We are confident that the move would not have a negative impact on the UK economy. We believe that it would actually make the Welsh economy more competitive." The UK government is expected to publish a white paper on the proposals in the coming months.

title: Tesco to fight dairy price-fixing fine from OFT
text: The supermarket giant was one of nine firms facing penalties totalling close to £50m for colluding over the price of milk and cheese in 2002 and 2003. But Tesco expressed "surprise and dismay" at the findings, saying it "fundamentally disagrees" with the decision and intends to appeal. The Office of Fair Trading (OFT) accused Tesco of discussing and agreeing price increases with other UK supermarkets, including Asda, Sainsbury's and Safeway. The investigation focused on price discussions that took place at a series of meetings that were allegedly organised by former dairy industry executive Robert Wiseman. The OFT said the meetings "created a climate in which it was easier for the supermarkets to implement the price increases, and to deter customers from switching between the supermarkets". The investigation also found that the supermarkets exchanged commercially sensitive information, such as details of their pricing plans. The OFT imposed fines totalling £49.5m on the nine companies involved. Tesco was fined £10.3m, the largest penalty. Other companies fined included Dairy Crest (£8.7m), Arla Foods (£6.3m) and Lactalis Nestle (£3.9m). Tesco said it "acted in the best interests of customers" and that it "did not engage in any anti-competitive behaviour". The company said it would "vigorously defend" its position in court. The other eight companies fined by the OFT have not yet commented on the decision. The OFT's investigation into dairy price-fixing is not the first time that the supermarket industry has been accused of anti-competitive behaviour. In 2002, the Competition Commission found that the four major UK supermarkets were operating a cartel in relation to the supply of fuel. The Competition Commission imposed fines totalling £252m on the four companies. The OFT's dairy price-fixing investigation is a reminder of the importance of competition in the food industry. Competition helps to keep prices low and encourages innovation. The OFT's findings suggest that the UK supermarket industry is not as competitive as it could be. The OFT's investigation may lead to changes in the way that supermarkets operate, which could benefit consumers.

title: Google's Street View faces multi-state US probe
text: It is the latest in a series of global investigations aimed at the firm. Google has admitted that its Street View cars "accidentally" collected data from unsecured wi-fi networks in 30 countries because of some rogue code in the company's software. The probes are looking into whether the data collection breached privacy laws and whether the company misled regulators. In the US, the investigation is being led by the attorneys general of seven states: Connecticut, Florida, Illinois, New Jersey, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Texas. They have asked Google to provide a range of documents, including records about the data collection process, the security measures that were in place and the communications between Google and its employees about the issue. Germany has already fined Google €145,000 (£107,000; $161,000) over the issue. The city of Hamburg has also banned Street View cars from operating in the area because of concerns about privacy. In June, Google agreed to pay £18m to settle a class action lawsuit brought by UK citizens over the Street View data collection. The company has since taken steps to tighten its privacy controls and has said that it is committed to protecting the privacy of its users. However, the latest investigations show that regulators are still concerned about the company's data collection practices. The probes are likely to take several months to complete. If any of the states find that Google has breached the law, they could impose fines or other penalties. Google has said that it is cooperating with the investigations and that it is confident that it has not broken any laws. However, the investigations could damage the company's reputation and make it harder to convince people to share their personal information with Google. The probes also come at a time when Google is facing increased scrutiny from regulators around the world. The European Commission is investigating Google's search practices, while the US Federal Trade Commission is looking into the company's advertising practices. The investigations show that regulators are increasingly concerned about the power of large technology companies and their ability to collect and use personal data.

title: Sellafield partly closed after 'above normal' radiation
text: Each building was checked after a perimeter alarm was triggered at the north of the site. The company later said it was naturally occurring background radiation and not a nuclear leak. A spokesman added: "Our priority is the safety of our workforce and the protection of the environment. We take all radiation alarms seriously and investigate them thoroughly. "We are confident that there has been no release of radioactive material from the site." The alarm was triggered at around 08:30 BST on Saturday. The site was partly closed as a precaution, with only essential staff allowed on the northern part of the site. The Environment Agency said it was monitoring the situation and had no concerns about any impact on the public or the environment. Sellafield is one of the UK's most hazardous nuclear sites. It is home to a number of nuclear reactors and reprocessing facilities. In 2005, a major fire broke out at the site, which led to the release of radioactive material. The fire caused widespread public concern and led to a number of investigations. The site has been subject to a number of safety upgrades since the fire, including the installation of new fire detection and suppression systems. The latest incident is a reminder of the potential risks associated with nuclear power. However, Sellafield's operator, Sellafield Ltd, said it was confident that the site was safe. A spokesman said: "We have a robust safety culture and we are committed to operating the site safely and securely." The latest incident is being investigated by the Office for Nuclear Regulation (ONR). The ONR said it was too early to say what had caused the alarm. title: Tamboran: Licence for fracking plans terminated
text: Tamboran was granted a petroleum licence in 2011. It had three years to inform the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) on its work programme and drilling schedule. Tamboran was unable to do this in the agreed timescale. DETI subsequently served several late submission notices on the company. In a statement, Tamboran Resources UK Ltd said that while the company "fundamentally disagrees with the decision" it would "comply fully" with the government's decision. The company said it was "disappointed" with the decision as it had submitted "a robust plan to undertake exploration drilling". "The company believes that the proposed exploration drilling programme would have been in accordance with the terms of the licence and Northern Ireland legislation and would have been carried out safely and responsibly," the statement continued. Tamboran also said that it had "confidence in the safety and regulation of onshore oil and gas exploration and drilling in the UK". In a statement, DETI said that the licence had been terminated "in accordance with the relevant legislation and after careful consideration of all available information". The department said that it "recognises the potential economic benefits of oil and gas exploration and production in Northern Ireland". However, it added that "the safety of our environment and the wellbeing of our communities must be paramount". DETI said it would "continue to engage with stakeholders on the future of onshore oil and gas exploration and production in Northern Ireland". The decision to terminate Tamboran's licence is likely to be welcomed by environmental groups. Friends of the Earth Northern Ireland said that the decision was a "victory for common sense and the environment". "This decision sends a clear message that fracking will not be tolerated in Northern Ireland," the group said in a statement. Greenpeace also welcomed the decision, saying that it was a "major victory for the people of Northern Ireland". "This decision is a testament to the power of people power," the group said in a statement. The decision is also likely to be welcomed by some local residents. Many people in the area where Tamboran was planning to drill have expressed concerns about the potential impact of fracking on their health and the environment. A petition against fracking in Northern Ireland has been signed by more than 50,000 people. The decision to terminate Tamboran's licence is a significant development in the debate over fracking in Northern Ireland. It is likely to make it more difficult for other companies to obtain licences to explore for oil and gas in the region.

title: North Korea access to outside media up, says US study
text: The government was unable to maintain a "total monopoly" over information and the people's "understanding of the world is changing", the report by InterMedia, a Washington-based research group, concluded. The report found that access to outside information in North Korea has increased significantly over the last few years, thanks to the widespread use of mobile phones and USB flash drives. This has opened up a new window to the outside world for North Koreans, who are now able to access a wider range of information than ever before. The report found that the North Korean government is aware of the increasing access to outside information and is trying to crack down on it. However, these efforts have been largely unsuccessful, and access to outside information continues to grow. The report's findings are based on a survey of North Korean defectors who have recently arrived in South Korea. The defectors were asked about their access to outside information, and their responses were used to estimate the overall level of access to outside information in North Korea. The report's findings are significant because they suggest that the North Korean government is losing its grip on the information environment. This is a major development, and it could have a profound impact on the future of North Korea. If the North Korean people continue to gain access to outside information, they will become more aware of the outside world and the possibilities that exist beyond their borders. This could lead to a growing demand for change, and it could eventually lead to the downfall of the North Korean government. The report's findings are a reminder that the world is changing, and that even the most repressive regimes cannot completely control the flow of information. The North Korean government may be able to block access to certain websites and social media platforms, but it cannot stop the flow of information altogether. The North Korean people are now more connected to the outside world than ever before, and this is having a profound impact on their lives. This could lead to a growing demand for change, and it could eventually lead to the downfall of the North Korean government.

title: Windrush scandal: Compensation could be capped under proposed scheme
text: Launching a 12-week consultation on a compensation scheme, the Home Office said a cap would ensure no-one got a "disproportionately high amount" compared to others who had been wronged. The department also insisted it planned to make the scheme "as simple and straightforward as possible". However, while the Home Office has proposed a minimum payment of £10,000 for each person who was unlawfully detained or deported, the proposed maximum compensation is yet to be set. Campaigners have said that a cap of £100,000 would not be acceptable as many people had lost much more than that as a result of the scandal. Diane Abbott, the shadow home secretary, described the consultation as "a complete insult to the victims". "The Windrush scandal is one of the most shameful episodes in recent British history and the victims deserve much more than what is being offered," she said. "A cap of £100,000 is completely inadequate. Many victims have lost their jobs, their homes, and their health as a result of this scandal. They deserve to be properly compensated." The Windrush generation refers to people who arrived in the UK from Caribbean countries between 1948 and 1971 to help rebuild the country after World War Two. Many were children at the time and had no idea they did not have the right documentation to be in the UK. The scandal erupted in 2018 when it emerged that some members of the Windrush generation had been wrongly detained and deported, while others had been denied access to healthcare and benefits. The government has since apologized for the scandal and set up a compensation scheme. However, the details of the scheme have been criticized by campaigners who say it does not go far enough. The Home Office said the consultation would give victims and their representatives the opportunity to have their say on the design of the scheme. "We want to make sure the compensation scheme is fair and proportionate, and that it provides the right level of support to those who have been affected," a Home Office spokesperson said. "We will be listening carefully to all the responses we receive during the consultation and will use them to inform the final design of the scheme." The consultation will run until 22 May.

title: Greene King Black Boy pubs renamed in 'anti-racist' move
text: Greene King has changed the names of three pubs called The Black Boy, and another called The Black's Head. Managing director Wayne Shurvinton said there was a perception the names were "linked with racism". The pubs have been renamed The Black Horse, The White Hart, The Coach and Horses, and The Duck. Shurvinton said the decision was made after "listening to feedback from our customers and local communities". He added: "We want our pubs to be welcoming and inclusive spaces where everyone can enjoy themselves. We believe that changing the names of these pubs is an important step in making that happen." The move comes amid a wider debate about the use of racially insensitive language and imagery in the UK. In recent months, several statues of historical figures with links to slavery have been toppled or removed. Greene King's decision has been welcomed by some anti-racism campaigners. "This is a positive step forward," said Simon Woolley, director of Operation Black Vote. "The names of these pubs were offensive and had no place in our society. Changing them is a sign that we are moving in the right direction." However, others have expressed concerns about the move. "This is a knee-jerk reaction to a very small minority of people who are trying to rewrite history," said historian David Starkey. "The names of these pubs have been around for centuries and they do not have any racist connotations." Greene King is one of the largest pub chains in the UK, with over 2,700 pubs. The company has said that it will continue to review the names of its pubs and make changes where necessary. In addition to the four pubs that have been renamed, Greene King also plans to change the name of a pub called The Black Boy in Nottingham. The company has said that it will work with local historians to find a new name for the pub that is "appropriate and respectful".

title: France: More than 2,500 break virus restrictions at illegal rave
text: Some of the 2,500 ravers in Lieuron near Rennes in Brittany had planned to party until Tuesday. title: Fifa 20: 'I play it at home and now my song is on the game'
text: By Levi Jouavel and Kirsty Grant Newsbeat reporters Yizzy, 19, has gone from studying and playing Fifa to having his song Hustle Hard featured on the game's soundtrack. The rapper, from Lewisham, south east London, told Radio 1 Newsbeat finding out was "a proud moment". "My friends were like 'bro, you've made it'," he said. Yizzy says he's always loved music, and started rapping when he was 15. "I used to just play around with it really, freestyling with my friends," he says. "I didn't really take it seriously until my mate sent me a beat and encouraged me to write some lyrics for it." Yizzy recorded his first track in 2019 and has since released an EP and a mixtape. He credits his success to staying focused and working hard. "I've had to miss out on a lot of things, but I'm making sacrifices for a better future," he says. Yizzy is now hoping to use his platform to inspire other young people. "I want to show them that anything is possible if you work hard and believe in yourself," he says. title: HIV flushed out by cancer drug
text: By James Gallagher Health and science reporter, BBC News website The cornerstone of treatment, anti-retroviral therapy, kills the virus in the bloodstream but leaves "HIV reservoirs" untouched. The study, published in PLoS Pathogens, showed the drug Vorinostat flushed out some of these reservoirs in the blood. Researchers say it is still early days, but this suggests a combination of cancer and HIV treatments could one day lead to a cure. HIV has a unique ability to evade the immune system - it hides its genetic material inside the DNA of immune cells. When an immune cell is activated to fight an infection, the latent HIV emerges to produce new virus particles. Finding and destroying these reservoirs is crucial for a cure for HIV. Dr Paul Bieniasz, from the Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center in New York, who led the study, said: "Most people believe that HIV cannot be cured with current therapies because of these latent reservoirs. "And because they are latent, they don't present a target to the immune system or to anti-retroviral therapy." His team treated HIV-infected human cells with Vorinostat for four days. Most of the virus remained hidden, but some of the dormant HIV was exposed. "It's only a modest effect," he said. "But it's an important proof-of-concept study that this type of approach might have promise." Dr Bieniasz said the next step would be to see if the drug has the same effect in animal models of HIV. And he said it was possible HIV-infected people who needed Vorinostat for their cancer could benefit from this side-effect. Dr Sarah Fidler, a HIV cure researcher at Imperial College London, who was not involved in the study, said the findings were "an interesting proof-of-concept". She said: "If this strategy could be translated to HIV patients, it could be used either to reduce reservoirs at the start of treatment to enhance standard therapy, as a strategy to eliminate reservoirs after the virus has been reduced to very low levels, or to enhance immune-based strategies where the aim is to kill infected cells." She added: "There will still be challenges to overcome, such as trying to identify the right time to administer the drug, and considering the side-effects or interactions with HIV drugs or treatments for other conditions."

title: Pontypridd's Muni Arts Centre to close over debts
text: Pontypridd's Muni Arts Centre to close over debts The Muni Arts Centre in Pontypridd was taken over by a limited company and charity after it closed in 2014. title: Football and dementia: Alan Jarvis' death 'caused by heading balls'
text: Alan Jarvis played for Everton and Hull City in the 1960s and 1970s, winning three caps for his country. The 76-year-old, who died in March, was diagnosed with dementia in 2016. A coroner ruled that heading footballs during his playing days "more than likely" caused the brain damage which led to Jarvis developing the condition. Professional footballers are three and a half times more likely to die of dementia than the general population and there is a growing concern about the long-term effects of heading the ball. Experts believe it could be linked to the repetitive heading of the ball causing small amounts of trauma to the brain. However, they say more research is needed to establish a definitive link between the two. The Football Association (FA) said it was "committed to improving the understanding of the long-term health of former players" and was funding research into the issue. In a statement, the FA said: "The FA is committed to improving the understanding of the long-term health of former players and is funding research into the issue. "We are aware of the concerns that have been raised about the potential risks of heading the ball and are committed to working with other organisations to help protect players." The FA has introduced a number of measures to try to reduce the risk of heading the ball, including limiting the number of headers that players can do in training and introducing a ban on heading for children under the age of 12. It is hoped that these measures will help to protect future generations of players from the risk of developing dementia. However, there is still a lot of uncertainty about the long-term effects of heading the ball. More research is needed to establish a definitive link between the two and to determine whether the measures that are being introduced are effective in reducing the risk of dementia.

title: Australian casino shares tumble after China arrests
text: Crown Resorts, controlled by James Packer, closed 13.9% lower after Crown confirmed 18 of its staff had been detained in China. title: Google hit with €1.5bn fine from EU over advertising
text: It is the third EU fine for the search and advertising giant in two years. The case accuses Google of abusing its market dominance by restricting third-party rivals from displaying search ads between 2006 and 2016. Google has previously faced EU antitrust fines of €2.4bn in 2017 and €4.3bn in 2018. The company said it would appeal the latest fine. "We will appeal this decision," a Google spokesperson said. "The decision ignores our investments in Android, which has created more choice for everyone, not less." The European Commission said Google's conduct had "denied consumers a genuine choice of mobile search apps and services and stifled innovation in the mobile advertising market". "Google has cemented its dominance in general search in the vast majority of member states through various practices," commissioner Margrethe Vestager said. "It has also used Android as a vehicle to consolidate its dominance in search via mobile devices." Vestager said the fine was "proportionate and dissuasive". The case relates to agreements between Google and mobile network operators and device manufacturers. The commission said the agreements included clauses that required the pre-installation of Google's search app on Android devices and prevented manufacturers from developing and distributing competing apps. The commission said Google also prevented rivals from accessing key information needed to develop competing search apps. Google denied the allegations, arguing that its agreements with partners were "pro-competitive". The company said its partners were free to choose any search provider they wanted. Google also pointed to the large number of competing search apps available on Android devices. The latest fine comes as Google faces increasing antitrust scrutiny around the world.

title: Outlaw King to be given world premiere at TIFF
text: The Netflix historical drama sees Star Trek and Wonder Woman star Chris Pine play warrior king Robert the Bruce. Scenes for the film were shot in Craigmillar, Aviemore and Glen Coe. Outlaw King is directed by Scottish filmmaker David Mackenzie, whose credits include the award-winning thriller Hell or High Water. The film tells the story of how Robert the Bruce defied overwhelming odds to lead his nation to victory over the mighty army of the English King. James Cosmo, Tony Curran and Billy Boyd co-star. "It's a period in history I'm very intrigued by," said Pine. "I think historically Robert the Bruce was one of the greatest warriors and greatest heroes of Scotland. "His story is one of rebellion and kind of triumph over tyranny and I think is still such a moving and exciting story today." Pine said he was attracted to the role as it allowed him to explore the idea of heroism. "I always like to think that heroism isn't just about the individual," he said. "It's about a community coming together. The sum of all the parts creates a heroic whole." He added: "There are so many different kinds of heroes, from those who stand up for what they believe in to those who are just trying to make a better life for their family. "Heroes are everywhere and I think that's the most exciting thing about Outlaw King, it shows that anyone can be a hero." Director David Mackenzie said he wanted to make a film that was both entertaining and authentic. "I wanted to make a movie that would feel like what it was like to live in Scotland during that time period," he said. "I wanted the audience to feel the cold, the rain, the hunger, and the danger. title: Google and Facebook duped in huge 'scam'
text: By Chris Baraniuk Technology reporter In March, it was reported that a Lithuanian man had been charged over an email phishing attack against "two US-based internet companies" that led to the theft of £79 million. An investigation by the BBC has discovered that the targets of the attack were Google and Facebook's parent company, Meta. The attack saw the fraudster pose as a representative of a Taiwanese hardware manufacturer and send emails to staff at Meta and Google. The emails contained links to a malicious website that looked like a genuine login page for the companies' email systems. Staff at Meta and Google were tricked into entering their usernames and passwords into this fake website. The fraudster then used this information to log in to Meta and Google's email systems and send out requests for payments to fraudulent bank accounts. In some cases, the fraudster also used the compromised email accounts to send out phishing emails to the companies' customers, in an attempt to steal their personal data. Meta and Google have not publicly confirmed that they were the targets of this attack, but a source close to the investigation has confirmed the BBC's findings. The attack is a reminder of the importance of being vigilant against phishing attacks. Phishing emails often look very genuine, but there are some tell-tale signs to watch out for. For example, phishing emails often: - Use generic greetings, such as "Dear Valued Customer" or "Dear Sir/Madam". - Contain spelling and grammar errors. - Ask you to click on a link to a website that you don't recognise. - Ask you to enter your personal information, such as your username, password, or credit card number. If you receive an email that you think may be a phishing email, do not click on any links or open any attachments. Forward the email to your company's IT department or to a dedicated phishing reporting service. You can also report phishing emails to the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) at report@phishing.gov.uk.

title: Hepatitis C vaccine: Oxford researchers' trial 'promising'
text: Designing a vaccine has been difficult as the virus changes its appearance, making it hard to find something to target. Writing in Science Translational Medicine, researchers say their vaccine targets all major strains of the hepatitis C virus (HCV). The vaccine is made using adeno-associated viruses (AAVs) – harmless viruses that can deliver genetic material into cells. It delivers genes encoding non-structural proteins (NS) of HCV, which are essential for viral replication and not targeted by current direct-acting antiviral drugs. They tested the vaccine in mice with liver disease and found that it produced high levels of antibodies and reduced levels of viral RNA in the liver. The findings were consistent across all strains of HCV tested, suggesting it could provide broad protection against the virus. They then tested the vaccine in non-human primates and found that it was safe and induced robust antibody responses. Dr Rebecca Spindler, of the University of Oxford, said: "These results are very promising and suggest that this vaccine strategy could be used to prevent or treat HCV infection. We are now planning to start clinical trials in humans." Hepatitis C is a blood-borne virus that can cause liver damage, scarring and liver cancer. It is estimated to affect around 71 million people worldwide. The current standard of care for HCV is direct-acting antiviral drugs, which are highly effective at clearing the virus but can be expensive and have side effects. A vaccine would be a more cost-effective and convenient way to prevent HCV infection. The new vaccine is still in the early stages of development, but the results from the animal studies are promising. If the vaccine is found to be safe and effective in humans, it could have a major impact on the global burden of HCV. In addition to developing a vaccine, researchers are also working on new treatments for HCV. One promising approach is gene editing, which could be used to cure the virus by removing it from the body. Clinical trials of gene editing for HCV are currently underway.

"We have heard from members who have seen a significant drop in footfall since the ULEZ was extended," the spokesperson said. "This is particularly concerning for businesses that are already struggling in the current economic climate." The spokesperson added that the chamber was calling on the Mayor of London to review the ULEZ and consider exemptions for certain types of businesses. The Mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, has defended the ULEZ, saying that it is necessary to improve air quality in the capital. He has also pointed to the fact that the ULEZ has been accompanied by a number of measures to support businesses, such as grants for electric vehicles and discounts on public transport. "The ULEZ is essential to protect the health of Londoners and reduce air pollution," Khan said. "We have provided support for businesses to help them adapt, and we will continue to work with them to ensure that they can continue to thrive." The ULEZ is part of a wider strategy to improve air quality in London. Other measures include the introduction of a low-emission zone for buses and coaches, and the promotion of walking and cycling.

title: Charity helps drug addicts set up their own businesses
text: By Chris Dearden BBC News Some residents at Penrhyn House - a rehabilitation centre in Bangor - have set up a not-for-profit company selling bottled water. The bottled water company - called Ocean 187 - was started with the help of the charity Action for Addiction. The project is the first business to be set up by the charity in Wales and is run by recovering addicts as part of their rehabilitation. Ocean 187 currently sells its bottled water at leisure centres and gyms across Gwynedd and plans to expand across North Wales. The recovered addicts who work for Ocean 187 say it has helped them change their lives around. The manager of Penrhyn House - David Evans - said: "What our guys are doing here is fantastic. "They are showing what can be achieved with a bit of support and positivity." The charity - Action for Addiction - has provided business skills training for the staff of Ocean 187 as well as helping them with product development. The founder of the charity - Steve Edgell - said: "The guys here have been brilliant in the way they have started this company. "It is the first business we have set up in Wales but it won't be the last. We want to help as many recovering addicts as we can to set up their own businesses." The bottled water is produced by the company at a factory in nearby Conway and is available in 20-litre and three-litre bottles. The company says that its water is "sourced from the pristine waters of the Atlantic Ocean". Customers can order the water online or by calling the company directly. Action for Addiction is a national charity that provides support and treatment for people with drug and alcohol problems. The charity has over 50 centres across the UK and employs over 500 people. For more information please visit: www.actionforaddiction.org.uk

title: Covid in Scotland: 'Majority' of criminal trials on hold for lockdown
text: Until the end of February only the "most serious" trials will proceed, to reduce the number of people needed to attend. Such cases will include those with a "significant risk" to life, sexual or violent offending, or vulnerable witnesses. From 1 March, all criminal trials due to begin before 28 February will be adjourned until after the end of the current lockdown period, unless they fall within the "most serious" category. The changes were announced by the Scottish Courts and Tribunals Service (SCTS) following a review by Scotland's senior judges during a meeting with the lord advocate, James Wolffe QC. Temporary legislation was passed in March last year to allow most hearings to be held virtually, but physical attendance is still required for trials, with witnesses present in person and jurors sitting physically distanced in courtrooms. The SCTS said it was "essential that the sheriffs and judges can exercise their discretion in the best interests of justice". It added: "This can only be done by holding hearings in person in court, where it is possible to do so safely." A spokesperson for the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) said: "We welcome the fact that, through the use of technology and other measures, it has been possible to continue to progress many cases during the pandemic. "However, the restrictions have had a significant impact on the ability of the criminal courts to operate at full capacity. "We are committed to continuing to work with our partners across the justice system to do all that we can to ensure that cases are progressed as quickly as possible without compromising on the principles of justice." The number of Covid cases in Scotland has surged in recent weeks, after the emergence of the Omicron variant. The latest figures show there were 23,607 new cases recorded in the past 24 hours - more than at any other point in the pandemic. The total number of cases confirmed since the start of the pandemic now stands at 1,000,262. Meanwhile, another 17 deaths have been recorded in Scotland in the past 24 hours, taking the total number of fatalities to 9,663. The Scottish government has urged people to stay at home as much as possible, and to avoid social gatherings, in a bid to slow the spread of Omicron. The latest measures announced by the SCTS are designed to reduce the number of people who need to attend court, and to help prevent the spread of Covid.

title: Farage: May 'wilfully deceiving' people over Brexit deal
text: The Brexit Party leader told the BBC's Andrew Marr the PM's proposed Brexit deal was a "new European treaty". In a tense interview, Mr Farage said he would not support it in Parliament and accused Mrs May of "wilfully deceiving" the public about the deal's implications. Mrs May has repeatedly said that her deal is the only one that can deliver Brexit and protect jobs. But Mr Farage said it would leave the UK "tied to the EU" and "subject to EU laws". "This is not Brexit," he said. "This is a new European treaty." Mr Farage also accused Mrs May of "wilfully deceiving" the public about the deal's implications. He said she had promised that the UK would be able to leave the EU without paying a "divorce bill", but the deal would actually see the UK paying £39bn. "She has wilfully deceived the public," he said. "She has lied to the public." Mrs May has denied that she has misled the public about the deal. She said that the £39bn payment is a "settlement" for the UK's obligations to the EU, and that it is necessary to secure a smooth and orderly Brexit. The interview came as Mrs May was facing mounting pressure from within her own party to abandon her Brexit deal. Several Conservative MPs have said they will not support the deal in Parliament, and there are fears that it could be defeated when it is put to a vote. If the deal is defeated, it would plunge the UK into further political uncertainty and could lead to a no-deal Brexit. This would mean the UK leaving the EU without a deal in place, which would have a significant impact on the UK economy and could lead to chaos at the border. The Brexit Party is a pro-Brexit party that was founded by Mr Farage. It is currently the largest party in the European Parliament, and has been gaining support in recent months. Mr Farage has been a vocal critic of Mrs May's Brexit deal, and has said that he would not support it in Parliament. He has also called for Mrs May to resign as Prime Minister.

title: Israel eases restrictions following vaccine success
text: From Sunday, shops, libraries and museums can open but social distancing and masks are still required. The health ministry says it is because of the country's successful COVID-19 vaccination programme that these restrictions can now be eased. Over 80% of the population have been fully vaccinated and over 90% of over 60s have been vaccinated. The easing of restrictions comes as a relief to many businesses and there are hopes that the economy will start to recover. However, the health ministry is warning that the pandemic is not over and people should continue to be cautious. "We have made great progress but we are not out of the woods yet," said health ministry spokesman Ofer Levy. "We need to continue to be vigilant and follow the guidelines." The easing of restrictions has been welcomed by some but others are concerned that it is too soon. "I'm glad that things are starting to open up again but I'm also worried that it might be too soon," said Jerusalem resident Sarah Cohen. "I think we should wait a little longer to make sure that the virus is under control." The government has said that it will continue to monitor the situation and will tighten restrictions if necessary. "We are taking a cautious approach," said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. "We will not hesitate to take whatever steps are necessary to protect the public." Here is a summary of the restrictions that are being eased: Shops, libraries and museums can open. Outdoor gatherings of up to 50 people are allowed. Indoor gatherings of up to 20 people are allowed. Restaurants and cafes can open with outdoor seating only. Hotels can open with restrictions. Public transport will operate with reduced capacity. The health ministry is urging people to continue to follow the guidelines: Wear a mask in public places. Maintain social distancing of two metres. Wash your hands frequently. Avoid large gatherings. Get vaccinated if you have not already done so.

title: Henry Moore statue: Minister's concerns over sale plan
text: Len Tingle Political editor, Yorkshire Now her planned sale is provoking a national outcry and the lady is certainly not going quietly. This week there was a fierce protest with locals blocking access to the site for hours. The statue, Ascending Form, is one of 11 works by Mr Moore commissioned for the Headingley campus in the 1970s. Following the collapse of the music department five years ago, the university sold the first of the bronze figures, Oval Forms, to an art dealer. It went to a private collector in Italy and fetched £6.5m. Now the university wants to sell more of its Moore artwork – three of the most significant pieces including Ascending Form. This has angered the local community, a large number of whom donated the money to pay for the statues in the first place. They believe that the university is reneging on an agreement made in 2004, when it was granted ownership, that the sculptures would remain on campus for the enjoyment of the people of Leeds. The protesters are furious and the outcry has reached Westminster. The arts minister, Lord Parkinson, has written to the university’s vice-chancellor, Prof Simone Buitendijk, expressing his concerns. The minister has also offered to meet the university and local representatives to discuss the matter. But the university has accused the protesters of spreading misinformation and insisted it is within its rights to sell the sculptures. The university says it is not planning to sell all three of the pieces. Ascending Figure could be bought back using donations, but the university says the other two are “likely to be of interest to national or international institutions”. It also argues that the funds raised from the sale of the sculptures will be used to benefit the university and its students. But Henri Brocklebank, of the Action for Moore group, says the university is trying to cash in on its “cultural inheritance”. Mr Brocklebank said: “The only thing that has changed since 2004 is that the value of the sculptures has increased. So now the university has given itself a get-out clause. “It is the people of Leeds who paid for these sculptures. Why should they be flogged off to private collectors?” The university says it is not ignoring the wishes of the Leeds people. It says it is asking the Arts Council England to review the agreement made in 2004 and hopes to reach an agreement that allows it to sell some of the statues while still satisfying the desire to “retain these important works within the public realm in Leeds”.

title: The Indian tribe that gave up hunting to save forests
text: At one time, 76-year-old Chaiyievi Zhiinyii was a skilled hunter. But he stopped hunting in 2001. The Angami tribe gave up what was an important source of livelihood some 20 years ago in order to create a community-owned forest reserve. The Angamis are one of the largest Naga tribes in Nagaland, a state in north-eastern India. They live in the foothills of the Himalayas, and their traditional way of life has always been closely tied to the forest. In the past, the Angamis hunted for food, and also to protect their crops from animals. But as the human population grew, so too did the demand for land. The forests were being cleared for agriculture, and the animals that the Angamis hunted were becoming increasingly scarce. In the late 1990s, the Angamis realized that they needed to take action to protect their forest. In 2001, they banned hunting in their traditional territory. They also set up a community forest management committee to manage the forest and ensure that it was used sustainably. The Angamis' decision to give up hunting was a difficult one, but it has paid off. The forest has now recovered, and the animals that live there are thriving. The Angamis are also able to collect firewood, fruits, and vegetables from the forest, which provides them with a source of food and income. The Angamis' story is an inspiring example of how a community can come together to protect their environment. It is also a reminder that we all have a responsibility to protect the planet for future generations. The Angamis' community-owned forest reserve is now a model for other communities in India. It has shown that it is possible to protect the environment while also meeting the needs of the local people. The Angamis are proud of what they have achieved, and they hope that their story will inspire other communities to take action to protect their environment.

title: NI political reaction to Birmingham pub bombing apology
text: Michael Christopher Hayes is a self-confessed republican bomb-maker. He said he was sorry that 21 innocent people died in the attack in 1974. Bombs exploded in two Birmingham pubs, killing 21 people and injuring over 180 on the evening of November 21, 1974, in what became known as the Birmingham pub bombings. Hayes, who was 28 at the time and had been serving a life sentence for his role in the bombings, was released in 2000 under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement. In a statement released through his solicitor, Hayes said: "I want to apologize to all those who suffered because of our actions. I know that an apology will not be enough for many people, but I hope that it will at least show that I am truly sorry for what happened that night." Hayes' apology has been welcomed by some victims' families, but others have said they find it hard to forgive. Julie Hambleton, whose 18-year-old sister Maxine died in the bombings, said she was not ready to accept Hayes' apology. "I don't think he's being genuine. I think he's just saying sorry because he's been caught," she said. "I don't think he understands the pain that he caused." Northern Ireland's First Minister Peter Robinson said that Hayes' apology was "a step in the right direction", but he added that "it is important to remember that this was a horrific crime that caused unimaginable suffering to many innocent people". Deputy First Minister Martin McGuinness said that Hayes' apology was "a significant gesture", but he added that "it is important that we do not allow this to overshadow the ongoing campaign for justice by the victims and their families". The Birmingham pub bombings were one of the most notorious atrocities of the Troubles in Northern Ireland. The bombings were carried out by the Provisional IRA, which was fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and create a united Ireland. The families of the victims have campaigned for justice for decades, and in 2012 the British government announced a new inquiry into the bombings. The inquiry is ongoing.

title: Rio 2016: 'Welcome to Hell' warn police
text: By BBC Trending\ What's popular and why Along with the relatives carrying flowers and taxi drivers waiting with name boards there were lines of off-duty police with banners that had a far more ominous message: "Welcome to Hell". These are not the usual words of welcome at an Olympic Games, but they are a reflection of the concerns that many in Brazil have about security at the Rio Games. In the lead-up to the Olympics, there have been several violent incidents in Rio, including a mugging of a Dutch journalist and a shooting in the Olympic Park. The police in Rio have been criticised for their heavy-handed tactics, and there are concerns that they may use excessive force during the Games. Despite these concerns, the Brazilian government has insisted that the Olympics will be safe. "We have taken all the necessary measures to ensure the safety of the athletes and the public," said Sergio Cabral, the governor of Rio de Janeiro. The Brazilian government has deployed 85,000 security personnel to the Games, including 47,000 police officers. The police will be using a variety of tactics to keep the Games safe, including facial recognition technology, surveillance cameras, and armed patrols. However, some experts are sceptical about whether the Brazilian government will be able to keep the Games safe. "The Brazilian government has a lot of experience in policing large events, but the Olympics is a different beast," said Robert Muggah, a security expert at the Igarape Institute. "The Olympics is a global event, and it attracts a lot of attention from criminals. The Brazilian government will need to be on its guard to prevent any major security incidents." The Olympics are a major opportunity for Brazil to showcase its culture and achievements to the world. However, the security concerns are a reminder that Brazil still has a long way to go in terms of reducing crime and violence.

title: Dog microchipping to be compulsory in Wales by 2015
text: The move is seen as a way to improve animal welfare and develop responsible dog ownership by helping identify strays. It is estimated 190,000 dogs will be microchipped over the next five years. The Welsh Government has said the scheme will help reunite lost dogs with their owners, reduce the number of strays in pounds, and deter dog theft. Compulsory microchipping is already in place in England, Scotland and Northern Ireland. The Welsh Government said it is working with local authorities and animal welfare organisations to implement the scheme in Wales. Microchipping involves implanting a small electronic chip under the dog's skin, which contains a unique identification number. This number can be scanned by a vet or animal welfare officer to identify the dog and its owner. The Welsh Government said it will provide funding to help local authorities and animal welfare organisations cover the cost of microchipping dogs. The British Veterinary Association (BVA) has welcomed the Welsh Government's decision to make microchipping compulsory. "Microchipping is a simple and effective way to identify dogs and reunite them with their owners if they get lost or stolen," said BVA president John Fishwick. "We believe that compulsory microchipping will help to improve animal welfare and responsible dog ownership in Wales." The RSPCA Cymru also welcomed the Welsh Government's decision. "Compulsory microchipping is a positive step forward for animal welfare in Wales," said RSPCA Cymru chief executive Chris O'Brien. "It will help to reunite lost dogs with their owners, reduce the number of strays in pounds, and deter dog theft." The Kennel Club has also welcomed the Welsh Government's decision. "The Kennel Club has long campaigned for compulsory microchipping of dogs in Wales," said Kennel Club chief executive Mark Beazley. "We believe that this will help to improve animal welfare and responsible dog ownership in Wales."

title: Iran nuclear deal: Rouhani says West has no right to make changes
text: The US and French leaders announced on Tuesday that they were working on a "new deal" that would expand and extend the terms of the 2015 accord. But Mr Rouhani said they had no right to do so. "The nuclear deal will remain in place in its present form," he said. "No one can change it, not even the US and France." Mr Rouhani's comments came after US President Donald Trump and French President Emmanuel Macron met in Paris and discussed the future of the Iran nuclear deal. Trump has repeatedly criticized the deal, calling it "the worst deal ever negotiated". He has also said that he will withdraw the US from the agreement unless it is renegotiated. Macron has said that he wants to preserve the deal, but he has also called for it to be expanded to include Iran's ballistic missile program and its regional activities. The other signatories to the deal - the UK, Germany, Russia and China - have all said that they want to preserve the agreement in its current form. The Iran nuclear deal was signed in 2015 after years of negotiations. Under the terms of the deal, Iran agreed to limit its nuclear program in exchange for the lifting of international sanctions. The deal has been credited with preventing Iran from developing nuclear weapons. However, it has also been criticized for not doing enough to address Iran's other activities, such as its ballistic missile program and its support for terrorism. The future of the Iran nuclear deal is uncertain. Trump has said that he will withdraw the US from the agreement unless it is renegotiated. Macron has said that he wants to preserve the deal, but he has also called for it to be expanded. The other signatories to the deal have all said that they want to preserve the agreement in its current form. It remains to be seen whether the US and France will be able to negotiate a new deal that is acceptable to all parties. If they fail to do so, the Iran nuclear deal could collapse, which would have serious consequences for the region and the world.

title: Protected status for flapper skate 'nursery' off Skye
text: The flapper skate "nursery" is in Skye's Inner Sound. The fish belong to the shark family and females can grow to 2.8m (9ft) in length. The MPA designation will enhance protection for the area, which was first identified as a potential site in 2019 following a study by the University of Hull. The Scottish government said the move would help safeguard the species and the wider marine ecosystem. Announcing the plans on Monday, Environment Minister Mairi Gougeon said: "We are determined to protect Scotland's seas and safeguard our extraordinary marine environment for future generations, and we know that Marine Protected Areas are vital to achieving that. "Designating Loch Torridon as an MPA will protect the area's diverse range of marine life, including the internationally important populations of basking sharks and other large marine species, as well as critically endangered flapper skate. "This designation will support Scotland's commitment to the protection of our seas, building on the recent agreement reached at COP15 to protect at least 30% of the world's oceans by 2030." The Scottish Wildlife Trust welcomed the announcement, saying it would help to protect "one of Scotland's most iconic marine species". "Flapper skate are a critically endangered species and we need to do everything we can to protect them," said the trust's chief executive, Maggie Keegan. "This designation will help to ensure that this important habitat is safeguarded for future generations." The MPA designation will prohibit activities such as bottom trawling, dredging and scallop dredging within the area. The Scottish government said it would work with stakeholders to ensure that fishing activities that do not damage the seabed can continue. The designation of Loch Torridon as an MPA is part of a wider programme of work to protect Scotland's seas. The Scottish government has already designated 33 MPAs around the coast of Scotland and is committed to designating more in the future. MPAs are designated under the Marine (Scotland) Act 2010. They are a key tool for protecting Scotland's marine environment and can help to conserve and enhance marine biodiversity, safeguard and restore marine ecosystems, and promote sustainable use of marine resources.

title: How many migrant children cross the English Channel?
text: By William McLennan BBC News More than 7,400 people have stepped into small boats and navigated one of the busiest shipping lanes in the world to reach the south coast of England in 2020. At least six people are now thought to have died trying to make the crossing so far this year, compared with at least four last year. The figures, released by the UK government, include people who have reached the UK on small boats, such as dinghies and kayaks, as well as larger commercial vessels. In 2019, the number of people crossing the Channel in small boats was 1,843. The majority of those crossing are single men from Iran, followed by Iraq and Afghanistan. The number of women and children crossing has also increased in recent months. In the first six months of 2020, there were 1,295 children who crossed the Channel, compared with 296 in the same period last year. The Home Office said it was "working round the clock to tackle the issue", including increasing patrols in the Channel and working with the French authorities to prevent people from leaving France. "We are also working to return people who have no right to be in the UK to their home countries," a spokesperson said. However, campaigners have said that the government's response is "inhumane" and called for more safe and legal routes for people to seek asylum in the UK. "The government's failure to provide safe and legal routes for people to seek asylum is forcing people to take desperate measures, like crossing the Channel in small boats," said Enver Solomon, chief executive of the Refugee Council. "The government needs to urgently change its approach and provide more safe and legal routes for people to seek asylum in the UK."

title: Carney and the "no deal" Brexit threat
text: Kamal Ahmed Economics editor@bbckamalon Twitter That the present Brexit process has had negative effects on the broader economy and on people's everyday lives is now widely accepted, by politicians and economists alike. The question that vexed Mark Carney was whether the effects are likely to persist, worsen or ease in the remaining time available to complete the UK's withdrawal negotiations with the European Union. Having concluded that any unresolved Brexit will likely inflict "material economic harm", the governor of the Bank of England told the Treasury Select Committee, the biggest threat is now "the risk of a no deal Brexit". Theresa May's deal may not be perfect, Carney said, but it at least provides business with "clarity" about the rules that will pertain after the UK's formal withdrawal from the EU in March next year. Without a deal, he warned, "firms would face significant disruption to their just-in-time supply chains, the movement of their staff, and the trade in goods and services". All of which could take the UK's economic growth "below zero for an extended period of time". Carney's remarks come just weeks after the prominent Brexit-supporting Conservative MP Jacob Rees-Mogg outlined his own vision of a "no deal" scenario, which included the prospect of reverting to trading with the EU under World Trade Organisation terms. The governor did not mention Rees-Mogg by name, but he warned that increased customs checks and tariffs would impose "significant costs" on UK companies. "WTO rules are not costless," he said. The prospect of a no-deal Brexit has been dismissed by some as scaremongering by Remainers. But the governor's comments serve as a reminder that it is a very real possibility. The government's own analysis, published in November, estimated that a no-deal Brexit would cost each UK household £2,000 a year. The Bank of England's job is not to tell the government what to do on Brexit, but to ensure it has the tools at its disposal to mitigate the negative effects. But Carney's comments make it clear that a no-deal Brexit should be avoided, if at all possible. The problem is that the prime minister has effectively ruled out changing her withdrawal agreement, which was rejected by a large margin in the House of Commons last month. And the EU has said it is not prepared to reopen the negotiation. That leaves MPs with a difficult choice. They can either accept May's deal, vote against it and risk the UK crashing out of the EU without a deal, or vote against it and force a delay to Brexit. The choice is theirs, but they should bear in mind the economic consequences of each option.

title: Ian Paisley challenges BBC over Maldives 'wrongdoing' evidence
text: He was speaking for the first time since a BBC Spotlight programme. It alleged the government minister paid for part of the trip. "If there is something untoward, I'll be the first one to say 'Mea culpa'. Frankly, I don't know what the problem is," he said. The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) politician was a guest of the Maldivian government on a five-day trip to the archipelago nation in November 2014. He travelled with his wife, Rhonda, and two party staff members. The programme alleged that the former North Antrim MP did not pay for any of the trip himself. It also said that the £10,000 cost was paid for by a Maldivian businessman who is a government adviser. It claimed that this businessman's company had subsequently been given a contract to provide security equipment to the Maldives government. Mr Paisley denies any wrongdoing and has threatened legal action against the BBC. He said: "I have never met the person who allegedly paid for the trip. Nor have I ever spoken to him." Mr Paisley said he believed the company that paid for the trip was owned by a different Maldivian businessman, whom he knows. "I was asked if I would go and meet with the opposition, which I had intended to do on this trip," he said. "I was told I would be meeting the president, the prime minister and other ministers and I agreed to do that." He said he had met with the Maldivian president and had also met with the leader of the then-opposition Maldivian Democratic Party. However, he did not meet any opposition figures on this particular trip. He said he believed the Maldives government had paid for the trip. "I did not pay for any of it," he said. "I am not responsible for other people's expenses." The BBC said it stands by the story. A spokesperson said: "We robustly defend our journalism and maintain the accuracy of our reporting."

title: Billy Caldwell: Campaigner's company sells cannabis oil
text: Charlotte Caldwell has been treating her severely epileptic son Billy, 12, with cannabis oil since 2016. His most recent supply was confiscated at Heathrow Airport. It was returned to him after doctors made clear it was necessary to prevent life-threatening seizures. Ms Caldwell, from Castlederg, Co Tyrone, believes the oil is the only thing that stops her son's seizures - which could otherwise strike up to 100 times a day. She has now set up a not-for-profit company that aims to import and distribute the oil to other families affected by childhood epilepsy. Charlotte's Web Ireland imports and distributes Bedrolite, a cannabis oil extract from the Netherlands. Bedrolite contains THC (tetrahydrocannabinol), the psychoactive component of cannabis, and CBD (cannabidiol), which has no psychoactive effect. The company has not yet received a license from the UK Home Office, making it illegal to sell or distribute the oil in the UK. However, Ms Caldwell said she is prepared to challenge the law if necessary. "I am not going to sit here and watch my son suffer," she told the BBC. "I am not going to wait for the government to give me permission to save my son's life." Ms Caldwell said she had been contacted by more than 100 families from the UK who are desperate to access cannabis oil for their children. "These children are suffering every single day," she said. "They are having seizures that could kill them. We have to do something to help them." A spokesman for the Home Office said: "The misuse of drugs can have a significant impact on individuals and communities. "The government has a responsibility to protect the public from the harms caused by controlled drugs and to ensure that they are used for legitimate medical purposes only." The spokesman added that the Home Office is "aware of the case of Billy Caldwell and is working closely with the relevant authorities to ensure that he receives the necessary medical treatment." Ms Caldwell's campaign has been supported by a number of high-profile figures, including the actor and campaigner Michael Sheen. Sheen said: "I believe that Charlotte Caldwell is a remarkable woman who is doing everything she can to save her son's life. "The government should be ashamed of themselves for not doing more to help her."
