title: Tintin and the vanishing murals: Brussels races to save art
text: In the early 1920s Hergé, then a 15-year-old Georges Remi, was a scout and student at Institut St Boniface, in the Ixelles. One day, during an outing, he and his fellow scouts came across a derelict cottage in the nearby Forest of Soignes. Intrigued, they ventured inside and discovered a series of murals depicting the adventures of a young boy and his dog. The boy in the murals bore a striking resemblance to Hergé himself, and the dog to his own wire-haired fox terrier, Milou. Inspired by the discovery, Hergé began to develop the character of Tintin, who would go on to become one of the most iconic figures in the history of comics. Fast forward to the present day, and the murals that inspired Hergé are under threat. The cottage in which they were found has been left abandoned for decades, and the murals themselves are fading and peeling. In a race against time, the City of Brussels has launched a project to restore and preserve the murals, ensuring that they can be enjoyed by future generations. The restoration project is a complex and delicate undertaking. The murals are painted on a variety of surfaces, including plaster, wood, and canvas, and each requires a different approach. Conservators are using a variety of techniques, including laser cleaning, retouching, and consolidation, to restore the murals to their former glory. The project is expected to take several years to complete, but the results are already impressive. The murals are gradually regaining their vibrant colors and intricate details, and they are beginning to tell the story of Tintin's adventures once again. The restoration of the Tintin murals is a testament to the enduring legacy of Hergé's creation. Tintin has been translated into more than 100 languages and has sold more than 250 million copies worldwide. He is a beloved character who has inspired generations of readers and artists. The murals that inspired Hergé are a precious part of Tintin's history, and their restoration is a fitting tribute to the artist and his work.

title: Pisa literacy survey: Finland loses top spot to Asians
text: The tri-annual Programme for International Student Assessment (Pisa) survey of 15-year-olds ranked China's Shanghai region in first place. With Finland coming third, its education system has been a source of envy for many nations. However, this latest report suggests that even the best can be challenged. The survey, which tests students' reading, mathematics, and science skills, has been conducted since 2000 and is considered one of the most comprehensive international assessments of student achievement. In the latest round of testing, Shanghai students outperformed their peers in all three subjects. Singapore and Hong Kong also ranked highly, while Finland dropped to third place. The results have sparked a debate about the reasons for Finland's decline. Some experts believe that the country's education system has become too focused on equality and that it needs to do more to challenge its top students. Others argue that Finland is simply facing the same challenges as other developed countries, such as an aging population and increasing diversity. Whatever the reasons, the Pisa results suggest that Finland's education system is no longer the gold standard it once was. The country will need to make some changes if it wants to regain its top spot. One possible explanation for Finland's decline is that the country's education system has become too focused on equality. Finland has a long tradition of egalitarianism, and its education system is designed to ensure that all students have equal access to quality education. However, some experts believe that this focus on equality has come at the expense of excellence. Another possible explanation for Finland's decline is that the country is simply facing the same challenges as other developed countries, such as an aging population and increasing diversity. As the population ages, there are fewer young people to fill the teaching positions. This can lead to a decline in the quality of teaching, which can in turn lead to a decline in student achievement. Whatever the reasons, the Pisa results suggest that Finland's education system is no longer the gold standard it once was. The country will need to make some changes if it wants to regain its top spot.

title: Lithuania country profile
text: Not much more than a decade after it regained its independence during the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1990, Lithuania was welcomed as a Nato member in late March 2004. The Baltic state also joined the EU in May that year, embracing the principles of economic and political integration. Lithuania is now a stable, modern country with a dynamic economy and a high standard of living. It is ranked among the top 30 countries in the UN's Human Development Index, and its citizens enjoy a wide range of freedoms and opportunities. The country has a rich cultural heritage, with a strong tradition of folk music, dance, and art. Lithuania is also home to a number of UNESCO World Heritage sites, including the Old Town of Vilnius, the Hill of Crosses, and the Curonian Spit. Lithuania is a popular tourist destination, with visitors drawn to its beautiful scenery, historic cities, and friendly people. The country is also well-known for its amber jewelry, which is made from fossilized resin. Lithuania is a forward-looking country that is committed to playing a positive role in the world. It is a member of the United Nations, the Council of Europe, and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE). Economy Lithuania has a diversified economy, with a strong focus on services, manufacturing, and agriculture. The country is a major exporter of electronics, machinery, and food products. Lithuania is a member of the eurozone, and its currency is the euro. The country has a low inflation rate and a stable financial system. Politics Lithuania is a parliamentary republic. The head of state is the president, who is elected for a five-year term. The head of government is the prime minister, who is appointed by the president. Lithuania has a multi-party system, with the main parties being the conservative Homeland Union – Lithuanian Christian Democrats, the social democratic Lithuanian Social Democratic Party, and the liberal Freedom and Justice Party. Foreign policy Lithuania is a strong supporter of NATO and the EU. The country is also committed to promoting democracy and human rights around the world. Lithuania has played an active role in international peacekeeping missions, including in Afghanistan and Kosovo. Conclusion Lithuania has come a long way since regaining its independence in 1990. The country is now a stable, modern, and prosperous democracy. Lithuania is a valued member of the international community, and it is committed to playing a positive role in the world.

title: Spyware use in domestic violence 'escalating'
text: By Zoe Kleinman Technology reporter, BBC News Tracking and listening devices, often disguised as everyday objects, retail online for under £50 and are easy to use. Used by law enforcement and intelligence agencies, they are increasingly being deployed by abusers in domestic violence cases. In June, the government launched a consultation on its Domestic Abuse Bill, which proposes creating a new offence of "non-fatal strangulation". However, the consultation does not address the issue of spyware. Sarah*, who was in an abusive relationship, said spyware was used on her during the eight years she was with her partner. "He always had to have his phone next to him, and I'd get messages saying 'Are you where you say you are?'" she said. "At first I laughed it off and said he was being a bit OTT [over the top]. But it got more sinister. He'd know where I was all the time, even if I hadn't told him." "I found a tracking app on his phone," said Sarah. "It was really easy to use. Once it's installed on a phone, it can track everything you do - where you go, who you call, and even your messages." "He'd send me messages saying 'I know you're with him' or 'I know you're there', and I'd be scared. I felt like I had no privacy. He knew everything about me." Sarah is not alone. In a survey of 2,000 women by domestic violence charity Refuge, 40% said they had been tracked or monitored by their partner. "In the past, domestic abuse was often physical," said Refuge's chief executive, Sandra Horley. "But now, with the advent of new technologies, abusers are finding new ways to control and coerce their victims." "Spyware is particularly insidious because it is often invisible to the victim," said Horley. "It can be installed on a phone without the victim's knowledge or consent, and it can be used to track their movements, access their messages, and even record their conversations." "This can have a devastating impact on the victim's life," said Horley. "It can make them feel isolated, it can make them fear for their safety, and it can make it difficult for them to escape the relationship." The government needs to do more to address the issue of spyware in domestic violence cases, said Horley. "We need to raise awareness of the issue, we need to make it easier for victims to report spyware abuse, and we need to make sure that the police have the resources to investigate these crimes."Sarah's name has been changed to protect her identity

title: Energy firm's Cheshire plans refused by councillors
text: Cheshire West and Chester Council's planning committee voted 10 to 1 to reject IGas's plans for Ellesmere Port because of "climate change" concerns. The company wanted to drill for gas at Ince Marshes, near the town, but councillors said it went against the council's policies on reducing emissions. IGas said it was "disappointed" but would "consider its options". The plans were opposed by environmental groups who said the project could increase greenhouse gas emissions. They also said it was located in an area that is at risk of flooding. The planning committee heard evidence from both sides before making its decision. IGas said the project would create jobs and help to reduce the UK's reliance on imported gas. The company also said it had taken steps to minimize the environmental impact of the project. However, the council's planning committee said the project was not in line with the council's policies on climate change. The committee also said it was not convinced that the project would create enough jobs to justify the environmental impact. IGas said it was "disappointed" by the council's decision. In a statement, the company said: "We are disappointed by the decision of Cheshire West and Chester Council's planning committee to refuse our planning application for Ince Marshes. "We believe that this project would have created jobs, reduced the UK's reliance on imported gas, and helped to meet the UK's energy needs in a responsible way. "We will now consider our options." The decision by the council's planning committee is the latest setback for IGas. In 2020, the company was forced to abandon plans to drill for gas at a site in Lancashire after it was refused planning permission. The company is also facing legal challenges to its plans to drill for gas in other parts of the UK.

title: Did Boris Johnson just announce an election without actually doing so?
text: Laura Kuenssberg Political editor @bbclaurak Twitter He's always said that he really doesn't want to go to the country again. Downing Street insists that all the talk of an imminent election is just "Westminster chatter". But there's a different tone now and it's coming from the top. Today, Boris Johnson signalled that he is preparing for an election, telling Sky News: "I don't want an election, but if there is one, we'll fight it and we'll win it." It's a significant shift in language from the prime minister, who has until now been adamant that he doesn't want an election. So what's changed? One possibility is that Johnson has been spooked by the recent polls, which suggest that Labour is now ahead. Another possibility is that he believes that an election would give him a chance to break the deadlock in Parliament and get his Brexit deal through. Whatever his reasons, it's clear that Johnson is now preparing for an election. He's doing the things that a prime minister would do if they were planning to go to the country, such as setting out his vision for the future and attacking the opposition. Of course, it's still possible that Johnson will change his mind and decide not to call an election. But the latest comments from the prime minister suggest that he is increasingly likely to do so. If Johnson does call an election, it will be the third general election in less than five years. It would also be a high-stakes election, with the future of Brexit and the country's political landscape at stake. The latest YouGov poll, conducted on 13-14 October, put Labour on 38%, the Conservatives on 33%, the Liberal Democrats on 12%, the Brexit Party on 7% and the Greens on 5%. The poll also found that 40% of voters think Johnson is doing a bad job as prime minister, while 31% think he is doing a good job. The Conservatives have been trailing Labour in the polls for several months, and Johnson's personal ratings have also been falling. If the polls are accurate, Johnson would face an uphill battle to win an election. However, the prime minister has a track record of defying the odds, and he will be hoping to do so again at the next election.

title: Amsterdam copies Cardiff's approach to reducing violence
text: Amsterdam copies Cardiff's approach to reducing violence It is adopting a Cardiff University professor's approach which he says has made the Welsh capital safer than similar sized UK cities. It works. Amsterdam is to adopt an approach to reducing violence that has been successfully used in Cardiff. The Dutch city is to introduce a system of 'violence reduction units' (VRUs) which will bring together police, health and community groups to tackle the root causes of violence. The VRUs will work to identify and support people who are at risk of becoming involved in violence, and to provide them with access to services such as education, employment and housing. The approach is based on the work of Professor Jonathan Shepherd of Cardiff University. Professor Shepherd has argued that violence is a public health issue, and that it can be reduced by addressing the underlying social and economic factors that contribute to it. The approach has been credited with helping to reduce violence in Cardiff. According to figures from the Home Office, the number of violent crimes recorded in Cardiff fell by 13% in the year to March 2022. This is compared to a 6% increase in violent crime across England and Wales as a whole. Professor Shepherd said: "I am delighted that Amsterdam is to adopt our approach to reducing violence. This is a clear sign that our work is having an impact, and that it can be replicated in other cities." The VRUs will be introduced in Amsterdam in the coming months. The city's mayor, Femke Halsema, said: "We are committed to making Amsterdam a safer city for everyone. We believe that the violence reduction unit approach can help us to achieve this goal." The VRUs will be part of a wider strategy to reduce violence in Amsterdam. The city is also investing in community policing, and in programmes to support young people who are at risk of becoming involved in violence. The Dutch city of Rotterdam is also considering adopting the Cardiff approach. Rotterdam is one of the most violent cities in the Netherlands, and the city council is keen to find ways to reduce violence. The Cardiff approach is a promising new approach to reducing violence. It is based on the evidence that violence is a public health issue, and that it can be reduced by addressing the underlying social and economic factors that contribute to it. The VRUs will be introduced in Amsterdam in the coming months. It will be interesting to see whether the approach can be as successful in Amsterdam as it has been in Cardiff.

title: Rhino poaching: South Africa and Vietnam sign deal
text: The price of rhino horn - used in traditional medicine in Asian countries - has soared. Rhino poaching is already banned under international conventions but the extent of the problem across Africa remains stubbornly high, driven by the huge profits to be made. South Africa is home to the majority of the world's rhinos. In 2017, 1,028 rhinos were killed for their horns in South Africa alone. In 2018, this number rose to 1,349. Vietnam is one of the largest markets for rhino horn, which is used in traditional medicine to treat a range of ailments, including cancer and impotence. The demand for rhino horn has led to a surge in poaching in South Africa, where the animals are often killed by armed gangs. The deal between South Africa and Vietnam is aimed at tackling the illegal trade in rhino horn. It will see the two countries work together to strengthen law enforcement, improve intelligence sharing, and reduce demand for rhino horn. The deal is a welcome step forward in the fight against rhino poaching. However, it is important to remember that this is a complex issue with no easy solutions. The demand for rhino horn in Asia is likely to continue to drive poaching, and it will take sustained efforts from all stakeholders to protect these iconic animals. In addition to the demand for rhino horn in Asia, there are a number of other factors that have contributed to the rise in poaching in South Africa. These include: Weak law enforcement: The South African government has been criticized for not doing enough to combat poaching. In many cases, poachers are able to operate with impunity. Corruption: Corruption within the South African government and law enforcement agencies has also been linked to the rise in poaching. This has made it difficult to bring poachers to justice. Poverty: Many of the people who are involved in poaching are poor and desperate. They see poaching as a way to make a living. The deal between South Africa and Vietnam is a positive step forward, but it is only one part of the solution. In order to effectively tackle rhino poaching, it is important to address all of the factors that are driving it. This includes strengthening law enforcement, reducing corruption, and addressing the poverty that is driving people to poach. It is also important to educate people in Asia about the devastating impact that the illegal trade in rhino horn is having on these iconic animals.

title: Seren Hughes' parents concerned over epilepsy drugs changes
text: Seren Hughes' father said Machynlleth Health Centre would no longer sign the repeat prescriptions for the medication that reduces her seizures. Hefin Hughes said the family had been told to get the prescriptions from Ysbyty Glan Clwyd in Bodelwyddan, Denbighshire, instead. But Mr Hughes said this was causing "great distress" to his daughter, who has severe epilepsy and autism. "This change has caused us a great deal of distress and anxiety," he said. "Seren has been on these medications for several years and they have been very effective in reducing her seizures. "The thought of changing her medication at this stage is very worrying." Mr Hughes said the family had been told that the change was being made because the health centre was no longer able to provide the necessary monitoring for Seren's medication. "We understand that the health centre is under a lot of pressure, but we feel that this change is not in Seren's best interests," he said. "We would urge the health centre to reconsider its decision." A spokesman for Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board said: "We are aware of the concerns raised by Mr Hughes and are currently looking into the matter. "We would like to assure Mr Hughes and his family that we are committed to providing the best possible care for Seren." Seren's mother, Elen Hughes, said the family was "very worried" about the change in medication. "Seren has been on these medications for a long time and they have been very effective," she said. "We don't want to change her medication at this stage, especially when she is doing so well." The family has now started a petition calling on the health centre to reverse its decision. The petition has already received over 1,000 signatures.

title: 'Inadequate' toilet provision on new TfW trains
text: Railfuture Wales said the provision was inadequate and could deter some people with health conditions. They are calling for changes to the design to be made now, allowing one toilet per carriage. Transport for Wales (TfW) said the level of provision will be “monitored and reviewed” after the new trains have entered service next year. TfW is currently replacing its entire fleet with new trains. The first of the new trains are due to enter service on the Core Valley Lines in north-east Wales in the autumn of 2023. But some passengers have expressed concern about the provision of toilets on the new trains. The new trains will have one toilet per three carriages. Railfuture Wales said this is inadequate. They say that some people with health conditions may need to use the toilet more frequently and that the current provision could deter them from using the trains. “We believe that the provision of one toilet per three carriages is inadequate and could deter some people with health conditions from using the new trains,” said Richard Clinnick, chairman of Railfuture Wales. “We are therefore calling on TfW to make changes to the design of the new trains now, to allow for one toilet per carriage.” TfW said the level of provision will be “monitored and reviewed” after the new trains have entered service next year. “The new trains will have one accessible toilet per three carriages, which is in line with industry best practice,” said a TfW spokesperson. “The level of provision will be monitored and reviewed after the new trains have entered service next year, to ensure that it meets the needs of our customers.” The new trains will also have a number of other features designed to improve the passenger experience, including air conditioning, free WiFi, and USB charging points.

title: Coronavirus: Transport for London expects to lose £4bn
text: Ahead of an emergency finance committee meeting, the organisation said it needs £3.2bn to balance a proposed emergency budget for the next two years. The remainder would come from existing cash reserves of £900m, which the organisation said was "unsustainable". Sadiq Khan has asked the government to provide "urgent financial support" to TfL, which has lost fare revenue as passenger numbers plummeted during the pandemic. He said the government support was "essential to avoid very difficult decisions that would damage London's economy". The emergency budget assumes there will be no return to pre-pandemic patronage, and that revenue will only account for 70% of operating costs. The fare increase was originally due to come into effect in January 2023, but TfL said it was now proposing to introduce it in March to raise more funds. The budget also proposed increasing the congestion charge for the most polluting vehicles from £12.50 to £24 in October 2023. TfL has already received about £4bn in government support during the pandemic. The transport authority said it was "committed to working with the government to find a mutually acceptable solution that ensures TfL can continue to deliver its vital services efficiently, without the need for significant cuts to its services or staff". A government spokesperson said: "We recognise the challenges facing TfL and are committed to working closely with the mayor to reach a fair and sustainable settlement. "We continue to provide multi-billion pound support and have recently agreed the principles of a long-term funding settlement. "We urge the mayor to take urgent action to improve TfL's financial position, including exploring additional commercial opportunities to generate revenue, reduce costs, and prioritise investment in the network." The London Assembly's transport committee has said that the emergency budget would be "devastating for London". "Londoners cannot afford a cut in services or a massive fare hike," the committee said. "The government must urgently provide the funding TfL needs to keep London moving."

title: Anti-Semitic Valentine at Republican student event sparks outrage
text: Warning: Some readers may find some language offensive College Republicans at Central Michigan University were distributing gift bags to students that included a Valentine's Day card containing a message widely condemned as anti-Semitic. The card, which featured a swastika on the front, read: "Roses are red, violets blue, gas the Jews". The university's president, Bob Davies, swiftly denounced the incident, calling it "abhorrent and unacceptable". "This type of hateful and offensive speech has no place on our campus," Davies said in a statement. "We will not tolerate anti-Semitism or any other form of bigotry." The College Republicans group has since apologized for the incident, saying that the cards were not intended to be offensive. "We deeply regret the distribution of these cards," the group said in a statement. "They were intended to be a joke, but we understand that they were deeply offensive and hurtful to many people." The group has also removed the cards from circulation and said that it will be conducting sensitivity training for its members. The incident has sparked outrage on campus and beyond. Many students have expressed their disgust and anger at the distribution of the cards. "This is absolutely unacceptable," said one student. "I'm disgusted that this happened on our campus." Another student said: "This is not just a joke. This is hate speech. It's dangerous and it needs to be condemned." The Anti-Defamation League, a Jewish civil rights organization, has also condemned the incident. "This is a clear example of anti-Semitism," said ADL regional director David Lorenz. "The use of the swastika and the phrase 'gas the Jews' is deeply offensive and hateful." Lorenz said that the incident is a reminder of the need for continued vigilance against anti-Semitism. "We must never forget the horrors of the Holocaust," Lorenz said. "And we must never allow anti-Semitism to go unchecked." The university is investigating the incident and has said that it will take appropriate disciplinary action against those responsible.

title: Hoo fire: 'Huge explosion' as fire rages at industrial unit
text: One resident of Hoo Marina, close to the blaze on Vicarage Lane, described hearing a "huge explosion" and an eyewitness said the "place shook". Kent Fire and Rescue Service said about 200 people were removed from the area and advised to stay away as crews battle the flames. Resident Nicola Allen said: "We just heard this massive explosion. We have just been watching the huge flames coming out of the warehouse." Eyewitness Lee Durrant added: "I was sat in my house, I am on the marina, and the whole place shook." The fire service was called to the blaze shortly after 5am and crews said they were likely to be there for "some time". Kent Fire and Rescue Service said: "We are currently in attendance at a large fire at an industrial building in Vicarage Lane, Hoo. Around 200 people have been evacuated and we would advise people in the area to keep their windows and doors closed while our crews deal with the incident." The A228 was closed in both directions between the A229 and the A289 as emergency services respond to the blaze. The ambulance service has also been called to the scene. A spokesman for the South East Coast Ambulance Service said: "We were called at 5.20am to reports of a fire affecting multiple industrial units in Hoo. "We currently have two ambulance crews in attendance and crews will remain at the scene to support the fire service. "At this stage we have not been made aware of any injuries."

title: Hilton DoubleTree Hotel in Aberdeen re-labelled food
text: The inspection of the Hilton DoubleTree Hotel found food had been re-labelled to extend its shelf life. Dozens of containers of items - including discoloured meat and fish - were uncovered by Aberdeen City Council's environmental health officers. The hotel, located in the city centre, has since been re-branded as the Sandman Signature Aberdeen Hotel & Spa. The council's report said: "During our inspection, the following issues were noted which were of major concern." Food items were being re-labelled with new dates to extend their shelf life. Discoloured meat and fish were being stored in the chiller. Cooked meat was being stored at an unsafe temperature. Raw meat was being stored above cooked meat. Food was being stored in open containers. The kitchen was dirty and unhygienic. The council's environmental health officers served the hotel with a prohibition notice, which means that the hotel cannot serve food until the issues have been resolved. A spokesperson for the Hilton DoubleTree Hotel said: "We are very sorry for the inconvenience this has caused our guests. We are working closely with the council to resolve the issues and ensure that our food safety standards meet the required level." The hotel has since been re-branded as the Sandman Signature Aberdeen Hotel & Spa. A spokesperson for the new owners said: "We are committed to providing our guests with a safe and enjoyable dining experience. We have already implemented a number of changes to our food safety procedures and are working closely with the council to ensure that we meet the required standards." The council's environmental health officers will be carrying out a follow-up inspection of the hotel in the near future.

title: Snow disruption warning stepped down
text: Snow disruption warning stepped down It steps down Police Scotland advice to stage two after being escalated to stage four "do not travel" overnight. A yellow Met Office weather warning for snow is in place until 12pm today. Stage two of Police Scotland's guidance means that road travel should only be undertaken when essential, and only if the journey can be completed safely. Stage four advice, which was in place from 8pm on Monday until 9am on Tuesday, meant that the public were told that all non-essential travel should be avoided. The Met Office yellow warning for snow and ice covers central, southern, and eastern parts of Scotland, as well as parts of northern England, including Cumbria, Lancashire, Greater Manchester, Merseyside, and Yorkshire and the Humber. The warning states that snow and ice could cause disruption to travel and may lead to power cuts and loss of mobile phone signal. The Scottish Government has urged people to follow the advice of Police Scotland and the Met Office. A spokesperson said: "The safety of the public is our top priority. We urge everyone to follow the advice of the police and the Met Office. If you have to travel, please do so with extreme care and only if your journey is essential." The Scottish Government has also advised schools to make their own decisions on whether to close based on the local conditions. A spokesperson said: "Head teachers will be best placed to make a decision on whether or not to close their school based on the local weather conditions. They will be able to take into account factors such as the safety of pupils and staff, the accessibility of the school, and the availability of public transport." The latest weather forecast for Scotland can be found on the Met Office website. Advice for motorists Only travel if your journey is essential. If you do have to travel, check the latest weather forecast and road conditions before you set off. Allow extra time for your journey and take breaks as needed. Be prepared for delays and cancellations. Make sure your vehicle is well-maintained and has winter tires fitted. Carry a winter emergency kit in your vehicle, including items such as blankets, food, water, and a first-aid kit.

title: Russia: Fire kills 14 sailors aboard navy research submersible
text: The crew was poisoned by fumes as the vessel was taking measurements in Russian territorial waters on Monday. The ministry gave no details about the type of vessel. But Russian media reports say it was an AS-12 Losharik-class deep-diving nuclear submarine. LOSHarik submarines are designed for underwater research, rescue operations and special missions. The vessel was said to have been operating in the Barents Sea when the fire broke out. The submarine managed to surface, and the crew evacuated onto a rescue vessel, the ministry said. But 14 sailors died from smoke inhalation. The rest of the crew received medical assistance, with three in a serious condition. The ministry said that all necessary measures were being taken to establish the cause of the fire and to provide assistance to the victims' families. Accidents involving Russian military vessels have happened before. In 2000, the nuclear-powered submarine Kursk was destroyed in a huge explosion, killing all 118 crew members. And in 2019, 14 sailors died in a fire on board a research submersible in the Pacific Ocean. Following Monday's disaster, the Russian navy has suspended all deep-sea operations. The AS-12 Losharik-class submarines are relatively new, entering service in 2003. They are designed to operate at depths of up to 6,000 metres (19,685 ft) and can stay submerged for up to 100 days. The submarines are equipped with a variety of sensors and equipment for underwater research and exploration. The Russian navy has a long history of operating submarines, dating back to the 19th century. The country has one of the largest submarine fleets in the world, with over 50 submarines in service. The submarines play a key role in Russia's nuclear deterrence strategy and are also used for intelligence gathering and other missions.

title: How Meryl became Margaret
text: By Tim Masters Entertainment correspondent, BBC News, in Los Angeles Mark Coulier is one half of the team that transformed one of Hollywood's most glamorous stars into one of Britain's most iconic prime ministers. The Oscar-winning make-up artist says Meryl Streep, who plays Margaret Thatcher in The Iron Lady, was instantly recognisable in the role. "She looks like her, she sounds like her, her mannerisms are like her," Coulier told the BBC. "But because the face is so familiar, the audience will be looking to find Meryl Streep. So part of the job is to distract the audience from that." The first step was to take a mould of Streep's face and make a plaster cast of it. This cast was then covered with a special make-up that became Thatcher's skin. Coulier had to be extremely precise in his work. "We had to get the age right, and we had to get the character right," he said. "We also had to make sure that the make-up was not too heavy, because it would have interfered with Meryl's performance." Coulier spent hours studying photographs and videos of Thatcher to get her look just right. He also had to take into account the fact that Streep would be wearing a wig and heavy prosthetics. "We had to make sure that the prosthetics fit perfectly and that they didn't move around when Meryl was speaking," Coulier said. "We also had to make sure that the make-up stayed in place under the lights and in different weather conditions." Coulier's work on The Iron Lady has been praised by critics and audiences alike. In a review of the film, the New York Times said that Streep's performance was "so physically accurate that it's almost uncanny." Coulier is proud of his work on The Iron Lady, but he says that the most important thing was to help Streep create a believable and compelling performance. "I wanted to create a make-up that would allow Meryl to disappear into the role," he said. "I think we achieved that."

title: Myanmar court finds trio guilty of insulting religion
text: Philip Blackwood, who managed the VGastro Bar in Yangon, was arrested in December along with bar owner Tun Thurein and colleague Htut. They were accused of insulting religion after a photo of them standing near a sign that referenced the Buddha in an allegedly disrespectful way was posted on Facebook. All three men denied the charges. The court heard that the defendants had been drinking at the bar when they decided to take a photo in front of the sign, which read "The Best F*ing Curry in Yangon". The prosecution argued that the photo was offensive to Buddhists because it showed the men standing with their backs to the Buddha image and making hand gestures that were considered disrespectful. The defendants' lawyers argued that the photo was not intended to be offensive and that the men had no intention of insulting religion. They said that the men were simply having fun and that the photo was taken in a light-hearted manner. The court found all three men guilty of insulting religion and sentenced them to two and a half years in prison. The defendants' lawyers said that they would appeal the verdict. The case has been widely condemned by human rights groups, who say that it is a violation of freedom of expression. The United States Embassy in Myanmar has also expressed concern about the verdict, saying that it "undermines freedom of religion and expression". The verdict has also sparked protests in Myanmar, with hundreds of people taking to the streets to demand the release of the defendants. The protests have been largely peaceful, but there have been some reports of violence. The case has highlighted the challenges that Myanmar faces in balancing freedom of expression with respect for religion. The country is home to a number of different religions, and there is a long history of religious tension. The government has been trying to promote religious tolerance, but the case of the VGastro Bar defendants has shown that there is still a long way to go.

title: Eurovision Song Contest: Ireland knocked out
text: By Neil Smith Entertainment reporter, Kiev Galway-born Brendan Murray, 20, had a hot-air balloon with him on stage in Kiev, but it was not enough to lift him into the Eurovision final. Murray made headlines with his whimsical performance of Dying to Try in Tuesday's semi-final but the song failed to take flight with voters. The singer was Ireland's first Eurovision entrant since 2015 and looked emotional as the results were being announced. "Thank you so much Ireland, from the bottom of my heart, for giving me this amazing opportunity," he wrote on Twitter after the show. "The memories I've made over the past few weeks will stay with me forever. I'm gutted not to qualify for Eurovision but it's been an incredible experience." Ireland has won the Eurovision Song Contest seven times, more than any other country, but Murray's defeat means the country will not be in the final for the fourth year in a row. Murray's performance was one of the most talked-about moments of the semi-final. He emerged from a large hot-air balloon wearing a sequined suit and clutching a microphone stand topped with a giant pair of angel wings. The song itself was a catchy pop number with a soaring chorus, but it was not enough to convince voters to part with their points. Ireland was one of 18 countries competing in the first semi-final, with only 10 progressing to the final on Saturday. The other countries to qualify were Albania, Australia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Bulgaria, Cyprus, Greece, Moldova and Sweden. The United Kingdom is automatically in the final as one of the "big five" countries, along with France, Germany, Italy and Spain. The remaining 10 finalists will be decided in Thursday's second semi-final, with the final taking place on Saturday.

title: Japan protests over China ships near disputed islands
text: This is the first such protest under new PM Shinzo Abe, who was elected last month. It also comes amid reports that he wants to increase defence spending. Chinese ships have sailed near the islands many times in the past, and the two countries have been embroiled in a long-running dispute over who owns them. The islands are known as the Senkaku Islands in Japan and the Diaoyu Islands in China. Japan says it has controlled the islands since 1895, but China says it has a long history of control over them. The dispute flared up again last month when Japan bought some of the islands from a private owner. China sent ships to the area in response, and the two sides have been engaged in a series of diplomatic protests ever since. The latest protest is likely to further strain relations between the two countries. It comes at a time when there is already tension between them over a number of issues, including trade and China's growing military power. The dispute over the islands is also seen as a test of Abe's resolve to stand up to China. Abe has taken a more hawkish stance on foreign policy than his predecessor, and he has promised to defend Japan's territory. However, he is also aware of the need to maintain good relations with China, which is Japan's largest trading partner. The protest over the ships is a sign that Abe is willing to take a tough line with China, but it is also likely to be a calculated risk. If the dispute escalates, it could have serious consequences for both countries.

title: Ipswich Town 1981 Uefa Cup victory exhibition
text: The club and Ipswich Museum have gathered together photos, video and memorabilia at the Town Hall Galleries. It includes the famous Gotcha! banner which was unfurled by fans during the match against Cologne at Portman Road. The exhibition also features the original Uefa Cup trophy on loan at Ipswich Town FC from Uefa. The exhibition is the highlight of a weekend of celebration of the 40th anniversary of the Uefa Cup win. On Saturday, there will be a screening of Blues Brothers, the film that the players watched on the eve of the match, at the Regent Theatre. On Sunday, former players and manager Bobby Robson will be guests of honour at a special church service at St Mary-le-Tower, the town centre church that overlooks the Town Hall. "This is a major milestone in the history of the club and we are grateful to everyone who has helped put on this exhibition at short notice. "It will be a great opportunity for fans old and new to learn more about the history of the club and celebrate the 40th anniversary of our greatest achievement. "It was a remarkable achievement for a small club like Ipswich to win a major European trophy, and it is something that the people of Ipswich can be proud of. "We hope that as many people as possible come to Portman Road to see the exhibition and join us in celebrating this historic anniversary." The exhibition runs until 23 May and is free to enter. The Town Hall Galleries are open from 10am to 4pm, Monday to Saturday. A commemorative book, Uefa Cup Winners 1981 published by Ipswich Town FC, is also on sale at the museum and the club shop, priced at £19.99.

title: Wales' child safety 'needs more co-ordination ,' says charity
text: On top of this, the report calls for a "whole-government approach to child accident prevention" with road and water safety the priorities, as well as home safety. The charity is also promoting 'play safety zones' where children can play freely without the risk of traffic, and for reduced speed limits around schools and other places where young people gather. The report also found that: • More than 30% of parents said they do not feel confident giving first aid to their children. • 300 children under 15 in Wales die or are seriously injured in accidents every year. • Accidents in the home account for almost a fifth of deaths or serious injuries among Welsh children. The NSPCC Cymru/Wales conducted an opinion poll among 1,000 parents in Wales of children aged 0-14, and gathered their experiences of accidents and safety concerns. The charity's head of service for Wales, Des Mannion, said: "Children learn from their experiences and accidents can happen when they are exploring their surroundings and trying out new things. "But we can prevent many childhood accidents from happening at all, and we can also reduce the severity of injuries by taking steps to make the places where children live and play safer. "All parents can follow our simple advice to help prevent accidents, but more action is needed from government and professionals to make our communities safer for all children. "This means improved training for staff working with children, a greater focus on road safety by local authorities and more resources for initiatives to educate parents and children about safety issues." A Welsh government spokesman said: "We welcome the NSPCC's report and share its aims of reducing the number of accidents involving children in Wales. "We have already introduced a number of measures to improve child safety, including reducing the default speed limit on restricted roads to 20 mph, and we are committed to working with our partners to further improve child safety in Wales." The Welsh government has also recently launched a new road safety campaign, 'Be Safe, Be Seen', which is aimed at reducing the number of children killed or seriously injured on the roads. The campaign is urging parents to ensure that their children are visible to drivers when they are out and about, by wearing bright clothing and using reflective materials.

title: Sydney seaplane crash: Wreckage raised from riverbed
text: On Sunday, high-profile UK business leader Richard Cousins, four members of his family and a Canadian pilot died when the plane plunged into a river. After days of planning, police used divers and a crane to lift the wreckage of the seaplane from the Hawkesbury River, north of Sydney, on Friday. The plane was raised from about 50m (165ft) underwater. The bodies of those on board were not found inside, but it is hoped the operation will help police determine how the crash occurred. The seaplane had been travelling from Sydney to Rose Bay when it crashed on New Year's Eve. Australian police said the plane was lifted slowly out of the water at a rate of 3m (10ft) per hour, with the process being delayed by the need to clear debris from the riverbed. Once the wreckage was raised, it was taken to a facility where it will be stored until further forensic examination can be carried out. Police divers had previously recovered the plane's fuselage and one of its floats, but the main body of the aircraft remained submerged. The crash is being investigated by Australian authorities. Preliminary findings suggest the plane sent out a distress signal before crashing, but it is not yet known what caused the incident. The victims have been identified as Mr Cousins, 58, his partner Emma Bowden, 48, his two sons Edward, 23, and William, 25, his daughter Sophie, 22, and the pilot Gareth Morgan, 44. Mr Cousins was the former chief executive of Compass Group, a UK-based food services multinational. He was also a director of the BBC and a former member of the UK government's Business Advisory Group. Paying tribute to him, Prime Minister Theresa May described him as "a great British business leader". "He was a passionate advocate for business and his contribution to the UK economy was immense," she said. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) is also investigating the crash. It is expected to release a preliminary report into the incident within the next six to eight weeks.

title: Covid: North East hospitals warn over 'rapidly rising' admissions
text: Gateshead's Queen Elizabeth Hospital has temporarily suspended non-urgent elective surgery to free up staff. In a joint statement, the bosses of several health trusts said they were having to deal with "rapidly rising" numbers of covid-related admissions. The number of Covid patients in North East hospitals has increased by 50% in the last week, with 1,118 people now being treated. The bosses of the Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, the Northumbria Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust, South Tyneside and Sunderland NHS Foundation Trust and the County Durham and Darlington NHS Foundation Trust said the rise was putting "significant pressure" on the region's hospitals. "We are seeing a rapidly rising number of patients with COVID-19 and this is having a significant impact on our hospitals," they said. "As a result, we have had to make the difficult decision to temporarily suspend non-urgent elective surgery at Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Gateshead. "This will allow us to free up staff to care for the increasing number of patients with COVID-19. "We understand that this will be disappointing for patients who have been waiting for surgery, but we hope they will understand that this is a necessary step to ensure that we can continue to provide safe and effective care for all of our patients." The bosses said they were doing everything they could to increase the number of beds available for COVID-19 patients and were working with other NHS organisations in the region to ensure that patients could be transferred to the most appropriate hospital. They urged people to continue to follow the government's advice on social distancing, wearing face masks in indoor public places, and getting vaccinated. "The best way to protect yourself and others from COVID-19 is to get vaccinated," they said. "We would urge everyone who is eligible to get vaccinated as soon as possible."

title: Covid: Swansea Bay and Hywel Dda health boards offer tests for 'flu symptoms'
text: People in the Swansea Bay and Hywel Dda health board areas with flu symptoms or who are unwell after contact with a confirmed Covid case can get tested. People are being urged to take up the offer even if they have had a negative Covid test in the past. The director of public health for Hywel Dda, Dr Brendan Mason, said: “We would encourage people to get tested for both flu and Covid-19 this winter, particularly if they have any symptoms, as it will help to protect both themselves and their loved ones.” Cwm Taf Morgannwg is offering mass testing for anyone over the age of 16 who lives in the county borough. The testing is being carried out at walk-in test centres in Aberdare, Merthyr and Mountain Ash. The leader of Rhondda Cynon Taf council, Andrew Morgan, said: “We strongly encourage everyone who can get tested to do so.” The Welsh government announced earlier this week that everyone over the age of 65 in Wales will be offered a free flu vaccine this winter. The health minister, Vaughan Gething, said: “I urge everyone who is eligible to take up the offer of a free flu vaccine.” The flu vaccine is the best way to protect yourself against the flu. It is safe and effective, and it can help to reduce your risk of getting the flu by up to 60%. If you do get the flu, the vaccine can help to reduce the severity of your symptoms. The NHS is also offering free flu vaccines to people who are pregnant, have a long-term health condition, or are in a care home. You can book an appointment for a flu vaccine at your GP surgery or local pharmacy. The flu virus can be spread through coughing, sneezing, or close contact with someone who is infected. Symptoms of the flu can include fever, chills, muscle aches, headaches, and fatigue. The flu can be a serious illness, and it can lead to hospitalisation or even death. If you have any symptoms of the flu, it is important to stay at home and get tested.

title: Canada's 'free the beer' case loses in Supreme Court
text: Canada's top court upheld a New Brunswick liquor law limiting the amount of alcohol that can be carried across its provincial border. In 2012, Gerald Comeau was stopped and fined for bringing more than the 12-pint maximum into the province. He challenged the law, arguing that it violated his mobility rights under the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. However, the Supreme Court ruled 6-3 against Comeau, finding that the law was a valid exercise of the province's authority to regulate alcohol sales. The Court found that the law was aimed at protecting public health and safety by reducing the risk of alcohol-related harm. It noted that New Brunswick has a higher rate of alcohol-related deaths and hospitalizations than other provinces. The Court also found that the law was not overly restrictive, as it allowed individuals to bring a reasonable amount of alcohol into the province for personal use. The Court's decision is a blow to those who advocate for the free movement of alcohol across provincial borders. However, it is also a reminder that provinces have the authority to regulate alcohol sales in order to protect public health and safety. The decision is also likely to have implications for other provinces that have similar laws. For example, Nova Scotia has a law that limits the amount of alcohol that can be brought into the province to 12 pints of beer, 12 ounces of spirits, or 1.5 litres of wine. It is possible that this law could also be challenged in court. The Supreme Court's decision is a complex one that weighs the individual's right to mobility against the province's right to regulate alcohol sales. Ultimately, the Court found that the province's interest in protecting public health and safety outweighed the individual's right to bring more alcohol into the province.

title: China jails two more Tibetan monks over fire death
text: Chinese authorities say the man, Rigzin Phuntsog of the Kirti monastery, immolated himself on 16 March. Tsering Tenzin and Tenchum will be jailed for 13 and 10 years respectively for "intentional homicide", Xinhua reported. The pair protested against Beijing's rule in Tibet, as well as China's treatment of the Dalai Lama, who fled Tibet in 1959 following a failed uprising against Chinese rule and now lives in India. The court heard the monks had spread leaflets and set fire to Tsering Tenzin's house to lure police to the scene, Xinhua reported. The monks had given Rigzin Phuntsog petrol and a lighter, the report said. The court was told that Tsering Tenzin "felt ashamed" after police put out the fire at his home. "But he and Tenchum encouraged the victim to continue carrying out his self-immolation action, which resulted in the victim setting himself on fire again," Xinhua news agency reported. The court said it had taken into consideration the fact that the pair had confessed and pleaded guilty. The verdict comes as Beijing is stepping up security in Tibetan areas after reports of several self-immolations. Chinese state media said troops have been deployed in the Tibetan area of Kardze, where there were five self-immolations over the last month. Meanwhile, in London, the protesters outside the Chinese embassy clashed with police as they tried to enter the building. About 150 members of the Tibetan community and their supporters were demonstrating against the jailing of the monks. The protesters shouted slogans and waved Tibetan flags and placards before police moved in to push them back. The demonstrators said they were angry about the sentences and wanted the Chinese government to respect Tibetan rights. "We are here to protest against the unlawful arrest and imprisonment of the two Tibetan monks," said Karma Yeshi, a spokesman for the Tibetan Community in the UK. "They have been charged with intentional homicide, which is a serious charge, but they are innocent," he said. "The Chinese authorities have failed to provide any evidence to support the charges and we believe they have been jailed for their peaceful protests against China's oppressive rule in Tibet."

title: Jack Phillips: Boy from Godalming became Titanic hero
text: By Sally Nancarrow BBC News, Surrey The son of a draper, Jack Phillips operated the most modern and powerful wireless equipment of any merchant ship of the time. But before the doomed vessel sailed, he learnt it was to be called Titanic rather than Olympic. The ships were often confused, as they were almost identical sister ships built by Harland and Wolff in Belfast. Born in Godalming, Surrey, the son of a draper, Phillips joined the Royal Naval Reserve, but suffered from seasickness so became a wireless operator instead. Aged 25, and just two months into his first job as a radio operator on the Amerika, he was called up to join the Titanic. Phillips was one of the two wireless operators on board and the only one to survive the sinking. For over 70 years after the ship hit an iceberg and sank on the night of 14 April 1912, it was believed that Phillips had gone down with the ship. But in 1985, his body was identified in a Nova Scotia cemetery. His grave bears an inscription reading: "In loving memory of Jack Phillips, wireless operator on the ill-fated SS Titanic, who gave his life in the service of others." 'A Titanic struggle' Some 80 years after his death, Phillips's great-nephew, Ian Phillips, a retired police officer from Farnham, Surrey, wrote a book, A Titanic Struggle, about his life and death. "I grew up knowing about Jack. He was a bit of a hero," he told the BBC. "When I started researching his life, I was particularly struck by his tenacity and his determination to complete a task. "He finished sending that final distress call, which led to lifeboats being despatched to help some of the passengers survive." Phillips tirelessly tried to get a distress message out. One of the last messages sent was: "Come at once. We have struck a berg." He stayed at his post in the Marconi wireless room despite taking time to put on a lifejacket. Phillips may have lived if he had got into a lifeboat, as his body was found with a lifejacket on. The Marconi wireless room was on the port side of the Titanic and therefore most exposed to the freezing water when the ship sank. His body was among the first to be recovered, just six days after the ship went down. Phillips was buried in Fairview cemetery in Halifax, Nova Scotia, where many of the Titanic dead were laid to rest, but his body was exhumed in 1985. DNA testing was used to positively identify his remains, which were reburied in the same plot. Phillips's story was brought to life again in the 1997 James Cameron film Titanic. The character Harold Bride, who sent the final distress call, was based partly on Phillips. His great-nephew believes Phillips has been undervalued in the aftermath of the Titanic disaster. "He was a Godalming boy who achieved international fame and has been largely forgotten," said Ian Phillips.

title: Church of England schools tackle gay bullying
text: The Bible or religious texts should not be used to justify homophobic behaviour, says the advice sent to all Church of England schools. But homosexuality is recognised as a "divisive issue" in the church. The guidance says that all pupils, staff, and visitors should be treated with dignity and respect, regardless of their sexual orientation. It adds that schools should: - Create a welcoming and inclusive environment for all students - Challenge homophobic behaviour and language - Support students who are experiencing homophobic bullying - Work with parents and carers to promote understanding and acceptance "We want to make it clear that there is no place for homophobia in our schools. We want to create a safe and welcoming environment where all pupils feel respected and valued," said Nigel Genders, chief education officer for the Church of England. In recent years, the Church of England has come under increasing pressure to clarify its stance on homosexuality. In 2017, the General Synod, the church's governing body, voted to reject a motion that would have allowed same-sex couples to marry in church. The decision was met with disappointment by many LGBT+ Christians and their supporters. It also led to calls for the church to do more to tackle homophobia in its schools. The new guidance is a step in the right direction. It sends a clear message that homophobia is not tolerated in Church of England schools. It also provides schools with practical guidance on how to create a more welcoming and inclusive environment for all students. However, the guidance does not go as far as some LGBT+ campaigners would like. For example, it does not require schools to teach about same-sex relationships in a positive way. Despite these limitations, the guidance is a welcome step forward. It shows that the Church of England is taking the issue of homophobia in schools seriously. It also provides schools with the tools they need to create a more welcoming and inclusive environment for all students.

title: Covid-19: University of Exeter virtual protests over 'lost' student experience
text: By Adam Durbin BBC News Online University of Exeter student Bella Enoizi's petition has more than 20,000 signatures. The petition cited "screen-sharing malfunctions, audio loss and Wi-Fi connectivity" in online learning as key concerns, prompting the creation of a campaign group called, "Not Exeter." The group is calling for a rent freeze and a "no detriment" policy for all students, along with financial support for students who are having to self-isolate. The university said it was "disappointed" by the virtual protests and that it was "confident that the vast majority of our students feel supported and positive about their learning experiences." The protests come as universities across the UK face criticism for their handling of the pandemic. Students at several other universities have also staged protests over issues such as rent, online learning, and mental health support. The National Union of Students (NUS) has called on the government to provide more financial support to students and to ensure that universities are providing a high-quality education online. The government has said that it is committed to supporting students during the pandemic and has announced a number of measures, including a £256m package of support for students in financial hardship. However, the NUS has said that more needs to be done to ensure that all students are able to access the support they need. The University of Exeter said it was "committed to providing a high-quality education for all of our students" and that it was "working hard to address the challenges posed by the pandemic." The university said it had invested in online learning resources and that it was providing additional support for students who are struggling with their studies. The university also said it was working with the government and the NUS to ensure that students are getting the support they need.

title: Justin Bieber treated by doctors after O2 Arena concert
text: Melissa Victor said the Canadian singer took a 20-minute rest before returning to the stage to finish the show. The 19-year-old star was performing the third night of his three-date "Believe" tour in London. "Justin came off stage after performing for about an hour and seemed to be struggling a bit," said Victor, who was standing near the stage. "He was breathing heavily and looked like he was going to pass out." "He walked off stage and I could hear a lot of people in the crowd saying, 'Oh my God, he's going to be sick'," she added. A spokesperson for the O2 Arena said: "Justin Bieber paused his show last night due to feeling unwell. He received medical treatment and returned to the stage to complete the show." The spokesperson added that Bieber was "feeling fine" after the show and that he had been taken to hospital as a precaution. The singer's representative said Bieber had been suffering from a cold and flu for the past few days. "He was determined to perform for his fans and he did," the representative said. title: Swine flu offers 'extraordinary super immunity'
text: By Michelle Roberts Health reporter, BBC News In beating a bout of H1N1 the body makes antibodies that can kill many other flu strains, a study in the Journal of Experimental Medicine shows. Doctors' hopes of developing an effective universal flu vaccine have been boosted by the discovery that natural infection with swine flu produces antibodies which can tackle many different strains of the virus. Flu is caused by an influenza virus that is constantly changing. This means the body needs to be exposed to a new vaccine every year. But scientists have been trying to develop a universal vaccine that would offer protection against all strains of flu. Now a study by researchers at Imperial College London and the US National Institutes of Health suggests that a Bout of H1N1 could act like a universal vaccine. They found that people who had recovered from swine flu developed antibodies that were able to recognise the 'stalk' of different strains of flu. The stalk portion of the influenza virus is well conserved, meaning that it does not change much from one strain to the next. This means that an antibody that can recognise the stalk can potentially kill a wide range of flu strains. Dr Michael Farzan, one of the authors of the study, said: "We were very excited to find out that antibodies from individuals infected with H1N1 can neutralise these viruses, which belong to different subtypes and have different hemagglutinin proteins. "This means that natural infection could induce a form of cross-immunity that we have not seen before with other flus." Participants who recovered from H1N1 were able to generate antibodies that neutralised the H1N1 virus they had been exposed to, but also the strains of flu virus involved in the Spanish flu pandemic of 1918, the bird flu strain, H5N1, and two other strains of H1N1 swine flu. The researchers say that the study offers hope for developing a universal flu vaccine. "This is a promising finding for the development of universal flu vaccines because it suggests that boosting antibodies to the influenza virus stalk could protect against viruses that may be very different from those encountered in the past," said Dr Farzan. However, the researchers caution that it will take many years of research to develop, test and refine a universal flu vaccine that is safe and effective. "We need to understand a little bit more about how these antibodies are induced by natural infection," said Dr Farzan. "But I think that this is a lead that we will pursue for our research going forward."

title: Wanted: PA to the Duchess
text: Because the Duchess of Cambridge is looking for a new private secretary. Her current assistant, 34-year-old Rebecca Deacon, is stepping down after working in the role for over five years. The Duchess's office is now beginning the search for a new PA, who will be responsible for managing her diary, organising meetings and engagements, and providing general administrative support. The ideal candidate will have a strong academic background, excellent organisational and time management skills, and be able to work both independently and as part of a team. They will also need to be discreet, have impeccable communication skills, and be able to maintain confidentiality. The job is based at Kensington Palace, London, and will require some travel. The salary is commensurate with experience and qualifications. To apply for the role, please send your CV and a covering letter to [email protected] The closing date for applications is 24th August 2023. Interview Tips: This is a highly competitive role and only the very best candidates will be shortlisted for interview. If you are fortunate enough to be invited to interview, here are a few tips to help you prepare: - Be yourself. The Duchess is looking for someone who is genuine and authentic. Don't try to be someone you're not. - Be prepared to talk about your experience and skills. The interviewers will want to know what you can bring to the role. Be able to give specific examples of your work history that demonstrate your skills in organisation, time management, and communication. - Be prepared to answer questions about your motivations for applying for the role. Why do you want to work for the Duchess of Cambridge? What do you think you can bring to the role? - Be prepared to ask questions of your own. This shows that you are engaged in the process and interested in the role. - Be professional and respectful. Dress appropriately for the interview and arrive on time. - Be confident. Believe in yourself and your abilities. If you are confident in your abilities, the interviewers will be more likely to be confident in you. Good luck!

title: Saudi Arabia's women vote in election for first time
text: Women were also standing as candidates, another first, despite the conservative kingdom being the only nation where women are not allowed to drive. A total of 978 women have registered as candidates in 13 of the country's 13 regions, competing for 20 seats allocated for women in the 150-member assembly. Among them is Samia al-Bakri, a 46-year-old running in the Red Sea city of Jeddah. "I am so proud of this moment. I have waited long for this," she said before the first round of voting on December 12. The female candidates represent a range of backgrounds and expertise, including doctors, lawyers, teachers, and businesswomen. Their decision to stand for election reflects a growing desire among Saudi women to have a greater role in public life. "Women's participation in the elections is a significant milestone in the history of Saudi Arabia," said Dr. Hala al-Dosari, a prominent Saudi women's rights activist. "It sends a message that women are just as capable as men to contribute to the decision-making process." The local elections are part of a wider process of reforms initiated by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who has sought to modernize the country and improve its image abroad. However, women's rights activists have criticized the government for not doing enough to address other restrictions on women, such as the driving ban and the male guardianship system that requires women to have permission from a male relative to travel, work, or study. Despite these limitations, many Saudi women are optimistic that the local elections will be a positive step towards greater equality. "This is just the beginning," said Aisha al-Mana, a 25-year-old voter. "We have a long way to go, but we are moving in the right direction." The elections are also being closely watched by other countries in the region, where women's rights are often severely restricted. The participation of Saudi women in the political process could inspire similar reforms elsewhere. The local elections are an important step forward for women's rights in Saudi Arabia. While there is still much work to be done, the participation of women in the political process is a sign of progress. It is hoped that these elections will lead to greater equality and representation for women in the kingdom.

title: Life-extending lung cancer nivolumab drug approved
text: Campaigners, including the late Sunday Times restaurant critic AA Gill, have repeatedly called for access to the immunotherapy, which can add months to life. Scotland already provides the drug through its health service. Prof Charles Swanton, chief clinician at Cancer Research UK, said: "We strongly welcome this announcement which will save lives, and it is an important moment for UK cancer care. "For too long, patients in England have faced unnecessary delays in getting access to nivolumab. Now, they will benefit from the same level of care as those in countries such as Scotland and Wales. "Nivolumab demonstrates the transformational power of cancer immunotherapy. It is a new type of cancer treatment that uses the body's own immune system to fight cancer cells. "Nivolumab has shown great promise in clinical trials, and it is already helping thousands of patients with lung cancer and other types of cancer around the world. "We look forward to seeing the NHS quickly implementing the use of nivolumab so that all patients who could benefit from it can access it as soon as possible." Dr Alex Stewart, Cancer Research UK's head of population science, said: "This is excellent news for patients with advanced lung cancer in England. "Nivolumab has been shown to improve survival in patients with this type of cancer, and it is a welcome addition to the range of treatments available to them. "We hope that the NHS will now quickly implement the use of nivolumab so that all patients who could benefit from it can access it as soon as possible." The approval of nivolumab for advanced lung cancer in England is a significant step forward in the fight against cancer. This new treatment offers hope to patients with this devastating disease, and it is a testament to the power of research and innovation.

title: UK to probe Huawei staff's role at cybersecurity centre
text: The news follows a report by Parliament's intelligence committee which raised concerns that staff working at the base in Oxfordshire were employed by the Chinese telecoms firm. Part of their job is to test Huawei's own equipment. The government has said it will now conduct its own investigation into the matter. A spokesperson for the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport said: "We are aware of the report by the Intelligence and Security Committee of Parliament and we are considering its findings." The report, which was published on Tuesday, said that the government had "failed to take account of the national security risks" of allowing Huawei to work at the centre. It also said that the government had "not properly considered" the potential for Huawei to use its access to the centre to gather intelligence. The government has defended its decision to allow Huawei to work at the centre, saying that the company is a "valued partner" in the UK's telecommunications industry. However, the report's findings have raised concerns about the government's approach to cybersecurity. The report comes at a time when the UK is facing increasing pressure from the US to ban Huawei from its 5G networks. The US has accused Huawei of being a security risk, and has urged its allies to do the same. The UK government has so far resisted pressure from the US, but the report's findings could make it more difficult for the government to continue to support Huawei. The report's findings are likely to fuel the debate about the role of Chinese companies in the UK's critical infrastructure. The government will need to carefully consider the report's findings and decide how to respond.

title: UK government to press for European Court reform
text: Ken Clarke said the government would press for changes to the way the court operated when the UK takes over the chairmanship of the Council of Europe. Speaking on the Andrew Marr show, he said the UK had been “too quick” to condemn the court in the past and should now focus on reforming it from within. The court has been criticized for being too slow, too expensive, and too political. Clarke said the government would propose changes to make the court more efficient and less bureaucratic. He also said the UK would push for the court to be given more powers to enforce its rulings. The Council of Europe is a 47-member organization that promotes human rights, democracy, and the rule of law. The UK will take over the chairmanship of the organization in November. Clarke's comments come after a number of high-profile cases in which the court has ruled against the UK government. In 2012, the court ruled that the UK's blanket ban on prisoners voting was unlawful. In 2014, the court ruled that the UK government had failed to protect the rights of a man who was killed by police. The government has argued that these rulings show that the court is out of touch with the British public. However, Clarke said the government should not simply withdraw from the court, but should instead work to reform it from within. He said: “We have been too quick to condemn the court. We should now focus on reforming it from within. The UK has a long history of upholding human rights and the rule of law. We should be at the forefront of efforts to strengthen the European Court of Human Rights.” Clarke's comments were welcomed by human rights groups. Amnesty International UK said: “Ken Clarke is right to say that the UK should not simply withdraw from the European Court of Human Rights. The court plays a vital role in protecting human rights across Europe.” Liberty said: “We welcome Ken Clarke's commitment to reforming the European Court of Human Rights. The court is an essential part of the UK's human rights framework and we will work with the government to ensure that it remains effective.”
