title: Pensioner liable for Donald Trump golf court expenses
text: US tycoon Mr Trump hopes to build the "world's greatest golf resort" at Menie, north of Aberdeen. Molly Forbes, 86, and her 84-year-old husband Ian live in a modest stone-built cottage next door to the proposed site of the luxury development. The couple has been told they could face a legal bill of up to £100,000 after formally objecting to Mr Trump's plans. They are among 12 people who have lodged challenges with the Scottish government against the development. The Forbeses say they cannot afford the legal costs they have already incurred and have appealed for financial help. They fear they could lose their home if they are forced to pay the full amount. "We're terrified," said Mrs Forbes. "We don't know where we're going to find that sort of money. We've never had to pay legal fees before." The Forbeses are not the only ones facing potential legal costs. Another objector, David Milne, has already been ordered to pay £15,000 in costs after losing a legal challenge against Mr Trump. Mr Milne, a retired teacher, said he was "disgusted" by the prospect of having to pay such a large sum of money. "It's a disgrace," he said. "I'm just an ordinary guy who was trying to stand up for what I believe in. I shouldn't be punished for that." Mr Trump has defended his legal action against his opponents, saying he is entitled to protect his business interests. "These people are trying to stop me from building a world-class golf resort," he said. "I'm not going to let them get away with it." The Scottish government is currently considering the objections to Mr Trump's plans. A decision is expected later this year. If the plans are approved, the Forbeses will be forced to sell their cottage and move out. They say they have no idea where they will go. "We've lived here for 50 years," said Mrs Forbes. "It's our home. We don't want to leave."

title: City of Culture: Leicester 'disappointed but defiant'
text: A "desperately disappointed" Peter Soulsby congratulated Hull and said it perhaps needed the regeneration more. He said he had previously believed Leicester was not up for the bid but had been proved wrong in "the most extraordinary way." The "heartbroken" Labour leader said: "I am proud of the campaign that we have run. We have made history in Leicester. When I started out, I didn't believe that Leicester was up for this bid. I have been proved wrong in the most extraordinary way. "The people of Leicester have shown what wonderful, warm-hearted, delightful and aspirational people they are. We have come together as a city and as a county as never before. "I wish Hull all the very best and I hope that this will indeed be the start of a renaissance for that great city. "Hull clearly needed - perhaps more than we did - the regeneration, the renaissance and the boost that this title has brought. And I am absolutely certain that they will make a great job of it. I hope that they will take the crown with good grace and I wish them well." Sir Peter, who admitted he felt "heartbroken" and "let down", said that despite not winning the contest, Leicester's campaign had brought the city together. He said: "Let us stay together in this unity and this spirit of co-operation that we have found over this campaign period. We have shown what we can do. "Let's resolve to go on and make this a better city, a great city for everybody to live in." Leicester's bid featured plans for a huge Diwali festival, transforming the city into a "beacon of light" and a "model of diversity". There were also plans for a 120-metre high "Helix" sculpture, a seven-day "River of Light" festival, a new Shakespeare centre and a new "cultural quarter" in the city centre. The city's bid had the support of celebrities including Leicester City manager Claudio Ranieri, comedian Ross Noble and Take That star Gary Barlow. It had also been backed by the county council and local businesses. Leicester's bid was one of six shortlisted for the title, alongside Hull, Dundee, Perth, Swansea Bay and the Great Yarmouth and Lowestoft area. Hull was eventually crowned as the winner of the title, with its bid promising a "once-in-a-lifetime transformation" of the city.

title: Kent's festivals set to draw large crowds this summer
text: By Andrew Parry BBC Kent In fact, we have more festivals than most down in the sunny south-east. From farms to parks, hills to zoos, no large space of land is safe from festival fever. Lounge on the Farm kicks off the main festival season in the county. Set in the beautiful surroundings of Merton Farm in Maidstone, it offers not only a great range of live music but also an array of street food and craft stalls. The week after Lounge, hip-hop will be taking over the Dreamland amusement park in Margate as part of Margate Soul Weekender. The three-day event will feature dozens of live acts, soul-star DJs, live art and street food. More music will follow just a week or so later at Folkestone Fringe, a scaled-down version of the town's much-loved Folkestone Book Festival, which takes place in the autumn. Music and comedy have always been a major part of Folkestone Fringe, but this year there will be plenty of other entertainment too, including science talks, nature walks and life drawing. If laughter is what you're after, then the Canterbury Festival is hosting a lineup of comedians as part of its annual month-long celebration of the arts. Taking place at venues across the city, the festival is once again promising a varied and exciting program of shows to suit all tastes. Not far from Canterbury is the small town of Tenterden, which is set to hold its first-ever Tenterden Folk Festival. Set in the beautiful gardens of Tenterden Recreation Ground, the one-day festival will welcome a variety of folk acts, as well as street food stalls and a real ale bar. This summer will also see the 20th anniversary of Hop Farm Festival. Taking place at the Hop Farm Country Park in Paddock Wood, it's one of the UK's biggest music festivals. This year's lineup includes acts such as McFly, The Fratellis and Rudimental. Away from the music, there will be comedy, street theatre, circus skills, family entertainment and a whole host of food stalls. And finally, for those who like their festivals with a touch of history, Dover Castle is hosting its first-ever Castle Concerts event. Taking place across three nights in August, the concerts will feature classical music, jazz and folk, with performances taking place in the castle's historic setting.

title: Sunday Times Rich List suggests UK's wealthiest defy recession
text: The newspaper's research found the combined worth of the country's 1,000 wealthiest people is £414bn, up 4.7%. It means their joint wealth has passed the level last seen in 2008, before the financial crisis, and is 25% above its level a decade ago. The Sunday Times Rich List attributes much of the surge in wealth to the performance of the stock market during the pandemic, which has lifted the value of many businesses. The list's compiler, Robert Watts, said: "The stock market has been the big driver this year. Those with big share portfolios have done very well indeed." The biggest winner on the list is James Dyson, the inventor and owner of the eponymous vacuum cleaner company. His wealth has increased by £3.2bn to £23bn, making him the richest person in the UK for the first time. Dyson is followed on the list by brothers Sri and Gopi Hinduja, whose wealth has increased by £2.4bn to £21.5bn, and Sir Len Blavatnik, whose wealth has increased by £2.3bn to £20bn. The Sunday Times Rich List also highlights the growing wealth of those in the technology sector. The co-founders of online supermarket Ocado, Tim Steiner and Jason Gissing, have seen their wealth increase by a combined £1.3bn to £3.3bn. Meanwhile, the wealth of Alex Chesterman, the founder of property website Zoopla, has increased by £1bn to £2.5bn. Despite the overall increase in wealth, the number of billionaires in the UK has fallen from 171 last year to 147 this year. This is due in part to the falling value of sterling against other currencies, particularly the US dollar. The Sunday Times Rich List is a snapshot of the wealth of the UK's richest people at a particular point in time. title: University of Nottingham rent protesters offered 'support package'
text: Hundreds of University of Nottingham students called for rents to be suspended when they were unable to return due to national restrictions. Now the university has said support will be available to some. The university has announced a "support package" which will include a rent rebate for students who were unable to return to halls of residence during the November and December national lockdown and a hardship fund for those who are struggling to pay their rent. The rent rebate will be for the 11 weeks of the November and December lockdown and will be paid to students who were unable to return to halls of residence during that period. The hardship fund will be available to students who are struggling to pay their rent, regardless of whether they were able to return to halls of residence during the lockdown. The university said it had made the decision after listening to feedback from students and the Students' Union. The Students' Union said it welcomed the "positive steps" the university had taken but said it would continue to push for rent to be suspended for all students. The university said it was committed to supporting its students during the pandemic and would continue to monitor the situation and make changes to its support package as necessary. The announcement of the support package comes after months of campaigning by students for rent suspensions. In November, over 1,000 students signed a petition calling for rents to be suspended. The Students' Union also held a series of protests, including a rent strike. The university has said it hopes the support package will help students who are struggling financially during this difficult time. It is important to note that this support package is not available to all students. title: Covid anxiety: Child 'asking if he's going to die'
text: By Sarah Easedale BBC Wales news Jane Griffiths, 47, said her four children had all been affected by the stress of the pandemic. "My eldest two haven't shown any obvious signs of anxiety but our two youngest have been very affected," she said. "My youngest says 'is it going to kill me?' and if I cough or sneeze he runs in fear." Mrs Griffiths, from Mold, Flintshire, says they, like many families, have been through a lot of upheaval in the past year with all four children being off school for months and not seeing their friends. "But I do also think there seems to be a lot of scaremongering out there about Covid and that has fuelled their fears," she added. "My husband is a nurse and despite all the reassurances he gives them, they still worry." Emma Thomas, from Llanelli, Carmarthenshire, is a single mum to nine-year-old Mia. She said her daughter - who has type 1 diabetes - had become very anxious during the pandemic, with her blood sugar levels rising as a result. "Mia's blood sugar levels are usually very stable but when she started to get anxious we saw her blood sugars start to rise and we had to increase her insulin," she said. "She's also started asking questions like 'mum, am I going to get Covid?' and 'am I going to die?' and it's heartbreaking as I'm trying to reassure her but also have to be mindful of not dismissing her concerns." She added: "I feel her anxiety has been fed by the media. I have a lot of friends who work in the NHS and I know it's been really tough but I don't think all of the reporting reflects that." Dr Nicola Davies, consultant clinical psychologist for Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services (CAMHS) at Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board, said children's anxiety had been amplified by the pandemic. "Many children and young people are anxious about the pandemic and how it's affecting their lives and those around them," she said. "Some children may also experience physical symptoms such as stomach aches and headaches. It's important for parents and carers to take their child's worries seriously and to reassure them that they are safe." Dr Davies said parents and carers can help children cope with anxiety by: Talking to them about their concerns and answering their questions honestly and reassuringly Helping them to develop coping mechanisms, such as relaxation techniques Limiting their exposure to news and social media about the pandemic Seeking professional help if their anxiety is severe or persistent If you are concerned about your child's mental health, you can contact your GP or local CAMHS team.

title: Power at Fukushima nuclear fuel ponds restored
text: A power cut shut down cooling systems for four spent fuel ponds at reactors 1, 3 and 4 on Monday evening, although cooling was restored two hours later. This is the latest in a series of problems since the massive earthquake and tsunami of 2011 destroyed the plant's cooling systems. The operator, Tokyo Electric Power Co (Tepco), said the power outage was caused by a fault with an electrical switch. A Tepco spokesman said the switch was damaged in the 2011 disaster and had been replaced, but still malfunctioned. He said the company was investigating the cause of the failure and working to prevent a recurrence. The ponds are not currently leaking and there is no immediate threat to the public, Tepco said. The ponds contain used fuel rods, which generate heat even after they have been removed from the reactors. The rods are covered with water to keep them cool and prevent them from overheating. If the water level were to drop too low, the rods could be exposed to air, which could cause them to catch fire. The power cut lasted for about two hours, and cooling was restored at all four ponds by 21:00 local time (12:00 GMT). Tepco admitted that it had allowed safety standards to slip in the months leading up to the 2011 disaster, which killed nearly 16,000 people. Following the 2011 disaster, the plant was closed and its operator, Tepco, has been struggling to decommission it. The plant is so badly damaged that it is expected to take decades to decommission, and the cost is expected to reach tens of billions of dollars. In the meantime, the vast majority of the plant's 26,000 spent fuel rods remain in cooling ponds, which are themselves vulnerable to earthquakes and other natural disasters. The power cut at the plant highlights the ongoing challenges of decommissioning the plant and the importance of ensuring the safety of the spent fuel rods.

title: Macedonia parliament votes to start name change process
text: Two-thirds of the chamber - 80 of 120 deputies - backed the start of the process, the requisite majority to start the move. Several more votes will be needed before the changes can be ratified, including a public referendum. The move is the culmination of years of negotiations between Macedonia and Greece, which has long objected to its neighbour using the name Macedonia, arguing that it implies territorial claims over its own northern province of the same name. The agreement has been hailed by many as a major breakthrough in relations between the two countries, and could pave the way for Macedonia to join the EU and NATO. However, it has also been met with opposition from some Macedonians, who argue that it amounts to a betrayal of their national identity. Prime Minister Zoran Zaev, who has staked his political future on the deal, said it was a "historic day" for Macedonia. "We are opening a new chapter in our history," he said. "We are building a new future for our children." Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras also welcomed the vote, saying it was a "victory for Europe". "This is a historic day for our region," he said. "We are overcoming the divisions of the past and building a better future for all our citizens." The name change process is expected to take several months to complete. Once it is ratified by the Macedonian parliament and approved in a referendum, it will need to be recognised by the United Nations and other international organisations. The deal has been met with mixed reactions from the international community. The United States and the European Union have welcomed the agreement, but Russia has expressed concerns that it could lead to instability in the region. The name change process is likely to be a complex and challenging one. However, if it is successful, it could have a major impact on the future of Macedonia and the wider Balkans region.

title: What has the UK accomplished in Afghanistan?
text: By Caroline Wyatt Defence correspondent, BBC News This has been the case since George Bush declared America's mission in Iraq over, under a banner that proclaimed 'Mission Accomplished'. The Taliban, Afghanistan's former rulers, seized control of much of the country again just 11 days after the US and UK finally withdrew their remaining 2,500 troops. The then US President Joe Biden said that America's mission was not to nation-build, but to "take down al-Qaeda and to deal with terrorism". And that, he insisted, had been achieved. The UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that the UK's aims in Afghanistan had been achieved too - they were to help the US with its counter-terror mission and to support the Afghan government and train the Afghan army. But while the US and UK have succeeded in removing the Taliban from power for 20 years - and in killing al-Qaeda leader Osama Bin Laden - it is clear from the Taliban's swift return to power that there is still much that remains unfinished. What did the UK achieve in Afghanistan? The UK has been heavily involved in the US-led intervention in Afghanistan for the past two decades. The UK has deployed more than 45,000 troops to Afghanistan since 2001, and has spent more than £40bn on the war effort. The UK's main objectives in Afghanistan have been to: Help the US to defeat the Taliban and al-Qaeda Help to build a stable and democratic Afghanistan Train and support the Afghan National Security Forces (ANSF) The UK has made some progress in achieving these objectives. The Taliban was removed from power in 2001, and the UK has helped to build a number of schools and hospitals in Afghanistan. The UK has also trained and supported the ANSF. However, the Taliban has remained a potent force in Afghanistan, and the country has remained unstable. The UK's withdrawal from Afghanistan in 2021 has raised questions about the long-term impact of the UK's intervention in the country. It is too early to say what the long-term impact of the UK's intervention in Afghanistan will be. However, it is clear that the UK has not achieved all of its objectives in Afghanistan. The UK's withdrawal from Afghanistan has been criticized by some. Critics argue that the UK's withdrawal has left a vacuum that the Taliban has been able to fill. They also argue that the UK's withdrawal has left the Afghan people vulnerable to the Taliban. The UK government has defended its decision to withdraw from Afghanistan. The UK government argues that the UK's objectives in Afghanistan have been achieved, and that it is now time for the Afghan people to take responsibility for their own country.

title: New prostate therapy recommended on NHS
text: New prostate therapy recommended on NHS It's called prostate artery embolisation. And it blocks some of the blood supply to the prostate using tiny synthetic beads, causing the troublesome tissue to shrink and die. Officials say there is "good evidence" the new treatment can relieve symptoms caused by an enlarged prostate, such as problems urinating and needing to go to the toilet frequently. It is recommended for men who aren't suitable for surgery or other treatments, including medication. Prostate artery embolisation (PAE) is carried out under local anaesthetic, usually as a day procedure. A fine tube, called a catheter, is inserted into an artery in the groin and threaded to the prostate. Tiny beads are then released into blood vessels supplying the prostate. The procedure takes about an hour and most people can go home the same day. Around a third of men over 50 experience problems urinating because of an enlarged prostate, known as benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Symptoms include: needing to urinate more often, including at night difficulty starting to urinate a weak flow dribbling after urinating a feeling that the bladder isn't fully empty after urinating Most men with BPH can manage their symptoms with medication. But for those who don't respond to drugs, or who have side-effects, surgery has been the main option. National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (Nice) says PAE is a "clinically and cost-effective option" for these men. The health body said it was "less invasive" than surgery, and was associated with "shorter hospital stays, less pain and fewer complications". "Around 75% of men treated with PAE report an improvement in their symptoms," Nice said. "It is recommended for men for whom surgery is not an option or who prefer a less invasive treatment." The treatment is not suitable for men with certain conditions, such as prostate cancer or a urinary tract infection. It is also not recommended for men with a very large prostate. PAE is also not yet widely available on the NHS, although Nice says it should be offered to all eligible men. The treatment costs around £2,500 privately. Prostate Cancer UK welcomed the recommendation, saying it was "great news" for men with BPH. "For many men, medication is enough to manage their symptoms, but until now surgery was the only real alternative for those whose symptoms are severe or don't respond to drugs," said the charity's head of research, Dr Matthew Hobbs. "PAE could offer a minimally invasive, day-case procedure that can significantly improve symptoms in many of these men, without the need for major surgery."

title: China and US 'agree North Korea nuclear test measures'
text: Unnamed diplomats said a deal was agreed late on Monday and they hoped a draft resolution would be put to the Security Council for a vote on Tuesday. title: Removing school bus chaperones in Birmingham 'dangerous'

title: Climate change: May was sunniest calendar month on record in UK
text: By Roger Harrabin BBC environment analyst The UK enjoyed 266 hours of sunshine in May - surpassing the previous record of 265 hours in June 1957. And it is even more extraordinary following a drenching winter, with record rainfall not seen for a quarter of a century. "It is certainly remarkable," said Dr Mark McCarthy, head of the Met Office's National Climate Information Centre. "The fact that it is the sunniest May on record is pretty exceptional because May is not normally a particularly sunny month, especially compared to June and July." The extreme sunshine has been driven by a combination of high pressure and clear skies over the UK. And while the weather might have brought cheer for many, it has also heightened concerns about the impacts of climate change. The world has already warmed by about 1C since the industrial revolution, mostly as a result of human activities that emit greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide. And climate scientists say that as the world continues to warm, the UK and other countries should expect further extremes in weather, with heatwaves, droughts, floods and storms becoming more frequent and severe. The Met Office says that "under a high emissions scenario", May's record sunshine could be the norm by the end of the century. "If we don't do anything and we continue as we are, then what we would have perceived as extreme as the record sunshine in May could be our new normal," said Mike Kendon, a climate scientist at the Met Office. And it is not just in the UK that extreme weather events are occurring. A series of heatwaves in India and Pakistan have killed hundreds of people and have led to concerns about water shortages. While in the US, the state of California is battling its largest wildfire on record, which has forced tens of thousands of people to flee their homes. The UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has described the worsening climate crisis as "a code red for humanity". And he called on governments to "sound the alarm" and take urgent action to address the issue. The UK government is due to host a major UN climate summit in November, which is likely to be a battleground between countries that are demanding bolder action and those most resistant to change.

title: Trump aide Michael Flynn Jnr out after 'Pizzagate' tweets
text: Michael Flynn, 33, left the US president-elect's transition team on Tuesday following his tweets about the so-called Pizzagate fake news story. His father, Michael Flynn Snr, Mr Trump's pick to be US national security adviser, has also shared viral Pizzagate content on social media. Pizzagate originated as a conspiracy theory that a Washington pizzeria was a front for a child sex trafficking ring run by Hillary Clinton and her campaign chairman John Podesta. The theory spread widely on social media during the election campaign, and a North Carolina man travelled to the pizzeria in December and fired an AR-15 rifle inside, because he believed the conspiracy theory was true. Michael Flynn Jnr's Pizzagate tweets prompted the New York Police Department to post a warning on social media about the "fictitious and unsubstantiated" claims about child trafficking. The White House did not immediately comment on Michael Flynn Jnr's departure, but Mr Trump responded to the controversy on Twitter on Tuesday. He wrote: "Michael Flynn Jr. - despite having an outstanding public record - is being treated very unfairly by the media. I failed to do a proper background check, therefore he is out." Michael Flynn Jnr's departure marks the latest in a series of high-profile departures from Mr Trump's team. His chief strategist Steve Bannon, a key figure in the president-elect's inner circle, was forced to resign last week. Mr Trump's pick for labour secretary, Andrew Puzder, also withdrew his nomination on Tuesday. The controversies surrounding Michael Flynn Jnr and others have raised questions about Mr Trump's ability to staff his administration. He has repeatedly said he wants to "drain the swamp" in Washington, but his picks for key positions have included several figures with controversial backgrounds. It remains to be seen whether Mr Trump can overcome these challenges and assemble a team that is capable of governing effectively.

title: Yardie actor on Idris Elba proposal: I had tears in my eyes
text: By Hannah Moore Newsbeat reporter The 21-year-old has said he was already overwhelmed with emotion to be at the screening of Yardie - and that's before Idris made a special appearance. "I was in the screening and it was a really emotional watch - I had tears in my eyes," said Aml Ameen, who plays the titular character D in the film. "I remember turning around and seeing Idris standing at the back in a cap, so I thought: 'He's here, that's cool.' And then he was like, 'Come on stage.'" After the screening, the audience was treated to a Q&A with Elba and the cast, where Elba revealed he'd asked Ameen to marry him. "When he said that I just turned around and looked at him and I just kind of hugged him and said: 'Yes'," Ameen told Newsbeat. "We kind of joked about it on set. It wasn't like a serious thing, but then he did it and it was amazing. It was just so natural." Elba and Ameen have known each other for years, having worked together on the TV series Luther. "I'd always wanted to work with him and I always wanted to play a character that he created," said Ameen. "I've been a fan of his for so long, so to actually work with him and then for him to be so gracious as to share this moment with me - it meant the world." Yardie is a crime drama set in 1970s Kingston, Jamaica, and London. It follows the story of D, who travels to London to avenge his brother's murder. The film has been praised for its authentic portrayal of Jamaican culture and its exploration of themes such as violence, masculinity and redemption. Ameen said he was drawn to the role of D because of its complexity. "He's a very layered character," he said. "He's a very violent man, but he's also very loving and caring. He's a very complex character and I was really interested in exploring that." Ameen said he hopes Yardie will resonate with audiences around the world. "It's a very universal story," he said. "It's about love, loss, redemption and family. I think it's a story that everyone can relate to."

title: Amnesty calls for GCHQ spying inquiry
text: It said it was "outrageous" that human rights bodies were being monitored. It came after the Investigatory Powers Tribunal (IPT) informed Amnesty that GCHQ had breached rules by keeping data intercepted from a secure communications network for longer than necessary. The tribunal ruled it had "no doubt that the retention of the metadata for so long was incompatible with the law". The tribunal's report follows a three-year legal battle by Amnesty to force the government to reveal the extent of its surveillance operations. Amnesty said the IPT's findings were "deeply troubling" and called for a full public inquiry into GCHQ's spying activities. "It is outrageous that human rights organisations are being targeted by the British government," said Kate Allen, Amnesty International UK's director. "This is not just about Amnesty, this is about the right of all of us to privacy and to freedom of expression. "The government must now come clean about the extent of its surveillance operations and establish an independent public inquiry into GCHQ." The IPT's report found that GCHQ had intercepted communications between Amnesty staff and activists, and had stored the data for up to two years. The tribunal said that GCHQ had breached the law by keeping the data for so long, as it was only allowed to retain intercepted data for 60 days. The government said it was "disappointed" by the IPT's ruling, but accepted its findings. A government spokesman said: "The Investigatory Powers Tribunal has ruled that GCHQ breached the rules in relation to the retention of metadata. "We are disappointed by this ruling, but we accept it and have already taken steps to address the issue. "We are committed to ensuring that our intelligence agencies have the powers they need to keep the country safe, while at the same time respecting the privacy of the public."

title: Culture secretary questions Edinburgh tourist tax plans

title: Covid in Scotland: First screening site opens at Edinburgh airport
text: Passengers and staff at the airport, as well as members of the public, will be able to pay for PCR swab tests before they travel, at a cost of £60. title: Depression: 'Mindfulness-based therapy shows promise'
text: By Smitha Mundasad Health reporter, BBC News Scientists tested it against anti-depressant pills for people at risk of relapse and found mindfulness worked equally well. The study, in the Lancet Psychiatry journal, involved more than 200 people who had recently recovered from a depressive episode. Half of them practised mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) while the others took the antidepressant drug escitalopram, or a placebo. Over 24 months, they found 43% of those who received MBCT relapsed compared with 51% of those on escitalopram and 60% on placebo. Researchers said this meant it could offer people who are struggling with repeat depression a safe alternative to or work alongside medication. Lead author Prof Willem Kuyken, from Oxford University, said: "MBCT looks to be an important additional treatment for depression relapse prevention. "Currently there are few psychological treatments that are effective against depression relapse, and those that are can be time-consuming or not widely available. "MBCT is a transdiagnostic treatment, meaning it can be used to treat and prevent all types of depression." Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy MBCT is a form of psychotherapy that draws on the principles of mindfulness meditation but is adapted to be focused on depression. It involves group sessions where people sit, walk or lie still to learn how to focus their awareness on the present moment and process their emotions without judgment. Participants are also encouraged to practice mindfulness at home. Prof Kuyken said it was the first study to find MBCT was as effective as medication in preventing depression relapse, but added it was still too early to recommend MBCT as a first-line treatment for everyone with depression. He said: "People at high risk of depression relapse are likely to prefer to take a pill once a day rather than practise mindfulness. "But for those who don't want to take medication, or who have not had good experiences of medication, MBCT is a welcome new option." Other experts said it was important to note the study did not compare MBCT against a talking therapy, so it was difficult to draw definite conclusions about its effectiveness. But Dr Carmine Pariante, a researcher from King's College London, said there was growing evidence that MBCT was effective in preventing depression relapse. "This is welcome news as it provides an alternative option for people who do not want to take medication, or who have not found medication helpful," he said. "It is also worth noting that MBCT is relatively easy to learn and deliver, so it has the potential to be widely accessible."

title: Hong Kong 'Umbrella' protesters sentenced to jail terms
text: Four others received suspended sentences on Wednesday, while one had their sentencing deferred until June. The nine activists were charged with offenses including conspiracy to commit public nuisance and incitement to unlawful assembly. Benny Tai, an academic and one of the leaders of the movement, was sentenced to 16 months in prison. Two other prominent activists, Joshua Wong and Nathan Law, were each sentenced to eight months in prison. The remaining six defendants received sentences ranging from six to eight months. The sentencing of the activists has been widely condemned by human rights groups and pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong. They argue that the sentences are politically motivated and intended to suppress dissent in the city. The Chinese government has defended the sentences, saying that the activists were convicted of serious crimes and that the sentences were proportionate to their offenses. The sentencing of the activists is likely to further polarize Hong Kong society and increase tensions between the city's pro-democracy movement and the Chinese government. It is also likely to have a chilling effect on freedom of expression and assembly in the city. The "Umbrella Movement" protests were sparked by the Chinese government's decision to restrict the number of candidates who could run for the city's top post in 2017. The protests lasted for 79 days and at their peak involved more than 100,000 people. The Chinese government has since cracked down on dissent in Hong Kong, arresting a number of pro-democracy activists and introducing new laws that restrict freedom of speech and assembly.

title: Cancer awareness 'low in black and South Asian groups'
text: By Smitha MundasadHealth reporter, BBC News The study of nearly 50,000 people found those with a black ethnic background were least likely to have ever had a cancer screening, and men from South Asian backgrounds were less likely to be aware of the risks of some cancers. Overall, 67% of people in the UK have ever had a cancer screening (not including cervical screening). But the study found just 57% of black respondents had ever had a cancer check, compared with 69% of white respondents. For some cancers - such as testicular, prostate and lung cancer - awareness of the risks was much lower among black and South Asian men compared with white men. Dr Julie Sharp, head of health and patient experience at Cancer Research UK, said the findings showed "clear disparities in cancer awareness between different ethnic groups". "This is concerning, as being aware of the signs and symptoms of cancer can lead to earlier diagnosis, and earlier diagnosis usually leads to better outcomes," she said. The study, published in the journal Cancer Epidemiology, Biomarkers & Prevention, looked at data from the Health Survey for England, which collected information on cancer screening and awareness from nearly 50,000 adults between 2018 and 2020. The researchers found that black respondents were less likely to have ever had a cancer screening than white respondents, even after taking into account factors such as age, sex, education and socioeconomic status. The study also found that men from South Asian backgrounds were less likely to be aware of the risks of testicular, prostate and lung cancer than white men. And women from South Asian backgrounds were less likely to be aware of the risks of cervical, breast and ovarian cancer than white women. Dr Sharp said the reasons for the disparities in cancer awareness were complex, but could include factors such as cultural beliefs, language barriers and a lack of trust in healthcare services. "It's important to address these disparities so that everyone has the opportunity to be diagnosed with cancer at an early stage when treatment is more likely to be successful," she said. Cancer Research UK is calling for more to be done to raise awareness of cancer in black and South Asian communities, and to make sure that everyone has access to high-quality cancer screening and treatment services.

In light of the rise in far-right extremism, the BBC is launching a new series of investigative reports into the threat posed by white supremacists in the UK. The series will examine the factors that drive people to adopt far-right ideologies and will investigate the activities of far-right groups in the UK.

title: Safoora Zargar: Bail for pregnant India student blamed for Delhi riots
text: She was more than three months pregnant when she was arrested in April. Police called her a "key conspirator" in anti-Muslim riots that swept Delhi in February. She is one of three Muslim women who are facing charges over the unrest, which left more than 50 people dead. All three women are accused of instigating violence, but they deny the charges. Safoora Zargar, a student at Jamia Millia Islamia University, was granted bail on Thursday by Delhi High Court. The court said that there was no evidence to support the charges against her. Her release was welcomed by activists and opposition politicians, who have accused the government of targeting Muslims in its crackdown on the Delhi riots. "This is a victory for justice and for all those who have been fighting against the Modi government's draconian policies," said Umar Khalid, a prominent Muslim activist who was also arrested in connection with the Delhi riots. The government has defended its handling of the riots, saying that it is committed to ensuring that all those responsible are brought to justice. However, critics say that the charges against Safoora Zargar and the other two women are politically motivated. They point out that the government has not arrested any of the Hindu nationalists who are accused of inciting violence against Muslims. The Delhi riots were sparked by protests against a new citizenship law that was seen as discriminatory against Muslims. The protests quickly turned violent, with mobs of Hindu nationalists attacking Muslim homes and businesses. The government has been accused of turning a blind eye to the violence, and even of encouraging it. In the aftermath of the riots, the police have been accused of using excessive force against Muslims and of carrying out arbitrary arrests. The case of Safoora Zargar has become a symbol of the government's crackdown on dissent. She is a young, pregnant woman who has been accused of serious crimes based on little evidence. Her release on bail is a small victory, but it is a reminder that the fight for justice in India is far from over.

title: Stanford rape case Judge Aaron Persky faces recall petition
text: Community leaders from Santa Clara County filed a notice of intention on Monday to collect signatures to recall Judge Aaron Persky next year. Judge Persky was accused of bias in the sentencing of Brock Turner, a former Stanford University swimmer convicted of sexually assaulting an unconscious woman in 2015. The recall effort is being led by Recall Judge Aaron Persky, a group of community members who believe that Judge Persky's actions in the Turner case were "unjust and biased." The group has 160 days to collect 58,632 valid signatures from registered voters in Santa Clara County in order to force a recall election. If the recall effort is successful, Judge Persky would be the first California judge to be recalled since 1932. Judge Persky has defended his handling of the Turner case, saying that he followed the law and the evidence in making his sentencing decision. He has also said that he is "deeply sorry" for the victim's pain. The Turner case generated national outrage and led to widespread criticism of Judge Persky's sentencing decision. Many people felt that the six-month sentence that he gave Turner was too lenient. In response to the criticism, Judge Persky announced in June that he would not seek re-election when his term expires in 2022. The recall effort is the latest development in the ongoing fallout from the Turner case. The case has also led to changes in California law, including a new law that requires judges to consider the impact of sexual assault on victims when making sentencing decisions. The recall effort is expected to be contentious. Judge Persky's supporters argue that he is a fair and impartial judge who has been unfairly targeted by activists. His opponents argue that he is unfit to serve on the bench and that he should be removed from office. The recall election is scheduled to be held on June 7, 2022.

title: Muslim families sending children to Catholic schools
text: By Sean Coughlan Education correspondent For the first time, an annual census of Catholic schools has collected information on the number of pupils from other religions. The biggest group of non-Catholic pupils are from other Christian denominations - but there are growing numbers of Muslims and Hindus. In England, there are around 2,300 Catholic schools, which educate about 10% of all school pupils. The census for 2022 shows that 83% of their pupils are now Catholic - down from 88% a decade ago. Of the remaining 17%, the biggest group are from other Christian denominations, such as Anglican or Methodist. But the number of Muslim pupils in Catholic schools is now 5%, up from 3% a decade ago. And the number of Hindu pupils is now 2%, up from 1% a decade ago. The growth in the number of non-Catholic pupils in Catholic schools reflects the changing demographics of England's population. According to the 2021 census, 46% of the population now identify as Christian, down from 59% a decade ago. The proportion of the population identifying as Muslim has increased from 4.9% to 6.5% over the same period. There are a number of reasons why Muslim families are choosing to send their children to Catholic schools. Some parents are attracted by the schools' strong academic record. Others appreciate the Catholic ethos of the schools, which emphasizes values such as compassion, service, and forgiveness. Some Muslim families also feel that Catholic schools provide a more welcoming environment for their children than non-religious schools. In a survey conducted by the Catholic Education Service, 80% of Muslim parents said that they felt their children were welcomed and respected in Catholic schools. The trend of Muslim families sending their children to Catholic schools is likely to continue in the years to come. As the Muslim population in England continues to grow, so too will the demand for schools that are both academically rigorous and welcoming to pupils of all faiths.

title: Isa Muazu: Nigeria to accept UK deportee's plane
text: Isa Muazu was returned to the UK after a private jet chartered to take him to Nigeria on Friday was met with protests and demonstrations, forcing it to return to England. Muazu, a Nigerian national, was detained by the UK Home Office in November 2021 on immigration grounds and has been fighting to remain in the UK ever since. The Home Office said Muazu had "no right to remain in the UK and has exhausted all legal avenues to do so" and they intended to remove him to Nigeria. However, Muazu's supporters argued that the 53-year-old had been living in the UK for more than 30 years and considered it his home. Muazu had travelled to Nigeria in 2019 to visit his sick mother but was refused re-entry to the UK on his return after officials said he had overstayed his visa. His supporters believe he is the victim of a Home Office "administrative error" and they have been campaigning for his return. The Nigerian authorities have now agreed to accept Muazu, after initially refusing to cooperate. A spokesperson for the Nigerian High Commission in London said it had "agreed to issue the necessary travel documents" for Muazu. "We are pleased that the Nigerian government has finally agreed to accept Mr Muazu's return," said Muazu's legal representative, Jacqueline McKenzie. "This is a victory for common sense and compassion. Mr Muazu has been living in the UK for over 30 years and it is his home. He should never have been deported in the first place." Muazu's return to the UK is expected to take place in the coming days. It is unclear whether he will face any further action from the Home Office.

title: Badger cull: Queen's Brian May praises Welsh government for halting plan
text: The Queen guitarist and badger campaigner congratulated Environment Minister John Griffiths and said he had made a courageous decision. Mr Griffiths has opted to vaccinate the animals following a review. May, a patron of the Badger Trust, said the government had listened to science and accepted "the overwhelming evidence that vaccination is the only humane and effective way to control bovine TB". "This is a momentous day for badgers and for the countryside," he said. "I applaud the Welsh government for taking this bold step." The badger cull has been a controversial issue in England, where it is used to try to control the spread of bovine TB. But there is no scientific consensus on whether the cull is effective, and there are concerns that it is cruel and inhumane. In 2019, the UK government announced that it would end the badger cull in England by 2025. But the Welsh government has said it will continue with its own cull, which is due to start in 2023. Mr Griffiths said he had decided to halt the cull after a review of the evidence. He said the review had found that vaccination was a more effective and humane way to control bovine TB. "I have listened to the science and I have accepted the overwhelming evidence that vaccination is the only humane and effective way to control bovine TB," he said. "I believe that this is the right decision for Wales and for the welfare of our badgers." The decision to halt the badger cull has been welcomed by animal welfare groups. The RSPCA said it was "delighted" by the news. "This is a victory for badgers and for common sense," said RSPCA Cymru chief executive Chris O'Brien. "We have always maintained that culling is not an effective or humane way to control bovine TB, and we are pleased that the Welsh government has finally listened to the scientific evidence." The Badger Trust said the decision was "a triumph for compassion and science". "This is a momentous day for badgers in Wales," said Badger Trust chief executive Dominic Dyer. "We are delighted that the Welsh government has made the right decision to stop the cruel and ineffective badger cull."

title: Germany strikes explained: The long and the short of it
text: This week's strikes could be the first of many. So why do they matter? And what do they say about Germany in 2018? We've boiled the long story short. This week, thousands of workers from various sectors in Germany have walked out in a series of strikes, causing major disruptions to public transport, schools, and other essential services. The short of it The strikes are primarily driven by demands for higher wages. High inflation and rising living costs have eroded the purchasing power of many workers. Trade unions, representing workers' interests, are negotiating with employers to secure better pay and benefits. Negotiations have reached an impasse, leading to the current strikes. The long of it Economic factors: The German economy is enjoying a strong period of growth, with low unemployment and rising wages. However, inflation has also been on the rise, outpacing wage growth in some sectors. This has led to a decrease in real wages and a squeeze on household budgets. Political factors: The strikes come at a time of political uncertainty in Germany, with the ruling coalition facing challenges and growing support for far-right and left-wing parties. The strikes could put pressure on the government to address economic concerns and inequality. Social factors: The strikes reflect a growing sense of frustration and dissatisfaction among many workers in Germany. They feel that the benefits of economic growth are not being shared fairly and that their voices are not being heard. What the strikes say about Germany in 2018 The strikes highlight several key trends and issues in contemporary Germany: Economic inequality: The widening gap between the rich and the poor is a growing concern in Germany, and the strikes are a reflection of that. Labor unrest: The strikes show that labor unions remain a powerful force in Germany, capable of mobilizing workers in large numbers. Political polarization: The strikes come at a time of political division in Germany, and they could further exacerbate tensions between the left and the right. What's next? The strikes are likely to continue in the coming weeks and months. Negotiations between unions and employers will be closely watched, and the outcome will have significant implications for the German economy and society.

title: Rag'n'Bone Man: New songs for Record Store Day 2018
text: By Jimmy Blake Newsbeat reporter Now in its 11th year, the event celebrates local, independent record stores. As part of his role Rag'n'Bone Man has recorded two new songs direct to vinyl. Don't Set and Fall In Love Again will be out on blue and white vinyl respectively. They're also being released on CD single and as digital downloads. The tracks were recorded at London's RAK Studios. They follow his album Human which went to number one last year. Rag'n'Bone Man will be signing copies of his vinyl at Rough Trade East in London on Saturday. He says: "I'm delighted to be this year's Record Store Day ambassador for the UK. "I'm passionate about supporting independent record stores and it's an honour to play a role in celebrating them and helping to raise their profile on a day that is all about the joy of buying records. "On top of that, I'm really excited to get to share two new songs that I've recorded especially for Record Store Day and can't wait to hear what people think of them." Other Record Store Day releases include a new EP from George Ezra, a limited edition vinyl of Sir Paul McCartney's 1997 album Flaming Pie and David Bowie's 2016 album Blackstar. As well as new and re-released music, there'll be plenty of other items on offer including T-shirts, books and prints. Record Store Day is the first Saturday of every April and this year takes place on 21 April. The event was started in 2008 in the US by a group of independent record store owners and employees. It's now celebrated in more than 20 countries around the world. The aim of the day is to promote independent record stores and encourage people to buy music in a physical format. Record Store Day has been credited with helping to revive the vinyl record industry. In the UK, vinyl sales have risen steadily over the past decade. Last year, more than 4 million vinyl records were sold, the highest number since 1990.

title: Andrew Lloyd Webber: Arts at risk over austerity cuts
text: Speaking at the House of Lords, Lord Lloyd-Webber said the sector was being put at risk by policies introduced in the wake of the recession. He added Britain's creative industries were being "strangled" due to the government's lack of support as theatres face rising costs while local authorities have been reducing funding for the arts. Lord Lloyd-Webber is one of 150 figures from the UK's theatre industry who have signed a letter to the government warning that the arts are "on the brink of collapse" because of soaring energy bills and other costs, while local authority spending cuts are also impacting them. The 150 signatories include stage and screen actors, theatre owners, directors and producers, as well as members of the Society of London Theatre and UK Theatre. They warn that the government cuts could have "devastating consequences for an industry that contributes £111bn to the UK economy every year". In a speech at the Lords, Lord Lloyd-Webber said that the arts must be seen as an investment, not a luxury, adding that "arts institutions and creative industries make our lives better and more beautiful". The letter to the government argues that "the energy crisis and cost of living crisis, alongside local authority funding cuts, threaten to decimate our theatres and arts organisations if more support isn't given." The signatories call on the government to provide urgent support, including a review of business rates, a reduction in VAT on theatre tickets and the introduction of a "theatrical investment relief" tax credit to encourage investment in theatre productions. They also demand a "freeze" on local authority cuts to arts funding and an acknowledgement of the "devastating impact" reductions in spending are having on theatre and other art venues. The letter concludes by stating: "The arts are in crisis. The government must act now to save them before it's too late."

title: Emiliano Sala: No further action after manslaughter arrest
text: Emiliano Sala: No further action after manslaughter arrest The Argentine striker, 28, was killed in a plane crash along with pilot David Ibbotson just two days after signing for Cardiff City in January 2019. Wiltshire Police arrested a 64-year-old man on suspicion of manslaughter by an unlawful act in June 2021. He was released under investigation while inquiries continued. The force said on Tuesday that the decision to take no further action was made after "careful consideration" of all the evidence gathered during the investigation. "Following a thorough investigation, we have concluded that there is no evidence to support a criminal prosecution and therefore no further action will be taken," a Wiltshire Police spokesman said. "This has been a complex and challenging investigation and we have worked closely with partner agencies including the Civil Aviation Authority, the Air Accidents Investigation Branch and the Crown Prosecution Service throughout. "Our thoughts remain with the family and friends of Mr Sala and Mr Ibbotson at this difficult time." Sala's family said they were "disappointed" by the decision not to prosecute. "We are extremely disappointed with the decision not to prosecute," a statement from the family said. "We believe that there is sufficient evidence to support a prosecution and we will continue to pursue all legal avenues to ensure that those responsible for Emiliano's death are held accountable." The Air Accidents Investigation Branch (AAIB) concluded in its final report that the pilot, Ibbotson, was not qualified to fly at night and that the plane was not airworthy. The report also found that Sala's transfer to Cardiff City had been rushed and that the club had not carried out due diligence on the plane or the pilot. Cardiff City said in a statement that it was "disappointed" by the decision not to prosecute. "We continue to offer our sincere condolences to the families of Emiliano Sala and David Ibbotson," the statement said. "We are disappointed that no criminal charges will be brought against any individuals in connection with this tragic incident." The club said it would now consider the AAIB's findings and "take any necessary steps to ensure that a similar tragedy does not happen again."

title: Vodafone error sees customers hit by thousands in charges
text: Customers took to Twitter, saying they were unable to use their phones and could not reach the operator. Many received automatic text messages from Vodafone apologising for the error and confirming that no charges had been deducted. However, some customers reported that they had been charged thousands of pounds, with one user saying they had been billed £17,000. Another customer said they had been charged £4,000, while others reported charges of hundreds of pounds. Vodafone has not yet confirmed how many customers have been affected by the error. In a statement, the company said: "We are aware of an issue that has affected a small number of our customers. We are working to resolve the issue as quickly as possible. "We apologise for any inconvenience this has caused and we will be contacting affected customers directly." The error comes just days after Vodafone announced that it was raising prices for some of its customers. The company said that the price increases were necessary to invest in its network and improve its services. However, the error is likely to damage Vodafone's reputation and could lead to customers switching to other providers. One customer, who was charged £1,500, said: "I'm furious. I've been with Vodafone for years and I've never had a problem. But this is unacceptable. I'm going to switch to another provider as soon as possible." Another customer, who was charged £2,000, said: "I'm so disappointed. I've always been happy with Vodafone, but this has really let me down. I'm not sure if I can trust them anymore." The error is the latest in a series of problems for Vodafone. In recent months, the company has been criticised for its poor customer service and its high prices. Vodafone has been contacted for further comment.
