title: Insurers warn of travel premium rise
text: By Simon Gompertz Personal finance correspondent, BBC News Drivers going on holiday could need also need extra paperwork, the Association of British Insurers said. Next Thursday, the UK leaves the European Union's single insurance market. This means that the Green Card - the document which proves your car is insured - will no longer be valid in the EU, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland and Andorra. You can now buy a Green Card from your insurer to prove you have adequate cover. It will cost between £25 and £50. The insurance industry says most people will not need a Green Card, but there are some cases where it is essential. You must have a Green Card if you drive: to Ireland - as it is not part of the EU to Serbia, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo to any country that is not part of the EU, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland and Andorra You might want to get a Green Card if you: are hiring a car abroad are driving near the borders of the countries not covered by the Green Card The ABI also warns the cost of travel insurance is likely to rise as the UK leaves the EU. EU rules mean that insurers can no longer ask customers where they come from when pricing their policies, or take into account previous claims history. This is likely to lead to higher premiums for British holidaymakers, because the UK is seen as a higher-risk country than many EU nations. "We anticipate that prices will go up for UK residents," said the ABI's Matthew Maxwell Scott. The ABI is the trade body for the UK insurance industry. It represents around 200 insurance companies. Sarah Francis, from the travel insurance comparison website TravelSupermarket, said: "Holidaymakers should expect to pay more for travel insurance when travelling to the EU. "The ABI are warning of a 6% increase in the cost of travel insurance when travelling to Europe this summer." The ABI says the increase in premiums is likely to be modest. But Mr Maxwell Scott said: "There is likely to be a widening of the differential between the prices of travel insurance for EU and non-EU destinations." He added: "It is more important than ever that holidaymakers shop around for the best deal on their travel insurance, and make sure they have adequate cover. "They should also remember that they may need a Green Card to drive in some countries."

title: Austria election: 'Grand coalition' can rule again
text: There was a surge in support for the Eurosceptic right-wing Freedom Party (FPOe), which got 21.4%. The Social Democrats (SPOe) came top with 27.1% and the conservative People's Party (OeVP) got 23.8% in Sunday's election. The conservative OeVP and centre-left SPOe could form a coalition, as they have been doing since 2008. The FPOe's rise was not unexpected - the party has been on the rise for some years, and has been predicting that the mainstream parties would lose support. It is not yet clear how the FPOe will behave in parliament, but it could be more disruptive than at any time since it entered parliament in 1999. The Freedom Party leader, Norbert Hofer, said on Monday that the party's advance was a "great mandate" for the party. He said the FPOe had won support from "those who want to regain power in this country". He added that the party was not interested in governing "at any price": "Personally I would prefer to be in opposition. But I will certainly not participate in a government that works against our values." The FPOe is opposed to same-sex marriage, immigration, and multiculturalism, among other things. It wants to leave the European Union, and hold a referendum on whether Austria should leave the eurozone. The FPOe's rise has been blamed on a number of factors, including: The public's dissatisfaction with the government's handling of the immigration crisis The country's economic problems The rise of populism across Europe It is unclear whether the OeVP and SPOe will be able to form a stable government. The two parties have very different views on a number of issues, and it is possible that they could clash over policy. The OeVP is more pro-European than the SPOe, and it is more likely to support austerity measures. The SPOe is more left-wing, and it is more likely to support social welfare programmes. If the OeVP and SPOe cannot form a coalition, it is possible that the FPOe could end up in government. This would be a major shift in Austrian politics, and it could have a significant impact on the country's future.

title: Cilla Black encouraged me to be an actress - now I'm playing her on stage
text: Hayworth followed her instruction. Now 28, she has won her first major role appearing as the star on stage. She will play the late singer and TV host in Cilla The Musical, which opens in August in London. Cilla Black, who died in 2015, was a national treasure, and was known for presenting the TV shows Blind Date and Surprise, Surprise. Hayworth will play Black through the various stages of her career, from her early days as a singer in the 1960s, through to her success as a TV star in the 1970s and 1980s. The musical will also feature Black's relationship with her husband, Bobby Willis. Hayworth was born in Liverpool, where Black grew up, and says she "has the same accent and mannerisms" as the star, who was known for speaking her mind and her infectious laugh. "I'd been told I was like her and I remember watching Cilla Black on TV and thinking she exuded warmth and fun, and she was very strong and independent. I felt like I could relate to her on that level," says Hayworth. Despite the similarities, Hayworth was determined to create her own interpretation of Black. "I wanted to find Cilla's vulnerability and her struggles, because she had a lot of those as well. This role has been a really nice challenge." Hayworth was cast after a long audition process, which involved singing, dancing, and acting. "I sang one of Cilla's songs, Anyone Who Had A Heart, and I performed a monologue that told her story," she says. "I had to do a lot of research to really understand her - reading her autobiography and watching lots of YouTube videos. I wanted to get the full picture of who she was." Hayworth says "it has been a huge privilege to play such an iconic figure". "Cilla was loved by so many people, and I hope I can do her story justice," she says. Cilla The Musical will run at the Lyric Theatre, London, from 25 August 2023 to 6 May 2024.

title: Coronavirus: Homebirths to restart with new safeguards
text: The arrangement in the Lothians includes a limit of one birthing partner and the need for a separate changing space for them to get into personal protective equipment (PPE). Homebirths currently account for 2% of births in Scotland. The Scottish government said it aimed to get this back to pre-pandemic levels of 5% to 10%. The Royal College of Midwives said homebirths were a "safe choice" for many women. The new guidelines were published by the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (RCOG) and the Royal College of Midwives (RCM). They include advice on how to protect against Covid-19, such as wearing face masks and washing hands regularly. The guidelines also recommend that women should have a birth plan in place that includes their preferences for pain relief and where they would like to give birth. The RCOG said that homebirths were a "safe and effective" option for many women. The college said that there was no evidence to suggest that homebirths were more risky than hospital births. The RCM said that homebirths were a "positive and empowering" experience for many women. The college said that homebirths could help to reduce the number of interventions, such as episiotomies and Caesarean sections. The Scottish government said that it was committed to providing women with a choice of where to give birth. The government said that it would continue to work with the NHS to ensure that women had access to safe and high-quality maternity care. The new guidelines are likely to be welcomed by many women who are planning to give birth. Homebirths can offer a number of benefits, including: A more relaxed and comfortable environment Reduced risk of interventions Greater control over the birth process If you are considering a homebirth, it is important to talk to your midwife or doctor to discuss the risks and benefits. You should also make sure that you have a birth plan in place that includes your preferences for pain relief and where you would like to give birth.

title: Unions call for end to local authority pay freeze
text: Unison, Unite and the GMB have lodged their annual pay claim, saying a "living wage" of £7.20 an hour should be brought in. They want to see a 1% pay rise for all staff and a minimum wage of £7.20 for all local authority workers. The unions say that the pay freeze has had a "devastating" impact on local authority workers, who have seen their wages fall in real terms by 20% since 2010. They say that many workers are now struggling to make ends meet, and that the pay freeze is making it difficult for local authorities to recruit and retain staff. The unions are calling on local authorities to end the pay freeze and to invest in their workforce. They say that a pay rise would boost the local economy and help to improve public services. The Local Government Association (LGA), which represents councils in England and Wales, said that it was "disappointed" by the unions' pay claim. The LGA said that councils are facing "significant financial pressures" and that they cannot afford to give their staff a pay rise. The LGA said that it was "committed to working with the unions to find a fair and affordable settlement" but that it could not "promise to meet the unions' demands in full". The unions have said that they are prepared to take industrial action if their demands are not met. They have warned that they could call a strike ballot of their members if the LGA does not agree to end the pay freeze. The pay freeze has been in place since 2010, when the government imposed a 1% cap on public sector pay rises. The government says that the pay freeze is necessary to reduce the national deficit. The unions say that the pay freeze is unfair and that it is having a devastating impact on public sector workers. They say that the government should end the pay freeze and invest in its workforce.

title: Greece 'may need 10bn euros more' in aid - Stournaras
text: Yannis Stournaras said: "If there is need for further support to Greece, it will be in the order of about 10bn". The comments come after the Greek government and its creditors reached an agreement on the terms of a third bailout. The deal is expected to provide Greece with up to €86bn in loans over the next three years. However, Stournaras said that the country may need additional funding if it is to meet its fiscal targets. He said that the Greek government is committed to reducing its budget deficit and debt, but that it may need help from its creditors to do so. "We are committed to meeting our targets, but we may need some additional support," he said. Stournaras' comments suggest that the Greek government is not confident that it can meet its fiscal targets without further assistance from its creditors. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has also warned that Greece may need additional funding, and has said that it is not prepared to provide any more loans to the country until it sees evidence that the Greek government is committed to reforms. The Greek government has been under pressure from its creditors to implement a series of reforms in order to reduce its budget deficit and debt. These reforms include cuts to public spending, tax increases, and reforms to the labour market. The Greek government has agreed to implement these reforms, but it is unclear whether it will be able to do so without causing social unrest. The country has already seen a number of protests against the austerity measures that have been implemented in recent years. If the Greek government is unable to implement the reforms that it has agreed to, it may find itself in need of additional funding from its creditors. This could lead to a further deterioration in the country's economic situation.

title: Crossing Divides: Do you live in a social bubble?
text: We asked people in an international poll how they felt about their choice of friends. See how you compare in our interactive quiz: The results of the survey, conducted among people with internet access across 27 countries, suggested that many of us feel we live in social bubbles. The findings were published in the journal 'Nature Human Behaviour'. They revealed that on average, people estimated that around half of their friends were like them in terms of their political views. This was true even in countries with a high degree of political polarisation, such as the United States and the United Kingdom. The researchers also found that people were more likely to be friends with people who were similar to them in terms of their age, education, and income. This suggests that we tend to associate with people who share our social and economic status. The findings of this study are important because they highlight the potential for social bubbles to reinforce existing biases and make it more difficult for us to see the world from different perspectives. So, what can we do to break out of our social bubbles? One way is to make a conscious effort to meet people who are different from us. This could involve joining a club or group that focuses on a topic that you're interested in, or volunteering your time to a cause that you care about. Another way to break out of your social bubble is to travel to different countries and cultures. This will expose you to new ideas and ways of life, and help you to see the world from a different perspective. Finally, it's important to be open to new experiences and to challenge your own beliefs. This doesn't mean that you have to agree with everything that everyone else says, but it does mean being willing to listen to other people's opinions and to consider their perspectives. Breaking out of our social bubbles can be challenging, but it's important to remember that we all have something to learn from each other. By making an effort to meet people who are different from us, we can broaden our horizons and become more understanding and tolerant individuals.

title: Mayor considers Hoo peninsula in Kent as airport option
text: Mr Johnson wants to increase flight capacity around London without expanding Heathrow. He has also been considering building an airport in the Thames Estuary to the east of the city. The Hoo peninsula is located in Kent, to the south-east of London. It is sparsely populated and has good transport links to the capital. The peninsula has been suggested as a potential site for an airport for many years. In 2014, a report by the Airports Commission concluded that the Hoo peninsula was one of the most feasible options for a new airport in the South East. However, the government ultimately decided to expand Heathrow instead. The Mayor of London's interest in the Hoo peninsula has reignited the debate about the need for a new airport in the South East. Supporters of a new airport argue that it is needed to meet the growing demand for air travel. They also say that it would create jobs and boost the economy. Opponents of a new airport argue that it would damage the environment and increase noise pollution. They also say that it is not needed, as there is already sufficient airport capacity in the South East. The government has not yet made a decision on whether to build a new airport in the South East. However, the Mayor of London's interest in the Hoo peninsula is likely to put pressure on the government to reconsider its options. If the government does decide to build a new airport in the South East, the Hoo peninsula is likely to be one of the frontrunners. It is a well-connected site with good transport links to London. However, there are also environmental concerns that need to be considered. The decision of whether or not to build a new airport in the South East is a complex one. There are a number of factors that need to be considered, including the environmental impact, the economic benefits, and the need for additional airport capacity. The government will need to weigh all of these factors carefully before making a decision.

title: Coronavirus: People 'have got the message' and stayed home
text: The Welsh Government responded by imposing severe curbs on people's lives, with fines for disobeying. It came after thousands of people had flocked to beauty spots in the first weekend after the lockdown was announced. But this weekend, things were very different. The streets were largely deserted, and the few people who were out were keeping their distance from each other. The same was true across the UK. In England, the government had advised people to stay at home over the long Easter weekend, and most people had heeded the advice. The roads were quiet, and the parks were empty. It seems that the public has finally got the message about the importance of social distancing. After weeks of mixed messages from the government, it is clear that people now understand the need to stay home to save lives. This is a major breakthrough in the fight against coronavirus. If people continue to follow the advice, it will help to slow the spread of the virus and protect the NHS. However, it is important to remember that the virus is still out there, and we must not become complacent. We must continue to stay home, wash our hands regularly, and avoid contact with others. The government has said that the lockdown will continue for at least three more weeks. This may seem like a long time, but it is important to remember that it is for our own good. By staying home, we are helping to protect ourselves, our loved ones, and the NHS. We can get through this together. By following the advice, we can help to stop the spread of coronavirus and save lives. The BBC has been reporting on the coronavirus pandemic since it began. We have a team of experienced journalists who are working around the clock to bring you the latest news and information. We are committed to providing accurate, impartial, and trustworthy journalism. You can find all of our coronavirus coverage on our website, where you can also sign up for our daily email newsletter. You can also follow us on Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram.

title: Bat virus clues to origins of Sars
text: By Keeren Flora BBC Radio Science Unit Two novel Sars-like coronaviruses were found in Chinese horseshoe bats which are closely related to the pathogen that infects humans.  The viruses are the closest relatives yet found to the one which caused the Sars outbreak in 2002-03, but differ from the virus that is now circulating and causing Covid-19. The discovery suggests that the original Sars virus may have originated in horseshoe bats, and jumped into humans via an intermediary animal. The two new viruses, named RmYN02 and RmYN05, were found in bats from Yunnan province in southern China. They were identified by researchers from the Wuhan Institute of Virology, who compared their genetic sequence to that of the original Sars virus. The findings have been published in the journal Nature Microbiology. The researchers say that the two new viruses are 96% and 97% identical to the original Sars virus, respectively. This suggests that they are closely related, and may have evolved from a common ancestor. However, the two new viruses are not identical to the original Sars virus. They have some small genetic differences, which means that they are not able to infect human cells in the same way. The researchers say that this suggests that the original Sars virus may have evolved from a common ancestor of the two new viruses, and then changed slightly over time. They believe that the two new viruses may have been circulating in horseshoe bats for some time, and that they may have jumped into humans via an intermediary animal. The researchers say that their findings provide important clues about the origins of the Sars virus, and could help to prevent future outbreaks. They say that their work highlights the need for further research into the viruses that circulate in bats, and the potential risks that they pose to humans. The Sars outbreak in 2002-03 caused widespread alarm, and led to the deaths of more than 700 people. Since then, there have been several other outbreaks of Sars-like viruses, including the current Covid-19 pandemic. The researchers say that their findings could help to develop new vaccines and treatments for Sars-like viruses, and could help to prevent future outbreaks.

title: Alex Salmond launches £103m renewable energy fund
text: The Renewable Energy Investment Fund (REIF) aims to attract more private investment to the sector. Its priorities include wave and tidal energy, and renewable district heating. Mr Salmond also announced plans to set up an expert taskforce to advise the Scottish government on the next steps toward achieving its renewable energy ambitions. The taskforce will be led by Professor Sir Jim McDonald, the principal and vice-chancellor of the University of Strathclyde, and will include representatives from industry, academia, and the public sector. It will advise the government on how to develop the right policy and regulatory framework to support the growth of the renewable energy sector, and how to ensure that Scotland remains at the forefront of this global industry. Mr Salmond said: "Scotland has the potential to be a world leader in renewable energy, and the Renewable Energy Investment Fund will help us to unlock that potential. This fund will attract more private investment to the sector, and will help us to develop the next generation of renewable energy technologies. "The expert taskforce that I am announcing today will provide us with the advice and expertise that we need to develop the right policy and regulatory framework to support the growth of the renewable energy sector. I am confident that this taskforce will help us to achieve our ambitious目标 of becoming a net exporter of renewable energy by 2030." The launch of the REIF was welcomed by the renewable energy industry. Stephen Kerr, the chief executive of Scottish Renewables, said: "The Renewable Energy Investment Fund is a welcome and significant commitment from the Scottish government to supporting the growth of the renewable energy sector. This fund will help to attract more private investment to the sector, and will help us to develop the next generation of renewable energy technologies. "Scotland has the potential to be a world leader in renewable energy, and the REIF will help us to unlock that potential. We look forward to working with the Scottish government and the expert taskforce to develop the right policy and regulatory framework to support the growth of the sector."

title: Twitter abuse and bomb threat claims probed by police
text: The Met said its central e-crime unit would investigate the claims, including three that were made outside London. On Wednesday, four female journalists, a student and a member of the public reported receiving threatening messages, including bomb threats. The threats were made in response to an article published in the Times newspaper about a former MP's alleged sexual harassment. The journalists were all women who had written about the allegations against the former MP. The student was a young woman who had tweeted about the article. The member of the public was a man who had also tweeted about the article. The Met said in a statement: "We are aware of a number of reports of threatening messages being sent to journalists, a student and a member of the public. These messages are being investigated by our central e-crime unit." The National Union of Journalists (NUJ) condemned the threats, saying that they were "an attempt to intimidate and silence journalists who are doing their job." The NUJ's general secretary, Michelle Stanistreet, said: "These threats are a reminder of the dangers that journalists face in the course of their work. We stand with our members and will not be intimidated by those who seek to silence us." The threats come at a time when there is growing concern about the level of abuse and intimidation faced by journalists online. A recent survey by the International Federation of Journalists (IFJ) found that nearly two-thirds of female journalists have experienced online abuse. The IFJ's general secretary, Anthony Bellanger, said: "Online abuse and intimidation are a serious threat to freedom of expression. We urge governments and social media companies to take action to protect journalists from these attacks." The Met's investigation into the threats is ongoing. No arrests have been made.

title: Liberia warlord 'Jungle Jabbah' jailed for 30 years in the US
text: Mohammed Jabbateh was found guilty of immigration fraud for falsely telling US authorities in the 1990s that he had never belonged to an armed group. One of the most notorious figures of the Liberian civil wars, Jabbateh - known as "Jungle Jabbah" - was jailed for 30 years in a US court in 2018. Jabbateh has always denied any role in the atrocities which took place during the two Liberian civil wars, from 1989-96 and 1999-2003, each of which claimed the lives of an estimated 250,000 people. The Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Liberia (TRC) found Jabbateh personally responsible for the massacre of more than 1,000 civilians during the first war. The TRC report alleges that Jabbateh recruited and trained child soldiers and ordered the ritualistic cannibalism of civilians. In 2001, Jabbateh was offered asylum in the US after being resettled by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). He did not disclose his past and was granted permanent residency in 2003. An indictment in 2016 charged Jabbateh with committing crimes in Liberia, including acts of murder, forced labour and the use of child soldiers. He was extradited from the US to Liberia in 2017, but the Liberian authorities failed to prosecute him and returned him to the US to face trial. The US trial focused on Jabbateh's immigration status. Prosecutors argued that he had lied on his asylum application, resulting in his acquiring citizenship which he was ineligible for. Jabbateh claimed he concealed his past to protect himself and his family. The jury found Jabbateh guilty of perjury and fraud and he was sentenced in 2018 to 30 years in prison. The presiding judge, Richard Gergel, said Jabbateh's crimes "went beyond mere deceit" and that he had committed "heinous atrocities that shocked the conscience". Jabbateh's case has drawn attention to the challenges of prosecuting war crimes in a country where the perpetrators live alongside their victims, and the importance of accountability for atrocities committed during civil wars.

title: Pakistan rules out offensive against Punjab militants
text: By M Ilyas Khan BBC News, Islamabad His remarks came hours after he told a parliamentary committee that "Punjabi Taliban" were entrenched in southern parts of Punjab. Mr Sharif said they were behind recent attacks in Punjab's Rajanpur and Dera Ghazi Khan districts. Recent attacks in the province have killed more than 100 people, including police officers and civilians. The Taliban are a banned militant group that was set up in Afghanistan in the 1990s with the support of Pakistan. After the US-led invasion of Afghanistan in 2001, many members returned to Pakistan. They have since regrouped and claimed responsibility for numerous attacks across the country. While the Pakistani government has launched major offensives against the group in other parts of the country, including the north-western tribal region of Waziristan, it has held back from doing so in Punjab. Some analysts believe that the government is reluctant to launch a full-scale operation in Punjab because it does not want to alienate the province's powerful feudal lords, many of whom are believed to have links to the Taliban. Others argue that the government is concerned that a military operation in Punjab could lead to a wider conflict. In his speech on Wednesday, Mr Sharif said that the government had been "successful in containing" the threat from the Punjabi Taliban. He said that the group had been "degraded" and that its "capacity to carry out terrorist attacks has been significantly reduced". However, he also acknowledged that the group remained a "threat" and that the government would continue to take "stern action" against it. Mr Sharif's speech was welcomed by some analysts, who said that it showed that the government was serious about tackling the threat from the Punjabi Taliban. However, others were more sceptical. They argued that the government had been talking tough on the Punjabi Taliban for years, but had failed to take any concrete action against them.

title: Belfast to host Gradam Ceoil trad music awards until 2021
text: By Robbie Meredith BBC News NI Education Correspondent The announcement was made as the city hosted the awards and concert for the first time. The Gradam Ceoil awards aim to promote Irish traditional music and culture, and are presented to musicians who have made significant contributions to the genre. The 2019 awards ceremony took place at the Belfast Waterfront Hall, with performances from a range of traditional musicians, including Martin Hayes and Dennis Cahill, Máiréad Ní Mhaonaigh, and the Armagh Rhymers. Speaking at the launch of the three-year deal, Belfast Lord Mayor John Finucane said: "It is a great honour for Belfast to host the Gradam Ceoil awards until 2021. "Traditional music is a vital part of our culture and heritage, and these awards celebrate the very best of Irish traditional music." Gradam Ceoil director Liam O'Connor said: "We are delighted to be partnering with Belfast City Council to host the Gradam Ceoil awards for the next three years. "Belfast has a vibrant traditional music scene, and we are confident that the awards will continue to grow and prosper in the city." The Gradam Ceoil awards were first held in 2002, and have been presented in a number of locations across Ireland, including Dublin, Cork, and Galway. Some of the previous winners of the awards include The Chieftains, Sharon Shannon, and Christy Moore. The 2020 Gradam Ceoil awards will take place in Belfast on 16 October.

title: Tories and SNP clash over wind power support
text: The YouGov poll suggests that a majority of supporters of every party - including Tories - support wind power. But anti-wind farm campaigners arranged a protest at the Conservative Party conference, where Ms Patel is due to speak on Monday. The Scottish Conservatives have said they will not support any new onshore wind farms without local consent, but Ms Patel is expected to say there should be an automatic presumption in favour of wind power projects at English planning applications. The SNP's Westminster leader Ian Blackford said the Tory government was "utterly out of touch" with public opinion on the issue. "The vast majority of people in this country support wind power, and they want to see more of it," he said. "The Tories are completely out of step with the public on this. They are more interested in protecting the interests of their wealthy friends than in addressing the climate crisis." title: Havelock House: Residents welcome rejection of demolition plans
text: The building, on lower Ormeau Road, was vacated in 2018 ahead of a UTV move to new offices on City Quays. London company Olympian Homes bought the site with plans to knock it down and build around 145 apartments. However, Belfast City Council's planning committee rejected the application, following a public consultation that saw 119 objections and one representation in support. The Twentieth Century Society welcomed the decision, saying it was an "important step in the right direction". "This is potentially a landmark case," said the society's director Catherine Croft. "Havelock House is a key part of Belfast's architectural heritage. It is a striking building that gives the city a distinctive character. "The council's decision sends a clear message that our architectural heritage is important and should be protected." The residents of Havelock House were also delighted with the decision. "We are so relieved," said resident Anne McMaster. "We love living here and we were determined to fight to save our homes. "This is a victory for the people of Belfast." Olympian Homes have been contacted for comment. The Twentieth Century Society is a charity that campaigns to protect and celebrate the architecture and design of the 20th century. Havelock House was designed by architects Lanyon, Lynn and Lanyon and completed in 1969. It is considered to be one of the best examples of Brutalist architecture in Northern Ireland.

title: Dog's dinner: DNA clue to how dogs became our friends
text: By Helen Briggs BBC News Our canine companions developed the ability to digest starchy foods during the farming revolution thousands of years ago, according to DNA. This helped them scavenge more effectively for human scraps and may have been key to their domestication. The results, published in Nature, suggest that genetic changes in dogs since wolves became our pets were heavily influenced by the changing diets of humans. Scientists at Uppsala University in Sweden analysed DNA from hundreds of ancient and modern wolves, dogs, and foxes. They found that dogs developed a new gene variant after they became domesticated that helped them digest amylase - a starch-digesting enzyme found in saliva. The emergence of this gene is thought to have coincided with the advent of agriculture around 10,000 years ago. Farming led to a shift in the human diet towards more plant-based foods, which produced a change in the types of food scraps available to dogs. "Around this time, dogs would have been hanging around humans and scavenging for scraps," said Prof Peter Savolainen, part of the research team. "Starch was a new type of food for them, so the selective pressure to adapt to this food source may have been essential for their survival." The study found a high frequency of the starch-digesting gene variant in dogs from East Asia, the region where rice farming first began. The scientists believe that dogs from this region then spread the gene to other dog populations around the world. The findings have implications for modern pet dogs, many of whom are fed a diet that is still relatively high in starch. And just like our early canine companions, modern dogs still seem to have a sweet tooth for starchy treats. "I know lots of dogs who love bread," said Prof Savolainen. "And although it's not great for their health, I think it's something that reflects their genetic interest in starches." The study also found that dogs developed other genetic changes since they diverged from wolves, including changes that affect their body size, behaviour, and disease susceptibility. These changes may have resulted from ongoing natural selection, artificial selection by humans, or a combination of the two. "Our results provide strong evidence that dogs have evolved in response to changes in the human diet," said Prof Savolainen. "This highlights the close relationship between humans and dogs, and the role of diet in this relationship."

title: South East hospitals charged £1.5m for ambulance delays
text: Patient handovers should not take longer than 15 minutes. Hospitals are charged £2.44 for each extra minute. Jonathan Fox, from the Association of Professional Ambulance Personnel, told the BBC the charges were "nothing new" but said the data highlighted the "severity, scale and cost to the NHS of handover delays". The data, released under freedom of information laws, show how much each NHS trust paid to South East Coast Ambulance Service (SECAmb) in 2021-22 for delayed handovers.  King's College Hospital NHS Foundation Trust in London was charged the most - £443,326.48 - followed by Guy's and St Thomas' NHS Foundation Trust which paid £345,617.44 and St George's University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust which was charged £297,940.80. Of the 28 trusts covered by SECAmb, only two were not charged in 2021-22. These were the Kent and Medway NHS and Social Care Partnership Trust and the Sussex Community NHS Foundation Trust, which is responsible for community health services rather than acute hospital care. The data also reveals the wide variation in charges between trusts. For example, in March 2022, the Princess Royal University Hospital NHS Trust was charged a total of £105,059.04 while Medway NHS Foundation Trust was charged just £3,332.96. A spokeswoman for SECAmb said the trust was "committed to working with our NHS partners to improve handover times and ensure that our patients receive the best possible care". She said: "We have invested significantly in our ambulance service, including increasing staff numbers and introducing new vehicles and technology. We are also working closely with NHS trusts to improve handover processes and reduce delays." The charges for delayed handovers are part of a national scheme introduced in 2017 to improve patient flow through A&E departments. The scheme is designed to encourage hospitals to improve their handover processes and reduce the amount of time that patients spend waiting in ambulances. The charges are paid by hospitals to ambulance services. The money is then used to fund ambulance services, including staff costs, vehicles and equipment. The BBC has approached King's College Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, Guy's and St Thomas' NHS Foundation Trust and St George's University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust for comment.

title: New Brexit referendum would be 'divisive and hate-filled' warns Hague
text: The former foreign secretary warned of the risk of a "hate-filled" campaign if the government attempted to revisit the issue and tell people "they got it wrong". He suggested that the government should focus on other issues, such as cost of living and climate change. "We need to talk about real issues, not repeat referendums," he said. Hague's comments come amid growing speculation that Prime Minister Liz Truss could call a new referendum on Brexit. Truss has said she is "not ruling out" a second referendum, but has also said that she wants to focus on "delivering" Brexit. However, a new poll suggests that the public is divided on the issue of a second referendum. The poll, conducted by YouGov, found that 42% of Britons would support a second referendum, while 38% would oppose it. The poll also found that support for a second referendum is highest among young people, with 54% of 18-24 year-olds saying they would support it. The issue of a second referendum is likely to continue to be debated in the coming months, as the government faces pressure from both sides of the Brexit divide. Meanwhile, the leader of the Liberal Democrats has said that he would support a second referendum if it were "the only way" to prevent a no-deal Brexit. Sir Ed Davey said that he would prefer to see the government negotiate a new deal with the EU, but that he would "not rule out" supporting a second referendum if necessary. "If it is the only way to stop a no-deal Brexit, then I would support a second referendum," he said.

title: MSPs back Scottish smacking ban proposals
text: A bill lodged by Green MSP John Finnie is designed to give children the same protection from assault as adults. It would repeal the common law defence of "justifiable assault" for parents and carers, which currently allows them to use "reasonable" physical punishment on children. The bill has the backing of the Scottish government and is likely to be passed by the Scottish Parliament. If it becomes law, Scotland will become the first country in the UK to ban smacking. Supporters of the ban say it is necessary to protect children from physical abuse and to promote positive parenting. They argue that smacking is ineffective as a form of discipline and can damage children's physical and mental health. Opponents of the ban say it is a step too far and that it will criminalise parents who use reasonable physical punishment. They argue that the law should not interfere in family life and that parents should be allowed to discipline their children as they see fit. The debate over smacking is a complex one. There are strong arguments on both sides, and it is likely to continue for many years to come. However, the Scottish government has made it clear that it believes that a ban on smacking is necessary to protect children from harm. If the bill is passed, it will send a clear message that smacking is not acceptable in Scotland. It will also help to change attitudes towards physical punishment and promote positive parenting. In addition to the bill lodged by John Finnie, there is also a separate campaign to ban smacking in Scotland. The campaign is led by the group Children 1st, which is calling for a public consultation on the issue. Children 1st argues that a ban on smacking would send a strong message that violence against children is unacceptable. It would also help to change attitudes towards physical punishment and promote positive parenting. The campaign has the support of a number of organisations, including the Scottish Children's Commissioner, the Scottish Parent Teacher Council and the Royal College of Nursing. The Scottish government has said that it will consider the findings of any public consultation on smacking before making a decision on whether to introduce a ban. However, the government has also made it clear that it believes that a ban on smacking is necessary to protect children from harm. It is likely, therefore, that the government will introduce a ban if it receives public support for doing so.

title: Algerian army 'kills jihadist behind Herve Gourdel beheading'
text: Abdelmalek Gouri and two associates were shot dead late on Monday in the town of Isser, a statement said. His group, Jund al-Khilafa (Soldiers of the Caliphate), pledged allegiance to Islamic State. The army said he was killed in an ambush after the three men refused to surrender. Gourdel, a 55-year-old mountain guide, was taken hostage in the mountains east of Algiers on 21 September. He was featured in a video released a week later by his captors, who threatened to kill him if France did not halt air strikes in Iraq. France refused and on 24 September the militants released another video showing Gourdel's severed head. President Francois Hollande described the killing as "a barbaric act" and said France would "continue to fight terrorism". The French air force has stepped up its strikes on Islamic State in Iraq since Gourdel's death. Jund al-Khilafa is believed to have only a few dozen members and is one of several small Islamist groups operating in Algeria. The group emerged in 2014 and is led by Mokhtar Belmokhtar, a veteran jihadist who was involved in the 2013 siege of a gas plant in eastern Algeria that killed 40 people. Belmokhtar's group is based in southern Libya and has been linked to several attacks in Algeria and neighboring Mali. The Algerian army has been fighting Islamist militants for decades, and has largely succeeded in containing the threat. However, the emergence of Jund al-Khilafa and other groups aligned with Islamic State has raised concerns that Algeria could become a new battleground in the militants' global campaign. The killing of Gourdel has also highlighted the security challenges facing Westerners in North Africa, where several other hostages have been taken in recent years. In 2011, two French journalists were killed in northern Mali by al-Qaeda-linked militants, and in 2013, a British tourist was kidnapped and held for three months before being released. The kidnappings and killings have led some Western governments to advise their citizens against traveling to certain parts of North Africa.

title: Wage inequality lowest in Wales, says ONS figures
text: By Sarah Dickins BBC Wales economics correspondent The highest paid 1% of Welsh workers earn on average £41.20 an hour, seven times the lowest 10% on £5.80. The figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) show there has been little change in wage inequality in Wales since 2019, when the gap was slightly narrower. Wales has the lowest wage inequality of the UK nations and regions. But unions say the squeeze on living costs means workers in Wales are still struggling. The ONS figures show that since records began in 1997, there has been a long-term increase in the hourly pay gap between the highest and lowest paid workers in Wales. In 1997, the top 10% of earners were paid 3.8 times more than the lowest 10%. The TUC said the rising cost of food, fuel and energy meant workers were "in the midst of a cost of living crisis". Shavanah Taj, the TUC's Wales regional secretary, said: "This data shows that the gap between the highest and lowest paid workers is growing. "Workers in Wales, like workers across the UK, are in the midst of a cost of living crisis." She called on the UK government to take "urgent action" to support low-income workers and families. "That means increasing the minimum wage to at least £10 an hour immediately, boosting Universal Credit and increasing investment in public services," she added. The Welsh government said it was "committed to tackling inequality" and had taken steps to support low-paid workers. A Welsh government spokesperson said: "We have introduced the real living wage for all our employees and NHS workers, and invested £36m to establish the Young Person's Guarantee, which will ensure young people in Wales are offered a job, apprenticeship, training opportunity or other support after completing their education or training. "We are also investing heavily in supporting businesses to grow and innovate, which will help to create more high-quality jobs in Wales."

title: Birmingham voters reject elected mayor plan
text:
Birmingham was among 10 English cities voting in mayoral referendums on the same day as the local council elections. In Birmingham 57.8% voted no. Eight other cities voted to adopt the elected mayor model. The referendum was held on 5 May 2023.
The proposal to change Birmingham’s system of local government was put forward by Birmingham City Council. It argued that a mayor would be able to provide stronger leadership and would be more accountable to the public than the current committee system.
However, the proposal was opposed by a number of groups, including the Birmingham Trades Union Council and the Birmingham Chamber of Commerce. They argued that an elected mayor would be too powerful and would not be representative of the city as a whole.
The turnout for the referendum was 28.9%, which was lower than the turnout for the local council elections. This suggests that many people were not engaged with the issue of whether or not to have an elected mayor.
The result of the referendum means that Birmingham will retain its current committee system of local government. This system is based on the principle of collective responsibility, meaning that all decisions are made by the council as a whole.
The result of the referendum is a blow to the government’s plans to introduce elected mayors in all of England’s major cities. However, it is not clear whether the government will abandon its plans in light of the Birmingham result.
The decision on whether or not to have an elected mayor is a complex one. There are a number of factors to consider, including the size of the city, the level of public engagement, and the nature of the local political landscape.
In the case of Birmingham, it is clear that the public was not convinced by the arguments in favor of an elected mayor. It is also worth noting that Birmingham has a long history of strong civic leadership, which may have made the public less likely to support a change to the current system.

title: Covid: Highest weekly deaths in Wales since pandemic began
text: There were 467 deaths in the week ending 15 January, which is 13 more than the week before. This was nearly 40% of all registered deaths, the highest proportion since the pandemic began. The figures, published by the Office for National Statistics (ONS), also show that the highest number of Covid-19 deaths in Wales since the pandemic began were recorded in the last week of December. Covid-19 was mentioned on the death certificate of 297 people in the week ending 29 December. This is up from 172 the previous week and is the highest weekly total since the week ending 7 May 2020. The number of Covid-related deaths in Wales has been rising in recent weeks, after a period when they had been relatively low. In the week ending 18 December, there were 15 Covid-related deaths. In the week ending 25 December, there were 29 Covid-related deaths. And in the week ending 1 January, there were 47 Covid-related deaths. The ONS figures show that the number of deaths from all causes in Wales has also been increasing in recent weeks. In the week ending 15 January, there were 1,165 deaths in Wales, up from 1,105 the previous week. This is the highest weekly total since the week ending 23 April 2020. The increase in deaths is likely to be due to a number of factors, including the cold weather, the flu season, and the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. The Welsh government has said that it is "closely monitoring" the situation and is "taking action to reduce the number of deaths". The government has urged people to get vaccinated against Covid-19 and flu, and to take other measures to protect themselves, such as wearing masks in crowded places and washing their hands regularly. The government has also said that it is "working with the NHS to ensure that there is enough capacity to meet the increased demand for healthcare services".

title: Belarus: Journalists covering protests stripped of accreditation
text: Two journalists with the BBC's Russian service are among those affected. In a statement, the BBC said it condemned "in the strongest possible terms" the move by the Belarusian authorities. "Journalists must be allowed to do their jobs without fear of reprisals," the statement said. "We stand by our journalists and will continue to report on the situation in Belarus." The Belarusian Association of Journalists (BAJ) said that the move was a "blatant attack on freedom of the press" and called on the authorities to reinstate the journalists' accreditation. "This is a clear attempt to intimidate and silence independent journalists who are reporting on the protests," BAJ chairman Andrei Bastunets said. "We will not be silenced." The move by the Belarusian authorities comes amid a wider crackdown on dissent in the country. In recent months, hundreds of people have been arrested and detained for taking part in protests against President Alexander Lukashenko's rule. Lukashenko has been in power since 1994 and has been accused of rigging elections and suppressing dissent. The current protests were sparked by the August 9 presidential election, which Lukashenko claimed to have won by a landslide. However, the opposition and many international observers have said that the election was rigged. The protests have been largely peaceful, but there have been some violent incidents. In August, a protester was killed by a police rubber bullet. The Belarusian authorities have responded to the protests with a heavy-handed crackdown. Police have used tear gas, stun grenades, and water cannons against protesters. Hundreds of people have been arrested and detained, and some have been tortured. The international community has condemned the crackdown and called for Lukashenko to step down. title: Coronavirus: Over 300 patients refuse ambulance over Covid-19 fears
text: Toby Lewis, chief executive of Sandwell and West Birmingham NHS Trust, said hospitals are now "much clearer" about how to manage the infection. "We've been doing this now for quite some time, we've had this experience over the last couple of months, so I think the trust is now much better placed and better equipped at managing this issue," he said. "So all our hospitals and all of our services have got safe pathways in place for managing patients. We're disinfecting equipment and we're cleaning our facilities regularly, our staff are washing their hands frequently, and we're providing masks and gloves where necessary." He said the trust is also working with Public Health England to "ensure that we're following all the guidance and that we're doing everything we can to protect our patients and our staff". Sandwell and West Birmingham NHS Trust is one of a number of trusts across the UK that have reported a rise in the number of patients refusing to be transported to hospital by ambulance because of fears over Covid-19. A survey by the Association of Ambulance Chief Executives found that 306 patients had refused to be taken to hospital by ambulance between 1 March and 10 April. The survey also found that 136 patients had left an ambulance or hospital department before they had been seen by a clinician. The association's chief executive, Martin Flaherty, said the findings were "concerning" and that the public should "not be afraid" to call for an ambulance if they need one. "We understand that people may be worried about catching Covid-19, but we want to reassure them that our ambulances are safe," he said. "Our crews are following all the necessary infection control procedures and we are doing everything we can to protect our patients and our staff." The Royal College of Emergency Medicine has also urged the public not to be afraid to call for an ambulance if they need one. The college's president, Dr Katherine Henderson, said: "It is really important that people don't delay calling for an ambulance if they need one. "We understand that people may be worried about catching Covid-19, but we want to reassure them that our hospitals are safe and that our staff are doing everything they can to protect our patients and our staff."

title: Hadiza Bawa-Garba: Suspension 'was correct decision'
text: Dr Hadiza Bawa-Garba was struck off due to mistakes in the care of Jack Adcock, six, after a criminal trial. The Court of Appeal heard her removal for a "one-off mistake" had caused "significant distress" but should not have resulted in her losing her career. The case has highlighted concerns over the GMC's approach to fitness to practise hearings and raised questions over whether doctors are being unfairly punished. Her suspension was met with widespread condemnation from the medical profession, who argued that it was disproportionate to the mistake she had made. They said it would have a chilling effect on other doctors, making them less willing to take risks. The GMC defended its decision, saying that it needed to protect the public and that Dr Bawa-Garba's mistake had fallen "far below the standards expected of a doctor". The Court of Appeal agreed that Dr Bawa-Garba's mistake had been serious but said that it did not justify striking her off. The court said that the GMC had failed to take into account her good character and her previously unblemished record. The court also said that the GMC had not given enough weight to the fact that Dr Bawa-Garba had admitted her mistake and had taken steps to improve her practice. The GMC said it would consider the court's judgment carefully and would decide whether to appeal. Dr Bawa-Garba said she was "relieved and grateful" at the court's decision. She said she hoped to return to work as a doctor as soon as possible. The case has raised important questions about the GMC's role and the way it regulates doctors. It has also highlighted the need for a more proportionate approach to fitness to practise hearings. The GMC needs to find a way to balance the need to protect the public with the need to ensure that doctors are treated fairly. It must also find a way to restore public confidence in the medical profession.

title: Why we need internet jokes and memes more than ever
text: By Will ChalkNewsbeat reporter But how closely are the two linked and what does that say about our mindsets, the internet and our society? Yeah. We're tackling some big questions. And, let's be honest, we are still in the early stages of working out its effects on our lives. But I'm interested in the internet from a philosophical point of view. On some level, the internet is a mirror to the human condition. Sure, it can be a tool for good. Sharing information, supporting each other and connecting people from across the globe. But we can't ignore the toxic side of the web. From misinformation to online abuse, the internet has fostered some of the ugliest parts of society. So much of what we are online is performed. We share the good and the funny things, but how much of ourselves are we shielding? I suggest we look to internet jokes and memes for answers. They're a reflection of ourselves, our foibles, our fears and our dreams. They can be stupid, smart, funny, dull, bizarre, satirical, nonsensical, absurd - all of these things and something we cannot yet comprehend or categorise. I mean, that's what memes are for. Take, for example, the "distracted boyfriend" meme that became popular in 2017. The picture is of a man walking down the street, looking at another woman. His girlfriend, walking next to him, is looking the other way. The caption reads: "Me trying to focus on something important while my mind is distracted by something stupid." This meme is funny because it is relatable. We have all been distracted by something stupid at some point in our lives. It also pokes fun at our own hypocrisy. We all want to be seen as intelligent and attentive, but we can't help but be distracted by the silly things in life. Another example is the "two buttons" meme. This meme shows two buttons, one labelled "good" and the other labelled "bad". The caption reads: "Which button will you press?" This meme is funny because it is so simple. It forces us to confront our own moral choices. We all like to think of ourselves as good people, but what would we do if we were faced with a difficult decision? Internet jokes and memes are not just a way to waste time. They are a way for us to express ourselves, to connect with others, and to make sense of the world around us. They are a reflection of our culture and our society. And they are more important than ever in a world that is increasingly complex and confusing. So next time you see an internet joke or meme, don't just scroll past it. Take a moment to think about it. What does it say about you? What does it say about the world? And most importantly, what does it make you laugh at?

text: A dozen US states are suing to block the move, saying it will deter immigrants from participating. title: Health regulator problems 'persist'
text: By Nick Triggle Health correspondent, BBC News The Care Quality Commission (CQC) was only created in 2009 but has been under fire virtually ever since. The House of Commons' Health Select Committee said the CQC had "a history of missed opportunities to improve quality and patient safety". The committee chair, Conservative MP Jeremy Hunt, said the CQC was "too quick to praise and slow to punish". "The CQC must become a more consistent, more effective, more transparent and more independent regulator," he said. The committee's report comes after a series of high-profile scandals in the NHS, including the Mid Staffordshire scandal, where hundreds of patients died unnecessarily due to poor care. The CQC has been criticized for failing to take tough action against underperforming hospitals and care homes. In its report, the committee said the CQC "needs to be much clearer about the standards it expects providers to meet, and it needs to be more consistent in its judgments". The committee also said the CQC "needs to be more transparent about its inspection process and its decision-making". The CQC has defended its record, saying it has made significant progress in improving the quality of care in the NHS. However, the committee's report suggests that much more needs to be done. The CQC is responsible for regulating all health and social care services in England. It was created in 2009 to replace the Healthcare Commission and the Commission for Social Care Inspection. The CQC's remit includes: Inspecting health and social care services Enforcing standards of care Taking action against providers who fail to meet standards Providing information to the public about the quality of services The CQC has been criticized for a number of reasons, including: Being too lenient on underperforming providers Failing to take tough action against providers who put patients at risk Not being transparent about its inspection process Not being independent enough from the government The CQC has defended its record, saying it has made significant progress in improving the quality of care in the NHS. However, the committee's report suggests that much more needs to be done.

title: Royal Cornwall Hospital 'neglected' woman who died in A&E
text: Katy Lowry, 30, who had chromosomal abnormalities and learning difficulties, was taken to Royal Cornwall Hospital on 13 December 2016. She had been vomiting every 15 minutes for nearly 24 hours. Despite her condition, Lowry waited for hours in A&E before being seen by a doctor. She was repeatedly sent home and told to come back the following day. On 14 December, Lowry returned to the hospital with her mother. She was seen by a doctor but was again sent home. On 15 December, Lowry was rushed back to the hospital by ambulance after her condition deteriorated. She was admitted to A&E at 8.20pm but died less than two hours later. A post-mortem examination found that Lowry died from a perforated bowel. The coroner ruled that her death was "wholly avoidable" and that she had been "neglected" by the hospital. The Royal Cornwall Hospital has apologized for the "failings" in Lowry's care and has launched an investigation. Lowry's family said they were "devastated" by her death and angry that she had been "failed" by the hospital. They said: "Katy was a vulnerable person who needed help. She should have been seen by a doctor and given proper treatment straight away." The family is now calling for a public inquiry into Lowry's death. The Royal Cornwall Hospital is one of several hospitals in the UK that have been criticized for providing poor care to patients. In 2013, a report by the Care Quality Commission found that the hospital was "inadequate" and "unsafe." The hospital has since been placed in special measures and is under close scrutiny by the government. The Health Secretary has said that he is "extremely concerned" about the care provided at the Royal Cornwall Hospital. He said: "I have asked the Care Quality Commission to carry out an urgent investigation into the hospital. I want to know what went wrong and why." The government is also planning to launch a new inquiry into the provision of care in hospitals. The inquiry will be led by Robert Francis QC, who previously led the inquiry into the Mid Staffordshire hospital scandal. The Francis Inquiry found that hundreds of patients died at Mid Staffordshire hospital due to poor care. title: Shakespeare's skull 'probably stolen' from Stratford grave
text: The discovery gives credence to a news report in 1879, later dismissed as fiction, that trophy hunters took the skull from his shallow grave in 1794. A team used a ground-penetrating radar (GPR) scan to look through the soil beneath the Holy Trinity Church floorboards, where Shakespeare is buried. The scan revealed anomalies which suggested that the poet's skull may have been removed from his grave. The parish clerk's record of the funeral in April 1616 states that Shakespeare's body was placed in a shallow grave dug seven feet deep. There was no evidence of a coffin. By the 17th Century, it was common practice to reuse graves after 10 years, and Shakespeare's grave was considered fair game. In 1794, the sexton of the church at the time, William Castle, offered visitors to Shakespeare's grave the opportunity to view the skull and other bones for a fee. A young man paid a shilling to view the skull, but when he wanted to sketch it, Castle demanded another five shillings. The youth refused, and a fight ensued. According to the press cutting from The Argos of 7th June 1879: "The struggle was witnessed by a sexton from an adjoining parish. When questioned about the disturbance, Castle confessed that he had dug up the remains the previous May. "He said that he sold the skull, which appeared to have been perforated by a pike or other weapon, to a man in a white coat and brown trousers. Castle was drunk at the time and did not know the buyer's name. The skull was then worth £300 but would now be worth many times that amount." In 1836, a monument was built close to the grave to deter visitors from trying to dig up the remains. The grave itself lies within the sanctuary and is covered by a stone slab. The GPR scan revealed significant voids beneath the floor around the tomb believed to be Shakespeare's. Dr. Kevin Colls, who led the GPR scan team, said: "We discovered a significant void in the area of the skull and neck, and other voids that appear to be consistent with the removal of long bones. "I am more convinced on the basis of what we saw on the scan, that the skull is not present in the grave. This is a significant development that supports the theory that Shakespeare's skull was stolen." The Vicar of Holy Trinity Church, the Rev. Patrick Taylor, said: "These findings are fascinating and provide fresh evidence to support the theory that Shakespeare's skull was stolen."

title: There's now a word for nails on a blackboard - but it's not in English
text: It's a word to describe the feeling we get when we hear the sound of fingernails on a chalkboard, or a knife scraping a plate. The word is "misophonia", and it comes from the Greek words "miso" (hatred) and "phone" (sound). People with misophonia have a strong negative reaction to certain sounds, even everyday ones like chewing, slurping, or breathing. These sounds can trigger feelings of anger, anxiety, or even panic. Misophonia is a relatively new condition, and it's not yet fully understood. However, research suggests that it may be caused by a combination of factors, including genetics, brain structure, and life experiences. There is no cure for misophonia, but there are treatments that can help to manage the symptoms. These treatments include sound therapy, cognitive behavioural therapy, and medication. If you think you may have misophonia, it's important to see a doctor to get a diagnosis. There are also a number of support groups available for people with misophonia, which can provide information and support. What causes misophonia? The exact cause of misophonia is unknown, but it is thought to be caused by a combination of factors, including: Genetics: Misophonia may be inherited, as it often runs in families. Brain structure: People with misophonia have been found to have differences in the way their brains process sound. Life experiences: Certain life experiences, such as trauma or abuse, may increase the risk of developing misophonia. What are the symptoms of misophonia? The symptoms of misophonia can vary from person to person, but they typically include: A strong negative reaction to certain sounds Feelings of anger, anxiety, or panic Difficulty concentrating Withdrawal from social situations Irritability Fatigue How is misophonia treated? There is no cure for misophonia, but there are treatments that can help to manage the symptoms. These treatments include: Sound therapy: This involves listening to sounds that are designed to reduce the negative reaction to trigger sounds. Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT): This type of therapy helps people to change the way they think about and react to trigger sounds. Medication: Some medications, such as antidepressants, can help to reduce the symptoms of misophonia.

title: Bowie: Every tour and studio album
text: Bowie: Every tour and studio album He was a prolific writer, toured extensively and released his last album days before he died. You Pretty Things" and "Changes". In 1972, Bowie released his fifth album, "The Rise and Fall of Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders from Mars". Bowie's eighth album, "Young Americans", was released in 1975 and was a more soul and funk-influenced album, with tracks like "Fame" and "Golden Years". Bowie's tenth album, "Low", was released in 1977 and was a collaboration with Brian Eno. The album was a more ambient and experimental album, with tracks like "Sound and Vision" and "Be My Wife". 1980-1989: The Berlin years and beyond Bowie's eleventh album, "Heroes", was released in 1977 and was a collaboration with Brian Eno. The album was a more accessible and commercial album than his previous work, with tracks like "Heroes" and "Beauty and the Beast". Bowie's twelfth album, "Lodger", was released in 1979 and was a more experimental album, with tracks like "Boys Keep Swinging" and "DJ". In 1980, Bowie released his thirteenth album, "Scary Monsters (and Super Creeps)". The album was a more pop-oriented album, with tracks like "Ashes to Ashes" and "Fashion". Bowie's fourteenth album, "Let's Dance", was released in 1983 and was his most commercially successful album, with tracks like "Let's Dance" and "China Girl". 1990-2016: The later years Bowie's fifteenth album, "Blackstar", was released in 2016 and was his last album before he died. The album was a more experimental and introspective album, with tracks like "Lazarus" and "Blackstar". Bowie died of liver cancer on 10 January 2016, just two days after his 69th birthday.

title: Blood test 'detects cancer relapse'
text: Blood test 'detects cancer relapse' By James Gallagher Health editor, BBC News website Scientists at the Institute of Cancer Research in London found traces of breast cancer eight months before doctors would normally have noticed. In the trial, the blood test spotted the secondary tumours in 33 out of 49 patients, or 67%, eight months earlier than scans, on average. And three-quarters of the patients were correctly identified by the test within five months. The findings, published in the journal Science Translational Medicine, could be used to guide doctors in giving follow-up treatment after surgery. 'This is a really important advance,' said Prof Nicholas Turner, who led the study. 'We know that detecting cancer recurrence at the earliest possible stage is critical to successful treatment, but current blood tests are far too insensitive.' The test measures the amount of circulating tumour DNA - ctDNA - in the blood. Every time a cell dies, it releases some of its DNA into the blood. Cancerous cells release more ctDNA than normal cells. So a higher-than-normal level of ctDNA in the bloodstream can indicate that cancer is present. In the trial, the test correctly spotted the tumours in almost all patients - 98% -  once they were larger than 3mm. But between 1 and 3mm, the detection rate was 30%. 'We don't yet have enough information to see if this approach could detect cancers less than 1mm, but we continue to improve our techniques,' said Prof Turner. The team think the test could be used to target follow-up treatments for patients who have had surgery. Doctors would be able to detect whether patients were likely to suffer a relapse at least five months earlier than they can with scans. 'For those patients identified with measurable disease, that means treatment can be started more quickly, so giving them the best chance of cure,' said Prof Turner. The team want to do further studies now to confirm the benefits of the test and to develop it for other cancers. 'This is an important step forward in the blood testing field,' said Dr Lisa Wilde, Cancer Research UK's head of research information. 'It's the first time researchers have seen the potential of detecting cancer recurrence at a time when doctors would not normally notice the tumour through standard imaging tests. 'This research could pave the way for a blood test that could improve the care of patients after surgery.'

title: Extra £40m for green spaces in England, Boris Johnson pledges
text: By Roger Harrabin BBC environment analyst The government says the cash will fund thousands of jobs in conservation. The prime minister also promised new national parks and greater protections for England’s iconic landscapes. Environmentalists welcomed the money, but said it represented only a very small proportion of the investment that was needed to tackle the climate and nature emergencies. The announcement came on the eve of the UN climate summit in Glasgow which the UK is hosting. At the summit, world leaders will discuss ways to cut carbon dioxide emissions and protect and restore nature. Campaigners will be looking to persuade governments to come up with more ambitious targets and the extra funding for green spaces will help the UK's case since it will demonstrate that the government is willing to back up its promises with cash. The government says the project will create or support about 6,000 jobs, 4,000 of which will be in the public sector and the rest in the private sector. The 1,500 miles of new footpaths and cycleways are intended to encourage people to get outdoors for exercise and improve their health and well-being. Other themes include: A National Forest for the north of England. Setting up a new national park in the Forest of Bowland in Lancashire. Extending the existing New Forest National Park in Hampshire. Creating a national park in the Yorkshire Dales. Planting millions more trees as part of the UK's commitment to reaching net zero emissions by 2050. Creating a Nature Recovery Network - a network of interconnected land and sea to aid wildlife. The government says the project will create or support about 6,000 jobs, 4,000 of which will be in the public sector and the rest in the private sector. In the run-up to the election last year, Mr Johnson promised to protect 30% of land for nature by 2030, with an interim target of 10% to be achieved by 2023. The government says 11% of land in England is now designated for protection and the new announcement is intended to help hit the target. Conservationists warned, however, that designating land is not enough and the government needs to ensure that the protected areas are managed in a way that benefits nature. The Wildlife Trusts said the extra funding was "a good start" but more was needed. "This funding is welcome at a time when the climate and nature crises are threatening to overwhelm the natural world," said the group's chief executive, Craig Bennett. "But it's just a drop in the ocean compared to the £1bn needed annually to restore and safeguard the UK's natural assets." The RSPB welcomed the creation of a National Forest for the north of England, saying it was a "huge opportunity" to bring back nature and tackle the climate emergency. "The creation of a National Forest, if done right, has the potential to be both a nature recovery powerhouse and a beacon for the north of England," said RSPB director of conservation Mike Clarke.
