title: Car immobiliser easy to crack, say researchers
text: Vehicles made by Ford, Toyota, Volkswagen and Chrysler have been affected, the researchers from Birmingham, Newcastle and Radboud University in the Netherlands said. The team say car manufacturers must change the encryption method used, as the current system is 'outdated'. The immobiliser, a security device fitted to most modern cars, is designed to prevent a vehicle from being started if the correct key is not used. It works by using a transponder chip in the key to send a unique encrypted code to the car's engine control unit. If the code matches, the engine will start. If it doesn't, the engine will not start. However, the researchers have found that the encryption system used in many car immobilisers can be cracked, potentially letting a thief steal the car. They say that the encryption system used in many car immobilisers is based on a technique called 'rolling code'. Rolling code is a method of encryption where the code changes each time the key is used. This makes it difficult for a thief to copy the code and use it to start the car themselves. However, the researchers have found that the rolling code system used in many car immobilisers is vulnerable to a type of attack called a 'replay attack'. A replay attack is a type of attack where a thief records the encrypted code being sent from the key to the car's engine control unit. The thief can then replay the recorded code to the car's engine control unit, which will then start the car. The researchers say that car manufacturers must change the encryption method used in car immobilisers to prevent replay attacks. They say that a more secure encryption method is available, called 'challenge-response'. Challenge-response is a type of encryption where the car's engine control unit sends a challenge to the key. The key then responds with an encrypted response. If the response is correct, the engine will start. If it is not, the engine will not start. The researchers say that challenge-response is a more secure encryption method than rolling code, and that car manufacturers should adopt it to prevent replay attacks. A spokesperson for Ford said: "We are aware of the research and are working to address the concerns raised. "In the meantime, we recommend that our customers use a steering wheel lock or other security device to protect their vehicles." A spokesperson for Toyota said: "We are aware of the research and are working to develop a solution. "In the meantime, we recommend that our customers use a steering wheel lock or other security device to protect their vehicles." A spokesperson for Volkswagen said: "We are aware of the research and are working to develop a solution. "In the meantime, we recommend that our customers use a steering wheel lock or other security device to protect their vehicles." A spokesperson for Chrysler said: "We are aware of the research and are working to develop a solution. "In the meantime, we recommend that our customers use a steering wheel lock or other security device to protect their vehicles."

title: Cocaine smuggling: The bizarre tactics used to hide drugs
text: But sneaking drugs under the noses of authorities can be a risky business, as a Colombian cocaine smuggler discovered this week. Security staff at Madrid airport apprehended him as he stepped off a flight from Bogota, with 5kg of cocaine hidden inside prosthetic buttocks he was wearing under his trousers. While this may seem like an extreme and bizarre method of drug concealment, it's just one example of the many tactics smugglers use to evade detection. In 2018, a Polish man was caught trying to smuggle 110 grams of cocaine by hiding it inside a hollowed-out loaf of bread. Another smuggler attempted to conceal cocaine in the lining of his coffin, apparently hoping that customs officials would be reluctant to open it. Food is a common hiding place for smugglers. One individual was caught trying to smuggle cocaine in frozen fish, while another used hollowed-out pineapples. Drug traffickers have even used the mail system to their advantage, sending packages of cocaine disguised as books, toys, and even clothing. Drugs have also been found concealed in items that are more difficult to search. In one case, smugglers hid cocaine in the plaster cast of a broken leg. In another, they concealed the drugs inside a prosthetic limb. And on one memorable occasion, a group of smugglers attempted to smuggle cocaine into the UK by hiding it inside a shipment of live giant African snails. The methods used to smuggle drugs are constantly evolving, as traffickers become more sophisticated in their attempts to outsmart authorities. But despite their ingenuity, smugglers often face harsh consequences if they are caught. Drug trafficking is a serious crime and can result in lengthy prison sentences. These bizarre tactics serve as a testament to the lengths that drug smugglers will go to in order to evade detection. However, the consequences of getting caught can be severe, and it's important to remember that drug smuggling is a very risky endeavor.

title: Singer Ruth Keggin 'breathes life' into ancient language
text: By Mark Edwards BBC Isle of Man Ruth Keggin's debut solo album features new arrangements of traditional and contemporary folk songs, most of which are sung in the Gaelic language. The singer, from the Isle of Man, has been hailed for her "ethereal" voice and her ability to "breathe life" into the ancient language. "I've always been drawn to the Gaelic language," says Ruth. "It's such a beautiful and expressive language, and it has a rich history and culture behind it." Ruth's album, 'Ta'n Aeg Tannagyn' ('It's Time'), features a mix of traditional and contemporary folk songs, including new arrangements of songs by well-known Manx musicians such as John Kelly and Gordon Hamilton. "I wanted to create an album that would appeal to both traditional folk fans and people who are new to the genre," says Ruth. "I think there's something for everyone on this album." One of the standout tracks on the album is 'Yn Chruinnaght' ('The Gathering'), a traditional Manx folk song that tells the story of a group of friends who gather together to sing and share stories. "It's a beautiful song about friendship and community," says Ruth. "I love singing it, and I hope it brings joy to others." Another highlight of the album is 'Arrane y Chrouw' ('The Song of the Crow'), a contemporary folk song by Manx musician Gordon Hamilton. "It's a really powerful song about the importance of standing up for what you believe in," says Ruth. "I think it's a song that will resonate with a lot of people." Ruth's album has been praised by critics for its "ethereal" sound and its "beautiful" arrangements. "Ruth Keggin has a voice that is both ethereal and powerful," wrote one reviewer. "Her arrangements of traditional and contemporary folk songs are simply stunning." Another reviewer said: "This album is a must-listen for fans of folk music. Ruth Keggin's voice is a gift, and her arrangements are simply breathtaking." Ruth is currently touring the UK to promote her album. She will be playing at a number of venues, including the Celtic Connections festival in Glasgow and the Cambridge Folk Festival. "I'm really excited to be touring with this album," says Ruth. "I can't wait to share my music with people and to hear what they think of it."

title: Chinese doctors jailed for illegal organ harvesting
text: The group had tricked the families of the deceased into thinking they were making official organ donations. title: Times and Sunday Times readership falls after paywall
text: Times Online was registering about 21 million unique users a month to its front page earlier this year but the figure fell to around 12 million in recent weeks. However, the publishers of The Times and The Sunday Times have defended the decision, arguing that it is necessary to protect the quality of their journalism. They also point out that the number of digital subscribers has increased since the paywall was introduced, suggesting that it is not deterring readers from accessing their content. The introduction of paywalls has become increasingly common in the newspaper industry in recent years, as publishers seek to find new ways to generate revenue in the face of declining print sales. However, the success of paywalls has been mixed, with some papers seeing a significant drop in readership while others have seen little or no impact. The Times and The Sunday Times are two of the most prestigious newspapers in the UK, and their decision to introduce a paywall has been closely watched by the industry. The fall in readership that they have experienced is likely to be a concern for other publishers who are considering introducing paywalls of their own. It is too early to say whether the fall in readership experienced by The Times and The Sunday Times will be permanent. title: Tiananmen crash: China police 'detain suspects'
text: All three people in the vehicle died at the scene, according to state media, while 40 people were injured, including five in critical condition. title: Hungary government proposes same-sex adoption ban

title: A83 Rest and Be Thankful reopens after landslip
text: Workers have been clearing 1,000 tonnes of debris from the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A83 after a series of landslips. Meanwhile, the Scottish government is to host a summit for key stakeholders next week to discuss a permanent solution to the "long-standing instability" affecting the route. The A83 has been closed since 2 August, when heavy rain led to the collapse of part of the hillside above the road. After initially being expected to reopen within three weeks, ongoing landslips have meant it has remained closed while contractors have worked to make the area safe and remove the debris. In total, seven landslips have happened at the Rest and Be Thankful over the past fortnight. The last occurred on 8 August, affecting 150m of the hillside and blocking the road with 60,000 tonnes of debris. A team of 100 workers have been involved in the clear-up operation, which has involved using helicopter sling operations to remove larger boulders from the affected area. The full reopening of the road is expected to be delayed until next week, with works ongoing to remove all remaining debris and vegetation, as well as to check for any outstanding subsidence. Eddie Ross, BEAR Scotland's north west representative, said: "I want to thank the communities impacted by the ongoing situation for their continued patience and understanding as our team safely removes remaining debris. "The landslips at the Rest have been challenging but the focus now is on getting the road fully reopened as quickly as possible and safely." While the A83 has been closed, a contraflow system has been in operation on the A82 between Tarbet and Inverarnan. Drivers have also been able to use the Old Military Road as a diversion, although this has been closed on occasion due to its own landslip issues. The Scottish government will host a summit next week to discuss long-term solutions for the Rest and Be Thankful, which has been subject to numerous landslips over the years. Transport secretary Michael Matheson said: "The Scottish government is committed to implementing a permanent engineering solution that will mitigate the risks of landslips at the Rest and Be Thankful. "I have instructed officials to progress design work for a solution that will reduce the frequency and impact of landslips and improve resilience. "Next week, we will bring together key stakeholders at a summit to discuss the geotechnical survey results and outline our plans to deliver a lasting solution."

title: Jermaine Jackson: 'No truth' to allegations in Michael documentary
text: In Leaving Neverland, James Safechuck and Wade Robson claim they were abused by the singer as children. Mr Robson acted as a main witness for Michael Jackson at his 2005 trial, but later filed a lawsuit against the late star after claiming the testimony was given under duress from the singer. The Jackson family and the singer's estate have strongly denied the claims made in the documentary, while several of Michael Jackson's former employees have also spoken out in his defence. A statement from the estate, released after part one of the documentary aired, said: "This so-called 'documentary' is just another rehash of stale and debunked allegations. It's pathetically one-sided and, in addition, crafted as a commercial product to be exploited for monetary gain." The statement accused Leaving Neverland's director, Dan Reed, of pursuing "a sensationalist and biased attack" on Michael Jackson, "using unvetted sources to create a salacious story." Jermaine Jackson, Michael's older brother, has been one of the most vocal members of the family in defending his late brother. In an interview with BBC News, he said: "To think that my brother would be accused of this is beyond comprehension. It's not true. We grew up together. I know my brother. He would never do something like that." Jermaine Jackson also said he had spoken to Wade Robson after the 2005 trial and that Robson had told him he was not abused by Michael Jackson. "He swore on the Bible," Jermaine Jackson said. "He was very adamant that he was not abused." Since the documentary aired, Robson has given several interviews in which he has defended his decision to come forward now. He told CBS News: "I was groomed from the age of seven. I spent every day with him at Neverland, alone with him in his bedroom, sleeping in his bed. There was no one there to protect me from him. "I don't want any other child to go through what I went through. That's why I'm sharing my story." The Jackson family has said they are considering legal action against the makers of Leaving Neverland.

title: Robot used to guide surgeons through knee operations
text: By Eleanor Bradford BBC Scotland Health Correspondent The technique is being tested at Glasgow Royal Infirmary where 150 patients are involved in trials. It is part of a collaboration between surgeons, bio-engineers and a US health care company and has the potential to make surgery more accurate, less invasive and quicker. The robot is called Rosa and it was originally designed to help remove brain tumours but can also be used to help carry out knee surgery. It works by using a CT scan to create an individual 3D model of a patient's knee, which the surgeon uses to plan the operation. During surgery, the robot then guides the surgeon's movements, making sure they are as precise as possible. This can reduce the risk of complications and speed up the recovery time for patients. Consultant orthopaedic surgeon Mufaddal Meghji said: "With the current techniques that we use at the moment, we still have to do an additional small incision in the knee to put a camera inside the knee to look around and check our accuracy. "With the robot, because of the 3D planning that we've done we don't have to do that - we can just go straight in and we're much more likely to be very accurate indeed." The robot is also being tested in a number of other hospitals around the world and the results so far have been very promising. In one study, patients who had knee surgery using the robot had a 50% reduced risk of complications and were able to recover more quickly than those who had surgery using traditional techniques. The robot is not yet widely available but it is hoped that it will become more common in the future. If it does, it could have a major impact on the way that knee surgery is performed.

title: Parking fine appeal success varies between council areas
text: Some English councils approve only one in 10 appeals against on-street fines, while others accept nearly every one. Runnymede Council in Surrey accepted just 9% of appeals while Basildon Council in Essex approved 93%. The figures, from the RAC Foundation, show a wide variation in success rates across 159 councils surveyed. The RAC Foundation's Steve Gooding said: "The gulf in the success rates between those councils at the top and the bottom of the table is extraordinarily wide." He said this suggested that some councils were "too ready to reject appeals" and called for greater consistency. The data shows that in some areas, drivers are more likely to have their appeals rejected than others. For example, in London, only 18% of appeals were successful, compared to 49% in the West Midlands. The RAC Foundation said this could be due to a number of factors, including the way that councils interpret the rules and the amount of evidence that drivers provide in their appeals. The group is calling for councils to be more transparent about their appeals process and to provide drivers with clear guidance on how to appeal a fine. The Department for Transport said it was "concerned" about the variation in success rates and was working with councils to improve the appeals process. A spokesperson said: "We have introduced a new statutory code of practice for councils to follow when handling parking appeals and will work with councils to ensure they comply with it." The RAC Foundation's research is based on data from the Traffic Penalty Tribunal, which is responsible for adjudicating parking appeals. The tribunal's data shows that the number of appeals has increased in recent years. In 2017, there were 415,000 appeals, compared to 360,000 in 2016. The RAC Foundation said this increase could be due to a number of factors, including the growing number of parking fines being issued and the increasing complexity of the appeals process. The group is calling for the government to simplify the appeals process and to make it easier for drivers to challenge unfair fines.

title: Megan Lee: Takeaway bosses jailed over allergy death
text: Megan Lee: Takeaway bosses jailed over allergy death Megan Lee, 15, suffered irreversible brain damage after having an allergic reaction to food from Royal Spice in Oswaldtwistle, Lancashire, in 2016. She died two years later. The takeaway's owners, Mohammed Abdul Kuddus, 40, and Harun Rashid, 38, were found guilty of manslaughter by gross negligence at Manchester Crown Court on Monday. The court heard that Megan had ordered a chicken tikka masala from the takeaway, which contained peanuts. She was allergic to peanuts and had made it clear to the restaurant staff when she placed her order. However, the food she received contained traces of peanuts, which triggered a severe allergic reaction. Megan's parents, Martin and Gemma, said they were "relieved" that the takeaway owners had been found guilty. They said: "We can now start to try to move on with our lives, knowing that justice has been done." The court heard that the takeaway had a history of food safety violations. In 2015, it was given a zero rating by the Food Standards Agency after inspectors found mouse droppings in the kitchen. The takeaway was also fined £5,000 for failing to properly label allergens on its menu. In a statement, the Food Standards Agency said: "This case is a tragic reminder of the importance of food businesses taking their responsibilities seriously. Food businesses must ensure that the food they serve is safe and that they have robust systems in place to manage allergens." The takeaway's owners have been sentenced to six years and eight months in prison. They have also been banned from working in the food industry for life. Megan's death has led to calls for tougher laws on food safety. Her parents have launched a campaign called "Megan's Law", which calls for mandatory prison sentences for food businesses that cause death or serious injury through negligence. The government has said it will consider Megan's Law as part of its review of food safety laws.

title: Everest: Top Sherpas slam Nepal's plan to clean rubbish from mountain
text: By Surendra Phuyal BBC Nepali The government says the army will be used for the task, which will cost 860 million Nepali rupees ($7.5m; £5.7m). Last year, they managed to clear about 10,000kg of waste from the region. But Kami Rita, who holds the record for the most successful Everest summits, said the plan was yet another "publicity stunt". "There is no guarantee that rubbish thrown in the icefall area will not slide down again," he said. "The only sustainable solution is a ban on trekkers taking oxygen cylinders above base camp." Most climbers use bottled oxygen to help them breathe at high altitudes, and many discard their empty cylinders on the mountainside. Another veteran Sherpa guide, Mingma Gyalje Sherpa, agreed. "This plan is impractical and a waste of taxpayers' money," he said. "The army should be used for more important tasks." The Sherpas have a long history of helping climbers on Everest, and their expertise is essential for the success of expeditions. They have been critical of the government's handling of the mountain in the past, accusing it of putting profit before safety. In 2019, they called for a limit on the number of climbers on Everest after 11 people died in a single week. The government has defended its plan, saying it is committed to cleaning up the mountain. "We are determined to make Everest clean and safe for climbers," said Tourism Minister Yogesh Bhattarai. "We believe this plan is the best way to achieve that." The clean-up operation is due to start in April, and it is expected to take several weeks.

title: Concern raised over changes to probation service
text: Concern raised over changes to probation service By the beginning of next year, 70% of its work in England and Wales will be run by private companies. The government says the move will improve efficiency and reduce reoffending, but critics say it will lead to job losses and a drop in standards. The National Probation Service (NPS) is responsible for supervising offenders who have been released from prison or given community sentences. The government has announced plans to split the NPS into two parts. One part will be responsible for high-risk offenders, and the other will supervise low-risk offenders. The high-risk part will remain in the public sector, but the low-risk part will be outsourced to private companies. The government says the move will save money and improve efficiency. It also says that private companies will be able to offer more innovative and effective ways of supervising offenders. However, critics of the plans say they will lead to job losses and a drop in standards. They also say that private companies will be more interested in making a profit than in rehabilitating offenders. Frances Crook, the director of the Howard League for Penal Reform, said: "This is a disaster for probation and for public safety. "Private companies have no experience of running probation services and they will be more interested in making a profit than in rehabilitating offenders. "This will lead to a drop in standards and an increase in reoffending." The Public and Commercial Services Union (PCS), which represents probation officers, has also criticized the plans. Mark Serwotka, the PCS general secretary, said: "These plans are a disgrace. "They will lead to job losses, a drop in standards and an increase in reoffending. "The government should be investing in the probation service, not dismantling it." The government has said that it will protect jobs and standards in the probation service. It has also said that it will monitor the performance of private companies closely. However, critics of the plans remain unconvinced. They say that the government is putting profit before public safety.

title: Coronavirus: Intensive care demand surged at peak of crisis
text: An official report on Covid cases requiring intensive care shows demand peaked on 29 March, with 29 patients admitted in a single day. Admissions remained close to the this level for the next four days, before falling away steadily to reach a low of four patients on 10 May. The 11-page report, published by Public Health Scotland, found the median age for admissions for Covid-related critical care was 67, and around two thirds of patients were male. In total, 1,002 Covid cases were admitted to intensive care in Scotland between 23 February and 15 June. Of those, 63% were discharged from hospital, and 37% died. The report's authors conclude: "Critical care admissions peaked on 29th March following which there was a slow but sustained decline in the number of admissions throughout April and May. "From 1st June, the number has remained low, with only one patient admitted to a critical care bed in the last three weeks. "These data show that the critical care surge capacity created was not required in Scotland." However, Prof. Andrew Elder, vice-president of the Scottish Intensive Care Society, warned: "The report is in effect a post mortem on the first critical phase of the COVID-19 pandemic and shows that the dreadful predictions made by some who even suggested using the car park at Hampden Stadium as an ICU did not come about. "NHS staff across Scotland should take heart from this, and from the fact that those who do become critically unwell have an extremely good chance of recovering." The report's findings come a month after the mortality data from the first wave of the pandemic in June were published, which revealed 85% of Covid-19 deaths had occurred in care homes. A separate report by the National Records of Scotland last month showed that at the peak of the crisis in mid-April, 80.5% of all deaths in Scotland were caused by Covid-19. On Wednesday, the Scottish government's daily update showed there had been 147 new cases of Covid-19 reported in the previous 24 hours - the highest UK total since 30 May. title: Oxford top of global university rankings

title: Israeli 'Freedom is basic' niqab advert criticised
text: By George Pierpoint, BBC Newsand Osob Elmi, BBC News The ad, for clothing brand Hoodies, opens with a caption reading "Is Iran here?" and depicts a young woman wearing a black niqab looking over her shoulder with the eyes cut out. title: At what age do you feel you have reached adulthood?
text: Nationwide's study of 2,000 over-18s found more than one in 10 did not think of themselves as fully fledged grown-ups until they reached the age of 27. This suggests that the traditional view of adulthood being reached at 18 is outdated, and that people are taking longer to feel like they have fully matured. There are a number of factors that may have contributed to this change. One is the increasing complexity of modern life. Young people today face a more challenging job market, higher levels of debt, and a more complex social landscape than their parents did. This can make it difficult for them to feel like they have their lives together, even if they have reached the age of 18. Another factor is the rise of social media. Social media can create a sense of comparison and competition, which can make young people feel like they are not measuring up. This can lead to feelings of insecurity and inadequacy, which can make it difficult to feel like an adult. Of course, there is no one-size-fits-all answer to the question of when adulthood is reached. Some people may feel like adults at 18, while others may not feel like they have fully matured until they are in their 30s or even 40s. Ultimately, it is up to each individual to decide when they feel like they have reached adulthood. However, the Nationwide study suggests that the traditional view of adulthood being reached at 18 is outdated. Young people today are taking longer to feel like they have fully matured, and this is likely due to a number of factors, including the increasing complexity of modern life and the rise of social media. It is important to remember that there is no right or wrong answer to the question of when adulthood is reached. Everyone develops at their own pace, and there is no need to compare yourself to others. If you are not feeling like an adult yet, don't worry. You will get there eventually.

title: Shoreham air crash pilot 'flew too low' at Southport airshow

The CAA said that the ATC staff had "failed to provide the pilot with adequate information and guidance about the minimum safe height" and that this was "a contributory factor to the accident". The CAA has made a number of recommendations to Southport Airshow and the ATC service provider in order to prevent a similar accident from happening again. These recommendations include: Revising the display authorisation to ensure that it clearly states the minimum safe height for the display Providing the pilot with a more detailed briefing on the risks of flying the aircraft below the minimum safe height Improving the training of the ATC staff Providing the ATC staff with better information about the minimum safe height Southport Airshow said that it had accepted the CAA's recommendations and that it would be implementing them. The ATC service provider said that it would also be implementing the CAA's recommendations. The BBC has contacted Mr Hill's family for comment.

title: Gemma Arterton to play Nell Gwynn in London's West End
text: The production has been playing at London's Shakespeare's Globe but will move to the Apollo in February. The play charts the rise of the 17th-Century actress from the slums to the stage – and into the heart of King Charles II. Arterton, who has starred in films such as Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time and Quantum of Solace, said she was "thrilled" to be taking on the role. "Nell Gwynn is a fascinating character," she said. "She was a woman of her time, but she was also ahead of her time. She was a successful actress, a mistress to the king, and a woman who spoke her mind." Arterton said she was particularly drawn to Gwynn's "wit and intelligence." "She was a very clever woman who used her intelligence to get ahead in life," she said. "She was also a very funny woman, and I think that comes across in the play." The play is written by Jessica Swale, who won the Olivier Award for Best New Comedy in 2015 for her play Nell Gwynn. Swale said she was "delighted" that Arterton was playing the title role. "She's a fantastic actress and I know she's going to bring something really special to the role," she said. Nell Gwynn is directed by Christopher Luscombe, who has previously directed productions such as The Importance of Being Earnest and The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time. Luscombe said he was "excited" to be working on the play. "It's a great play with a wonderful cast and crew," he said. "I can't wait to share it with audiences." Nell Gwynn will open at the Apollo Theatre on February 13, 2023.

title: Italy's Giuseppe Conte tells populist leaders: 'Stop fighting or I'll quit'
text: Mr Conte said the parties must "honour the government's obligations" or he would "simply end my mandate". The fractious year-old coalition of the League, the far-right party of Interior Minister Matteo Salvini, and the populist Five Star Movement, headed by former Prime Minister Luigi Di Maio, has been on the verge of collapse for weeks. On Tuesday, Salvini, who is also deputy prime minister, repeated his call for fresh elections, saying the coalition was "finished... beyond repair". His comments came after the League failed in an attempt to pass a motion of no confidence in Transport Minister Danilo Toninelli from the Five Star Movement. Di Maio has accused Salvini of seeking to "destroy" the government and has said that Five Star will not be "blackmailed". He has also said that the government should be allowed to continue until its term expires in 2023. The coalition has been riven by disagreements over a range of issues, including immigration, the economy and Europe. Salvini has been a vocal critic of the EU and wants to renegotiate Italy's membership. Five Star, on the other hand, has a more pro-European stance. The crisis in the coalition has raised concerns about Italy's political stability and the future of its membership of the eurozone. The country is already struggling with a high level of public debt and a weak economy. If the coalition collapses, it could lead to fresh elections and a period of political instability. This could damage Italy's economy and its relationship with the EU. Conte has said that he is "determined" to keep the government together, but it is unclear whether he will be able to do so. The parties have until 20 August to reach an agreement or the government will collapse. The Italian President, Sergio Mattarella, has said that he will not allow Italy to become ungovernable and has warned that he will not hesitate to dissolve parliament and call fresh elections if necessary.

title: Conservation: Bid to save reptiles and amphibians in Wales
text: Conservation: Bid to save reptiles and amphibians in Wales By Matt Lloyd BBC Wales More than 50% of snake, newt and toad species are under threat globally, conservationists have said. In Wales, common lizards are the only reptiles that are not considered a priority for conservation action. But adders, slow-worms, and grass snakes are all "of conservation concern", while the natterjack toad has undergone severe population decline. Efforts are underway to help these species. The Wildlife Trust of South & West Wales is appealing for volunteers to help survey reptiles and amphibians. The survey is part of a larger project, funded by the National Lottery Heritage Fund, which aims to create a network of homes for wildlife across south and west Wales. The trust's conservation officer, Katie-jo Luxton, said: "Reptiles and amphibians are an important part of our ecosystem. "For example, adders help to control rodent populations, while grass snakes eat small mammals and birds. "They are also a food source for other animals, such as foxes and buzzards." The trust's survey will help to identify where reptiles and amphibians are found, and to assess the threats they face. This information will then be used to develop conservation plans to help these species. Ms Luxton said: "We need volunteers to help us with this survey. It's a great opportunity to learn more about these fascinating creatures and to help us to protect them." Volunteers will be trained to identify reptiles and amphibians, and to record their sightings. They will also be asked to collect data on the habitat where they see these animals. The survey will run from April to September. Anyone who is interested in volunteering can contact the Wildlife Trust of South & West Wales. In addition to the survey, the trust is also working to create new homes for reptiles and amphibians. This includes creating ponds for toads and newts, and creating log piles and stone walls for snakes and lizards. Ms Luxton said: "We hope that by creating new homes for these animals, we can help to increase their populations and to ensure their long-term survival."

title: Honour of Kings: China's most vilified online game
text: By Timothy McDonald Business Reporter, BBC News Access to Honour of Kings is now restricted to one hour a day for children aged under 12 and two hours for children between 12 and 18. The limits were announced by Tencent, the Chinese gaming giant behind the title, in response to growing concerns about gaming addiction among young people. Honour of Kings is one of the most popular mobile games in the world, with over 100 million daily active users. However, it has also been the subject of much controversy, with critics arguing that it is addictive and harmful to children. Tencent has defended the game, saying that it has taken steps to address the issue of addiction. In addition to the new time limits, the company has also introduced a number of other measures, such as limiting the amount of money that children can spend on in-game purchases. However, some experts believe that the new measures do not go far enough. They argue that the time limits are too lenient and that the game should be banned for children altogether. The debate over Honour of Kings is part of a wider discussion about the impact of gaming on children. In recent years, there has been growing concern about the amount of time that children spend playing video games, and the potential effects of this on their physical and mental health. Some studies have suggested that excessive gaming can lead to a number of problems, including addiction, obesity, and sleep deprivation. However, other studies have found that gaming can also have positive benefits, such as improving cognitive skills and social development. The debate over the impact of gaming on children is likely to continue for some time. In the meantime, parents should be aware of the potential risks and benefits of gaming, and should set limits on their children's gaming time. Tencent's new time limits on Honour of Kings are a step in the right direction, but they do not go far enough. The company should consider banning the game for children altogether, or at least reducing the time limits further.

title: Cambridge homeless man Raymond Boyle's killer, 18, jailed
text: Jack Robinson stamped on 53-year-old Raymond Boyle's head and back, in Jesus Green last June. He dragged him unconscious to the River Cam, where his body was found the following day. On Friday, Robinson, 18, was convicted of murder and jailed for life with a minimum term of 18 years. The court was told that Boyle, who was originally from County Down, had been sleeping rough in Cambridge for a number of months at the time of his death. Witnesses described how Robinson had been drinking all day and was "in a rage" before launching his brutal attack on Boyle, who was unarmed and had done nothing to provoke him. In a victim impact statement read to the court, Boyle's sister said: "My brother was a gentleman. He always had time for others and never had a bad word to say about anyone. He did not deserve what happened to him." Detective Inspector Emma Whitting, who led the investigation, said: "This was a senseless and brutal act of violence that has robbed a family of a loved one. Our thoughts are with Raymond's family and friends at this difficult time." Robinson had denied murder, claiming that he had acted in self-defense. However, the jury rejected his account and convicted him by a majority of 11 to one. In sentencing Robinson, Judge David Farrell said: "This was a sustained and violent attack on a defenseless man who was sleeping on the streets. You have shown no remorse for your actions and I am satisfied that you are a dangerous offender." Robinson's conviction is a reminder of the dangers faced by homeless people in the UK. According to the charity Crisis, there are over 4,000 people sleeping rough on the streets of England on any given night. Many of these people are vulnerable to violence and abuse. The death of Raymond Boyle is a tragedy. It should never have happened. We must do more to help homeless people and to ensure that they are safe.

title: MP Yeo cleared by standards watchdog
text: The Tory MP was secretly filmed by Sunday Times investigators posing as representatives of a fictional energy company seeking to hire his services. The paper said he had suggested charging up to £7,000 for a day's work, and had offered to use his parliamentary status to "bang the drum" for the company. In a statement, Mr Yeo said he had "fully co-operated" with the investigation and had "nothing to hide". He said he was "completely confident" that he had not broken any rules. The Standards Commissioner is an independent watchdog that investigates allegations of breaches of the MPs' code of conduct. It can recommend sanctions, including suspension from Parliament. In its report, the Commissioner said that there was "no evidence" that Mr Yeo had breached the MPs' code of conduct. It said that he had not used his parliamentary status to lobby for the company, and that he had not charged for any work that he had not carried out. The Commissioner did, however, find that Mr Yeo had "failed to declare" his meeting with the Sunday Times investigators. He said that this was a "minor breach" of the MPs' code of conduct, but that it did not warrant any further action. Mr Yeo welcomed the Commissioner's findings, saying that they "vindicated" his position. He said he was "pleased" that the investigation had been "thorough and impartial". The Sunday Times said it stood by its story, and that it believed Mr Yeo had "abused his position" as an MP. The case is a reminder of the importance of MPs following the MPs' code of conduct. The code is designed to ensure that MPs act in the public interest, and that they do not use their position for personal gain. The Commissioner's findings will be seen as a blow to the Sunday Times, which has been campaigning for tougher action against MPs who are alleged to have broken the MPs' code of conduct. The case is also likely to raise questions about the role of the Standards Commissioner. Some critics have argued that the Commissioner is too lenient on MPs, and that it is not doing enough to uphold the MPs' code of conduct.

title: Birmingham bin strike: Council 'backtracking on deal'
text: Unite said the council was sending out refuse trucks without "leading hands", who operate at the back of vehicles. title: Council demanded payment card details via email
text: Islington Council had required residents to share the security code from the rear of their cards, as well as their card number and expiry date, before being able to access services including paying council tax or reporting repairs. The council said these details were required to provide an extra layer of security as residents were able to set up accounts to view and pay their bills without registering a password. "This is an optional process and residents can still make payments via our website, phone or in person without providing these details," a spokesperson told the BBC. However, once shared, the information could potentially have been used by fraudsters to make purchases online. "Sharing the three-digit CVV number, which is used to verify card payments online and over the phone, is never a good idea," said David Emm, principal security researcher at Kaspersky. "Even if your council asks for it, it should raise an alarm bell. There are far more secure ways to provide additional authorisation." The council said it was reviewing its processes after receiving complaints from residents and advice from a data protection officer. A freedom of information request by the BBC revealed that Islington Council had received 162 complaints from residents about data security since 2019. However, the council insisted that no payment card details had been compromised as a result of the email demand. "Protecting residents' personal data and money is of paramount importance to us and we would never knowingly put residents' data at risk," the spokesperson said. The council also said it was "committed to transparency" and had been "open and honest" about the process used to verify residents' identities. "We understand that some residents may have concerns about sharing this information, and we are therefore reviewing our processes to identify alternative ways of providing additional authorisation," the spokesperson said.

title: New Zealand's Dunedin jokes about losing 'steepest street' title
text: For years, Dunedin's Baldwin Street proudly held that title, and was listed in the Guinness Book of Records. But on Tuesday, the accolade went to a little lane in the Welsh town of Harlech. The new steepest street, Ffordd Pen Llech, has a gradient of 37.45%, compared to Baldwin Street's 34.8%. Dunedin Mayor Aaron Hawkins took the news with good humor, joking that he would be sending a "wee bit of coal" to Harlech to help them "keep their fires burning". "We're not going to begrudge them the title," Hawkins said. "We've had a good run, and it's time for someone else to have a turn." Baldwin Street has been a popular tourist attraction for years, with people flocking from all over the world to see the "steepest street in the world." But locals say they're not too worried about losing the title. "It's still a pretty steep street," said one resident. "And it's still a lot of fun to walk up and down." Others agreed, saying that the title didn't really matter. "It's still a beautiful street, and it's still a part of our community," said another resident. "We're not going to let a little thing like this change that." In fact, some people say that losing the title could actually be a good thing for Dunedin. "It might make us more unique," said one resident. "We're not just the steepest street in the world anymore. We're the second steepest." Whatever happens, Dunedin residents are determined to make the most of their city's unique feature. "We're proud of Baldwin Street," said Mayor Hawkins. "And we're going to keep celebrating it, no matter what." In the meantime, Harlech residents are enjoying their newfound fame. "It's great to be the new home of the steepest street in the world," said one resident. "We're hoping it will bring more tourists to our town." Only time will tell whether Harlech can keep its title. But for now, the Welsh town is enjoying its moment in the spotlight.

title: Tate Britain hits £45m renovation target
text: Nine of the building's gallery rooms are being refurbished, as are the entrance area and other public spaces. The target was reached with a £5m donation from the Dorset Foundation, set up by the late philanthropist Sir John Paul Getty Jr. Tate's director Maria Balshaw said: "This £45m fundraising success is a magnificent achievement and I am enormously grateful to all of our donors for their incredible support. "This major refurbishment will transform the visitor experience and enable us to share more of the national collection of British art with our audiences. We can't wait to welcome visitors back to Tate Britain in 2023." The redevelopment will include new artworks and displays, as well as improved accessibility and facilities. It is the first major refurbishment of the building since it opened in 1897 as the National Gallery of British Art. The gallery is home to works by some of the UK's most famous artists, including JMW Turner, John Constable and Francis Bacon. The renovation project is expected to be completed in 2023. The Dorset Foundation is a charitable trust that supports a wide range of causes, including the arts, education and healthcare. Its donation to Tate Britain is the largest single donation the gallery has ever received. Sir John Paul Getty Jr was an American billionaire who lived in the UK for many years. He was a passionate collector of art and donated many works to Tate Britain. He died in 2003 and left a large bequest to the Dorset Foundation. The foundation's donation to Tate Britain will help to ensure that the gallery can continue to share its world-class collection with the public for many years to come.

title: Tropical forests 'better managed'
text: By Richard Black Environment correspondent, BBC News The area under some form of sustainable management plan increased by about 50% over the period; but about 90% of tropical forest is still managed under no plan at all. In addition, the researchers highlight three main areas of concern: - Deforestation: Primary forest loss increased by 40%, with the vast majority of it in the tropics. - Fragmentation: Forests are increasingly being broken up into ever-smaller blocks, which can damage their ecological function. - Species on the move: Major tree species are moving towards the poles at faster rates than ever - about 4.2km per decade on average since the early 2000s. This could have major implications for the functioning of forest ecosystems. The study used a range of publicly available data, including high-resolution satellite images. Some of this is available for free, which enabled the researchers to repeat previous assessments and see how the situation was changing. "We're trying to track the state of the world's forests on the basis of the best available information," Prof Hansen told BBC News. "It's not perfect and there are gaps, but it's the first consistent global picture," he said. The paper's lead author, Prof Nate McDowell of the University of Virginia, told BBC News: "One of the striking things, particularly in the tropics, is the fragmentation of the forest. "We are seeing this pretty substantial increase over time. And this is related to deforestation, and it's also related to the development of infrastructure - roads and agriculture. "These fragmentation effects can lead to a suite of negative impacts on the forest, affecting things like biodiversity, carbon storage and hydrological function," he explained. The research team say their findings show that there has been limited progress towards implementing sustainable forest management in the tropics - but they are hopeful that the information they have provided could strengthen global efforts to protect the world's forests. "Our results suggest the international community still has a long way to go in reaching its goal of sustainable forest management," said Prof McDowell. "But they also highlight the fact that there have been some positive changes, and they provide evidence that could be used to further improve tropical forest management."

title: Artist's designs for Alabama church bombing window on display
text: The bombing by members of the Ku Klux Klan was a new low in the fight for civil rights. title: Deepfake queen prompts 200-plus complaints to Ofcom

title: Islamic State claims Kabul's latest deadly attacks

title: Couple who met on Bardsey Island to be its new wardens
text: Mari Huws, 27, and Emyr Glyn Owen, 33, will be looking after Bardsey Island off the Llŷn Peninsula from September. The couple replace Chris and Beca Williams, who were the island's wardens for over a decade. Mari, a former primary school teacher from Gaerwen, on Anglesey, and Emyr, a freelance forestry worker from Beddgelert in Gwynedd, met on Bardsey in 2018 while they were both volunteering for the island's conservation charity, The Bardsey Island Trust. They were drawn to the island's unique atmosphere and natural beauty and have been returning regularly ever since. Now, they are excited to take on the role of wardens and play their part in looking after this special place. "We're both passionate about the island and its wildlife, and we believe it's important to protect and conserve this unique environment," said Mari. "We're also looking forward to meeting and working with the many visitors who come to Bardsey each year." Emyr added: "We're grateful to Chris and Beca for all the hard work they've done over the years. They've been amazing wardens and we're looking forward to building on their legacy." As wardens of Bardsey Island, Mari and Emyr will be responsible for a range of duties, including: Welcoming and informing visitors Maintaining the island's infrastructure Carrying out conservation work Monitoring the island's wildlife Acting as ambassadors for the island They will also be working closely with the Bardsey Island Trust to help protect and manage the island and its wildlife. Bardsey, also known as Ynys Enlli, is a small tidal island situated two miles off the tip of the Llŷn Peninsula. It is home to a variety of wildlife and is a popular destination for birdwatchers and nature lovers. Visitors to the island can also explore the ruins of a medieval monastery and a Victorian lighthouse. The island has a long and rich history, and has been inhabited for centuries. It is said that 20,000 saints are buried on the island, and it was once a place of pilgrimage. Bardsey is also a popular destination for day-trippers and campers. There is a small campsite on the island, and visitors can also stay in the former lighthouse keepers' cottages. The island is accessible by boat from Aberdaron. title: UK interest rates remain at record low of 0.5%
text: It has also decided not to extend its quantitative easing programme, designed to stimulate lending in the economy, beyond the £375bn already spent. title: Missed this week's entertainment and arts news?
text: Cheers and applause greeted the record-breaking sale of a 500-year-old painting of Jesus believed to be by Leonardo da Vinci. title: BBC World Service to lose 73 jobs
text: 25 jobs will go on the English-language service with news coverage reduced from 18 hours to 14 each weekday. Arts show The Strand will be axed from April next year, while World Briefing will end in the spring. The corporation said the move was necessary to make savings in the wake of a £285m funding cut recently imposed by the government. In a statement, the BBC said it was committed to continuing to provide "high-quality, impartial and independent journalism" to audiences around the world. "These changes are essential to ensure that the BBC World Service remains sustainable and relevant for the future," the statement said. The job cuts are part of a wider restructuring of the BBC World Service, which will see the corporation focus on its digital and mobile platforms. The BBC said it was investing in new technology to improve the user experience and make its content more accessible to audiences around the world. The cuts to the English-language service will be phased in over the next year. The Strand, which has been broadcast for over 20 years, will end in April next year. World Briefing will also end in the spring. The BBC said it would continue to produce other arts and culture programming, such as The Documentary and Witness. The corporation said it was committed to "exploring new ways to inform, educate and entertain audiences" around the world. The cuts to the BBC World Service have been met with criticism from some quarters. The National Union of Journalists (NUJ) said the job cuts were "devastating" and would "damage the BBC's reputation for providing independent and impartial journalism". The union said the cuts would "make it harder for the BBC to tell the stories of people around the world, and to hold power to account". The BBC has defended the cuts, saying they are necessary to ensure the long-term sustainability of the World Service.

title: GP concern over Betsi Cadwaladr board's hospital plan
text: But Dr Phillip Banfield said the proposals were the harsh reality of Wales' "health care rationing debate". Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board (BCUHB) is the first in Wales to set out plans that would see two full-time consultant-led obstetric and gynaecology units, and a neonatal unit, at Ysbyty Glan Clwyd and Wrexham Maelor Hospital. The proposals are part of a wider plan for the future of health and care in North Wales, and were put out for public consultation on Thursday. The plans would mean four general hospitals in North Wales - Ysbyty Gwynedd, Ysbyty Glan Clwyd, Wrexham Maelor Hospital, and Ysbyty Maelor Wrecsam - receiving specific services in a bid to create specialist centres that provide the best possible care for patients. Under the plans, Ysbyty Gwynedd would become a planned surgical centre for heart surgery - at present the hospital only carries out emergency heart surgery - and would also specialise in cancer care and a range of other services. Ysbyty Glan Clwyd would become the region's emergency medical centre, providing acute stroke care, trauma services, and respiratory care, among other things. Wrexham Maelor Hospital would become the planned surgical centre for non-heart surgery, and would also provide renal dialysis, some of the region's breast cancer services, and would be the main centre for musculoskeletal services. Dr Phillip Banfield, chair of the BCUHB, said the new model of care would involve "rethinking the way we deliver services" but said the board believes it would deliver "high quality and safe care" for patients in North Wales. "The plans represent the culmination of 18 months of work and listening to our staff, our patients, and our communities," he said. "The plans will see us create specialist centres in North Wales that will provide the best care for patients locally and reduce the need for patients to travel outside of the region for treatment." He added: "The plans are designed to ensure all of our hospitals are providing the right care in the right place, and that our patients receive the best possible treatment by highly-skilled teams that specialise in a particular area." The board said it has invested heavily in Ysbyty Glan Clwyd and Wrexham Maelor Hospital to provide the "appropriate infrastructure and equipment" necessary to deliver this new model of service provision. The plans are currently out for public consultation, and BCUHB said it will "carefully consider" all of the feedback it receives before making any final decisions. The consultation will close on March 9, 2023.

title: Charity's 'concern' at number of beavers culled in Scotland
text: The Scottish Wildlife Trust said the impact of the cull, estimated at about a fifth of the beaver population, could be "quite significant". But Scottish Natural Heritage (SNH), which authorised the cull, said it was necessary to manage the beaver population and prevent damage to the environment and infrastructure. The beavers were introduced to Scotland in the 1990s as part of a conservation project. They have since spread to other parts of the country, and their numbers have increased rapidly. Beavers are known to dam rivers, which can cause flooding and damage to property. They can also damage trees and crops. SNH said the cull was carried out in response to concerns from landowners and other stakeholders about the impact of beavers on their property and livelihoods. The cull was carried out by licensed trappers, and the beavers were killed humanely. The Scottish Wildlife Trust said it was "deeply concerned" about the cull. The trust said the cull could have a negative impact on the beaver population in Scotland, and could also damage the wider ecosystem. The trust said it was calling on SNH to review its beaver management strategy and to consider alternative methods of managing the beaver population, such as relocation or contraception. SNH said it would continue to monitor the beaver population in Scotland and would carry out further culls if necessary. The agency said it was committed to managing the beaver population in a way that balances the needs of conservation with the needs of landowners and other stakeholders. The debate over how to manage the beaver population in Scotland is likely to continue. The cull has highlighted the need for a long-term strategy for managing beavers in Scotland, and for a balance to be struck between the needs of conservation and the needs of landowners and other stakeholders.

title: Scottish government funding for youth unemployment priority areas
text: The Scottish government has announced the priority areas set to benefit from its youth employment strategy fund. Glasgow, Renfrewshire, North and South Lanarkshire, West Dunbartonshire and Inverclyde will receive a share of £9 million to tackle youth unemployment. The fund is part of the government's £100 million Youth Guarantee scheme, which aims to provide all young people in Scotland with the opportunity to access education, training or employment. The priority areas were selected based on a range of factors, including the number of young people unemployed, the proportion of young people not in education, employment or training (NEET), and the local economy. The funding will be used to support a range of projects, including: Providing pre-employment training and work experience opportunities for young people Creating new apprenticeships and other job opportunities Supporting young people to start their own businesses The Scottish government hopes that the fund will help to reduce youth unemployment and give young people the skills and experience they need to succeed in the workplace. In addition to the priority areas, the fund will also be used to support a range of national projects, such as: A new national youth employment agency A website providing information and advice on youth employment A social media campaign to promote youth employment The Scottish government is committed to tackling youth unemployment and giving young people the best possible start in life. The Youth Employment Strategy Fund is a key part of this commitment. The fund is expected to create up to 1,000 new jobs for young people and help to reduce youth unemployment by up to 5%. The Scottish government is working with a range of partners to deliver the Youth Employment Strategy Fund, including local authorities, businesses and third sector organisations. The fund is part of a wider range of measures the Scottish government is taking to tackle youth unemployment, including: Investing in education and training Creating new apprenticeships and other job opportunities Supporting young people to start their own businesses The Scottish government is committed to giving young people the best possible start in life. The Youth Employment Strategy Fund is a key part of this commitment.

title: Read all about it: The online newspaper archive
text: The British Library's newspaper archive at Colindale in north London has long been a place of pilgrimage for writers. They've come to search for historical nuggets that can illuminate the present. But now, it's all accessible online, and the first 40 million pages are available free of charge. The digitisation project began 15 years ago and has been gathering momentum ever since, thanks to technology which makes it possible to scan the fragile newsprint without causing any damage. Over 400 UK newspapers are represented, covering more than 300 years of history. In 1900, there were more than 2,500 papers published in the UK - many of them local titles that reported on events of only passing interest. But there are also the big hitters - national titles like The Times and the Daily Telegraph. And of course, the regional papers that are so essential for local historians. The library hopes to digitise every last page, and so far, they've covered 178 regional titles. They include the Manchester Guardian (now The Guardian), which published the first reports of the Peterloo Massacre in 1819. There's also the Liverpool Mercury, which reported on the sinking of the Titanic in 1912. And the Western Daily Press, which carried the first reports of the Bristol Bus Boycott in 1963. The digitisation project has revealed some surprising facts. In 1812, for example, there was an attempt to assassinate Prime Minister Spencer Perceval. The Times reported the story, but only as a paragraph on page 3. The bigger story of the day was the execution of a group of Luddites in Yorkshire. The online archive is now a treasure trove for researchers and anyone with an interest in the past. I started my own search by looking for stories about my home town, Cardiff. I found reports of the opening of the new Cardiff Arms Park in 1921. There's a detailed account of a rugby match between Wales and New Zealand in 1935. And I found a fascinating story about the theft of a tram in 1945. I also used the archive to track down the reports of my own birth in 1952. My mother had told me that it was a difficult birth and I was lucky to survive. The Western Mail reported that I was born "after a long and anxious confinement". It was a relief to read that I was "doing well". The online archive is a remarkable resource and it's free to use. It's a great place to start your own journey into the past.

title: Apostrophe ban on Devon council's new street names
text: Apostrophe Ban on Devon Council's New Street Names Mid Devon District Council said its new streets had not contained apostrophes for many years, but the policy was now being formalised to ensure consistency and clarity. The decision was taken at a full council meeting on Wednesday, 25 January. The council's street naming and numbering policy states that apostrophes should not be used in street names, except in cases where the name is a direct quote or is an established historical name. The policy also states that street names should be concise, easy to spell and pronounce, and should not be offensive or confusing. The council said the removal of apostrophes from new street names would make them easier to read, understand, and navigate. The council also said it would help to avoid confusion and ambiguity, particularly in the case of streets that are named after people or places. The ban on apostrophes in Devon's new street names has been welcomed by some residents and businesses in the area. Peter Smith, a resident of Tiverton, said he supported the council's decision to remove apostrophes from street names. "I think it's a good idea," Smith said. "Apostrophes can be confusing and unnecessary. It's easier to read and understand street names without them." Sarah Jones, a business owner in Crediton, said she also supported the council's decision. "I think it's a good move," Jones said. "It will make it easier for customers to find my business, and it will also help to create a more consistent and professional look for the area." While some residents and businesses have welcomed the council's decision to ban apostrophes from new street names, others have expressed concerns. John Brown, a historian from Exeter, said he was concerned that the ban could lead to the loss of important historical information. "Apostrophes can be used to indicate possession or ownership," Brown said. "By removing them from street names, we could be losing valuable information about the history of our towns and villages." The council said it understood the concerns of those who opposed the ban on apostrophes, but it believed that the benefits of the new policy outweighed the risks. "We believe that the removal of apostrophes from new street names will make them easier to read, understand, and navigate," a council spokesperson said. "We also believe it will help to avoid confusion and ambiguity, particularly in the case of streets that are named after people or places." The council said it would be reviewing the new policy in the future to ensure that it is working effectively.

title: Bill Clinton regrets 'three strikes' bill
text: Speaking to a civil rights group, he said: "I signed a bill that made the problem worse and I want to admit it." It put 100,000 more people in prison, and for longer. Clinton backed a crime bill in 1994 that imposed mandatory minimum sentences for certain offences, including drug-related crimes. "We had a huge crime problem, more kids were being killed… crack cocaine was ravaging poor communities," he said. "But it wasn't just that bad judgment, we had this idea that the way to do it is just lock 'em all up. And we did, 100,000 more people – mostly African-Americans." The 1994 crime bill was designed to tackle a surge in violent crime in the US. The law expanded federal funding for prisons and created new mandatory minimum sentences for certain offenses. Critics argue that the law led to mass incarceration, particularly among African-Americans. Clinton's comments come as the US grapples with a renewed debate on criminal justice reform. In recent years, there has been a growing movement to reduce mass incarceration and address racial disparities in the criminal justice system. Clinton's admission of regret over the 1994 crime bill is a significant moment in the debate. It is a sign that the political consensus on mass incarceration is shifting. Clinton's comments are also a reminder that the criminal justice system is a complex issue with no easy solutions. While there is a need to address the problem of mass incarceration, it is also important to find ways to keep communities safe from crime. Clinton's comments suggest that he believes that it is possible to find a balance between these two goals.

title: Former US intelligence analyst charged with leaks to media
text: Daniel Everette Hale, 31, of Nashville, Tennessee, was arrested after allegedly providing at least 17 top secret documents to an unnamed journalist. According to the indictment, the files related to counterterrorism and intelligence gathering in Afghanistan, Iraq and Yemen. Hale, a former US Air Force intelligence analyst, worked as a contractor for the National Security Agency (NSA) from 2013 to 2016. He is accused of accessing the classified documents on a secure computer system and then transmitting them to the journalist via an encrypted email account. The indictment alleges that Hale knew the documents were classified and that their unauthorized disclosure could cause "grave damage" to the United States. It also claims that he had a "pattern of unauthorized access to classified information" while working at the NSA. Hale's arrest is the latest in a series of high-profile prosecutions of government employees accused of leaking classified information to the media. In 2013, former NSA contractor Edward Snowden leaked a trove of classified documents about the agency's surveillance programs, prompting a global debate about privacy and security. Hale's case is different from Snowden's in that he is not accused of leaking documents to a foreign government or of directly harming national security. However, the charges against him are still serious and could result in a lengthy prison sentence. Hale's arrest has drawn criticism from some who argue that he is being prosecuted for whistleblowing. They say that the documents he leaked revealed important information about the US government's counterterrorism operations and that he was acting in the public interest. However, the government maintains that Hale violated the law by leaking classified information and that his actions put the country at risk. The trial is expected to begin in the spring of 2023. Hale's case is a reminder of the tension between the public's right to know and the government's need to protect sensitive information. It is a complex issue with no easy answers.

title: Army morale declining, Ministry of Defence survey shows
text: Thirty per cent of army personnel described their morale as low - up from 26% last year - the report showed. And the proportion of personnel who said they would recommend the army as a career had also decreased, from 68% last year to 64%. The annual survey of 12,000 serving personnel, carried out by researchers at King's College London, found that morale had declined across all ranks and services. The army's chief of the general staff, General Sir Patrick Sanders, said the findings were "deeply concerning". "We know that morale is a key factor in operational effectiveness, and we are committed to addressing the issues that are driving down morale," he said. The survey found that the most common factors driving down morale were: Pay and allowances Career progression Training and development Workload Leadership Sanders said the army was taking a number of steps to address these issues, including: Increasing pay and allowances Investing in career progression Improving training and development Reducing workload Strengthening leadership He said the army was also working to improve the welfare support available to personnel and their families. "We are committed to creating an army that is attractive to serve in, and we will continue to work hard to address the issues that are affecting morale," he said. However, the report also found that there were some areas where morale had improved. For example, the proportion of personnel who said they were satisfied with their accommodation had increased from 72% last year to 76%. The report also found that morale was higher among personnel who had been deployed on operations. This suggests that the army's focus on operational effectiveness is having a positive impact on morale. Overall, the report provides a mixed picture of morale in the army. While there are some areas where morale has improved, there are also some areas where morale is declining. The army is taking a number of steps to address the issues that are driving down morale, but it is clear that more needs to be done.

title: Fishing boat discards 'hard to comply with'
text: Boats having to land unwanted fish caught in their nets started being phased in at the start of the year, under European laws. Throwing dead fish back into the sea had previously been widespread, in part because it was easier and cheaper than bringing it ashore. But environmentalists have long argued that discarding large quantities of fish at sea damages the marine ecosystem, removing food from other creatures and making the seabed a less hospitable environment. The new rules, which have been controversial, say that discarding fish likely to survive if returned to the sea is forbidden, as well as fish that are below a set size. In the case of herring, for example, any fish below 8cm long cannot be thrown away. But the industry says it is very difficult to measure and check every catch at sea, and that the new rules could lead to extra costs and bureaucracy. "There have been boats coming into land with [under-sized] fish but not discarding them, which used to be the legal way to do it," said Dr Paul Trebilco, the Marine Conservation Society's (MCS) head of policy. "Now they're under an obligation to land and sell it." But he acknowledged that the new rules could also lead to some fishermen disregarding them and discarding anyway. "This regulation is a pragmatic measure to help stop the dumping of dead fish at sea and to tackle overfishing," he said. "The fact is we simply cannot afford to waste fish." Richard Benyon, the environment minister, sagte, the government was aware of the industry's concerns, and that it was "working with the industry to help them comply with the new regulations". He told the BBC: "We want to make sure we have a sustainable fishing industry, and we want to make sure that the fish that come out of our seas are used in the best possible way." The rules were first announced in 2013, and have been phased in over the course of this year. The full ban comes into force on 1 January 2016.

title: Ed Sheeran stops sell-out Cardiff concert for the toilet - twice
text: The Grammy award winning singer halted his Saturday night set in Cardiff because he "needed a pee" after performing his smash hit Galway Girl. Then three songs later Sheeran stopped in the middle of singing Photograph, telling the packed Principality Stadium crowd: "I'm going for another wee." Sheeran, 30, has previously spoken of his embarrassing bladder problems and in his 2017 track Castle On The Hill, he sings about "having to pee" during a date. After he left the stage for the second time on Saturday, his backing singers began playing a cover of Oasis' Don't Look Back In Anger. But Sheeran returned after about three minutes to finish his set, jokingly telling the crowd: "I'm not leaving you again. You're stuck with me now." He added: "Whoever thought of putting portable toilets so far away? How do you have a site this big with a stage this big and the toilets are a 15-minute walk away? "I'm going to have to have a word. This is a health and safety issue." But Sheeran's toilet breaks did not appear to dampen the spirits of the 74,000 fans inside Cardiff's Principality Stadium. "It's our Ed, isn't it?" said one fan. "He's real, isn't he?" Sheeran's concert was part of his Mathematics world tour and it was his first in the UK since 2018. He ended Saturday's set with his hit Perfect while fireworks filled the night sky. "Absolutely unreal," said fan Kirstie Hopkins. "He was amazing and so so funny with it. "I'm glad he told us why he had to go - I'd hate to think he'd just left. He's such a down to earth performer." Sheeran had also been due to play at the Principality Stadium on Friday night but that concert was postponed because of bad weather. He told the crowd: "I'm sorry again about last night. I hated to do it but it was dangerous, lightning and all that. "I feel bad, but the people who came last night get a double treat."

title: Libya civil war: UN envoy Salamé says foreign intervention must end
text: On the eve of peace talks in Berlin, Mr Salamé said foreign support of proxy groups in the conflict had created a "vicious cycle" of violence. But Mr Haftar, who is based in eastern Libya and is backed by Russia, Egypt and the United Arab Emirates, rejected the ceasefire. The escalation of foreign involvement in Libya has raised fears that the conflict could become a wider proxy war. The UN has warned that the fighting could lead to a "catastrophic" humanitarian crisis, with hundreds of thousands of people displaced and shortages of food, water and medicine. The Berlin talks are seen as a last-ditch effort to find a political solution to the conflict. But it is unclear whether the warring parties are willing to compromise. Mr Salamé said that he hoped the talks would produce a "road map" for a ceasefire and a political settlement. "We are at a critical moment in Libya's history," he said. "The future of the country is at stake. We cannot afford to fail." The conflict in Libya began in 2011 with the overthrow of long-time leader Muammar Gaddafi. Since then, the country has been plagued by violence and political instability. The UN-backed Government of National Accord (GNA) has struggled to assert its authority over the whole country. The GNA is headquartered in the capital, Tripoli, and is supported by Turkey and Qatar. It is opposed by the Libyan National Army (LNA), which is led by Mr Haftar and is based in eastern Libya. The LNA has made significant gains in recent months, and now controls much of eastern and southern Libya. The GNA has been weakened by defections and internal divisions. The international community has been divided on how to respond to the conflict in Libya. Some countries, such as the United States and the United Kingdom, have called for a ceasefire and a political settlement. Others, such as Russia and the United Arab Emirates, have supported Mr Haftar's military campaign. The UN has called for an end to foreign intervention in Libya and for the warring parties to negotiate a political settlement. But it is unclear whether the parties are willing to compromise. The Berlin talks are seen as a last-ditch effort to find a solution to the conflict, but it is unclear whether they will be successful.

title: Sri Lanka met Ban ki Moon panel
text: The meeting in New York was not announced to the media by either the UNSG or the Sri Lankan government. "The panel members took part in a discussion along with an officer named Lynn Pascoe (United States as the Under Secretary-General for Political Affairs) and met with Vitaly Churkin, the Russian ambassador to the UN who now holds the rotating presidency of the UN Security Council," the source explained. The panel is expected to visit Sri Lanka in the coming months to conduct its investigation. The panel is tasked with investigating allegations of human rights violations and war crimes committed during the final stages of the civil war in Sri Lanka. The civil war in Sri Lanka ended in May 2009 with the defeat of the Tamil Tigers. The war was a brutal conflict that claimed the lives of an estimated 100,000 people. There have been allegations that both sides in the conflict committed human rights violations, including extrajudicial killings, torture, and sexual violence. The UN panel is expected to investigate these allegations and report its findings to the UN Secretary-General. The Sri Lankan government has denied the allegations of human rights violations.
