The visit by the UN panel to Sri Lanka is expected to be a significant development in the ongoing debate about human rights violations in the country. title: Halton Transport: Bus company with huge losses goes into liquidation
text: Halton Transport, which runs more than a third of services across the Cheshire borough, lost almost £620,000 in 2019, up from £50,500 in 2017. Halton Borough Council said it had agreed to provide up to £3m to keep the company, which was founded in 1988, operating until the end of the month. But the council and its private sector partners said they were unable to support the business beyond March 29. About 120 jobs are now at risk. The council said it was working with Merseytravel, Transport for Greater Manchester and other bus operators to ensure the majority of Halton Transport services continue to be provided. It added that a review will be carried out of the council's public transport needs in the light of the company's collapse. Halton Transport, which is based in Runcorn, operates 50 buses on 26 routes across Halton, St Helens, Widnes and Warrington. The move represents the latest in a string of bus companies going into administration, following the collapse of several firms including Bordaline, Central Buses and Yourbus. In a statement, Halton Council said: "Halton Transport has been operating at a financial loss for some time and despite the huge efforts made by staff and management, the company has reached a point where it can no longer continue to trade. "The council has been working closely with the company and its private sector partners to explore all options to keep the business viable, including a request for more external funding. "However, following a thorough review of the company's position and its prospects for the future, the council and its partners have reluctantly reached the conclusion that they are unable to support the business beyond March 29." Council leader Rob Polhill said: "This is a very difficult day for all the staff, customers and partners of Halton Transport. "The council has done everything within its power to support the business, but sadly it has not been possible to secure a viable future for the company." He added: "The priority now is to ensure the continuation of bus services across Halton. We are working closely with other operators to put in place arrangements to cover as many of Halton Transport's routes as possible."

title: Will you be lonely this Christmas?
text: Will you be lonely this Christmas? Nick TriggleHealth correspondent Nights spent at parties and catching up with friends, culminating with a Christmas surrounded by family. But the festive period is not like that for everyone. Age UK estimates about 450,000 will be spending this Christmas on their own, while others will have minimal contact with loved ones over the festive period. How many people are affected by loneliness? A survey for the charity found 1.4 million older people said they felt lonely some or all of the time. It warned that half of all older people have unmet social needs and more than 200,000 older people have not had a conversation with a friend or family member in more than a month. One of the groups most at risk at Christmas is widowers. They may be used to celebrating Christmas with their other half, so being alone can be particularly poignant. Caroline Abrahams, Charity Director at Age UK, said: "The holiday season can be a very difficult time for older people. "We know that loneliness is a huge issue for older people all year round, but Christmas and the winter months can be particularly hard. "Loneliness can have a very negative impact on people's health and wellbeing. It can increase your risk of developing a wide range of health problems, including heart disease, stroke, depression and dementia. "It can also make it harder to cope with the challenges of daily life, such as getting out and about or managing your finances. "That's why it's so important that we all do what we can to help older people feel less lonely. This could involve simply reaching out to an older neighbour or relative, or volunteering with a local charity." What can be done to help? There are a number of things that can be done to help older people feel less lonely. Reach out to them. Simply calling someone up or popping round for a cup of tea can make a big difference. Listen to them. Sometimes, all people need is someone to talk to. Offer them practical help. This could involve anything from running errands to helping them with their shopping. Encourage them to get involved in activities. This could involve anything from joining a club to volunteering. Be patient and understanding. It may take time for someone to open up about how they're feeling. Christmas can be a lonely time for many people. If you are struggling with loneliness, there are organizations that can help. Age UK's website has a section on loneliness which includes tips on how to cope and where to go for support.

title: Government sets out £1bn plan to cut industrial carbon emissions
text: By Roger Harrabin BBC environment analyst The UK government has set out a £1bn plan to cut industrial carbon emissions by nearly half by 2033. It wants firms to waste less energy, develop low-carbon technologies and invest in equipment that can store captured CO2 under the North Sea. Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng said the plan was a "triple win". It would reduce carbon emissions, cut company costs and create jobs in the UK's industrial heartlands, he said. Industrial sites account for 15% of the UK's greenhouse gas emissions. The announcement is part of the government's strategy to cut UK carbon emissions to net zero by 2050. Next month, the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) is expected to publish a contract to find and licence a storage site under the North Sea. It will then run a competition to find the best technology to capture and store CO2 from nearby industrial sites. The new funding is likely to be measured against the government's climate commitments in the run-up to crucial UN climate talks this November in Glasgow. At the last major UN climate conference in Paris in 2015, the UK promised to reduce carbon emissions 68% below 1990 levels by 2030. The Climate Change Committee - the UK's independent climate advisory body - has said the UK needs to cut emissions faster in this decade so it can make deeper cuts later. It has called on the government to do more to cut emissions in sectors including industry and transport. The government says the new funding is part of its commitment to decarbonise the whole of the UK economy. It says the money will pay for things such as more efficient equipment, staff training and investment in low-carbon technologies. The Green Alliance think tank said the funding was a good start, but there was far more to do, especially in industries such as steel and chemicals. "We need a strong policy framework with clear targets and deadlines to ensure that industry decarbonises quickly enough," said the group's deputy director Dustin Benton. title: Are we stuck with plastic drinking straws?
text: By Louise Greenwood Business reporter John Sidanta, chief executive of Primaplast, said he was aware of rising global concern over levels of plastic pollution. "We are looking to be ahead of the curve," he said, adding that research into alternatives such as paper and biodegradable straws was at an "exploratory" stage. "That's the route we are aiming to go down," he added. But environmentalists say that this journey is taking too long. "Single-use plastic straws are one of the most avoidable plastics," said Sam Chetan-Welsh, oceans campaigner at Greenpeace UK. "Most people don't need them and it's so easy to find alternatives." The UK government has pledged to ban all avoidable single-use plastics by 2042. While many restaurants and bars have stopped giving out straws unless they are requested, campaigners say this is not enough. "The best way forward is a total ban," said Ms Chetan-Welsh. "It's all very well businesses and individuals choosing to reduce their use or replace plastic, but it's really tricky on a large scale and at the end of the day it's up to the government to lead." However, Mr Sidanta argues that a total ban would only force businesses to import single-use straws from overseas, which could have a greater environmental impact. "It's not as simple as just banning them," he said. "We need to look at the entire life cycle of a product and make sure that the alternatives are better." Ultimately, he believes that the key lies in changing consumer behavior. "People need to challenge their own use of products and make a conscious decision," he said. "It's a combination of government, businesses and individuals working together to reduce plastic consumption." So, are we stuck with plastic drinking straws? Not necessarily, but it may take a while to find a truly sustainable alternative. In the meantime, campaigners are urging people to refuse straws when they don't need them and to choose reusable alternatives where possible.

title: Statins alert over IT glitch in heart risk tool
text: A third of GP surgeries have been told to contact people who may have been given an inaccurate assessment of their future risk of heart disease. title: Arizona wildfire: Battling the blaze
text: The interagency "hotshot" team - of which there are a number across the US - are highly trained and equipped to work in remote locations, tackling the most challenging wildfires. They are often the first responders in the most dangerous areas, where terrain and fire conditions are most extreme. With the Tunnel fire in northern Arizona threatening the remote community of Munds Park, one team of 20 hotshots from New Mexico was deployed to help bring the fire under control. They were joined by a second 20-member team from Arizona. On 20 April, the hotshots were airlifted into a clearing close to the fire and spent the day hiking through thick vegetation, digging fire lines and removing flammable material. The aim was to starve the blaze of fuel and stop it from spreading towards the community and popular tourist destination of Flagstaff. As well as battling the fire on the ground, aircraft were also deployed to drop retardant and water on the flames. Helicopters filled their tanks from a nearby lake, flying low over the fire to dump their loads with pinpoint accuracy. Working alongside the hotshots on the ground were bulldozers and other heavy machinery, clearing vegetation to create fire breaks and widening existing roads to allow fire engines to reach the blaze. As night fell, the hotshots camped out at their remote base, ready to resume their work at daybreak. Weather conditions were mostly favourable, with light winds and no rain, but the fire was continuing to burn and they knew there was still a long way to go. The following day, the hotshots continued to dig fire lines and remove vegetation, working in shifts to ensure there was always a fresh team ready to take over. The fire had spread to around 25,000 acres (10,000 hectares) but firefighters were slowly managing to bring it under control, with containment lines established around 20% of its perimeter. As the sun set on the second day of the operation, the hotshots were finally able to return to their base camp, exhausted but satisfied that they were making progress in containing the blaze. They knew there was still much work to be done, but they were confident that they would eventually succeed in bringing the fire under control.

title: Air pollution: Benefits of cycling and walking outweigh harms - study
text: Air pollution: Benefits of cycling and walking outweigh harms - study Air pollution contributes to 40,000 early deaths each year in the UK and we gulp in more of it when we exercise. On the other hand, regular exercise reduces the risk of diabetes, heart and lung disease, and early death. So what are the risks and benefits of cycling and walking in polluted cities? A new study published in the journal Environment International has found that the health benefits of cycling and walking outweigh the risks from air pollution, even in cities with high levels of pollution. The study was conducted by researchers at the University of Cambridge and the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine. The researchers used data from the UK Biobank study, which included over 500,000 adults. They looked at the participants' levels of physical activity, air pollution exposure, and health outcomes. They found that people who cycled or walked regularly had a lower risk of death from all causes, including death from heart disease, stroke, cancer, and respiratory disease. The researchers also found that the benefits of cycling and walking were greater than the risks from air pollution, even in cities with high levels of pollution. In fact, the benefits were greatest in cities with the highest levels of pollution. The study provides strong evidence that the health benefits of cycling and walking outweigh the risks from air pollution. This is important news, as it means that people can still enjoy the benefits of exercise, even in polluted cities. However, the study also found that air pollution can have a negative impact on lung function. The researchers found that people who were exposed to high levels of air pollution had lower lung function than people who were exposed to low levels of air pollution. This suggests that air pollution may contribute to the development of respiratory diseases, such as asthma and chronic bronchitis. The study's findings are consistent with other research that has found that the health benefits of cycling and walking outweigh the risks from air pollution. However, the study's findings are particularly important because they are based on a large sample size and because they looked at the effects of air pollution on a wide range of health outcomes. The study's findings have important implications for public health policy. The findings suggest that policymakers should encourage people to cycle and walk more, even in polluted cities. The findings also suggest that policymakers should take steps to reduce air pollution levels in cities.

title: Nora Ephron remembered at star-packed memorial

title: Tony Nicklinson's 'courage' will lead to law change
text: Mr Nicklinson, a man with locked-in syndrome who fought to legally end his life, died on Wednesday. The High Court ruled against him, but the Court of Appeal overturned that decision in 2014. However, the Supreme Court ruled against Nicklinson in 2015. Lord Joffe said Nicklinson's "courage" would lead to a change in the law. "The public is overwhelmingly in favor of a change in the law," he said. "MPs should reflect the views of the nation." title: 'Golden hello' offered to some new GPs in Scotland
text: One hundred new GP training places are being advertised, with a £20,000 incentive for some who choose to take up hard to fill posts. The new GP training places will be available from August 2023. The £20,000 "golden hello" will be paid in two instalments - £10,000 after the first year of training and £10,000 after the second year. title: Scottish women return after stem cell transplants in Russia
text: By David Cowan BBC Scotland Jill McLaren and Michele Murray have been living with multiple sclerosis for almost 20 years. They travelled to Moscow for stem cell transplants after initial treatment failed to ease their symptoms. The trips have left both women feeling much better, although it is too early to tell if the stem cells have reversed any of the damage to their immune systems. MS is a neurological condition that affects the brain and spinal cord. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fatigue, pain, difficulty with movement, and problems with vision and speech. There is no cure for MS, but treatments can help to manage the symptoms. In some cases, stem cell transplants can be used to repair the damage to the immune system that causes MS. Jill, 46, from Perth, was diagnosed with MS in 2002. She began experiencing symptoms in 1999, including fatigue, blurred vision, and numbness in her hands and feet. Over the years, her symptoms worsened, and she began to experience problems with her mobility. She was eventually forced to give up her job as a nurse. In 2017, Jill heard about a stem cell transplant clinic in Moscow that was offering treatment for MS. She decided to travel to Russia for the procedure. The transplant involved harvesting stem cells from Jill's own blood and then re-infusing them into her body. The stem cells were then able to travel to the damaged areas of her immune system and repair them. Jill underwent the transplant in 2018, and she has noticed a significant improvement in her symptoms since then. She is now able to walk and move more easily, and she has less pain and fatigue. Michele, 50, from Dundee, was diagnosed with MS in 2003. She began experiencing symptoms in 2000, including fatigue, loss of balance, and problems with her speech. Over the years, her symptoms worsened, and she eventually had to give up her job as a social worker. In 2019, Michele travelled to Moscow for a stem cell transplant. She has also noticed a significant improvement in her symptoms since then. She is now able to walk and move more easily, and she has less pain and fatigue. Both Jill and Michele are hopeful that the stem cell transplants will continue to improve their symptoms and that they will eventually be able to live full and active lives.

title: Gunman's parents 'raced to stop him'

The video showed the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB) psychology major sitting in his car, driving around Isla Vista. He also detailed how he had been rejected by women and was angry at being treated as an "inferior" because he was Asian. "I have been laughed at, mocked, humiliated, and scorned," he wrote. title: The psychological secrets to successful resolutions
text: Unfortunately, quite a few fail. But there are some psychological tactics which can be employed to increase the chances of success. 1. Persistence Psychologist Prof Richard Wiseman, author of 59 Seconds: Think a Little, Change a Lot, says: "Successful people are persistent. They don't give up if they don't see results immediately." So, if you don't achieve your goal straight away, don't despair. Just keep at it and you'll eventually get there. 2. Small steps Don't try to do too much at once. Break your goal down into smaller, more manageable steps. This will make it seem less daunting and more achievable. "If your goal is to lose weight, don't try to lose 20kg in a month," says Wiseman. "Start with a more realistic goal, like losing 2kg in a month. Once you've achieved that, you can set a new goal." 3. Positive self-talk The way you talk to yourself can have a big impact on your success. If you keep telling yourself that you can't do something, you're more likely to give up. Instead, try to be positive and encouraging. Tell yourself that you can do it, and that you're going to achieve your goal. "Self-talk can be a powerful tool for motivation," says Wiseman. "Positive self-talk can help you to stay focused and determined, even when things get tough." 4. Accountability Tell someone else about your goal. This could be a friend, family member, or colleague. Having someone to hold you accountable can help you to stay on track. "When you're accountable to someone else, you're more likely to follow through on your commitment," says Wiseman. 5. Reward yourself When you achieve a milestone, reward yourself. This will help you to stay motivated and make the process more enjoyable. "Rewards can be anything that you enjoy, such as buying yourself something nice, going out for a meal, or spending time with friends," says Wiseman. "Just make sure that the reward is something that you'll really enjoy, so that you're motivated to work towards it." By following these psychological tactics, you can increase your chances of success and achieve your goals. So what are you waiting for? Get started today!

text: The cull ended last week, with an estimated 65% reduction in the badger population in the west Somerset cull zone – 1,177 badgers, according to the Department of Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra). But it failed to meet its target of at least a 70% reduction. Between 2013 and 2017, government-led badger culls took place across four areas of England with the aim of reducing the incidence of bovine tuberculosis in cattle. Since the culling licenses were last renewed in 2018, the cull areas have been reduced and the Gloucestershire cull zone was closed in 2021. Two cull zones remain in west Somerset and west Gloucestershire, despite ongoing legal challenges and opposition from animal welfare groups. Defra said it was "disappointed" the target was not met, but said the 65% reduction did represent "good progress". The department said: "Badger numbers are estimated to be significantly higher than in 2013, so although the 70% cull target was not achieved, the number of badgers removed in the last five years represents a substantial reduction in the badger population in both cull areas." The Badger Trust, which has long campaigned against the cull, said the results showed it was "inhumane, ineffective and unscientific". Dominic Dyer, the chief executive of the Badger Trust, said: "After five years and six weeks of badger killing, Defra has failed even to achieve its own arbitrary cull target. "Defra have blamed 'bad weather' for the fact they killed fewer badgers than they set out to do. What a pathetic excuse. If cold and wet weather can scupper a multi-million-pound cull of badgers, what a terrible indictment of the operation." The RSPCA also condemned the cull, saying it was "cruel and unnecessary". David Bowles, the RSPCA's head of public affairs, said: "We continue to believe that the badger cull is a cruel and unnecessary way of managing the spread of TB in cattle. "There is no scientific evidence to prove that badger culling is effective in reducing TB in cattle, and there are more humane and effective ways of controlling the disease." The government has said it will review the results of the cull before making a decision on whether to continue with it. A Defra spokesperson said: "We are considering the results of the badger cull and will make a decision on future policy in due course."

title: David Cameron backs Maria Miller as expenses inquiry launched
text: The prime minister said his culture secretary had "excellent answers" to questions about her expenses claims. Labour MP John Mann submitted a complaint about her claims on Tuesday. It follows reports she had allowed a taxpayer-funded nanny to work on her party political activities. Downing Street said Cameron remained "fully supportive" of Miller (pictured) after receiving a letter from the Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority (Ipsa) on Wednesday. Ipsa has launched an inquiry into Miller's expenses and requested documents from her office. The complaint centre on the employment of a full-time nanny. The BBC understands the nanny cared for Miller's young child while her husband was living at the family home. Miller's expenses claims have caused controversy since they were first reported by the Daily Telegraph in 2012. The newspaper alleged Miller claimed for mortgage interest payments on a buy-to-let property she owned despite not living in it. Miller was accused of abusing the "second homes" allowance, which was intended to help MPs with the cost of maintaining a second home in London. The MP for Basingstoke claimed £90,000 over a five-year period through the arrangement. In 2013, the Commons Standards and Privileges Committee ordered Miller to repay £45,000 of the £90,000 she had claimed. A spokesman for Miller said she had "always followed the rules and acted in the best interests of taxpayers". The spokesman added: "She welcomes the Ipsa inquiry and will co-operate fully." The inquiry is likely to take several months. The report will conclude whether Miller broke the rules and, if so, what sanction she should face. The expenses scandal has damaged public trust in politicians. It has also led to the creation of new rules governing MPs' expenses. The Ipsa inquiry is the latest in a series of investigations into MPs' expenses. In 2010, the Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority (Ipsa) was set up to oversee MPs' expenses. Ipsa has since introduced new rules governing MPs' expenses. The new rules are designed to make the system more transparent and accountable.

title: Kincora should be part of UK inquiry into child abuse says Amnesty
text: The announcement of a new inquiry into the governmental handling of historic child abuse claims brings the issue of Kincora boys' home back into the spotlight. Amnesty International has called for the notorious institution to be included in the probe, citing concerns that it formed part of a wider pattern of abuse that was allegedly covered up by authorities. The Kincora scandal erupted in the 1980s when it was revealed that boys at the Belfast home had been subjected to horrific sexual abuse by staff members. The case sent shockwaves through Northern Ireland and beyond, leading to the resignation of several government ministers and the establishment of a public inquiry. However, Amnesty International has raised concerns that the public inquiry, known as the Historic Abuse Inquiry, did not fully examine the systemic failures that allowed the abuse to take place. The group is particularly interested in exploring the potential links between Kincora and other institutions where child abuse was allegedly covered up. "There are serious concerns that Kincora was not an isolated case, but part of a wider pattern of abuse that was facilitated by a culture of secrecy and impunity," said Patrick Corrigan, Amnesty International's Northern Ireland programme director. "This new inquiry must leave no stone unturned in examining the full extent of these allegations." The Home Secretary's announcement of a new inquiry has been welcomed by victims' groups and campaigners. However, there are concerns that the inquiry may be too narrow in scope. The terms of reference for the inquiry are yet to be published, but it is understood that it will focus on how the government handled allegations of child abuse within its own institutions. Amnesty International is calling for the inquiry to be expanded to include wider institutional failures, such as those that occurred at Kincora. The group also wants the inquiry to examine the role of the security services in the alleged cover-up of child abuse. "It is essential that this inquiry is independent, thorough, and transparent," said Corrigan. "The victims of child abuse deserve nothing less." The Kincora scandal is a dark chapter in Northern Ireland's history. The new inquiry provides an opportunity to shine a light on the full extent of the abuse that took place and to ensure that those responsible are held to account.

title: Scrap metal laws to be tightened to tackle theft
text: Home Secretary Theresa May announced the proposed new laws in a written statement to MPs. The measures will end the current "low-risk transactions" for scrap metal dealers, as they will now be required to get a licence to trade. They will also have to carry out checks on customers' identities and record details of all transactions. Failure to comply could result in a fine of up to £5,000 or a prison sentence of up to two years. The new laws are part of a wider crackdown on metal theft, which has seen a sharp increase in recent years. In 2013, there were an estimated 56,000 incidents of metal theft in England and Wales, with a total value of £77m. Much of the stolen metal is sold to scrap dealers, who often pay cash and ask no questions about where it came from. The new laws are designed to make it more difficult for thieves to sell stolen metal, and to encourage scrap dealers to be more vigilant about the sources of the metal they purchase. They will also make it easier for the police to track down stolen metal and prosecute those responsible for its theft. The new laws have been welcomed by the scrap metal industry, which has long argued for tougher action to tackle metal theft. The British Metals Recycling Association (BMRA) said that the new laws "will help to create a level playing field for all scrap metal dealers and will make it more difficult for criminals to operate." However, some concerns have been raised about the impact of the new laws on legitimate scrap metal dealers. The BMRA has warned that the new regulations could increase the cost of doing business for scrap metal dealers, and could lead to some legitimate businesses closing down. The government has said that it will work with the scrap metal industry to ensure that the new laws do not have a negative impact on legitimate businesses. It has also said that it will provide funding to help scrap metal dealers comply with the new regulations. The new laws are due to come into force in 2016.

title: Nintendo forecasts loss amid weak Wii U sales
text: It now expects to make an operating loss of 35bn yen ($335m; £205m) for the financial year ending 31 March 2014. Its initial estimate in April had been for a 100bn yen profit. Nintendo said sales of its Wii U console - launched in November 2012 - have "fallen short". It sold 2.72 million units globally in the nine months to 31 December, short of its target of three million. In a statement, Nintendo president Satoru Iwata said: "As sales of the Wii U have fallen short of our expectations, our overall financial results have also fallen short." He added: "We are currently working to increase the sales of our Wii U hardware and software as soon as possible." Nintendo has already cut the price of the Wii U twice since its launch and has also announced plans to release a range of new games for the console. However, analysts have said that it will be difficult for Nintendo to turn around the fortunes of the Wii U, which has been outsold by rival consoles such as the PlayStation 4 and Xbox One. The Wii U is Nintendo's first console to use a tablet-style controller. It has been praised for its innovative design, but has struggled to attract a wide audience. Some analysts believe that Nintendo has failed to market the console effectively, while others have said that the Wii U's games library is too small. Despite the Wii U's disappointing sales, Nintendo remains one of the most successful video game companies in the world. Its other products, such as the Nintendo 3DS handheld console and the Wii, have been huge hits. Nintendo's financial results will be a blow to the company and its investors. However, it is still too early to say whether the Wii U will be a commercial failure. Nintendo has a history of bouncing back from setbacks, and it will be hoping that it can do the same with the Wii U.

title: Sabarimala temple: Indian women form '620km human chain' for equality
text: The Sabarimala shrine was historically closed to women of "menstruating age" - defined as between 10 and 50. India's top court overturned the ban in September, but conservative groups have protested the decision. As a mark of resistance, hundreds of women participated in a 620km human chain on January 1, 2019. The chain extended from the northern city of Kasaragod to the southern city of Thiruvananthapuram, passing through several towns and villages. Women of all ages and backgrounds joined the chain, which was organised by the Kerala Women's Wall collective. Many of the women carried placards demanding equality and respect for women. The event was largely peaceful, but there were some reports of violence. In one incident, a group of men attacked a woman who was participating in the chain. Despite the challenges, the women's wall was seen as a major success. It sent a strong message of unity and solidarity, and it demonstrated the growing demand for gender equality in India. The Sabarimala temple issue has been a flashpoint for debate about gender equality in India. Conservative groups have argued that the ban on women is necessary to protect the "purity" of the temple. However, many women's rights activists have condemned the ban as discriminatory and unjust. The Supreme Court's decision to overturn the ban was a significant victory for women's rights in India. However, the ongoing protests by conservative groups show that the fight for gender equality is far from over. In the wake of the women's wall, the Kerala government has announced that it will provide security for women who want to visit the Sabarimala temple. The government has also said that it will not tolerate any violence against women who are trying to enter the temple. These are positive steps, but it is important to remember that the fight for gender equality in India is an ongoing one. There are still many laws and practices that discriminate against women in India. The women's wall was a powerful symbol of resistance against these discriminatory practices. It showed that women in India are increasingly determined to fight for their rights.

title: Dumfries and Galloway Council made £6.9m waste deal payment
text: The figure emerged after a BBC Freedom of Information request about the financial impact of ending the contract on the Dumfries and Galloway authority. Company accounts of Shanks show that in the year to the end of March 2018, it billed the council £2.6m for the disposal of municipal waste and £2m for landfill tax - a total of £4.6m. In addition, the council paid the firm £1m in "early termination payments" after the two-year contract ended in May 2018 and a further £1.3m in "residual waste treatment costs" over the next six months. The £6.9m package paid to Shanks led to opposition councillors claiming the authority was "paying over the odds" to terminate the contract. And it has also emerged that when the council ended the contract it was still contractually obliged to pay Shanks the £2m annual landfill tax until 2023. The authority secured a loan from the Scottish Government in order to settle the £6.9m bill, which will be paid back over a number of years. A spokesman for the council said: "The early termination payment was to cover the costs that Shanks had incurred in setting up the contract, and the residual waste treatment costs represented the cost of having waste treated at other facilities." He added that the council had "no option" but to end the waste contract as it was "not sustainable". "The council is now working with other local authorities to explore options for waste disposal in the region," he said. Shanks declined to comment. The council's waste bill has been the subject of much debate and scrutiny in recent years. In 2017, it emerged that the authority had paid out £1.4m in compensation to Shanks after a dispute over the quality of recycled materials. And last year, it was revealed that the council was paying £3.7m a year to store waste on a site near Gretna. The Scottish Conservatives have accused the Scottish Government of "failing" the people of Dumfries and Galloway by allowing waste costs to spiral out of control. Tory MSP Oliver Mundell said: "The SNP has presided over a shambles in waste disposal in Dumfries and Galloway, which has led to spiralling costs for taxpayers. "The people of Dumfries and Galloway are paying the price for the SNP's incompetence." In a statement, a Scottish Government spokesman said: "We are aware of the financial challenges faced by Dumfries and Galloway Council in relation to waste management and we are working with the council to explore options to support them in delivering better value for money services."

title: 'Slow progress' on child abuse claims in Pembrokeshire
text: A follow-up report says improvements have been made in child safeguarding. But management of allegations against Pembrokeshire council professionals remains "inconsistent". The council is one of 20 in the UK subject to extra scrutiny over how they handle child abuse claims. Inspectors found "significant and sustained" improvements have been made since a previous visit in 2019. But, they said: "Progress in progressing and resolving individual allegations remains slow." Inspectors said this was partly caused by the council's managers having "inconsistent" approaches to dealing with complaints. However, they praised the council's staff for their "strong commitment" to protecting children. Inspectors found a "significant increase" in the number of child protection cases investigated by the council's social workers. There were 803 investigations in the year to March 2022, compared with 486 in 2018-19. The number of cases where children were subject to a child protection plan has also increased, from 173 in 2018-19 to 203 in 2021-22. Inspectors welcomed the increase, saying it showed the council was taking a "more proactive approach" to child protection. However, they said the council needed to improve the quality of its assessments and plans. Inspectors said the council had made "significant progress" in improving its record-keeping. However, they said the council still needed to do more to ensure all records were kept up to date and easily accessible. Overall, inspectors said the council was making "progress" in improving its child protection services. However, they said there was still room for improvement, particularly in relation to the management of allegations against council professionals. A Pembrokeshire Council spokesperson said: "We welcome the recognition of the significant progress that our social care workforce has made in safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children and their families. "We are committed to providing a comprehensive and robust child protection service that places children at the heart of everything we do."

title: Luton Borough Council proposes cuts to plug £22m shortfall
text: Luton Borough Council said its income from Luton Airport "has all but dried up". It faced a £50m shortfall and needed to save nearly £22m. Without "adequate emergency funding" the authority "will be forced to implement extreme savings", it said. The airport, which is owned by the council and operated by London Luton Airport Operations, has been closed since March due to the coronavirus pandemic. The council said it was working with the airport to "explore options", but warned that "significant redundancies" could be necessary. The council's leader, Kevin Chapman, said: "The impact of the pandemic on Luton Airport has been catastrophic. We are facing a £50m shortfall in our income and we have to save nearly £22m. "We have been working with the airport to explore options, but we are now at the point where we have to consider implementing extreme savings. "This could include significant redundancies, which would be a devastating blow to our staff and the local economy." The council is also facing a £20m shortfall in its council tax collection. Chapman said: "We are doing everything we can to support our residents and businesses during this difficult time, but we need the government to provide us with adequate emergency funding. "Without this funding, we will be forced to implement extreme savings, which will have a devastating impact on our services and the lives of our residents." The government has provided local authorities with £3.2bn to help them cope with the financial impact of the pandemic, but Luton Borough Council says this is not enough. Chapman said: "The government needs to do more to help local authorities. We are facing a financial crisis and we need their support to protect our services and the lives of our residents."

title: Sydney seaplane crash: Sharp turn 'inexplicable', operator says
text: Five members of a British family and a Canadian pilot died in the incident on 31 December. There were no survivors. A preliminary report, released on Wednesday, did not determine the cause of the crash, but it did note that the aircraft made a sharp right turn seconds before it crashed into the water. Ken Watson, managing director of Sydney Seaplanes, the company that operated the flight, said the turn was "inexplicable". "We don't know why the pilot made such a sharp turn at low altitude," he told the BBC. "It's something that we're trying to understand." The aircraft was carrying seven people - the pilot and six passengers, including five members of a British family who were on holiday in Australia. The passengers have been named as Richard Cousins, his wife Emma, their two children, William and Isabella, and Emma's sister, Heather. The pilot has been named as Gareth Morgan. The Cousins family were from Hampshire, in southern England. Richard Cousins was the former chief executive of the catering company Compass Group. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) is investigating the crash. A final report is expected to be released in the coming months. In the meantime, Sydney Seaplanes has suspended all flights. The company has also offered its condolences to the victims' families. "Our thoughts are with the families of the victims," said Mr Watson. "We are doing everything we can to support them during this difficult time." The crash has raised questions about the safety of seaplanes. However, Mr Watson insisted that seaplanes are a safe form of transport. "Seaplanes have a very good safety record," he said. "This is a very rare incident." The ATSB is expected to release more information about the crash in the coming days.

title: Demi Lovato fans organise 'get well soon' singalong
text: But rather than getting angry, the fans who'd arrived at the venue got together to send a message to the singer, who'd taken ill earlier in the day. Gathering at the O2's Blueroom Cafe, they began singing a rendition of Lovato's song Warrior. Videos on social media show dozens of fans standing arm-in-arm, arms aloft, singing the lyrics directly into their camera phones. "Now I'm a warrior/Now I got thicker skin/I'm a warrior/I'm stronger than I've ever been," they sang. The song has long been a favourite among Lovato's fans, who identify with its message of overcoming adversity. Lovato herself tweeted that she was "blown away" by the fan support. "I am so grateful for all of your love and support," she wrote. "Thank you for making me feel so loved." The singalong wasn't the only way Lovato's fans showed their support. Many took to social media to share messages of love and encouragement. One fan wrote: "Demi, you are a warrior and you will get through this. We are all here for you." Another wrote: "Demi, your music has helped me through so much. Thank you for sharing your story with the world." Lovato's illness is the latest in a series of health struggles she has faced in recent years. In 2018, she was hospitalised for an apparent drug overdose. She has since spoken openly about her struggles with addiction and mental health. Lovato's fans are hoping that this latest setback will not derail her progress. They are confident that she will bounce back stronger than ever before.

title: Coastguard rescues suspected migrants off Kent coast
text: The BBC has been told some of the passengers phoned relatives in Calais to say they were in trouble after their boat started taking in water. HM Coastguard said it started receiving multiple 999 calls at about 18:30 BST on Thursday. Two RNLI lifeboats, Dover lifeboat and two French patrol vessels were sent to the scene. One person was airlifted to hospital but their condition is not yet known. The remaining 30 on board the rigid inflatable boat (RIB) were described as "cold and wet" when they were brought back to Dover. Dover RNLI coxswain Mark Jackson said: "It was a very rough night with a large swell and Force 6 winds so the sea conditions were challenging for both the passengers and the rescue teams. "It's believed the vessel had been at sea for some considerable time before we reached it. "All of the people were quickly moved to the shelter of the lifeboat and given blankets and hot drinks to warm them up." French officials say they are stepping up efforts to tackle Channel crossings, which they blame on organised crime gangs. The government has been criticised by opposition politicians for its handling of the numbers of migrants arriving in the UK from France. More than 4,000 people have crossed the Channel so far this year, a figure that is already higher than the total for the whole of last year. In April, the government announced a plan to send migrants who arrive in the UK illegally to Rwanda. The policy has been condemned by refugee charities and human rights groups, and is currently being challenged in the courts.

title: Warning of challenges for UK oil sector from Wood Group
text: Bob Keiller warned that the second half of the North Sea story is going to be different from the first. He was speaking ahead of the Offshore Europe exhibition and conference in Aberdeen. Mr Keiller said the industry was at a "critical juncture" as the world transitioned to net zero and countries looked to reduce their reliance on hydrocarbons. "We're going to have to find ways to do things which we haven't done before," he said. "We're going to have to work more collaboratively, more efficiently, and we're going to have to be more innovative." Mr Keiller said the industry needed to focus on three key areas: Improving recovery rates: The UK currently recovers around 40% of the oil and gas from its North Sea fields. Mr Keiller said this could be increased to 50% or even 60% by using new technologies. Developing new technologies: The industry needs to invest in new technologies that can help to reduce costs and improve efficiency. This includes technologies such as artificial intelligence, robotics, and automation. Collaboration: The industry needs to work more closely together to share ideas and expertise. This includes working with companies in other sectors, such as the renewable energy sector. Mr Keiller said the industry needed to "change the narrative" around the North Sea. "We need to show that the North Sea is still a vital part of the UK's energy mix," he said. "And we need to show that the industry is committed to investing in the future." The Offshore Europe exhibition and conference is one of the world's leading events for the offshore energy industry. It takes place in Aberdeen every two years and attracts over 35,000 visitors. The event is a showcase for the latest technologies and innovations in the offshore energy sector. It also provides a platform for industry leaders to discuss the challenges and opportunities facing the industry. This year's event takes place from 5-8 September and will focus on the theme of "Reimagine the Energy Future."

title: Michael Gove accuses Sussex council of 'academy fail'
text: In a letter sent to all East Sussex MPs, Michael Gove asked them to persuade the council to "take a more constructive position". He criticised the council for "failing to support a single academy proposal in the county, despite the government's push to increase the number of academies in England." The council has said it is "committed to working with all schools in the county, including academies," but that it has "concerns about the impact of academisation on the local education system." The government has said that academies are more autonomous than council-run schools and are therefore able to "innovate and improve more quickly." However, critics have argued that academies can be less accountable to parents and the local community. The letter from Michael Gove comes after the council rejected a proposal to turn Bexhill High School into an academy. The school is currently run by the council. In the letter, Mr Gove said that the council's decision was "disappointing" and that it was "letting down the children of East Sussex." He said that the government would continue to work with the council to try to persuade it to change its mind. The council has said that it is "disappointed" by the letter from Michael Gove and that it stands by its decision to reject the proposal to turn Bexhill High School into an academy. The council said that it had "carefully considered" the proposal and that it had "concluded that academisation was not in the best interests of the school or the local community." The council said that it was "committed to working with all schools in the county, including academies, to ensure that all children in East Sussex have access to a high-quality education."

title: The consequences of a busy day
text: Nick Triggle Health correspondent The day before Liverpool had won the Carling Cup football final, while the Sun on Sunday had just been launched. For the NHS, it was just another manic Monday. The emergency department at the Royal Liverpool Hospital was packed. It was the busiest day of the year so far, with more than 400 patients passing through its doors. Dr Rebecca Jones, the department's clinical director, said it was a "perfect storm" of factors that had led to the surge in demand. "We had a lot of people coming in with injuries from the football match, as well as people who had been drinking too much and had fallen over," she said. "We also had a lot of patients with respiratory problems, which is common at this time of year. It all added up to a very busy day." The Royal Liverpool Hospital is not alone. Emergency departments across the country are reporting similar levels of demand. A recent survey by the Royal College of Emergency Medicine found that more than half of emergency departments are seeing more patients than they can safely accommodate. The college's president, Dr Taj Hassan, said the NHS was facing a "crisis" and called for urgent action to address the problem. "We are seeing more and more patients coming through our doors, but we are not getting the resources we need to meet demand," he said. "This is putting patients at risk and it is also putting staff under a lot of pressure." The government has said it is committed to investing in the NHS, but the college says more needs to be done. It is calling for an increase in funding for emergency departments, as well as more staff and more beds. The college is also calling for a review of the way emergency services are provided. It says the current system is too fragmented and does not provide patients with the best possible care. The government has said it is considering the college's proposals, but it is not clear when any changes will be made. In the meantime, emergency departments across the country are continuing to struggle to cope with demand. Dr Jones said the staff at the Royal Liverpool Hospital were doing their best to provide the best possible care for their patients, but they were under a lot of pressure. "We are all working very hard, but it is a challenge," she said. "We need more resources and we need a better way of providing emergency care."

title: Military Wives Choirs and The Hepworth Wakefield get share of £76m fund
text: Whitby's Gothic Festival, London's Somerset House and Kneehigh Theatre in Cornwall are also set to benefit. The latest raft of grants, for 588 organisations, will come out of the government's Culture Recovery Fund, established to help the sector weather the financial impact of the pandemic. The money will go towards projects such as the relaunch of Military Wives Choirs, which provides singing and social support to women with partners in the armed forces, and the redevelopment of The Hepworth Wakefield, a gallery dedicated to the work of sculptor Barbara Hepworth. The grants will be used to support a wide range of cultural activities across England, including theater, dance, music, visual arts and museums. Culture Secretary Nadine Dorries said: "These grants will help our fantastic cultural organizations bounce back strongly from the challenges of the last year and continue to entertain and inspire audiences all over the country." The Culture Recovery Fund was launched in July 2020 with a total of £1.57 billion to support cultural and heritage organizations. It has awarded grants to more than 2,500 organizations so far. The latest round of funding will support organizations across England, from small community groups to major cultural institutions. The full list of organizations receiving grants can be found on the government's website. Some of the other organizations to receive grants include: The Roundhouse, a performing arts and community center in London The Royal Opera House, a world-renowned opera and ballet company The Tate, a group of four art museums in London, Liverpool, St Ives and Cornwall The National Gallery, a museum in London housing a collection of paintings from the 13th to the 19th centuries The British Museum, a museum in London housing a collection of artifacts from around the world These grants will provide a much-needed boost to the cultural sector in England and will help to ensure that it continues to thrive in the years to come.

title: UK Conservatives 'row back' in Europe rights battle
text: UK Conservatives 'row back' in Europe rights battle By Laurence Peter BBC News The UK's ruling Conservatives clashed with European judges over a UK ban on prisoners voting. The European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) ruled in 2005 that a blanket ban on prisoners voting was a breach of human rights. However, the UK government has refused to implement the ruling, arguing that it is a matter of national security. In recent months, there have been signs that the government is softening its stance. In March, Justice Secretary Dominic Raab said he was "open-minded" about the possibility of allowing some prisoners to vote. And in June, the government published a consultation paper on the issue. The consultation paper set out two options for reform. The first option would allow prisoners serving sentences of less than four years to vote. The second option would allow all prisoners to vote, except those convicted of serious violent or sexual offences. The consultation closed in September, and the government is now considering the responses. It is expected to announce its decision in the coming months. Some Conservative MPs have expressed concerns about the government's plans. They argue that allowing prisoners to vote would be a betrayal of victims of crime. However, other Conservatives have welcomed the government's move. They argue that it is important to uphold the rule of law and that prisoners should not be denied their basic rights. The issue of prisoner voting is a complex and controversial one. There are strong arguments on both sides of the debate. Ultimately, it will be up to the government to decide whether or not to change the law. Update: 12 October 2022 The government has now announced its decision on prisoner voting. It has decided to adopt the first option set out in the consultation paper, which will allow prisoners serving sentences of less than four years to vote. The decision has been welcomed by some Conservative MPs, who argue that it is a sensible compromise that will uphold the rule of law while also respecting the rights of prisoners. However, other Conservative MPs have expressed disappointment, arguing that it is a betrayal of victims of crime. The decision is likely to be challenged in the courts. In 2020, the Supreme Court ruled that the government's blanket ban on prisoners voting was unlawful. However, the government argues that the new law is compliant with the Supreme Court's ruling. The issue of prisoner voting is likely to continue to be a source of debate and controversy for some time to come.

title: Grindr cheat pharmacist guilty of wife's murder
text: Mitesh Patel, 37, denied killing Jessica, 34, and staging a burglary at the couple's home in Middlesbrough. Teesside Crown Court heard he had planned the murder for months, buying chloroform, tape, gloves, and a stun gun. He also created a fake Grindr profile to lure men to the house while Jessica was out. On May 14, 2020, Patel lured victim Anthony Armstrong to the house and attacked him with the stun gun. He then strangled Jessica and staged a burglary to cover up the crime. Armstrong survived the attack and later identified Patel as his attacker. The court heard that Patel was in financial trouble and had been having an affair with a man he met on Grindr. He had also been taking steroids and had a history of domestic violence. The jury heard that Patel had sent a series of text messages to his lover in the weeks leading up to the murder, discussing his plans to kill his wife. In one message, he said: "I'm going to do it. I'm going to kill her." Patel was found guilty of murder and sentenced to life in prison. The judge said that he had shown "no remorse" for his crime and that he was a "dangerous and manipulative" individual. The case has shocked the community of Middlesbrough. Jessica's family said they were "devastated" by her death and that they could not believe that Patel had killed her. The case has also raised concerns about the safety of Grindr users. The app has been criticized for not doing enough to protect users from predators. In response, Grindr has introduced a number of new safety features, including a panic button and a way for users to report suspicious activity.

title: Tourists in trainers rescued in Ben Nevis blizzard
text: They said the tourists who were caught in blizzard conditions had "no ice axes, no crampons and as far as we are aware, no maps". Three of them were airlifted to hospital with serious injuries after getting into difficulties on Saturday night. The remaining four members of the group made it off the mountain but were also assessed by medics. The Lochaber Mountain Rescue team raised the alarm after receiving a call from a member of the public at 8pm on Saturday, sparking a major operation involving several mountain rescue teams, the RAF and coastguard helicopter crews. The team said: "The group had intended on completing the Ben Nevis Horseshoe but soon lost their way after bad weather closed in. They then tried to descend via Carn Mor Dearg but became disoriented in the worsening conditions. The onset of darkness further complicated matters and the group found themselves stranded on steep ground, having become separated. "It was apparent the group had no ice axes, no crampons and as far as we are aware, no maps. Three of the group, two men and a woman, sustained serious injuries after falling on the icy slopes." The injured hikers were airlifted from the mountain to Fort William's Belford Hospital by RAF helicopter, where they were treated for multiple injuries. The remaining four members of the group made it off the mountain but were also assessed by medics. Lochaber MRT said: "This was a protracted and complex rescue involving multiple teams, aircraft and partner agencies. We wish the injured walkers a speedy recovery and commend the actions of the teams involved." The incident is a reminder of the importance of being well-prepared when heading out into the mountains. The Mountaineering Scotland website advises hikers to plan their route carefully, check the weather forecast and take appropriate clothing and equipment, including an ice axe, crampons and a map. The website also advises hikers to let someone know where they are going and when they expect to be back, and to carry a whistle and a torch in case of emergencies.

title: Stormont deadlock: Sinn Féin to meet Leo Varadkar
text: Party leader Mary Lou McDonald has said she will tell the British and Irish governments this week that "direct rule from London is not an option". McDonald will meet Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar on Tuesday and Northern Ireland Secretary Chris Heaton-Harris on Wednesday in a bid to break the Stormont deadlock. The meeting comes after the UK government announced plans to introduce legislation that would allow it to unilaterally set a budget for Northern Ireland in the absence of a functioning devolved government. The move has been met with anger by Sinn Féin, which has accused the UK government of "bullying" and "bad faith". McDonald said she would use her meetings with Varadkar and Heaton-Harris to set out Sinn Féin's position and to "explore any and all possibilities" for restoring power-sharing. "I will be making it very clear to both governments that we will not accept any attempt to impose Tory cuts and austerity on the people of the north by the back door," she said. "Direct rule from London is not an option, and we will not allow it to happen. "The people of the north have a right to have their say in how they are governed, and that right must be respected." The Stormont Assembly has been in deadlock since May 2022 after the DUP withdrew from the power-sharing Executive in protest at the Northern Ireland Protocol. The UK government has said it is prepared to call fresh elections for the Assembly if a new Executive is not formed by the end of October. However, Sinn Féin has said it will not participate in any elections until the UK government agrees to implement the Protocol in full. The Protocol is a part of the Brexit deal that was designed to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. However, the DUP has argued that the Protocol has created a trade barrier between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK and has damaged the region's economy. The UK government has said it is willing to make changes to the Protocol, but only if the EU agrees. The EU has said it is willing to discuss changes to the Protocol, but only if they do not undermine the integrity of the single market. The Stormont deadlock has left Northern Ireland without a functioning government for over a year. This has led to a number of problems, including a lack of progress on key issues such as health, education, and infrastructure. The deadlock has also damaged Northern Ireland's reputation as a place to do business.

title: Coronavirus in NI care homes a 'critical battle' for executive
text: By Jayne McCormack BBC News NI Political Reporter On Friday it emerged some residents were being moved from a north Belfast care home due to concerns about its handling of an outbreak. Almost half of the 664 Covid-linked deaths in Northern Ireland have been in care homes. The BBC has been told of families who are so concerned about the care their loved ones are getting that they have made alternative arrangements. One woman, whose mother has dementia, said she cannot sleep at night because she is so worried about what is going on. "I'm very worried," she said. "All sorts of things could be happening." She said she had been trying to get information from the home but was finding it difficult. "I feel like I am constantly bombarding them with phone calls," she said. "The staff have been great but I feel like I am being left in the dark." The woman said she had heard that some residents were being moved out of the home. "I don't know if that's true or not," she said. "But if it is, I worry about what that says about the level of care." The outbreak in the north Belfast care home is not the first. There have been a number of outbreaks in care homes across Northern Ireland in recent weeks. On Thursday, the Public Health Agency (PHA) said it was investigating an outbreak at a care home in County Antrim. The PHA said that it was working with the care home to manage the outbreak and that it was providing support to the residents and staff. The PHA did not say how many people had been affected by the outbreak. The outbreaks in care homes have raised concerns about the level of care that is being provided to residents. The Health and Social Care Board (HSCB) has said that it is working with care homes to ensure that they are providing a safe environment for their residents. The HSCB has also said that it is providing additional support to care homes that are experiencing outbreaks. The Executive has said that it is committed to supporting care homes during the pandemic. The Executive has also said that it will continue to work with the HSCB to ensure that care homes are providing a safe environment for their residents.

title: Rower, 72, set to become oldest to cross Atlantic
text: Graham Walters, from Thurmaston in Leicestershire, is raising money for Help for Heroes by rowing from Gran Canaria to Antigua. This is his fifth and arguably most challenging ocean rowing attempt. If successful, at 72 years old, he will become the oldest person to row solo, unsupported, across the Atlantic Ocean. Graham retired from his job as a financial adviser in 2016 and within a year he was attempting a record-breaking row across the Atlantic Ocean. However, due to a series of injuries and adverse weather conditions, he had to abandon his attempt. Undeterred, in 2018, he set a new Guinness World Record by becoming the oldest person to row solo, unsupported, across the Indian Ocean from Australia to Mauritius. In March 2020, just days before he was due to set off on his second attempt to row the Atlantic, the Covid-19 pandemic forced him to postpone. But on 12 December 2022, Graham finally set off on his Talisker Whisky Atlantic Challenge, a 3,000-mile solo row from Gran Canaria, in the Canary Islands, to Antigua in the Caribbean. Graham's boat is a Rannoch R45 ocean rowing boat, which is just 23ft long and weighs just 450kg. He will be carrying all of his food, water, and equipment, weighing an additional 200kg. He will be rowing non-stop 24 hours a day. He will be getting food and sleep in short naps, typically in 20-minute bursts. Graham is aiming to raise £100,000 for Help for Heroes, a charity that supports members of the armed forces who have been wounded or injured in the line of duty. He said: "I'm doing this to raise money for Help for Heroes, a charity that is very close to my heart. I have been supporting them for many years, and I know what a difference they make to the lives of our wounded servicemen and women. "I'm also doing this to show that age is no barrier to achieving your dreams. If you have a dream, go for it. It doesn't matter how old you are." You can follow Graham's progress on his website: www.atlanticrows.com

title: Seychelles protects an area 'as big as Britain' in Indian Ocean
text: In exchange for getting some of its national debt paid off, the island nation has agreed to protect 210,000 sq km (81,000 sq miles) of ocean. The reserves will ban commercial fishing, oil and gas exploration, and mining. The Seychelles is an archipelago of 115 islands in the Indian Ocean, with a total land area of just 455 sq km (176 sq miles). The new marine protected areas (MPAs) will be more than 400 times larger than the country's landmass. The Seychelles is home to a rich diversity of marine life, including coral reefs, sea turtles, sharks, and rays. The new MPAs will help to protect these species and their habitats from overfishing and other threats. The debt-for-nature swap was arranged by The Nature Conservancy, a US-based environmental organization. The Seychelles government will receive $21 million to pay off its debt, and The Nature Conservancy will provide technical assistance to help the government manage the new MPAs. The debt-for-nature swap is a win-win for the Seychelles and for the environment. The Seychelles will get some of its debt paid off, and the new MPAs will help to protect the country's marine resources. The Seychelles is not the first country to use a debt-for-nature swap to protect its environment. In 2016, Belize agreed to protect 30% of its territorial waters in exchange for getting $586 million of its debt paid off. Debt-for-nature swaps are a creative way to finance conservation efforts. They can help countries to protect their environment while also reducing their debt burden. The Seychelles' new MPAs are a significant step forward in the fight to protect the world's oceans. They will help to ensure that future generations can enjoy the beauty and bounty of the Seychelles' marine environment.

title: Rise in ambulance delays at South East hospitals
text: South East Coast Ambulance Service (SECAmb) figures show ambulances had 36,000 hours "handover time" in 2011/12, 50% more than three years ago. The service says it's "very concerned" by the trend. Ambulances waiting to handover patients to A&E staff have more than doubled in some areas of Kent over the period, analysts found. In November 2012, SECAmb reported delays of more than an hour at Darent Valley Hospital in Dartford on 115 occasions, compared to just five the same month in 2011. Medway Maritime Hospital in Gillingham reported 104 hour-long delays, and Maidstone Hospital had 23. SECAmb boss Paul Sutton said it was a "national problem". He told BBC South East Today: "It's not just about putting more ambulances on the road. It's about the whole system." SECAmb said delays occur when ambulances are stuck outside A&E departments waiting to hand over patients to hospital staff. The handover process can take several hours, and during that time the ambulance crew is unavailable to respond to other calls. SECAmb said the increase in handover time was putting a strain on its resources. The service said it was working with hospitals to find ways to reduce handover delays but admitted it was a "complex" issue with no easy solutions. The BBC understands that delays are being caused by a number of factors, including the increasing number of elderly and frail patients who need more time to be assessed and admitted to hospital. Another factor is the number of patients who are staying in hospital for longer periods of time, which means there are fewer beds available for new admissions. The delays are also being caused by a shortage of nurses in A&E departments, which means that patients are waiting longer to be seen by a doctor. SECAmb said it was working with hospitals to find ways to reduce handover delays but admitted it was a "complex" issue with no easy solutions.

title: Guatemala's President Otto Perez Molina resigns
text: Prosecutors accuse Mr Perez Molina of masterminding a scheme to defraud the customs service of millions of dollars. He denies the allegations. On Tuesday, Congress stripped him of his immunity from prosecution, paving the way for him to be arrested and charged. Mr Perez Molina, a retired general, becomes the latest in a string of Latin American presidents to be embroiled in corruption scandals. His resignation comes amid growing public anger over corruption and impunity in Guatemala. The scandal, known as "La Linea" (The Line), is alleged to have involved a network of officials and businesspeople who charged importers bribes in exchange for reducing their customs duties. The scheme is said to have operated for several years, netting millions of dollars. Mr Perez Molina has denied any involvement in the scandal, but several of his close associates have been arrested, including his former vice-president, Roxana Baldetti. The resignation of Mr Perez Molina is a major victory for the anti-corruption movement in Guatemala. It is also a sign that the region's leaders are becoming increasingly vulnerable to prosecution for corruption. In recent years, several other Latin American presidents have been accused of corruption, including Dilma Rousseff of Brazil, Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner of Argentina, and Nicolas Maduro of Venezuela. Some of these leaders have been impeached or removed from office, while others are still facing charges. The corruption scandals in Latin America have led to widespread public anger and protests. Citizens are demanding greater transparency and accountability from their governments. The resignation of Mr Perez Molina is a sign that these demands are being heard. It is too early to say whether Mr Perez Molina's resignation will lead to lasting change in Guatemala. However, it is a clear sign that the country's citizens are no longer willing to tolerate corruption and impunity.
