title: Boeing 'is not a trustworthy company anymore'
text: Ms Kuria, who met with Europe's aviation watchdog on Wednesday, said: "I wouldn't even use the word trust anywhere near Boeing." Boeing is fighting for its reputation and survival after two deadly crashes involving its 737 Max jet. The company has been accused of putting profits before safety, and its relationship with the US aviation regulator, the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), has come under scrutiny. In the wake of the crashes, Boeing has made changes to the design of the 737 Max and its safety protocols. However, some experts believe that the company's problems go beyond the technical issues with the aircraft. "Boeing has a culture problem," said Richard Aboulafia, an aviation analyst at Teal Group. "They have been focused on cost-cutting and shareholder returns, and they have lost sight of their core mission of safety." Boeing has admitted that it made mistakes in the design and certification of the 737 Max. The company has also agreed to pay billions of dollars in compensation to the families of the victims of the crashes. However, some experts believe that Boeing's problems are more deep-rooted. They argue that the company has lost its way and that it needs to undergo a fundamental change in its culture. "Boeing needs to go back to its roots," said Aboulafia. "They need to focus on building safe, reliable aircraft, and they need to put the interests of their customers first." Boeing's future is uncertain. The company is facing a number of legal challenges, and its reputation has been badly damaged. However, Boeing is a resilient company with a long history of innovation. It remains to be seen whether Boeing can overcome its current challenges and regain the trust of its customers. In the meantime, Ms Kuria's comments are a reminder of the importance of trust in the aviation industry. Passengers need to be able to trust that the aircraft they are flying on are safe. Boeing has a lot of work to do to rebuild that trust.

title: Peter Sutcliffe victim highlights 'imbalance of justice' for women
text: Mo Lea, 61, from Bedford, was an art student in Leeds in 1980 when she was attacked by a man with a hammer. She has been named as one of the likely victims of Sutcliffe, but despite suffering life-changing injuries including a fractured skull, permanent sight loss in one eye and severe brain damage, Sutcliffe was never charged with her attempted murder. "I think about him every day," Mo told the BBC. "The fact he is dead doesn't make life any easier. I don't feel any closure. I am still living with the consequences of what he did to me." Mo's story is one of many that highlights the historical imbalance of justice for women who were victims of serious sexual and violent crime. In Sutcliffe's case, his victims were predominantly women from disadvantaged backgrounds, who were often sex workers or runaways. This meant that their cases were often treated with less seriousness by police and the justice system, and they were less likely to be believed or taken seriously. "When you are seen as being of less value by society, you are less likely to get justice," said Diane Taylor, chief executive of Leeds Women's Aid. "It's a sad indictment of our society that women like Mo have to fight for recognition and justice." In recent years, there has been a growing recognition of the historical injustice faced by women victims of violence. This has been partly driven by campaigns by women's rights groups and the #MeToo movement, which has highlighted the prevalence of sexual harassment and assault. As a result, there have been some changes in the way that police and the justice system deal with cases of violence against women. For example, there is now a greater focus on victim support and the need to believe and take seriously the experiences of women who report crimes. However, Mo believes that there is still more to be done to address the historical imbalance of justice for women. "I think it's really important that we don't forget the women who were victims of Peter Sutcliffe and other serial killers," she said. "They deserve to be remembered and their stories need to be told." Mo also believes that more needs to be done to support women who have been victims of violence and to help them access justice. "There needs to be more support for women who have suffered serious sexual and violent crime," she said. "They need to be able to access specialist services that can help them to cope with the trauma they have experienced and to get the justice they deserve."

title: Greggs profits set to bounce back to pre-pandemic levels
text: The bakery chain said sales had seen a "strong recovery" since non-essential shops reopened in April. While it warned that trading conditions were "clearly challenging", Greggs said it was confident in its ability to navigate the headwinds. Roger Whiteside, chief executive, said: "We are pleased to report a strong recovery in sales since the reopening of our shops in April. This has been driven by a combination of factors, including the easing of lockdown restrictions, the return of customers to our shops, and the success of our new product launches." He added: "While trading conditions are clearly challenging, we are confident in our ability to navigate the headwinds and continue to grow our business. We have a strong balance sheet, a loyal customer base, and a proven track record of innovation." Greggs said it expects to return to pre-pandemic levels of profitability in the current financial year. The company also said it plans to open around 100 new shops in the UK this year. Analysts said the update from Greggs was "encouraging". Shore Capital said: "Greggs has reported a strong recovery in sales since the reopening of its shops in April. This is a clear indication that the company is well-positioned to benefit from the easing of lockdown restrictions." Liberum said: "Greggs is a well-managed company with a strong track record. The company is well-positioned to navigate the current challenges and continue to grow its business." Shares in Greggs rose by 2% in early trading on Tuesday. In other news, the FTSE 100 index of leading UK shares rose by 0.5% on Tuesday morning. The index is now up by 9% since the start of the year. The biggest risers on the FTSE 100 were Glencore, Anglo American, and Rio Tinto. The biggest fallers were AstraZeneca, Unilever, and Diageo.

title: Covid-19: Stoke-on-Trent and Coventry move into tier 2
text: Restrictions came into force at 00:01 BST on Saturday. Slough has also moved into the tier two "high" category. The restrictions in tier two mean households can no longer mix indoors, including in pubs and restaurants, unless those venues are serving substantial meals. People are also advised against travelling in and out of the affected areas. Stoke-on-Trent City Council leader Abi Brown said: "These restrictions may not be what we wanted to hear, but they are absolutely necessary to protect our residents and communities. We know that the vast majority of people in Stoke-on-Trent have been following the guidance and doing everything they can to stop the spread of the virus." She added: "But we cannot be complacent. This is not the time to let our guard down. We must all continue to follow the guidance and do everything we can to protect ourselves and others." Coventry City Council leader George Duggins said: "We are very disappointed that Coventry has been placed in tier two. We have been working hard to keep the number of cases down in our city, and we believe that we have been successful in doing so." He added: "However, we understand the government's decision and we will be working with them to ensure that the restrictions are implemented effectively. We urge all Coventry residents to follow the guidance and do everything they can to stop the spread of the virus." The move to tier two comes as the number of Covid-19 cases continues to rise in the UK. On Friday, the government announced that there had been 17,234 new cases of the virus in the UK, the highest daily total since May. The government has said that it will review the tier system on a weekly basis, and that areas could be moved up or down the tiers depending on the number of cases and the rate of transmission.

title: Budget 2020: The chancellor's very large cheque book
text: Rishi Sunak has barely been in one of the biggest jobs in the country for a month, but he has already pulled out his biggest weapon - the cheque book. Wednesday's Budget was never going to be a normal one. The new chancellor arrived in Parliament with the weight of Brexit uncertainty lifting, but the looming threat of the coronavirus hanging over everything. So, he used his set-piece speech to set out how he wants the UK to look in the years to come, with big investment in infrastructure, changes to taxation for businesses and a boost to the NHS. It was a budget based on the idea that the government could spend its way out of trouble, without worrying too much about what it might mean for the long-term. But this was also a Budget that was trying to do too much. It wanted to fix the nation's creaky infrastructure, simultaneously invest in the NHS, and then slash taxes for businesses. The result is a plan that looks like it has been cobbled together from the ideas of three or four different chancellors. The green bits - the money for new infrastructure, the support for electric cars - are very much in keeping with the direction of travel of Boris Johnson's government. The bits that focus on public services - the extra doctors, the nurses, the schools - are what you would expect from a Conservative government. And then there are the tax cuts - a classic Thatcherite policy that seemed to catch some of the chancellor's cabinet colleagues off guard. Ultimately, this was a Budget that lacked a coherent narrative. It was an attempt to do too much, and in doing so, risked losing focus. The chancellor used the language of investment and growth, but at the heart of the Budget was an old-fashioned Conservative philosophy - let's give businesses a tax break and they'll pass it on to their workers. That's a gamble. It's also the opposite of the approach taken by the chancellor's predecessor, Sajid Javid, who wanted to use the tax system to create a fairer society. It's a big gamble and it's one that could backfire spectacularly. But then again, Rishi Sunak is a politician who likes to rewrite the rules.

title: Astronaut Scott Kelly attacked for quoting Winston Churchill
text: American astronaut Scott Kelly put that to the test on Sunday when his use of Winston Churchill quotes landed him in hot water with people who oppose the wartime British prime minister's views on empire and race. Kelly, who spent a year on the International Space Station in 2015 and 2016, is a big fan of Churchill and often quotes him on social media. But his recent tweet about Churchill's quote on democracy sparked a backlash, with many accusing him of supporting Churchill's views on race and empire. "Democracy is the worst form of government except for all those other forms that have been tried from time to time," Kelly tweeted, quoting Churchill. The tweet was quickly met with criticism from people who pointed out that Churchill also believed in the superiority of the white race and supported the British Empire. "I'm sorry, but I can't support someone who quotes Winston Churchill," tweeted one person. "His views on race and empire were abhorrent." "Churchill was a racist and an imperialist," tweeted another. "He has no place in modern society." Kelly has since deleted the tweet and apologized for any offense he caused. "I apologize if my tweet caused any offense," he tweeted. "I am a big fan of Churchill's leadership during World War II, but I do not endorse his views on race and empire." However, some people believe that Kelly should not have apologized for quoting Churchill. "I think it's important to remember that Churchill was a complex figure," said historian Andrew Roberts. "He was a great leader who also had some very flawed views. We should not judge him by today's standards." The debate over Churchill's legacy is likely to continue for many years to come. He was a complex figure who made both great and terrible decisions. It is up to each individual to decide how they view him.

title: 'Shrewsbury 24': MPs vote for release of government papers
text: Campaigners want to quash convictions against 24 men who were accused of violent picketing and intimidating workers in Shropshire, in 1972. The men, known as the "Shrewsbury 24", were convicted following a 15-week trial and have spent decades campaigning to clear their names. MPs voted in favour of a motion calling on the government to release papers relating to the case, which campaigners say could prove the men's innocence. The motion was passed by 270 votes to 0, with 23 Conservative MPs abstaining. It called on the government to release all "relevant papers" relating to the case, including those that are currently withheld on national security grounds. The government has said it is "carefully considering" the motion, but has not yet committed to releasing the papers. The Shrewsbury 24 were convicted of conspiracy to intimidate, unlawful assembly, and affray. They were accused of attacking non-striking workers and damaging property during a strike at the Shrewsbury plant of the construction company, GKN Sankey. The men have always maintained their innocence, and their supporters say that the convictions were based on fabricated evidence. In 2018, the Criminal Cases Review Commission (CCRC) referred the case back to the Court of Appeal. The CCRC said there was "a real possibility" that the men's convictions would be quashed. The Court of Appeal is currently considering the case. The release of the government papers could provide crucial evidence in the appeal. The campaigners say that the papers could show that the police and security services fabricated evidence against the men. They also say that the papers could show that the government was involved in a cover-up. The government has said that it is "committed to transparency" and that it will release the papers if it is "appropriate to do so". However, the government has not yet said when it will make a decision on the matter. The campaigners have welcomed the vote in Parliament, but they say that the government must now act quickly to release the papers. A spokesperson for the Shrewsbury 24 Campaign said: "This is a historic moment. The vote in Parliament shows that there is overwhelming support for the release of the government papers. "We now call on the government to act quickly and release the papers in full. The men have waited decades for justice, and they deserve to have their names cleared."

title: Maplin collapses as rescue talks fail
text: Maplin, which has more than 200 stores and 2,300 staff, will continue to trade through the process. title: Colchester Hospital: Police launch formal inquiry
text: The Care Quality Commission (CQC) said earlier this month Colchester Hospital staff were "pressured or bullied" to change data. Essex Police announced on Tuesday it would be investigating. NHS England also revealed details of a review. The inquiry will consider whether staff were pressured to change patient data, the impact this has had on patient care, the extent of the issue within the hospital, and the actions taken to address it. The CQC's report, published on 4 July, found that staff at the hospital had been altering data to meet targets. This included changing the time patients were admitted and discharged, and the length of time they spent in hospital. The report also found that staff were "pressured or bullied" to change data by their managers. This was done in order to make the hospital look better in performance tables. The police investigation will now consider whether any criminal offences have been committed. NHS England has also announced that it will be conducting a review of the hospital. This review will look at the extent of the data manipulation and the actions taken to address it. The review will also make recommendations on how to prevent similar incidents from happening in the future. The hospital has said that it is "fully cooperating" with the police and NHS England investigations. It has also said that it is "committed to providing high-quality care to its patients". title: Tidal energy project proposed off Bardsey Island
text: Local community enterprise YnNi Llyn has teamed up with Edinburgh-based Nova Innovation to explore the possibility of deploying a 3MW tidal energy array off Bardsey Island, north Wales. The project, which would be the first of its kind in Wales, could generate enough electricity to power around 2,000 homes. It would also create jobs and boost the local economy. Tidal energy is a clean, renewable source of energy that can be generated from the movement of the tides. Nova Innovation is a world-leading developer of tidal energy technology. The company's turbines are designed to be low-impact and fish-friendly. The proposed tidal energy array would be located in the Bardsey Sound, between Bardsey Island and the Llŷn Peninsula. The site has strong tidal currents and is well-suited for tidal energy generation. YnNi Llyn is a community-owned enterprise that is working to develop renewable energy projects in the Llŷn Peninsula. The company is committed to working with local communities to ensure that the benefits of renewable energy are shared by all. The tidal energy project is still in the early stages of development. However, YnNi Llyn and Nova Innovation are confident that it has the potential to be a major success. "This project has the potential to transform the way we generate energy in Wales," said YnNi Llyn project manager Geraint Jones. "Tidal energy is a clean, renewable source of energy that can help us to reduce our carbon emissions and create jobs." "We are delighted to be working with YnNi Llyn on this exciting project," said Nova Innovation CEO Simon Forrest. "We believe that our tidal energy technology can make a significant contribution to the UK's renewable energy targets." The project has been welcomed by local politicians and environmental groups. "This project is a great example of how communities can work together to develop renewable energy projects," said local MS Sian Gwenlli. "It has the potential to create jobs, boost the local economy, and reduce our carbon emissions." "We are very supportive of this project," said Friends of the Earth Cymru campaigner Dewi Williams. "Tidal energy is a clean, renewable source of energy that can help us to tackle the climate crisis." The project is expected to be submitted for planning permission in the coming months. If approved, it could be operational by 2025.

title: Why India’s mobile users go offline for video
text: By Prasanto K Roy Technology writer It sells odds and ends, and DVD discs, each with up to 10 movies of doubtful quality. Asim Mandal, 26, a checkout clerk at a local retailer, is a regular. He pops out his phone's memory card and hands it over to the shop owner. In return, he is handed back a fresh card featuring the latest - and equally dubious - Bollywood blockbusters. "I have five, six cards at home, Each one has different films on it," he says. "I watch them on my phone when I'm at work, or when I'm travelling." Mandal is not alone. Many Indians who have low-quality or unreliable internet access prefer to download movies and store them on memory cards so that they can be watched offline later. It is a phenomenon that is particularly common in smaller towns and villages, where data connectivity can be patchy or expensive. "I don't have a Wi-Fi connection at home, and my mobile data is very slow," says 19-year-old college student Soniya Gupta. "So I download movies onto my phone when I'm at college, and then watch them later." The trend has been boosted by the rise of cheap smartphones and memory cards. Even low-end phones now have enough storage space to hold several movies, and memory cards are widely available for less than $10. This offline viewing trend is not unique to India. In many developing countries, where internet access is limited or expensive, people often download content to watch later. But in India, the practice is particularly widespread. There are several reasons for this. First, India has a large population of low-income earners who cannot afford to pay for high-speed internet. Second, the country's mobile networks are often congested, making it difficult to stream video smoothly. Third, India has a strong tradition of piracy, and many people are willing to download copyrighted content illegally. The offline viewing trend has had a significant impact on the Indian film industry. In the past, people who lived in rural areas had to wait for months or even years to see the latest Bollywood releases. Now, they can download them within days of their release. This has led to a decline in ticket sales at movie theaters in smaller towns and villages. But it has also created new opportunities for filmmakers. Bollywood producers are now making more low-budget films that are specifically targeted at the offline market. These films are often made with smaller casts and crews, and they feature less-known actors. But they are still able to generate significant profits, thanks to the large number of people who watch them offline. The offline viewing trend is likely to continue to grow in India in the coming years. As more and more people gain access to smartphones and memory cards, they will be able to enjoy their favorite movies and TV shows whenever and wherever they want.

title: Hospital funding issues put local MPs on the spot
text: The irony is that the private finance initiative was devised by the previous Conservative administration. But it was Labour who adopted it with a will, as a way of replacing crumbling or outdated hospital buildings. The PFI scheme meant that hospitals were built by private companies, which then leased the buildings back to the NHS. The NHS paid a rent for the buildings over a period of many years, often 30 or 40 years. The intention was to provide new hospitals quickly and without having to make the full cost of the building immediately available. But the PFI scheme has been criticised for being expensive and inflexible. Critics argue that the NHS has been paying too much rent for the buildings, and that the leases have prevented the NHS from making changes it would like to make. In recent years, the government has been moving away from PFI as a way of funding new hospitals. Instead, it has been using a system called the Public Sector Comparator, which is designed to be more transparent and flexible. However, the legacy of PFI continues to haunt the NHS. Many hospitals are still paying rent on PFI-funded buildings, and the contracts can be difficult to break. This is putting pressure on NHS budgets and making it difficult for hospitals to invest in new services and equipment. Local MPs are now being put on the spot by angry constituents who are demanding to know why their local hospitals are struggling for funding. In some cases, MPs are being accused of not doing enough to stand up for their local NHS services. One MP who has been particularly vocal in his criticism of the government's handling of the NHS is Labour's David Winnick. Winnick has accused the government of "underfunding" the NHS and of failing to address the problems caused by PFI. He has also called for the government to scrap the PFI scheme and to invest more money in the NHS. The government has defended its record on the NHS, arguing that it has increased funding for the health service in recent years. However, the government has also acknowledged that the NHS is facing financial challenges, and it has said that it is working to address these challenges. The debate over NHS funding is likely to continue in the run-up to the next general election. The NHS is a vital part of the UK's public services, and it is essential that it is properly funded.

title: Scotland's economy grows by 0.1%
text: The GDP (gross domestic product) figures for the second quarter were down from the 0.6% growth at the start of 2017. Scotland's first quarter figures were above the equivalent rate for the UK as a whole. The GDP figures are compiled by the Scottish government and measure the value of all goods and services produced in Scotland. They are used to track the performance of the Scottish economy and to compare it to the performance of the UK economy as a whole. The second quarter figures, which cover the period from April to June 2017, showed that the Scottish economy grew by 0.1%. This was down from the 0.6% growth recorded in the first quarter of the year. The UK economy as a whole grew by 0.3% in the second quarter. The slowdown in growth in the second quarter was driven by a number of factors, including a decline in oil and gas production and a slowdown in manufacturing. However, the Scottish economy is still performing better than the UK economy as a whole. Over the past year, the Scottish economy has grown by 1.2%, compared to 1.1% for the UK as a whole. The Scottish government welcomed the latest GDP figures, but said that there was still more to be done to improve the performance of the economy. A spokesperson for the Scottish government said: "These figures show that the Scottish economy is continuing to grow, but we are not complacent. We are determined to create a stronger, fairer and more prosperous Scotland for everyone." The UK government also welcomed the latest GDP figures, but said that the figures showed that the UK economy was still facing challenges. A spokesperson for the UK government said: "These figures show that the UK economy is continuing to grow, but we are not complacent. We are determined to build an economy that works for everyone, not just the privileged few." The latest GDP figures have been met with mixed reactions from economists. Some economists have praised the Scottish government for its handling of the economy, while others have said that more needs to be done to improve the performance of the economy. Overall, the latest GDP figures show that the Scottish economy is continuing to grow, but there are still challenges to be faced. The Scottish government is committed to improving the performance of the economy, but it will need to work with the UK government to achieve this.

title: Michael Gove 'shuddered' at UKIP migrants poster
text: The justice secretary joined a number of politicians attacking the poster, featuring a photo taken in Slovenia, with George Osborne saying it had "echoes" of 1930s propaganda. The poster has been widely condemned by anti-racism campaigners, who say it is racist and divisive. The Runnymede Trust, a race equality think tank, said the poster was "a new low in British politics" and that it "demonstrates a frightening disregard for the feelings of minority communities in this country". The Stop Hate UK campaign group said the poster was "a blatant attempt to stir up racial hatred" and that it "should be condemned by all decent people". title: India PM Narendra Modi warning about religious attacks
text: By Sanjoy Majumder BBC News In one instance, a Catholic church was burned down in a suburb of the capital. The violence has upset India's Christian community, which is a small but visible and influential minority. Church leaders have alleged that some of the attacks have been carried out by Hindu nationalist groups. The government denies that it tolerates violence against religious minorities. However, critics say that it has not done enough to protect Christians and other religious minorities from attack. In a speech to mark Christmas, Prime Minister Narendra Modi condemned the attacks on Christians and said that violence against any religious group was "unacceptable". He also appealed for religious harmony and peace. "Violence against any religion is unacceptable," Modi said. "We must respect every religion and every faith. There is no place for violence in a civilised society." Modi's speech was welcomed by some Christian leaders, but others said that it did not go far enough. They called on the government to take more concrete steps to protect Christians and other religious minorities from attack. In recent years, there has been a rise in communal violence in India. According to a report by the National Crime Records Bureau, there were 282 incidents of communal violence in 2020, up from 230 in 2019. The majority of the victims of communal violence are Muslims, but Christians have also been targeted. In 2020, there were 35 incidents of violence against Christians, up from 26 in 2019. The violence has raised concerns about the safety of religious minorities in India. Some Christian leaders have said that they fear that the country is becoming increasingly intolerant. The Indian government has said that it is committed to protecting religious freedom and that it will not tolerate violence against any religious group. However, critics say that the government needs to do more to address the root causes of communal violence and to ensure that all religious minorities feel safe and secure.

title: Views sought on art at Taunton's Musgrove Park Hospital
text: Art for Life is an organisation which displays paintings and sculptures in the buildings and grounds of Musgrove Park Hospital, Taunton. An open day will be held on 3 September from 1pm to 4pm in the Atrium Gallery, where there will be an opportunity to view the exhibited pieces. Over 450 works of art by established as well as budding professionals are displayed throughout the organisation, with the majority of these being donated. The artwork, which includes oil paintings, watercolours, sculptures and other media, is intended to create a brighter and more positive environment for patients, staff, and visitors. The open day will provide an opportunity for members of the public to meet the artists and volunteers involved in bringing the project to life. There will be free refreshments in the Atrium Gallery and guided tours of the hospital's art collection are available for booking at the event or in advance by emailing artforlife@tst.nhs.uk or calling 01823 344277. Art for Life curator Sylvia Goldsmith said: "The upcoming open day is a great opportunity to see how Art for Life enlivens the hospital environment and provides a positive distraction for staff, visitors and patients. "We welcome people to come along and meet the artists responsible for these incredible works of art, many of whom regularly give their time to offer practical demonstrations and art workshops at the hospital. "Our volunteers and staff play a very important role in supporting our artists and visitors and we are always grateful for any time people can give to support the Art for Life programme. If you can spare time on an ad-hoc or regular basis and would like to be part of our team please get in touch." Art for Life is run by a steering group of hospital staff and volunteers in partnership with Taunton's Brewhouse Theatre and Arts Centre and Somerset Art Works. The organisation is funded by a mixture of grants and donations. In addition to the open day, activities to look out for include: 8 August - Painting demonstration in the Atrium Gallery from 1pm to 3pm 22 August - Photography exhibition by Taunton Camera Club in the main corridor 3 September - Make an Art Day drop-in session at the Atrium Gallery from 1pm to 4pm For more information about Art For Life visit the website at  www.artforlife.org.uk

title: Pakistan is hit by dengue fever epidemic
text: By M Ilyas Khan BBC News, Islamabad They have warned that it threatens to affect other parts of the country. More than 2,000 cases have been reported so far this year, with nearly half of them in Punjab province. Health officials say they are struggling to contain the outbreak due to a lack of resources and awareness about the disease. "We are facing a shortage of doctors, nurses, and medicine," said Dr. Rana Safdar, a spokesman for the Punjab Health Department. "We also need to raise awareness about dengue fever so that people can protect themselves." Dengue fever is a viral disease that is transmitted by the bite of an infected mosquito. Symptoms can include fever, headache, muscle and joint pain, and nausea. In severe cases, dengue fever can lead to bleeding, organ failure, and death. The outbreak in Pakistan has been blamed on a number of factors, including heavy rainfall, poor sanitation, and a lack of mosquito control measures. "We have been seeing a lot of rain this year, which has created breeding grounds for mosquitoes," said Dr. Safdar. "We also need to improve our sanitation practices and do a better job of controlling mosquitoes." The Pakistani government has launched a campaign to raise awareness about dengue fever and to encourage people to take steps to protect themselves. The campaign includes distributing pamphlets, airing public service announcements, and setting up mosquito traps. However, health officials say that more needs to be done to contain the outbreak. They are calling on the government to provide more resources and to do a better job of coordinating efforts between different agencies. "We need to take this outbreak seriously," said Dr. Safdar. "If we don't, it could spread to other parts of the country and cause a major health crisis."

title: Condor Ferries bought by investment fund
text: Condor currently operates between Portsmouth, Poole, Guernsey, Jersey and St Malo, and carries about a million passengers every year. title: Over to you, chancellor
text: Although a cut of a quarter of a percent was not a surprise, a specific message that it would happen was. The Bank welcomed the Budget and claimed it would reduce the risk of a recession. Mr Bailey also reiterated that keeping inflation under control was the Bank's priority. "There are some signs that global inflation may have peaked, and, of course, there are the energy markets," he said. "It's going to be bumpy, and there are still a lot of risks and uncertainties out there." The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) now expects inflation to fall to around 5% by the end of this year, and to the 2% target by 2024. But the committee also revised down its growth forecasts for 2023, from 1.5% to 0.75%. Mr Bailey said the UK economy had "weakened materially" since the Bank's last meeting in November, and that the outlook had "deteriorated materially". The Bank's decision will have come as a relief to some businesses, which had been calling for a cut in interest rates to help them through the cost of living crisis. But it is likely to be seen as a blow to savers, who have seen the value of their savings eroded by high inflation. The cut in interest rates is the first since March 2020, when the Bank slashed rates to a record low of 0.1% in response to the Covid pandemic. Since then, the Bank has raised rates nine times in a row, as it tries to get inflation under control. The Bank's decision to cut rates now suggests that it believes the economy is slowing down and that the risk of a recession is increasing.

title: Hundreds of children wait years for asylum decisions
text: Hundreds of children wait years for asylum decisions By Patrick Cowling & Sadaf Maruf BBC News Home Office figures obtained by the BBC show delays have almost tripled since January 2014, when 484 children had been waiting for more than six months for an asylum decision. Last year, 1,272 under-18s were waiting this long, rising to about 1,300 this year. The situation is so bad, a number of children have received support from specialist trafficking lawyers to argue their asylum cases should be heard more quickly. This is because the government initially refused to screen them for potential risks of harm, such as torture or sexual exploitation. The UK is signed up to the Dublin regulations, which state that asylum applications should be processed in the first safe country an individual enters. But the system does not put a time limit on how long that should take. However, last year, the European Court of Justice ruled that the lack of a time limit meant children could be left in legal limbo, and member states have a duty of care. This is why the lawyers have been able to use the court's ruling to challenge the Home Office. They argue that delays, particularly when there has not been an initial screening process, can mean children at risk of serious harm are not identified. The government is now reconsidering its screening policy following a recent judicial review. But Liberty, which brought the case, says there is still no firm commitment from the Home Office to screen all asylum-seeking children. Processing delays in deciding asylum cases are also affecting adults. Home Office data shows it takes around four months on average for a decision to be made about an adult's asylum application. But some foreigners have to wait years to find out if they have the right to remain in the UK. Iraqis are among those who have been experiencing the longest delays and in many cases, have been left destitute, forced into homelessness and barred from work. There are concerns that many have already given up and returned to their home countries. The Home Office says it is processing asylum cases as quickly as possible and that it encourages any asylum seekers who face hardship while their application is being considered to apply for support.

title: Hong Kong: What is China's 'patriot' plan for electoral reform?
text: Beijing says the goal is to keep "unpatriotic" figures from positions of political power in Hong Kong. But critics warn it would mean the end of democracy in Hong Kong, eradicating whatever opposition there is. Under the proposals, a new vetting committee would be set up to screen all candidates for public office. This committee would be composed of members loyal to Beijing, and would have the power to disqualify anyone deemed to be a threat to national security. In addition, the number of directly elected seats in the Legislative Council would be reduced from 35 to 20, while the number of seats appointed by the Beijing-controlled Election Committee would be increased from 30 to 40. These changes would give the pro-Beijing camp an overwhelming majority in the legislature, making it virtually impossible for the opposition to block any government proposals. Critics say these measures would effectively dismantle Hong Kong's democratic system, turning it into a one-party state like mainland China. "This is a clear attempt to silence dissent and eliminate any form of opposition in Hong Kong," said pro-democracy lawmaker Claudia Mo. "It would mark the end of democracy in Hong Kong." The proposals have also been condemned by the international community. The United States has said that they would "fundamentally undermine Hong Kong's autonomy and freedoms." The United Kingdom has said that the proposals "raise serious concerns about the future of democracy in Hong Kong." Despite the international outcry, Beijing has remained defiant. It has said that the proposals are necessary to "safeguard national security" and "maintain stability" in Hong Kong. It is unclear whether Beijing will ultimately go ahead with the proposals. However, the fact that they have been put forward at all is a sign of the increasing pressure that Beijing is putting on Hong Kong. Democracy in Hong Kong has been in decline for several years. In 2014, pro-democracy protesters occupied the streets of Hong Kong for 79 days in a failed attempt to force the government to introduce universal suffrage. Since then, Beijing has cracked down on dissent in Hong Kong, arresting pro-democracy activists and closing down independent media outlets. The new electoral reform proposals are the latest in a series of measures designed to tighten Beijing's control over the city. The future of democracy in Hong Kong is uncertain. However, the new electoral reform proposals are a clear indication that Beijing is determined to end it.

title: Iran scientist Shahram Amiri free to leave, US insists
text: The state department rejected claims by Tehran that Shahram Amiri, who surfaced at a Pakistani embassy building, had been abducted by US agents. Mr Amiri vanished more than a year ago. In June, three videos apparently showing him distressed and allegedly held in the US against his will, were posted on the website of Iranian state media. Later, Iranian state television aired what it said was a phone conversation between Mr Amiri and his mother, in which he said he had been kidnapped by the US, and did not know his whereabouts. On Friday, Iran's foreign ministry spokesman, Ramin Mehmanparast, said the US "kidnapped" Mr Amiri in Saudi Arabia in 2009, and the claims he had been working voluntarily for the CIA were untrue. If Mr Amiri's claims are true, it would mean that his account of being forcibly taken from Saudi Arabia to the US contradicts an earlier statement on Iranian state television, which he allegedly made in a phone call to his mother. The phone call to his mother was reported to have taken place on 14 June, while the alleged abduction by US agents is said to have taken place in 2009. However, if Mr Amiri's claims are accurate, it would mean that he was already in US custody at the time of the phone call, which would suggest that the claims made in the phone call are not true. In the videos, Mr Amiri said he was a nuclear scientist working for the Iranian government, and claimed he had been abducted by the US in 2009. The US state department said the videos were "not credible", and that Mr Amiri was free to leave the US and return to Iran whenever he wanted. Mr Amiri was a professor at Malek Ashtar University, a military academy in Tehran, and was reportedly involved in Iran's nuclear programme. He disappeared in June 2009 while on a pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia. His wife previously said she believed he was abducted by US agents, but later said she thought he had voluntarily defected to the US.

title: Meet the butterflies from 200 million years ago
text: Meet the butterflies from 200 million years ago By Helen Briggs BBC News Scientists found fossilised butterfly scales the size of a speck of dust inside ancient rock from Germany. The find pushes back the date for the origins of the Lepidoptera, the scientific order which includes butterflies and moths, by an extraordinary 25 million years. Previous butterfly fossils had only been found in ancient rocks dating back no more than 175 million years. Now, a team of German researchers has unearthed 12 fossilised butterfly scales trapped in rock around 40m years older than anything seen before. The Lepidoptera evolved from a moth-like ancestor, but the deep fossil record for butterflies is scarce. Studying the microscopic scales under an electron microscope, the researchers noticed finger-like indentations and other features that are characteristic of butterflies, distinguishing them from moth scales. The findings, published in Nature Communications, suggest that butterflies emerged earlier than previously thought, perhaps as early as 200 million years ago during the Triassic period. "This makes our butterflies the oldest modern butterflies ever found," said study lead author Dr. André Nel of the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology in Japan. The butterfly scales were found in fine-grained limestone rock that was once mud and silt at the bottom of a shallow ocean. The limestone was deposited in what is now the Saar region in western Germany. Dr. Nel said that the discovery was "wonderful and very exciting" and added that the butterflies would have been tiny, about the size of a hummingbird. “We see an incredible diversity of butterflies in the Triassic,” he said, adding: “It means that as soon as butterflies appear, they show a rather large amount of anatomical variation." The researchers say that the butterfly scales, with their display of fine features that are diagnostic for butterfly scales, are unlikely to be mistaken for those of any other insect group. They conclude that butterflies probably went through an explosive evolutionary episode in the middle of the Triassic. The team now plans to look for butterfly fossils in other ancient rocks. They hope to find preserved adult butterfly fossils, which would give a better idea of how these creatures looked 200 million years ago.

title: Guildford Four's Gerry Conlon: Funeral takes place in Belfast
text: His coffin was carried into St Peter's Cathedral in west Belfast by four members of the Birmingham Six. Mr Conlon, who was wrongly convicted of the IRA pub bombings in 1974, died on 21 June aged 60. Among the mourners at the funeral were Mr Conlon's sisters, Anne and Kate, and his brother, Michael. His wife, Sarah, died in 2008. The service was led by Bishop Noel Treanor, who said Mr Conlon was "a man of courage, resilience and dignity". "He was an innocent man who was never broken by the injustice he suffered," the bishop said. "He never gave up hope that one day he would be free and cleared of the terrible crimes he was falsely accused of." The service was followed by a private burial at Milltown Cemetery. Mr Conlon's wrongful conviction was one of the most high-profile miscarriages of justice in British legal history. He was sentenced to life in prison in 1975, along with five other men who became known as the Guildford Four. The four were convicted of carrying out the IRA pub bombings in Guildford and Woolwich in 1974, which killed five people and injured many others. However, their convictions were overturned in 1989 after it emerged that police had fabricated evidence against them. Mr Conlon spent 15 years in prison before he was finally released. He went on to campaign for justice for other victims of miscarriages of justice. In 2001, he was awarded £5m in compensation for his wrongful conviction. In a statement released after his death, Mr Conlon's family said he had been "a loving husband, father, brother and uncle". "He was a man of great integrity and courage, who never gave up fighting for justice," the statement said. "He will be deeply missed by all who knew him."

title: EU-student funding guarantee extended
text: By Katherine Sellgren BBC News education reporter And these students' loans and grants will be available for the duration of their degree. This is because the Department for Education has extended its funding guarantee for EU students, who started courses in England in autumn 2021, until they complete their studies. The guarantee means that these students will continue to be eligible for the same level of support as UK students, including access to student loans, grants and scholarships. This is a significant change from previous years, when EU students were only eligible for student loans for the first year of their studies. The extension of the funding guarantee is a welcome relief for many EU students, who were facing uncertainty about their future funding. One of those students is 22-year-old Eva from Spain, who is studying medicine at the University of Manchester. "I was so worried about how I was going to afford to continue my studies after the first year," she says. "But now I know that I will be able to complete my degree, thanks to this funding guarantee." The funding guarantee is also a positive step for the UK higher education sector, which relies on EU students for a significant proportion of its income. In the 2020-21 academic year, there were over 140,000 EU students studying in the UK. These students contributed £2.6bn to the UK economy, according to Universities UK. The extension of the funding guarantee is a sign that the UK government is committed to supporting the higher education sector and ensuring that the UK remains an attractive destination for international students. However, some experts have warned that the funding guarantee could be undermined by the government's plans to introduce a new post-study work visa for international students. The new visa will allow international students to stay in the UK for two years after they graduate, to work or look for work. But it is not clear whether EU students will be eligible for the new visa, which could make it harder for them to remain in the UK after their studies. The government has said that it is still considering the eligibility criteria for the new visa, and that it will make an announcement in due course.

title: General Election: Loyalists warn unionists not to vote Alliance
text: By Mark Devenport BBC News NI Political Editor The Loyalist Communities Council (LCC) was launched in 2015. In a statement, it said that "any unionist who votes for the Alliance Party is driving a stake into the heart of unionism". The LCC is an umbrella group representing loyalist paramilitary organisations. It said that the Alliance Party "cannot be trusted" and that "they will never stand up for the interests of unionism". The LCC's statement comes after the Alliance Party made gains in the recent local government elections. The Alliance Party is a centrist party that does not identify as either unionist or nationalist. It is the largest party on Belfast City Council and the second-largest party in Northern Ireland. The LCC's warning to unionists not to vote for the Alliance Party is a sign of the growing tensions between unionists and centrists in Northern Ireland. Unionists believe that the Alliance Party is a threat to their goal of maintaining Northern Ireland's place within the United Kingdom. Centrists, on the other hand, believe that the Alliance Party is the only party that can build a shared future for everyone in Northern Ireland. The LCC's statement is likely to further alienate centrists from unionism. It is also likely to make it more difficult for the Alliance Party to make further gains in the next Assembly election. The Assembly election is due to be held in May 2022. The LCC's statement is a reminder of the deep divisions that still exist in Northern Ireland. It is also a warning that the peace process is still fragile and that there is still a long way to go before Northern Ireland can truly be at peace.

title: Runshaw college: Machete found after gang attack
text: The weapon was found by a police dog in a search after the disorder at Runshaw College in Leyland, Lancashire, on Monday. Six teenagers have been arrested on suspicion of violent disorder following the incident, in which a group of masked men entered the college grounds and attacked a 16-year-old boy. The machetes were not used in the attack, police said, but were found nearby. Det Insp Mark Haworth-Oates, of Lancashire Police, said: "This was a serious incident which has caused a great deal of concern in the community. "We are determined to bring those responsible to justice and I would appeal to anyone who has any information about the disorder to come forward." Runshaw College principal Annmarie Caunce said the college was working with police to investigate the incident. She said: "The safety and well-being of our students and staff is our top priority and we are doing everything we can to support those who have been affected by this incident." The college has increased security measures in the wake of the attack, including additional patrols by police and security guards. Students have also been advised to be vigilant and to report any suspicious activity to the college or police. The incident has shocked the local community and has raised concerns about the safety of students at the college. Leyland councillor Paul Foster said: "This is a very worrying incident and I am very concerned about the safety of students at the college. "I am calling on the police to do everything they can to catch those responsible and to bring them to justice." The college has said it is working with the police to investigate the incident and has increased security measures.

title: Covid-19: Northamptonshire moves to tier 3
text: The county, currently in tier two, will face the higher level of restrictions from 00:01 GMT on 26 December, the government has announced. People in tier three can form bubbles with another household on Christmas Day, but not stay overnight. They are also being urged not to travel to other parts of the UK unless it is for essential reasons. The move to tier three in Northamptonshire follows a rise in Covid-19 infections in recent weeks. The seven-day infection rate in the county is now 160.3 cases per 100,000 people, well above the England average of 127.5. The government said the decision to move Northamptonshire to tier three was made after taking into account a number of factors, including the number of cases, the rate of transmission, the number of hospital admissions and the capacity of the local NHS. The new restrictions in Northamptonshire will include: A ban on household mixing indoors, except for Christmas Day when one household can mix with one other household. A ban on meeting anyone outside your household in a private garden. A ban on meeting anyone outside your household in a public place, except for organised sports and exercise. A ban on travel between different parts of the UK, unless for essential reasons. The government said the restrictions would be reviewed every two weeks. Matt Golby, North Northamptonshire's council leader, said the move to tier three was "disappointing" but "understandable". "The decision was not taken lightly," he said. "The government have looked at the data and made the decision that they believe is necessary to protect the people of Northamptonshire." Mr Golby urged people in the county to follow the new restrictions and to get tested if they have symptoms. "We all need to play our part to get this virus under control," he said.

title: Gamer Hbomberguy hands funding row charity Donkey Kong boost
text: YouTuber Hbomberguy made £265,000 by playing Nintendo 64's Donkey Kong live online after a proposed lottery grant for Mermaids was put under review. Father Ted sitcom writer Graham Linehan had expressed concerns about Mermaids' approach to supporting transgender children. Mermaids later accused Linehan of spreading "anti-trans hate speech", and Linehan has faced calls to be banned from Twitter. Hbomberguy, a vocal supporter of transgender rights, began livestreaming the Donkey Kong marathon in response to these events. He aimed to raise £1,000 for Mermaids but quickly surpassed that target. "I usually just play games that I like and stream them. But this is a real situation that's impacting people's lives, and I wanted to do something to help," Hbomberguy told the BBC. "I'm not a charity, but I have a platform, and I can use that to raise awareness and funds for Mermaids." Hbomberguy's marathon lasted for over 57 hours, during which time he played Donkey Kong and responded to donations from viewers. The stream attracted over 500,000 viewers and raised a total of £265,000 for Mermaids. "I'm so grateful to Hbomberguy and everyone who donated to this fundraiser," said Susie Green, CEO of Mermaids. "This money will make a huge difference to our work supporting transgender children and their families." The fundraiser has been praised by many in the gaming community, who have hailed Hbomberguy as a hero. However, some have criticized the fundraiser, arguing that it is unfair to target Linehan for his views. "I think it's important to remember that Graham Linehan has the right to his opinion, even if we don't agree with it," said one Twitter user. "This fundraiser is a form of harassment and it's not right." Despite these criticisms, Hbomberguy's fundraiser has been a huge success. It has raised a significant amount of money for Mermaids and has helped to raise awareness of the issue of transgender rights.

title: Olympic Games £500k steam cloud artwork in Wirral delayed
text: The £500,000 publicly funded spinning column of cloud was set to rise over the Wirral estuary from 31 December as part of the UNBOXED: Creativity in the UK project. However, strong winds have forced the postponement of the artwork by Liverpool-based artist,  Anthony McCall. The 200m-high column, titled Between the Ear and the Eye, will now take place at an alternative location on Thurstaton Common from 27-30 January. The relocation is due to safety concerns as high winds can affect the stability of the column. The 10-minute artwork is part of the UNBOXED: Creativity in the UK project, which is a government-funded initiative to bring large scale, free public artworks to towns and cities across the UK as part of the 2022 Festival. The artwork is meant to evoke the iconic image of the Olympic rings and will be visible from across the Mersey estuary. It will be made up of a series of spinning clouds of steam, creating a dynamic and ever-changing sculpture in the sky. The artist said: "This new outdoor artwork is conceived specifically for the Wirral peninsula, Liverpool City Region and its communities. Through the transformative properties of steam, Between the Ear and the Eye, taps into our shared histories of invention, industry and migration in this area, while also looking towards the future. "As you view the artwork from different vantage points, it presents multiple shifting and dynamic perspectives which both connect and divide the viewer from the work, and from each other." The cloud column will be visible from the Wirral side of the estuary, as well as from Liverpool and parts of North Wales. It will be accompanied by a soundscape composed by Matthew Herbert. The artist,  Anthony McCall, is known for his pioneering work with film and installation. His work has been exhibited in major galleries around the world, including the Tate Modern in London and the Museum of Modern Art in New York. The UNBOXED: Creativity in the UK project is a government-funded initiative to bring large scale, free public artworks to towns and cities across the UK as part of the 2022 Festival. The project is supported by the National Lottery Heritage Fund and Arts Council England.

title: Not guilty plea in landmark Kodi box trial
text: By Jane Wakefield Technology reporter Mr Thompson is accused of selling "fully loaded" Kodi boxes, modified with software that allowed users to stream copyrighted content for free. The prosecution claims the boxes are illegal because they bypass copyright protections. But Mr Thompson's lawyer argued that the boxes are not illegal because they do not contain any copyrighted content themselves. He said users are responsible for what they stream on the boxes. The jury has been told that Mr Thompson sold more than 100,000 Kodi boxes. The trial is expected to last two weeks. Kodi is a free and open-source media player software application developed by the XBMC Foundation. It allows users to play videos, music, and other digital media on a variety of devices. Kodi can be installed on computers, smartphones, tablets, and other devices. It is compatible with a wide range of file formats, including AVI, MP4, MKV, and WMV. Kodi can also be used to stream live TV and radio. In 2015, the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) filed a lawsuit against the XBMC Foundation, alleging that Kodi was being used to facilitate copyright infringement. The MPAA argued that Kodi was being used to stream pirated movies and TV shows. The XBMC Foundation denies these allegations and argues that Kodi is a legitimate software application that can be used for a variety of purposes. The lawsuit is still pending. The trial of Mr Thompson is the first of its kind in the UK. It is unclear whether the outcome of the trial will have any impact on the use of Kodi in the UK. However, the trial is sure to raise awareness of the issue of copyright infringement and the role of Kodi in this issue.

title: Surrey Police investigation over 'misgendering' tweets
text: Caroline Farrow said Surrey Police wants to "conduct a taped interview under caution" because of tweets posted in October. They were made after she was accused of misgendering a transgender woman in a previous tweet. In the October tweets, Ms Farrow said she was responding to "what she believed was a series of tweets by a man", who had previously been protected by an interim Gender Recognition Certificate (GRC). The tweets that prompted the police investigation cannot be published for legal reasons. GRCs were introduced under the Gender Recognition Act 2004 and allow transgender people to change their legal gender. However, Ms Farrow has previously argued that the 2004 Act allows "male-bodied people to self-identify into the female sex and access women-only spaces, resources and opportunities." Following the complaint about her October tweets, Surrey Police confirmed that the case was being investigated and a file had been sent to the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS). The CPS subsequently decided not to press charges against Ms Farrow. Mark Burns-Williamson, the Police and Crime Commissioner for Surrey, said the decision not to prosecute was "wholly unsatisfactory". He said the force had "tried to do the right thing" and had acted in "good faith". Surrey Police referred questions on its current investigation to the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC). The IOPC said it was "assessing the available information to determine what further action may be required." Ms Farrow, a former magistrate and journalist, stood unsuccessfully for the Brexit Party in the 2019 General Election. She has previously been a vocal critic of the Gender Recognition Act and has said she believes it "undermines" the rights of women. In a statement, she said she was "appalled" by the police investigation and accused Surrey Police of "trying to silence" her. "I am a law-abiding citizen and I have done nothing wrong," she said. "The police are wasting their time and resources on this investigation when they should be focusing on real crimes." The investigation is the latest in a series of cases involving police investigations into alleged "hate speech" online. In 2020, a man was arrested for "inciting hatred" after he posted a tweet that was critical of transgender people. The case was later dropped, but it raised concerns about the potential for freedom of speech to be curtailed in the name of protecting minority groups.

title: Wife of 39 years fails in divorce refusal appeal
text: Tini Owens, 66, asked the Court of Appeal to overturn a family court ruling, which said she could not divorce her husband Hugh Owens, 78. But the appeal judges, led by Sir Geoffrey Vos, unanimously dismissed her challenge. They said the original judge had been right to conclude that the marriage had not irretrievably broken down and that it was possible for the couple to reconcile. Mrs Owens had argued that she could not reasonably be expected to live with her husband after 40 years of marriage, during which time she had been subjected to “coercive and controlling” behavior. She said Mr Owens had isolated her from her friends and family, had stopped her from working, and had made her feel like a “prisoner” in her own home. But the Court of Appeal judges said that Mrs Owens had not provided sufficient evidence to support her claims. They said that she had only made general allegations of controlling behavior and had not provided any specific examples. They also said that Mrs Owens had not shown that she had taken any steps to try to improve the situation, such as seeking help from a therapist or counselor. The judges said that it was clear that the couple had some difficulties in their relationship, but they said that these difficulties were not so serious that the marriage had irretrievably broken down. They said that it was possible for the couple to reconcile if they were willing to work on their relationship and seek help from a therapist or counselor. The judges also said that they were taking into account the fact that the couple had been married for a long time and had built up a life together. They said that it would be wrong to end the marriage without giving the couple a chance to try to reconcile. Mrs Owens said she was “disappointed” with the Court of Appeal's decision. She said she was determined to divorce her husband and would continue to fight for her freedom.

title: North Korea: Mike Pompeo rejects 'gangster-like' accusation
text: After two days of talks with senior officials, he said efforts to push Pyongyang towards abandoning nuclear weapons had international support. His comments were released in a statement, after Mr Pompeo left North Korea. "As we work to implement the commitments from the Singapore summit, the US is committed, along with our allies in the region, to a brighter future for the Korean people on the Korean Peninsula," he said. "North Korea made clear to us that they understand the need to denuclearize," he added. "We look forward to continuing these discussions in Singapore on 12th June." However, analysts said that despite the talks, North Korea has not made any concrete commitment to scrap its nuclear arsenal. And some have said that the Trump administration is being too eager to trust Pyongyang's promises. Mr Pompeo's comments also come just two days after North Korean leader Kim Jong-un threatened to pull out of his planned summit with US President Donald Trump in Singapore next month. Mr Kim said he would not attend if the US tried to force him to give up his nuclear weapons. In response, Mr Trump said he was still confident that the summit would go ahead. He has also warned that he is ready to scrap the summit if he doesn't believe North Korea is serious about denuclearisation. The Singapore summit is the first ever meeting between a sitting US president and a North Korean leader. It is the culmination of months of diplomatic efforts to bring the two sides to the negotiating table. However, there are still many obstacles to overcome, including the issue of nuclear weapons. North Korea has been developing nuclear weapons and missiles since the 1990s. It is thought to have up to 60 nuclear warheads, and is developing intercontinental ballistic missiles that could reach the US. The US has long considered North Korea's nuclear programme to be a threat to its security. It has imposed tough sanctions on the country, and has threatened military action if necessary.

title: UN net meeting 'hit by hackers' causing website disruption
text: The World Conference on International Telecommunications (Wcit) is debating changes to a wide-ranging communications treaty. Delegates were unable to access material relating to the meeting after its website was forced offline. Hacker groups had claimed responsibility, organisers said. The UN's secretary general António Guterres addressed the summit on Monday from New York. He hailed the conference as a "historic opportunity" to establish a new era of global co-operation. "We are living in a world awash with new technologies, which are changing our lives in ways we could scarcely have imagined," he said. "But with these new technologies come new challenges, and new responsibilities." Mr Guterres said the summit was an opportunity to establish a "new global consensus" on how to use technology for the benefit of all. The website for the conference was taken offline on Tuesday, the second day of the meeting. A spokesperson for the organisers said the website had been targeted by a distributed denial of service (DDoS) attack. This type of attack involves flooding a website with so much traffic that it becomes inaccessible to users. A hacker group called Anonymous had claimed responsibility for the attack. The group said it was protesting against the proposed changes to the treaty, which it said would give governments too much control over the internet. The treaty in question is known as the International Telecommunication Regulations (ITRs). It has been in place since 1988 and sets out the rules for how telecommunications networks are managed and operated. The proposed changes to the treaty would give governments more power to regulate the internet. This has raised concerns among some human rights groups, who say it could be used to censor online content. The World Conference on International Telecommunications is taking place in Dubai and is due to end on 16 December.

title: Head and neck cancer drug 'game changer'
text: Trial results coming out of a US cancer conference suggest the treatment works better than standard chemotherapy. Nivolumab significantly improved the survival odds of patients with these hard-to-treat tumours. Head and neck cancer is the sixth most common cancer worldwide, and in the UK there are around 12,000 new cases every year. The majority of patients are diagnosed with advanced disease, and, until now, their prognosis has been very poor. Nivolumab is an immunotherapy drug and works by blocking a protein on the surface of immune cells called PD-1. This allows the immune system to recognise and attack the cancer cells. The CheckMate 141 trial involved nearly 400 patients with advanced head and neck cancer and compared nivolumab with standard chemotherapy. After a year, 36% of those treated with nivolumab were still alive, compared with 17% of those who received chemotherapy. Median overall survival improved from 10.7 months to 14.3 months. The treatment was also found to significantly reduce the risk of the disease progressing, or recurring. Dr Ursula Nestle, lead author, said: "This is a practice-changing study because it is the first to show a significant improvement in overall survival for these hard-to-treat head and neck cancer patients." Dr Nishant Agrawal, a consultant clinical oncologist at the Christie Hospital in Manchester, said: "This is a game-changer. It changes the management and the approach to patients with head and neck cancer." He said the treatment was particularly promising for those who are not able to receive standard treatments such as surgery, radiotherapy or chemotherapy. "These are patients who are in pain, bleeding, and who have difficulty with eating and drinking," he said. The results of the study were presented at the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) annual meeting in Chicago. Nivolumab has not yet been approved by the UK's National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE), but Dr Nestle said she hoped this would change in the light of the new findings. She added: "I don't think it will take long. The data are very compelling."

title: Brexit: Further clashes over work on NI port controls
text: In July, the UK government announced that it would delay the introduction of full checks on goods coming into Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK until October. The EU has said that it is willing to discuss changes to the protocol, but only within the limits of the existing agreement. The latest row comes after the UK government published a command paper setting out its plans for implementing the protocol. The paper said that the UK would introduce a "grace period" for checks on goods coming into Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK, and that it would not implement checks on goods moving from Northern Ireland to the Republic of Ireland. The EU has said that the UK's plans are not compatible with the protocol, and that it will take legal action if the UK does not implement the protocol in full. The UK government has said that it is committed to implementing the protocol, but that it needs to do so in a way that protects the Good Friday Agreement. The Good Friday Agreement is a peace agreement that was signed in 1998 and ended the Troubles in Northern Ireland. The row over the protocol is the latest in a series of disputes between the UK and the EU over Brexit. The UK left the EU on 31 January 2020, and the two sides are still negotiating a trade agreement. The dispute over the protocol has raised concerns about the future of the Good Friday Agreement. The agreement is based on the principle of cross-border cooperation between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, and some fear that the protocol could undermine this cooperation. The UK government has said that it is committed to the Good Friday Agreement, and that it will not do anything that could put it at risk. However, the EU has said that the UK's plans for implementing the protocol are not compatible with the agreement. The dispute over the protocol is a complex and difficult issue, and it is unclear how it will be resolved. However, it is clear that the issue has the potential to damage relations between the UK and the EU, and to undermine the Good Friday Agreement.

title: Zika virus: 'Strongest evidence yet' of effect on babies
text: Dr Tom Frieden, head of the Center for Disease Control (CDC), was testifying before politicians in Washington. He said that data from the cases of two infants in Brazil showed "the strongest evidence yet" that the Zika virus can cause brain damage in babies. The babies were born in Brazil and had severe brain defects. Their mothers had been infected with the Zika virus during pregnancy. Dr Frieden said that the data "adds to the growing body of evidence that Zika virus infection during pregnancy is a cause of brain defects." He said that the CDC is now recommending that pregnant women consider not traveling to areas where Zika virus is spreading. The CDC has also issued a travel warning for pregnant women to avoid areas where Zika virus is spreading. The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared a public health emergency of international concern over the Zika virus. The virus is spread by the Aedes mosquito, which is also responsible for transmitting dengue fever and chikungunya. There is no vaccine or treatment for Zika virus. The best way to prevent infection is to avoid mosquito bites. Pregnant women should take extra precautions to avoid mosquito bites, such as wearing long sleeves and pants, using insect repellent, and staying in air-conditioned areas. If a pregnant woman is infected with the Zika virus, she should see her doctor immediately. The Zika virus can also be transmitted through sexual contact. Men who have traveled to areas where Zika virus is spreading should use condoms during sex with their pregnant partners. The Zika virus is a serious threat to pregnant women and their unborn babies. It is important to take steps to prevent infection and to seek medical care if you are infected.
