title: HS2 underground protest: Activists 'being forced out' of tunnel
text: HS2 Rebellion, who are camped out at Euston Square Gardens, say the team is burrowing a vertical tunnel causing crumbs of earth to fall onto their camp. They say the noise and dust is making it very difficult to stay and that they are concerned about their safety. HS2 Ltd said it was aware of the concerns and that it was taking steps to minimise the impact of the work on the protesters. It said a "dialogue" was ongoing. The protesters have been camped out in the gardens since the end of August, in protest at the HS2 high-speed rail line. They say the line will cause environmental damage and that the government should be investing in public transport instead. In recent weeks, the protesters have been joined by Extinction Rebellion activists, who have been blocking roads and bridges in London in protest at the government's climate change policies. The HS2 project has been beset by delays and cost overruns. It was originally due to open in 2026, but is now not expected to be completed until 2034. The cost of the project has also risen from £56bn to £106bn. The government has said that HS2 is a vital infrastructure project that will boost the economy and create jobs. However, critics say that the project is too expensive and that the money would be better spent on other projects. The protests against HS2 have been ongoing for several years. In 2019, activists staged a series of demonstrations, including blocking the M4 motorway. In 2020, activists occupied a construction site in Buckinghamshire. The protests have led to a number of arrests and convictions. In 2020, nine activists were jailed for contempt of court after they refused to leave the construction site in Buckinghamshire. The government has said that it respects the right to protest, but that it will not tolerate illegal activity. It has also said that it is committed to HS2 and that the project will go ahead. The protests are likely to continue until the HS2 line is completed. The activists say they are determined to stop the project and that they will not give up until they have succeeded.

title: Bishop Peter Ball victim withdraws from church abuse review
text: Peter Ball, 84, was jailed in October for offences against 18 teenagers and young men in the 1970s, 80s and 90s. One of his victims, Rev Graham Sawyer, said he had taken the decision "with great sadness" after his requests for a role in shaping the review were rejected. "I believe in Jesus and I love his church, but I can no longer be part of this particular institution," Sawyer said in a statement released by his lawyer. The Church of England announced last month that it would be holding an independent review into safeguarding failures that allowed Ball's abuse to continue undetected for decades. The review, to be led by retired High Court judge Sir David Calvert-Smith, will examine how the church responded to allegations against Ball and whether there were any systemic failings that allowed him to continue in his role. Sawyer said he had been "deeply disappointed" by the church's response to his request to be involved in the review. "I had hoped that my experience and insights as a survivor of abuse within the church would be of value to the review," he said. "However, it has become clear that the church is not willing to listen to the voices of survivors. This is a betrayal of trust and a missed opportunity to learn from the mistakes of the past." The Church of England said it understood Sawyer's decision and that it remained committed to listening to the voices of survivors. "We deeply regret the pain and suffering that Graham Sawyer has experienced," a spokesperson said. "We understand his decision to withdraw from the review and we will continue to work to ensure that the review is as comprehensive and independent as possible." Ball was the Bishop of Lewes from 1977 to 1992 and the Bishop of Gloucester from 1992 to 2001. He was convicted of sexually abusing 18 teenagers and young men over a period of 20 years. His victims included young men who had been invited to stay at his home in Chichester and students at the theological college where he taught. Ball was sentenced to 32 months in prison in October 2015. He was released from prison in February 2017 after serving half of his sentence.

title: Gareth Bayliss presents debut exhibition at Ipswich Art School
text: Richard Haugh BBC News Bayliss, 35, studied at Ipswich Art School, which is now a gallery, before providing designs for clients including Dizzee Rascal, Mo Wax, Stussy and Habitat. Bayliss, who also teaches at Norwich University's College of Arts and Media, said he was excited to exhibit his artwork in the place where his creative journey began. "It feels absolutely amazing to be able to showcase my work in this space. Coming back to the place where I studied, which has such a special place in my heart, and being able to share my creations with the people here is an honour," he said. The exhibition, titled "Gareth Bayliss: Deconstructed," features a range of Bayliss's signature abstract works, known for their vibrant colours, bold shapes and intricate patterns. Bayliss draws inspiration from a variety of sources, including nature, music and personal experiences, which he then transforms into visually striking compositions. "My work is all about expressing myself through colour and form. I want to create pieces that are visually stimulating and emotionally engaging for the viewer," he said. "I'm particularly interested in the relationship between colour and shape, and how different combinations can evoke different feelings and sensations." Bayliss's work has been featured in numerous exhibitions and publications, and he has collaborated with a diverse range of artists and musicians. He is known for his innovative and experimental approach, and his work continues to push the boundaries of abstract art. The exhibition at Ipswich Art School is free to attend and will run until 26th March 2023. It is a rare opportunity to see Bayliss's work in person and gain insights into his creative process.

title: Alstom: GE and French state agree to work on new offer
text: France's economy minister Arnaud Montebourg said that neither the GE bid, nor a joint Siemens-Mitsubishi Heavy Industries offer, met the government's demands. But the government had been presented with a new offer from GE and Alstom that he said provided "real guarantees". Montebourg said the government would now enter into exclusive negotiations with GE and Alstom, and that he hoped a final deal could be reached by the end of July. GE's initial offer for Alstom was worth €12.35bn (£10bn), while Siemens and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries had offered €11.6bn. GE has since increased its offer to €12.4bn, but it is unclear whether this will be enough to satisfy the French government. The French government is keen to protect Alstom's independence, and has said it will not approve any deal that would see the company lose its status as a French champion. GE has said it is committed to maintaining Alstom's headquarters in France and its research and development centre in Belfort. However, the government is also concerned about the impact of the deal on employment. GE has said it will cut 6,500 jobs at Alstom, but the government wants to ensure that these cuts are limited to the company's overseas operations. The government is also concerned about the impact of the deal on Alstom's technology. GE has said it will invest €1bn in Alstom's research and development, but the government wants to ensure that this investment is used to develop new technologies in France. The negotiations between GE and the French government are expected to be tough, but both sides are keen to reach an agreement. GE needs Alstom to expand its presence in the global energy market, while the French government needs GE to invest in Alstom's technology and protect its independence. If a deal can be reached, it would be a major coup for GE and a major blow to Siemens. It would also be a significant victory for the French government, which has been determined to protect Alstom's independence.

title: Covid: New lockdown needed, say Yorkshire leaders
text: Schools in England have shut to most pupils and people have been asked to stay at home under tighter rules. Dan Jarvis, Mayor of Sheffield City Region, said: "We believe that a short, sharp, national lockdown is now necessary to prevent the NHS from being overwhelmed and to save lives." He said that the current restrictions were not enough to stop the spread of the virus, and that a "circuit break" was needed to give the NHS time to recover. "We know that a lockdown will be difficult for many people, but we believe it is the right thing to do to protect our communities," he said. The call for a lockdown has been echoed by other leaders in the region, including the Mayor of West Yorkshire, Tracy Brabin. She said: "We are facing a very serious situation in Yorkshire and the Humber. The number of cases is rising rapidly and our hospitals are coming under increasing pressure. "We need to take urgent action to prevent our NHS from being overwhelmed. A short, sharp lockdown is the best way to do this." The leaders have written to the Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, asking him to impose a national lockdown. A spokesperson for the government said that the Prime Minister was "keeping all options on the table" but that he was not currently planning to impose a national lockdown. However, the government has announced a number of new measures to try to slow the spread of the virus, including: Closing schools to most pupils Asking people to stay at home Banning gatherings of more than six people Making it compulsory to wear face coverings in shops and on public transport The government has also said that it will provide financial support to businesses that are affected by the new restrictions. The new measures have been welcomed by some, but others have expressed concern about the impact they will have on the economy and on people's mental health. It is not yet clear whether the new measures will be enough to stop the spread of the virus, and it is possible that the government will be forced to impose a national lockdown in the future.

title: Bloodhound takes first drive across the desert
text: By Jonathan Amos BBC Science Correspondent Pilot Andy Green took the jet-powered vehicle on a gentle 100mph (160km/h) shakedown test run on Friday. Bloodhound is in Northern Cape for high-speed trials as it works towards a world land speed record attempt of 1,000mph (1,600km/h) in 2023. Friday's run began with engineers simulating the conditions the car will experience when it's flat out at Mach 1.4. The team fired the rocket that will eventually provide most of the vehicle's thrust, but kept the rocket's throttle low to limit speeds. The vehicle then drove for 5km along a straight section of the 12-mile (19km) Hakskeen Pan track. It will now stay on the surface to have its data systems checked over the next 10 days. The Bloodhound car has been in development since 2008. Originally, the team behind the project hoped to break the 1,000mph barrier in 2015. But the effort has been beset by funding and technical setbacks. Bloodhound's shakedown run on Friday was conducted without driver Andy Green onboard. The aim of the exercise was to test the vehicle's systems, including its rocket and its parachute recovery system. Green will take the wheel for the first time on Monday. He will drive the car at progressively higher speeds, culminating in a 200mph (320km/h) run on Friday of next week. "This is a fantastic moment for the team and a real milestone in the project," said Green. "We're now one step closer to our goal of setting a new world land speed record." The Bloodhound project is a privately funded venture that aims to push the boundaries of engineering and to inspire the next generation of scientists and engineers. If successful, Bloodhound will become the first vehicle to break the 1,000mph barrier on land. The current record of 763mph (1,228km/h) was set by ThrustSSC in 1997.

title: Farm profits may halve after Brexit, says report
text: The report, by the Agriculture & Horticulture Development Board (AHDB), says the "worst-case scenario" would cut average farm profits from £38,000 a year to just £18,000. The AHDB says this is because farmers will lose access to the EU's single market, which allows them to sell their products tariff-free. This will make it more expensive for them to export to the EU, which is their biggest market. The report also warns that farmers will face new costs from having to comply with new regulations and tariffs, which will further reduce their profits. The AHDB's report is based on a survey of 1,000 farmers. The survey found that 80% of farmers are concerned about the impact of Brexit on their businesses. The report has been welcomed by farming organisations, who say it highlights the need for the government to support farmers through Brexit. The National Farmers' Union (NFU) said the report was a "wake-up call" for the government. The NFU said the government needs to provide financial support to farmers and help them to prepare for Brexit. The government has said it is committed to supporting farmers through Brexit. The government has announced a £3 billion package of support for farmers, which includes funding for research and development, and grants to help farmers invest in new equipment. However, the NFU said the government's support package was not enough and that more needs to be done. The NFU said the government needs to do more to help farmers prepare for the new regulations and tariffs that will come into force after Brexit. The government has said it is working with farmers to help them prepare for Brexit. The government has set up a task force to help farmers with the new regulations and tariffs. The government has also said it is committed to maintaining the UK's high food safety and environmental standards after Brexit. The government has said it will not lower food standards in order to secure a trade deal with the EU. However, the NFU said the government needs to do more to reassure farmers that they will not be left behind after Brexit. The NFU said the government needs to provide more certainty about the future of farming and provide more support to farmers.

title: Covid: Will Margaret Ferrier remain an MP after breaking rules?
text: And the SNP has said if she does not stand down, the party will seek to have her expelled from the House of Commons. Ms Ferrier has said she is "deeply sorry" for her actions and has apologised to the people of Rutherglen and Hamilton West. She has also said that she will "co-operate fully" with the police investigation. The Metropolitan Police has said that it is investigating a "potential offence" under the Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) Regulations 2020. The regulations make it an offence for anyone to know that they have the virus and leave their home, or fail to self-isolate if they have been instructed to do so by a public health official. The maximum penalty for breaching the regulations is a £10,000 fine. Ms Ferrier is the first MP to be accused of breaking the coronavirus regulations. The case has raised questions about whether MPs should be subject to the same rules as everyone else. Some people have argued that MPs should be held to a higher standard, as they are public figures. Others have said that MPs should be treated the same as everyone else, and that it is up to the police to decide whether or not to investigate. The case is also likely to put pressure on the government to review the current coronavirus regulations. Some people have argued that the regulations are too strict and that they are having a disproportionate impact on people's lives. Others have said that the regulations are necessary to protect public health. The government has said that it is keeping the regulations under review and that it will make changes if necessary.

title: UKIP make their mark in Scotland
text: Brian Taylor Political editor, Scotland So, quite deliberately, I grabbed the chance today to offer my congratulations to each of Scotland's elected MEPs among the throng gathered in Edinburgh City Chambers for the final declaration. And commiseration. After an election which, in many ways, was a bit of a damp squib, there was a palpable sense of anti-climax as the formal announcement was made of the 6 MEPs elected to represent Scotland in the European Parliament. Only 35% of the electorate voted. That's a record low. And, as a consequence, Nigel Farage's UKIP now has its first MEPs in Scotland. Two of them - David Coburn and David McHugh. UKIP deputy leader Paul Nuttall believes this is the start of something big north of the border. "This is the thin end of the wedge. We know from our polls, from our membership numbers, this thing is growing and growing. And that's what people need to be aware of." There was, of course, no formal election night celebration planned by UKIP in Scotland last night. But at a city centre bar, there was a gathering of supporters and elected representatives - including Mr Coburn. In an interview with me, he said the election of two UKIP MEPs to Strasbourg was: "A kick in the teeth for the establishment." "It proves that the status quo is not good enough," he said. "People want change and they want it now." So what of the other parties? Labour remain Scotland's largest party in the parliament, despite losing one of their previous three seats. Their leader, Richard Leonard, was keen to point out that his party secured nearly twice as many votes as UKIP. "We topped the poll in Scotland, the Labour Party. And I'm very proud of that." The SNP also lost one of their previous two seats. They now have two MEPs, including 19-year-old Alyn Smith, the youngest politician ever to be elected to the European Parliament. He said the SNP's "positive" and "optimistic" message was what attracted voters to their party. "We showed that, even in this referendum Parliament, that we are the most positive, optimistic party in Scotland." Ruth Davidson's Conservatives secured one seat and there was also one seat for the Liberal Democrats. Catherine Stihler topped the poll for her party, just as she did 5 years ago. She said the result was "a difficult night" for her party across the UK but she was pleased to win a seat for the Lib Dems in Scotland. So, UKIP has made its mark in Scotland, albeit on a relatively low turnout. The challenge for the party now is to build on what they have achieved and become a more significant player on the Scottish political stage. As for the other parties, they will be looking to the future and with the next Scottish parliament election in 2 years, they will need to ensure they are ready to challenge the SNP's dominance of Scottish politics.

title: Zero waste society plans for Scotland unveiled
text: Environment Secretary Richard Lochhead said it was time to tackle nearly 20m tonnes of waste currently produced by Scotland every year. The zero waste plan includes: A ban on sending biodegradable waste to landfill by 2021. A 70% recycling target by 2025. A deposit return scheme for drinks containers. A ban on microbeads in cosmetics. The Scottish Government will also invest £70m in new recycling infrastructure. The plans have been welcomed by environmental groups. "This is a bold and ambitious plan that has the potential to make Scotland a world leader in waste reduction," said Dr Richard Dixon, director of Friends of the Earth Scotland. "The Scottish Government has listened to the public and is taking action to tackle the growing problem of waste." The Scottish Conservatives have also welcomed the plans, but have called for the government to go further. "We need to see more detail on how these plans will be implemented and funded," said Murdo Fraser, the party's environment spokesman. "We also need to see a stronger focus on reducing waste at source." Zero waste is a term used to describe a society that produces little or no waste. This can be achieved through a combination of measures, such as: Reducing consumption. Reusing items. Recycling materials. Composting organic waste. Zero waste societies are often more sustainable than traditional societies, as they reduce the amount of pollution and greenhouse gases produced. They can also be more resilient, as they are less reliant on finite resources. The Scottish Government's zero waste plan is a significant step towards creating a more sustainable Scotland. If successful, it will help to reduce the country's environmental impact and create a more resilient society.

title: Views sought on new ideas to further regenerate Cardiff
text: Replacing the current St David's Dewi Sant shopping centre with new office, retail and leisure space, and demolishing the NCP car park and Capitol Shopping Centre for a new residential, workspace, hotel and leisure hub are among the suggested projects. The proposals have been outlined in a consultation which splits the city into five areas for different types of development. The Central Cardiff area covers the city centre and Cardiff Bay. Replacing the current St David's Dewi Sant shopping centre with new office, retail and leisure space, and demolishing the NCP car park and Capitol Shopping Centre for a new residential, workspace, hotel and leisure hub are among the suggested projects. The Inner Cardiff area includes Butetown, Riverside and Pontcanna. It proposes a mix of residential, commercial, educational and cultural uses to "intensify and diversify the offer". The East Cardiff area covers Splott, Tremorfa and Adamsdown. The proposals here focus on "enhancing and improving local services" by delivering new homes, employment and leisure opportunities. The North Cardiff area includes Cathays, Roath and Gabalfa. The council wants to create a "vibrant health innovation district" around Cardiff University's new £300m innovation campus at the former Cardiff Royal Infirmary. The West Cardiff area covers Grangetown, Riverside and Cardiff Bay. The proposals include the potential for new homes, a new school and improvements to public spaces. The council said the new ideas would "build on the momentum" of recent regeneration projects in the city, including the Central Square development, the redevelopment of Cardiff Market and the opening of the new Cardiff Bus Interchange. It added that the plans would help to "create a more vibrant, sustainable and inclusive city" and would "support the city's economy and create jobs". The consultation is open until 12 December. Cllr Russell Goodway, Cardiff council's cabinet member for investment and development, said: "We are committed to making Cardiff a better place to live, work and visit. "These proposals are ambitious, but they are also achievable. We believe that by working together with our partners and the people of Cardiff, we can create a city that we can all be proud of." The consultation can be viewed online at www.cardiff.gov.uk/regeneration

title: Kashmir uproar over Afzal Guru clemency plea
text: By Mehboob Khan BBC News A resolution had been tabled on the case of Afzal Guru, who was convicted over the 2001 India parliament attack. Sheikh said that "the real culprits behind the attack are still at large," suggesting that the supreme court had "hastened" Guru's execution three years ago and that the Afzal Guru family had been "denied justice." The government in New Delhi has not commented on the resolution, but the speaker of the state assembly, Kavinder Gupta, adjourned the proceedings until next week. Guru was sentenced to death in 2002 for his role in the attack on India's parliament in 2001. He was hanged in Delhi's Tihar jail in February 2013, aged 43. Guru's family and supporters long maintained that the trial was unfair and that he was made a scapegoat. They argue that Afzal Guru was not present at the time of the attack and that the evidence against him was fabricated . The resolution in the Jammu and Kashmir assembly is the latest sign of growing support for Guru's family and campaigners who believe he was wrongly executed. The attack on the Indian parliament on 13 December 2001 left 14 people dead, including five attackers. The attack was blamed on Pakistan-based militant group Jaish-e-Mohammed. India and Pakistan have fought three wars since independence in 1947, two of them over Kashmir. The neighbours have been locked in a bitter territorial dispute over the Himalayan region since then. Pakistan denies any involvement in the parliament attack, but India says it has "incontrovertible evidence" of Islamabad's involvement. The resolution in the Jammu and Kashmir assembly has been welcomed by the Hurriyat Conference, an umbrella group of separatist leaders in Kashmir. The conference said that the resolution "vindicates our stand that Afzal Guru was innocent and his execution was a travesty of justice. The resolution is also likely to raise tensions between India and Pakistan. India has already accused Pakistan of interfering in its internal affairs. The Indian government has said that it will not tolerate any interference in its internal affairs and that it will take all necessary steps to protect its sovereignty and integrity. The resolution in the Jammu and Kashmir assembly is a significant development. It is the first time that a state assembly in India has passed a resolution calling for the reopening of the Afzal Guru case.

title: Robin Gibb: Bee Gees singer's funeral held in Thame
text: Hundreds of fans lined the streets of Thame earlier as a lone bagpiper led a procession through the town. Gibb's body was carried in a horse-drawn carriage, followed by two Irish wolfhounds and guests, including his brother Barry and his son Adam. The service was held at St Mary's Church, where Gibb was a regular worshipper. It was a private ceremony, but fans were able to watch the procession and listen to the service on loudspeakers outside the church. Gibb's widow, Dwina, gave a reading during the service, and his son Robin-John performed a song. Gibb's brother Barry also spoke, paying tribute to his brother's "unique talent" and "warm heart." After the service, Gibb's body was taken to the town cemetery for a private burial. Gibb, who was 62, died on May 20 after a long battle with cancer. He was a member of the Bee Gees, one of the most successful pop groups of all time. The group sold over 200 million records worldwide and had a string of hits, including "Stayin' Alive," "How Deep Is Your Love," and "Night Fever." Gibb was born on the Isle of Man in 1949. He moved to Australia with his family when he was a child, and the Bee Gees were formed in 1958. The group moved to England in the early 1960s, and their career took off after they were discovered by Brian Epstein, the manager of the Beatles. The Bee Gees had their first major hit in 1967 with the song "Massachusetts." They went on to have a string of hits in the 1970s, including "Stayin' Alive," which was featured in the film "Saturday Night Fever." Gibb was also a successful solo artist. He released a number of albums, including "Robin's Reign" (1983) and "Secret Agent" (1984). Gibb was diagnosed with cancer in 2010. He underwent treatment, but the cancer returned in 2012. Gibb died on May 20, 2012, at the age of 62. Gibb was a talented singer, songwriter, and musician. He was a member of one of the most successful pop groups of all time. He will be remembered for his music and his warm heart.

title: More than one in 10 providing unpaid care
text: Figures from 2011 show that the largest increase was in unpaid carers working for 50 or more hours a week. Their numbers rose by 14% to more than 500,000, accounting for 14% of all unpaid carers. The number of people providing unpaid care for more than 20 hours a week also increased - up by 200,000 since 2001 to 2.1 million. Those providing unpaid care for more than 50 hours a week were more likely to be female (64%), and the majority were aged between 45 and 64. The increase in the number of people providing unpaid care is thought to be due to a number of factors, including the growing number of older people, and the increasing prevalence of long-term conditions such as dementia. The unpaid care provided by these individuals is essential to the UK economy, saving the government billions of pounds each year. However, it can also have a significant impact on the health and well-being of carers. Those providing unpaid care are more likely to experience physical health problems, mental health problems, and financial difficulties. They are also more likely to give up work or reduce their working hours, which can lead to a loss of income and career progression. The government has been criticized for not doing enough to support unpaid carers. There have been calls for increased financial support, more respite care and better access to health and social care services. In 2016, the government announced a new Carers' Allowance of £62.70 a week for those providing unpaid care for at least 35 hours a week. However, this is only available to those who are not in receipt of certain other benefits, and it is not enough to cover the costs of caring for someone full-time. There are a number of organizations that provide support and advice to unpaid carers, including Carers UK, Age UK, and the Alzheimer's Society. These organizations can provide information about benefits, respite care, and other services available to carers. They can also offer emotional support and practical help, such as organizing support groups and providing training for carers.

title: Stormont deal: what are thorny issues for NI politicians?
text: Stormont deal: what are thorny issues for NI politicians? By John Campbell BBC News NI Economics Editor Talks aimed at resolving the political deadlock continue at Stormont. The talks are focusing on welfare reform, finance, paramilitary activity, language, and culture. Welfare reform is a major issue for the DUP, which wants to see the introduction of a universal credit system in Northern Ireland. Sinn Féin, on the other hand, is opposed to welfare reform, arguing that it will disproportionately affect the most vulnerable in society. Finance is another key issue. The DUP wants to see a reduction in corporation tax in Northern Ireland, while Sinn Féin wants to see more investment in public services. Paramilitary activity is also a major concern. The DUP wants to see an end to paramilitary activity, while Sinn Féin wants to see a process of demilitarization. Language and culture are also sensitive issues. The DUP wants to see the promotion of British identity in Northern Ireland, while Sinn Féin wants to see the promotion of Irish identity. These are just some of the thorny issues that the Stormont talks will need to address. If a deal can be reached, it will be a major breakthrough. However, if the talks fail, it will be a major setback for the peace process in Northern Ireland. Welfare reform Welfare reform is a major issue for the DUP, which wants to see the introduction of a universal credit system in Northern Ireland. Universal credit is a single payment that replaces six existing benefits. The DUP argues that universal credit will simplify the welfare system and make it fairer. Sinn Féin, on the other hand, is opposed to welfare reform, arguing that it will disproportionately affect the most vulnerable in society. Sinn Féin says that universal credit will lead to cuts in benefits and that it will make it more difficult for people to claim benefits. Finance Finance is another key issue. The DUP wants to see a reduction in corporation tax in Northern Ireland. Corporation tax is a tax on the profits of companies. The DUP argues that a reduction in corporation tax would make Northern Ireland more attractive to businesses and would create jobs. Sinn Féin, on the other hand, wants to see more investment in public services. Sinn Féin says that public services are essential for the well-being of society and that they should be properly funded. Paramilitary activity Paramilitary activity is also a major concern. The DUP wants to see an end to paramilitary activity, while Sinn Féin wants to see a process of demilitarization. The DUP argues that paramilitary activity is a threat to the peace process and that it needs to be stopped. Sinn Féin, on the other hand, argues that paramilitaries are a legitimate part of the republican struggle and that they will only disarm when there is a united Ireland. Language and culture Language and culture are also sensitive issues. The DUP wants to see the promotion of British identity in Northern Ireland, while Sinn Féin wants to see the promotion of Irish identity. The DUP argues that Northern Ireland is part of the United Kingdom and that British identity should be promoted. Sinn Féin, on the other hand, argues that Northern Ireland is a distinct entity with its own unique culture and identity.

title: Balfour Beatty boss quits after profit warning
text: Balfour Beatty boss quits after profit warning The UK's largest building firm said it expected a shortfall in its UK construction unit, meaning 2014 group pre-tax profits would be "significantly lower" than expected. Balfour said group revenue for 2014 was about £8bn - up 12% on the previous year. However, it had been hit by "unforeseen losses" at its UK construction business, the group said. Chief executive Andrew McNaughton said: "Today's results are not acceptable and we have immediately begun a comprehensive review of our UK construction business. "In the meantime we will continue to focus on our international operations and other strong parts of the group to ensure we deliver on our commitments to clients, employees and shareholders." Shares in the firm fell by 14% on Monday morning. Balfour Beatty has been in talks with its banks about its financial position. It said it was also considering job cuts as it seeks to cut costs. Analysts said the profit warning was a "big blow" to Balfour Beatty. "The company has been struggling for some time and this is another setback," said Liberum analyst Joe Brent. "The UK construction market is tough and Balfour Beatty is not the only company to be struggling. But this is still a big blow." Balfour Beatty is one of the UK's largest construction companies. It is best known for building Heathrow Terminal 5, the new Wembley Stadium and Terminal 2 at London's Gatwick Airport. The company has been hit by a number of problems in recent years, including a dispute over a school building project in Edinburgh and delays to a major rail project in the Midlands. In 2013, Balfour Beatty announced plans to cut 500 jobs as part of a cost-cutting drive. The company's share price has fallen by more than 50% in the past year.

title: Sea lice and disease behind Marine Harvest bid to save £44m
text: By Douglas Fraser Business/economy editor, Scotland In Scotland, the company plunged to a 4.5m euro (£4m) loss in the final three months of 2019. It blamed the outbreak of a parasite and a virus, which led to 4.8 million fish dying last year. The loss was the first for Marine Harvest in Scotland since 2009. The company said it would cut jobs and reduce the amount of antibiotics it uses. The outbreak of sea lice, which are small crustaceans that can attach themselves to fish, was the main factor behind the losses. The company had to transfer fish to other sites to try to control the spread of the parasite. The virus, which causes a disease called infectious salmon anaemia (ISA), was also a major problem. ISA is a highly contagious disease that can kill up to 80% of farmed salmon. The losses have led Marine Harvest to announce a £44m investment plan to try to improve the health of its fish. The plan includes the installation of new equipment to control sea lice and the use of new vaccines to protect fish from ISA. The company also said it would cut the number of fish it farms in Scotland by 10%. This will reduce the pressure on the environment and help to control the spread of disease. Marine Harvest is the world's largest salmon farmer. It has been operating in Scotland for more than 30 years and employs around 1,300 people. The company's losses have raised concerns about the future of the Scottish salmon farming industry. The industry is worth around £2bn a year and employs around 12,000 people. However, the industry has been facing a number of challenges in recent years, including rising costs and competition from other countries. The outbreak of sea lice and ISA has added to these challenges. The Scottish government has said it is committed to supporting the salmon farming industry. The government has provided funding for research into sea lice and ISA and has introduced new regulations to try to control the spread of disease. However, the industry is still facing a number of challenges and it is unclear whether Marine Harvest's investment plan will be enough to save the company from further losses.

title: Myanmar coup: India asked to return police officers who crossed border
text: Indian officials said the officers and their families had crossed the border in recent days. In a letter, Myanmar authorities asked for their return "in order to uphold friendly relations and cooperation between the two countries". The development follows last month's coup in Myanmar, which has been widely condemned by the international community. The military has detained elected leader Aung San Suu Kyi and other top officials, and has imposed martial law in parts of the country. The Indian government has not yet responded to Myanmar's request, but it is facing pressure from both within India and from the international community to take action. Some Indian lawmakers have called on the government to grant asylum to the police officers and their families, while others have said that they should be returned to Myanmar. The United States and the United Kingdom have both called on India to respect the rule of law and to uphold its international obligations. The situation is a delicate one for India, which has close ties to both Myanmar and the United States. India has been a major supporter of Myanmar's democratic transition, but it is also concerned about the stability of the country, which shares a long border with India. India is also facing pressure from China, which has backed the military coup in Myanmar. China has significant economic and strategic interests in Myanmar, and it is likely to try to influence India's response to the crisis. The Indian government is likely to take its time in deciding how to respond to Myanmar's request. It will need to weigh the various factors involved, including the domestic political situation, its relations with Myanmar and the United States, and the potential for regional instability. Whatever decision India makes, it is likely to have a significant impact on the future of Myanmar and the region.

title: Chagos legal status sent to international court by UN
text: The UN General Assembly voted by 94 countries to 15 that The Hague should examine the legal status of the Chagos Islands. The former British colony was a naval base and home to 1,500 people before they were forced out in the 1960s and 1970s to make way for an American military base on the main island of Diego Garcia. The UK maintains that the islands have always been part of British territory and that the islanders were not permanent residents. Mauritius argues that the islands were part of its territory when it gained independence from Britain in 1968 and that the islanders were forcibly removed. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) will now consider whether the Chagos Islands were legally separated from Mauritius in 1965 and whether the UK has an obligation to return them. The UK government has said that it will not abide by the ICJ's ruling if it goes against the UK's position. The US government has also said that it will not withdraw its military base from Diego Garcia. The Chagossians, who now live in Mauritius, the UK, and the Seychelles, have welcomed the decision to refer the case to the ICJ. They hope that the court will rule in their favor and that they will be able to return home. The Chagos Islands dispute is a complex and long-running issue. The ICJ's ruling could have a significant impact on the future of the islands and their people. In addition to the legal arguments, the case also involves issues of human rights and self-determination. The Chagossians were forcibly removed from their homes and have been living in exile for decades. They have been denied the right to return to their homeland and have been subjected to discrimination and abuse. The ICJ's ruling could help to address these human rights concerns and could contribute to the resolution of the Chagos Islands dispute.

title: Ysgol Coed Menai school, Bangor, closure plan is backed
text: Ysgol Coed Menai near Bangor - formerly called Ysgol Treborth - provides education for pupils who have social, emotional and behavioural problems. Gwynedd council said it had developed plans to support the pupils at local schools, and most parents were in favour of the plans. However, some parents are still not convinced. One parent said: "I don't think that the local schools are equipped to deal with children with autism. I'm worried that my child will not get the support that he needs." The council has said that it is confident that the transition to local schools will be successful. It has also said that it will continue to monitor the situation and provide additional support if necessary. title: Covid: Moray moving to level two 'hugely welcome'
text: The area had been kept in level three over concerns about its infection rate. However it has dropped in recent days, to under 40 cases per 100,000 people - below the level two threshold. The move means that pubs and restaurants will be able to serve alcohol indoors until 10pm, and up to eight people from four households can meet in homes and gardens. Moray's MSP, Richard Lochhead, said the move was "hugely welcome" news for businesses and residents. He said: "This is a result of the hard work and sacrifices made by people across Moray in recent weeks. "It's important to remember that the virus is still here, so we must all continue to follow the guidance and protect each other." Moray Council's leader, Graham Leadbitter, said the move was a "significant step forward" for the region. He said: "This is a testament to the efforts of our communities in working together to bring down infection rates. "We must not become complacent, however, and we must all continue to play our part in protecting ourselves and others." The Scottish government's national clinical director, Jason Leitch, said the decision to move Moray to level two was made following a "careful assessment" of the data. He said: "We are seeing a sustained reduction in cases in Moray, and the infection rate is now below the level two threshold. "This is a positive sign, but it is important to remember that the virus is still circulating, so we must all continue to follow the guidance and protect each other." Moray is one of several areas in Scotland that have been moved to level two in recent weeks. Other areas that have been moved to level two include: East Dunbartonshire East Renfrewshire Renfrewshire Stirling The Scottish government is expected to announce which other areas will be moved to level two next week.

title: Microsoft seeks to clean up Xbox game chat with AI
text: It is introducing customisable filters that let gamers choose the vocabulary they see in messages from friends and rival players. The four levels of filtering range from child-friendly through to entirely unfiltered.  The new feature builds on Microsoft’s existing approach to Xbox chat moderation, which saw it remove 2.3 million abusive messages between July and September last year, and take action on more than 4.6 million accounts.  Xbox’s new chat filter arrives at a time when online toxicity is becoming an increasingly prominent issue, with many games suffering from severe levels of harassment and abuse. The problem has become so bad in some titles that players have started to boycott matches if they involve certain maps or game modes, due to the fear of encountering particularly nasty opponents.  In one of the most notorious recent examples, Valve was forced to remove a popular community-created map from Counter-Strike: Global Offensive after it emerged that the map’s creator had left a series of racist easter eggs hidden within it.  Microsoft is at least one of several major players in the games industry attempting to tackle the problem, with Sony and Nintendo also taking steps to reduce toxicity on their own platforms. In November last year, Sony rolled out a new update for the PlayStation 5 that allowed players to mute messages from specific individuals or groups, while Nintendo has been working with researchers at Kyoto University to develop an AI capable of detecting and filtering out abusive messages in real time.  However, despite the efforts of major platform holders, online toxicity remains a significant problem in gaming. There have been particular concerns expressed about its impact on marginalised groups, such as women and players from minority backgrounds.  In theory, customisable chat filters – especially ones that give players the option of completely disabling text communication – could offer an effective way to address these concerns. However, they also raise the potential for players to abuse the system by blocking legitimate criticism or commentary.  Microsoft is hoping to strike a balance between protecting players from abuse and giving them the freedom to have unfiltered discussions with friends. Whether or not it succeeds will likely depend on how well the new chat filters are implemented and enforced.

title: Merged Isle of Wight prison criticised in report
text: An inspection of HMP Isle of Wight found "degrading" sanitation provision, high use of force and inmates seeking sanctuary in a segregation unit. The report also found that inmates were increasingly seeking sanctuary in the segregation unit, which is supposed to be used for prisoners who are at risk of harming themselves or others. title: Being a couch potato could be genetic say Aberdeen scientists
text: Scientists from Aberdeen University, working with colleagues in China, have been looking at why some people are less inclined to exercise and more likely to put on weight. The team said they had found a "substantial genetic basis" for a sedentary lifestyle. The research, published in the journal Obesity, analysed genetic data from almost 400,000 people and found 148 regions of the human genome which were linked to physical activity. The study also looked at whether genes were linked to adiposity or fatness. Researchers say they identified approximately 400 genetic areas associated with obesity or adiposity. It was found that physical inactivity and fatness tended to share some genetic causes. Some of the genes associated with physical inactivity were found to be linked to depression and schizophrenia. The Aberdeen team say they believe that when combined with data on other factors, such as diet and environment, the genetic insights could be used to better predict the likelihood of a person being less active. "In terms of identifying individuals who may be at higher risk of being inactive and obese, then knowing something about their genetic predisposition would allow interventions to be implemented at a younger age," said Professor Emmanuel Stamatakis, one of the authors of the paper. "In large-scale population studies, the genetic data gathered from each individual could be used to calculate a risk score for inactivity and obesity. This score could then be used to target resources to those more likely to benefit from an intervention." The team also believe that learning more about the genetic causes of physical inactivity could help in the development of new drugs designed to overcome the lack of motivation to exercise. "Physical inactivity remains one of the most pressing public health concerns of the 21st century," said Professor Stamatakis. "Overcoming physical inactivity is a complex issue as it is influenced by a wide range of factors, including genetic, physiological, psychological, environmental, and socio-economic determinants."

title: Viagogo threatened with fresh court action
text: By Simon Read Personal finance reporter The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) took Viagogo to court last year for breaking consumer protection law. The ticket seller was given a deadline of February 16 to comply with the order, but the CMA says it has not done so. The CMA is now seeking a court order to force Viagogo to comply, and is also considering additional enforcement action. A spokesperson for the CMA said: "We are extremely disappointed that Viagogo has failed to improve its practices and comply with the order that we secured last year. "We will not hesitate to take further action to protect consumers and ensure that competition in the secondary ticketing market remains fair." Viagogo has said that it is "committed to complying with the law and the CMA's order". A spokesperson for the company said: "We have been working hard to implement the changes required by the CMA, and we are confident that we will be able to comply with the order in full by the end of March." The CMA's investigation found that Viagogo had broken the law by: Failing to provide accurate information about the tickets it sells, including the price, the location of the seats, and the availability of tickets. Charging hidden fees that were not clearly disclosed to customers. Making it difficult for customers to get a refund if they could not attend an event. The CMA's order requires Viagogo to: Provide clear and accurate information about the tickets it sells. Disclose all fees and charges to customers upfront. Make it easier for customers to get a refund if they cannot attend an event. The CMA's action against Viagogo is part of a wider crackdown on the secondary ticketing market. In 2018, the government introduced new legislation to regulate the secondary ticketing market. The legislation gives the CMA powers to investigate and take enforcement action against ticket sellers who break the law. The CMA has also been working with other regulators in Europe to tackle the issue of online ticket touts. In 2019, the CMA and the European Commission signed a Memorandum of Understanding to cooperate on the enforcement of consumer protection law in the secondary ticketing market. The CMA's action against Viagogo is a significant step towards ensuring that the secondary ticketing market is fair and transparent for consumers.

title: NHS contaminated blood scandal victims urged to come forward
text: Thousands of people were infected with HIV and hepatitis C from contaminated blood after blood transfusions and other treatments. After 30 years of repeated calls, Parliament will announce the terms of reference for the public inquiry. The inquiry will investigate how the infections happened, why they were not discovered sooner, and what lessons can be learned to prevent similar tragedies in the future. Jason Evans, chief executive of the Haemophilia Society, said: "This is a historic day for people affected by the contaminated blood scandal. Sue Threakall, co-founder of the Campaign for Contaminated Blood Justice, said: "This is a day we have been waiting for for a long time. We are delighted that the government has finally agreed to hold a public inquiry, and we will continue to fight for justice for all those affected by this scandal." The inquiry is expected to take several years to complete. It will be led by a panel of independent experts, and will hear evidence from victims, their families, and healthcare professionals. The government has said that it is committed to learning the lessons from the contaminated blood scandal, and that it will take action to prevent similar tragedies from happening in the future. In addition to the public inquiry, the government has also announced a compensation scheme for victims of the scandal. The scheme will provide payments to those who were infected with HIV or hepatitis C, and to their families. The compensation scheme is a welcome step forward, but campaigners say that it does not go far enough. They say that the government should also provide long-term support for victims, including access to healthcare and financial assistance. The contaminated blood scandal is one of the biggest medical scandals in British history. It is a tragedy that has caused immeasurable suffering for thousands of people. title: Ants use Sun and memories to navigate
text: By Helen BriggsBBC News Scientists say they can follow a compass route, regardless of the direction in which they are facing. It is the equivalent of blindfolded humans finding their way out of a maze, except the ants are navigating a jungle. When ants forage for food they use the sun as a navigational reference, and it was thought that they could only follow a compass route when the sun was out. But researchers have shown that ants can also store the sun's position in their memories, enabling them to navigate accurately even when the sky is overcast. Dr Antoine Wystrach, who led the study and is now at Cornell University, US, said: "They know where the sun is even if they can't see it." The experiments, which were performed by a team at the University of Edinburgh, involved training wood ants to associate a particular compass direction (in their case, west) with a food source. The ants were then taken into a featureless arena, which was either lit from above or below so that they could not see any visual cues from the sun or sky. "We expected that when we placed them down in the arena they would become disoriented and just wander around," said Dr Wystrach. "But within a couple of minutes they started to walk in a particular direction, and they kept doing it. It was a clear indication that they were using sun compass information that they had stored in their memory." Dr Wystrach and his colleagues then showed that the ants could still navigate accurately after a period of time in the dark - indicating that they could remember the sun's position even after an extended period without exposure to it. The researchers say that their findings could help to improve the navigation systems in robots and other artificial systems. Dr Wystrach said: "Ants are able to use very limited amounts of information to navigate, and they do this in very complex environments. "If we can understand how they do this, then we can use this information to design better navigation systems for robots."

title: Lifespan gap 'widening between rich and poor'
text: By Judith Burns BBC News Everyone is living longer but rich people's lives are extending faster, the City University London study says. Better life expectancy narrowed the gap in the early 20th Century but this trend reversed for men in the 1980s and for women in the late 1990s. The authors say these trends are "unlikely to improve anytime soon". The study, published in the Journal of Epidemiology & Community Health, looked at data from the National Health Service (NHS) for England on more than 190,000 people over a 40-year period. It found that the life expectancy of men and women has increased substantially since 1970. In 1970, a woman born in the most deprived areas could typically expect to live until just after her 71st birthday. By 2010, this had risen to just under 81. But she could still expect to die six years earlier than a baby girl born in the most affluent area. For men, the gap was wider still. In 1970, a baby boy in the most deprived areas could expect to live until he was just 65, compared with nearly 72 in the most affluent areas. By 2010, men in the most deprived areas could expect to live to 76, but this was still four years fewer than those in the most affluent areas. The researchers say the gap between rich and poor is particularly wide around the age of 60. In 2010, a 60-year-old woman living in the most deprived area of England could expect to live another 22 years, compared with 27 years for a woman in the most affluent area. For men, a similar gap exists. A 60-year-old man living in one of the most deprived areas could expect to live nearly 19 years longer, compared with 23 years for a man in the most affluent area. The authors say the widening gap between rich and poor is due to a number of factors, including differences in lifestyle, diet and access to healthcare. They say it is unlikely to improve anytime soon, as the same factors are continuing to affect people's life expectancies.

title: The climber who bagged all 282 Munros in one winter
text: By Linda Sinclair BBC Scotland News Kevin Woods, from Glasgow, is believed to be only the third person to have achieved the feat in a winter season following in the footsteps of Sir Chris Bonington and Donald Bennet.
