I have been blown over by winds and had snow in my eyes, but it has all been worth it. "I was 200m from the summit of Slioch when I completed the challenge. It was a great feeling although I admit the last two Munros were really hard work." The 40-year-old began his quest to climb all 282 Munros - mountains in Scotland over 3,000ft - in the winter of 2018. He had initially aimed to complete the challenge in two years but due to bad weather and injury scaled that back to five years. He is believed to be only the 16th person ever to have climbed all 282 Munros in winter. Mr Woods said his achievement would not have been possible without the support of his wife Lorna and other supporters. "I couldn't have done it without them," he said. "I have been away from home so much and they have picked up the slack. "I have met some great people on the Munros and made some very good friends." The landscape gardener said he still hasn't decided what his next challenge will be but said he could not rule out completing the Munros in summer as well. "I am going to take a well-earned break and plan my next move," he said. "I am a completionist. I like doing things properly and this is no different. I love the outdoors and I cannot imagine my life without it." The first person to climb all 282 Munros in winter was Sir Chris Bonington in 1978, followed by Donald Bennet in 1983.

title: Abellio Greater Anglia rail firm faces franchise challenge
text: Abellio Greater Anglia currently runs the East Anglia franchise, but it is being re-let in October 2016. It includes services to Stansted Airport and to Cambridgeshire, Suffolk, Norfolk and Essex. The rail franchise is being relet because a new specification was drawn up by the Department of Transport and in order to bid for the franchise, companies had to show how they would meet this specification. Abellio has reportedly failed to meet some of the requirements and, as a result, its bid has been put in doubt. The new franchise will be awarded to the company that can meet the new specification and provide the best value for money for passengers. Abellio Greater Anglia has said that it is "disappointed" by the decision and that it will be "considering its options." However, the Department for Transport has said that it is "confident" that the new franchise will be awarded to a company that can meet the new specification and provide the best value for money for passengers. The re-letting of the East Anglia franchise is part of a wider plan by the government to improve the UK's rail network. The government has said that it wants to see more competition on the railways and that it wants to see more investment in new trains and infrastructure. The new East Anglia franchise will be one of the first to be awarded under the new specification and it will be interesting to see how the new franchisee performs. Abellio Greater Anglia has been running the East Anglia franchise since 2012. It has a good track record of performance and has invested in new trains and infrastructure. However, the new franchise will be awarded to the company that can meet the new specification and provide the best value for money for passengers. It remains to be seen whether Abellio Greater Anglia will be successful in its bid to retain the franchise.

title: Scrap dealer law aims to reduce metal theft
text: All scrap dealers and motor salvage operators in England and Wales must now apply for a licence from their local authority and keep records on every transaction involving scrap metal. The new law, which came into force on 1 October 2013, is aimed at reducing metal theft, which costs the UK economy an estimated £770m a year. Under the new law, scrap dealers must keep a record of the following information for each transaction: The name and address of the seller The type and quantity of scrap metal sold The date of the transaction The price paid for the scrap metal The method of payment Scrap dealers must also keep a record of all waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE) that they receive. This information must be kept for a period of three years and must be made available to the police or other authorised officers on request. Failure to comply with the new law could result in a fine of up to £5,000. The new law is part of a wider government crackdown on metal theft. In 2012, the government introduced a new offence of "going equipped to steal metal", which carries a maximum sentence of five years in prison. The government has also increased the number of police officers dedicated to tackling metal theft. In 2013, the government announced that it would be investing £5m in new technology to help police officers catch metal thieves. The new law has been welcomed by the scrap metal industry. The British Metals Recycling Association (BMRA) said that the law would help to "legitimise" the scrap metal industry and make it more difficult for criminals to operate. The BMRA said that the law would also help to reduce the amount of metal theft, which has a negative impact on the environment. Metal theft can lead to pollution and damage to property. The new law is a significant step forward in the fight against metal theft. It will make it more difficult for criminals to operate and will help to reduce the amount of metal theft that takes place.

title: Coronavirus: Hospices call for fundraising to continue
text: Coronavirus: Hospices call for fundraising to continue Bluebell Wood Children's Hospice in Dinnington, South Yorkshire, has started a #LetsPledge campaign to keep people motivated in challenging times. It comes after Sheffield-based cancer charity Weston Park Hospital Cancer Charity closed its shops. The closure means the charity is losing out on over £30,000 a month. To make up for this shortfall, the hospice is promoting the #LetsPledge campaign, which aims to replace the income lost by people pledging the cost of an item they would have bought from a charity shop. Rob Wilson, the hospice's chief executive, said: "We need to keep our fundraising going, because if we don't, we won't be here to care for the children and families who need us. "There are so many ways to pledge, from setting up a monthly direct debit to donating the cost of a cup of coffee or a slice of cake. Every penny helps." The hospice is also launching a new online shop, where people can buy items that have been donated to the charity. The shop will sell a range of items, including clothes, books, and toys. Mr. Wilson said: "Our online shop is a great way to support the hospice and find unique items at the same time. We would encourage everyone to have a look and see what they can find." Other hospices around the country are also feeling the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. St. Luke's Hospice in Sheffield has lost over £100,000 in income due to the closure of its shops and the cancellation of its fundraising events. The hospice's chief executive, David Whiting, said: "This is a very difficult time for hospices. We are losing out on vital income at a time when our services are needed more than ever. "We want to thank everyone who has supported us so far. Your donations are making a real difference to the lives of our patients and their families." Hospices provide essential care for people with life-limiting illnesses. They offer a range of services, including pain management, symptom control, and support for families. The coronavirus pandemic has put a strain on the finances of many hospices. However, the hospices are determined to continue providing their vital services. They are calling on the public to support them in any way they can.

title: Sixth forms in England given £91m cash injection
text: By Katherine SellgrenBBC News education reporter The cash injection of £91m includes £57.4m for sixth form colleges for building needs and £30m for school and college places for 16 to 19-year-olds. A further £3.9m maintenance grant will given direct to 24 councils in England to replace school sixth forms with sixth form colleges. The government says the funding will provide 20,000 new sixth form places by 2025-26 and 30,000 new technical education places by 2024-25, including a £21m investment in new T-level classrooms. It will also part-fund the £450m expansion of the University of Suffolk. Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said the investment will create "high-quality training environments" for young people and "ensure businesses have the skilled workforce they need". But Labour said the announcement was "nothing more than a drop in the ocean" for England's "underfunded schools and colleges". The National Education Union (NEU) said the government is "simply papering over the cracks". Kevin Courtney, joint general secretary of the NEU, said, "The injection of capital funding does not solve the chronic underfunding of post-16 education in England. Imagine the impact on young people's life chances if this level of funding was available every year for the next 10 years." The announcement comes amid a wider review of post-16 qualifications, including A-levels and T-levels. In December 2022, the government said it will not be making any immediate changes to A-levels. But it is considering reforms to T-levels after a report from the Education Policy Institute raised concerns about their quality. The £91m cash injection is part of a £1.6bn investment in skills and further education announced in the autumn statement. The government says this investment will help to "level up" skills and boost the economy. But shadow education secretary Bridget Phillipson said the government's record on education is "nothing short of a disaster". She said, "Schools and colleges are facing real-terms cuts, teachers are leaving the profession in droves, and young people are being left behind. This announcement is nothing more than a drop in the ocean for England's underfunded schools and colleges."

title: Wilson Jerman: Ex-White House butler dies with coronavirus
text: It was Jackie Kennedy who noticed Wilson Roosevelt Jerman while he worked as a cleaner in the White House. The then First Lady had him promoted, and he went on to become the first black man to serve as a butler in the presidential mansion. Jerman, who has died aged 91 from coronavirus, was born in the segregated South, the son of a sharecropper. He left school at 14 to help support his family. After serving in the army during World War II, he moved to Washington DC, where he worked as a waiter and a cleaner. In 1957, he was hired as a cleaner at the White House. It was not long before his quiet competence and warm personality caught the attention of Jackie Kennedy. She had him promoted to butler, and he quickly became a trusted member of the household staff. Jerman served eight presidents, from Dwight D Eisenhower to George H W Bush. He witnessed some of the most momentous events in American history, including the Cuban Missile Crisis, the Vietnam War, and the Watergate scandal. He was also present at many state dinners and receptions, where he served world leaders and celebrities. Jerman was a discreet and private man, but he was also proud of his role in the White House. He once said: "I am a butler, but I am also a historian. I have seen a lot of things, and I have learned a lot of things." Jerman retired from the White House in 1986, but he remained active in public life. He was a frequent speaker at schools and universities, where he shared his experiences of working in the White House. He also wrote a memoir, My Life in the White House: The Extraordinary Story of the First Black Butler of the White House. Jerman's death has been met with sadness by many who knew him. Former President George W Bush said: "Wilson Jerman was a true American hero. He served his country with honor and distinction, and he made the White House a more welcoming place for all who visited." Former First Lady Michelle Obama said: "Wilson Jerman was a pioneer who broke down barriers and made history. He was a role model for generations of African Americans, and his legacy will continue to inspire us all." Jerman is survived by his wife, Doris, and their three children.

title: North Korean man caught by South after crossing border
text: The man, in his 20s, was wearing a diving suit and a set of fins when he was stopped in the de-militarized zone (DMZ), South Korea said. He is thought to be seeking asylum in the South. The incident comes at a time of heightened tensions between the two Koreas, with Pyongyang ramping up its missile tests and threatening to resume nuclear testing. South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff said in a statement that the man was caught in the eastern part of the DMZ shortly before midnight on Saturday. He was carrying a pair of scissors, a flashlight and some dried squid. The man told South Korean authorities that he had defected from North Korea on Friday night by swimming across the Han River, which forms part of the border between the two countries. He then walked for several hours before reaching the DMZ. The man's account of his defection is being investigated by South Korean authorities. If confirmed, he would be the first person to successfully defect from North Korea to the South by swimming across the Han River since 2019. The incident highlights the perilous journey that North Koreans face when trying to escape the repressive regime in their country. Many risk their lives by crossing the heavily fortified DMZ, which is patrolled by armed guards from both sides. The number of North Korean defectors to the South has declined in recent years, as Pyongyang has tightened border security and cracked down on defectors. However, there has been a slight increase in defections in recent months, possibly due to the worsening economic situation in North Korea. South Korea has welcomed the defector and said it will provide him with protection and support. The man is expected to be transferred to a South Korean government facility where he will be interviewed and processed. The incident is likely to further strain relations between North and South Korea, which have been on a downward spiral since the collapse of a nuclear summit between the two leaders in 2019.

title: Colombia offers reward after eight young partygoers killed
text: Four gunmen burst into a party held at a house in Samaniego on Saturday and shot dead seven men and one woman. The victims were part of a group of about 20 revellers. The motive for the attack is still unclear, but police are investigating whether it was related to a local drug gang. The incident has shocked the community in Samaniego, which is located in the south-western Colombian department of Nariño. Nariño is one of Colombia's most violent departments, with a high rate of drug-related crime. In recent years, there has been an increase in violence in the region, as rival drug gangs battle for control of the lucrative cocaine trade. The Colombian government has offered a reward of up to 100 million pesos ($33,000) for information leading to the capture of the gunmen responsible for the attack. President Iván Duque has condemned the attack and vowed to bring the perpetrators to justice. "This cowardly and heinous crime will not go unpunished," Duque said in a statement. "We will continue to fight against drug trafficking and violence in all its forms." The attack in Samaniego is the latest in a series of violent incidents that have taken place in Colombia in recent months. In January, at least 20 people were killed in a car bomb attack in the city of Cúcuta. And in March, at least 10 people were killed in a shooting at a bar in the city of Cali. The violence in Colombia is a major concern for the government, which is struggling to contain the drug trade and other forms of organised crime. The government has increased security measures in recent months, but the violence continues to escalate.

title: Orhan Pamuk on Man Booker International Prize shortlist
text: Orhan Pamuk, who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 2006, is nominated for his book A Strangeness in My Mind. Italian writer Elena Ferrante, whose identity is unknown, is nominated for The Lost Daughter. Pamuk's novel follows the life of Mevlut Karataş, a street vendor in Istanbul, from the 1950s to the present day. The book explores themes of love, loss, and the changing face of Turkey. Ferrante's novel tells the story of Leda, a college professor who becomes obsessed with a young woman and her daughter while on vacation in Italy. The book examines themes of motherhood, female desire, and the complexities of relationships. Joining them on the shortlist are: Geetanjali Shree (India) for Tomb of Sand, translated by Daisy Rockwell, published by Tilted Axis Press Jon Fosse (Norway) for A New Name: Septology VI-VII, translated by Damion Searls, published by Fitzcarraldo Editions Mieko Kawakami (Japan) for Heaven, translated by Samuel Bett and David Boyd, published by Picador The Man Booker International Prize is awarded every year to a writer of any nationality who writes in English or whose work is translated into English. The prize is worth £50,000 (about $69,000). The shortlist was announced on April 12, 2022. The winner will be announced on May 26, 2022. Chair of the judges Frank Wynne said: "These books are all outstanding in their originality and ambition and although they are very different from each other they share a deep and moving humanity and a fearless exploration of the human condition." He added: "It is a particular pleasure for me as Chair of the judges to see writers from all over the world represented on this list, showing once again that great literature transcends borders and speaks to our common experiences." The Man Booker International Prize is one of the most prestigious literary awards in the world. It is awarded to a writer who has made a significant contribution to world literature.

title: Covid: Cardiff police given random vehicle check powers
text: South Wales Police said it would increase the numbers of officers on duty to encourage people to adhere to the rules. The powers will be in place from 5pm on Friday until 6pm on Monday, although this could be extended if deemed necessary. "The vast majority of people are abiding by the rules and we want to thank them for their continued efforts in protecting themselves and others and preventing the spread of the virus," said Assistant Chief Constable Mark Travis. "However, there is a minority who continue to blatantly ignore the advice, which is designed to keep us all safe. "Those who do will face the full force of the law, including fines. "We are increasing our patrols and will be stopping vehicles. If you are stopped and have no reasonable excuse to be out, you will be instructed to return home. "We can't stress enough how important it is to stay at home to protect the NHS and save lives." Under the new powers, police will be able to: Stop any car, van, lorry or other vehicle Ask the driver and passengers why they are making the journey Instruct the driver to return home if they have no reasonable excuse to be out Issue a fine of £200 to anyone who fails to comply The powers are in addition to those already in place, which include: Fining people £100 for leaving their homes without a reasonable excuse Fining people £60 for failing to wear a face covering in enclosed public spaces Breaking up illegal gatherings of more than two people The Welsh Government has also announced a new £500 fine for anyone who travels to Wales from a Tier 4 area in England without a reasonable excuse. The new measures are part of a wider crackdown on people breaking the Covid-19 rules. Last week, the government announced that it would be increasing the number of police officers patrolling the streets and increasing the number of fines issued. The government has also urged the public to report anyone they see breaking the rules.

title: Gaia Pope: Missing teenager murder suspects released
text: Gaia, 19, from Langton Matravers, Dorset, disappeared from nearby Swanage, where she had been staying, on 7 November. Rosemary Dinch, 71, and her 19-year-old grandson, Nathan Elsey, both from Swanage, know no more than the rest of the community about her whereabouts, their lawyer said. Dinch is said to have helped search for Gaia after she went missing, while Elsey is believed to have been one of the last people to see her. Police have said they are keeping an open mind about Gaia's disappearance and are not ruling out the possibility that she may have come to harm. In a statement issued through their lawyer, Dinch and Elsey said: "We are deeply shocked and saddened by the news of Gaia's disappearance. "We have been doing everything we can to help the police with their inquiries and we will continue to do so. "Our thoughts and prayers are with Gaia's family and friends at this difficult time." The pair were arrested on suspicion of murder on 19 November and have been released on bail. Gaia's disappearance has sparked a major search operation, involving police, coastguard and volunteers. Searches have been carried out across Dorset, including in Swanage, Langton Matravers and Studland. Police have also been searching the coastline and the sea. Gaia's family have appealed for information about her whereabouts. In a statement, they said: "We are desperate for any information that will help us find Gaia. "We have had no contact with her since she went missing and we are extremely worried about her. "We would urge anyone who has any information, no matter how small, to contact the police."

title: US nuclear fears block Intel China supercomputer update
text: Intel applied for a licence to export tens of thousands of chips to update the Tianhe-2 computer. The Department of Commerce, which oversees exports, declined the request citing concerns that the update could benefit China's military. Intel said it was disappointed and that the decision would slow the development of artificial intelligence in the US. The company said it would continue to work with the US government to address concerns. The US has expressed concerns about China's rapidly developing artificial intelligence capabilities. In 2019, the US added several Chinese companies to a trade blacklist, citing concerns that they were developing artificial intelligence for military purposes. The US is not the only country with concerns about China's artificial intelligence capabilities. In 2018, the European Union called on China to develop ethical guidelines for the use of artificial intelligence. The US-China trade war has made it more difficult for US companies to do business in China. The Trump administration has imposed tariffs on Chinese goods and has restricted the sale of US technology to Chinese companies. The Biden administration has taken a more conciliatory approach to China, but it has not reversed the Trump administration's policies on technology exports. The decision to block the Intel export licence is a sign that the US is still concerned about China's artificial intelligence capabilities. It is also a sign that the US is willing to use trade restrictions to protect its interests. The decision is likely to have a negative impact on the US artificial intelligence industry. Intel is a leading supplier of chips for artificial intelligence applications. The decision will make it more difficult for US companies to develop artificial intelligence products. The decision could also damage relations between the US and China. China has already criticised the US for blocking the Intel export licence. The decision could lead to further retaliation from China. The US-China relationship is already strained. The two countries have clashed over a range of issues, including trade, technology, and human rights. The decision to block the Intel export licence is likely to further damage the relationship.

title: GP recruitment drive film 'tackles outdated stereotypes'
text: By Jane Dreaper Health correspondent, BBC News It has been launched by the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP), which claims at least 10,000 extra GPs will be needed by 2020. The three-minute film features doctors talking about how they find the job rewarding, but also extremely busy. It tackles outdated stereotypes, such as the suggestion that GPs are essentially "gatekeepers" whose main role is to block patients from accessing specialists. Rather it shows GPs proactively caring for the whole person, considering both their physical and mental health, and also the social circumstances that might be affecting them. In the film, newly qualified GP Dr Aneel Bhangu says: "If you're interested in a career that's diverse and challenging, I would encourage you to look at general practice." Dr Amir Hannan, who appears in the film alongside his wife, a fellow GP, adds: "It's such a lovely feeling helping people get better, and that's what makes the late nights and early mornings all worthwhile." 'Cradle to grave' care In 2017 the Health Foundation warned that the UK was facing a shortage of 10,000 family doctors by 2020. The RCGP says the situation has not improved. Prof Helen Stokes-Lampard, chair of the RCGP, told the BBC: "There are some outdated stereotypes about general practice that just aren't true. "The truth is that GPs are on the frontline of healthcare, offering 'cradle to grave' care to their patients. "They are also highly skilled clinicians who are doing more complex work than ever before." 'Exceptionally challenging' The recruitment campaign is also targeting medical students. The film features current students talking about what attracted them to the profession. One of these is Anushka Patel, a fourth-year medical student at King's College London. She says: "I've always loved the idea of helping people. Medicine is a really diverse profession, and general practice offers something different every day." NHS England says it is "committed" to increasing the GP workforce and has allocated £2bn to help recruit family doctors. But Prof Stokes-Lampard says it will be "exceptionally challenging" to meet the target of 10,000 extra GPs by 2020. She said: "We need to ensure that the current and future GP workforce is supported to stay in general practice, and that medical students and junior doctors are attracted to a career in general practice."

title: Autism brain secrets revealed by scan
text: Scans revealed children carrying the gene variant appeared to have more nerve cell "connections" within the frontal lobe. They had fewer connections in the temporal lobe, another brain area involved in autism. The findings help explain why the gene variant boosts the chance of autism - which affects one in 100 children in the UK. The variant is found in a gene that provides instructions for making a protein called FMRP. This protein plays a crucial role in the brain's development. In people with autism, FMRP is often faulty or missing altogether. The new research suggests that the faulty FMRP protein disrupts the normal pruning process that occurs in the brain during childhood. This process involves the shedding of excess nerve cell connections, which helps to refine the brain's neural networks. In children with the gene variant, the pruning process is thought to be less efficient, leading to an overgrowth of connections in some brain areas and a shortage in others. This imbalance may underlie the social and communication difficulties seen in autism. Dr Emily Jones, from the University of Cambridge, said: "Our findings provide new insights into the biological mechanisms that underpin autism. "We hope that this research will lead to new treatments that can target the underlying causes of the condition." The study was published in the journal Nature Neuroscience. It involved 153 children with autism and 112 typically developing children. The researchers used magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans to measure the thickness of the cortex - the outermost layer of the brain - in different brain regions. They also used a technique called diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) to measure the number of nerve cell connections in different brain areas. The researchers found that children with autism had thinner cortex in the frontal and temporal lobes, compared with typically developing children. They also found that children with the gene variant had more nerve cell connections in the frontal lobe and fewer connections in the temporal lobe. These findings suggest that the FMRP gene variant disrupts the normal pruning process that occurs in the brain during childhood. This leads to an imbalance of nerve cell connections in different brain areas, which may underlie the social and communication difficulties seen in autism.

title: Domestic violence legal aid changes were 'invalid'
text: Rights of Women said victims were being unlawfully denied funding in civil court cases because of changes made by ex-Lord Chancellor Chris Grayling. A rule that proof of domestic violence must be less than 24 months old was "invalid", the charity said. It added that guidance making victims provide evidence to police was "unlawful". Changes brought in by Grayling in 2013 "were invalid because they were not made in accordance with Parliament's intention," Rights of Women said. The Ministry of Justice said it was "carefully considering" the judgment. The charity said its analysis of the changes, introduced in March 2013, showed women in eight out of 10 cases did not get legal aid because of the new rules. It is now calling for the old rules to be reinstated. Harriet Wistrich, director of Rights of Women, said: "This is a hugely significant judgment. "It means that the government has been unlawfully denying victims of domestic violence access to justice by wrongly removing their entitlement to legal aid. "The government must now reinstate the old rules." The case was brought by two women represented by the charity. In a judgment on Wednesday, the Upper Tribunal said the changes - which were designed to save the government money - were "invalid" because they were not "made in accordance with Parliament's intention". The tribunal added that a provision "had the effect of denying access to justice to victims of domestic violence" and that guidance issued by the Legal Aid Agency was "unlawful". The judgment is the latest in a series of legal challenges to Grayling's cuts to legal aid. In 2014, the Supreme Court ruled that changes to legal aid for civil cases were "irrational" because they would "deny access to justice to some of the most vulnerable in society". The Ministry of Justice said it was "carefully considering" the judgment. "We are committed to providing access to justice for victims of domestic violence," a spokesman said. "We will respond to the court's judgment in due course."

title: Vietnam War: French court to hear landmark Agent Orange case
text: The case was brought by Tran To Nga, a 78-year-old French-Vietnamese woman who covered the conflict as a journalist. She accuses the chemical firms of causing harm to her and other victims by knowingly producing and supplying a toxic herbicide that was widely used by the US military during the war. Agent Orange was a defoliant used by the US military to clear vegetation that could provide cover for enemy troops. It contained a highly toxic chemical compound called dioxin, which has been linked to a range of health problems including cancer, birth defects and nerve damage. Nga alleges that she was exposed to Agent Orange while reporting on the war and that she has suffered from health problems as a result. She is seeking compensation from the chemical firms for her suffering and for the suffering of other victims. The chemical firms have denied liability, arguing that they were not responsible for the way that Agent Orange was used by the US military. They also argue that there is no scientific evidence to support the claim that Agent Orange causes the health problems that Nga and other victims allege. The case is being closely watched by victims of Agent Orange and their advocates. If Nga is successful in her case, it could set a precedent for other victims to seek compensation from the chemical firms. The trial is expected to last several weeks. The court will hear evidence from both sides and will then make a decision on whether the chemical firms are liable for the harm caused by Agent Orange. The case is a landmark moment in the fight for justice for victims of Agent Orange. It is the first time that a court has heard a case against the chemical firms that produced and supplied the herbicide. The outcome of the case could have a significant impact on the lives of victims of Agent Orange and their families.

title: Gentoo penguins are four species, not one
text: By Helen Briggs BBC Environment correspondent According to new evidence, the birds are slightly different in shape and size, and can be told apart by their DNA. Counting them as separate species will help in conservation, they argue, making it easier to focus resources on protecting the most vulnerable. There's Adelie, Chinstrap, King and Gentoo penguins. But a new study that looked at the DNA of these black-and-white birds suggests that Gentoos are actually four different species, not one. The differences between them may be subtle but they are there, says the team at the University of California in San Diego. The birds vary slightly in shape and size, and each has a slightly different song. Their DNA also shows significant differences. This means that what was previously considered a single species of Gentoo penguin is now four separate species: Northern Gentoo (Pygoscelis papua) Southern Gentoo (Pygoscelis taeniata) Eastern Gentoo (Pygoscelis ellsworthi) Western Gentoo (Pygoscelis adamsi) The researchers say that around 80% of the world's Gentoo penguins are in the Northern Gentoo species. They live in Antarctica and the sub-Antarctic islands. The other three species breed on different islands and archipelagos in the Southern Ocean and the sub-Antarctic. "We propose the recognition of four Gentoo penguin species, which will contribute to more effective conservation," the team concludes in a paper published in the journal Molecular Ecology. "Defining separate species for management and conservation is crucial for protecting biodiversity," said Dr Steve Emslie, from the British Antarctic Survey, who was not involved in the new research. "As the Gentoo penguin group is distinctive, genetically divergent, and occupies separate breeding ranges, these are all good reasons to consider them separate species." This will help in conservation, they argue, making it easier to focus resources on protecting the most vulnerable. For example, they say that the Southern and Western Gentoo penguins may be bigger, but they are also less numerous, and more in need of protection. Lead researcher Michael Parsons said: "Under the current paradigm, all Gentoo penguin populations are assessed as a single unit. As a result, the smaller and less-known populations such as the Southern and Western Gentoos may not be receiving the conservation attention they deserve." Dr Emslie said that work needs to continue to understand the distinctions between the different types of Gentoo penguin. "DNA analysis is a useful tool, but it's not the only way of separating species," he said. "We also look at the birds' morphology - their shape and size - as well as their behaviour, distribution and ecology. By combining all of this information, we can build up a comprehensive picture of each species."

title: Microsoft reports better-than-expected earnings
text: The firm reported a net income of $6.56bn (£3.94bn) for the quarter, up from $6.38bn a year earlier. Its earnings were boosted by a rise in demand for its cloud computing and software services. Analysts had predicted that Microsoft would report earnings per share of $59.65, but the company actually reported earnings per share of $61.72. This beat expectations by 3.5%. Microsoft's revenue for the quarter was $11.36bn, up from $10.85bn a year earlier. This was also above analysts' expectations, who had predicted revenue of $11.28bn. The company's cloud computing business, Azure, continues to be a major growth driver. Azure revenue grew by 30% year-over-year to $4.33bn. Microsoft's Office 365 software subscription service also continues to grow, with revenue growing by 18% year-over-year to $3.63bn. Microsoft's earnings report is a sign that the company is continuing to benefit from the shift to cloud computing and other digital services. The company is also well-positioned to benefit from the ongoing transition to remote work and learning. title: Sony to sell PC unit and cut jobs

Sony's restructuring programme is a significant step towards addressing the challenges it faces in its core businesses. title: Mark Kennedy: 'No misconduct by Nottinghamshire Police'
text: Mark Kennedy: 'No misconduct by Nottinghamshire Police' Despite acknowledging "collective failings" in the prosecution case of the climate change activist, the Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) has concluded that there was no misconduct by Nottinghamshire Police in relation to undercover officer Mark Kennedy. The watchdog's investigation found that evidence from Kennedy, who infiltrated environmental groups for seven years, had not been properly shared or recorded. This led to the collapse of the trial last year of six activists accused of conspiracy to commit aggravated trespass in 2009. However, the IPCC said there was no evidence that any officer had "knowingly or recklessly misled" the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS). It also found that the failure to disclose Kennedy's evidence was not due to "a deliberate attempt to suppress material beneficial to the defendants." The IPCC's findings have been welcomed by Nottinghamshire Police, which said it was "disappointed" by the collapse of the trial but accepted the watchdog's conclusions. "We have learned lessons from this case and have already made improvements to our disclosure processes," said Chief Constable Craig Guildford. "We are committed to ensuring that such failings do not happen again." The activists who were cleared of the charges last year have expressed disappointment at the IPCC's findings. "It's clear that there were serious failings in the prosecution process," said one of the activists, who did not want to be named. "The IPCC's report doesn't go far enough in holding the police to account." The IPCC's investigation was launched following a critical report by the Police and Crime Commissioner for Nottinghamshire, Paddy Tipping. Tipping found that there had been a "catalogue of errors" in the prosecution case, including the failure to disclose Kennedy's evidence. In response to the IPCC's findings, Tipping said: "I am concerned that the report does not go far enough in addressing the systemic failures that led to the collapse of the trial." He added: "I will be writing to the Home Secretary to raise my concerns and to call for a full public inquiry into the role of undercover policing in the environmental movement."

title: Tikrit: Iran key in fight to wrest city from IS
text: By Nafiseh Kohnavard BBC Persian, Beirut Shia militia sources in Iraq have confirmed that Gen Qasem Soleimani, the commander of Iran's elite Quds Force, has been visiting Tikrit to oversee operations to retake the city from the Islamic State group. The Iraqi army, backed by Shia militias and Iranian advisers, launched an offensive to retake Tikrit on 2 March. The city is a former stronghold of Saddam Hussein and is seen as a symbolic prize for IS. The operation to retake Tikrit has been slow and bloody, with hundreds of Iraqi soldiers and Shia militiamen killed or wounded. IS has been putting up fierce resistance, and has used suicide bombers and car bombs to target Iraqi forces. However, the Iraqi army and its allies have made some progress in recent days, and they are now believed to be in control of most of the city. IS fighters are still holding out in some areas, but they are expected to be defeated in the coming days. The liberation of Tikrit would be a major blow to IS, which has been losing ground in Iraq and Syria in recent months. It would also be a significant victory for the Iraqi government and its allies, and it would help to boost morale among Iraqi forces. Iran has been a key player in the fight against IS in Iraq, and it is likely to continue to play a role in the country's future. Gen Soleimani's presence in Tikrit is a sign of Iran's commitment to the fight against the jihadists, and it is a reminder of the important role that Iran is playing in the region.

title: Pte Sean Benton: Sister hopes Army will learn from Deepcut inquest

title: Coronavirus: Newquay man weeding his way around town
text: Alex Russell, from Newquay in Cornwall, suffers with anxiety and depression but said starting the activity during the lockdown helped with his mental health. title: Scientists find 'better way' to grow adult stem cells
text: Standard surfaces have proved limited for growing large amounts and retaining the stem cells' useful characteristics. It is hoped the discovery could lead to the creation of stem cell therapies to treat a range of conditions. The researchers, whose work is published in Nature Communications, used a technique called electrospinning to create a nanofibre scaffold that mimics the natural environment of stem cells. This scaffold provides a more supportive and three-dimensional structure for the cells to grow on. In tests, the researchers found that the new scaffold allowed them to grow 10 times more stem cells than on standard surfaces. The stem cells also retained their ability to differentiate into a variety of cell types, which is essential for their use in therapies. "This is a significant breakthrough in the field of stem cell research," said lead researcher Professor Molly Stevens of Imperial College London. "For the first time, we have been able to grow large amounts of stem cells on a surface that mimics their natural environment. This opens up the potential for using stem cells to treat a range of conditions, from heart disease to Alzheimer's." The researchers are now working on developing the technology further and testing it in clinical trials. They hope that the new scaffold could eventually be used to create stem cell therapies that are safe and effective for treating a wide range of diseases. Stem cells are unspecialised cells that have the potential to develop into any cell in the body. They are therefore seen as a promising source of cells for use in therapies to treat a range of conditions, such as heart disease, Alzheimer's, and Parkinson's disease. However, growing stem cells in the laboratory has proved challenging. Standard surfaces have not been able to support the growth of large amounts of stem cells, and the cells often lose their ability to differentiate into different cell types. The new scaffold developed by the researchers overcomes these problems. It provides a more supportive and three-dimensional structure for the cells to grow on, and it helps to maintain their ability to differentiate. This makes it a promising platform for the development of stem cell therapies.

title: Prison day release rules to be tightened, minister says
text: Prison day release rules to be tightened, minister says Tighter rules about who is eligible for the scheme are to be introduced, the Ministry of Justice said. Prisoners will only be allowed out for a few hours at a time, with no overnight stays, and only if they are assessed as being at low risk of reoffending. The review found that some prisoners were being released on day release who should not have been, and that the scheme was not doing enough to help prisoners reintegrate into society. The new rules will be introduced in phases, starting with a pilot scheme in six prisons. The pilot scheme will run for six months, and the results will be evaluated before the new rules are rolled out to all prisons. The Ministry of Justice said that the new rules will make the scheme more effective and will help to protect the public. The changes have been welcomed by some, but others have expressed concern that they will make it harder for prisoners to reintegrate into society. However, the Howard League for Penal Reform said that the changes were "necessary" and that they would help to make the scheme more effective. The changes to the day release scheme are part of a wider package of reforms to the prison system. The reforms include plans to introduce new "boot camps" for young offenders and to give prisoners more opportunities to learn skills and qualifications. title: Cancer costing European Union countries 'billions'
text: The charity Cancer Research UK said it was a "huge burden". The figures, published in the Lancet Oncology, included the cost of healthcare, lost productivity and premature death. The study found that the annual economic cost of cancer in the EU was €179 billion (£155 billion; $209 billion). This is equivalent to 1.3% of the EU's gross domestic product (GDP). The cost of cancer is expected to rise to €246 billion (£214 billion; $289 billion) by 2030. The study also found that the number of cancer cases in the EU is expected to increase by 26% by 2030. This is due to a number of factors, including the ageing population and unhealthy lifestyles. The five most common cancers in the EU are breast cancer, lung cancer, colorectal cancer, prostate cancer and bladder cancer. The study's authors say that the rising cost of cancer is a major concern for European governments. They say that more needs to be done to prevent cancer and to improve the treatment and care of cancer patients. The European Commission has pledged to invest €4 billion (£3.5 billion; $4.7 billion) in cancer research over the next seven years. The Commission is also working to improve access to cancer screening and treatment. Cancer is a major public health challenge in the EU. The rising cost of cancer is a concern for governments and healthcare systems. More needs to be done to prevent cancer and to improve the treatment and care of cancer patients. What can be done to reduce the cost of cancer? There are a number of things that can be done to reduce the cost of cancer, including: Prevention: Preventing cancer is the most effective way to reduce its cost. This can be done by promoting healthy lifestyles, such as eating a healthy diet, maintaining a healthy weight, and getting regular exercise. It is also important to get vaccinated against HPV and hepatitis B, which can both cause cancer. Early detection: Detecting cancer early can lead to more effective treatment and better outcomes for patients. This is why it is important to get regular cancer screenings, such as mammograms, colonoscopies, and Pap tests. Effective treatment: Advances in cancer treatment have led to improved survival rates for patients. However, cancer treatment can be expensive. Governments and healthcare systems need to ensure that patients have access to the most effective treatments. Palliative care: Palliative care is important for improving the quality of life for cancer patients. This care can help patients manage their symptoms and cope with the challenges of living with cancer. By taking these steps, we can reduce the cost of cancer and improve the lives of cancer patients.

The Indian parent company Tata Group has been trying to sell its UK business for several months but has so far failed to find a buyer. The UK government has said it will provide financial support to Tata Steel if necessary, but has not said how much it would be willing to provide. Tata Steel's UK operations employ about 15,000 people and produce about 4 million tonnes of steel a year. The UK government has said it is committed to supporting the steel industry, which it sees as a vital part of the UK economy.

title: Wales weather: M4 clear after Storm Frank flooding
text: Police dealt with three separate crashes where there was standing water on both sides of the carriageway between junctions 35 (Pencoed) and 36 (Sarn). Flooding also blocked one lane eastbound near junction 32 (Coryton Interchange). Officers advised drivers to avoid driving through floodwater and, if they had to, to reduce their speed. Natural Resources Wales (NRW) said the River Ely burst its banks in St Athan throughout the night, leading to flooding on the A48 and nearby roads, but the water was receding by Monday morning. It also issued a number of flood alerts across the south of the country, including the River Taff catchment, River Cynon, River Rhondda, River Ewenny, River Ogmore and River Ely. The Met Office said that while most of the rain from Storm Frank had now passed, further heavy showers were expected on Monday afternoon and Tuesday morning. NRW warned that river levels are likely to remain high in some areas for the next few days, and that further flooding could occur if there is heavy rainfall. The Environment Agency in England has also issued a number of flood alerts and warnings, including for the River Severn and the River Thames. The Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning for rain for south-west England and south Wales, which is in place until Tuesday morning. It said there is a risk of further flooding and travel disruption in some areas. The RAC said it had attended more than 5,000 breakdowns on Sunday, with the majority of call-outs being for vehicles that had broken down due to flooding. It urged drivers to avoid driving through floodwater, as even a small amount of water can cause a vehicle to stall. The AA also advised drivers to be cautious when driving in wet weather, and to reduce their speed and increase their following distance.

title: Cambridgeshire teen felt 'not believed' after abuse probe dropped
text: Chris Gould, 17, died in January 2019 while an informal patient at a mental health unit near Cambridge. Her parents told the inquest that clinicians felt alleged sexual abuse by a member of staff was "not credible". Cambridgeshire and Peterborough NHS Foundation Trust, which runs the unit, said it was "deeply sorry" for Chris's death and accepted the inquest's findings. The inquest heard that Chris had been admitted to the unit in December 2018 after attempting to take her own life. She had a history of self-harm and had been diagnosed with emotionally unstable personality disorder. While at the unit, Chris alleged that she had been sexually abused by a member of staff. The allegations were investigated by the police, but no charges were brought. Chris's parents said they were "not believed" by clinicians when they raised concerns about the alleged abuse. They said that they felt "fobbed off" and that the unit was "more interested in protecting its staff than in protecting patients". The inquest jury found that the alleged abuse was a "contributory factor" to Chris's death. It also found that the unit had failed to provide adequate care for Chris and that there had been a "lack of communication" between staff. The trust said it had "learned lessons" from Chris's death and had made changes to its safeguarding procedures. It said it was "committed to providing safe and high-quality care for all patients". Chris's parents said they were "relieved" that the inquest had found that the alleged abuse was a "contributory factor" to their daughter's death. They said they hoped that the trust would "learn from its mistakes" and that other families would not have to go through what they had. The inquest is one of a number of recent cases that have raised concerns about the care of young people in mental health units. In February, an inquest into the death of 14-year-old Amy El-Keria found that she had been failed by the mental health system. Amy died in 2019 after taking her own life. The government has said that it is committed to improving the care of young people in mental health units. In March, it announced a £500 million investment in mental health services for children and young people.

title: Chase criticised for 'mocking' customers' spending habits
text: By Georgina Rannard BBC News Offering financial advice on Twitter, the bank appeared to chastise consumers who question their low bank balances but buy take-away coffee and short taxi rides. The meme was roundly criticized for being condescending and out of touch with the financial difficulties faced by many people. "Millions of people are worried about the rising cost of living and how to make ends meet," said a spokesperson for the consumer group Which? "It's unhelpful and unkind for a bank to imply that people are struggling financially because they are spending money on small treats or conveniences." The bank has since apologized for the tweet, saying that it was not intended to be judgmental. "We recognize that the cost of living is rising and that many people are struggling to make ends meet," said a spokesperson. "We are committed to helping our customers manage their finances and make the most of their money." However, the tweet has sparked a wider debate about the role of banks in society. Some argue that banks should be doing more to help customers manage their finances, while others believe that individuals are ultimately responsible for their own financial decisions. "Banks have a responsibility to help their customers," said Martin Lewis, founder of the consumer website MoneySavingExpert.com. "They should be providing clear and impartial advice, and helping people to understand their finances and make informed decisions." However, others argue that individuals need to take more responsibility for their own financial decisions. "People need to be more aware of how they are spending their money and make changes if necessary," said a spokesperson for the National Consumer Council. "Banks can't be held responsible for people's poor financial decisions." The debate is likely to continue as the cost of living continues to rise. In the meantime, it is important for individuals to be aware of how they are spending their money and make changes if necessary. Banks can also play a role in helping customers manage their finances, but ultimately, individuals are responsible for their own financial decisions.

title: Ex-Australian PMs make appeal over Bali Nine drug pair
text: Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran were given the death sentence in 2006 for leading a drug trafficking group known as the Bali Nine. The former prime ministers said they deserved clemency. An Indonesian official has told the BBC that President Widodo has not yet made a decision on the pair's fate, but that he is aware of the pleas for clemency. The former Australian prime ministers, Tony Abbott, John Howard and Malcolm Fraser, have written to Indonesian President Joko Widodo, urging him to grant clemency to two Australian drug smugglers on death row. In the letter, the former leaders said that Chan and Sukumaran had shown "genuine remorse" for their crimes and had been rehabilitated during their time in prison. They also said that the pair's execution would damage relations between Australia and Indonesia. "We believe that the execution of Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran would be a grave injustice and a serious setback to the relationship between our two countries," the letter said. The letter was sent ahead of a meeting between Widodo and Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull in Jakarta on Thursday. Turnbull is expected to raise the issue of Chan and Sukumaran's execution with Widodo. The Indonesian government has said that it will not grant clemency to Chan and Sukumaran. However, President Widodo has the final say on whether or not the pair will be executed. An Indonesian official has told the BBC that President Widodo has not yet made a decision on the pair's fate, but that he is aware of the pleas for clemency. "The president is aware of the pleas for clemency," the official said. "He is considering all of the factors involved, including the views of the Australian government." The official said that President Widodo would make a decision on the pair's fate "in due course." Chan and Sukumaran were arrested in Bali in 2005 for attempting to smuggle heroin out of Indonesia. They were convicted and sentenced to death in 2006. The pair have been on death row since 2010. Their executions have been delayed several times. The Australian government has been lobbying the Indonesian government to grant clemency to Chan and Sukumaran. However, the Indonesian government has said that it will not grant clemency to drug traffickers.

title: Sir Alan Parker, director of Bugsy Malone and Evita, dies aged 76
text: The double Oscar nominee's many other credits include Midnight Express, Mississippi Burning, The Commitments, Angela's Ashes and Birdy. Evita composer Andrew Lloyd Webber tweeted Sir Alan had been "one of the few directors to truly understand musicals on screen". The Phantom of the Opera and Cats impresario added: "He will be much missed." Sir Alan's death was announced by the British Film Institute. No cause of death was given. Born in Islington, north London, Sir Alan began his career as an advertising copywriter, before moving into film in the 1970s. His first feature as director, the London-set gangster comedy Bugsy Malone, was released in 1976 and starred children, including a young Jodie Foster. Bugsy Malone was followed by Midnight Express (1978), which was nominated for six Oscars and won two, and Fame (1980). Sir Alan was nominated for best director at the Academy Awards in 1988 for Mississippi Burning, an examination of race and civil rights in the US. In 1996, he directed the film version of Evita, for which Madonna received a Golden Globe Award for best actress in a musical or comedy. The Commitments, released in 1991, was a musical comedy about a group of young musicians from Dublin. The film was a critical and commercial success and launched the career of Irish singer Glen Hansard, who played the lead character. As well as feature films, Sir Alan also directed commercials, short films and music videos. He was awarded a Bafta Fellowship in 2013. He was married to Lisa Moran and is survived by their five children. Tributes have poured in for Sir Alan from the world of film and music. "I am very sad to hear of the passing of Sir Alan Parker, a truly great British director who made so many iconic films," said BFI chair Tim Richards. "His work was always full of humanity, humour and passion." Film director Edgar Wright described Sir Alan as "one of our greatest filmmakers" and said his work "defined a generation of British cinema".

title: War Horse musicians lose legal bid
text: The musicians took legal action last week following the theatre's decision to end their contribution - of playing live over a pre-recorded soundtrack. They had sought an injunction to be allowed back on stage, but their bid was unsuccessful. The theatre contends that the use of a pre-recorded soundtrack enhances the storytelling and brings the production closer to the film on which it is based. However, the musicians argued that they had a "unique and irreplaceable role" in the show and that their removal diminished the experience for audiences. In their High Court ruling, Deputy High Court Judge, Anthony Mann, said that while the musicians' removal had caused them "considerable distress and disappointment", it was within the theatre's rights to make the change. The judge also rejected the musicians' argument that the theatre had breached the terms of their agreement. A spokesperson for the theatre said that they were "pleased with the court's decision" and that they "remain committed to providing our audiences with the best possible experience". The theatre also said that they would be "exploring ways to recognise the contribution that the musicians have made to War Horse over the past 10 years". The musicians have expressed their disappointment with the outcome and are considering their options. They said in a statement, "We're very sad to have to accept that the curtain has come down on our time at War Horse. We're proud of our contribution to the success of the show and we're grateful to the audiences who have enjoyed our music over the last decade." War Horse has been a critical and commercial success since its premiere in 2007. Despite being out of theaters, the show is available on DVD and Blu-ray and has been adapted for film, television, and radio.

title: Prison staff misconduct investigations rise by third
text: Prison staff misconduct investigations rise by third More than 2,500 charges were investigated in 2018-19, up from 1,894 the previous year. Alleged "breach of security" - which includes the unauthorised introduction of contraband - accounted for more than a third of all charges. The figures, obtained by the BBC via a Freedom of Information request to HM Prison and Probation Service, also show a rise in allegations of assault, violence, discrimination and bullying. There were 557 allegations of assault in 2018-19, compared with 389 the previous year. And there were 229 allegations of discrimination, up from 183 in 2017-18. The Ministry of Justice said it was "committed to creating a safe and secure environment for all prisoners and staff" and that it would "not tolerate any form of misconduct or abuse". The rise in misconduct allegations comes at a time when the prison system is menghadapi increasing pressure. The number of people in prison in England and Wales has risen by more than 20,000 since 2010, and the prison population is now at its highest level since the early 19th century. The number of prison staff has also fallen in recent years, and there are now just over 28,000 prison officers in England and Wales, compared with 33,000 in 2010. This has led to concerns that prisons are understaffed and that staff are struggling to cope with the increased workload. The Prison Officers' Association said the rise in misconduct allegations was a "serious concern" and that it was a "reflection of the pressure that prison staff are under". "The government needs to invest in the prison service and provide more resources for staff," said POA general secretary Steve Gillan. "We also need to see a change in the culture of the prison system. Too often, prisoners are treated with disrespect and violence, and this creates a hostile and dangerous environment for staff." The BBC spoke to several prison officers who said they had been victims of misconduct. One officer, who did not want to be named, said he had been assaulted by a prisoner on several occasions. "I've been punched, kicked and spat at," he said. "I've also been threatened with death. It's a very dangerous job, and I'm constantly worried about my safety." Another officer said she had been discriminated against because of her gender. "I've been told that I'm not strong enough to be a prison officer," she said. "I've also been told that I'm only in the job because I want to meet men. It's really demoralising." The Ministry of Justice said it was "committed to protecting staff from harm" and that it would "not tolerate any form of misconduct or abuse". "We have introduced a number of measures to improve the safety of prison staff, including increasing the number of body-worn cameras and introducing new training programmes," a spokesperson said.

title: Theresa May warning over police targets 'comeback'
text: She told the Police Superintendents' Association of England and Wales that the government had scrapped "top-down diktats" and urged police confidence in the new approach. "We have scrapped inappropriate top-down diktats," she said. "The days of unrealistic targets and unnecessary bureaucracy are over." The home secretary promised that the new policing model would give forces the flexibility to set their own targets and priorities. "We will continue to work with you to develop a more flexible and less bureaucratic approach to policing that keeps the public safe," she said. May's comments come amid concerns that the government is planning to reintroduce police targets. Last year, the government announced that it would be scrapping police targets in favor of a new system of "outcomes-based policing." However, there have been reports that the government is considering bringing back some form of targets. In her speech, May did not rule out the possibility of reintroducing targets, but she said that any new system would be "proportionate" and "effective." "We will not introduce targets for targets' sake," she said. "Any targets we do introduce will be proportionate and effective." May's comments were welcomed by the Police Superintendents' Association of England and Wales. "We welcome the home secretary's commitment to a more flexible and less bureaucratic approach to policing," said Paul Griffiths, the association's president. "We believe that this will give forces the freedom to set their own priorities and to focus on what matters most to their communities." The government's decision to scrap police targets has been controversial. Some argue that targets are necessary to ensure that the police are held accountable for their performance. Others argue that targets can lead to perverse incentives and can result in the police focusing on the wrong things. The government's new policing model is still in its early stages of development. It remains to be seen whether it will be successful in reducing crime and improving public confidence in the police.

title: Bristol friends raise £5,500 after free school meal upset
text: Chloe and Imogen Wood were shocked to see the lack of food given to families for free school meals packages. In one week they raised £3,460 online and more than £2,000 offline, filling a dozen trolleys of food that were split between three local charities. They were inspired to act after seeing a photo on Facebook of a free school meal package sent to a family of four. "It had two potatoes, two carrots, a small bag of pasta, one onion, a pepper and a 90p voucher for fruit and veg," Chloe said. "That is not enough to feed a family, let alone a family of four for a week." The sisters were so appalled by the image that they decided to do something about it. They launched a GoFundMe page, with the aim of raising enough money to provide 100 families with a week's worth of food. Within 24 hours, they had reached their target. A week later, they had raised more than £5,000. "We were not expecting this at all," Chloe said. "We thought we might get a few hundred pounds, but we never thought we would raise this much." The sisters have been working with three local charities - the Trussell Trust, FareShare and Children's Food Aid Network - to distribute the food. They have also been working with local businesses to get food donated at a discounted price. They are using the money raised to buy fresh fruit and vegetables, as well as long-life items such as pasta, rice and tinned food. The charities involved in the distribution of the food have been overwhelmed by the generosity of the sisters and the local community. "This is an incredible gesture from Chloe and Imogen," said a spokesperson for the Trussell Trust. "It will make a real difference to the families we support." FareShare said the donation was "a lifeline" for the charity. "We are so grateful to Chloe and Imogen for their support," a spokesperson said. "This donation will help us to continue to provide vital food supplies to people in need." The Children's Food Aid Network said the donation was "a wonderful example of community spirit." "This is a great example of how people can come together to make a difference," a spokesperson said. "We are so grateful to Chloe and Imogen for their support." The sisters say they are "humbled" by the response to their campaign. "We never thought we would be able to make such a difference," Chloe said. "We just wanted to do something to help families who are struggling."

title: Ronan Kerr's brother attacks Tom Elliott 'scum' remarks
text: Tom Elliott hit out at people waving Irish flags at Omagh Leisure Centre, calling them the "scum of Sinn Fein". On his Twitter account, Cathair Kerr, Ronan Kerr's brother, attacked the comments, saying "Look who's talking. Tom Elliott, former member of the Ulster Resistance terror gang." Elliott, a former politician for the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), has a history of making controversial statements. In 2017, he was suspended from the party after he said he would not share a platform with Sinn Fein because they were "terrorists". Kerr's brother, Ronan Kerr, was a Catholic police officer who was killed by dissident republicans in 2011. Kerr was a vocal critic of the Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI), accusing them of being too close to Sinn Fein. In a statement, the PSNI said it was "aware of the comments made by Mr Elliott and is considering its response". The incident has sparked outrage from politicians and community leaders. Sinn Fein MLA Gerry Kelly said Elliott's comments were "disgraceful" and "designed to stir up sectarian hatred". SDLP MLA Matthew O'Toole said Elliott's comments were "deeply offensive" and "have no place in our society". Alliance Party leader Naomi Long said Elliott's comments were "reckless and irresponsible" and called on him to withdraw them. The Irish government has also condemned Elliott's comments. Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Coveney said Elliott's comments were "inflammatory and unhelpful" and called on him to "reconsider his words". Elliott has since apologized for his comments, saying he "regrets the hurt and offense" they caused. However, he has not withdrawn the comments. The incident has raised concerns about the rise of sectarianism in Northern Ireland. In recent years, there have been a number of incidents of sectarian violence, including attacks on churches and community centers. Police have warned that sectarianism is a "serious threat" to peace in Northern Ireland and have urged people to report any incidents of sectarianism to the police.

title: New Treasury Chief Secretary Danny Alexander
text: The appointment of Mr Alexander to his second Cabinet post in less than a month marks the next step in his rapid political rise. Virtually unknown outside his native Scotland a decade ago, he is now one of the most influential figures in the UK government. Alexander, 41, was born in Perth and educated at the universities of Aberdeen and Edinburgh. He worked as a financial journalist before entering politics, and was elected to the House of Commons in 2005. He served as Chief Secretary to the Treasury from 2010 to 2015, and was responsible for overseeing the government's austerity programme. He was also involved in the negotiations that led to the formation of the Conservative-Liberal Democrat coalition government. Alexander was appointed Secretary of State for Scotland in 2015, but he resigned from the post in 2016 after the UK voted to leave the European Union. He has since been a vocal critic of Brexit, and has called for a second referendum on the issue. Alexander's appointment as Treasury Chief Secretary is seen as a sign that the government is taking a more pro-European stance. He is a strong supporter of the single market and the customs union, and he has said that he wants to "keep all options on the table" in the Brexit negotiations. Alexander's appointment has been welcomed by the business community. The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) said that he was "a safe pair of hands" who would "bring a wealth of experience to the role." However, some critics have questioned Alexander's credentials for the job. They point out that he has no experience in the Treasury, and that he has been a vocal critic of the government's austerity programme. Despite the criticism, Alexander is expected to be a key figure in the government's Brexit negotiations. He is a close ally of Prime Minister Theresa May, and he is likely to play a leading role in shaping the government's approach to the talks.

title: Childcare recruitment 'catastrophe' looms, say campaigners
text: By Judith Burns Education reporter New recruits to key jobs must have at least GCSE C grades in the subjects, with alternative equivalent qualifications no longer accepted. The Save our Early Years campaign group said it means a "catastrophe" is looming for the sector, with thousands of qualified candidates facing being turned away. The Department for Education (DfE) said the reforms were "not about excluding people" but ensuring all childcare professionals have strong literacy and numeracy skills. From September 2023, all level 2 and level 3 early years educators will need at least a C grade in GCSE English and maths, or an approved equivalent. This is a change from the current rules, which allow alternative qualifications, such as functional skills or entry-level certificates, to be used instead. The Save our Early Years campaign group said this will affect thousands of qualified candidates who do not have GCSEs or the approved equivalent qualifications. Neil Leitch, chief executive of the Pre-school Learning Alliance, which runs nurseries in England, said: "We are facing a recruitment catastrophe. "This new requirement will make it all but impossible for nurseries to recruit new staff, which will inevitably lead to settings having to close or reduce their opening hours." Mr Leitch said many people working in the early years sector come from disadvantaged backgrounds and may not have had the opportunity to achieve GCSEs. He said: "The vast majority of them are incredibly capable and passionate about working with young children." The DfE said the reforms were "not about excluding people" but ensuring all childcare professionals have strong literacy and numeracy skills. A DfE spokesperson said: "Children deserve the best possible start in life and we want to make sure that all early years practitioners have strong literacy and numeracy skills. "We are not seeking to exclude people from working in the sector, but to ensure they have the essential skills needed for effective practice." The DfE said alternative routes into the sector will still be available for those who do not have GCSEs or equivalent qualifications, such as apprenticeships and traineeships.

title: #ElPasochallenge: Boy responds to shooting to help community heal
text: Ruben Martinez is the youngster behind the #elpasoCHALLENGE. He wants people to carry out 22 random acts of kindness to honour the victims of the El Paso shooting. The challenge, which has quickly spread on social media, comes in response to the horrific attack on a Walmart store in Texas, which left 22 people dead. Ruben, 12, is a sixth-grader at Bassett Middle School in El Paso. He is raising money for the El Paso Victims Relief Fund, which is providing financial assistance to those affected by the shooting. Ruben says he was inspired to start the challenge after seeing a quote from the Dalai Lama: "If you want others to be happy, practise compassion. If you want to be happy, practise compassion." He says: "We have to be there for each other. We have to support each other. We have to show that we're stronger than this." The challenge has already had a huge impact, with people across the country sharing their stories of how they are carrying out acts of kindness. One woman shared how she paid for the person behind her in the grocery line. Another told how she donated blood. Ruben says he is "blown away" by the response to the challenge. "It shows that we are all connected," he says. "We can make a difference in the world, one act of kindness at a time." How to take part in the #elpasoCHALLENGE To take part in the challenge, simply carry out 22 random acts of kindness. These can be anything you want, from holding the door open for someone to giving a compliment to a stranger. Once you have completed your 22 acts of kindness, share your story on social media using the hashtag #elpasoCHALLENGE. You can also donate to the El Paso Victims Relief Fund at www.elpasovictmsrelief.org.

title: NSA workers disciplined over Snowden leaks
text: The employee was among three NSA workers sanctioned over the incident, according to an NSA memo. It is said to be the first disciplinary action taken over the breach, which the agency has previously called one of the "most significant security breaches in US history". The memo said two other employees had their security clearances revoked and were barred from accessing classified information. Snowden copied and leaked classified information about the NSA's surveillance programs, including its PRISM program, which collected data from internet companies. The leaks sparked a global debate about the balance between national security and privacy. The NSA has said that the leaks caused "significant damage" to national security. The memo did not specify the specific actions taken against the three employees. The news of the disciplinary action comes amid growing scrutiny of the NSA's surveillance programs. In June, the US Senate voted to end the NSA's bulk collection of phone records. The program was authorized under Section 215 of the Patriot Act. The House of Representatives has yet to vote on the measure. The NSA has defended the bulk collection program, saying it is a valuable tool in preventing terrorism. However, critics say the program is an invasion of privacy and has not been shown to be effective in preventing terrorism. The disciplinary action against the three NSA workers is likely to further fuel the debate about the NSA's surveillance programs. It is also likely to raise questions about the agency's ability to protect classified information.
