title: Manila district police force removed after teen deaths
text: Manila police chief Oscar Albayalde said 1,200 officers from the Caloocan district would be retrained and then assigned to other units. The move comes amid growing scrutiny of police operations amid accusations of extrajudicial killings and corruption. The Caloocan district police force has been under fire since the deaths of two teenagers in drug raids. The deaths of Kian Loyd delos Santos and Carl Angelo Arnaiz sparked outrage and protests in the Philippines. President Rodrigo Duterte has defended the police, but has also said that he will not tolerate abuses. He has ordered the police to stop conducting drug raids and has created a new task force to investigate the deaths of the teenagers. The removal of the Caloocan district police force is a significant development. It is a sign that the government is taking the allegations of extrajudicial killings and corruption seriously. However, it remains to be seen whether the retraining and reassignment of the officers will be enough to address the systemic problems within the police force. The Philippine National Police (PNP) has been plagued by allegations of corruption and abuse for years. A 2017 report by the Human Rights Watch found that the PNP had "a long history of committing grave human rights violations, including extrajudicial killings, torture, and enforced disappearances." The report also found that the PNP was "systematically failing to investigate and prosecute human rights violations committed by its officers." The PNP has denied the allegations of systemic abuse and corruption. However, the recent deaths of the two teenagers have raised serious questions about the force's commitment to human rights. The removal of the Caloocan district police force is a welcome step, but it is only a first step. The government must do more to address the systemic problems within the PNP. This includes investigating and prosecuting human rights violations, reforming the force's training and recruitment procedures, and increasing transparency and accountability.

title: Stars stay silent in X Factor protest
text: By Ian Youngs Entertainment reporter, BBC News Madness star Suggs and dance acts Orbital and Pendulum were among those who did nothing in a recording studio. They were recreating the recording session that led to the Sex Pistols' classic track "God Save the Queen". The Sex Pistols refused to sing along to the backing track, in a form of protest against the monarchy during the Queen's silver jubilee in 1977. The protesters hope to get their new version of the song to number one by the time of the Queen's diamond jubilee next year. Other stars taking part in the project include John Lydon, the singer with Public Image Ltd and former Sex Pistols frontman, Brian Eno, and Steve Mason of The Beta Band. The 2011 recording session took place on the 34th anniversary of the Sex Pistols' original protest. Orbital's main man Paul Hartnoll told BBC News: "We've been asked to be part of the recording, basically, of re-enacting that moment, and all the participants in the recording are not singing on the track." He said the recording was about "making a point" about the state of the UK. "We've recorded the backing track, which is the Pistols' backing track, but nobody's singing on it. And the reason for that is that our generation doesn't have a voice. Our generation doesn't have anything to say. The people in charge haven't got a clue." Suggs from Madness told BBC News why he got involved. "For me, the Sex Pistols' 'God Save the Queen' in 1977 was one of the most important records of my teenage years," he said. "It was a two-fingered salute to everything that was happening, the ridiculous week-long jubilee, and we've got something similar this year. "And so I think it's important that we do it again and, if we do it again, then we should do it in the same way, just in silence." Public Image Ltd singer John Lydon said the current state of the UK was more of a "joke" than it was in the 1970s. "Anybody who thinks they have a voice, doesn't," he said. "The country's a joke… It's worse than it was in '76. There's nothing." "So I think we should be very quiet, let's make a bloody noise with silence. I think it's a brilliant idea." The song is being released on 29 August on iTunes and 5 September on 7" vinyl. All profits from the sale of the single will be donated to the Crisis charity for the homeless.

title: Monmouthshire and Newport get 30 new electric car points
text: A new scheme will provide free installation to 20 businesses, thanks to funding from the EU, Welsh Government and Monmouthshire council. Ten more will be installed in most Monmouthshire town centre car parks. That means the number of public electric car points in the county will increase by more than 30. Monmouthshire County Council's climate change and transport cabinet member, Cllr Jane Pratt, said: "I'm really excited that we are able to offer this scheme to businesses and residents in Monmouthshire. "This council is committed to tackling the climate emergency and reducing our carbon footprint and this scheme is one step towards encouraging and supporting the use of electric vehicles in Monmouthshire." The scheme is open to any business in Monmouthshire and is funded by the EU Interreg NWE project - Electric Vehicle Smart Charging Across Borders (E-STOR). Firms only need to pay for the electricity used and can charge a small fee to customers to recoup some of the costs if they wish. Newport City Council has also announced it will be installing 30 new electric car charging points as part of the Ultra Low Emissions Vehicle Infrastructure Scheme (ULEVIS). The points will be available for public use at the following locations: Six in Malpas Road Five in Caerleon Road Four in Usk Way Three in Stow Hill Three in Lliswerry Square Two in Commercial Street Two in George Street Two in Kingsway Newport City Council's cabinet member for sustainability and transport, Cllr Roger Jeavons, said: "We're committed to tackling climate change and reducing air pollution in Newport. "That's why we're investing in electric vehicle charging infrastructure, to make it easier for people to switch to electric vehicles and reduce their carbon footprint. "These new charging points will be a welcome addition to the city and will help to support the growing number of electric vehicle owners." The installations in Newport are funded by the Office for Zero Emission Vehicles (OZEV) through the ULEV Infrastructure Fund.

title: The Apprentice: Series launch down 900,000 viewers
text: The Apprentice: Series launch down 900,000 viewers Thursday evening's opening episode on BBC One attracted an average of 5.5 million viewers, a 26.3% share of the available viewing audience. The launch of the 17th series marked a significant decline in viewership compared to the previous year, when 6.4 million viewers tuned in for the premiere. The decline in ratings does not come as a complete surprise, as many reality TV shows have experienced a drop in viewership in recent years. However, the margin of the decline for The Apprentice is notable, particularly given the popular appeal of Lord Sugar as the show's host. The Apprentice has long been a staple of British television, known for its cutthroat challenges and revealing insights into the world of business. Previous contestants have gone on to establish successful careers in their respective industries, including Tim Campbell, the series' first winner, and Carina Lepore, who recently served as CEO of fashion brand Missguided. Despite the decline in viewership, BBC One remains confident in the show's appeal. A spokesperson for the channel said, "The Apprentice is a hugely popular format that continues to attract a loyal audience. We are excited to see what this series has in store, with Lord Sugar putting 18 new candidates through their paces." The series launch drew a mixed reaction from critics. Some praised the fresh faces and competitive challenges, while others criticized the lack of innovation and the predictable nature of the format. Despite the contrasting opinions, The Apprentice remains one of the most talked-about shows on British television. Its ability to spark conversation and inspire viewers to pursue their own business aspirations ensures its enduring relevance. As the series progresses, it remains to be seen whether it can regain some of the viewership lost in the opening episode. With Lord Sugar's sharp wit and the determined contestants' ambitions on display, The Apprentice is sure to provide plenty of entertainment and business insights in the weeks ahead.

title: Titanic menu expected to fetch up to £70,000 at auction
text: It was owned by Elise Lurette, who was one of about 700 people who survived after the passenger liner hit an iceberg in April 1912. She was working as a maid for a family travelling on the ship when disaster struck. Her menu has been passed down through the family, and her great-nephew David Reay is now selling it along with other personal effects that belonged to his great-aunt. Mr Reay, a retired teacher from Ringwood, Hampshire, decided to auction the items to raise money for the Alzheimer's Society and the RNLI. He said: "Elise was only 21 when she was on the Titanic, and she went on to live to the grand old age of 94. "When the ship hit the iceberg she was in bed, and she recalled that the chief steward came round telling all the passengers that they should get dressed, get their lifebelts on and go on deck. "When they got on deck they were told to go back down to their cabins and wait for further instructions. "At no time did anyone tell them to get into the lifeboats. She said the general feeling was that they were safer staying on the boat than getting into the lifeboats, which they felt were getting overloaded. "It was a real last-minute thing, and she was one of the last people to get into a lifeboat. "She said the crew were really good. She said they just quietly and calmly went about getting people into the lifeboats. "She survived along with her mistress, Mrs Futrelle, and Mrs Futrelle's maid. "My great-aunt didn't talk about it very much. She didn't dwell on it, but she must have thought about it an awful lot. "My great-uncle, her husband, was a bit of a gambler, and a bit of a spendthrift, and he sold the menu about 40 years ago. I know it went to America. "I'm quite pleased it's come back to England. I think it belongs in England." The menu was printed on high-quality paper, measuring 7 1/2in by 10 1/2in, and folded in two. It was one of only a small number of first-class passenger menus to survive the sinking. It lists a dozen courses, including consomme Olga, poached salmon with mousseline sauce, roast beef, lamb, spring chicken, asparagus and Waldorf pudding.

title: Shetland Super Puma crash: Co-pilot's actions 'crucial' to survival
text: Super Puma passengers Sarah Darnley, 45, from Elgin, Gary McCrossan, 59, from Inverness, Duncan Munro, 46, from Bishop Auckland, and George Allison, 57, from Winchester, died when the aircraft came down on its approach to Sumburgh Airport in August 2013. The helicopter was operated by CHC Scotia, part of Canadian Helicopter Corporation, and carrying oil workers to and from North Sea platforms when it crashed. An investigation, published by the Air Accidents Investigation Branch (AAIB), found the co-pilot's "decisive and timely" actions "materially contributed to the survival" of the 14 other passengers and crew on board. The AAIB report found that the helicopter had been flying too fast and low on its approach to Sumburgh. The co-pilot, who was in control of the aircraft, took over from the captain seven minutes before it crashed. The report said the co-pilot had been "placed in a difficult position" because of the captain's "inadequate supervision" and "limited guidance". It said he had been "faced with a situation where he was receiving incorrect and ambiguous guidance from the captain, who appeared to have become confused and disorientated". The co-pilot had been able to take control of the aircraft and avoid obstacles as it came in to land, but had been unable to prevent it from crashing into the sea. The AAIB said the co-pilot's actions had been "crucial" to the survival of the other passengers and crew on board. The report also made a number of recommendations to the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and CHC Scotia, including improving training for pilots and providing them with better support. The CAA said it would be "carefully considering" the recommendations and would "take any necessary action to improve safety". CHC Scotia said it was "deeply saddened" by the loss of life and that it was "committed to working with the authorities to improve safety".

title: Councils reject two-thirds of requests for care
text: Councils reject two-thirds of requests for care By Nick Triggle Health correspondent Nearly 1.85 million requests for support were made last year, but just over 650,000 people received help. Councils have been warning for a number of years that they are struggling to meet demand for the care that people are legally entitled to. This is putting a huge strain on the system, with some people having to wait years for the help they need. The figures were obtained by BBC News through a Freedom of Information request to the Association of Directors of Adult Social Services. They show that the number of requests for care has increased by 20% in the past four years, while the number of people receiving help has only increased by 5%. This means that councils are now rejecting two-thirds of requests for care. The vast majority of requests for care come from older people, who need help with things like washing, dressing and eating. But councils are also seeing an increasing number of requests from younger people, who may have disabilities or mental health problems. The Local Government Association said the figures were "deeply concerning". "Councils are facing an impossible task in trying to meet the growing demand for care," said David Simmonds, chairman of the LGA's community and wellbeing board. "We need the government to urgently provide us with more resources to help us meet this demand." The government has said it is committed to providing more funding for social care, but it has not yet said how much this will be. In the meantime, councils are having to make difficult decisions about who to provide care for. This is often a matter of life and death, as people who are not receiving the care they need are more likely to end up in hospital or even die. The BBC has spoken to a number of people who have been refused care by their council. One is a 65-year-old woman with dementia who lives alone. She needs help with washing, dressing and eating, but her council has told her that she is not eligible for care. Another is a 40-year-old man who has a learning disability. He needs help with managing his finances and finding work, but his council has told him that he is not eligible for care. The government has said that it is committed to ensuring that everyone who needs care receives it. But the figures obtained by BBC News suggest that this is not happening.

title: Japan frees Chinese boat captain amid diplomatic row
text: Japan had accused Zhan Qixiong of deliberately ramming two patrol vessels near disputed islands in the East China Sea. China said his detention was "illegal and invalid", and cut off ministerial-level contacts with Japan. The release came after four tense months of heightened diplomatic tensions. The captain's release came after a Japanese court rejected a request to extend his detention without charge and ordered his immediate release. Zhan Qixiong returned to China, where he was greeted as a hero by Chinese officials and the media. The incident that led to the captain's arrest took place near the Senkaku Islands, which are controlled by Japan but also claimed by China. The islands are known as the Diaoyu Islands in China. Both countries have been engaged in a territorial dispute over the islands for decades. The dispute over the islands is a major source of tension between Japan and China. In recent years, there have been frequent incidents involving Chinese fishing vessels and Japanese patrol boats in the area. The release of Zhan Qixiong is likely to ease tensions between the two countries, but the underlying dispute over the islands remains unresolved. The release of Zhan Qixiong has been met with mixed reactions in Japan. Some people have welcomed the move, arguing that it will help to improve relations between Japan and China. Others have criticized the government for releasing the captain, arguing that he should have been prosecuted for his alleged crimes. The Japanese government has said that it will continue to work with China to resolve the dispute over the Senkaku Islands. However, it is clear that the issue will continue to be a source of tension between the two countries for the foreseeable future.

title: Solar Impulse aeroplane reaches Ohio
text: The zero-fuel aircraft arrived in Dayton at 21:56 local time (01:56 GMT) having flown from Tulsa, Oklahoma. The 1,113km journey took pilot Andre Borschberg about 16 hours to complete, a relatively short hop for the aircraft that has already covered more than 35,000km on its round-the-world journey. The aircraft is powered by more than 17,000 solar cells, which charge batteries that drive the propellers. It has a wingspan of 72m (236ft) - wider than a Boeing 747 - but weighs only 2,300kg (5,100lb) - less than a family car. The plane's progress has been delayed by bad weather and technical problems, but the team is now hoping to complete the circumnavigation by the end of July. The aircraft is scheduled to make its next stop in Pennsylvania, before crossing the Atlantic to Europe. If successful, it will be the first time a solar-powered aircraft has flown around the world. The plane's journey has been closely followed by environmentalists, who see it as a symbol of the potential for renewable energy. The aircraft's success could help to inspire the development of new technologies that could reduce our reliance on fossil fuels. However, some critics have questioned the environmental benefits of the aircraft, arguing that it is too expensive and impractical to be a viable alternative to fossil fuels. They also point out that the aircraft's batteries are made from lithium, which is a finite resource. Despite the criticism, the Solar Impulse team remains confident that the aircraft can make a significant contribution to the fight against climate change. The team hopes that the aircraft's success will inspire people to think differently about energy and encourage them to adopt more sustainable lifestyles.

title: Virgin's Unity plane rockets skyward
text: By Jonathan Amos BBC Science Correspondent Chief pilot, Scotsman Dave Mackay, and co-pilot, American Mike Masucci, took the vehicle to almost 89km (55 miles) during a four-hour flight. It was the first of five powered test flights planned over the next few months. "It was the most exhilarating moment of my career," Mike Masucci said. "We've just changed the world," Dave Mackay commented. Virgin Orbit is the brainchild of Sir Richard Branson who says the goal is to "open up space for business". His company is a relative latecomer to the emerging small satellite launch market. But it has the backing of big money investors and is also aiming to bring down the cost of access to orbit. "We're committed to making this a routine service," said Will Pomerantz, the Virgin Orbit chief technology officer. "Our plan is to fly every month; there's a huge market for this." The launches will be conducted from various locations around the world, depending on the needs of the customers. The LauncherOne rocket is carried aloft under the wing of a specially modified Boeing 747 aircraft. Once the plane reaches the appropriate altitude and position, the rocket is released and fires its engine to propel itself and its payload into orbit. This "air-launch" system is less expensive than the more traditional method of launching rockets from a ground-based pad. Virgin Orbit says it can provide flexible and responsive launch services, putting satellites into orbits ranging from a few hundred kilometres up to 5,000km in altitude. The company is also developing a reusable first stage for its LauncherOne, which will further reduce the cost of operations. "We're at the very beginning of a new era in space launch," said George Whitesides, chief executive of Virgin Galactic and Virgin Orbit. "The key is to reduce the cost of launching small satellites into orbit. That's what will open up the market to new technologies and applications." The first commercial flight of Virgin Orbit's LauncherOne is targeted for later this year.

title: Steve Easterbrook's new McJob
text: By Jamie Robertson Presenter, BBC World News The former Watford Grammar School boy is seen as the man who revitalised the group's UK business. And McDonald's needs a turnaround specialist as it struggles with its image, assailed by criticism over everything from its food to its role in creating obesity and paying low wages. Steve Easterbrook says he's not concerned about the naysayers. He told me that he's a "big believer" in the power of the McDonald's brand. "It's one of the most recognised brands in the world," he said. "And it's a brand that people have a lot of emotional attachment to." Easterbrook says he's going to focus on improving the quality of the food, making the restaurants more welcoming, and providing better customer service. He also wants to make the company more environmentally friendly. But it won't be easy. McDonald's is facing competition from a growing number of fast-food chains, and it's also struggling with changing consumer tastes. People are increasingly looking for healthier, more sustainable food options. Easterbrook is aware of the challenges, but he's confident that he can turn things around. He says he's a "results-oriented person" and he's not afraid to make tough decisions. "I'm not here to tinker around the edges," he said. "I'm here to make a difference." Only time will tell if Easterbrook can deliver on his promises. But he's certainly not short of ambition. He wants to make McDonald's the "world's best quick-service restaurant". If he succeeds, it will be a remarkable turnaround for a company that has been struggling for years. But if he fails, it will be another nail in the coffin for one of the world's most iconic brands. Steve Easterbrook has also pledged to improve McDonald's UK operations, saying he wants to make the company "the best place to eat and work" in the country. He said he would focus on improving the quality of food, making restaurants more welcoming, and providing better customer service.

title: Church of England to keep Amazon shares despite Welby criticism
text: The Church Times has revealed Amazon was among the 20 biggest global investments by the Church last year. A statement from the CofE said it considered "a range of factors" in its investment decisions, including companies' environmental, social and governance (ESG) performance. The Church's ethical investment policy is designed to "promote the flourishing of all creation and the common good," a spokesperson said. "This includes investing in companies that are committed to reducing their carbon footprint, respecting human rights, and promoting economic justice." Amazon has been criticized by some for its labor practices, environmental record, and tax avoidance strategies. However, the Church said it believes that "engaging with companies" is the best way to encourage them to improve their ESG performance. "We believe that by investing in companies like Amazon, we can have a positive impact on their behavior and encourage them to make changes that will benefit all of society," the spokesperson said. The Church's decision to keep Amazon shares has been met with mixed reactions. Some have praised the Church for its ethical stance, while others have accused it of hypocrisy. The Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, has previously criticized Amazon for its labor practices. In 2018, he said that the company's "ruthless" treatment of its workers was "a scandal." However, the Church said that it is "confident" that Amazon is committed to improving its ESG performance. "We will continue to monitor the company's progress and engage with them on issues of concern," the spokesperson said. The Church of England is one of the world's largest investors, with a portfolio worth around £10 billion. It has been investing in ethical funds since the 1980s. In recent years, the Church has come under increasing pressure to divest from companies that are involved in activities that are harmful to the environment or society. However, the Church has said that it believes that engagement is the best way to encourage companies to change their behavior.

title: UK unemployment rises to 1.7m
text: That is the first increase since the May-July period of last year. The unemployment rate remained at 5.1%, which is still near historic lows. However, the number of people claiming unemployment benefits rose by 10,400 to 1.2 million. The rise in unemployment was driven by a fall in the number of people in employment, which decreased by 56,000 to 32.5 million. This was the first quarterly fall in employment since the three months to May 2020. The number of people economically inactive, which includes those who are not working and not looking for work, increased by 25,000 to 8.9 million. This was driven by an increase in the number of people looking after family or home, which rose by 44,000 to 1.4 million. The latest figures come as the UK economy faces a number of challenges, including rising inflation, the war in Ukraine, and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The Bank of England has raised interest rates to try to curb inflation, but this is also expected to slow economic growth. The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Rishi Sunak, said that the government was "monitoring the situation closely" and was "committed to supporting people through this challenging period." He said that the government would "continue to provide targeted support to those most in need, and help people into work." The TUC General Secretary, Frances O'Grady, said that the rise in unemployment was "a worrying sign" that the UK economy was "heading in the wrong direction." She said that the government needed to "do more to support people who are losing their jobs" and to "boost the economy." The CBI Director-General, Tony Danker, said that the rise in unemployment was "a reminder that the cost of living crisis is having a real impact on businesses and individuals." He said that the government needed to "take action to support businesses and households" and to "invest in skills and infrastructure to create jobs."

title: Manchester Arena Inquiry: Area where Abedi hid 'not our domain'
text: Showsec supervisor David Middleton said he had never been instructed to check the mezzanine area. "We were to keep the steps clear but we were not to check the mezzanine area. That was not our domain," he said. "If someone was loitering there, then somebody else would have to move them on." The inquiry heard that Abedi had been seen "milling around" on the mezzanine level for 45 minutes before the explosion. Mr Middleton said that, had he known Abedi was there, he would have challenged him. "The minute I knew he was there, I would have challenged him to say, what are you doing there? Can I help you? What are you waiting for?" The inquiry also heard from Showsec supervisor Paul Wright, who was in charge of the evacuation of the arena after the explosion. Mr Wright said that he had not been trained in how to deal with a bomb attack. "I'm not a security expert. I'm just a doorman," he said. "I know what I'm supposed to do for crowd control, but I don't know what I'm supposed to do for a bomb attack." The inquiry heard that Mr Wright had been given a "briefing" on what to do in the event of a bomb attack, but that this had only lasted for about 10 minutes. Mr Wright said that he had not been given any specific instructions on how to evacuate the arena in the event of a bomb attack. "I had to make it up as I went along," he said. The inquiry is continuing.

title: Sturgeon wants Indyref2 in 'second half of 2020'
text: Speaking in Dublin Ms Sturgeon said the "latter half" of next year would be the "right time" for a new poll. The SNP leader predicted victory in any future referendum. Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson expressed a "cynical" viewpoint in response to Sturgeon's comments. "It is no coincidence that Nicola Sturgeon is plotting a second referendum during the Brexit process," she said. "She knows that this is the only opportunity she will have to rip the United Kingdom apart. "She is not interested in what is best for Scotland. She is only interested in securing her goal of independence — no matter the cost." Meanwhile Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard said that the first minister had put "narrow nationalism ahead of the national interest" by outlining plans for a new poll. He said: "Nicola Sturgeon has made clear she is prepared to put her own party's future ahead of the interests of the people of Scotland. "The timing of a second independence referendum is not in the national interest and most people do not want one. "Nicola Sturgeon is putting narrow nationalism ahead of the national interest." Responding to the criticism, Ms Sturgeon hit back by accusing the Conservatives and Labour of being "out of touch" with the Scottish people. She said: "The people of Scotland have the right to choose their own future. "The Tories and Labour are out of touch with the people of Scotland if they think that we should be denied that right." The first minister also said that she was "confident" that Scotland would vote for independence in a second referendum. "I am confident that the people of Scotland will vote for independence when they are given the chance," she said. "We have a strong case for independence and I believe that the people of Scotland will make the right choice."

title: Why are young Indians killing themselves?
text: Soutik Biswas Delhi correspondent If new research is to be believed, a disturbingly high number of young Indians are losing the courage to live. A study published in The Lancet Child & Adolescent Health journal finds that suicide is the leading cause of death among 15 to 19-year-olds in India. In 2016, an estimated 25,000 children and teenagers died by suicide in India. That's more than the number of people who died in road accidents in the same year. The study, which was conducted by researchers at the National Institute of Mental Health and Neurosciences in Bengaluru, found that the suicide rate among young Indians has been increasing steadily over the past decade. In 2001, the suicide rate among 15 to 19-year-olds was 8.8 per 100,000. By 2016, it had increased to 15.3 per 100,000. The researchers found that there are a number of factors that are contributing to the high suicide rate among young Indians. These include: Academic pressure: Indian students are under a lot of pressure to succeed in school. They are often expected to get good grades in order to get into a good college and get a good job. This pressure can lead to anxiety, depression, and suicidal thoughts. Family problems: Many young Indians experience family problems, such as divorce, domestic violence, and financial difficulties. These problems can also lead to anxiety, depression, and suicidal thoughts. Social isolation: Young Indians who feel isolated and alone are more likely to experience suicidal thoughts. This can be due to a number of factors, such as bullying, cyberbullying, and discrimination. Mental health problems: Young Indians who have mental health problems, such as depression, anxiety, and bipolar disorder, are at an increased risk of suicide. The study's authors say that the high suicide rate among young Indians is a serious public health problem. They call for more research to be done on the causes of suicide among young Indians and for more effective suicide prevention programs to be developed. If you are thinking about suicide, please get help. You can call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255 or visit their website at https://suicidepreventionlifeline.org/.

title: Bulgarian writer wins BBC Short Story Award
text: The winner was announced at a ceremony in London, broadcast live on Radio 4 arts show Front Row. Penkov takes the £15,000 prize, while the runner-up, South African writer Henrietta Rose-Innes, wins £2,500. Penkov's story, "The House", is set in a remote village in Bulgaria and follows the story of an elderly woman who lives in a house filled with memories of a past life. The judges praised the story for its "lyrical and evocative prose" and its "profound exploration of themes of memory, loss, and longing." Rose-Innes' story, "The Fog", is set in Cape Town and follows the story of a young woman who is haunted by the memory of a traumatic event. The judges praised the story for its "atmospheric and suspenseful writing" and its "powerful exploration of the themes of guilt and redemption." Penkov said he was "overwhelmed and honoured" to win the award. "I'm so grateful to the BBC for giving me this opportunity to share my work with a wider audience," he said. Rose-Innes said she was "thrilled and humbled" to be a runner-up. "It's a huge honour to be recognised by the BBC, and I'm so grateful to the judges for their support," she said. The BBC Short Story Award is one of the most prestigious literary awards in the world. It is open to writers from all over the world, and the winner is selected by a panel of judges who are experts in the field of literature. The award was founded in 1984, and has been won by some of the world's most famous writers, including Salman Rushdie, Margaret Atwood, and Zadie Smith. In addition to the cash prize, the winner of the BBC Short Story Award is also given the opportunity to have their story published in the BBC's prestigious literary magazine, The London Magazine.

title: Volkswagen's UK sales fell in October, says SMMT
text: The motor group has been embroiled in controversy over the level of emissions from its diesel and petrol cars. Sales of VW branded cars fell 9.8%, Skoda dropped 3% and SEAT was down 8.3%. The figures show that registrations of new cars dropped for the third month in a row in October, down 1.7% compared with the same month last year, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT). Overall, diesel cars accounted for just over half of all new vehicles, down from 53% a year ago. The number of petrol cars registered rose 4.3%, while demand for hybrid and electric models increased 17.7%. SMMT chief executive Mike Hawes said: "October's figures continue the recent trend of a slowing new car market, with consumer and business confidence hit by a range of factors. "These include ongoing economic uncertainty, rising interest rates and high fuel prices." The drop in VW sales comes as the German automaker faces a barrage of lawsuits and investigations over its use of emissions-cheating devices in its diesel cars. The company has admitted to installing software in millions of vehicles that allowed them to pass emissions tests, even though they emitted far more pollutants than allowed under the law. The scandal has damaged VW's reputation and led to a sharp decline in sales. In the UK, VW sales fell 20% in 2016, the biggest drop of any major automaker. In addition to the emissions scandal, VW is also facing challenges due to Brexit. The company has warned that a no-deal Brexit would disrupt its supply chain and could lead to job losses in the UK. Despite the challenges, VW remains one of the largest automakers in the world. The company is investing heavily in new technology, including electric vehicles and autonomous driving. VW is also hoping to rebuild its reputation by investing in sustainability and social responsibility. The company has announced plans to become carbon neutral by 2050 and to invest in renewable energy and electric vehicles.

title: Dashcam footage submission website goes live
text: The website allows visitors to upload videos before sending footage to the right police force. It also redirects visitors to those forces with their own submission websites. The site is being run in partnership with the National Police Chiefs' Council (NPCC) and the College of Policing. Deputy Chief Constable Adrian Hanstock, NPCC lead for roads policing, said: "We are pleased to be working with the BBC on this initiative which provides a simple and effective way for the public to submit footage to the police, whilst also signposting to forces that have their own online systems. "We know that dashcam footage can be vital in helping us investigate collisions and other incidents on the road. This new tool will make it even easier for people to share their footage with the police and help us keep our roads safe." The website is the latest in a series of initiatives from the BBC to support road safety. In 2018, the BBC launched a campaign called "Share the Road" which aimed to raise awareness of the dangers of dangerous and inconsiderate driving. The BBC has also worked with the police to produce a number of films and documentaries about road safety. The new dashcam footage submission website is part of the BBC's ongoing commitment to road safety. The BBC believes that everyone has a role to play in making our roads safer, and that by working together we can make a real difference. How to submit footage To submit footage to the police, visit the BBC's dashcam footage submission website. You will need to provide some basic information about the incident, such as the date, time and location. You will also need to upload the footage. The website will then send your footage to the right police force. If the police force has its own submission website, you will be redirected to that website. The police will review your footage and decide whether to take any further action. What happens to my footage? The police will use your footage to investigate the incident. They may also use it to educate other drivers about the dangers of dangerous and inconsiderate driving. Your footage will be stored securely by the police. It will not be shared with any other organisations without your consent. How can I find out more? For more information about the BBC's dashcam footage submission website, please visit the website or contact the BBC Press Office.

title: India raises withdrawal limit as rupee anger mounts
text: Customers can now withdraw up to 2,500 rupees a day from cash machines, rather than 2,000, the finance ministry said. Many cash machines are not working because they have run out of money. The move comes after days of protests across India over the government's shock decision to ban high-denomination banknotes. The ban has caused chaos for ordinary Indians, who rely on cash for most transactions. Long queues have formed outside banks as people try to exchange their old banknotes for new ones. Some people have been forced to sleep on the streets overnight to secure a place in the queue. The government has said that the ban is necessary to combat corruption and tax evasion. However, critics say that it is causing more harm than good. The opposition Congress party has called for the government to reconsider the ban, saying that it is punishing ordinary Indians for the crimes of a few. The government has also been criticized for not doing enough to prepare for the ban. Many banks have not been able to cope with the demand for new banknotes, and there have been reports of cash machines being empty. The central bank has said that it is working to improve the situation. However, it is likely to take some time for the cash shortage to ease. In the meantime, the government has urged people to use electronic payments instead of cash. However, many people in India do not have access to electronic payment systems. The ban on high-denomination banknotes has also had a negative impact on the Indian economy. Businesses have reported a sharp decline in sales, and some factories have been forced to close. The government has said that it is committed to supporting the economy during this difficult time. However, it is clear that the ban on high-denomination banknotes is having a significant impact on ordinary Indians.

title: Objective reality exists, says UK minister Matt Hancock
text: By Brian Wheeler Political reporter Matt Hancock said it was "something of a disappointment" that he had to state publicly that "objective reality exists". But it was "incredibly important" to hang on to that principle in the face of "post-truth" and "alternative facts". The health secretary made his comments in an article for The Times Red Box. In it, he said: "The very idea that objective reality may not exist is not only dangerous but also self-defeating. "If we cannot agree on what is true, how can we possibly hope to make progress on anything? "Whether it's climate change, the economy or even just the day-to-day decisions we make in our own lives, we need to be able to rely on a shared understanding of the world around us." Hancock said that the rise of social media had made it easier for people to live in "echo chambers", where they only encounter views that they agree with. This, he said, had led to a "fragmentation of our society" and made it harder to have "meaningful conversations" about important issues. He called on people to "be more open to hearing different perspectives" and to "challenge our own beliefs" from time to time. "It's not always easy, but it's essential if we want to live in a society where we can all understand each other," he said. Hancock's comments come at a time when there is growing concern about the spread of misinformation and disinformation online. A recent study by the University of Oxford found that people are more likely to believe false information if they see it shared by their friends and family on social media. This, the study said, could have a "significant impact" on public discourse and could make it harder to address important issues such as climate change and the economy.

title: Tunisia attack: Sousse killer Rezgui 'trained in Libya'

title: Fear suppressing neurons found
text: By Melissa Hogenboom Science reporter, BBC Radio Science These inhibitory neurons ensure that a neutral memory of a context or location is not contaminated by an unpleasant event occurring at the same time. The team says their work could help to explain why sometimes people have difficulty forgetting traumatic experiences. The research is published in the journal Nature Neuroscience. "We can all recall a time when we experienced something unpleasant, like a bad meal or a car accident," said Dr Andrea Lobo, from the Champalimaud Centre for the Unknown in Lisbon, Portugal. "Normally, we would remember that experience as being associated with that place or time, but in some cases, that link can become too strong and we end up associating the place or time with the negative experience, even when we are not there. "This is what happens in post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), when people have flashbacks and nightmares about a traumatic event." The team wanted to understand how the brain prevents this from happening normally. They used optogenetics, a technique that allows them to control the activity of specific neurons using light, to inhibit a type of neuron in the hippocampus of mice. The hippocampus is a brain region involved in memory formation. They found that inhibiting these neurons caused the mice to associate a neutral place with an unpleasant experience, even though they were not in that place at the time. "This suggests that these neurons are normally responsible for preventing us from making these kinds of incorrect associations," said Dr Lobo. "Our findings could help to explain why some people have difficulty forgetting traumatic experiences. In these people, these inhibitory neurons may not be working properly, which could lead to the development of PTSD." The team now hopes to investigate whether these neurons are also involved in other memory disorders, such as Alzheimer's disease. "We know that memory loss is a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease, but we don't know exactly what causes it," said Dr Lobo. "It's possible that these inhibitory neurons could be involved, so we want to investigate this further."

title: Global dip in renewable energy investment
text: By Mark Kinver Environment reporter, BBC News It said investment fell for the second year in a row because of cheaper technology, but also as a result of uncertainty surrounding the global economy and the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The report, from the UN Environment Programme and Bloomberg New Energy Finance, found that 65% of global renewable energy markets are now cost-competitive compared with fossil fuels. This has caused a sharp fall in investment in new projects, particularly wind and solar, which have become less profitable. But concerns over energy security and the need to tackle the climate crisis have led analysts to warn that clean energy investment needs to be ramped up, not reduced. "In the midst of a global energy crisis and climate emergency, new investment in fossil fuel infrastructure is simply out of step with reality," said Inger Andersen, executive director of UNEP. "We need to move towards a new energy economy that is more equitable and sustainable." The report found that investment in renewable energy in China, the world's largest emitter of greenhouse gases, fell by 17% in 2022 to $92.6bn. This is due in part to the country's zero-Covid policy, which has disrupted supply chains. But investment also fell in Europe, the second largest market, by 24% to $55.6bn. This is due to the impact of the war in Ukraine, which has made energy prices more volatile and created economic uncertainty. The US, however, bucked the trend, with investment in renewable energy increasing by 31% to $65.5bn. This is due in part to the Biden administration's support for clean energy, as well as the growing demand for electricity from renewable sources. Despite the overall decline in investment, the report found that the share of renewable energy in the global energy mix is still growing. In 2022, renewable energy accounted for 29% of global electricity generation, up from 26% in 2021. This is due in part to the falling cost of renewable energy technology, as well as the increasing demand for clean energy from businesses and consumers. The report's authors said that the world is still on track to achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement, which aims to limit global warming to 1.5C above pre-industrial levels. But they warned that investment in renewable energy needs to be accelerated in order to meet these goals.

title: British bluebells 'have advantage over Spanish bluebells'
text: By Helen Briggs BBC News The introduced Spanish variety has lower fertility and is unlikely to wipe out the native plant, according to genetic tests. The Spanish bluebell has been spreading rapidly across the UK, particularly in woodlands. It has larger blue flowers than the native bluebell and flowers around two weeks earlier. Some experts have expressed concern that the Spanish bluebell could eventually outcompete the native plant. However, the new research suggests that the native bluebell has a significant advantage. The scientists compared the fertility of the two species in the laboratory. They found that the Spanish bluebell produced fewer seeds than the native bluebell. They also found that the Spanish bluebell seeds were less likely to germinate and grow into seedlings. The researchers say that their findings suggest that the native bluebell is unlikely to be wiped out by the Spanish bluebell. "Our results suggest that the native bluebell is likely to be able to persist alongside the Spanish bluebell," said Dr. Richard Ennos, one of the researchers from the University of Edinburgh. "This is good news, as the native bluebell is an important part of our natural heritage." The researchers say that their findings do not mean that the Spanish bluebell is not a threat to the native plant. They say that the Spanish bluebell could still have a negative impact on the native bluebell population, for example by reducing the number of pollinators available to the native plant. However, the researchers say that their findings do provide some reassurance that the native bluebell is not likely to be wiped out by the Spanish bluebell. The study was published in the journal AoB Plants.

title: UK seeks new no-deal Brexit freight plan
text: The hurried ferry procurement process as the UK prepared to leave the EU on 29 March cost taxpayers more than £85m. That included £78m for two vessels that were never used and remain tied up in Belfast Lough. The Department for Transport (DfT) told the National Audit Office (NAO) it chartered the ferries "to provide additional resilience" in case there was disruption at Channel crossings after Brexit. But the NAO said there was a "lack of clarity" about what resilience meant and whether the procurement process represented value for money for the taxpayer. The report also found that the DfT had not put enough effort into considering how the ferries would be used, which led to delays and inefficiencies. For example, the DfT had not considered whether the ferries would need to be modified to meet UK regulations, which delayed their deployment. The NAO said the DfT had now taken steps to improve its ferry procurement process, but it said there was "more to do" to ensure that taxpayers' money is being spent wisely. The DfT said it was "disappointed" with the NAO's findings, but it accepted the recommendations and was working to implement them. The department said it had "learned lessons" from the ferry procurement process and was "confident" that it would be better prepared for any future no-deal Brexit. The NAO's report comes as the UK government is preparing for the possibility of leaving the EU without a deal on 31 October. The government has said it will "do everything necessary" to ensure that the UK is ready for a no-deal Brexit, including chartering additional ferries. However, the NAO's report suggests that the government may need to do more to ensure that taxpayers' money is being spent wisely on Brexit preparations.

title: Sugababe changes 'hard on Amelle'
text: By Natalie Jamieson Newsbeat entertainment reporter It was announced on the band's website that 25-year-old Amelle would be taking time out at the end of the girls' current Get Sexy tour for personal reasons. Could this be the first step towards the end of the Sugababes? They're one of the most successful girl bands ever. They've had a string of hits since they first got together in 1998. But they've had their troubles over the years. Mutya Buena left in 2005. Then Heidi Range took over from her. Amelle replaced Keisha in 2009. And now Amelle's decided to step away. I've spoken to some of the fans who've been following the Sugababes' career for years. Amelle is the fourth different member who's sung on their songs. "It's just a bit weird," said 16-year-old Charlotte. "I feel like I've got to learn new names and faces all the time." Another fan, Lucy, said: "It's not fair on the fans to keep changing the line-up." But despite the changes, the Sugababes have kept going and have had plenty of hit records. "They've always managed to reinvent themselves, so I'm sure they'll be fine," said one fan called James. However, I don't think it's as simple as that. I think the Sugababes are at a crossroads. If Amelle does decide to leave, it could be the end of the band as we know it. The other girls could try to find another replacement. But would it be the same? Or they could decide to call it a day. Whatever happens, I think it's fair to say that the Sugababes will never be quite the same again. title: Asbestos: Cwmcarn High School could reopen after scare
text: Cwmcarn High School in Caerphilly county closed in October after a report said asbestos posed a threat to health. But the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) says it is an "essentially uncontaminated school" after new tests. A section of the school's roof was replaced over the weekend, and air tests on Monday came back clear. The school will now reopen on Tuesday with the HSE confirming that the school is safe. title: US slavery: How is America marking the 400th anniversary?
text: Why is the date significant? In 1619, a ship arrived in an English settlement in what is now the US state of Virginia, carrying some 20 captured Africans. It's the first documented arrival of enslaved Africans in what would become the United States. The 1619 Project, a Pulitzer Prize-winning initiative from The New York Times Magazine, has drawn attention to the lasting impact of slavery in the US. It has argued that the country's history has been shaped by slavery and its legacy in ways that are often overlooked. To mark the 400th anniversary, a number of events and initiatives have been planned. The Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture is hosting a year-long exhibition entitled 'Slavery and Freedom'. The exhibition tells the story of slavery in the US from its beginnings to the present day. Other events include a national day of remembrance on August 20, the date when the first enslaved Africans arrived in Virginia. There will also be a series of lectures, workshops, and community events. The 400th anniversary of the arrival of enslaved Africans in the US is an important opportunity to reflect on the country's history and the legacy of slavery. It is a chance to learn from the past and to work towards a more just and equitable future. Here are some additional perspectives on the 400th anniversary: Ibram X. Kendi, author of 'How to Be an Antiracist': "The 400th anniversary of the arrival of enslaved Africans in the United States is a time to reflect on the deep and enduring legacy of slavery in our country. It is a time to recommit ourselves to the fight for racial justice and to create a more just and equitable society for all." Nikole Hannah-Jones, creator of 'The 1619 Project': "The 400th anniversary of the arrival of enslaved Africans in the United States is a time to remember the millions of people who were enslaved, the brutality they endured, and the lasting legacy of slavery. It is also a time to celebrate the resilience of the African American community and the progress we have made towards racial justice." Bryan Stevenson, founder of the Equal Justice Initiative: "The 400th anniversary of the arrival of enslaved Africans in the United States is a time to confront the dark chapters of our history and to recommit ourselves to the pursuit of justice. It is a time to remember the victims of slavery and to work towards a day when all Americans are treated with dignity and respect."

title: The Prodigy and Slash top Friday Download Festival bill
text: By Del Crookes Newsbeat reporter at Download Festival The dance band were 20 minutes late for their set but made up for it with more than an hour of their infectious beats and wild stage show. Fireworks exploded, dancers in animal costumes roamed the stage and frontman Keith Flint showed off his trademark wild hair during tracks such as Breathe and Firestarter. But it was the rockers who seemed to be the favourites of the Friday night crowd - whether it was US band Stone Sour, Welsh rockers Bullet For My Valentine or Los Angeles metallers Slipknot. Stone Sour frontman Corey Taylor wore full make-up and sang and screamed his way through the likes of Get Inside and Through Glass. He even jumped down into the crowd and walked across the barrier at one point. Bullet For My Valentine sang about tears, pain and anger - but got the whole crowd moving with tracks like Your Betrayal, Tears Don't Fall and Scream Aim Fire. As night fell, Slipknot took to the stage in their trademark masks. The crowd went wild for Duality, Psychosocial and Wait And Bleed during a hard-hitting set featuring smoke, flames and a giant stage show. Frontman Corey Taylor said the crowd had been "f awesome". "There's fans out there that know the lyrics better than we do, they sing the songs louder than we do and there's nothing more beautiful," he said. "We are Slipknot, you are our family and we love you." The day had begun with the return of thrash metal legends Megadeth. They played a crowd-pleasing set featuring Hangar 18, Symphony of Destruction and Holy Wars. They closed with Peace Sells, with frontman Dave Mustaine saying: "We'd like to thank you all for coming out here and supporting live music - because without you there would be no us."

title: Redcar Regent Cinema demolition inspires memory 'flood'
text: Redcar's Regent Cinema opened as a music hall, the Pavilion, in 1928, and was where Larry Grayson, performing under stage name Billy Breen, coined his "shut that door" catchphrase. It closed in 1989, and the memories of its halcyon days flooded back to many as demolition work began this week. Photos from the cinema's heyday show a glamorous main entrance with staff in smart uniforms greeting filmgoers. Michael Grainge, who lives in Redcar, was nine when he first visited in 1967. "I can remember the Central Cafe next door and the old-fashioned bar where you could get lemonade and a packet of crisps," he said. "I think they sold ice cream during the intervals but you had to have a dish with an ice cream wafer in it." His memories, he said, "came flooding back" on Monday when he visited the former building. Others shared their memories on social media after seeing the work begin on Monday. "I can remember sitting on my dad's knee, he would normally fall asleep and I would get away with eating the whole box of chocolates," said one. "My ex-husband worked there when he was at school, he said the boxes full of film canisters were huge and he would try and stand in them," said another. It held 2,200 people in its prime and was also used to host bingo, dances and concerts. Dave Robb, 63, said he saw everyone from Showaddywaddy to Chas and Dave perform there. "I have seen films with mates and taken my kids when they were young," he said. "It was part of the area's history and culture - it's sad to see it go." Redcar and Cleveland Council sold the building in 2018 due to the cost of ongoing repairs. It then passed into private ownership and plans for flats and a hotel on the site were approved.

title: Coronavirus: Almost 900 Manchester Airports Group job cuts
text: Manchester Airports Group (MAG) said 465 roles were under threat at Manchester Airport as well as 376 at London Stansted Airport and 51 at East Midlands Airport. It confirmed it is "beginning a consultation process with trade unions and employee representatives". Charlie Cornish, MAG's chief executive, said: "These are deeply regrettable steps. We know there is more to do and we're committed to emerging from this crisis as a stronger and more sustainable business, but right now our focus is on making the right decisions to protect as many jobs as possible in the future." It comes after airports across the UK have been severely impacted by the coronavirus pandemic, with the number of passengers flying plummeting. MAG had already announced plans to cut 1,250 jobs in August, and it has now confirmed that the majority of those roles will be lost. The group said it "will explore all possible options" to avoid compulsory redundancies and said it was "committed to supporting all affected colleagues". John Holland-Kaye, Heathrow Airport's chief executive, said plans to cut 25% of its workforce were "very difficult" but "are essential". He said: "We are doing everything we can to protect as many jobs as we can and to support our people through this very difficult time. We will continue to work with our colleagues, the government and the wider aviation industry to ensure the UK maintains a world-class aviation sector." The cuts come as the aviation industry continues to be hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic. Earlier this week, British Airways announced plans to cut up to 12,000 jobs, while Ryanair said it could cut up to 3,000 jobs. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has warned that the airline industry could lose $84bn (£63bn) this year, and that passenger numbers could fall by 55%. title: Female Islamic clerics in Indonesia issue rare child marriage fatwa
text: The fatwa, which is not legally binding but will be influential, was issued after a three-day congress of female clerics in the country. The clerics urged the government to raise the minimum legal age of marriage for girls from 16 to 18, in line with the Convention on the Rights of the Child, which Indonesia has ratified. Child marriage is a serious problem in Indonesia, with an estimated 1.2 million girls married before the age of 18. The practice is particularly prevalent in rural areas and among poor families. The fatwa issued by the female clerics is a significant step towards addressing the problem of child marriage in Indonesia. The fatwa also urges the government to take steps to prevent child marriage, such as raising the legal age of marriage and providing education on the harmful effects of child marriage. The fatwa has been welcomed by many human rights activists and child protection organizations. title: Five things Green Party co-leader Jonathan Bartley told Newsbeat
text: By Jonathan BlakeNewsbeat politics reporter Speaking to Newsbeat at a rally in Bristol, Mr Bartley said voting for a smaller party like his "sends a message" that change to the political system is needed. He also said the time was right for new politics as neither the Conservative nor Labour governments had addressed the climate emergency and poverty. Here are five key things he told us: Voting Green is a vote for change: "This election is an opportunity to change the political system in this country. It's a chance to end the dominance of the two old parties and bring in new ideas." The government has failed on climate change: "We are in an ecological emergency, a climate emergency and neither the Tories or Labour are doing enough. We need a Green New Deal to create a million green jobs and invest in a zero-carbon future." The government has failed on poverty: "Poverty has risen in this country under the Tories and Labour's policies haven't helped. We need a universal basic income to give everyone a safety net." The Green Party is a progressive alternative: "We are a party that believes in social justice, equality and environmental sustainability. We are a home for people who want to make a positive difference to the world." The Green Party is growing: "We are the fastest growing party in the UK. People are recognising that the old parties are not delivering and they are looking for a new alternative." Mr Bartley's comments come as the Green Party is hoping to make gains in the general election. The party is currently polling at around 5% and is hoping to win its first ever MP. title: Avocado prices at record high due to reduced harvests
text: Avocado prices have risen to a record due to surging global demand and reduced harvests from major producers Mexico, Peru and California. However, in recent months, production in Mexico has been hit by a combination of factors, including drought, disease and organized crime. As a result, wholesale prices in Mexico have risen by more than 100% in the past year, and retail prices in the United States and Europe have also risen sharply. In the United Kingdom, a single avocado can now sell for as much as £2 in supermarkets, and some restaurants have even taken the fruit off their menus. The surge in prices has been particularly painful for countries like Mexico, where avocados are a staple food. However, as the avocado crisis continues, there are signs that the market may be starting to cool down. In recent weeks, wholesale prices in Mexico have started to decline slightly, and some analysts believe that the worst may be over. "The market is starting to stabilize," said Juan Carlos Anaya, the head of the Mexican Avocado Producers and Packers Association. "The Pontypool Gateway development will create jobs, boost the economy and provide a major regeneration of a site that has lain empty for far too long." The British steelworks was once a major employer in the area, but closed in the 1980s. The site has been derelict ever since, but the new development is expected to breathe new life into the area and create much-needed jobs.

title: Boohoo warned over advertising real fur as fake
text: The Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) upheld a complaint it received about a pom pom jumper being sold by the online retailer. Tests by animal rights charity Humane Society International (HSI) found it contained real fur, despite Boohoo advertising it as a faux fur item. Boohoo has since removed the misleading information from its website and admitted ''an administrative error'' had been made. HSI said the case highlights the risks of ''mislabelling'' when a retailer sources products from around the world. Claire Bass, HSI's UK executive director, said: ''HSI's investigation has exposed a major problem within the online fashion industry - consumers being duped into buying real fur when they believe they are buying faux fur. ''Boohoo has been caught red-handed misleading customers. We hope this ruling sends a clear message to all retailers that this kind of mislabelling will not be tolerated and that consumers deserve honesty and transparency when making purchasing decisions.'' The ASA said Boohoo had not provided evidence to prove the jumper's fur was fake and that it considered the ad to be ''misleading''. It ruled that the advert must not appear again in its current form and told Boohoo not to make similar claims in future unless it was able to provide evidence to back them up. A Boohoo spokesperson said: ''We are committed to ensuring that all of our products are clearly and accurately labelled. We have investigated this matter and believe that an administrative error was made in this instance. We have removed the misleading information from our website and taken steps to ensure that this does not happen again.'' The spokesperson added that the company prides itself on its animal welfare policy and that it does not tolerate the use of real fur in any of its products. The sale of real fur has been banned in the UK since 2003, but the import of fur from animals that have been farmed overseas is still legal. This means that some retailers may be able to sell real fur items as long as they are labelled correctly. However, HSI's investigation found that some retailers are using misleading labelling to sell real fur items as faux fur. This can be difficult for consumers to spot, as it can be hard to tell the difference between real and fake fur.

title: New electric trains approved after windscreens changed
text: Train drivers' union Aslef had said the curved windscreen on the Class 385s were causing reflections of other signals at night. New flat windscreens will now be installed on the carriages, which are used on the Elizabeth line and the Great Western Railway. The first trains are expected to be in service by the end of the year, with the entire fleet of 70 trains to be modified by the end of 2025. Aslef general secretary Mick Whelan said the union was "pleased that common sense has prevailed and that Hitachi and the DfT have listened to our concerns". "Our members have been saying for a long time that the curved windscreens on the Class 385s were causing problems with reflections at night," he said. "This has been a safety issue, and we are glad that it has now been resolved." A DfT spokesperson said: "We are committed to ensuring that our railways are safe and reliable. "We have worked closely with Hitachi and Aslef to address the concerns raised about the windscreens on the Class 385 trains. "The new flat windscreens will improve the visibility for drivers, particularly at night, and we are pleased that this issue has been resolved." A Hitachi spokesperson said: "We are pleased to have worked with the DfT and Aslef to find a solution to the concerns raised about the windscreens on the Class 385 trains. "The new flat windscreens will improve the visibility for drivers, and we are confident that this will make the trains even safer and more reliable." The Class 385 trains are part of a £1.5 billion investment by the DfT to improve rail services in the south east of England. The trains are longer and more spacious than the previous generation of trains, and they feature a range of new features to improve passenger comfort, including free Wi-Fi and air conditioning.

title: UN: World's forests fundamental to human well-being
text: By Mark Kinver Environment reporter, BBC News Eva Mueller, director of the Food and Agriculture Organization's Forestry Division, said trees provided a direct source of food, fuel, shelter and medicines. "Forests provide products that sustain the livelihoods of more than a billion people," she said. "We can't afford to neglect our forests any longer. We need to halt their loss and continue to invest in forest sustainability." The report also highlights the importance of forests in regulating the climate. "Forests act as a carbon sink, absorbing about a third of the carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere from fossil fuel burning," said Julian Fox, a professor of forest science at the University of Edinburgh. "They also play a major role in regulating the water cycle, providing a natural filter for our water and helping to prevent flooding." The report calls for urgent action to protect the world's forests. "We need to take a comprehensive approach to forest management, balancing economic, social and environmental considerations," said Ms Mueller. "We also need to empower local communities to play a role in managing their forests. They have a vested interest in ensuring that forests are used sustainably for generations to come." The UN report is a timely reminder of the importance of forests to our planet. As the world's population continues to grow, so too will the demand for food, fuel and other forest products. It is vital that we find ways to meet these demands without destroying our forests. The UN report provides a roadmap for how we can achieve this goal. It is now up to governments, businesses and individuals to take action to protect the world's forests for future generations. Here are some things you can do to help: Reduce your paper consumption Recycle paper and other forest products Support sustainable forestry practices Educate others about the importance of forests

title: Hollywood actor Jason Statham shoots SAS movie in Wales
text: The Killer Elite is reportedly based on a book by explorer Sir Ranulph Fiennes about the murder of SAS soldiers. Scenes featuring Statham were shot in the Brecon Beacons on Wednesday, supporting claims the film is based on a true story. The film, directed by Snowdonia-born Gareth Evans, also stars Dominic Cooper, Aden Young, Robert De Niro, and Clive Owen. Locations included Merthyr Tydfil town centre, where filming took place at the Redhouse, a former department store, and the nearby former Crown pub. The production also filmed in Cardiff, with scenes shot at the city's central railway station. Other locations used include Fforest Fawr, near Abergavenny, Monmouthshire, and the Big Pit National Coal Museum in Blaenavon, Torfaen. The Killer Elite is the second Statham film to be shot in Wales in recent years, following The Expendables 3, which was filmed in Newport and Cardiff in 2013. Statham is said to have been impressed by the locations and the crews he worked with in Wales, and is keen to return for future projects. The Killer Elite is expected to be released in cinemas in 2024. The film's producers have said they are confident that it will be a critical and commercial success, and that it will help to raise the profile of Wales as a filming location. The Welsh Government has welcomed the production of The Killer Elite in Wales, and said it is evidence of the country's growing reputation as a world-class filming destination. The government has provided financial support to the film through its Creative Wales scheme, which is designed to attract and support film and television productions in Wales.

title: Cancer fight 'hampered in UK by stiff upper lip'
text: By Michelle Roberts Health editor, BBC News online Researchers, who surveyed nearly 20,000 adults in six high-income countries, said they found embarrassment often stopped people from discussing cancer symptoms with family and friends, or even seeking a diagnosis. The work, published in the BMJ, suggests that the UK lags behind other countries when it comes to what is known as "cancer awareness". "Our research suggests that the 'stiff upper lip' attitude in the UK may be a barrier to earlier diagnosis and treatment of cancer" said Dr Anne Johannson, a Senior Research Fellow in the Department of Primary Care and Public Health Sciences at King's College London. "We need to find ways to encourage more open discussion about cancer, both within families and in wider society." The survey found that people in the UK were less likely to discuss cancer symptoms with family and friends than people in other countries. They were also less likely to be aware of the signs and symptoms of cancer. This could be due to a number of factors, said Dr Johannson. "One possibility is that the British are less likely to talk about their health problems in general," she said. "Another possibility is that there is a stigma associated with cancer in the UK." Whatever the reason, the impact of this "stiff upper lip" attitude could be significant. "Early diagnosis and treatment of cancer is vital for improving survival rates," said Dr Johannson. "If people are not aware of the signs and symptoms of cancer, or if they are embarrassed to discuss them, they may be less likely to seek help until it is too late." The researchers say that there is a need for more public health campaigns to raise awareness of cancer and to encourage people to seek help early. "We need to create a culture where people feel comfortable talking about cancer," said Dr Johannson. "We need to make it clear that there is no shame in seeking help, and that early diagnosis and treatment can save lives." In the meantime, there are a number of things that people can do to improve their cancer awareness. Get to know your own body and be aware of any changes. Be aware of the signs and symptoms of cancer. Talk to your family and friends about cancer. Seek help from a healthcare professional if you have any concerns about cancer.

title: Coronavirus: Bangladesh mass prayer event prompts alarm
text: Local police chief Tota Miah told AFP news agency that 10,000 Muslims had gathered in Raipur town to pray "healing verses" from the Koran. But some eyewitnesses told the BBC the figure was closer to 30,000. A similar religious event in Pakistan last month was blamed for a spike in infections in the deeply conservative country. Bangladesh has reported more than 60,000 cases of Covid-19 and more than 800 deaths, according to Johns Hopkins University. The country is now under its fifth week of a strict lockdown that has shut down all public and religious gatherings. On Thursday, the government said it would extend the stay-at-home order until 5 June, but the crowds in Raipur suggest that some people are growing weary of the restrictions. During the event on Monday, the crowd prayed together in a large field, with many people standing shoulder-to-shoulder and not wearing face masks. One resident, who asked not to be named, said he had been shocked to see so many people gathered together. "There was no social distancing at all," he said. "It's like people have forgotten about the virus." The gathering has prompted alarm among health officials, who fear it could lead to a surge in infections. The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned of the potential for superspreader events, where a large number of people are infected by a single carrier. "We are very concerned about this event," said Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the WHO's director-general. "It is exactly the kind of event that we have been warning about." The Bangladesh government has said it will investigate the event and take action against anyone who violated the lockdown rules. "We will not tolerate any violation of the lockdown," said Health Minister Zahid Maleque. "We will take strict action against anyone who puts the health of the nation at risk."
