title: China: Limited victory for man in transgender dismissal case
text: Mr C, who was born female but identifies and dresses as a man, was working at a health centre in Guiyang last year. Despite fulfilling all the requirements for the job and receiving good performance reviews, he was fired after the centre found out about his gender transition. Mr C filed a complaint with the local labour arbitration authority, arguing that his dismissal was a form of sex discrimination. The arbitration authority rejected his complaint, but he appealed to the local court. In its ruling, the Guiyang Xixi District Court stated that the health centre had failed to prove that Mr C's gender identity was "objectively inappropriate" for the job. It also found that the centre had not provided any reasonable justification for dismissing him. However, the court stopped short of declaring Mr C's dismissal unlawful. It ruled that the health centre had acted "disproportionately" in dismissing him, but that it was not liable for damages because it had not acted "intentionally". Mr C's case is significant because it marks the first time a Chinese court has ruled in favour of a transgender person in an employment discrimination case. However, the decision also highlights the limitations of the country's anti-discrimination laws. While Chinese law prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex and gender identity, transgender people often face difficulties in accessing employment, healthcare and other essential services. Activists say that the law needs to be strengthened to provide more explicit protections for transgender people. "This judgment is a small step forward but there is still a long way to go," said Xiao Tie, a transgender rights activist. "We need to continue to raise awareness and fight for the rights of transgender people." Mr C himself expressed disappointment with the court's ruling, saying that he felt it was "only a partial victory". He told the BBC that he is considering appealing the decision to a higher court. "I was born in the wrong body, but I have the right to live my life as I choose," he said. "I will not give up fighting for my rights."

title: Apple ordered to re-write 'inaccurate' Samsung statement
text: Apple was forced on 18 October to publish a message making it clear that Samsung had not infringed the iPad's registered design. However Samsung complained the message was “inaccurate and not a sufficient remedy”. Now the High Court has agreed and has ordered Apple to publish a clearer version of the message. The court also ordered Apple to pay Samsung’s costs. Samsung had argued that the original message published by Apple continued to give the “false impression” that it had copied the iPad’s design. It complained that the message stated the ruling only applied to “the specific products in issue in the proceedings”. Samsung had wanted the message to make clear that the ruling applied to all of its Galaxy Tab products. Mr Justice Arnold agreed with Samsung’s arguments. He said Apple’s clarification was “insufficient” and that “the inaccuracy was likely to cause substantial and unjustifiable damage to Samsung”. He added that while Apple had complied with the court order to publish a message clarifying the court’s judgment, "it has not complied with the spirit of the order". Apple has now published a new message on its website which states: "Samsung did not infringe Apple's registered design for the iPad." The message also makes clear that the ruling applies to all of Samsung's Galaxy Tab products. Samsung has welcomed the High Court’s decision. In a statement, Samsung said: "We are pleased with the court's ruling, which clarifies that Apple's original statement was inaccurate. We hope that this will finally put an end to this matter and allow us to focus on our business." Apple has declined to comment on the High Court’s decision. The legal battle between Apple and Samsung has been going on for several years. In 2012, Apple won a landmark case in the US against Samsung, in which it was awarded $1.05bn (£657m) in damages. However, Samsung has since appealed against the ruling and the case is due to be heard by the US Supreme Court in 2016.

title: Aberdeen sanitary product pilot to start across Scotland
text: The Scottish government scheme - designed to tackle "period poverty" - was launched in July last year. The six-month pilot was continued in March, and has distributed free products to more than 1,000 women. Equalities Secretary Angela Constance said the expansion was a "key part" of ongoing work to ensure "no-one should have to go without essential items due to financial hardship." The council areas involved in the latest phase of the scheme for six months are: South Lanarkshire, East Renfrewshire, Renfrewshire, Inverclyde, Dundee, and Shetland. It follows the pilot in Aberdeen, where products were made available in 20 community locations such as libraries, leisure centres, and food banks. In North Lanarkshire, products were also made available in schools. A recent survey by Young Scot found that 20% of girls and young women aged between 14 and 21 said they had struggled to afford period products in the last year. It also found that 15% of respondents had missed school because they did not have access to period products. Charities have welcomed the scheme, but say more needs to be done. The Scottish Women's Rights Centre said the scheme was a "positive step" but urged the government to make it a permanent provision. The center also called for free products to be made available in more places, including workplaces, and for the government to tackle the "stigma" around periods. The Lib Dems said the scheme was a "sticking plaster" and called for the government to provide free sanitary products to all women in Scotland. Scottish Labour said the scheme was a "welcome step" but called for the government to do more to tackle the underlying causes of period poverty, such as low incomes and insecure work. The Scottish Conservatives said they were "committed" to tackling period poverty but did not specify what measures they would take. The Scottish government said it was "committed" to ensuring that everyone has access to free period products, and that it was working with partners to "develop a long-term solution" to period poverty.

title: Models from Gerry Anderson's The Investigator up for sale
text: The speedboat and sports car were produced for the 1973 show The Investigator, which never made it beyond a pilot episode. The models, both fitted with Honda 50cc engines, are now being sold by Anderson Entertainment. The Investigator was a secret agent series that was to star James Franciscus as Kim Grant, an investigator for the World Security Bureau. The show was to be produced by Gerry Anderson, who was best known for creating Thunderbirds, Space: 1999, and UFO. However, the show was never picked up by a network, and only the pilot episode was ever produced. The models of the speedboat and sports car that were used in the pilot episode have been in storage for many years, but are now being sold by Anderson Entertainment. The speedboat is a 10-foot-long model of a 30-foot Bertram 31 Bertram Cruiser. It is made of fiberglass and is powered by a Honda 50cc engine. The sports car is a 1969 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray model. It is made of fiberglass and is powered by a Honda 50cc engine. Both models are in good condition and are expected to fetch a high price at auction. Anderson Entertainment is selling the models as part of a larger auction of Gerry Anderson memorabilia. The auction will be held on November 18, 2023, at the Bonhams auction house in London. In addition to the speedboat and sports car, the auction will also feature other items from Gerry Anderson's shows, including models of Thunderbirds, Space: 1999, and UFO. The auction is expected to attract a large number of collectors and fans of Gerry Anderson's work. Gerry Anderson was a British television producer and director who was best known for creating a number of popular science fiction television series, including Thunderbirds, Space: 1999, and UFO. Anderson's shows were known for their use of marionette puppets, which were often used to create complex action sequences. Anderson died in 2012 at the age of 83. He is survived by his wife, Mary, and his four children.

title: New environmental watchdog to get legal teeth after Brexit
text: By Roger Harrabin BBC environment analyst Ministers say the Office for Environmental Protection (OEP) will be an independent statutory body to safeguard environmental standards. It will have the power to take the government to court over failures to enforce environmental law and also intervene in planning decisions. However, it will not be able to take action over breaches that occurred before the UK left the European Union. The new watchdog will replace the EU's environmental governance system. When asked in the Commons about the scale of its legal powers, Environment Secretary George Eustice said: "The OEP can take enforcement action against public authorities, including government departments." He added: "The OEP may also take enforcement action against private individuals or companies, but only if a public authority is involved in the alleged breach of environmental law." The former Environment Secretary, Theresa Villiers, pledged to establish a "world-leading" environmental watchdog after Brexit. She said it would "drive continuous improvement in environmental outcomes". The new body will be headquartered in Bristol and have operating bases in London, York, Cardiff and Edinburgh. It will have a budget of £13.3m for the next financial year. The OEP's remit covers all environmental law, including air and water quality, waste management, biodiversity and climate change. It will also be able to initiate investigations and make recommendations to government about improving environmental law. The new body has been welcomed by environmental groups. The Wildlife and Countryside Link said it was "a big step towards the UK having an independent watchdog that can hold government and public bodies to account for environmental failures". However, some environmentalists have expressed concerns about the OEP's powers. The Environmental Investigation Agency said it was "disappointing" that the body would not be able to take action over historic breaches of environmental law. The OEP will be able to take on cases brought to it by members of the public. However, unlike the EU system, it will not be able to levy fines.

title: Facebook: Norwich painting-a-day artist 'overwhelmed' by praise
text: Nick Chinnery has painted a watercolour of a Norwich landmark and posted it on Facebook every day since the new year. He said he had received hundreds of messages of support and encouragement since he started the project on January 1. "I've been overwhelmed by the response," said Mr Chinnery, 63, from Norwich. "I never expected so many people to be interested in my paintings." Mr Chinnery, who works as a teaching assistant at the University of East Anglia, said he started the project as a way to challenge himself creatively. "I've always loved painting, but I don't get much time to do it," he said. "So, I thought this would be a good way to force myself to paint more regularly." Mr Chinnery said he chooses the landmarks he paints based on their architectural interest or historical significance. "I'm trying to capture the essence of Norwich," he said. "I want to show people the beauty of the city and its rich heritage." Mr Chinnery's paintings have been praised for their detail and accuracy. He said he spends several hours on each painting, working from photographs and sketches. "I want to make sure that my paintings are as true to life as possible," he said. "I want people to be able to recognize the landmarks I'm painting and to appreciate the beauty of the city." Mr Chinnery said he has been surprised by the positive reaction to his paintings. "I've had people tell me that my paintings have made them appreciate Norwich more," he said. "That's really rewarding." Mr Chinnery said he plans to continue painting a landmark a day until the end of the year. "I'm really enjoying the project," he said. "It's a great way to learn about the city and to share my love of painting with others." Mr Chinnery's paintings can be viewed on his Facebook page, Nick Chinnery Artwork.

title: Covid-19: Record day for UK vaccinations as total nears 9m
text: As of Saturday a total of 8,977,329 people had received a jab, and 491,053 of those have had a second dose. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said he was "delighted", adding each vaccine "brings us one step closer to normality". Experts say the latest figures show the UK's vaccination programme is among the most successful in the world. Some groups, including the over-80s and healthcare workers, have already received both doses of the vaccine, and the government is now working to offer the vaccine to everyone over the age of 18 by the end of July. The success of the vaccine rollout has been attributed to a number of factors, including the government's early investment in vaccines, the efficient deployment of the vaccines by the NHS, and the willingness of the public to get vaccinated. The government has said it is confident that the vaccination programme will have a significant impact on the spread of Covid-19, and that it will help to protect the most vulnerable members of society. However, some experts have warned that it is too early to say when the pandemic will end. They say that the virus could mutate, and that new variants could emerge that are resistant to the current vaccines. The government has said that it is monitoring the situation closely, and that it will take whatever steps are necessary to protect the public. In the meantime, the public is being urged to continue to follow the government's advice on social distancing, hand hygiene, and mask-wearing. The UK's vaccination programme is a major step forward in the fight against Covid-19. However, it is important to remember that the pandemic is not over yet. The public must continue to follow the government's advice in order to protect themselves and others.

title: Macron aide Alexandre Benalla to be dismissed after protesters beaten
text: The action against Alexandre Benalla was taken after "new facts" emerged in the case, French President Emmanuel Macron's office said on Friday. Mr Benalla is being questioned over the footage of the May Day protests. The Elysee Palace said the new information was "particularly serious." It said Mr Benalla had been suspended since May 4, when the alleged assault took place. Mr Benalla, 26, is a close associate of Mr Macron and was filmed wearing a police helmet and beating a protester during a demonstration on May 1. He has admitted being present at the protest but denies assaulting anyone. The Interior Ministry has launched an internal investigation into the incident. The scandal has caused embarrassment for Mr Macron, who has been accused of being too close to his staff. It has also raised questions about the use of force by police during protests. Mr Macron has said he will not tolerate violence against protesters. "I want to be very clear: violence is unacceptable, whether it comes from protesters or from the police," he said. The incident has also sparked a debate about the role of private security firms in policing protests. Mr Benalla was employed by a private security firm that was hired by the Elysee Palace to provide security for Mr Macron. Critics have questioned why a private security guard was allowed to wear police gear and intervene in a police operation. The Interior Ministry has said it will review the use of private security firms in policing protests. The scandal comes at a time when Mr Macron is facing a number of other challenges. His approval ratings have fallen in recent months, and he has been criticized for his handling of the economy and other issues. The Benalla scandal is likely to further damage Mr Macron's reputation and make it more difficult for him to implement his reforms.

title: Brit Awards 2018: Stars to wear white rose pins on red carpet
text: By Mark Savage BBC Music reporter The show's organisers wrote to the head of every UK record label on Wednesday to inform them of the plan. The letter says performers, presenters and guests will be given a white rose pin to wear on the red carpet and on stage. The gesture has been endorsed by the UK's Music Managers Forum, the Featured Artists Coalition and the Musicians' Union. The Brit Awards are the UK's biggest music awards ceremony. They will be held at London's O2 Arena on 21 February. In their letter, the Brits organisers say: "We would like to invite all those attending the event to wear a white rose pin as a symbol of solidarity, hope and peace. "This is not a political statement, it is a human one. It is about recognising and celebrating the power of music to bring people together." The white rose has long been a symbol of Yorkshire, and has been adopted by the county's cricket team and rugby league team. It has also been used as a symbol of hope and peace by anti-war campaigners. The Brit Awards have been criticised in the past for being too male-dominated. In 2018, only one female artist was nominated for the best album award. In response to the criticism, the Brits organisers have made a number of changes to the awards this year. They have increased the number of female judges, and have introduced a new category for female artists. The white rose pin is the latest in a series of initiatives designed to make the Brits more inclusive. The Brits are not the first awards ceremony to use a symbol of solidarity. At the 2018 Golden Globes, actresses wore black dresses to protest against sexual harassment and assault. At the 2019 Grammy Awards, musicians wore white roses to show their support for the Time's Up movement. The white rose pin is a powerful symbol of hope and peace. It is a reminder that music can bring people together, and that we can all stand up against discrimination and violence.

title: Zoom sees more growth after 'unprecedented' 2020
text: The video conferencing company expects sales to rise more than 40% this year, reaching more than $3.7bn (£2.66bn). The forecast pushed shares in the company up more than 6% in after-hours trading. The growth comes after a bumper year for Zoom in 2020, when the pandemic forced millions of people to work from home. In the past 12 months, the company's shares have increased in value by more than 500%. Zoom said its growth is being driven by businesses, which are increasingly using its services for internal meetings and customer calls. The company is also benefiting from the growing popularity of hybrid working, which allows employees to work from both the office and home. Zoom is not the only video conferencing company to have seen strong growth during the pandemic. Other providers, such as Microsoft Teams and Google Meet, have also seen a surge in usage. However, Zoom has been able to maintain its market leadership, thanks to its easy-to-use interface and reliable service. The company is also investing heavily in new features, such as artificial intelligence and virtual reality. Analysts say that Zoom is well-positioned to continue growing in the years to come, even as the pandemic recedes. The company's focus on business customers and its strong track record of innovation are likely to help it maintain its market leadership. "Zoom has become the de facto standard for video conferencing," said Dan Ives, an analyst at Wedbush Securities. "The company has a strong moat around its business, and we expect it to continue to grow at a rapid pace in the years to come." Zoom's growth is also being helped by the increasing adoption of cloud computing. Businesses are increasingly moving their applications and data to the cloud, which makes it easier for them to use Zoom's services. The company is also benefiting from the growing popularity of video conferencing in emerging markets. In the past year, Zoom has seen strong growth in countries such as India, Brazil, and China. Overall, Zoom is well-positioned to continue growing in the years to come. The company's focus on business customers, its strong track record of innovation, and the increasing adoption of cloud computing are all likely to help it maintain its market leadership.

title: Coronavirus: MPs debate pet theft law change amid lockdown rise
text: They were debating two petitions, signed by almost 300,000 people, urging the government to make pet theft a specific offence. Ipswich MP Tom Hunt also presented a 10-minute rule bill, which, if approved, would see the creation of a new law on pet abduction. Mr Hunt said there had been a "shocking" increase in the number of pets being snatched from their owners - 2,438 dogs in the past year alone, according to police figures. "Since the first lockdown alone, 50,000 cats and dogs were reported stolen to police, which is shocking and unacceptable," he said. "Pet theft is a terrible crime that causes deep distress to owners. We must take action now, before more people fall victim to these ruthless criminals." The petitions to the government also highlighted the distress caused to owners, with more than one in 10 saying the experience was "traumatic". "The government must recognise the severity of this issue and give pet theft the attention it deserves," one petition said. "Current laws are failing to deter pet thieves and are failing to protect innocent animals." The government amended the Animal Welfare Act 2006, in 2018, to include a new offence of pet abduction, punishable by a maximum sentence of five years in prison. Mr Hunt said this was a "step in the right direction" but called for further clarification in law, to treat pet theft more seriously. The Petitions Committee, which considers e-petitions with more than 100,000 signatures, has also backed calls for better protection for pets. In a report, it said: "The committee believes that pet theft should be a specific offence." It recommended that the government review sentencing for pet theft, to ensure it is proportionate and reflects the severity of the crime. The committee also called for improved police training, better data collection on pet theft and more support for victims. The government has previously said it is considering the Petitions Committee's recommendations.

title: Alcohol age rise plan rejected
text: The SNP administration wanted to let local licensing boards ban off-licence sales to under-21s but the move was blocked by Holyrood's Equalities and Human Rights Committee. The motion was voted down by six votes to five following concerns about discrimination against young people. The plans sparked a fierce debate, with supporters arguing that they would reduce alcohol-related harm among young people. Opponents, however, claimed that they would unfairly penalise responsible young adults and would be difficult to enforce. The Scottish government said it was "disappointed" with the outcome of the vote and would continue to explore ways to tackle underage drinking. "We are committed to reducing alcohol-related harm, particularly among young people," a spokesperson said. "We will continue to work with stakeholders to develop and implement effective measures to achieve this." The Scottish Conservatives welcomed the committee's decision, saying it was the "right thing to do". "These plans would have unfairly targeted responsible young adults and would have been difficult to enforce," said Miles Briggs, the party's justice spokesman. title: Polish bishops for total ban on Sunday shopping
text: By News from Elsewhere....as found by BBC Monitoring "Free Sundays are what all Catholics, non-Catholics and non-believers need," Archbishop Stanislaw Gadecki told Polish Radio ahead of a meeting of the Bishops Conference on Friday. The influential church body is expected to issue a formal appeal for a law change to end Sunday trading. Poland's large supermarket chains are currently allowed to open on Sundays, but there are restrictions on the types of shops that can trade, and small, family-run businesses are banned from doing so. A government bill to impose a full ban on Sunday shopping was approved by the lower house of parliament in 2017, but later vetoed by President Andrzej Duda. The president said he wanted a "reasonable compromise", which would still allow some shops, like petrol stations and cafes, to open on Sundays. The issue is deeply polarising in Poland. Poorer and rural communities often support the ban, saying it protects family values and local businesses. But many city dwellers oppose it, arguing it restricts consumer choice and hurts businesses. Opinion polls show that Poles are roughly evenly split on the issue. The government has said it will not support a new ban without public backing. "We're still looking at the arguments for and against," the family, labour and social policy minister, Elzbieta Rafalska, told the Tok FM radio station. "It's a question of how we organise our work and free time. On the one hand, it's about the vitality of the economy, on the other, it's about the right to rest and a decent life." The debate comes as Poland grapples with a labour shortage, with many businesses complaining they cannot find enough staff to work on weekdays. "A ban on Sunday shopping would make it even harder to find staff, because the vast majority of retail workers are women with families, and they often need to work on Sundays to make ends meet," said Rafal Matusiewicz, of the Polish Chamber of Commerce. The ban is expected to be a key issue in next month's European Parliament elections. The ruling Law and Justice party (PiS), which supports the ban, is expected to do well, but polls show that most Poles want the government to focus on other issues, such as the economy and healthcare.

title: Coronavirus: UK's already huge changes may just be the start
text: Laura Kuenssberg Political editor @bbclaurakon Twitter Whitehall had been monitoring and fearing the arrival of the coronavirus on these shores for many weeks. But when Boris Johnson told the nation on Sunday evening that the UK was moving to the "delay" phase of its response to Covid-19, it was clear that the moment had come and the precautions and social distancing measures that had previously been under consideration were now imperative. The government's scientific advisers had warned that without stepping up the response to "delay" the peak of the epidemic, even under the best-case scenario the NHS would be overwhelmed by a vast increase in the number of patients needing hospital treatment. There would have to be what the prime minister called "very significant" changes in people's lives and "a very considerable change in the way we behave". What does the delay phase involve? The government is now explicitly asking people to: Avoid unnecessary social contact Stay home if you have a high temperature or a new and continuous cough Work from home if you can Avoid large gatherings, and gatherings in smaller public spaces such as pubs, clubs and theatres. Schools are now closed, exams have been cancelled and people are being encouraged to self-isolate if they have underlying health conditions. The scale of this response is huge - while few people are yet to self-isolate, towns and cities across the UK are noticeably quieter, with pubs, restaurants and shops already reporting a significant drop off in trade. But the government has been clear that this may not be enough. The prime minister warned that if the public does not follow this advice, then "no amount of NHS capacity" will be enough. The next phase - "contain" - would involve even more draconian measures such as further restricting movement and closing down public transport. Could this be just the start? In fact, the cabinet has been discussing even tougher policies, including measures akin to a full-scale lockdown that would mean no one could leave their homes. While it has been decided not to put such measures in place at this stage, they could be revisited if the current social distancing measures do not have the desired effect. The prime minister's address to the nation on Sunday was notable for its sombre and direct tone - he warned that "many lives will sadly be lost" and that the government was "seeking to slow the spread of the disease to reduce the number of lives lost". The government knows the weeks and months ahead are likely to be the toughest in decades - the scale of the challenge is enormous. The coming weeks will be a test for the government and for society as a whole. If we do not follow the advice of the scientists and the government, the consequences will be catastrophic. It is time to take this seriously - our lives, and the lives of our loved ones, may depend on it.

title: Trial raises Parkinson's therapy hope
text: The Japanese team hope their work could lead to stem cell trials in human patients before the end of 2018. Parkinson's disease causes the progressive loss of nerve cells that release dopamine, a chemical that helps control and coordinate body movements. Tremors, slowness of movement, muscle stiffness and impaired balance are common symptoms of the disease. Medications can help ease the symptoms, but current therapies cannot stop or reverse the progression of the condition. As the disease progresses, patients can struggle with everyday activities such as walking and talking, and experience difficulties with thinking and memory. The team, led by Dr Jun Takahashi at Kyoto University, took skin cells from a patient with Parkinson's disease and turned them into iPS cells. These stem cells can be grown and coaxed into developing into the type of brain cell that produces dopamine: a type called midbrain dopamine (mDA) neurons. The scientists then transplanted these cells into the brains of mice that had lost their own mDA neurons and showed signs of Parkinson's. The results, reported in the journal Nature, showed that the transplanted cells lived and produced dopamine for at least six months, improving the motor function of the mice. The team also showed that the transplanted cells could survive for at least two years in the brains of monkeys, another animal model of Parkinson's disease. The cells also seemed to integrate into the monkeys' brains and form connections with other neurons. "Our findings suggest that transplantation of iPS cell-derived mDA neurons is a promising strategy for the treatment of Parkinson's disease," said Dr Takahashi. "We hope that our work will lead to the development of clinical trials in human patients in the near future." Professor David Dexter, an expert in Parkinson's disease at the University of Cambridge, said the study was "a major advance" in the field of stem cell research for Parkinson's disease. He said the work "provides further evidence of the potential for cell-based therapies to treat neurodegenerative diseases" and added that it was "particularly encouraging" that the transplanted cells had survived and integrated for as long as two years in the monkeys. However, he cautioned that there was still a long way to go before such treatments could be tested in humans. "There are a number of challenges that need to be addressed before we can move to clinical trials, such as the risk of the transplanted cells causing side-effects or forming tumours," he said. "But this study is a very promising step forward."

title: Zimbabwe media slow to cover military takeover
text: By BBC Monitoring The world through its media State TV and radios were re-broadcasting the statement by Major-General Sibusiso Moyo announcing that the military had taken over but offered little by way of analysis or context. Independent newspapers and websites carried the story prominently as the main event. Some had little detail while others carried full transcripts of the statement made by the major-general. The privately-owned NewsDay, the first newspaper to be printed after the takeover, carried a front-page editorial comment on the military's intervention under the heading: "Zimbabwe now on edge". The paper's editor, Wisdom Mdzungairi, said: "We are witnessing the demise of a dictatorship that has been aided and abetted by an incompetent government which has presided over years of grand-scale corruption, maladministration and economic meltdown." He added that many people had not been surprised by the military's intervention, but he called on the military leaders to move quickly "to restore stability and legitimacy". Another privately-owned newspaper, the Daily News, also published a transcript of the major-general's statement under the headline: "Army steps in to end Mugabe's rule." However, the paper's website carried much more - including speculation over possible motives for the military intervention. It quoted former cabinet minister Jonathan Moyo as saying that the military was likely to be unhappy with the first lady Grace Mugabe's "monopoly" over her husband. It also carried reports of violence in Harare's central business district on Wednesday where the army had clashed with supporters of the ruling Zanu-PF party. The online version of the Standard newspaper said the army had denied these reports and that there had been no violence. However, another privately-owned newspaper, the Zimbabwe Independent, said that "soldiers ran amok" in the capital, attacking people in company attire and searching cars. The paper also quoted businessman and political analyst, Trevor Ncube, as saying it was time for Zimbabwe to move on and embrace a "new dispensation". The online edition of the privately-owned Financial Gazette carried the transcript of the major-general's statement. It also carried articles on the international reaction to the military intervention and the implications for the country's economy. There was also an article headlined: "Mugabe resigns: End of an era", which described the president's rise and fall and the political turmoil that had engulfed the country in recent months.

title: Under 40s to be offered alternative to AZ vaccine
text: By James Gallagher Health and science correspondent The UK's medicines safety regulator says there have been 242 clotting cases and 49 deaths, with 28.5 million doses of the vaccine administered. But the risk is slightly higher in younger people. Most of the cases have occurred in younger people - three-quarters of the cases have been in people under 50. The problem has been linked to the vaccine triggering an unusual immune response which causes clotting. There are two other effective vaccines being used in the UK - Moderna and Pfizer. Experts say these use slightly different technology that has not been linked to this rare clotting problem. This is why the recommendation is only for under-40s. The JCVI says the small number of blood clots means the overall benefits of vaccination in preventing Covid-19 outweigh the risks. It says the advice will be kept under review as more data becomes available. Prof Jonathan Van-Tam, England's deputy chief medical officer, said: "This is a risk-benefit decision and we have decided that the balance of risk and benefit favours the use of the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines in adults under 40." Prof Anthony Harnden, deputy chair of the JCVI, said: "The JCVI has advised that adults aged 30 and over who have not yet received their first dose of Covid-19 vaccine should be offered an alternative to the AstraZeneca vaccine. "We have also advised that adults aged 18-29 years who have not yet received their first dose of Covid-19 vaccine should be offered the Pfizer or Moderna vaccine." The JCVI says that those who have already had a first dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine should still receive a second dose of the same vaccine. This is because the risk of a blood clot after the first dose is much lower than the risk of Covid-19. It also says that there is no need to test people for clotting disorders before they get a Covid vaccine. The JCVI's advice is based on the latest data on the safety of the AstraZeneca vaccine. It says that the data shows that the benefits of the vaccine in preventing Covid-19 outweigh the risks.

title: Fiscal Phil's Budget - is it just about the cash?
text: David Cornock Parliamentary correspondent, Wales The Budget throws up more than enough to last a lifetime. And when there's not much money around, politicians tend to begin the vital process of kicking the can down the road. In Rishi Sunak's first outing as Chancellor of the Exchequer, there was some trust-me jam tomorrow. Fiscal Phil, as some have started calling him, is a can-kicker extraordinaire. Here is a brief list of things the UK government will be doing: 1. Borrowing £355bn to fund the package of measures 2. Raising corporation tax from 19% to 25% in 2023 3. Freezing income tax personal allowances and higher rate threshold 4. Cutting Universal Credit by £20 a week 5. Setting up a new UK Infrastructure Bank 6. Spending £12bn on the Restart programme to create jobs 7. Providing £15bn for the NHS 8. Investing £5bn in new bus and cycle lanes 9. Confirming that HS2 will be completed 10. Increasing the minimum wage to £9.50 an hour for over-23s There has been much criticism of the detail in the package but the broad effect is clear. Rishi Sunak is attempting to limit the impact of the economic shock that followed the pandemic. He is doing that by holding off on tax rises and borrowing more to keep spending levels very high. He is using the Infrastructure Bank and the Restart scheme to create jobs. And he is protecting the NHS and other public services from the full force of the spending cuts. This is all very expensive. The Chancellor has increased borrowing to record levels. It means that the government will now have to borrow more than £2,000 every second over the next five years just to pay the interest on the UK's vast debts. However, the Chancellor argues that the alternative would be even more painful. Without this support, the UK economy would shrink by 6% over the next two years, according to the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR). Unemployment would reach almost 12%, the worst recession seen in the UK for three centuries. And public services would have to be slashed to the bone. The Chancellor is gambling that the economic recovery will be strong enough to allow him to pay down the debt in the future. But if the recovery is slower than expected, the UK will be left with a very expensive hangover. The Budget has been welcomed by some economists, who argue that it was necessary to prevent a deep recession. Others have criticized the package as being too expensive and unfair. The Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) said the Budget was "regressive", meaning it would hit the poorest in society hardest. The Resolution Foundation think tank said the Budget did not do enough to help low-income families. The government has argued that the Budget is fair because it includes a number of measures to help low-income families, such as increasing the minimum wage and spending more on childcare. However, the IFS said that these measures were not enough to offset the regressive impact of other measures, such as freezing income tax personal allowances and cutting Universal Credit. The Budget is a complex and controversial package of measures. It is too early to say whether it will be successful in preventing a deep recession. But it is clear that the UK government is taking a big gamble with the country's finances.

title: Who, What, Why: How dangerous is bullfighting?
text: Who, What, Why: How dangerous is bullfighting? Bullfighting is a "supremely dangerous art", says Garry Marvin, professor of human-animal studies at Queen's University, Ontario. "It's not just the risk of being gored or trampled, but also the psychological and emotional toll it takes on the participants." Who is at risk? The most obvious people at risk are the matadors, who face the bulls in the ring. But other participants are also at risk, including the banderilleros, who place barbed sticks in the bull's neck, and the picadors, who lance the bull on horseback. Even spectators can be injured, as bulls have been known to jump the barriers and into the stands. What are the injuries? Bullfighting injuries can be severe and even fatal. Matadors can suffer from goring, trampling, and other blunt force trauma. Banderilleros and picadors can also suffer from serious injuries, including broken bones and puncture wounds. Spectators have been known to be gored, trampled, and even killed by bulls. Why is bullfighting dangerous? Bullfighting is dangerous because it involves interacting with a large, powerful, and unpredictable animal. Bulls are capable of inflicting serious injuries with their horns, hooves, and body weight. They are also very agile and can move quickly and unpredictably. This makes it difficult for matadors and other participants to avoid being injured. How can the risks be reduced? There are a number of ways to reduce the risks associated with bullfighting. One is to use more protective gear, such as helmets, chest plates, and leg guards. Another is to train matadors and other participants more thoroughly. Finally, the rules of the sport can be changed to make it less dangerous. For example, the use of swords could be banned, and the bulls could be given more space to escape. Is bullfighting worth the risk? The question of whether or not bullfighting is worth the risk is a complex one. There are strong arguments on both sides of the issue. Ultimately, it is up to each individual to decide whether or not they believe that the sport is worth the risks involved.

title: Will Brexit last longer than other winning words of the year?
text: The word had its first recorded use in 2013 but as the EU referendum approached, more and more people started using it. It's an increase that Collins says is "unheard of". But Brexit is not the first word to have been popularised by a major political event. In 2016, Oxford Dictionaries named "post-truth" as its word of the year, reflecting the growing trend towards people shaping their political beliefs around emotion rather than facts. And in 2017, Merriam-Webster's word of the year was "feminism", reflecting the growing prominence of the feminist movement in popular culture. So, could Brexit be another short-lived phenomenon? It's certainly possible. Political language often changes rapidly, as new events and ideas emerge. For example, the word "austerity" was relatively obscure before the 2008 financial crisis, but it quickly became a household term as governments around the world implemented cuts to public spending. However, it's also possible that Brexit could stick around for longer. The UK's withdrawal from the EU is a complex and unprecedented process, and it could have a major impact on British society for many years to come. As a result, it's likely that people will continue to use the word Brexit to describe the process and its consequences. Of course, it's impossible to say for sure how long Brexit will remain in the public consciousness. However, it's clear that the word has already had a major impact on the English language. It has become a shorthand way of describing the UK's withdrawal from the EU, and it has also entered the wider political lexicon as a term for a major political upheaval. Whether Brexit will continue to be used for decades to come remains to be seen. But for now, it seems clear that the word is here to stay for the foreseeable future.

title: Garden eels 'forgetting about humans' need people to video-chat
text: Keepers at Tokyo's Sumida Aquarium, which has been closed since 1 March due to the coronavirus pandemic, are starting to worry about their garden eels. The sensitive little creatures had become used to seeing hundreds of faces peering into their tank every day, and now they're starting to forget about humans. "They're not used to seeing people anymore, so they're starting to lose their trust in us," said aquarium keeper Rina Ono. "They used to come up to the surface and say hello, but now they're hiding in their burrows." The garden eels are not the only animals at the aquarium that are being affected by the lack of visitors. The penguins are also starting to get restless, and the sea otters are spending more time sleeping. "All of our animals are social creatures, so they're used to interacting with people," said Ono. "It's hard for them to understand why we're not around anymore." The aquarium staff is trying to keep the animals entertained and engaged, but it's not the same as having visitors around. "We're doing everything we can to make sure they're happy and healthy," said Ono. "But we can't replace the interaction they get from people." The aquarium is hoping to reopen soon, but it's not clear when that will be. In the meantime, the staff is asking people to video-chat with the animals. "It's not the same as being here in person, but it's a way for people to connect with the animals and show them that they're still loved," said Ono. To video-chat with the animals, visit the Sumida Aquarium website. You can choose to chat with the penguins, the sea otters, or the garden eels. "We hope that people will take advantage of this opportunity to connect with the animals," said Ono. "It's a way to bring a little bit of joy into their lives during this difficult time."

title: Coronavirus: Bat scientists find new evidence
text: They have discovered a virus that is a close match to the virus that causes Covid-19 in bats at a wildlife sanctuary in eastern Thailand. And blood tests from nearby villagers revealed that some had antibodies which may have been the result of a previous infection with a bat coronavirus. This suggests that the virus could have spread from bats to humans, although more research is needed to show whether this definitely happened. The Thai researchers say their findings "support the hypothesis that bats could be the natural reservoir for the Covid-19 virus". But experts say we may never know for sure whether bats were the original source of the coronavirus that causes Covid-19. There are lots of different viruses in bats but only a handful have been known to infect humans, and most cause mild symptoms. But the Sars and Mers coronaviruses, which have both led to deadly outbreaks in the past two decades, originated in bats. Bats are thought to be the most likely hosts of the new coronavirus because they are mammals like us and they are known to carry coronaviruses. The Thai researchers collected samples of saliva and faeces from 649 bats in Thailand between June 2020 and May 2021. They tested more than 300 samples and identified nine different coronaviruses. One of them was a close match to the virus that causes Covid-19 in humans. The researchers say it is the closest match between a coronavirus in bats and the Covid virus yet identified. They also collected blood samples from 829 people living near the wildlife sanctuary. More than 10% tested positive for antibodies to a coronavirus. This means they had already been exposed to a coronavirus. The researchers speculate that exposure to bats may be the cause. However, they admit that the blood tests could be picking up antibodies to other coronaviruses and not the virus that causes Covid-19. More research is needed to determine whether these people were infected with the novel coronavirus. The researchers say their work highlights the risk of bat coronaviruses getting into humans. They are calling for greater surveillance and more research to understand bat viruses. They also say it is important to protect bat habitats.

title: Supreme Court divorce approval sought by 'unhappy wife'

title: Don Lock murder: Mother of accused pleaded for help for son
text: Matthew Daley, 35, denies murder but has admitted attacking 79-year-old retired solicitor Donald Lock claiming diminished responsibility. Lynda Daley agreed at Lewes Crown Court the day Mr Lock died on 30 October 2021, her son was very unwell. She said the defendant told her he had been hearing voices that he described as "demons", had stopped taking his prescribed medication and slept on the sofa because he thought someone was trying to get into his room. The court heard Matthew Daley had self-harmed in the past, including cutting his wrist, and his mother feared he was suicidal. "I was worried about him," she said. "He was not the son I knew." She told the jury her son was vulnerable, with a history of mental health issues and cannabis use. On the day of the killing, Matthew Daley shouted at her and his father as they drove through Lewes, telling them to pull over so he could be sick. He swore at traffic wardens and started "acting out" in the street, Mrs Daley said. She said she and her husband, who died in July this year, were left "distressed and upset." Matthew Daley was taken to the Princess Royal Hospital in Haywards Heath, West Sussex, where his mother says he threatened to kill a nurse. She said her son's mental health worsened after he was discharged from hospital. Jurors heard Mrs Daley called police on the day of the murder, worried about her son's behaviour. "I wanted him to be sectioned," she said. "He was very unwell." Her son did not contact her on the day Mr Lock died, she told the court. She found out what had happened on the news and went to the police station. "I said it was awful what he had done," said Mrs Daley. "I was disgusted." She added: "If I thought for one minute that he would hurt somebody, I would have never left him alone." The trial continues.

title: Elaine Doyle murder: DNA samples could give clues to death
text: Detectives used sticky tape to recover fibers from the dead girl's skin and found traces of DNA from "an unknown male" on Elaine's back. Forensic experts believe that this may show there was a sexual assault before she was killed. The new breakthrough comes after a cold case review into Elaine's murder was launched by detectives in the Serious Crime Review Team last year. A pollen expert has also been brought in to analyze the soil found in some of her clothing. Elaine vanished in April 1980 after leaving her office at Butlins holiday camp in Ayr, South Ayrshire. Her body was found 12 days later in a field at nearby Monkton. She had been strangled and her clothes were partially burned. Over the years, police have questioned more than 100 people about her death and major searches have been carried out in the Monkton and Prestwick areas. The fresh evidence has come to light during a cold case review into her murder which was launched by detectives in the Serious Crime Review Team last year. A spokesman for Police Scotland said: "The inquiry team is committed to carrying out a thorough and robust review of Elaine's case and is working closely with forensic experts to ensure that all lines of inquiry are fully explored. "We are continuing to make inquiries to identify the unknown male whose DNA was recovered from Elaine's body, and to establish the circumstances surrounding her death." Elaine's family said they were "delighted" that her case was being reviewed. In a statement, they said: "For the past 40 years our thoughts and prayers have been with Elaine day and night. We have never given up hope that one day the person or people responsible for taking her from us would be caught. "We understand that as part of the inquiry they are trying to identify the DNA and that could take a little time. We are pleased that the police have taken this step and would ask that anyone with information comes forward and speaks to the police. "We would also like to thank the police for their continued commitment to trying to catch Elaine's killer." Anyone with any information about Elaine's death is being asked to contact the Serious Crime Review Team on 01786 406798 or email SCDReviewTeam@scotland.police.uk

title: Joe Anderson: Liverpool mayor in police probe will not seek re-election

title: Rain forecast as Glastonbury Festival opens
text: Fans queued outside the Somerset site from dawn on Wednesday and counted down as the pedestrian gates were opened. They face a wet weekend, with heavy downpours predicted on Thursday and a potential mudbath on Friday. The Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning for the area, with up to 40mm of rain expected to fall within six hours on Thursday afternoon. Campers have described the site as "a quagmire" with many resorting to wearing wellington boots. Others battled through the thick mud in bare feet, leaving trails of brown footprints in their wake. The downpours have led to some road closures and disruptions, as well as delays to the festival shuttle buses. There are also concerns that the rain could lead to flooding, so festival-goers are being advised to take precautions. title: Tony Blair: Hard Irish border would be 'disaster'
text: The former UK PM said later he believed there was a "common desire" to make Northern Ireland a "special case" in Brexit negotiations. Blair's comments come as the UK and EU continue to negotiate the terms of the UK's exit from the bloc. The issue of the Irish border has been one of the most contentious issues in the talks, with both sides keen to avoid a hard border that could damage trade and lead to violence. The UK government has said it is committed to maintaining an open border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, but has not yet set out how it will do so. The EU has said it is willing to consider a "special arrangement" for Northern Ireland, but has not yet agreed to any specific proposals. Blair's comments are likely to be welcomed by both the UK and Irish governments, who are keen to avoid a hard border. However, it remains to be seen whether the UK government will be able to come up with a solution that is acceptable to the EU. In a speech in Belfast in January, Blair said that the UK should "stay as close as possible" to the EU after Brexit. He said that the UK should remain in the single market and the customs union, and should continue to cooperate with the EU on issues such as security and foreign policy. Blair's comments were welcomed by some in the UK, but were criticized by others who said that he was out of touch with the public mood. The UK government has said that it will not remain in the single market or the customs union after Brexit, but has said it will seek a close relationship with the EU. It remains to be seen what kind of relationship the UK will have with the EU after Brexit. However, Blair's comments suggest that he believes that the UK should stay as close as possible to the EU, and that a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland should be avoided at all costs.

title: Subsidy for non-existent flights costs Stormont £2.3m a year
text: The deduction was part of the deal which allowed long-haul air passenger duty (APD) to be devolved in Northern Ireland. The decision was taken in 2013 when Stormont was sharing power with the UK government. EU rules state that subsidies for reduced air fares can only be made for flights to a specified destination, usually for economic reasons, such as establishing links to holiday destinations. The Department of Infrastructure told BBC News NI that there was a mechanism in place to claw back the money. "A system is in place to reconcile the subsidy payments to airlines based on the actual number of passengers carried on the routes each year," the Department said. "This ensures that if an airline does not meet the number of passengers projected the subsidy is reduced and repaid." However, the subsidy is still paid in advance. The BBC understands that the funds for the current financial year were released last November, even though most of the flights linked to the subsidy have not yet taken off. The European Commission approved the subsidy on condition that the amount was gradually reduced over a period of time. The current payment of £2.3m is set to be reduced to £2.1m next year, and to £1.3m the following year. In 2020 the EU rules allowing the subsidy will expire. By that time, the total amount of money spent on the subsidy will be around £22m, of which around £15m will have been paid by Stormont. The majority of the flights supported by the subsidy are operated by United and Delta. They fly between Belfast City Airport and New York Newark, and Belfast International Airport to Orlando and New York JFK. The routes have been consistently used, with sometimes every seat sold. The argument from the airlines and DUP is that they are essential. They argue that the flights bring tourists to Northern Ireland, create jobs and allow people to travel to America for business or to visit family and friends. However, the subsidy has been criticised for being too expensive and for not being used to support new routes or services. Critics say there is a danger it is simply allowing the government to pay for existing flights that would happen anyway.

title: International GCSEs to be axed from school league tables
text: The change is part of the government's overhaul of the exam system in England. IGCSEs are currently offered in over 140 countries and are recognised by universities and employers around the world. They provide pupils with the opportunity to study a wide range of subjects, including languages, humanities and sciences, at a higher level than GCSEs. The axing of IGCSEs is a significant change to the English education system. It is too early to say what the full impact of this change will be, but it is clear that it has the potential to have a major impact on the way that pupils are taught and assessed. In addition to the concerns raised above, there are also concerns that the axing of IGCSEs could lead to a decline in the number of pupils studying modern foreign languages. IGCSEs are currently the most popular qualifications in modern foreign languages, and they provide pupils with the opportunity to study a language in depth. title: Neo-Nazi group led by 13-year-old boy to be banned
text: By Daniel De Simone BBC News Feuerkrieg Division, an international group that largely existed online, said earlier this year it had dissolved. But Home Secretary Priti Patel has announced plans to ban it under UK anti-terror laws. The group was led by a 13-year-old boy from the United States, who allegedly recruited children as young as 10 to carry out terrorist acts. Patel said the group posed a "grave and credible threat to the security of the UK" and that the ban would "make it illegal for anyone to be a member of the group, to attend its meetings, or to support it in any way". The ban is the first time a neo-Nazi group has been proscribed in the UK since 2016, when the far-right group National Action was outlawed. Feuerkrieg Division was founded in 2018 and quickly gained a presence on social media platforms such as Telegram and Discord. The group's members shared racist, anti-Semitic and homophobic propaganda, and encouraged their followers to carry out violence against minorities. In 2020, the group was linked to a number of plots to carry out terrorist attacks, including a plan to bomb a synagogue in the US. The group's leader, who has not been identified, was arrested in 2021 and charged with a number of offences, including conspiracy to commit murder. Patel said the ban on Feuerkrieg Division was a "necessary step to protect the public from this dangerous group". "We will not tolerate hatred or violence in our society," she said. The ban on Feuerkrieg Division has been welcomed by anti-fascist groups, who say it is a positive step in the fight against extremism. However, some civil liberties groups have expressed concern about the ban, saying it could be used to target people who hold unpopular views. The ban is expected to come into force within the next few weeks.

title: Coronavirus: Self-employed bailout ‘problematic’
text: By Faisal Islam Economics editor Rishi Sunak, however, repeatedly spelt out difficulties in applying the same terms as his recent bailout for companies. With that scheme, the Treasury agreed to pay 80% of wages for furloughed staff - those whose work has dried up because their employers cannot operate. But this relies on employers having a payroll through which wages are paid to begin with. The self-employed - by definition - do not have PAYE (pay as you earn) wages from a single employer through which the government can channel this cash. HMRC has estimated that about two million self-employed people are not eligible for Universal Credit, the main benefit for low-income families and people out of work. The Chancellor hinted at more assistance to these two million self-employed workers, but without giving details. He said: "We are also considering what more we can do to help those who are not eligible for Universal Credit." In a sign of frustration at the lack of clarity, the Liberal Democrats proposed an interim scheme for those self-employed workers left out. They want the government to give them a taxable grant equivalent to 80% of their average monthly income over the past three years, capped at £2,500 a month, backdated to March. The Treasury said: "We recognise that the self-employed are facing significant challenges at the moment, and we are working on a package of measures to support them." The chancellor also confirmed that the income tax self-assessment deadline would be deferred from 31 July to 31 January next year, but said this only applied to tax payments, not to filing the tax return itself. He said this would give people more time to complete and file their tax returns. In further support of businesses, the Treasury announced: Businesses with turnover less than £1 million will get a £10,000 grant Funding increased for the small business loan scheme from £350bn to £500bn Mr Sunak also said he would increase the generosity of the loan scheme by offering loans on a 100% guarantee, rather than 80%, from Tuesday. This would be backed up by the introduction, from next week, of a "Coronavirus Large Business Interruption Loan Scheme" offering loans of up to £25 million to businesses with an annual turnover of more than £45 million. The Bank of England also cut interest rates today from 0.75% to 0.1%, their lowest level since the Bank's inception 325 years ago, in order to stimulate the economy. The governor of the Bank, Andrew Bailey, said the "coronavirus is the biggest economic shock that the UK has faced in living memory". But the Treasury and Bank of England are now working together to "do whatever it takes" to protect businesses and jobs from the impact of the outbreak.

title: Windows 7 hardest hit by WannaCry worm
text: More than 97% of the infections seen by Kaspersky Lab and 66% of those seen by BitSight used the older software. Microsoft has since released a new patch for the SMB flaw, and it is urging users to install it as soon as possible. The company has also advised users to keep their software up to date, as this can help to protect them from future attacks. Here are some additional tips to help protect your computer from malware: Use a strong password and change it regularly. Keep your software up to date. Be careful about clicking on links in emails or on websites. Use anti-virus software and keep it up to date. Back up your data regularly. By following these tips, you can help to protect your computer from malware and keep your data safe. The WannaCry worm was a wake-up call for many businesses and organisations. It showed how important it is to keep software up to date and to have a strong cyber security strategy in place. By taking the necessary steps to protect their systems, businesses and organisations can help to prevent future attacks from causing widespread disruption. In the wake of the WannaCry attack, Microsoft has taken steps to improve the security of Windows 10. title: Neil McEvoy: Commission reconsiders decision to recognise new party

title: Oil firms 'need fresh strategies' says PwC report
text: Oil firms 'need fresh strategies' says PwC report PwC said companies should be looking to deploy fresh strategies, following a sustained fall in the price of oil. PwC's report has been welcomed by some industry experts as a useful contribution to the debate on the future of the oil and gas industry. title: Dinas Dinlle beach erosion plan unveiled
text: It is believed a flood defence built to protect Dinas Dinlle near Caernarfon, Gwynedd, from coastal flooding in 1994 has made the problem worse. Environment Agency Wales was outlining its plans for tackling the problem on Wednesday. The agency said: "The main cause of erosion at Dinas Dinlle beach is the long-term loss of sediment from the beach and dunes. "This is caused by a combination of factors, including the natural movement of sediment along the coast, changes in wave climate, and the presence of the flood defence structure. "The flood defence structure was built in the early 1990s to protect the village of Dinas Dinlle from flooding. However, it has had the unintended consequence of exacerbating erosion to the beach." The agency's preferred option is to build a new rock revetment along the length of the beach. This would be a sloping structure made of large rocks, which would absorb the energy of waves and protect the beach from further erosion. The agency said that the revetment would be "sympathetic to the surrounding environment" and would not have a significant impact on the visual amenity of the area. The agency is currently consulting on its plans and will be holding a public exhibition at Dinas Dinlle village hall on Thursday 12 July. Residents have welcomed the agency's plans. title: London Underground: How does the Tube compare globally?
text: By Nick Tarver BBC News Transport for London (TfL) has announced that every ticket office on the Tube is to shut by 2022. The move is part of a wider plan to modernize the network and make it more efficient. TfL says that ticket offices are no longer needed as the majority of passengers now use contactless payment or Oyster cards. The closure of ticket offices has been met with mixed reactions. Some passengers have welcomed the move, saying that it will make the network more streamlined and efficient. Others have expressed concern that it will make it more difficult for people to buy tickets, particularly those who are not familiar with using contactless payment or Oyster cards. TfL has said that it will provide additional support for passengers who need help buying tickets. This will include staff on hand at stations to help people use contactless payment or Oyster cards, and machines that will allow people to buy tickets using cash. The closure of ticket offices is just one of a number of changes that are being made to the Tube network. TfL is also investing in new trains, signaling systems, and stations. These changes are all part of a wider plan to improve the reliability, capacity, and frequency of services on the Tube. The Tube is one of the oldest and most iconic public transport systems in the world. It was first opened in 1863 and has since grown to become one of the busiest metro systems in the world. The Tube carries over 1 billion passengers every year and is an essential part of London's transport network. The Tube compares favorably to other metro systems around the world. It is generally clean, safe, and reliable. However, it is also one of the most expensive metro systems in the world. A single journey on the Tube can cost up to £5.60, which is more than the cost of a single journey on the New York City Subway or the Paris Métro. Despite its high cost, the Tube remains a popular and convenient way to travel around London. It is a fast, efficient, and reliable way to get from one place to another. The closure of ticket offices is unlikely to have a major impact on the Tube's popularity or convenience.

title: Auschwitz victim Jane Haining's relatives attend reunion
text: The recently discovered document offers fresh insight into the life of Jane Haining from Dunscore. In total some 14 of her relatives attended the event in Edinburgh. One of them, Catriona Routledge, said she thought it would be fascinating to learn more about her great-great-aunt, adding: "I'm so glad we are able to do this at long last." "We remember her as Aunty Jane and we know she used to send wee parcels to her family back home," Catriona said. "We did not know about the extent she cared for the children." Another great-great-niece, Morag Pollard said: "My grandfather and his brother, the sons of Jane Haining's sister, were brought up as if they were Jane's own children. "They were looked after by the family while their mother died when they were young. "They did not talk about it too much but what I did gather is that they were happy times." Rev Iain MacDonald from Jane Haining's home church said she was "an extraordinary woman. "She was one in thousands of people who were caught up in circumstances that they did not have any control over," he said. "For her to have the courage to go and help and then to stay when everyone was wanting her to go back makes her quite an extraordinary woman. "She was a remarkable person." The document states that Jane Haining came to the sanctuary to make a deliberate decision to stay. It shows that she was "not prepared to leave the girls under any circumstances whatsoever." Catriona Routledge said: "We knew all along that she stayed to look after the children but we did not know that she made a conscious decision to do so. "It might have been more courageous than we thought." A memorial to Jane Haining was erected in Dunscore in 1995 and she is set to be honoured with a permanent display in the Museum of Edinburgh dedicated to her life. The current exhibition there has been visited by more than 50,000 people. A film has also been made to tell the story of Jane Haining. Entitled For Those I Loved, it charts the story of her work in Budapest and the circumstances of how she went to Auschwitz. It features family photographs, a commentary by niece Margaret Haining and readings by actress Siobhan Redmond.

title: Three-point turn may be dropped from UK driving test
text: Under a revised practical exam, learners may also be asked to use a satellite navigation system instead of following road signs. The DVSA said the changes are not a "watering down" of the test, but rather a "modernisation" to reflect the way people drive today. The three-point turn has been a staple of the UK driving test for decades, but it is becoming increasingly less relevant as more and more drivers rely on sat navs. Sat navs can provide clear and concise directions, which can be helpful for drivers who are unfamiliar with an area. The DVSA said that the decision on whether or not to remove the three-point turn from the test will be made after the trial has been completed. title: Homeless mental health and drugs services 'broken' in Wales
text: By Daniel Davies BBC Wales, Correspondent Funding is too low to cope with a "rough sleeping crisis" in Wales, according to a committee report which also cited a lack of leadership. Charities want "radical action", including extra money to deliver better drug and alcohol services. The Welsh government said it was committed to addressing homelessness. The Senedd's health committee found a "lack of coherent and cohesive leadership" in homelessness and mental health services. Urgent action needed, say homelessness charities Jenny Rathbone MS, chair of the health committee, said: "Despite some good work by individuals and organisations, overall progress on tackling homelessness is too slow and inconsistent across Wales. "In particular, we are concerned about the lack of co-ordination and leadership that exists at a local and regional level." The committee found that statutory guidance and regulation was "too weak" and was not followed consistently. "Consequently, a range of services are not operating to required standards," the report said. Its findings come at a time when homelessness in Wales is at a record high. Official figures show an 11% increase in the number sleeping rough in December 2022 compared to the same time in 2021. In 2023, 350 people were counted sleeping on the streets. The committee said that "piecemeal" work by councils and the voluntary sector "cannot be a substitute for a co-ordinated, more consistent and transformative approach". It has called on the Welsh government, local authorities, and health boards to "collaborate to develop a 10-year strategy to end rough sleeping". The report also said investment in addiction and mental health services was "far too low". "We consider this to be wholly inadequate given the high levels of substance misuse and mental health problems among the homeless population," it added. Dr Patrick Kitley, chairman of the Royal College of Psychiatrists in Wales, said: "We need a radical approach to our drug and alcohol services. "This must be embedded within broader homelessness services with a focus on recovery." Plaid Cymru's health spokesman, Rhun ap Iorwerth MS, said: "The homelessness crisis and the lack of suitable provision of mental health and drug and alcohol services have gone on for far too long." A Welsh government spokesperson said: "We are committed to addressing homelessness and providing support for those who need it most. "The Tackling Homelessness Action Plan sets out our plan to deliver our commitment to end rough sleeping in Wales by 2030." The spokesperson said it was "committed to supporting people who are homeless for whatever reason" and it provided more than £20m annually to local authorities to support them. "We will continue to work collaboratively with health boards, the homelessness sector and others to deliver the right support for people who are homeless."

title: MPs doubt supermarket scheme to spot carers
text: By Rebecca Keating BBC News Sainsbury's has begun training staff to look for signs that customers may be caring for elderly or disabled people. They are told to give those doing two lots of shopping at once, or struggling to manage heavy bags, a little extra help. But some MPs fear the supermarket giant is only doing this to boost profits, by aiming to sell more products to carers. The retailer said its staff would be "discreet and sensitive" when approaching customers, and would only offer help if it was clear that it was needed. Customers would not be asked about their personal circumstances, Sainsbury's said. The move is part of a wider initiative by the supermarket to help vulnerable customers. Staff are also being trained to identify people who may be lonely or isolated. Sainsbury's said it had listened to feedback from carers and other groups, and had designed the scheme to be as non-intrusive as possible. However, some MPs have expressed concerns about the scheme. Labour's Barbara Keeley said she was worried that it could be used to target carers with marketing campaigns. "I think it's a bit patronising and actually, it might be counter-productive," she said. "If people feel like they're being targeted, they might be less likely to come forward and ask for help." Conservative MP Caroline Nokes said she was "a little bit sceptical" about the scheme. "I think it's great that Sainsbury's are trying to help vulnerable customers, but I just worry that this could be a way of them trying to sell more products," she said. Sainsbury's said it was "committed to supporting carers" and that the scheme was "not about selling more products". "This is about helping people who are struggling to do their shopping," a spokesperson said. "We're not going to be asking people about their personal circumstances. We're just going to be offering them a little bit of extra help if we think they need it." The scheme is being piloted in 20 stores across the UK. If successful, it could be rolled out to all of Sainsbury's 600 stores.

title: Family of man shot dead by sheriff's deputy awarded $4 damages
text: Gregory Vaughn Hill Jr was shot through his garage door on 14 January 2014 by the deputy in St Lucie County, Florida, while his hands were up. His family has now been awarded $4 in damages after an eight-year legal battle. The fatal shooting happened as Hill opened his garage door as the deputy was looking for someone else. The deputy claimed to have mistaken his phone for a gun. Body camera footage of the incident was released by the sheriff's office in 2017. It showed Hill opening his garage door and raising his hands in the air as the deputy fired four shots through it. Hill's family filed a wrongful death lawsuit against the sheriff's office in 2015. The case went to trial in 2019, but a federal jury found that the deputy did not use excessive force. The family appealed the verdict and in April 2022, the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the jury's verdict was not supported by the evidence. The court ordered a new trial on the issue of whether the deputy used excessive force. In November 2022, the family reached a settlement with the sheriff's office for $4. The settlement was approved by a federal judge on 10 January 2023. Hill's family said they were "disappointed" with the amount of damages they were awarded. "We feel like our son's life was worth more than $4," Hill's mother, Beatrice Hill, said. "But we're grateful that we were able to get some justice for him." The sheriff's office said it was "pleased" that the case had been resolved. "We believe that the settlement is fair and reasonable," a spokesperson for the sheriff's office said. The settlement comes after a string of high-profile police killings of unarmed black men in the United States. The deaths of George Floyd, Breonna Taylor, and Ahmaud Arbery sparked widespread protests and calls for police reform. In response to the outcry, some police departments have begun to adopt new policies, such as requiring officers to wear body cameras and to de-escalate situations before using force. However, critics say that more needs to be done to address the issue of police brutality.
