title: Concern over drivers using social media at the wheel
text: Concern over drivers using social media at the wheel By Ben Mundy Newsbeat reporter The head of roads policing in England and Wales, Chief Constable Suzette Davenport, says people are increasingly posting updates, taking photos and video calling behind the wheel. She says this is a "real concern" as it can be just as dangerous as drink driving. "We are seeing increasing numbers of people using social media while they're driving," she said. "They're posting updates, taking photos, even video calling. It's a real concern because it's just as dangerous as drink driving." Research by the RAC found that one in five drivers admitted to using social media while driving in the past year. The survey also found that drivers who used social media at the wheel were more likely to have been involved in a crash in the past five years. Chief Constable Davenport said: "We need to do more to educate drivers about the dangers of using social media at the wheel. "It's not just about the risk of crashing, it's also about the fact that it can distract you from other hazards on the road." The RAC is calling for tougher penalties for drivers who use social media at the wheel. RAC spokesman Simon Williams said: "We believe that using social media at the wheel should be treated as seriously as drink driving. "We want the government to introduce a specific offence for using social media while driving, with a minimum penalty of a £200 fine and six points on your licence." Chief Constable Davenport said she supports the RAC's call for tougher penalties. "We need to send a clear message that using social media at the wheel is unacceptable," she said. "We will continue to work with our partners to educate drivers about the dangers of this behaviour and we will also be taking enforcement action against those who break the law."

title: West Coast Main Line bid probe 'must be external'
text: The decision to award the franchise to FirstGroup was scrapped over "technical flaws" in the bidding process. The government has since announced a review of what went wrong, but Labour says this should not be carried out by the Department for Transport (DfT). Shadow transport secretary Andy McDonald said an external probe was needed to restore trust in the process. "The botched West Coast Main Line competition has cost the taxpayer millions of pounds and undermined trust in the government's ability to run a fair and transparent bidding process," he said. "An internal DfT review into what went wrong simply won't cut it. The public needs to know that the government is taking this seriously and that lessons will be learned to prevent the same mistakes happening again. "The only way to achieve this is through an independent external review." The DfT has said it will "carefully consider" Labour's request. A spokesman said: "We are conducting a thorough review of the West Coast Main Line bidding process to understand what went wrong and learn lessons for the future. "We will carefully consider Labour's request for an external review and respond in due course." The West Coast Main Line is one of the busiest railway lines in the UK, running from London Euston to Glasgow Central. The franchise to operate the line was awarded to FirstGroup in August 2022, but the decision was scrapped in October 2022 after the DfT found "technical flaws" in the bidding process. The government has since announced a review of the process, which is being led by former civil servant Keith Williams. The review is expected to report back by the end of the year.

title: Children need more exercise - especially girls, study says
text: By Nick Triggle Health correspondent, BBC News University College London researchers found just 51% of the 6,500 children they monitored achieved the recommended hour of physical activity each day. For girls, the figure was just 38%, compared with 63%. They say girls are more reluctant to take part in activities that will make them sweaty, messy or put them at risk of injury. And for both boys and girls, after-school clubs and family outings play a key role in "topping up" children's activity levels. The research, published in The Lancet Child and Adolescent Health journal, is the largest of its kind, and tracks activity in 11-12 year olds from 12 countries, including the UK, US, Belgium and Australia. The World Health Organization recommends children aged five to 17 years should do at least 60 minutes of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity every day, to maintain a healthy weight and reduce the risk of heart disease, stroke and type 2 diabetes. But the study found that around half (49%) of children across the globe were falling short. "The good news is that across all of the countries, over 80% of children were managing at least some physical activity," said Prof Russell Viner, one of the authors of the study. "But the bad news is that it's not enough." The study used accelerometers - worn on the wrist like a watch - to measure children's activity. "What we found was, girls were much less active than boys. On average, they did 25 minutes less activity per day," said Prof Viner. "There are a number of factors at play - girls are more likely to spend time at home, playing video games or watching TV, and they are more concerned about getting messy or sweaty." "And doing strenuous activities can be painful for girls, because they may be beginning to develop breasts." The study also found that activity levels varied widely between countries - with children in Australia and New Zealand the most active and those in Colombia, Brazil and South Africa the least active. One of the reasons for this was the time spent on "active travel". "Children in New Zealand and Australia were much more likely to walk or cycle to school," said Prof Viner. "And going to school and walking home provide kids with an easy way to top up their daily activity level." The study also found that watching TV and playing video games can reduce activity levels by the equivalent of one to two hours per day. "But while screen time is important, what really concerns us is the children who are not doing any structured activity," said Prof Viner. "It's really important that we find ways to increase physical activity in children. And that means encouraging them to take part in activities that they enjoy, and making sure there are safe places for them to play."

title: Italy coalition: Thousands rally in Rome against cuts
text: Wielding red flags and placards, they urged the centre-left Prime Minister, Enrico Letta, to scrap austerity measures and focus on job creation. Public trust in his fragile coalition with the centre-right is dropping, opinion polls suggest. "We're here today to tell the government to stop killing us," said one protester, Livia Albertini, a retired teacher. "We want them to stop cutting education, health and public services. We want them to start investing in jobs and the future." The protest was called by the largest Italian trade union, the CGIL, as well as several leftist parties and social movements. They say that the government's austerity measures are hitting the poor and working class the hardest, while the rich and powerful continue to get richer. "This government is making the rich richer and the poor poorer," said Susanna Camusso, the leader of the CGIL. "We cannot accept this anymore. We need a change of course." The government has defended its austerity measures, saying they are necessary to reduce Italy's high debt and deficit. But critics say the measures are too harsh and are causing unnecessary hardship. "These cuts are killing people," said Antonio Lai, a disabled protester. "I'm here to fight for my rights and the rights of all disabled people. We cannot afford to lose any more." The protest comes at a time of growing public discontent in Italy. The government's popularity has plummeted in recent months, and there is increasing speculation that it could collapse. A recent opinion poll found that only 29% of Italians approve of the government's performance. Dissatisfaction with the government is particularly high among young people, who are struggling to find jobs and afford housing. The government is facing a difficult balancing act. It needs to reduce the deficit while also addressing the needs of the population. If it fails to do so, it could face a wave of protests and instability.

title: Tay Cities Deal £1.84bn plan to create 15,000 jobs
text: The Tay Cities Deal submission document includes more than 50 projects, including a scheme to boost employment through oil and gas decommissioning. The bid seeks £826m over 10 years from the Scottish and UK governments. Angus Council leader Beth Whiteside welcomed the bid submission but warned that the region needed "transformational investment". Local government body Cosla said the submission was a "positive step". Tay Cities Deal is a partnership of six local authorities - Angus, Dundee City, Perth and Kinross, Fife and Clackmannanshire councils. The deal is expected to contribute £1.84bn to the area's economy and create 15,000 jobs. Angus Council convener Beth Whiteside said: "I welcome the submission of the Tay Cities Deal to the Scottish government. We have worked hard to produce a bid which, if successful, will attract significant investment into Angus. "The area, however, has unique challenges which need to be met and it is crucial that we receive transformational investment." Ms Whiteside added: "The Scottish government have led this process and I would like to thank all those who have been involved in the development of the bid." Bruce Crawford convener of Cosla's Tay Cities Deal Joint Committee said: "This is a positive step and a welcome development. We look forward to discussing the submission and the projects it contains with the partners, the Scottish government and UK government." The Tay Cities Deal submission includes projects such as: A £100m project to regenerate Perth city centre A £10m project to improve public transport in Dundee A £20m project to create a new innovation centre in Angus A £10m project to develop a new tourism strategy for the Tay Cities region A £10m project to support the oil and gas decommissioning sector The UK government said it would "carefully consider the bid". A spokesman said: "The UK government is committed to working with the Scottish government to support economic growth in the Tay Cities region. "We will now carefully consider the Tay Cities Deal bid and work with the Scottish government to explore the potential for further investment in the region."

title: Betsi health board chief criticises 'misleading' Tawel Fan claims
text: It made major criticisms but found no evidence of institutional abuse at the now-closed Tawel Fan ward for dementia patients at Glan Clwyd Hospital. Some politicians and some families had claimed that abuse on the ward was widespread and systematic. The independent inquiry into the ward was ordered by Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board in 2020. It was chaired by former High Court judge Wyn Williams QC. Its report found there was no evidence to back up the claims of abuse, but it did find there were many problems on the ward, which has now been closed. In a hard-hitting report, it concluded that the board's governance arrangements "required significant improvement". It also said the board had failed to respond adequately to concerns and complaints about the ward. In response to the report, a spokesman for the health board said it had accepted "all the findings and recommendations in the report and is already taking action to address each one". The report made 24 recommendations to the health board, including: Improve its governance arrangements Respond more effectively to concerns and complaints Improve safeguarding arrangements Improve staffing levels and training Establish an independent body to provide assurance that improvements are being made. In a statement, the Welsh government said it was "deeply concerned" by the findings of the report. It said it was working with the health board to ensure that the recommendations were implemented. The report comes after a series of allegations of abuse at the ward. In 2019, a BBC Wales investigation revealed that a number of patients had been subjected to physical and emotional abuse. The health board initially denied the allegations, but later apologized and launched an internal investigation. The independent inquiry was commissioned to investigate the allegations in more detail. It heard evidence from a number of witnesses, including patients, their families, and staff. The report concluded that there was no evidence to support the claims of institutional abuse. However, it did find that there were a number of problems on the ward, including: Understaffing Poor communication Lack of training A culture of fear The report also found that the health board had failed to respond adequately to concerns and complaints about the ward. It said the board had a "defensive and dismissive approach" to concerns raised by families and staff. In response to the report, the health board has said it has accepted all the findings and recommendations. It has also apologized to the families of patients who suffered poor care on the ward. The report is a damning indictment of the health board. It shows that the board failed to protect some of the most vulnerable people in its care. The board must now take action to implement the recommendations of the report and ensure that such abuses can never happen again.

title: TEDGlobal: Burns portrait comes alive at TED
text: By Jane Wakefield Technology reporter, TEDGlobal, Edinburgh The demonstration was part of a session at the TEDGlobal (Technology, Entertainment and Design) conference dedicated to makers and DIY-ers. With a nod to the talking portraits at Harry Potter's Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, the portrait of Robert Burns started to move and speak after Farrow put on a pair of special glasses. Farrow, who describes himself as a "digital artist and necromancer" - someone who brings the dead back to life with technology - said that using his glasses, the portrait "becomes a window into some parallel universe". "I'm using a camera to film my video and then I'm projecting it back on to the painting," he explained. "It's all real time. There are no pre-recorded videos. Instead, my software is analysing the video of my face and neck and then mapping that on to the painting. "This technology has been around for years in films and the video game industry but I wanted to see if it could be used in a different way. "This is the first time that I've used it with a portrait. I'm really interested in the use of artificial intelligence. Can we use computers to bring dead people back to life? Can I upload my brain to the cloud? "If I could, I would want to be like Tupac. I would want to be a rapping ghost." Farrow's work may seem like a gimmick, but he said that it could have a serious use in the future. "I can see this technology being used for historical figures," he said. "Imagine a museum where you can put on a pair of glasses and see Churchill making a speech. Or you could watch Neil Armstrong walking on the moon." "I think it's a really exciting and powerful way to connect with the past." The audience at TEDGlobal seemed impressed with Farrow's work. Afterwards, many people queued up to put on the glasses and see the portrait of Burns for themselves. One person said that it was "like magic". Farrow's work is a reminder that technology is constantly evolving and that we are only just beginning to explore its possibilities.

title: France's Macron calls for 'historic reconstruction' of Europe
text: Speaking in Berlin on the first full day of his presidency, he was joined by German Chancellor Angela Merkel. She said the pair had a "joint conviction" that they needed to "deepen the European Union". Mr Macron's speech was titled "For a Democratic and Sovereign Europe", and he laid out his plans for a "rebirth of Europe" based on three key principles: a sovereign, united Europe; a more democratic Europe; and a Europe that is "open to the world". On the first point, Mr Macron said that Europe needed to become more independent and less reliant on others. He called for a "European defence force" to protect the continent from external threats, and for a "European energy union" to reduce dependence on Russian gas. On the second point, Mr Macron said that Europe needed to become more democratic and accountable to its citizens. He called for a "European citizens' initiative" to give people a greater say in EU decision-making, and for a "European Parliament that is truly representative of the people". On the third point, Mr Macron said that Europe needed to be more open to the world. He called for a "European trade policy that is fair and ambitious", and for a "European immigration policy that is humane and effective". Mr Macron's speech was well-received by the German audience, and it was seen as a sign that he is serious about reforming the EU. However, it remains to be seen whether he will be able to convince other EU leaders to follow his lead. Ms Merkel, who has been a close ally of Mr Macron, said that she shared his "vision for Europe". She said that the EU was "at a crossroads" and that it was time to "take bold steps" to reform it. The speech comes at a time when the EU is facing a number of challenges, including the rise of populism, the threat of terrorism, and the ongoing migration crisis. Mr Macron's speech was seen as an attempt to provide a positive vision for the future of Europe and to reassure people that the EU can meet these challenges. However, it remains to be seen whether Mr Macron will be able to convince other EU leaders to follow his lead. The EU is a complex institution, and it is difficult to get all 28 member states to agree on anything. Mr Macron will need to use all of his diplomatic skills to build a consensus around his plans for reform.

title: Potholes cost councils £1,600 a day in compensation
text: In total, £584,745 was paid out last year to drivers, with the five-year total now passing £2.7m. Glasgow City Council had by far the highest amount of compensation claims, with 190 over the past five years. A Freedom of Information request by BBC Scotland found that the number of successful claims has risen by more than a fifth since 2017-18. The local authority with the second-highest number of successful claims is Edinburgh, with 100 over the same period. The Scottish government said it was "committed to maintaining" the country's roads and "encouraging active travel." It said it had provided more than £1bn for maintenance in the past five years. However, the RAC said the "alarming" increase in compensation payouts showed that more investment was needed. "Our roads continue to deteriorate at a time when traffic levels are rising and more people are choosing to cycle," said the RAC's Nicholas Lyes. "It is clear that much more action is needed to bring our roads up to scratch and keep road users safe." The Scottish government said it was "committed to working with local authorities to improve the condition of our roads." "We have provided more than £1 billion for maintenance in the past five years, and we will continue to invest in our infrastructure to support sustainable economic growth," a spokesman said. "We also encourage active travel, such as walking and cycling, and recognize the importance of safe and accessible roads for all users." The RAC's Nicholas Lyes said: "The alarming increase in compensation payouts shows that more investment is needed in our roads." "Our roads continue to deteriorate at a time when traffic levels are rising and more people are choosing to cycle," he said. "It is clear that much more action is needed to bring our roads up to scratch and keep road users safe."

title: China 'to survey disputed East China Sea islands'
text: State news agency Xinhua said the survey was part of China's "programme to safeguard its maritime rights and interests". The islands are controlled by Japan, which refers to them as the Senkakus, but also claimed by China, which calls them the Diaoyus. The move comes amid heightened tensions between the two countries over the islands, which are located in an area believed to be rich in natural resources. Beijing's announcement on Tuesday (19 July) confirmed the survey had started near the disputed islands the previous day. Japan has lodged a formal protest with China, saying the survey was "unacceptable" and a violation of its territorial waters. Tokyo said it had dispatched patrol ships and aircraft to the area to monitor the Chinese activity. China's foreign ministry spokesman, Qin Gang, said the survey was a "routine" operation, carried out in waters under China's jurisdiction. He urged Japan to "immediately stop its illegal activities", and respect China's sovereignty. The Diaoyu/Senkaku islands are a group of uninhabited islands in the East China Sea, about 200km (124 miles) north-east of Taiwan. They have been under Japanese control since 1895, but China claims they were first discovered by Chinese sailors in the 14th Century. The dispute over the islands has escalated in recent years, with both countries sending ships and aircraft to patrol the area. The islands are thought to be surrounded by rich fishing grounds and potentially valuable oil and gas reserves. The survey by China is likely to further increase tensions between the two countries, which are also at odds over a number of other issues, including their respective claims to parts of the South China Sea. The United States has urged both China and Japan to resolve their dispute peacefully, and has said it would not take sides in the matter. The US has also said that it has no view on the ultimate sovereignty of the islands, and that it expects both sides to avoid actions that could escalate tensions.

title: First peek at Harry Potter and the Cursed Child play
text: By Amelia Butterly Newsbeat reporter Published on Pottermore, JK Rowling's Harry Potter website, the images show a young boy in a nest. The photos also show an older boy, said to be an adult Harry Potter, talking to a bearded man thought to be Ron Weasley. The photographs have fuelled speculation that the play, which is set 19 years after the end of the Harry Potter series, will focus on one of Harry's children. But the latest information released on the play's official website suggests Harry and Ron will have a more prominent role in the production. The full synopsis reads: "While Harry grapples with a past that refuses to stay where it belongs, his youngest son Albus must struggle with the weight of a family legacy he never wanted. "As past and present fuse ominously, both father and son learn the uncomfortable truth: sometimes, darkness comes from unexpected places." The synopsis indicates that not everything is plain sailing for Harry and his family in later life. Fans will get a chance to find out what Harry has been up to since the Battle of Hogwarts when the play opens at the Palace Theatre in London's West End on 30 July 2016. While little has been revealed about the plot of the play, speculation is already rife among Potter fans. Some fans have suggested that Albus, Harry's youngest son, will struggle to live up to his family name. Others have speculated that the play will explore the relationship between Harry and his rival Draco Malfoy, whose son Scorpius will also be attending Hogwarts. Whatever the plot, the play is sure to be a major event in the Harry Potter calendar. Tickets for the play went on sale in October 2015 and sold out within hours. A second batch of tickets went on sale in November 2015 and also sold out quickly. The play will run for an initial run of 16 weeks, with further tickets due to be released in the coming months.

title: 'Scrap ban' on term-time holidays
text: By Hannah Richardson BBC News education reporter Since September last year, local authorities have been obliged to fine parents who take children out of school for unauthorised absences. But the Local Government Association says the "zero-tolerance" approach for term-time holidays has resulted in "huge" variations in fines across the country. And campaigners argue that the rules are unfair, disproportionately affecting poorer families. In theory, local authorities are supposed to issue a fixed penalty notice (FPN) of £60, rising to £120 if it's not paid within 28 days, and possibly a fine of up to £1,000 for non-payment. However, a BBC investigation has found some are not issuing any fines, while others issue penalties of up to £2,500 in some cases. A Department for Education spokesperson said it was "disappointing" that "very small number of parents continue to take their children out of school without authorisation - and that there is a "small but significant variation in enforcement." Here are some key points: Fining parents for taking their children out of school during term time is a hot topic at the moment, with strong opinions on both sides of the debate. The government introduced a "zero-tolerance" approach to term-time holidays in September 2013, and since then, local authorities have been obliged to fine parents who take their children out of school for unauthorised absences. However, there is a huge variation in fines across the country, with some councils issuing no fines at all and others issuing fines of up to £2,500. The Local Government Association says this is because the government has not provided clear guidance on how to enforce the new rules. Campaigners argue that the new rules are unfair, disproportionately affecting poorer families. The government says it is "disappointing" that a very small number of parents continue to take their children out of school without authorisation, and that there is a small but significant variation in enforcement. Only 10 councils out of 128 in England issued more than 1,000 fines for absence last year, according to the LGA. A handful, including Hartlepool and Bristol, issued no fines at all. The LGA, which represents more than 370 local councils, said there was "confusion and inconsistency" about how the rules should be enforced. "It's unworkable and unfair on families," he said. "The system needs urgent reform." The government said it was committed to improving school attendance and that it was working with local authorities to ensure the rules were enforced fairly.

title: Wife 'stunned' by wedding ring find
text: Paul Higson had been scared to tell his wife Jan he had lost the ring and it took him two months to confess. He works all over and is often away for long periods, so he was relieved when a metal detectorist called to say they had it. "I'm amazed it's been found," he said. "It's quite amazing it's been found. I can't believe it." The ring was discovered by keen detectorist David Moore with the help of his 11-year-old grandson Curtis. The pair were searching a field near Hearsall Common, close to the Hearsall Hangar community centre in Coventry, when they found the platinum band. It had the name "Jan" engraved inside, as well as the date the couple married in 1977. "I could tell it was a wedding ring, it's quite a distinctive pattern," Mr Moore said. "We get quite a lot of wedding rings brought into us and I've got quite a collection at home. Now and again, we get a call from the owner, but they usually give up searching after a while. "So when I saw it had 'Jan' engraved on it, I thought I'd give it a go and try to find the owner. "I put the details on Facebook and a friend of Jan's got in touch to say it was hers." Jan, a retired nurse, was at home when she got the call. She initially thought it was a joke, but was stunned when she realized it was true. "I was watching Songs of Praise on television and I got a call from a lady called Janet and she said, 'You've lost your wedding ring, haven't you?'" she said. "She said, 'My husband and grandson have found it.' I just couldn't believe it. "I thought, 'Oh no, there's no way.' I've had it ever since we got married in 1977. I couldn't believe somebody had found it. I just can't believe it." The couple, who live in nearby Keresley, were reunited with the ring on Monday. "I'm so relieved to have it back," Jan said. "I never thought I'd see it again." Paul added: "It was my fault, I should never have taken it off."

title: VW US sales rise despite scandal
text: On Monday US regulators said an extra 800,000 cars had been identified as using devices that concealed emission levels during testing. The carmaker sold 30,387 cars in October, a rise of 6.6% on the same period last year. It was the third month in a row that sales have increased. The company's US chief executive Hinrich Woebcken said October's results were "encouraging". However, the firm still faces a number of challenges, including a criminal investigation by the US Department of Justice and a class action lawsuit filed by owners of affected vehicles. Volkswagen has admitted that 11 million of its cars worldwide were fitted with software, known as a "defeat device", that allowed them to cheat on emissions tests. The scandal has cost the company billions of dollars in fines and compensation, and has led to the resignation of its chief executive Martin Winterkorn. In the US, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has ordered Volkswagen to recall nearly 500,000 vehicles. The company has also agreed to pay a $4.3bn (£2.8bn) fine for violating environmental regulations. Despite these challenges, Volkswagen's US sales have remained relatively strong. The company has been offering incentives to customers, such as zero-percent financing and cash rebates. It has also been promoting its new models, such as the redesigned Tiguan SUV and the all-electric e-Golf. Volkswagen's US sales chief Mark McNabb said that the company was "pleased" with October's results. However, he acknowledged that the company still faces a "number of challenges". "We are working hard to address the issues related to the diesel emissions situation, and we are committed to regaining the trust of our customers," he said.

title: Women still do more household chores than men, ONS finds
text: The Office for National Statistics said that, when it came to unpaid chores at home, women were doing almost 40% more than men on average. Men averaged 16 hours a week on unpaid work in the home, compared with women's 22 hours. The ONS data showed a small improvement on the previous year, when the gap was 41%. However, the data also showed that the share of unpaid work done by women had not changed significantly since the early 1990s. The figures come from the ONS's annual Time Use Survey, which asks people about how they spend their time. The survey found that women were more likely to do unpaid chores such as: Cleaning Cooking Laundry Childcare Caring for elderly or disabled relatives Men were more likely to do unpaid chores such as: DIY Gardening Car maintenance The ONS said that the gender gap in unpaid work was "partly due to the fact that women are more likely to work part-time or have caring responsibilities". However, the ONS also said that "gender stereotypes and expectations" may play a role. The ONS data also showed that the gender gap in unpaid work was wider among younger people. Women aged 25-34 did an average of 25 hours of unpaid work a week, compared with 17 hours for men of the same age. The gender gap in unpaid work has been declining in recent decades, but progress has been slow. The ONS said that "more needs to be done to address the gender gap in unpaid work". The ONS data also showed that the amount of time people spend on paid and unpaid work has increased in recent decades. In 1995, people spent an average of 37 hours a week on paid and unpaid work. By 2015, this had increased to 42 hours a week. The ONS said that the increase in working hours was partly due to the fact that more women are now in the workforce. However, the ONS also said that "the increasing demands of work and family life" may be playing a role.

title: Coronavirus: Ex-soldier self-isolating on 'uninhabited' Hildasay
text: Chris Lewis has walked 12,000 miles after setting off from near his home in Swansea in August 2017. He has now been self-isolating on the remote Scottish island of Hildasay since March 23. The island, which is located in the North Atlantic, is home to only one other person, a farmer who lives on the neighboring island of Sanday. Lewis, a former soldier, decided to self-isolate on Hildasay after the UK government imposed a lockdown in response to the coronavirus pandemic. He said he wanted to "get away from the crowds" and "minimize the risk" of contracting the virus. "I'm not afraid of the virus," Lewis told the BBC. "I'm just being sensible. I don't want to put anyone else at risk." Lewis has been living in a bothy, a small stone hut, on Hildasay. He has been foraging for food and fishing for mackerel. He has also been keeping a blog about his experience. "I'm really enjoying it," Lewis said. "It's a beautiful island and I'm getting plenty of exercise. I'm also learning a lot about survival skills." Lewis is not the only person who has chosen to self-isolate on a remote island during the pandemic. In April, a group of six people from the UK sailed to the uninhabited island of Gigha in the Inner Hebrides. The group, which included a doctor, a nurse, and a teacher, said they wanted to "create a safe haven" away from the virus. "We're not trying to escape reality," one of the group members told the BBC. "We just want to live a more sustainable and self-sufficient life." The decision to self-isolate on a remote island is not without its risks. The islands are often exposed to harsh weather conditions and there is limited access to medical care. However, for some people, the benefits of escaping the crowds and living a simpler life outweigh the risks. "I'm not sure how long I'll stay on Hildasay," Lewis said. "But I'm in no rush to leave. I'm enjoying the peace and quiet and I'm learning a lot about myself."

title: Putin's Stasi spy ID pass found in Germany
text: The Russian president has expressed pride in his record as a communist KGB officer in Dresden in the 1980s. His Stasi pass, a document that allowed him to access restricted areas in East Germany, was recently discovered in the archives of the German secret service. The pass, which bears Putin's photo and signature, was issued in 1989, shortly before the fall of the Berlin Wall. It is a reminder of Putin's close ties to the former East German regime, which was one of the Soviet Union's closest allies. Putin has never denied his past as a KGB officer, and he has often spoken fondly of his time in Dresden. In a 2014 interview, he said that he "learned a lot" from his experience in East Germany, and that it helped him to "understand the world." However, some critics have accused Putin of glorifying the Soviet Union and its repressive regime. They argue that his nostalgia for the past is a sign that he is not committed to democratic values. The discovery of Putin's Stasi pass is likely to fuel further debate about his past. It is a reminder of his close ties to the former East German regime, and it raises questions about his commitment to democratic values. In addition to the pass, the German secret service also discovered a number of other documents related to Putin's time in Dresden. These documents include reports on his activities, as well as assessments of his character. The documents provide a glimpse into Putin's life as a young KGB officer. They show that he was a ambitious and dedicated agent, who was highly valued by his superiors. The documents also reveal that Putin was involved in a number of controversial activities while in Dresden. These activities include the surveillance of dissidents and the suppression of political dissent. The discovery of Putin's Stasi pass and the related documents is a significant event. It provides new information about his past, and it raises important questions about his commitment to democratic values.

title: Trump tariffs: President says EU makes business 'impossible'
text: Defending his tariff plans as he hosted the Swedish PM at the White House, Mr Trump said other countries had "taken advantage of" the US for many years. He said the EU was "very difficult to deal with" and made it "impossible" for US businesses to make money. "We can't have that, we're not going to have that," he said. The EU has said it will retaliate against the US tariffs, which it believes violate World Trade Organization (WTO) rules. The US has already imposed tariffs on steel and aluminium from the EU, and is threatening to impose tariffs on cars and other products. The EU has said it will impose tariffs on a range of US products, including motorcycles, bourbon and jeans. The trade dispute is the latest in a series of tensions between the US and the EU. The two sides have also been at odds over Iran, climate change and the Iran nuclear deal. The US has also imposed tariffs on China, and is threatening to impose further tariffs on Chinese goods. title: Sir Terry Matthews: Wales lacks IT commerce skills
text: The industrialist, who made his fortune in hi-tech firms, is to address a conference in Newport on how businesses can use IT to boost profits. He said: "We don't lack people who can write an algorithm, or design a software programme, or get a computer system up and running. What we lack, and this is across all industries, is people who really understand how to transform businesses by using IT." Sir Terry believes the Welsh government is taking important steps to improve the situation, but more is needed from industry itself. "The Welsh government has a role, through schools and training, to make sure people get the basic skills they need," he said. "But really, we need more people to become IT-savvy middle managers. Businesses need to create more jobs specifically in this area." He said companies need to move away from the "traditional mindset" of seeing IT as a "geeky backroom function". He said: "It's not that. IT is a powerful tool that can help businesses reach new customers, increase efficiency, improve productivity, and make better decisions." Sir Terry said the conference will hear practical advice from business leaders who have successfully used IT to boost their profits, including examples from industries as diverse as manufacturing, tourism and retail. "I hope a lot of business people from all over Wales will come along," he said. "The conference will leave them in no doubt that IT can be a big help to businesses of all sizes." The conference, called "IT for Business Growth", will be held at the Newport Hilton on 10 May. Further information can be found at www.itforbusinessgrowth.com. Sir Terry Matthews is a Welsh entrepreneur and philanthropist. He is the founder and former chairman of several successful hi-tech firms, including Mitel, Newbridge Networks and Dialog Semiconductor. He is also the founder of the Celtic Manor Resort in Newport. In 2004, Sir Terry was awarded a knighthood for his services to business and philanthropy. He is a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering and a member of the Welsh Business Hall of Fame.

title: Mayor hopes Treasury will hop on board travel plans
text: Tom EdwardsTransport correspondent, London@BBCTomEdwardson Twitter Today the mayor is in Northern Ireland showing off the new chassis production line for the 'New Bus for London', a modern design based on the old Routemaster which has been built at Wrightbus in Ballymena for 70 years. It will be a hybrid diesel-electric double-decker with more wheelchair spaces and USB charging points and, crucially, the ability to convert to 100% electric when the technology allows. At the same time, Transport for London (TfL) has begun its own consultation on proposals for a new bus franchising system in the capital. Under the plans, all buses would be run by a small number of companies under contract to TfL, rather than the current system where each operator is responsible for its own routes. The mayor hopes the Treasury will hop on board his travel plans by providing funding for a pilot scheme and, crucially, for the conversion to electric buses. The government's Integrated Rail Plan for the north of England, published last week, has been criticised for ignoring Leeds and Bradford and the potential to develop the Northern Powerhouse. There is a glimmer of hope for West Yorkshire, however, with the promise of £200m towards a new mass transit system that will link Leeds Bradford Airport with the city centres of Leeds and Bradford. In his speech, the mayor will also unveil plans for a new walking and cycling superhighway between Barking Riverside in east London and the City of London. The 12-mile route, which will be open 24 hours a day, will be mostly segregated from traffic and is intended to make it easier and safer for people to travel between east and central London. The mayor is also expected to announce a new push to make London the most cycle-friendly city in the world. The plans include a new 'Cycle Superhub' at Waterloo station, which will provide secure parking for 10,000 bikes, and a new 'Cycleway to Heaven' that will link the North Circular with Alexandra Palace. The mayor's plans are ambitious, but they are also essential if London is to meet its goals of reducing air pollution and congestion. With the government's support, he can make London a more sustainable and livable city for everyone.

title: ME, or chronic fatigue syndrome, 'not caused by the XMRV virus', say researchers
text: By Helen Briggs Health reporter, BBC News US scientists linked the condition, also known as ME, to a mouse-like virus in 2009 after finding it in a few patients. The finding raised hopes that a cause had been found and even that a cure might be on the horizon. But subsequent research has cast doubt on this idea, with other scientists failing to find the virus in ME patients. Now a new study in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences provides the strongest evidence yet that the virus is not a cause of ME. The study tested nearly 1,000 people - about half with ME, and half healthy - for the presence of XMRV. They found that, out of about 500 people with ME, 6.7% had antibodies to the virus. But, out of about 500 healthy controls, 6.5% also had antibodies to the virus. This suggests that the presence of the virus is not what distinguishes people with ME from healthy people. The researchers also looked for the actual virus in the blood of people with ME and in healthy controls, again finding no difference between the groups. They also looked for signs of an active viral infection in people with ME and did not find any. This all adds to the growing body of evidence that XMRV is not a cause of ME. At the very least, the virus is not necessary for the development of ME, and it is unlikely to be sufficient to cause the condition. The researchers say that this does not mean that a virus is not involved in ME. It could be that another virus, so far undetected, is the cause. Or it could be that a virus is a trigger for ME in some people, but that other factors are also required. The researchers say that more research is needed to find the cause of ME. In the meantime, they say that people with ME should not be discouraged by the latest findings. There is still hope that a cause will be found and that a cure will be developed.

title: Netflix removes Dave Chappelle's show after comedian's complaint
text: Chappelle's Show first aired on Comedy Central from 2002 to 2006. But in an excerpt from a recent stand-up gig that he posted on Instagram, he claimed he "never got paid" royalties. "They didn't have to pay me because I signed a contract," he says in the clip. "But is that right? I found out that these people were streaming my work, and they never paid me a dime..." Netflix confirmed to the BBC that it had removed the show from its platform. "We licensed Chappelle's Show from ViacomCBS, and we're removing the show from Netflix until we can resolve the licensing issues," a spokesperson said. ViacomCBS, which owns Comedy Central, said in a statement that it "has been actively working with Netflix to resolve this issue". The move has sparked a debate about the rights of artists and performers, particularly in the streaming era. Some have argued that Chappelle is right to demand payment for his work, while others have questioned whether he has the legal right to do so. In a statement posted on his website, Chappelle said he was "deeply disappointed" by Netflix's decision to remove the show. He said he had "no idea" that Netflix was not paying him royalties and that he had asked his lawyers to "look into this and find out what happened". The comedian also said that he was "not going to go into a lot of detail" about the matter, but he wanted to make it clear that he "will not tolerate" being "taken advantage of". "I hope that we can come to a resolution soon," he said. "But if we don't, I will take whatever legal action is necessary to protect my rights." The dispute highlights the complex legal landscape around streaming rights. In the past, artists and performers have often signed contracts that give streaming services the right to distribute their work without paying them royalties. However, there is a growing movement to challenge these contracts and to ensure that artists are fairly compensated for their work. It is unclear how the Chappelle's Show dispute will be resolved. However, it is likely to have a significant impact on the way that streaming services negotiate with artists and performers in the future.

title: Man's surgery wait death 'avoidable', says ombudsman
text: Gareth Lewis Jones, from Neath Port Talbot, who had adult congenital heart disease (ACHD), died in March 2013 shortly before his operation. An investigation by the Welsh health ombudsman has found that his death was "avoidable" and that there were "failings" in his care. The ombudsman's report said that Mr Jones's condition was "not adequately managed" by the Abertawe Bro Morgannwg University Health Board. It said that there were "missed opportunities" to diagnose and treat his condition earlier, and that the board failed to provide him with "appropriate and timely care". The report also found that the board did not have a "clear and consistent" policy for managing ACHD patients. Mr Jones's family said they were "deeply disappointed" by the ombudsman's findings. They said in a statement: "We believe that the health board could have done more to prevent Gareth's death, and we are concerned that other patients may be at risk of similar failings." The health board said it accepted the ombudsman's findings and apologized to Mr Jones's family. It said in a statement: "We have already taken steps to improve our services for ACHD patients, and we will continue to work to ensure that all our patients receive the best possible care." The ombudsman's report made a number of recommendations to the health board, including: Developing a clear and consistent policy for managing ACHD patients Improving communication between different healthcare professionals involved in the care of ACHD patients Providing more training for healthcare professionals on ACHD The health board said it would implement all of the ombudsman's recommendations. The ombudsman's investigation also found that the health board had "failed to provide the family with a prompt and adequate response" to their concerns about Mr Jones's care. The board apologized to the family for this failing and said it would take steps to improve its complaints handling procedures. The family said they were pleased that the ombudsman had made this finding. They said: "We hope that this will help to ensure that other families do not have to go through the same experience that we have."

title: Le Patourel brothers could be set for Guernsey blue plaque honour
text: Plans to place the plaque at their former home in the Fosse Andre, in St Peter Port, have been submitted. John Herbert Le Patourel was a leader in the fight to have capital punishment abolished in the British Isles. He was also a campaigner for the rights of homosexuals and for animal welfare. His brother, Clement Le Patourel, was a painter and photographer who was also active in the campaign against capital punishment. The plaque will commemorate the brothers' contribution to social justice. It will also serve as a reminder of the importance of fighting for what you believe in. The Le Patourel brothers were born in Guernsey in the 19th century. John Herbert was born in 1863 and Clement in 1864. The brothers were raised in a religious family and were educated at Elizabeth College in Guernsey. John Herbert Le Patourel studied law at Cambridge University and was called to the bar in 1888. He returned to Guernsey and practiced law until 1905, when he was elected to the States of Guernsey. He served as a member of the States until 1945. During his time in the States, John Herbert Le Patourel was a vocal opponent of capital punishment. He introduced a bill to abolish capital punishment in Guernsey in 1906, but it was defeated. He continued to campaign against capital punishment and in 1943 he succeeded in having it abolished in Guernsey. John Herbert Le Patourel was also a campaigner for the rights of homosexuals. He was one of the founders of the Homosexual Law Reform Society in 1958. He also worked with the Albany Trust, which provided support to homosexuals who had been convicted of crimes. Clement Le Patourel was a painter and photographer. He studied art at the Royal Academy of Arts in London. He returned to Guernsey and worked as a portrait painter. He also took photographs of Guernsey's landscape and people. Clement Le Patourel was an active member of the Society for the Abolition of Capital Punishment. He also worked with the Albany Trust. The Le Patourel brothers were both committed to social justice. They fought for what they believed in and they made a real difference in the world. The plaque at their former home will be a fitting tribute to their work.

title: Covid: Device aids 'virtual' treatment of Leicester patients
text: Patients take their own blood oxygen readings using the small device, which is linked to a smartphone app that sends the data to clinical staff. The monitor, known as a pulse oximeter, measures the level of oxygen saturation in the blood, which can drop to dangerously low levels in Covid-19 patients. The data can then be reviewed by healthcare professionals at the trust's Covid Oximetry@Home service, who can provide advice and support remotely. In some cases, the service has been able to prevent patients from needing to be admitted to hospital. Dr Andy Carson, a consultant respiratory physician at University Hospitals of Leicester Trust, said: "Covid Oximetry@Home has been a real success story. "It has meant that patients can be monitored and treated in the comfort of their own homes, while also freeing up hospital beds for those who need them most. "The pulse oximeters are small and easy to use, and the app is very user-friendly. "Patients have really appreciated being able to take an active role in their own care, and it has given them peace of mind to know that they are being monitored remotely by healthcare professionals." One patient who has benefited from the service is 70-year-old John Smith. Mr Smith, who has underlying health conditions, tested positive for Covid-19 in January. He was initially treated at home by his GP, but his condition deteriorated and he was referred to the Covid Oximetry@Home service. Mr Smith said: "The service was fantastic. I was able to monitor my oxygen levels at home and send the data to the hospital. "The staff were very supportive and they always got back to me quickly if I had any questions. "I'm so grateful that I was able to be treated at home. It meant that I didn't have to be admitted to hospital, and I could recover in the comfort of my own surroundings." The Covid Oximetry@Home service is now being rolled out to other hospitals across the country.

title: Monarch airline awaits package holiday licence decision
text: The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) extended Monarch's licence by 24 hours on Saturday amid uncertainty about the company's future. However, with the deadline now passed, the regulator has yet to comment on whether the airline will be granted a package holiday licence. Monarch, which was founded in 1967, is the UK's fifth largest airline. It operates scheduled and charter flights to destinations in Europe and North Africa. The CAA has said that it will not grant Monarch a licence if it is not satisfied that the airline is financially sound. The regulator is also concerned about Monarch's plans to reduce its fleet and staff. Monarch has said that it is confident that it will be granted a licence. The airline has said that it has a strong business plan and that it is committed to providing a quality service to its customers. However, industry experts have expressed doubts about Monarch's future. title: 'Tuition grants affecting Welsh universities'
text: Prof Colin Riordan, the chair of Universities Wales and vice-chancellor of Cardiff University, said the policy of paying the majority of Welsh students' tuition fees has to change. He wants it replaced with a means tested grant. Ministers are set to announce a major review of student funding in Wales. Prof Riordan wants the Welsh government to bring in a system of student grants that would replace the current system of tuition fee loans. Under the existing scheme, the poorest students pay nothing towards their tuition fees, while the majority pay £9,250 a year towards their degree. This money is paid back through the tax system once graduates are earning more than £27,295 a year. But critics of the current system argue that it is unfair on students from poorer backgrounds, who often end up with large debts. They also say it has contributed to the widening gap between rich and poor. Prof Riordan said the current system was "not sustainable" and needed to be replaced with a "fairer" system. "We need to move to a system of grants that are means tested," he said. "This would mean that students from poorer backgrounds would get more support, while those from wealthier backgrounds would pay more." He said this would help to "level the playing field" and ensure that all students had an equal chance of success. "We want to create a system that is fair and equitable for all students," he said. "We believe that a means tested grant system is the best way to do this." The Welsh government said it was "committed to ensuring that higher education is affordable and accessible to all". "We are currently undertaking a major review of student funding in Wales and will be announcing our findings in due course," a spokesman said. The review is expected to look at a range of options, including a means tested grant system. Any changes to the current system would likely to be phased in over a number of years.

title: NHS pressure: Hospital corridors 'the new emergency wards'
text: By Nick Triggle Health correspondent The warning comes as figures for the NHS in England showed January was one of the busiest months on record for A&E. The figures showed a record number of patients waiting longer than 12 hours in A&E. Dr Adrian Boyle, vice-president of the Royal College of Emergency Medicine, said the service was "under extreme pressure". "We have just had one of the busiest Januarys on record in terms of ambulance arrivals and in A&E," he said. "This means long waits in A&E for patients - and for ambulances waiting to hand over patients. "This results in crews being delayed in the community and unable to respond quickly to the next person." Dr Boyle said the current situation was "unsustainable". "We are seeing more and more patients in our emergency departments, with more complex conditions," he said. "This is putting a huge strain on our resources, and we are having to make difficult decisions about which patients to see first." Dr Boyle said the NHS needed more funding to recruit and retain staff, and to invest in new technology. "We also need to work with our partners in social care to ensure that patients can be discharged from hospital as quickly as possible," he said. A spokesperson for the Department of Health and Social Care said the government was "fully committed to supporting the NHS". "We are investing record amounts in the NHS, and we are working to recruit and retain more staff," the spokesperson said. "We are also working with our partners in social care to ensure that patients can be discharged from hospital as quickly as possible." The spokesperson said the government was "aware of the pressures facing the NHS, and we are working to address them". However, the Royal College of Emergency Medicine has warned that the situation is "unsustainable", and that the NHS needs more funding to recruit and retain staff, and to invest in new technology.

title: Celebrities join calls to axe sixth-form 'learning tax'
text: Unlike schools and academies, sixth-form colleges in England are unable to claim back their VAT costs. The government says they are liable for VAT because they are classified as "commercial organisations". This means that sixth-form colleges have to charge VAT on their fees, which can add up to thousands of pounds for each student. The government has been urged to scrap the VAT charge on sixth-form education, with critics arguing that it is a "stealth tax" on further education. A number of celebrities have now joined the calls to axe the VAT charge, including actor and comedian David Walliams, singer Paloma Faith and TV presenter Davina McCall. In a letter to the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Rishi Sunak, they said: "VAT on sixth-form education is a barrier to learning and opportunity for young people. "It is a stealth tax on further education that is unfair and unjust. We urge you to scrap it." The government has said that it is "committed to supporting further education" and that it will "continue to look at ways to make the system fairer". However, it has not yet committed to scrapping the VAT charge on sixth-form education. The Association of Colleges (AoC) has welcomed the support of celebrities for their campaign to axe the VAT charge. AoC chief executive David Hughes said: "We are grateful to these celebrities for using their voices to highlight the unfairness of VAT on sixth-form education. "This is a tax that is holding back young people and preventing them from reaching their full potential." The AoC is calling on the government to scrap the VAT charge on sixth-form education as a matter of urgency. Mr Hughes said: "We believe that every young person should have the opportunity to access high-quality further education, regardless of their background or financial circumstances. "Scrapping the VAT charge would be a major step towards making this a reality."

title: Edinburgh's Christmas: Market did not have 2018 planning consent
text: Underbelly are still awaiting planning permission to operate in 2019/20, and still need a crucial building warrant. title: Ex-MI6 boss warns over electronic voting risk
text: Sir John Sawers told the BBC that casting a ballot with pencil and paper was "actually much more secure". He warned: "The more things that go online, the more susceptible you are to cyber attacks." But campaigners for electronic voting argue it is more accessible and could increase turnout. Sir John, who was head of MI6 from 2009 to 2014, said the move to online banking during the Covid pandemic had led to a surge in cyber crime. He said the government needed to make an "active decision" on whether the risk of fraud outweighed the benefits of increased accessibility. "I think they have an obligation to make us confident that the systems they are proposing will be safe and secure," he added. The government is currently consulting on plans for online voting in some elections in England. It says it will "not introduce digital-only voting unless and until we are fully satisfied that it is secure". But Sir John said he was "not yet persuaded" that the government had done enough to ensure the security of e-voting systems. "There is still a lot of work to be done," he said. "I think the government needs to be very careful about this. This is not something that can be rushed. It needs to be done properly." The Electoral Reform Society, which campaigns for more accessible voting, said e-voting could make it easier for people to participate in elections. "We know that electronic voting can be secure if it is done properly," said the society's chief executive, Darren Hughes. "It is important to remember that there are many different types of electronic voting systems, and not all of them are created equal. "The government needs to ensure that any system it introduces is robust and secure." Mr Hughes said the government should also consider the accessibility benefits of e-voting. "For many people, electronic voting could make it easier to cast their ballot," he said. "This could be particularly important for people with disabilities, people who work long hours, or people who live in remote areas." The government has said it will not introduce e-voting unless it is confident that it is secure and accessible. It is currently consulting on plans for e-voting in some elections in England.

title: Ballymena: Green Pastures 'urban village' is approved by councillors
text: Ballymena: Green Pastures 'urban village' is approved by councillors By Louise Cullen BBC NI News Green Pastures church plans to build an urban village on the edge of Ballymena, with housing, business parks, a hotel and community facilities. Planners recommended the multi-million pound proposal should be rejected, but elected members on Mid and East Antrim Borough Council's planning committee voted five to three in favour. The development will include 430 homes, a business park, hotel, medical centre and shops. The site at Cushendall Road is just outside the town and Green Pastures is also planning to build a church and community facilities there. The church initially proposed 700 homes on the 64-acre site, which had been opposed by some residents due to traffic concerns, but that was reduced to 430. DUP Alderman William McCaughey said the development was "in the wrong location". "We don't want to see green fields and open space sacrificed for profit. That is not what we should be doing and it's not what the constituents who put us here want to see, either," he said. However, Sinn Féin councillor Ryan McMullan proposed the application be approved. "This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for Ballymena and our borough," he said. The development has been welcomed by Ballymena's business community. "This is a very significant development for the town and one which will deliver hundreds of jobs," said Ballymena Chamber of Commerce and Industry president John Hood. "It will create 430 new homes which will help address the current housing shortage in the area." Mrs Cullen added that the Green Pastures church's application was one of several major housing developments currently at the planning stage in Ballymena. In total, almost 2,000 new homes are expected to be built in the town in the coming years.

title: Ariana Grande says she feels 'broken' after Manchester concert attack
text: The US star was not physically hurt, but posted a tweet saying: "Broken. from the bottom of my heart, i am so so sorry. i don't have words." The blast happened just after the 23-year-old singer had finished performing. It is the deadliest terrorist attack in Britain since the 7 July 2005 London bombings. Speaking a few hours after the explosion, Greater Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham said: "Tonight we have seen the worst of humanity. But I've also seen the best of humanity." He said people had risked their own lives to help others, describing an off-duty nurse who had saved a child's life. Prime Minister Theresa May chaired a meeting of the government's emergency committee Cobra on Tuesday morning and praised the "extraordinary bravery" of the emergency services. "This was an act of appalling barbarism," she said "The people who did this want to divide us, but we will never let them succeed." The Queen said she was "deeply saddened" by the attack. "The whole nation has been shocked by the death and injury in Manchester last night," she said. "This was a particularly cruel attack, which targeted young people who should have been enjoying one of the most memorable nights of their lives." The attack is being investigated by the North West Counter Terrorism Unit. Police have arrested a 22-year-old man in connection with the bombing. The force said he was arrested at 12:30 BST and remains in police custody. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack. However, many experts believe the attack bears the hallmarks of the Islamic State group. The group has claimed responsibility for previous attacks on civilians in Europe, including the November 2015 Paris attacks and the March 2016 Brussels bombings. The US State Department has issued a travel warning for the UK, urging US citizens to be aware of the "increased threat of terrorism". The warning said that "terrorists may be planning attacks targeting tourist sites, transportation hubs, and other public areas in the UK". US President Donald Trump has offered his condolences to the victims of the attack. "I extend my deepest condolences to those so terribly injured in this terrorist attack and to the many killed," he said. "The United States stands with the people of the United Kingdom. Together, we will defeat terrorism."

title: Why good economics can make for bad politics
text: Why Good Economics Can Make for Bad Politics India's beleaguered Congress-led ruling coalition in Delhi is discovering that, in its attempts to push through major economic reforms, it may have been inadvertently opening itself up to political backlash. On Tuesday evening, its unpredictable ally the Trinamool Congress pulled out of the ruling United Progressive Alliance coalition, destabilizing the government and raising questions about the future direction of India's economic policy. At the heart of the matter is a sharp divide between the government's technocratic approach to economic reform and the political realities of India's complex and fractious politics. For example, the government's recent relaxation of foreign investment rules in a bid to attract capital and boost growth has been met with staunch opposition from several of its coalition partners. These parties fear that such measures will lead to job losses and the erosion of indigenous industries. This clash between good economics and bad politics is not unique to India. In fact, it is a recurring theme in many developing countries, where governments often face the difficult choice of implementing unpopular but necessary economic policies or appeasing their political base. In the case of India, the government's focus on austerity and fiscal consolidation has drawn criticism from the Left, which argues that it is hurting the poor and marginalized. Similarly, the government's efforts to reform the labor market, which include making it easier for businesses to hire and fire workers, have sparked protests from unions and opposition parties. This tension between economic reform and political expediency is often referred to as the "political economy" problem. It is a complex and multifaceted issue that has stymied policymakers around the world. In India, the political economy problem is compounded by a lack of consensus on what constitutes "good economics." Different political parties and interest groups have competing visions for the country's economic development, making it difficult to forge a cohesive policy agenda. Moreover, the government's credibility has been eroded by a series of corruption scandals, making it even harder to convince the public of the need for austerity and reform. As the Indian government continues to grapple with the political economy problem, it will need to find a way to balance the demands of good economics with the realities of bad politics. This is no easy task, but it is essential for the country's long-term economic well-being.

title: Germany migrant shelter fire 'cheered by onlookers'
text: The fire in the town of Bautzen in the early hours of Sunday morning destroyed the roof of a former hotel that was being used to house 101 refugees, mostly Syrians and Iraqis. No one was injured in the blaze but police are treating it as arson.  Saxony, where Bautzen is located, has been at the forefront of resistance to Angela Merkel's open-door refugee policy. The state has borne the brunt of the new arrivals, taking in 45,000 refugees last year - about 10% of the national total. Recent weeks have seen a series of attacks on refugee shelters in the eastern state. Local officials said three suspects were seen fleeing the scene and that witnesses had reported hearing people celebrating as the shelter burned. "It is a miracle that no one was killed," said Saxony's interior minister Markus Ulbig. "This was an act of inhumanity." The fire comes just days after another refugee shelter was attacked in the town of Clausnitz, also in Saxony. In that case, a group of far-right protesters prevented asylum seekers from entering the shelter, chanting xenophobic slogans. The attacks have prompted widespread condemnation from politicians and community leaders. "This is a dark day for Germany," said Chancellor Angela Merkel. "These attacks are an attack on our values ​​and our humanity." The head of Germany's Central Council of Jews, Josef Schuster, said the attacks were reminiscent of the Nazi era. "We must never forget that anti-Semitism and xenophobia go hand in hand," he said. The attacks have also raised concerns about the growing influence of far-right groups in Germany. The Alternative for Germany (AfD) party, which has campaigned against immigration and Islam, has made significant gains in recent elections. Some critics have accused the AfD of stoking anti-immigrant sentiment and creating a climate of fear and intimidation. The AfD has denied these accusations, blaming the attacks on a small number of extremists. However, the party's rhetoric has been welcomed by some far-right groups, who see it as giving legitimacy to their views. The attacks on refugee shelters have sent shockwaves through Germany and raised serious questions about the country's ability to integrate newcomers. The government has vowed to crack down on those responsible for the attacks and to protect refugees from further harm. However, it remains to be seen whether these measures will be enough to stem the tide of xenophobia and violence.

title: Wild animals circus ban passes first Holyrood vote
text: MSPs unanimously signed off the general principles of the ban, which would be the first of its kind in the UK. Environment Secretary Roseanna Cunningham said using animals in this manner was "morally objectionable". MSPs raised a series of concerns over the impact of the ban, including the livelihoods of circus performers and animal welfare during transportation. Opposition parties broadly supported the legislation, but raised questions about the timing of the ban and whether it provided enough support for the industry to adapt. Scottish Labour said it was "disappointed" the government had not provided more detail on a financial support package for circuses. The party's environment spokesperson, Claudia Beamish, said: "Scottish Labour supports the principle of banning the use of wild animals in circuses, but we have concerns about the timing of the bill. "We want to make sure that the right support is in place to assist circuses in transitioning to animal-free shows." The Scottish Conservatives also raised questions about the potential impact on jobs. Rural affairs spokesman Finlay Carson said: "The ban will put 50 jobs at risk and it is going to make it very difficult for small circuses which use wild animals to operate." He called on the government to provide a "proper financial support package" for affected businesses. The Scottish Greens welcomed the legislation, saying it was a "landmark moment" for animal welfare. Environment spokesperson Mark Ruskell said: "This ban is a victory for animal welfare and a reflection of changing public attitudes. "We have campaigned for this ban for many years and we are delighted that the Scottish Parliament has taken this historic step." The Scottish Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (SSPCA) also welcomed the vote, saying it was a "great day for animals". Chief executive Kirsteen Campbell said: "This is a landmark decision that will spare countless animals from a life of suffering. "We have long campaigned for a ban on the use of wild animals in circuses and we are delighted that the Scottish Parliament has listened to our concerns." The legislation will now be subject to further scrutiny by MSPs before it can be passed into law.

title: Essex County Council HQ swastikas should be removed says UKIP group
text: Earlier this week, it was reported the markings on County Hall had been deemed "potentially upsetting". The carvings on Chelmsford's County Hall, built between 1928 and 1939, were made by a local stonemason and are believed to be based on ancient Hindu symbols of good luck. However, the swastika was later adopted by the Nazi party in Germany and has since become associated with fascism and racism. As a result, some people have called for the carvings to be removed from the building. In a statement, UKIP group leader John Vasey said: "These carvings are a reminder of a dark period in our history and have no place on a public building. They should be removed as soon as possible." Vasey said the carvings were "offensive" and "upsetting" to many people. "They need to go," he said. An Essex County Council spokesperson said: "We are aware of the concerns that have been raised about the carvings on County Hall. We are currently reviewing the situation and will be taking into account all of the views that have been expressed. "We understand that the swastika is a symbol that can cause offence and we want to be sensitive to the concerns of all our residents." The spokesperson said the council would be making a decision on the future of the carvings "in due course". The swastika is an ancient symbol that has been used by many cultures around the world. However, its association with the Nazi party in Germany has led to it being widely regarded as a symbol of hate and intolerance. In recent years, there have been a number of calls for the removal of swastikas from public buildings and other places. In 2018, the London Borough of Camden voted to remove a swastika from the facade of a building in Hampstead. The decision to remove the swastikas from County Hall will ultimately be up to Essex County Council. The council will need to weigh the concerns of those who find the carvings offensive against the historical and architectural significance of the building.

title: Amber Peat: Hanged girl, 13, 'felt her dog was treated better'
text: Amber Peat's teacher David Wallace said he drove her home because her mother and step-father were dealing with their pet after it went into labour. Amber's body was found hanging in her bedroom in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, on 29 May 2015. An inquest into her death heard that Amber had told school staff she felt her dog was treated better than her. She had also self-harmed and written a note saying she wanted to die. Mr Wallace said he had concerns about Amber's welfare and had spoken to her about her home life. He said she had told him that she felt like a "burden" on her family. "She said she felt like her dog was treated better than her," Mr Wallace said. "She said she felt like she was in the way." Amber's mother, Kelly Peat, said she had been unaware of her daughter's feelings. She said Amber had been a "happy-go-lucky" child who had never expressed any suicidal thoughts. "I didn't know she felt like that," Ms Peat said. "She never said anything to me." Amber's stepfather, Danny Peat, said he had also been unaware of her feelings. He said Amber had been a "lovely" girl who had never caused any problems. "She was always smiling and happy," Mr Peat said. "I can't believe she's gone." The inquest heard that Amber had been self-harming for several months before her death. She had also written a note saying she wanted to die. The note was found in her bedroom after her death. It said: "I want to die. I can't take it anymore. I'm a burden on my family. I'm sorry." The inquest heard that Amber had been struggling with her mental health in the months leading up to her death. She had been seeing a therapist and had been prescribed medication for depression. The inquest is expected to last for two weeks.

title: Leeds war hero's statue could be moved to heritage centre
text: Flt Sgt Arthur Aaron, from Leeds, was killed on a bombing mission in Italy. The RAF pilot was posthumously awarded the Victoria Cross, Britain's highest military honour, for his bravery in continuing to fly his stricken plane so his crew could bail out. His statue currently stands in Leeds city centre, but a campaign has been launched to move it to the Royal Armouries Museum's new £25m visitor centre. The museum is dedicated to telling the story of the British Army and is already home to a number of war memorials and artefacts. Supporters of the move say the statue would be more fittingly displayed in a place that tells the story of the armed forces and would be seen by more people. However, others have argued that the statue should remain in the city centre as a reminder of Leeds's proud military history. The decision on whether to move the statue will be made by Leeds City Council. A council spokesman said: "We are aware of the campaign to move the statue of Flt Sgt Arthur Aaron to the Royal Armouries Museum. "We will be considering all options and consulting with stakeholders before making a decision." In a statement, the Royal Armouries Museum said: "We are honoured to have been approached to house the statue of Flt Sgt Arthur Aaron. "We believe that the museum would be a fitting home for the statue and that it would be seen by more people here than in its current location. "We are committed to working with Leeds City Council and other stakeholders to ensure that the statue is displayed in a way that is respectful and appropriate." Flt Sgt Aaron was born in Leeds in 1914. He joined the RAF in 1940 and flew with 105 Squadron. On 12 August 1942, he was piloting a Lancaster bomber on a bombing mission to Turin in Italy. His plane was hit by enemy fire and badly damaged. Despite being wounded himself, Flt Sgt Aaron continued to fly the plane so his crew could bail out. He was eventually forced to abandon the plane himself but was killed when his parachute failed to open. Flt Sgt Aaron was posthumously awarded the Victoria Cross for his bravery. The citation for his award reads: "For most conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty in the face of the enemy. "Flight Sergeant Aaron pressed home his attack with the utmost determination, in spite of heavy opposition, until his aircraft was set on fire. "Although wounded himself, he continued to fly the aircraft so that his crew could escape."
