title: Sheffield family 'betrayed' over gambling death case
text: Chris Bruney, 25, died after being given VIP status by a gambling firm that did not check he could afford it. The Gambling Commission (GC) said PT Entertainment had breached social responsibility rules. Chris's father, Mark, said the family felt "betrayed" by the industry and the authorities. "We feel so let down by the Gambling Commission," he said. "They knew about the problems with VIP schemes but they did nothing. They've allowed these companies to continue operating and people are dying because of it. "Chris was a vulnerable young man who should never have been given VIP status. He had a history of mental health problems and he was struggling with addiction. "PT Entertainment should have known that he was not in a position to gamble. But they didn't care. They just wanted his money. "We want the Gambling Commission to be held to account for what they've done. They need to do more to protect people from the dangers of gambling. "We also want PT Entertainment to be held responsible for their actions. They have a lot to answer for." The GC said it was "deeply concerned" about Chris's death and that it was "investigating the circumstances surrounding it". A spokesperson for PT Entertainment said the company was "committed to responsible gambling" and that it was "co-operating fully with the GC's investigation". Chris's death has highlighted the dangers of VIP gambling schemes, which have been linked to a number of other problem gambling cases. VIP schemes are designed to attract high-spending customers by offering them a range of perks, such as free bets, bonuses and access to exclusive events. However, there is concern that these schemes can encourage people to gamble more than they can afford, and that they can lead to addiction. The GC has introduced a number of measures to try to reduce the risks associated with VIP gambling schemes, including a new affordability check requirement. title: US 'preparing indictment against Julian Assange' of WikiLeaks
text: The reports came as a filing in a separate court case hinted that charges were being prepared. Justice officials said the filing was made in error. Mr. Assange fled to Ecuador's London embassy in 2012 to avoid being extradited to Sweden, where he was wanted for questioning over sexual assault allegations. He has always denied the allegations. In 2017, Sweden dropped its investigation into the sexual assault allegations, but Mr. Assange remained in the embassy, fearing that if he left, he would be extradited to the United States to face charges related to WikiLeaks' publication of classified US documents. In April 2019, Mr. Assange was arrested by UK police after Ecuador withdrew its asylum protection. He was sentenced to 50 weeks in prison for breaching his bail conditions. In May 2019, the US Justice Department announced that it had charged Mr. Assange with conspiracy to hack into a US government computer system. The indictment alleges that Mr. Assange conspired with former US Army intelligence analyst Chelsea Manning to obtain and publish classified US documents. Mr. Assange's lawyers have argued that the charges against him are politically motivated and that he is being persecuted for his work as a journalist. They have also said that the indictment is an attempt by the US government to set a precedent for prosecuting other journalists who publish classified information. The government has also said that it is committed to protecting freedom of the press. The case against Mr. Assange is expected to go to trial in 2023. title: Coronavirus: Plaid Cymru call for all Commons debates to be digital
text: With the UK under lockdown and MPs returning from recess on Tuesday, members of parliament will take part in hybrid meetings with up to 120 attending online and some in person. Plaid Cymru, the Welsh nationalist party, has called for all Commons debates to be conducted digitally to reduce the risk of spreading coronavirus and to ensure MPs are able to participate. Liz Saville Roberts, the leader of Plaid Cymru, said: "The Westminster bubble needs to wake up to the reality of Covid-19. The UK government has said that it is committed to ensuring that parliament can continue to function during the coronavirus pandemic, but has not yet made a decision on whether to switch to fully digital debates. A spokesperson for the Leader of the House of Commons said: "We are working hard to ensure that Parliament can continue to meet safely and effectively during this challenging time. "We are monitoring the situation closely and will keep our plans under review in line with the latest public health advice." Some MPs have expressed concerns about the practicalities of holding fully digital debates, such as ensuring that all members have access to the necessary technology and that there are no technical glitches. However, others have argued that the benefits of reducing the risk of spreading coronavirus outweigh these concerns. SNP MP Pete Wishart said: "The government needs to act now and switch to fully digital debates. "There is no excuse for not doing so and it is the only way to ensure that parliament can continue to function safely and effectively during this pandemic." The House of Commons Commission, which is responsible for the administration of the House of Commons, is expected to meet this week to discuss the issue.

title: Guides oath change consultation gets 30,000 responses
text: Guides oath change consultation gets 30,000 responses By Judith Burns BBC News education reporter Guides currently pledge: "I will do my best, to love my God, to serve my Queen and my country, to help other people, and to keep the Guide Law." But in a consultation on whether to change it, more than half of the 30,000 respondents thought the wording should be altered to reflect the diversity of members and modern society. The changes would affect more than 300,000 Guides, aged four to 14, across the UK. The organization has published a report on the consultation, which it says shows a "clear desire" for change. The three main suggestions are: Removing references to God, Queen, and country Replacing the phrase "to help other people" with "to serve my community" Adding a promise to "be inclusive" The Girlguiding chief executive, Angela Salt, said: "Our current promise was written in 1930 and has stood the test of time, but language evolves and society changes, and we want to ensure that our promise remains relevant and meaningful to our members today." She added that the changes would "make it clearer that Guiding is for everyone, regardless of their beliefs, background or circumstances." The consultation, which ran from October to December 2022, was the biggest ever undertaken by Girlguiding. Some of those who responded felt that the current wording was too narrow and prescriptive. "I am a British citizen with a Hindu faith," said one. "The promise as it is now is alienating and exclusive for me and my daughter." Others said that the changes would dilute the organization's unique identity. "We are a Christian organization and our promise should reflect that," wrote one Guide. The Girlguiding council will now consider the consultation responses and make a decision on whether to change the oath. If changes are approved, they are likely to be implemented in 2024.

title: UK retail sales stall in April
text: The Office for National Statistics said sales in April were flat on March, and higher than the 0.3% fall expected. In the three months to April, sales increased by 1.8%, with a record quarter for the online sector. The figures suggest that consumers are still spending despite the cost of living crisis, but experts warn that the outlook is uncertain. "The retail sector has been remarkably resilient in the face of significant headwinds, including the cost-of-living squeeze and the war in Ukraine," said Helen Dickinson, chief executive of the British Retail Consortium (BRC). "However, we are not immune to the wider economic pressures, and the outlook for the rest of the year is uncertain." The BRC said that consumer confidence remains low, and that retailers are facing rising costs for energy, wages, and transportation. "The next few months will be critical for the retail sector," said Dickinson. "Retailers will need to continue to innovate and adapt to the changing consumer landscape, while also finding ways to mitigate the impact of rising costs." The ONS figures showed that food sales fell by 1.4% in April, the first decline since September 2021. Non-food sales increased by 0.6%, with strong growth in clothing and footwear. Online sales continued to grow strongly, rising by 8.2% in April. This is the highest quarterly growth rate since the start of the pandemic. The ONS said that the increase in online sales was driven by strong demand for clothing, footwear, and household goods. "The online sector continues to benefit from the shift to online shopping that occurred during the pandemic," said ONS statistician Rhian Murphy. "However, it is too early to say whether this growth will continue in the long term."

title: Paul Cleeland: ‘Non-disclosure’ claim over 1972 murder
text: Paul Cleeland: ‘Non-disclosure’ claim over 1972 murder By Tanya Gupta BBC News Paul Cleeland has made a fresh request to the Criminal Cases Review Commission (CCRC) to revisit his case. He served 26 years for the murder of Terry Clark, who was found dead in a derelict building in Rotherham in 1972. Mr Cleeland, now 70, has always maintained his innocence. He was released on licence in 1999, and his conviction was quashed by the Court of Appeal in 2006 after it found vital evidence had not been disclosed to his defence team at the time of his trial. In 2012, an independent review of Mr Cleeland's case found there had been "a serious miscarriage of justice" and described the police investigation as "woefully inadequate". It also found that officers had put "improper pressure" on witnesses. However, the CCRC refused to refer Mr Cleeland's case back to the Court of Appeal, saying it was not satisfied that the conviction was unsafe. Mr Cleeland has now submitted a fresh application to the CCRC, arguing that new evidence has come to light which shows that the police failed to disclose a number of key documents to his defence team. The documents include: A statement from a witness who saw Mr Cleeland leaving the scene of the murder with another man. A report from a forensic scientist which concluded that the blood found on Mr Cleeland's clothing did not match the victim's blood. A transcript of a telephone conversation between a police officer and a witness which suggests that the police were aware of Mr Cleeland's innocence. Mr Cleeland's solicitor, Mark Newby, said: "These documents are highly significant and they should have been disclosed to the defence at the time of the trial. They would have had a material impact on the outcome of the case." The CCRC has confirmed that it has received Mr Cleeland's application and is considering whether to refer his case back to the Court of Appeal. Mr Cleeland said: "I have always maintained my innocence and I am determined to clear my name. I hope that the CCRC will finally agree to refer my case back to the Court of Appeal so that I can have a fair trial." South Yorkshire Police said: "We are aware of the application made to the CCRC. We will be co-operating fully with their investigation."

title: Nóra Quoirin: 'Compelling evidence' of abduction

Her body was found 10 days later about 1.6 miles (2.5km) from the resort in a rainforest. The post-mortem examination found that Nóra died as a result of starvation and stress. In announcing the results of the second inquest, Coroner Maimoonah Aid said there was "compelling evidence" that Nóra had been abducted. The coroner said that Nóra's disappearance had been "a mystery from the start" and that she had considered "all possible scenarios". She said: "I have considered all the possible scenarios, including the possibility that Nóra wandered off and got lost, but I do not find this to be a likely explanation. "I have also considered the possibility that Nóra was killed by a wild animal, but I do not find this to be a likely explanation either." The coroner said that the key piece of evidence in the case was the fact that Nóra's body was found in a stream. She said: "The fact that Nóra's body was found in a stream is significant because there is no evidence to suggest that Nóra was able to swim. "I find it more likely than not that Nóra was placed in the stream after she died." The coroner said that she had also considered the possibility that Nóra had been killed by a human being. She said: "I cannot rule out the possibility that Nóra was killed by a human being, but I do not find this to be the most likely explanation." The coroner said that she had come to her conclusion after considering all the evidence in the case. title: Waspi campaign: The fight against changes to women's state pension age
text: By Reality Check team BBC News That effort goes back decades, so to help understand the issue here is some background. How did we get here? From 1948 for more than 60 years men received their state pension at 65 and women at 60. However, concerned about the impact of an ageing population and the rising cost of state pensions, in 1995 the government announced plans to equalise the state pension age for men and women at 65. This was always going to be a controversial move and a campaign was quickly launched to oppose it, led by the Women Against State Pension Inequality (Waspi) movement. The campaign argued that the changes were unfair to women who had been paying National Insurance contributions based on the assumption they would get their pension at 60. They also pointed out that many women, particularly those who worked in lower paid jobs, had been unable to build up enough private pension provision to compensate for the loss of their state pension for five years. The government did make some concessions in response to the campaign, such as bringing forward to 2026 the date when the state pension age for women would reach 65 and introducing a transitional period during which women born in the 1950s would receive some additional state pension payments. However, Waspi argued that these concessions did not go far enough and continued to campaign for the changes to be scrapped altogether. What's the current status? In 2019, the Parliamentary and Health Service Ombudsman published a report which found that the government had failed to communicate the changes to the state pension age adequately, particularly to women born in the 1950s. The Ombudsman recommended that the government should make a one-off payment of £12,000 to women affected by this communication failure. The government has accepted this recommendation and is in the process of making these payments. However, Waspi is still campaigning for further compensation, arguing that the government should fully compensate women who lost out financially as a result of the changes to the state pension age. The government has so far resisted these calls, but the issue is likely to remain a source of political debate for some time to come.

title: Fifth of UK women decline cervical smear tests
text: Early detection through screening, followed by treatment, can prevent up to 75% of these cancers developing. Yet despite high-profile cases such as that of Jade Goody, who died of the disease aged 27 in 2009, the uptake of cervical screening continues to fall. In England, only 68.6% of women aged 25 to 64 attended a screening appointment in the year to March 2022, down from 83.4% in 2000. The decline has been attributed to a number of factors, including embarrassment, fear of pain, and a lack of awareness about the importance of screening. Dr Vanessa Saliba, consultant epidemiologist at the UK Health Security Agency, said: "It is worrying to see that so many women are not taking up this potentially life-saving screening." She added: "Cervical screening is not painful and only takes a few minutes. The benefits of screening far outweigh any discomfort that women may experience." There are a number of things that can be done to improve the uptake of cervical screening. These include: Raising awareness of the importance of screening through public health campaigns and school education programs. Making it easier for women to access screening appointments, by offering them at convenient times and locations. Providing information about the screening process in a clear and accessible way. Training healthcare professionals to be sensitive and supportive when discussing cervical screening with women. By taking these steps, we can help to ensure that more women benefit from the life-saving benefits of cervical screening. In addition to the reasons cited by Dr Saliba, other factors that may be contributing to the decline in cervical screening uptake include: A belief that cervical screening is no longer necessary because of the availability of the HPV vaccine. A fear of being judged or stigmatized for having a sexually transmitted infection (STI). A lack of trust in healthcare professionals. It is important to note that the HPV vaccine does not eliminate the need for cervical screening. While the vaccine protects against the most common strains of HPV, it does not protect against all strains. It is therefore still important for women to have regular cervical screenings to check for any abnormal cells that could develop into cancer. It is also important to remember that cervical screening is a private and confidential procedure. Healthcare professionals are bound by law to protect the privacy of their patients. If you are concerned about being judged or stigmatized, you can speak to your doctor or nurse in confidence. If you have any concerns about cervical screening, please speak to your doctor or nurse. They will be able to provide you with more information about the screening process and answer any questions you may have.

title: Norfolk and Waveney mental health: Dissatisfaction with care
text: The survey, by the Norfolk and Waveney Sustainability and Transformation Partnership (STP), said 40% did not know how to access services at their GP practice. title: Welsh theatre company launches translation app
text: By Ian Youngs Arts reporter, BBC News Theatr Genedlaethol Cymru, the Welsh-language national theatre, has developed the smartphone app called Sibrwd, which means Whisper. It will allow audience members to hear key lines and explanations of scenes in English. The theatre hopes it will help non-Welsh speakers, tourists, and deaf and hard of hearing people to enjoy its productions. Sibrwd is the latest example of how apps and technology are being used to make theatre more inclusive. In 2016, the Royal Shakespeare Company launched an app called RSC Play On, which provides closed captions, audio descriptions, and sign language interpretation for its productions. And in 2017, the National Theatre launched an app called NT Live, which allows audiences to watch live and recorded performances on their phones and tablets. Sibrwd is different from these other apps in that it is designed specifically for Welsh-language theatre. "We wanted to create something that would help people who might not be fluent in Welsh to enjoy our productions," said Elen Bowman, the theatre's artistic director. "We hope it will make our work more accessible to a wider audience." The app is free to download from the App Store and Google Play. It is available for all of the theatre's main stage productions, as well as for some of its touring shows. Users can select the language they want to hear the translation in, and they can adjust the volume and speed of the narration. The app also includes a glossary of Welsh words and phrases, and a guide to Welsh pronunciation. "We hope Sibrwd will help to break down some of the barriers that can prevent people from enjoying Welsh-language theatre," said Bowman. "We want to make our work as accessible as possible to everyone." Theatr Genedlaethol Cymru is not the first Welsh theatre company to use technology to make its work more inclusive. In 2015, the Sherman Theatre in Cardiff launched an app called Theatr Clwyd, which provides audio descriptions and closed captions for its productions. And in 2016, the National Theatre Wales launched an app called Theatr na n'Og, which provides Welsh-language and English-language content for children. The use of technology to make theatre more inclusive is a welcome development. It is helping to make theatre more accessible to a wider range of people, and it is making it possible for people to enjoy theatre in new and different ways.

title: Home ownership 'overestimated by official data'
text: The official estimate of a 64% home ownership rate was too high, the Resolution Foundation said, as many people shared or owners had taken on extended family members during the pandemic. The think tank said this "disguised" a fall in owner-occupation, to a true rate of 62%. It said the government should focus on supporting home ownership among lower-income households, renters, and first-time buyers. The Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities said the government is "committed to increasing home ownership". The official figures count anyone who owns a home, even if they share it with others, as a home owner. Before the pandemic, around one in seven of all households in England contained multiple adult generations, or two or more unrelated adults. During the pandemic, however, that figure rose to one in four as many people moved in with family or friends because of the high cost of housing and the need for childcare. This inflated the official count of home owners by about 300,000, the Resolution Foundation estimated. The think tank said its "true" home ownership rate of 62% is in line with other recent estimates. Polly Neate, chief executive of Shelter, said: "These figures expose the government's failure to get to grips with the housing emergency. "Home ownership shouldn't be a pipe dream for most. But the harsh reality is that our broken housing system is pricing millions of people out of a decent home. "Millions of people are trapped in the renting trap, unable to save for a home of their own. The government must deliver a new deal for renters and build more social homes." A government spokesperson said: "We are committed to increasing home ownership and ensuring everyone has a safe and secure place to live. "We have supported over 800,000 first-time buyers onto the property ladder since 2010, and have invested over £12 billion to support affordable housing. "We recognise that more needs to be done, and our Levelling Up White Paper sets out our plans to deliver more affordable homes."

title: Facebook buys virtual reality headset start-up for $2bn
text: The start-up's flagship product, the Oculus Rift, is a goggle-like "immersive" headset for video gaming. The latest deal is further evidence of Facebook's commitment to virtual reality, a technology that many see as the future of entertainment and communication. title: Lorry drivers who drink coffee 'cut their crash risk'
text: By Michelle Roberts Health editor, BBC News online Australian investigators say they found the link while comparing 530 heavy goods vehicle drivers who had recently been in a crash with 517 who had not. Coffee and other beverages containing the stimulant caffeine helped counter the effects of fatigue, say the researchers writing in the journal Sleep. The researchers from the University of Sydney and the University of Adelaide also found that the more caffeine the drivers consumed, the lower was their risk of crashing. Those drivers who had the highest levels of the caffeine breakdown product paraxanthine in their urine had a 63% reduced risk of being in a crash compared with the drivers with the lowest levels. "The reduction in crash risk was likely due to caffeine's effects on alertness," said Dr Harriet Hiscock, lead author of the study from the University of Sydney. She added that the effects of a single cup of coffee or other caffeinated drink could last for several hours, "which is the length of a typical work shift for a heavy vehicle driver." Previous research has shown that the hours between midnight and 6am are when the most fatigue-related truck crashes occur, she added. Fatigue is more common among long-distance drivers who may be working long hours and driving through the night. Dr Hiscock recommended that heavy vehicle drivers with long work hours should consider increasing their intake of caffeine, such as by drinking two to three cups of coffee before starting work and having more as the work shift progresses. "The risk of consuming too much caffeine and experiencing side-effects like insomnia is very low in healthy adults," she said. "The benefits of consuming caffeine to reduce fatigue and crash risk appear to outweigh any risks associated with moderate caffeine intake." The researchers say that studies have shown that caffeine can help with alertness, attention, memory and reaction time. It can also reduce feelings of fatigue and sleepiness. Dr Hiscock said that in addition to consuming caffeine, drivers should take breaks when they feel fatigued, avoid working long hours and avoid driving while on medication that causes drowsiness. She said that there was also a need for more research to examine the relationship between caffeine and other factors that can affect crash risk, such as age, experience, and road and traffic conditions. "In the meantime," she said, "caffeine appears to be a useful strategy for reducing the risk of fatigue-related crashes in heavy vehicle drivers."

title: Richard Wadani: Austrian Nazi deserter dies aged 97
text: Richard Wadani was drafted into the German army but escaped on his second attempt in 1944, going on to serve in a British-led unit. After the end of the conflict, he helped prosecute his former comrades and settled in the UK. Born in April 1925, he was the youngest of four children. His family was Jewish, but not religious, and lived in a predominantly Christian area of Vienna. After the Nazis annexed Austria in 1938, his father was arrested and sent to the Dachau concentration camp. He was released after six weeks, but the family was forced to give up their business and home. Richard was conscripted into the German army in 1943 and sent to the Eastern Front. He was captured by the Soviets in 1944, but escaped during a train journey to a prisoner-of-war camp. He made his way to Vienna, where he hid for several months before joining a group of Jewish partisans. In 1945, Richard joined the British-led Jewish Brigade, which fought alongside the Allies in Italy. After the war, he helped prosecute Nazi war criminals at the Nuremberg trials. In 1947, he settled in the UK, where he worked as a builder and later as a social worker. Richard rarely spoke about his experiences during the war, but he was a strong advocate for Holocaust education and reconciliation. He visited schools and gave talks about the dangers of prejudice and discrimination. In 2015, he was awarded the Austrian Cross of Honour for Science and Art, First Class, for his work in promoting understanding and tolerance. He died on 15 March 2023, aged 97. Richard Wadani's story is a reminder of the horrors of war and the importance of fighting against prejudice and discrimination. He was a brave and compassionate man who dedicated his life to making the world a better place.

title: Marsden Moor fire: Crews at scene of mile-long blaze
text: The fire on Marsden Moor near Black Moss Reservoir and Swellands Reservoir started at 19:00 BST on Sunday, owner National Trust said. It has caused major damage and could have been avoided, the conservation charity believes. West Yorkshire Fire and Rescue Service currently has 12 fire engines at the scene and has asked members of the public to avoid the area. The fire service said there are "no immediate concerns for public safety" but the blaze is "causing significant damage to the moorland". The fire is believed to have started between Wessenden Head and the A640, and is the second large moorland fire in West Yorkshire in less than a month. The National Trust said it believed the fire was started deliberately and had been "totally avoidable". "We're shocked and saddened by the damage this fire has caused to the beautiful landscape of Marsden Moor," said the National Trust's general manager for the area, Rob Stoneman. "We know the vast majority of people would never dream of doing anything to harm such a special place, but a minority seem hell-bent on destroying it. "This fire could have easily been avoided and is causing enormous damage to wildlife, the landscape and to people's enjoyment of this area. "We're working closely with the fire service and the police to identify the people responsible and bring them to justice." The fire comes just three weeks after a huge blaze on Saddleworth Moor, which took more than three weeks to bring under control, destroyed 2,000 acres of land and cost millions of pounds to extinguish. That fire is also believed to have been started deliberately and police have offered a reward of £50,000 for information leading to the conviction of those responsible. The National Trust said it was "deeply concerned" by the recent spate of moorland fires in West Yorkshire and urged the public to report any suspicious activity to the police or the fire service.

title: Police chief responds to Fred West 'murder victim' petition
text: Fifteen-year-old Mary Bastholm was last seen alive in Gloucester 44 years ago. Gloucestershire Police is being petitioned to carry out a fresh investigation into her reported murder by serial killer Fred West, after new evidence was uncovered by amateur detectives. Gloucester's Police Chief Supt Ian Chisolm, said: "The remains of Mary Bastholm have never been found and no-one has ever been charged with her murder. "The investigation into her murder remains open and we will continue to investigate any new information that is brought to our attention. "In 2015, following media interest in the case, we agreed to review the investigation to ensure that all possible lines of enquiry had been exhausted. "This review was overseen by an independent detective chief inspector. "As part of this review, Gloucestershire Police liaised with the relevant authorities in Portugal where Mary's parents were living at the time of her disappearance. "We also met with Mary's family in the UK to provide an update on the investigation. "The review concluded that all reasonable lines of enquiry had been exhausted and that there was no new evidence to suggest that Fred West was involved in Mary's disappearance or murder. Pete Moore, who runs the 'Mary Bastholm Murder Investigation' Facebook group, said: "In 2017, myself and three other volunteers started looking into the case. "Last year, we took our findings to Gloucestershire Police. "They said our investigation matched their own but we had taken it a stage further. "We believe there is enough evidence to prove that Fred West abducted Mary and murdered her at his Cromwell Street home." Mary's younger sister Janet added: "We want Gloucestershire Police to follow up on all the evidence that we've presented to them. "We want them to take a fresh look at it and see if they can find Mary's remains. "We need to know what happened to her. "It would be the best outcome if we could find out what happened." Mr Moore said that the retired officer added he was assisting the BBC in making a programme about the case. The petition states: "The family of Mary Bastholm and an independent group of investigators have presented new evidence that we believe may finally solve a 44-year-old murder mystery. "We ask Gloucestershire Police to take ownership of this compelling new information and investigate with the aim of finding Mary Bastholm's body and finally securing justice for her family and loved ones and ending the decades of torment they have suffered."

title: GCSE computing tasks withdrawn after answers appear online
text: By Judith Burns Education reporter, BBC News The exam board OCR has confirmed the units will be "replaced" to avoid the risk of students gaining an unfair advantage. It follows claims that answers to the GCSE exam papers were posted online before the exams had taken place. OCR said it was made aware of "potential issues" with the Computing units on 18 May - the same day the exams were sat. The board said an investigation was launched immediately and a decision to withdraw the units was made shortly afterwards. It is understood that the papers had been leaked online and that students had accessed them before the exams. The move to withdraw the units affects students in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. In a statement, OCR said: "We are aware of some potential issues with the GCSE (9-1) Computing units 1 and 2 that have been brought to our attention. "As a result, we have taken the decision to replace units 1 and 2 only. "This decision has been made to ensure there is no unfair advantage given to any students." The board said it was still investigating the leak and that it would be "taking all necessary actions" to prevent a similar incident happening again. It added that it would be providing further updates to students and schools as soon as possible. The move to withdraw the units has been met with anger from some students and parents. One student, who asked not to be named, said: "I'm really angry. I've been revising for this exam for months and now it's been cancelled because of someone else's mistake. "It's not fair." A parent of a student who was due to sit the exam said: "I'm furious. My child has worked so hard for this exam and now it's been taken away from them. "OCR needs to take responsibility for this and ensure that it doesn't happen again." The exam board has said it is committed to ensuring that all students are treated fairly and that they will be working closely with schools to provide support during this time.

title: Small businesses in Scottish council spend call
text: The FSB said public bodies should be required to publish regular assessments of how they spend their cash. It argued they should also have to identify areas for improvement. The FSB called for a "small business act" to give small firms more representation on public sector boards. The move would create a powerful voice for small businesses to challenge public sector spending decisions. It would also help to ensure that small businesses have a fair chance of winning public sector contracts. The FSB said that small businesses were often overlooked by public sector bodies. It said that this was because small businesses did not have the resources to lobby or tender for contracts. The FSB's call for action was welcomed by the Scottish government. A spokesperson said that the government was committed to supporting small businesses. The spokesperson said that the government would consider the FSB's proposals. The Scottish government has a target of increasing the number of public sector contracts awarded to small businesses to 25%. The target was set in 2014. The government has made some progress towards meeting the target. In 2016, 22% of public sector contracts were awarded to small businesses. However, the government is still some way short of meeting its target. The FSB's proposals would help the government to meet its target. The proposals would also help to ensure that small businesses have a fair chance of winning public sector contracts. The FSB's call for action is a positive step. It is important that small businesses have a voice in public sector spending decisions. The FSB's proposals would help to ensure that this happens. The Scottish government should support the FSB's proposals. The proposals would help the government to meet its target of increasing the number of public sector contracts awarded to small businesses to 25%. The proposals would also help to ensure that small businesses have a fair chance of winning public sector contracts.

title: George Alagiah's debut novel up for author's award
text: Alagiah's The Burning Land, is up for the Paul Torday memorial prize, awarded to a first novel by a writer over 60. The thriller's plot revolves around corruption and homicide. It follows the story of Charles Hilary, a headteacher who has rebuilt his life in Kenya 10 years after his wife's death in a car accident.  His existence is challenged when he is drawn into a police investigation of a murder and corruption in a local school. Speaking to the BBC, Alagiah said the book had been "percolating" for many years and was inspired by many visits to Kenya and his experiences there. "It was an attempt to think through some of the dilemmas and issues facing the country, particularly corruption," he said. "I wanted to write a story that is hopeful, ultimately, about people's resilience and determination to live their lives and bring up their families with dignity." The Paul Torday prize is named after the author of Salmon Fishing in the Yemen, who died of cancer in 2012. Chair of judges Elizabeth Buchan said the prize celebrated "the most exciting and original" debut novelists over 60. "It is a great pleasure to announce the longlist for this year's prize, which contains so many vivid, compelling and original voices," she said. Alagiah, who turned 65 on 22 November 2022, is best known to the public as a newsreader, having been a BBC journalist for over 30 years. He was diagnosed with bowel cancer in 2014, and subsequently wrote about his experience in a memoir, The Burning Land, published in 2022. Alagiah said that writing a novel had always been "a little bit of a dream" for him. "I've always found writing very enjoyable, but the news is so relentless and so time-consuming that it was very hard to make the time to do it," he said. "But my illness gave me the opportunity to step back. I've not given up broadcasting, but I'm only doing one day a week now, so I've carved out some time to write." Alagiah said he was "thrilled" that The Burning Land had been shortlisted for the Paul Torday prize. "It's a great honour," he said. "I'm looking forward to reading the other books on the longlist and seeing who wins."

title: Brexit: Trade deal now looking remote
text: Laura Kuenssberg Political editor@bbclaurakon Twitter But eventually, sometimes, failure is what follows. That now seems the likely outcome of months of talks designed to create a smooth path for the UK's post-Brexit relationship with the EU. The big sticking points remain: EU fishermen's access to UK waters, and the UK's plans to potentially undercut EU standards on issues such as workers' rights. Both sides are now saying that, without movement, a no-deal Brexit is the most likely scenario - although they insist they want to keep talking. So what would no-deal mean? Economically, it would lead to tariffs and quotas on goods traded between the UK and the EU - so that means higher costs for businesses and consumers. The food and drink sector, for example, says prices will go up - and some produce might not even be available. Manufacturers and retailers warn of disruption to supply chains. More than just a question of economics, a no-deal Brexit would also mean the UK would no longer take part in EU programmes - for example, the research and development programme Horizon or the Erasmus student exchange scheme. UK universities are worried about how they will continue to collaborate with European partners. And for UK businesses, it means losing the right to trade freely across the EU - they would face new checks and restrictions. For travel, it would mean the end of freedom of movement within the EU. British passport holders would need visas to stay in the EU for longer than 90 days. Tourists would have to check roaming charges. And it would mean British citizens who live in the EU could lose some of their rights. So what about those lorry queues? Under no-deal, there would be new checks and customs controls on goods entering or leaving the UK. If these are not ready by the end of the year, it is highly likely we will see major delays and congestion at ports. This will not just affect UK food and industry, but also businesses in the EU that rely on the UK. This is perhaps one of the most urgent issues that needs to be resolved. And the UK government says it will be ready. It says it has already massively increased capacity at ports, and it will be setting up inland customs sites. But there are many who remain highly sceptical as to whether this is enough. And the government admits that there will be some disruption. For its part, the EU has been planning too. Its negotiator, Michel Barnier, has been setting up lorry parks - essentially giant car parks where vehicles can be stored while awaiting customs checks. The UK wants to avoid this. But no-deal would not just be economically and logistically challenging. It would also be a huge diplomatic headache. The UK would have to negotiate new agreements with countries around the world. It will probably have to join the World Trade Organization and sign up to its rules. And it will have to work out how to maintain open borders with the Republic of Ireland if Northern Ireland is following EU rules. For many people, this would be a big departure from the UK's current position, as a member of a large trading bloc. The government says it will be able to continue to trade with the EU. But it is acknowledged that there will be costs to the UK economy, and that no-deal will make the UK a less attractive place to do business. The EU's message is that it will survive without the UK.

title: Suspected Tamil rebels shot dead in Sri Lanka
text: By Charles Haviland BBC News, Colombo It says they were taking instructions from two LTTE leaders based in Europe. The reported incident, if true, is the first such admission by the Sri Lankan authorities of extra-judicial killings carried out in the final phase of the civil war. Tamil politicians told the BBC that the men killed were suspected of links to the LTTE but not of involvement in violence. They said the men were shot after they tried to flee a house that had been surrounded by the military in the final months of the conflict. The LTTE was defeated in May 2009 after a 26-year campaign for an independent Tamil homeland. The Sri Lankan government has been accused of serious human rights abuses during the final months of the war, including the extra-judicial killing of suspected Tamil Tiger rebels. The government denies the allegations, but a UN panel appointed by then-Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon concluded that the Sri Lankan military had been responsible for "credible allegations" of extra-judicial killings and other serious violations of international humanitarian law. The group of men now reported to have been shot dead is said to have included a former town mayor, a local councillor and several businessmen. The Tamil National Alliance (TNA), the main Tamil political party, has called for an independent investigation into the killings. The government has not commented on the allegations. The reported incident has taken place against a backdrop of growing international pressure on Sri Lanka to investigate allegations of war crimes and other human rights abuses committed during the final months of the civil war. In March, the UN Human Rights Council passed a resolution calling on Sri Lanka to implement the recommendations of the UN panel and to establish a credible mechanism to investigate allegations of war crimes. The Sri Lankan government has said that it will not accept any external interference in its internal affairs. However, the international community is likely to continue to press for accountability for the alleged crimes committed during the war. The reported incident is a reminder of the dark chapter in Sri Lanka's history and of the need for the country to confront its past in order to build a truly reconciled and peaceful future.

title: Wirelessly charged electric buses set for Milton Keynes
text: By Neil Bowdler Science and technology reporter, BBC News A fleet of eight new electric vehicles will operate along a busy route in Milton Keynes from late January. The buses can run for longer than previous models because they are fitted with wireless charging technology, avoiding the need for regular overnight charging.  Rapid charging points are located at bus stops along the H5 route, which connects the new university quarter to the city centre via Milton Keynes Central railway station. The vehicles will charge for four minutes while passengers get on and off at the stops. The buses, which are made by Chinese company Yutong and are known as E12s, are replacing diesel vehicles on the route. Each bus can carry up to 90 passengers. Wireless charging is achieved through the use of a charging plate installed under the road at bus stops. As the bus parks over the plate, it begins to receive an electric current. The system is designed to be efficient and safe, with no risk of electric shocks or damage to the bus or the road surface. The wireless charging system has been developed by a consortium of companies including Milton Keynes Council, bus operator Arriva UK Bus, power company UK Power Networks and infrastructure firm Conduent. Milton Keynes Council leader Pete Marland said: “We are leading the UK in developing innovative solutions to improve air quality and reduce carbon emissions. These new electric buses will make a real difference to the lives of people in Milton Keynes, providing a cleaner, greener and more reliable public transport service.” Arriva UK Bus managing director Paul O'Neil said: “We are delighted to be working in partnership with Milton Keynes Council and other stakeholders to bring this exciting new technology to Milton Keynes. These new electric buses will provide a significant improvement to the customer experience, with faster journey times and reduced emissions.” The introduction of the electric buses is part of Milton Keynes Council’s plan to become carbon neutral by 2030. The council has already invested in a number of other green initiatives, including the installation of solar panels on council buildings and the planting of trees.

title: Lundy Island visitors return to mainland after ferry failure
text: The MS Oldenburg arrived to collect 65 holidaymakers on Saturday but had a mechanical fault and was towed back. The Landmark Trust, which leases the island, found extra accommodation for the stranded visitors. On Sunday, another vessel, the MV Balmoral, was dispatched to the island. The 65 holidaymakers disembarked the MV Balmoral at Ilfracombe, Devon, at around 17:00 BST. One of the stranded visitors, Dave Thornton, said it had been a "great adventure". "We were supposed to be leaving on Saturday morning, but the ferry broke down," he said. "We were supposed to be going home on Saturday, but we ended up staying on the island for two extra nights." "The Landmark Trust made us very welcome," he added. The MV Balmoral is expected to return to Lundy Island on Monday to collect the remaining visitors. The Landmark Trust said in a statement: "We are pleased that the holidaymakers have been able to return to the mainland. "The safety of our visitors is our top priority and we are grateful to the crew of the MV Balmoral for their assistance." Lundy Island is a small island in the Bristol Channel, about 12 miles (19 km) off the coast of Devon. It is owned by the National Trust and is leased to the Landmark Trust. The island is a popular tourist destination, with visitors attracted by its wildlife, geology, and history. The MS Oldenburg is a passenger ferry that operates between Lundy Island and Ilfracombe. The MV Balmoral is a larger passenger ferry that is used for day trips to Lundy Island.

title: Essex lorry deaths: Accused made earlier crossing attempt
text: Essex Lorry Deaths: Accused Made Earlier Crossing Attempt The Vietnamese nationals, aged between 15 and 44, suffocated as they were transported from Zeebrugge in Belgium to Purfleet on 23 October last year. Jurors heard how the victims had been sealed in the pitch black unit with no ventilation or light for at least 12 hours, and that they died from a combination of suffocation and hyperthermia. The six defendants on trial for manslaughter and conspiracy to traffic people include Ronan Hughes, 41, of Armagh, and Maurice Robinson, 26, of Craigavon, who are accused of being the ringleaders of the smuggling operation. The other defendants are Gheorghe Nica, 43, of Basildon; Alexandru-Ovidiu Hutanu, 33, of Grays; Christopher Kennedy, 24, of Co Armagh; and Valentin Calota, 37, of Birmingham. All deny the charges. The court heard that Hughes and Robinson had made an earlier attempt to smuggle people into the UK using the same mode of transport. On that occasion, they had successfully transported 10 Vietnamese nationals in a refrigerated container from France to Ireland. However, the victims in the Essex lorry deaths were not so fortunate. Prosecuting barrister Bill Emlyn Jones QC told the jury that the defendants had shown "callous disregard for human life" by cramming the victims into the lorry in "utterly dangerous and inhumane" conditions. He said that the defendants had known that the journey would be long and dangerous, and that they had deliberately created a situation in which the victims were likely to die. The defense has argued that the defendants were not responsible for the deaths of the victims, and that they had been duped by people higher up the smuggling chain. They have also claimed that the victims had voluntarily entered the lorry, and that they had not been aware of the dangers involved. The trial is expected to last for several weeks.

title: Golden and sea eagle decline since Dark Ages mapped
text: Researchers looked at places named after eagles in Gaelic and Old English to help estimate populations of the birds in AD500. From the Dark Ages, they drew on historical material, such as laws protecting the birds, which are among Europe's largest birds of prey. Golden eagles are found across much of the UK, while sea eagles are only found in Scotland. Numbers of both species fell sharply since the Middle Ages. The study suggests the biggest decline took place between AD800 and AD1100, though this varied regionally. In the Highlands of Scotland, for example, golden eagles made a recovery, with their numbers peaking around AD1200. This is in contrast to the rest of the UK, where numbers continued to fall after AD1100. This detailed study shows how golden and sea eagle populations have fluctuated over the centuries, providing important context for understanding current conservation efforts. Dr Justin Dodd of Royal Holloway, University of London, who led the research, said: "Our work gives us a better and more detailed understanding of the historical changes in the fortunes of these magnificent birds, and can help inform future conservation action." The research was motivated by the lack of long-term data on golden and sea eagle populations in Britain. To address this, the team of scientists used historical ecology to look at the spatial and temporal dynamics of the birds over many centuries. The team searched online gazetteers for place names that referenced eagles, such as "Aird an Iolair" (Eagle Height) in Scotland and "Lydd" (meaning "eagle") in England. They found 1,126 place names across Britain that contained the word "eagle" or a direct translation. Combining this data with historical sources, including legal documents and medieval chronicles, allowed the researchers to reconstruct the likely distribution of eagles in different parts of Britain at a series of different time periods since AD500. This provides the first detailed historical map of golden and sea eagle distribution and abundance in Britain. The researchers also discovered that the total area across Britain occupied by golden and sea eagles has declined by nearly two-thirds since AD500.

title: Homeless people struggle to access healthcare, report says
text: A third of people surveyed by housing charity Cymorth Cymru said health problems contributed to them losing their home. Seven recommendations have been made to health boards and the Welsh government to improve access to healthcare for homeless people. The report, published on Tuesday, found that homeless people often face barriers to accessing healthcare, including a lack of ID, difficulties registering with a GP, and stigma. One in five people surveyed said they had been refused healthcare because they did not have an ID. A quarter said they had been treated with disrespect by healthcare staff. The report makes seven recommendations to health boards and the Welsh government, including: Establishing a system to allow homeless people to register with a GP without an ID Providing training for healthcare staff on how to work with homeless people Setting up outreach services to provide healthcare to homeless people on the streets The report also calls for more research to be done on the health needs of homeless people. Cymorth Cymru's chief executive, Bethan Jones, said: "Homeless people often face multiple barriers to accessing healthcare, including a lack of ID, difficulties registering with a GP, and stigma. This report highlights the need for urgent action to improve access to healthcare for homeless people." A Welsh government spokesperson said: "We are committed to ensuring that everyone in Wales has access to the healthcare they need, regardless of their circumstances. We welcome the recommendations in this report and will work with health boards to implement them." The report comes as the number of homeless people in Wales continues to rise. According to the Welsh government, there were 3,243 homeless people in Wales in 2021, up from 2,963 in 2020. Homelessness is a complex issue with many causes, including poverty, mental health problems, and addiction. It can have a devastating impact on people's lives, leading to health problems, social isolation, and unemployment.

title: JVP 'planned to kill' MP
text: A senior leader of Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (JVP), Sunil Handunnetti, MP, is under house arrest by the party after he tried to flee the country, amid revelations that he and his brother had allegedly conspired to kill a fellow lawmaker. Handunnetti's attempted flight follows the arrest of his brother, Upul Shantha Handunnetti, by the Criminal Investigations Department (CID) on charges of planning to kill Wijeyadasa Rajapaksa, an opposition legislator. According to the CID, Upul Shantha Handunnetti had hired a group of hitmen to carry out the assassination, providing them with a firearm and a down payment of 1 million Sri Lankan rupees (around £4,300). The plot was allegedly hatched in response to an ongoing dispute between Rajapaksa and the JVP. Sources within the JVP have told the BBC that Sunil Handunnetti had been warned by senior party officials to cooperate with the investigation into his brother's alleged involvement in the assassination plot. However, he is believed to have ignored these warnings and attempted to flee the country. The JVP, a Marxist-Leninist party, has a long history of violence and political intimidation, dating back to the 1980s and 1990s when it launched an armed rebellion against the Sri Lankan government. Since the end of the civil war in 2009, the JVP has been active in mainstream politics, but it has continued to face accusations of authoritarianism and human rights abuses. The arrest of Sunil Handunnetti and the allegations against his brother have raised concerns about the potential for further political violence in Sri Lanka. The CID is continuing its investigation into the assassination plot, and it is expected that further arrests will be made. The JVP has condemned the allegations against its members and has vowed to cooperate with the investigation. However, critics have accused the party of harbouring individuals who are capable of carrying out violence and intimidation. The allegations against the JVP have also cast a shadow over the upcoming parliamentary elections, which are scheduled to be held in August. The JVP is expected to perform well in the elections, but the revelations about its alleged involvement in a murder plot could damage its chances of gaining significant support.

title: Covid: Labour MP apologises for calling pandemic 'good crisis'
text: Kate Green was reported to have made the comments earlier this month at an online event during the party's annual conference. She told Sky News she "really regretted" the remarks, admitting they were "hurtful and offensive". She added: "It's not what I believe. It's certainly not what the Labour Party believes. I want to apologise to anyone who was hurt or offended by what I said." Green's comments were widely condemned by politicians from across the political spectrum. Prime Minister Boris Johnson said they were "deeply offensive" and "completely unacceptable". Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer said he had spoken to Green and made it clear that her comments were "completely wrong". "The pandemic has been a terrible time for our country," he said. "She needs to do more than just apologise," said bereaved families group Covid-19 Bereaved Families for Justice. "She needs to resign from her position as an MP." The group said Green's comments showed that she was "out of touch" with the experiences of those who had lost loved ones to Covid-19. "Her words have caused immeasurable pain to thousands of families," they said. "She needs to be held to account." Green's comments come at a time when the Labour Party is already facing criticism for its handling of the pandemic. The party has been accused of being too close to the government and not doing enough to oppose its policies. Green's apology may help to quell some of the criticism, but it is likely to take time for the party to rebuild trust with the public.

title: Brazilian Senate eases Amazon protection rules
text: Brazilian Senate eases Amazon protection rules The bill, which now returns to the lower house, also eases fines for some previous illegal clearance if farmers commit to a reforestation programme. Supporters say Brazil needs land for food production, but environmentalists warn of increased Amazon deforestation. The bill reduces the size of the protected Amazon biome by two million hectares (7,700 square miles) and opens up new areas to mining and other commercial activities. It also weakens environmental oversight and enforcement in the region. Environmentalists say the bill will lead to increased deforestation and biodiversity loss in the Amazon, which is the world's largest rainforest and a vital carbon sink. They argue that the government should be focusing on sustainable development and protecting the Amazon for future generations. "This is a disaster for the Amazon and for the climate," said Marcio Astrini, the public policy coordinator for the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) in Brazil. "The government is putting short-term economic gain ahead of the long-term health of the planet." The bill was approved by the Senate by a vote of 63 to 13. It now returns to the lower house of Congress, where it is expected to pass easily. The bill has been criticized by scientists, environmentalists, and indigenous groups. They argue that it will lead to increased deforestation and biodiversity loss in the Amazon, and that it will undermine Brazil's efforts to combat climate change. The bill's supporters say that it is necessary to open up more land for agriculture and other economic activities in order to meet the needs of Brazil's growing population. They also argue that the bill includes safeguards to protect the environment, such as the requirement that farmers commit to a reforestation programme if they clear land illegally. The bill is part of a broader effort by the Brazilian government to weaken environmental protections in the Amazon. In recent years, the government has reduced funding for environmental enforcement and has made it easier for companies to obtain permits to clear land in the rainforest. The weakening of environmental protections in the Amazon is a major concern for the international community. The Amazon is a vital carbon sink, and deforestation in the region contributes to climate change. The Amazon is also home to a vast array of biodiversity, and deforestation threatens the survival of many species. The international community has urged Brazil to strengthen, not weaken, environmental protections in the Amazon. In 2015, Brazil signed the Paris Agreement on climate change, which commits the country to reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The weakening of environmental protections in the Amazon makes it more difficult for Brazil to meet its commitments under the Paris Agreement.

title: Australia to hold royal commission inquiry into banks
text: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull said the commission - Australia's highest form of public inquiry - would help restore confidence in the sector. Australian banks have been embroiled in scandals in recent times. Mr Turnbull had resisted calls for an inquiry, but the government has come under increasing pressure to act. The inquiry will be led by former High Court judge Kenneth Hayne, who will have the power to compel witnesses and documents. It will examine a wide range of issues, including lending practices, financial advice, and the culture of the banking industry. "We need to restore trust in our financial system," Mr Turnbull said. "This royal commission will help us to get to the bottom of the problems that have been identified and make sure that our banks are operating in a way that is in the best interests of all Australians." The announcement of the royal commission has been welcomed by consumer groups and the opposition Labor Party. "This is a significant step towards cleaning up the banking sector and rebuilding trust with the Australian people," said Labor leader Bill Shorten. The inquiry is expected to take about two years to complete. It will report its findings and recommendations to the government, which will then decide what action to take. Scandals involving Australian banks In recent years, Australian banks have been involved in a number of scandals, including: The Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) was found to have breached anti-money laundering laws on over 53,000 occasions. The National Australia Bank (NAB) was found to have charged fees for financial advice to dead customers. The Westpac Banking Corporation was found to have sold inappropriate financial products to customers. The ANZ Banking Group was found to have engaged in misleading conduct in relation to the sale of financial products. These scandals have led to a loss of trust in the banking sector. A recent survey found that only 37% of Australians trust banks to act in their best interests. The royal commission is expected to shed light on the causes of these scandals and make recommendations for how to prevent them from happening again.
