title: What are the UK's commitments to overseas territories?
text: James Landale Diplomatic correspondent @BBCJLandale on Twitter Britain has 14 overseas territories. They are mostly former colonies and are located all over the world, from Gibraltar and the Falklands to Anguilla, Turks and Caicos, and Bermuda. The UK has a legal and moral responsibility to its overseas territories. This is set out in the UN Charter, which states that "all peoples have the right of self-determination". This means that the people of the overseas territories have the right to choose their own future. The UK government has said that it will not force any overseas territory to become independent against its will. However, it has also said that it will not stand in the way of any territory that wishes to become independent. The future of the overseas territories is a matter for the people of those territories to decide. The UK government has said that it will support the people of the overseas territories in whatever decision they make. There are a variety of views on the future of the overseas territories. Some people believe that they should all become independent. Others believe that they should remain part of the UK. There is no consensus on this issue. The UK government has said that it will continue to engage with the people of the overseas territories and support them in their decision-making. The government has also said that it will continue to work with other countries and organisations to ensure that the overseas territories are able to prosper and develop. The UK's commitment to its overseas territories is a complex and long-standing one. The government has a legal and moral responsibility to the people of these territories. The future of the overseas territories is a matter for the people of those territories to decide. The UK government has said that it will support the people of the overseas territories in whatever decision they make.

title: Pubic hair grooming 'STI risk linked to skin tears'
text: Doctors say small tears in the skin from shaving or trimming could make it easier for infections to take hold. But they also say groomers - particularly extreme ones - tend to be more sexually active too. STIs are spread through contact with infected bodily fluids, such as during vaginal, anal, or oral sex. They can also be passed on from an infected mother to her baby during birth. There are a number of different types of STIs, including: Chlamydia Gonorrhea Syphilis HIV Herpes HPV Symptoms of STIs can vary depending on the type of infection, but they may include: Painful or itchy genitals Discharge from the penis or vagina Sores or rashes on the genitals, anus, or mouth Swollen lymph nodes Fever Fatigue If you think you may have an STI, it is important to see a doctor or sexual health clinic as soon as possible. Treatment for STIs varies depending on the type of infection, but it may include antibiotics, antiviral medications, or surgery. There are a number of things you can do to reduce your risk of getting an STI, including: Using condoms every time you have sex Getting vaccinated against HPV and hepatitis B Limiting your number of sexual partners Avoiding sex with people who have symptoms of an STI If you have any questions about STIs, please speak to your doctor or sexual health clinic. Pubic hair grooming and STI risk A number of studies have found a link between pubic hair grooming and an increased risk of STIs. One study, published in the journal "Sexually Transmitted Infections", found that women who groomed their pubic hair were more likely to have chlamydia and gonorrhea than women who did not groom their pubic hair. Another study, published in the journal "The Lancet Infectious Diseases", found that men who trimmed or shaved their pubic hair were more likely to have HIV than men who did not groom their pubic hair. The researchers believe that the increased risk of STIs among pubic hair groomers may be due to the fact that shaving or trimming can create small tears in the skin. These tears can then provide a pathway for bacteria and viruses to enter the body. Extreme pubic hair grooming Extreme pubic hair grooming, such as Brazilian waxing or laser hair removal, may further increase the risk of STIs. This is because these procedures can remove all of the hair from the pubic area, leaving the skin more exposed to bacteria and viruses. Conclusion The decision of whether or not to groom your pubic hair is a personal one. However, it is important to be aware of the potential risks associated with pubic hair grooming, including the increased risk of STIs. If you decide to groom your pubic hair, be sure to do so carefully to avoid creating tears in the skin.

title: Term-time holiday outlook - what might change?
text: However, they maintain the policy to reduce school absence is "clear and correct" and they also plan to strengthen the statutory guidance on the issue to schools and local authorities. It was changes to this guidance that led to the most recent row. The government is consulting on a number of possible changes to the guidance, including: Reducing the number of authorised leave days for family holidays from 10 to five. Requiring parents to give schools more notice of any planned absence. Making schools responsible for ensuring that children are up to date with their work when they return from holiday. The consultation closes on 31 October, and the government is expected to publish its final decision in early 2023. Head teachers have welcomed the prospect of a change in the guidance, but they are concerned that the proposed changes do not go far enough. They argue that the number of authorised leave days should be reduced further, and that parents should be required to get permission from the head teacher before taking their children out of school at all. The National Union of Teachers (NUT) has also called for the government to go further, arguing that the only way to reduce school absence is to make it a criminal offence for parents to take their children out of school without permission. The government has said that it is committed to reducing school absence, but it is also mindful of the need to avoid criminalising parents who simply want to spend time with their children. It is likely that the final decision will be a compromise between these two competing interests. In the meantime, parents should be aware that the rules on term-time holidays are likely to change in the near future. They should also be prepared for the possibility that they may be fined if they take their children out of school without permission.

title: Manchester homeless man's shock at Spice use in city
text: In the space of a year, William Nicholson said he has noticed a marked rise in use of the formerly legal drug. Mr Nicholson, who spent six months in Manchester in 2016 before returning this May, said spice is now "rife" on the city's streets. He said: "I was shocked when I came back, I didn't realise how bad it had got. "There are people smoking it in broad daylight, in doorways, on park benches, everywhere you look. "It's a real problem because it's so addictive and it's causing a lot of harm." Spice is a synthetic cannabinoid that was first developed in the early 2000s. It is similar to cannabis in its effects, but it is much more potent. Spice has been linked to a number of health problems, including seizures, heart problems, and psychosis. It can also be fatal. In 2016, the UK government banned the sale and possession of spice. However, the drug is still widely available on the black market. Mr Nicholson said he has seen the devastating effects that spice can have on people. "I've seen people who are addicted to spice and they're just not the same people anymore," he said. "They're withdrawn, they're aggressive, and they're just not functioning properly. "It's really sad to see." Mr Nicholson said he is concerned that the use of spice is increasing in Manchester. "I think it's because it's so cheap and easy to get," he said. "It's also very addictive, so once people start using it, it's very difficult for them to stop. "I'm worried that we're going to see more and more people dying from spice." Mr Nicholson said he hopes that the government will take action to tackle the problem of spice use. "I think the government needs to do more to educate people about the dangers of spice," he said. "They also need to do more to crack down on the sale and supply of the drug. "We need to do everything we can to stop people from dying from this terrible drug."

title: Tyne and Wear Metro strike: Commuters and shoppers affected
text: The network has been brought to a standstill after talks between operator Nexus and the RMT union broke down. Nexus has apologised to passengers and local bus companies. The strike, which began at 11pm on Monday, is over a pay dispute. The RMT is demanding a 7.1% pay increase, while Nexus has offered 2%. The strike is causing major disruption to commuters and shoppers. Many people are having to walk, cycle or drive to work or school. Local bus companies are also reporting a surge in demand. Nexus has said it is "disappointed" that the strike has gone ahead. It has urged the RMT to return to the negotiating table. However, the RMT has said it is "determined" to get a fair deal for its members. It has accused Nexus of "failing to take the concerns of its workers seriously". The strike is expected to last for three days. However, it could be extended if the two sides cannot reach an agreement. In the meantime, commuters and shoppers are advised to check the Nexus website for the latest information on services. They are also urged to consider alternative modes of transport. The strike is the latest in a series of industrial disputes that have hit the UK in recent months. Workers in various sectors, including rail, education and healthcare, have taken action over pay and conditions. The government has said it is "concerned" about the rising number of strikes. It has urged unions to work with employers to find a solution that is fair to both sides. However, unions have accused the government of failing to address the underlying issues that are causing the disputes. They have said that workers are simply trying to keep up with the rising cost of living. The strike is likely to cause further disruption to the UK economy. It is estimated that the rail strikes alone have cost the economy £1 billion. The government has said it is "committed" to supporting businesses that are affected by the strikes. However, it has also said that it will not tolerate "unreasonable" demands from unions.

title: Virus rebuilds heart's own pacemaker in animal tests
text: The heartbeat is controlled by electrical signals and if these go awry the consequences can be fatal. In the heart, a small group of cells called the sinus node acts as the body's natural pacemaker, generating the electrical pulses that initiate each heartbeat. But if the sinus node becomes damaged, the heart's rhythm can become irregular and dangerously slow. Current treatments such as pacemakers rely on implanted devices to take over the role of the damaged sinus node. Now, scientists have developed a virus that appears to rebuild the body's own natural pacemaker in animal tests. The technique was developed by a team at the University of Utah and the results are published in the journal Nature Biotechnology. The virus is a harmless adeno-associated virus, which has been genetically engineered so that it carries a gene that makes a key protein needed to generate electrical signals in the heart. When the virus is injected into the heart, it infects and modifies a small group of cells within the sinus node. These modified cells are then able to generate electrical signals, effectively rebuilding the heart's natural pacemaker. In animal tests, the technique led to a significant improvement in heart function in animals with damaged sinus nodes. The research is at an early stage and the team is now working on adapting it for use in humans. They are currently conducting a trial in patients with heart problems to assess the technique's safety and effectiveness. Dr Carlos Henrique, who carried out the research, said: "This technique could potentially revolutionise the treatment of heart rhythm disorders. It could provide us with a way to restore normal heart function without the need for implanted devices." Heart rhythm disorders - or arrhythmias - are a major global health problem. Irregular heart rhythms are caused by disruptions to the heart's normal electrical impulses. Arrhythmias affect one in four people in their lifetime. They can lead to a range of problems including dizziness, palpitations, breathlessness and tiredness. Some arrhythmias can also be fatal. Current treatments include medications, pacemakers and defibrillators. But these have a range of limitations and can lead to complications. The new technique could provide a more effective and less invasive treatment option for arrhythmias caused by damage to the sinus node.

title: Brexit: Differences remain over trade deal, say UK and EU
text: UK negotiator Lord David Frost said "wide divergences" remained in some areas, despite progress being made. His EU counterpart, Michel Barnier, said there were "serious divergences" over fishing and competition rules. Negotiation resumed last week after a three-week break, but talks broke up at the weekend without agreement. Speaking after a meeting of EU ambassadors, Mr Barnier said the "essential" issue of fisheries and the "crucial" subject of "governance" - including rules on state aid and competition - remained unresolved. "I regret the UK's position as it stands... It is not up to the task," he added. In a statement, Lord Frost said: "We made progress in some areas but serious differences remain, particularly on fisheries and the so-called level playing field. Resolving these issues is essential for an agreement." The UK government wants a deal that allows it to set its own rules, while the EU wants to ensure that the UK does not gain an unfair advantage over its member states. One EU diplomat said that the UK was demanding "the best of both worlds" - access to EU markets without following EU rules. "This is not acceptable," the diplomat said. "We are not going to give them a better deal than our own members." The UK left the EU on 31 January, but remains in a transition period until the end of the year. During this time, the UK abides by EU rules and regulations, but does not have a say in how they are made. If no trade deal is agreed by the end of the year, the UK will leave the EU's single market and customs union without a deal. This would mean that tariffs and other barriers to trade would be imposed between the UK and the EU. Many businesses have warned that a no-deal Brexit would be damaging to the UK economy. Lord Frost said the UK was "prepared to leave without a deal at the end of the year". "But we continue to believe that it is possible to reach a mutually beneficial agreement with the EU," he added.

title: Australia approves strikes against IS in Iraq
text: Prime Minister Tony Abbott said IS was a "death cult" that had "declared war on the world" and must be stopped. IS controls a broad swathe of territory, spanning a borderless stretch of Syria and Iraq. The group, which is also known as ISIS, has led a campaign of abduction, rape and murder against civilians, and has become one of the biggest security threats to the West. Australia has already committed 600 personnel to the international coalition against IS, including 30 special forces soldiers who will train Iraqi army personnel in Iraq. The government has said it will not rule out sending combat troops to the region if necessary. The decision to approve air strikes was made after the government received a briefing from the chief of the Defence Force, General David Hurley. General Hurley said the strikes would be carried out "as part of the international coalition", and that they would be "precise and proportionate". The government has said that the strikes will be targeted at IS headquarters, training camps and command centers. It has also said that the strikes will be carried out in accordance with international law. The decision to approve air strikes has been welcomed by the opposition Labor party. Labor leader Bill Shorten said that the strikes were "necessary" and that they would help to "degrade" IS. However, some critics have argued that the strikes will not be effective in stopping the spread of IS. They argue that IS is a highly mobile and adaptable group, and that it will be difficult to target its leaders and headquarters. Others have argued that the strikes could lead to civilian casualties. The government has said that it will take all possible measures to avoid civilian casualties, but there is no guarantee that this will be possible. The decision to approve air strikes is a significant escalation of Australia's involvement in the fight against IS. It is a sign that the government is increasingly concerned about the threat posed by the group, and that it is willing to take military action to stop it.

title: Menzies Aviation workers face redundancy after global travel slump
text: The Unite trade union said Menzies Aviation has started a 45-day consultation with staff. Before most aircraft were grounded, the company was one of those providing ground handling for aircraft and baggage. The firm said it had taken “all possible steps” to keep staff employed throughout the pandemic, including furloughing 90% of its workforce. However, it said it now needs to “restructure” its operations to survive the downturn in air travel. Unite regional officer Willie Thomson said: “This is devastating news for Menzies Aviation workers and their families, particularly at this time of year. “The aviation industry has been hit hard by the pandemic but it is also true that Menzies has been struggling financially for a number of years.” He said the union would be “doing everything we can” to support members during the consultation process and would be “pressing the company to do everything possible to avoid compulsory redundancies”. Menzies Aviation is a global aviation services company headquartered in Edinburgh, Scotland. It provides ground handling, cargo handling, and fuelling services to airlines at more than 200 airports worldwide. The company has been hit hard by the COVID-19 pandemic, which has caused a collapse in air travel. In September, Menzies Aviation announced plans to cut 400 jobs in the UK, citing the impact of the pandemic on its business. The company said the job cuts would affect all areas of its UK operations, including ground handling, cargo handling, and fuelling. The aviation industry has been one of the hardest hit sectors by the COVID-19 pandemic. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has estimated that the industry will lose $84 billion in revenue in 2020. The pandemic has led to a sharp decline in air travel, as people have been reluctant to fly due to concerns about the virus.

title: Challenge of Redcar blast furnace relighting
text: Dave Johnson and Derek Thomas have between them more than 80 years' experience in the steel industry. Both spoke about the huge achievement of reopening the Redcar steelworks, which is now owned by SSI UK. "It's a massive achievement to get this plant back up and running," said Johnson, who is the plant manager. "It's a credit to the hard work and dedication of everyone involved." Thomas, who is the operations manager, said that the restart of the blast furnace was a "critical milestone" for SSI UK. "This is a major step forward for the company and for the Teesside area," he said. The Redcar steelworks was mothballed in 2015 after its previous owner, Sahaviriya Steel Industries (SSI), went into liquidation. SSI UK bought the site out of administration in 2016 and has since invested heavily in restarting production. The blast furnace is the heart of the steelmaking process. It uses coke, iron ore and limestone to produce molten iron, which is then converted into steel. Restarting the blast furnace is a complex and time-consuming process. It took around three months to complete, and involved the work of hundreds of people. The first iron was produced from the blast furnace on 17 October 2022. This was a major milestone for SSI UK and for the Teesside area. The restart of the blast furnace has created hundreds of jobs and is a major boost for the local economy. It is also a sign of the growing confidence in the steel industry in the UK. However, the challenge is not over yet. SSI UK still needs to raise significant funding to complete the restart of the steelworks. The company is also facing challenges from the global steel market, which is currently in a downturn. Despite these challenges, Johnson and Thomas are confident about the future of SSI UK. They believe that the company has the potential to become a major player in the global steel industry. "We have a great team of people and we have a great product," said Johnson. "We are confident that we can make SSI UK a success."

title: Scots NHS staff to receive pay rise denied to English
text: By Reevel Alderson BBC Scotland's social affairs correspondent Scots NHS staff are to receive a 1% pay rise backdated to April 2022, the Scottish government has announced. This is in contrast to England, where staff will not be given the 1% increase recommended by the NHS pay review body. The Scottish government said the pay rise was "fair and affordable" and that it recognized the contribution of NHS staff during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Royal College of Nursing in Scotland welcomed the pay rise, but said it was "disappointing" that the Scottish government had not gone further. "This pay award is a welcome step in the right direction, but it is still a real-terms pay cut for our members," said Julie Lamberth, the RCN's director in Scotland. "The Scottish government must now commit to a multi-year pay deal that will ensure that our members' pay keeps pace with inflation." The Scottish government said the pay rise would cost £125m and would be funded from existing budgets. The announcement of the pay rise comes after months of negotiations between the Scottish government and trade unions. In England, the government has refused to implement the 1% pay rise recommended by the NHS pay review body. The government said it could not afford the pay rise and that it would have to be funded by cuts to services. The decision has been met with anger from trade unions, who have accused the government of breaking its promise to NHS staff. The Royal College of Nursing in England has said it will ballot its members for industrial action if the government does not agree to a pay rise. The pay dispute is the latest in a series of disputes between the government and public sector workers. In recent months, teachers, civil servants and railway workers have all taken strike action over pay and conditions. The government has said it is committed to keeping public sector pay down, but unions have argued that public sector workers are falling behind the cost of living. The pay dispute is likely to continue in the coming months, with unions warning of further industrial action if the government does not meet their demands.

title: Kelly Mary Fauvrelle: Pregnant woman killed in Croydon named
text: Two men have been arrested on suspicion of murdering the 26-year-old, who was pronounced dead at a house in Croydon, south London, early on Saturday. Her baby was delivered at the scene by paramedics and is in hospital in a stable condition. The victim has been named locally as Kelly Mary Fauvrelle, who lived in Thornton Heath, Croydon. Police were called to a house on London Road shortly before 3.30am on Saturday to reports of a woman in cardiac arrest. Officers and paramedics found Ms Fauvrelle suffering from multiple injuries. Despite the efforts of paramedics, she died at the scene. A post-mortem examination found that Ms Fauvrelle died from multiple stab wounds. Two men, aged 29 and 43, were arrested on Saturday on suspicion of murder. They remain in custody at a south London police station. Detective Chief Inspector Mick Norman, who is leading the investigation, said: "This is a tragic incident in which a young woman has lost her life and her baby is now fighting for his life. "We are doing everything we can to establish the circumstances of what happened and to bring those responsible to justice. "I would urge anyone who has any information about this incident to come forward and speak to us. No matter how small or insignificant you think the information may be, it could be vital in helping us to piece together what happened." Anyone with information is asked to call the incident room on 020 8721 4005 or Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111. Additional information Ms Fauvrelle was originally from Mauritius and had been living in the UK for several years. She was a single mother to a young daughter. Her family have described her as a "loving and caring mother" who was "always smiling". A GoFundMe page has been set up to raise money for Ms Fauvrelle's funeral and to support her family. Update On Monday, June 20, the two men who were arrested on suspicion of murdering Kelly Mary Fauvrelle were charged with murder. They appeared at Croydon Magistrates' Court on Tuesday, June 21, and were remanded in custody to appear at the Old Bailey on a date to be fixed.

title: Scottish steel task force in 'urgent action' pledge
text: The announcement came after the group held its first meeting. It was chaired by Scotland's business minister Fergus Ewing and included representatives from trade unions, industry, and government. Ewing said the task force would "take urgent action" to address the challenges facing the industry. He said the group would focus on four key areas: Improving the competitiveness of the Scottish steel industry Developing new markets for Scottish steel Supporting innovation in the industry Attracting investment to the sector Ewing said the task force would work closely with the UK government and other stakeholders to ensure that the Scottish steel industry has a "sustainable future." The task force was established in response to the recent closure of two steel plants in Scotland, with the loss of around 1,000 jobs. The closures have raised concerns about the future of the industry in Scotland. The task force will be led by Ian Livingston, the former chief executive of BT Group. Livingston has a wealth of experience in the steel industry, having previously worked for British Steel and Tata Steel. The task force will also include representatives from the Scottish government, the UK government, the steel industry, and trade unions. The task force is expected to report back to the Scottish government within six months. The Scottish government has also announced a £10 million fund to support the steel industry. The fund will be used to provide grants to businesses that are investing in new equipment or processes. The Scottish government has said that it is committed to supporting the steel industry in Scotland. The industry is a key part of the Scottish economy, and the government is determined to ensure that it has a sustainable future. The task force is a welcome step in the right direction. It is important that the Scottish government takes action to address the challenges facing the industry. The task force will provide a forum for stakeholders to come together and develop a plan for the future of the Scottish steel industry.

title: PC Gordon Semple death: Stefano Brizzi 'spent days' with body
text: Stefano Brizzi, 50, is accused of strangling PC Gordon Semple, 59, and attempting to dispose of the remains in an acid bath. He told detectives he "thought he was getting away with it" when he spent days with the body before fleeing to Italy. Brizzi is said to have attacked the officer on April 1 following "a brief discussion" at his home in Southwark, south London. The pair were known to each other. The Old Bailey heard how Brizzi placed the officer's body in a large bag before keeping it in his living room for several days. Jurors were told he bought a number of items, including bleach, drain cleaner, and a new suitcase, which he planned to use to dispose of the body. Prosecutor Oliver Glasgow KC said Brizzi's "only intention" was to dissolve the body in acid and dispose of it down the drain. He told the court: "He embarked upon a series of significant actions in an attempt to destroy the body of PC Gordon Semple." Brizzi bought caustic soda, which he poured over the officer's body, the court heard. He also attempted to use a circular saw to dismember the remains. When police arrived at Brizzi's home on April 9, they found the officer's body in a bag filled with acid in the hallway. Brizzi was arrested the following day in Dover as he prepared to board a ferry bound for France. Mr. Glasgow said Brizzi, originally from Italy, had been living in the UK for 12 years. He told jurors that the defendant had been having financial difficulties and was facing eviction from his home. Brizzi denies murder and attempting to pervert the course of justice. The trial continues.

title: Undercover police: Legal challenge over inquiry
text: Dominic Casciani Home affairs correspondent @BBCDomCon Twitter In a legal warning letter to the home secretary, they say one of the officers at the centre of the inquiry was responsible for their mother’s death. The lawyers acting for Jean Charles de Menezes’ family have sent a legal warning letter to the home secretary over a public inquiry into undercover policing. In a legal warning letter to the home secretary, they say one of the officers at the centre of the inquiry was responsible for their mother’s death. The inquiry, set up in 2014, is examining the use of undercover police officers to infiltrate political and social activist groups, and the way these officers have acted while undercover. Jean Charles de Menezes was shot dead by police in 2005 after being mistaken for a suicide bomber. The police officer who shot him, known only as W40, was one of the undercover officers at the centre of the inquiry. The family’s lawyers say that W40 was responsible for the death of Jean Charles de Menezes and that the inquiry has failed to properly investigate his role. They are now calling for the inquiry to be halted and for a new one to be set up. The home secretary has said that she will not halt the inquiry, but she has agreed to meet with the family’s lawyers to discuss their concerns. The inquiry is due to report back to the home secretary by the end of 2023. The legal warning letter from the family’s lawyers is the latest in a series of challenges to the inquiry. Earlier this year, a group of campaigners launched a legal challenge to the inquiry’s terms of reference, arguing that they were too narrow. The campaigners’ challenge was unsuccessful, but the family’s lawyers hope that their warning letter will be more successful. The inquiry into undercover policing is one of the most important public inquiries in recent years. It is examining a serious issue that has raised questions about the role of the police and the way they operate. It is vital that the inquiry is able to conduct its work properly and that it is not subject to political or legal interference.

title: Libby Squire murder trial: Accused's behaviour 'frightening'
text: Libby Squire, 21, disappeared after she was refused entry to a Hull nightclub on 31 January 2019 and was found seven weeks later in the Humber Estuary. Pawel Relowicz, 26, denies murdering and raping her. Prosecutor Richard Wright QC has told Hull Crown Court how Relowicz, a Polish butcher, was "determined that night to have sex with Libby, come what may". Wright said Relowicz, who had drunk vodka and Jagerbombs before going out that night, had been "casing" women in the city centre, and had driven around in his van looking for a victim. He said Relowicz saw Ms Squire "vulnerable" and alone and decided to pursue her. He followed her in his van as she walked from the nightclub and through an alleyway. When Ms Squire fell over in the snow, Relowicz got out of his van and grabbed her. Mr Wright said Relowicz dragged Ms Squire back to his van and raped her. He said Relowicz then drove Ms Squire to Oak Road playing fields and attacked her again. Mr Wright said Relowicz had told police in his interviews that he did not remember what happened next, but had woken up the next day with Ms Squire in his bed. He said Relowicz had told police that Ms Squire left his flat the next morning, but the prosecution claims this is a lie. He said Ms Squire was dead by the time she left Relowicz's flat. Mr Wright said Relowicz's behaviour was "frightening" and that he had shown "a complete lack of respect" for Ms Squire. He said Relowicz had lied to police and had tried to cover up his crimes. The trial continues.

title: Yemen's Houthis step back on threats to tax aid
text: The rebel group, which has controlled the capital Sanaa and much of Yemen since 2014, had said they would impose a 2% tax on all aid entering the country, a move that would have had a devastating impact on the millions of Yemenis who rely on humanitarian assistance. The Houthis' decision to back down on their threat came after intense international pressure, including from the United Nations and the United States. The UN envoy to Yemen, Martin Griffiths, said that the Houthis had "agreed to reconsider" their plans after he met with their leader, Abdul-Malik al-Houthi. The US State Department also welcomed the Houthis' decision, saying that it was "a positive step" and that it would "allow aid to continue to flow into Yemen." The Houthis' decision to impose a tax on aid had been widely condemned by aid agencies, who said that it would have made it even more difficult to provide assistance to those in need. The UN estimates that 24 million Yemenis are in need of humanitarian assistance, and that 10 million are on the brink of famine. The Houthis have been accused of using aid as a weapon of war, and of diverting it to their own supporters. In 2018, the UN accused the Houthis of stealing food aid from warehouses and selling it on the black market. The Houthis have denied the allegations, but they have been accused of making it difficult for aid agencies to operate in Houthi-controlled areas. Aid agencies have said that they have been subjected to harassment and intimidation, and that they have been prevented from accessing some areas. The Houthis' decision to back down on their threat to tax aid is a welcome step, but it remains to be seen whether they will allow aid to flow into Yemen without hindrance. The humanitarian crisis in Yemen is one of the worst in the world, and it is essential that all parties allow aid to reach those in need.

title: Dame Jenni Murray on why she's taking her clothes off on TV
text: Dame Jenni will strip to her underwear on the ITV show to raise awareness of the importance of checking for cancer. The 70-year-old, who has presented Woman's Hour on BBC Radio 4 for more than 30 years, will appear on Lorraine next Thursday, where she will be joined by other celebrities including Carol Vorderman, Victoria Derbyshire and Sally Phillips. Dame Jenni said she decided to take part in the show after being diagnosed with breast cancer in 2016. She underwent a mastectomy and chemotherapy, and is now cancer-free. "I'm doing this because I want to encourage other women to check their breasts regularly," she said. "I know it can be daunting, but it's so important. If you find something early, it's much more likely to be treatable." Dame Jenni's appearance on Lorraine will be part of a week-long campaign by ITV to raise awareness of cancer. The campaign will include a series of films featuring people who have been affected by cancer, as well as information on how to check for different types of cancer. ITV's head of factual entertainment, Kate Teckman, said: "We're delighted that Dame Jenni has agreed to take part in this campaign. Her story is an incredibly powerful one, and we hope it will inspire others to take action." Dame Jenni's decision to strip off on TV has been praised by cancer charities. Breast Cancer UK's chief executive, Delyth Morgan, said: "We applaud Dame Jenni for her bravery in speaking out about her experience. Her appearance on Lorraine will help to raise awareness of the importance of checking your breasts regularly." Macmillan Cancer Support's chief executive, Lynda Thomas, said: "We're grateful to Dame Jenni for using her platform to highlight the importance of cancer awareness. Her story will help to encourage others to seek help and support, and to take steps to reduce their risk of cancer."

title: Karate punching power 'all in the brain'
text: By Jonathan Ball BBC News In a close-range punching contest described in Cerebral Cortex, experts consistently out-hit novices. Scientists peered deep into the brains of the experts to reveal alterations in two regions related to balance and coordination - the basal ganglia and the cerebellum. They discovered that expert karateka have different patterns of activity in these regions compared with less experienced fighters. It's as if the expert brains have fine-tuned these areas for punching. The study also found that better-skilled fighters showed greater levels of connectivity between the two brain regions. "I've been training now for 42 years and the movements are almost automatic," says Gary "Tiger" Mullins, a world champion karate fighter and one of the experts involved in the study. "I can't think, 'I'm going to do this movement now' - I just do it, and I don't think about it. "It's good to know what's happening in the brain. It's a bit like magic - you don't know how you do it." "Balance control is very important - when you're punching, you need to stay balanced," says Prof Etienne Sibille, one of the researchers on the study from the University of Strasbourg in France. "These brain regions are really important for punching." The scientists speculate that the changes they observed may have been caused by the act of training. Previous research has shown that the brain is able to adapt to the demands of training, for example by increasing the size of certain brain regions. "When you train over a long period of time, you can change your brain," says Prof Sibille. "So if you were a karate fighter, you could increase the volume of the cerebellum." The researchers believe that their findings could help to improve training methods for karateka and other martial artists. "We hope that this can lead to new ways of training - for example, we could devise exercises that target these specific brain regions," says Prof Sibille. "It's a very exciting area of research and I think it's going to open up a lot of new possibilities in the future."

title: Respite reported for Scotland's daily newspaper sales
text: By Jamie McIvor BBC News correspondent The Scotsman and The Herald both recorded very small rises in their circulations between April and May. This was probably helped by the general election. However The Courier and The Press and Journal suffered falls in their circulation. The figures from the industry body Newsworks show a decline of 4.8% in Scotland's daily newspaper market over the past year, with an average sale of 460,318 copies per day. Sunday papers in Scotland saw larger circulation rises, but the increase of 8.9% was based on only 387,000 copies sold each day. It means total newspaper sales have fallen 4.7% over the past year with 847,318 papers being sold each day, down 41,426. On a UK basis, the Daily Mail saw a small circulation rise of 0.4% and is now the UK's biggest selling daily newspaper, ahead of The Sun. The Times, The Daily Telegraph, the Financial Times, The Guardian and The Independent all saw falls in their circulation during May. Sunday newspaper sales were down 5.8% across the UK in May, with only the Mail on Sunday and The Sunday Times recording increases. The market for print newspapers has been in long-term decline, with readers increasingly getting their news online. The shift towards digital is a particular concern for regional newspapers, which rely more heavily on print sales than national titles. In Scotland, The Scotsman and The Herald have both launched digital subscription services in an attempt to boost revenue. The Courier and The Press and Journal have also been investing in digital, but they have not yet seen the same level of success as their rivals. The latest circulation figures from Newsworks show that newspapers are facing a tough battle to retain readers. The industry is hoping that the introduction of new technologies, such as virtual reality and augmented reality, will help to attract new readers. However, it is clear that print newspapers will continue to face challenges in the coming years.

title: Apple apologises and fixes security flaw
text: Dave Lee North America technology reporter The flaw, revealed on Tuesday, made it possible to access a Mac without a password, and also have access to powerful administrator rights. The latest version of macOS will automatically download the update. "We greatly regret this error and apologize to all our customers, both for releasing with this vulnerability and for the fact that it took us so long to correct it," Apple said in a statement. The security flaw was discovered by researcher Cedric Owens and responsibly disclosed to Apple. Owens said the bug could have been exploited in several scenarios, including phishing attacks. "An attacker could have sent a malicious link to a victim, and once the victim clicked on the link, the attacker would have been able to gain full control of the victim's Mac," Owens said. "This could have been used to steal sensitive data, install malware, or even take complete control of the victim's Mac." The security update, which is available now, fixes the flaw and prevents attackers from exploiting it. Apple also recommends that users update their software to the latest version. This is not the first time that Apple has been criticized for its security practices. In 2018, the company was criticized for a security flaw that allowed attackers to access users' iCloud accounts without a password. Apple also came under fire in 2017 for a security flaw that allowed attackers to install malware on Macs without the user's knowledge. Apple has said that it is committed to improving its security practices. The company has hired more security engineers and has invested in new security technologies. title: Brexit: Corbyn aides warn against pre-election referendum
text: By Iain Watson Political correspondent, BBC News These senior aides are concerned he is being pushed into a position which would delay a general election for some months by the shadow cabinet's Brexit policy spokesman, Sir Keir Starmer. A second referendum would effectively give the public a direct say on whether they want to leave the EU or not and would therefore change Labour's current policy. It would also open up the possibility of delays to the whole Brexit process because, if the public voted to remain, the government would have to extend its discussions with the EU. Mr Corbyn is facing calls to consider a second referendum on his own terms in order to unite the party but some of his closest allies are vehemently opposed to one. One senior aide told the BBC: "A referendum would be a huge gamble for us and could open up big divisions in the party. "Our main focus should be on winning the next election and we have to be careful not to get bogged down in Brexit, which is still a big problem for us." The shadow cabinet will consider the proposal again on Tuesday, the BBC understands. Speaking at a rally in Harlow, Essex, Mr Corbyn said the referendum "is an option on the table". "It's part of our policy-making process and we will take our time to reach a conclusion," he said. "Our priority is to get a general election, to get a Labour government and to implement our manifesto. "That means taking urgent action on the cost-of-living crisis, the housing crisis, the climate crisis and bringing our NHS back into public ownership." Sir Keir has argued that a public vote is the only way to resolve the Brexit impasse. "The country is deeply divided and many people are losing faith in our democracy," he said. "A referendum would give the public a chance to have their say and would help to unite the country." However, his proposal has been met with resistance from left-wing Labour MPs, who argue that it would be a betrayal of the 2016 referendum result. They believe that a second referendum would only serve to prolong the Brexit process and would undermine public trust in democracy.

title: Glasgow School of Art fire safety system 'was weeks away'
text: The British Automatic Fire Sprinkler Association said huge pumps needed for the water mist system had arrived on site the day before. It was due to go live on 15 June - two weeks after the blaze started. However, there was not enough time to install it before the fire. A spokesman for the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service said the water mist system would have been "unlikely" to prevent the huge fire that destroyed much of the art school building on 15 June 2018. Architects had hoped the system would extinguish any blaze within 15 minutes and stop it spreading. The £2m water mist system was part of a major refurbishment project at the art school. It included 243 sprinkler heads and five pumps - one of which was still on a lorry outside the building when the fire broke out. A source close to the project said the pumps had been delivered the day before and two were already in place in the basement. The remaining pumps were due to be installed in the coming weeks. The source said the sprinkler heads had been installed but the pumps were needed to power the system. "Without the pumps, the system couldn't work," the source said. "It was due to go live on 15 June." The Glasgow School of Art fire was one of the biggest fires in the UK in recent years. It destroyed much of the art school's Mackintosh Building, which was designed by renowned architect Charles Rennie Mackintosh. The building is now being rebuilt and is expected to reopen in 2029. The Scottish Fire and Rescue Service said the fire was "unprecedented" and that the water mist system would have been "unlikely" to prevent it. "The fire was so intense that it caused the roof to collapse and the building to be gutted," a spokesman said. "It is difficult to say for certain what would have happened if the water mist system had been in place, but it is unlikely that it would have prevented the fire from spreading." The British Automatic Fire Sprinkler Association said the water mist system would have been "a valuable addition" to the art school's fire safety system. "It is a very effective way of extinguishing fires and preventing them from spreading," a spokesman said. "It is a shame that the system was not in place before the fire."

title: Pakistanis respond after 'spy pigeon' detained in India
text: BBC Trending What's popular and why It all started when a 14-year-old boy in an Indian village close to the border with Pakistan found a white pigeon with a mysterious ring attached to its foot. The Indian authorities were alerted, and the bird was soon labelled a "spy pigeon", leading to a diplomatic row between India and Pakistan. However, Pakistanis have taken to social media to respond to the incident with a mixture of humour and anger. Some have suggested that the pigeon may have been sent by Pakistan's intelligence agency, the ISI, to gather information about India's military installations. Others have joked that the pigeon was a peace envoy, or even a "freedom fighter". However, many Pakistanis have also expressed anger at the Indian authorities for detaining the pigeon and accusing it of being a spy. They argue that the bird is an innocent creature that should not be used as a political pawn. "#FreeThePigeon" has become a trending hashtag on Twitter in Pakistan, with many users calling for the bird to be released immediately. One user tweeted: "This is a travesty of justice. The pigeon has done nothing wrong and should not be held captive." Another user wrote: "The Indian government is making a mockery of itself with this stunt. It's time to let the pigeon go." The incident has also been met with amusement by some Pakistanis. One user tweeted: "I can't believe India is accusing us of sending spy pigeons. This is the funniest thing I've heard all week." Another user wrote: "I wonder what kind of secrets the Indian government thinks the pigeon was carrying. Maybe it was carrying a message from our prime minister to the Indian president?" The Indian authorities have not yet commented on the incident, but it is likely to further strain relations between the two countries. This is not the first time that pigeons have been accused of being spies. In 2018, a pigeon with a camera attached to its back was found in Pakistan-administered Kashmir. The Indian authorities claimed that the pigeon was being used to spy on Indian military installations, but Pakistan denied the allegations, saying that the bird was a pet. The use of pigeons as spies is a centuries-old practice. In ancient times, pigeons were used to carry messages between armies. In more recent times, pigeons have been used to spy on enemy territory during wartime. However, the use of pigeons as spies is becoming increasingly rare as technology advances. Today, there are more effective and less risky ways to gather intelligence.

title: A US judge asked lawyers to explain the lyrics to Thriller
text: US Tax Court Judge Mark Holmes had always been puzzled by the rap at the end of Michael Jackson's Thriller, so when the star's former lawyer John Branca appeared in front of him, he decided to ask him for an explanation. Branca, who also happens to be the co-executor of Jackson's estate, duly obliged, giving a detailed breakdown of the lyrics. The rap, performed by Vincent Price, is a spoken-word monologue that serves as a chilling epilogue to the song's eerie narrative. It begins with the line, "Darkness falls across the land," and goes on to describe a group of ghouls and monsters emerging from their graves. Price's sinister delivery adds to the sense of dread, as he warns the listener, "Thriller night is here." Branca explained to Judge Holmes that the rap was Jackson's way of paying homage to the horror films of his youth. "Michael was a big fan of Vincent Price and horror movies in general," Branca said. "He wanted to create a song that would be both scary and fun, and he thought that Price's voice would be the perfect addition." The rap also contains a number of references to classic horror films, such as "Boris Karloff" (the actor who played Frankenstein's monster) and "your local drive-in." These references serve to further enhance the song's creepy atmosphere. Judge Holmes was clearly fascinated by Branca's explanation, and he thanked the lawyer for his time. "I've always been a fan of Thriller," Holmes said, "but I never really understood the rap at the end. Now I do, and I appreciate it even more." Branca's explanation is a reminder of the importance of context when it comes to interpreting art. The rap at the end of Thriller may seem like a strange and out-of-place addition to the song, but when you understand the references and the inspiration behind it, it becomes clear that it is an integral part of the song's overall impact.

title: Belfast homeless: At least five dead since January, says charity
text: By Andy West BBC News NI There are no specific statistics on those who die during or after a period of homelessness. However, the Welcome Organisation said rough sleepers are dying due to mental and physical illness, as well as suicides and accidents as a result of their situation. Patrick Corrigan, the Welcome Organisation's chief executive said: "We have been working in the city centre for 30 years and we are seeing more people dying on the streets." "What we are seeing now is people who are much younger and that is a real cause for concern, in the past it was people who may have had a dependency on alcohol and maybe in their 40s or 50s might pass away, now we are seeing people in their 20s and 30s." He said funding cuts were having an impact on the health and welfare of homeless people. "We don't have the funding to help the people who need our help the most, something has to change," he said. The Welcome Organisation runs two centres in Belfast that provide day services to homeless people and those at risk of homelessness. In a statement, the Department for Communities said it was "deeply saddened" by the deaths of homeless people. "We are committed to tackling homelessness and providing support to those who need it most," the statement said. "We are investing over £100m in homelessness services this year, including funding for outreach and support services for those living on the streets." The department said it was working with the Welcome Organisation and other partners to improve services for homeless people, including those with complex needs such as mental health issues and addiction. The department also said it was working to prevent people from becoming homeless in the first place, including providing financial assistance and support to those at risk of losing their homes. SDLP councillor Paul McCusker said the deaths of homeless people were a "tragedy". "These are people who are dying on our streets, in our city centre, and it is a disgrace," he said. "We need to see more funding for homeless services, and we need to see more support for people who are struggling with mental health issues and addiction." The Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency (Nisra) said it does not routinely collect data on deaths among homeless people. However, a Nisra spokesperson said the agency was "working with partners to develop a better understanding of the issue".

title: Artificial intelligence 'as good as cancer doctors'
text: By James Gallagher Health and science reporter, BBC News website The Stanford University team said the findings were "incredibly exciting" and would now be tested in clinics. Eventually, they hope AI will help doctors to make more accurate diagnoses and personalize treatments. However, they stress the technology is still in its early stages and is not ready to replace doctors. Instead, they will help doctors in the same way a calculator helps an accountant. The AI system is trained on a vast dataset of mammograms and corresponding patient outcomes. This includes images where cancer has been detected and where it has not. The system learns to identify patterns in the mammograms that are invisible to the human eye, and it uses these to make its predictions. In the study, the researchers trained their AI on a dataset of more than 28,000 mammograms and tested it on a separate dataset of almost 2,000 mammograms. They found that the AI system was as good as a human radiologist at detecting cancer, but it was better at identifying benign lumps. The researchers say their system could assist radiologists by providing a second opinion or by highlighting suspicious areas on mammograms for further examination. Dr Michael Abramoff, who led the research, said: "Our AI has achieved a level of accuracy that is comparable to the best human radiologists. This is a major milestone in the development of AI for healthcare." However, he cautioned that the technology is still in its early stages. "AI is not a replacement for doctors. It is a tool that can help doctors to make more accurate diagnoses and personalize treatments," he said. The next step is to test the AI system in a clinical setting. The researchers are planning to launch a trial in the US later this year. If the trial is successful, the AI system could be used in clinics within the next few years. The research is published in the journal Nature Medicine. Artificial intelligence (AI) has been shown to be as good as cancer doctors at detecting breast cancer on mammograms, a new study has found. The researchers, from Stanford University in the US, say their findings are "incredibly exciting" and could lead to more accurate diagnoses and personalized treatments for patients.

title: Coronavirus: Cases are recorded in 64 NI schools
text: Coronavirus: Cases are recorded in 64 NI schools By Robbie Meredith BBC News NI Education Correspondent The Department of Education (DE) revealed the figure to the Stormont Education Committee on Tuesday. Up until that point, the department had only confirmed cases in 62 schools. The DE said it is not releasing the names of schools with confirmed cases for data protection reasons and to avoid creating unnecessary stigma. The new school term began on 31 August. There are nearly 1,200 schools in Northern Ireland, catering for more than 350,000 pupils. The latest figures come as teachers' unions warned of an "explosion" in Covid-19 cases in schools. The National Education Union (NEU) said the number of confirmed cases will not give the full picture as schools are not expected to report cases to the Public Health Agency (PHA) unless they reach a certain threshold. NEU joint secretary Gerry Murphy said schools that are not reporting cases to the PHA have pupils who are positive and "they are becoming super spreaders" due to "the lack of mitigations in place". "This is a really serious situation," he said. "We want to see schools open but they need to be safe environments for all concerned." The INTO teaching union said it had received "many calls" from teachers and principals asking what they should do if they have a positive case in their school. John Boyle, the union's general secretary for Northern Ireland, said that in some schools full classes of pupils have been sent home due to one positive case, while other schools have been advised that pupils do not need to go home as long as they wear face coverings. "That is not acceptable," he said. "Schools need urgent clarification from the Department of Education and the Public Health Agency on how to deal with confirmed cases and what mitigations need to be in place to maintain a safe learning environment." The Public Health Agency (PHA) said it was "very concerned" about the increase in the number of cases in schools. The PHA's head of health protection Dr Gerry Waldron said it was "important to remember that while children and young people are less likely to become seriously ill from Covid-19, they can still transmit the virus to others". "We are urging everyone to take steps to reduce the risk of transmission, including getting vaccinated, wearing face coverings in crowded indoor settings, and washing your hands regularly," he said. The Department of Education said it was "fully aware" of the concerns raised by the teaching unions. A spokesperson said the department was "working closely with the Public Health Agency to provide guidance and support to schools". "We will continue to monitor the situation and take any necessary steps to ensure that schools remain safe environments for pupils and staff," the spokesperson said.

title: Drones hamper US firefighting efforts
text: Lives were put at unnecessary risk because helicopters could not fly, said fire department officials. The helicopters were helping to contain a large wildfire in San Bernadino county over the weekend. Five drones spotted hovering over the fire were thought to belong to members of the public who had flown them into the area to take pictures or videos. Repeated attempts to contact the drone operators and tell them to move their aircraft failed, said fire officials. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), which is responsible for regulating all airspace, was also unable to make contact. As a result, the helicopters were grounded for safety reasons. Without the aerial support, the firefighters on the ground had to work harder to bring the fire under control. The fire eventually spread to cover more than 1,000 acres. The use of drones is becoming increasingly common, and while they can be a useful tool for taking aerial photographs and videos, they can also pose a serious safety risk to aircraft. In this case, the drones prevented the helicopters from doing their job and put lives at risk. The FAA has strict rules about flying drones in the vicinity of wildfires. These rules are in place to protect the safety of firefighters and other aircraft. If you are planning to fly a drone near a wildfire, please be sure to check the FAA's website for the latest regulations. In addition to the safety risks, flying drones near wildfires can also interfere with firefighting efforts. The drones can create a distraction for pilots and can also damage equipment. If you see a drone flying near a wildfire, please report it to the authorities immediately. The FAA is working to develop new technologies that will make it easier to identify and track drones. The agency is also working to educate the public about the dangers of flying drones near wildfires. In the meantime, it is important to be aware of the risks and to follow the FAA's regulations.

title: Bird family tree shaken by discovery of feathered fossil
text: By Helen Briggs BBC News The turacos, or banana-eaters, are today found only in Africa, living in forests and savannah. They are brightly coloured birds with distinctive red flight feathers and green or blue bodies. A beautifully preserved fossil bird from 52 million years ago is shaking up the family tree of turacos and other highly charismatic and colourful birds including parrots, the businesslike hoatzins, and the ground-dwelling curassows. The newly discovered species, named Primobucco jaguaribensis, not only belongs to the turaco family, but is also a direct ancestor of all parrots and their relatives. The fossil, found in Brazil, suggests that the ancestor of today's turacos and the ancestor of parrots were one and the same. Dr Borja Figueirido, lead author on the paper in Nature, from the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, told BBC News: "We were expecting to find the fossil of a parrot or a hoatzin relative because that's what we have in the Palaeocene in Brazil. But it looked more like a turaco." The fossil bird was the size of a pigeon, with a long tail, short wings and remarkably long toes. When the team "dissected" its foot bones to see which muscles attached where, they found that it walked like a turaco, too. "This bird pretty much had the same foot morphology as modern turacos. This is quite astonishing," Dr Figueirido said. It was not an easy fossil to study. The specimen is squashed flat, so its skull is difficult to see. Its back was also missing, having fallen off the slab. DNA from the fossil itself could not be recovered. So, the team compared its DNA sequence with that of all living turacos, parrots and hoatzins to place it on their family tree. The researchers found that the DNA of the fossil was a mix of turaco and parrot, proving that the fossil was a missing link between the two families. "We were surprised to find that the fossil was not only a turaco but also the direct ancestor of all parrots and their relatives," Dr Figueirido said. "It shows that the diversification of parrots and other colourful birds occurred much earlier than we previously thought." Many scientists had thought that parrots evolved in Australia, because of the high diversity of species found there today. But the new fossil find in Brazil adds weight to the idea that the turaco/parrot ancestor originated in South America and then spread to other continents, possibly flying across the Atlantic Ocean. The fossil bird Protoavis, from about 66 million years ago, is often considered to be the ancestor of all modern birds. It also had long legs and a long tail, not unlike Primobucco jaguaribensis. "Having two fossils that are so old and show long legs and long tails suggests that this might be a plesiomorphic character - a primitive characteristic that's inherited from the last common ancestor of all modern birds," Dr Figueirido said. "If this is true, then the short-legged, short-tailed birds like chickens, ducks and eagles evolved from long-legged, long-tailed ancestors."

title: Liposuction rise linked to gym wear trend
text: Rajiv Grover, from the British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons, says latest UK data shows procedures have gone up 12% in a year, from 44,000 to 49,000. The increase has been linked to the "athleisure" fashion trend, which has seen gym wear become more popular as everyday clothing. This trend has made it more acceptable to show off the body, which in turn has led to increased demand for cosmetic procedures such as liposuction. Grover says: "There's no doubt that the athleisure trend has had a significant impact on the popularity of liposuction. In the past, people were more likely to cover up their bodies, but now they're more comfortable showing them off. This has led to a greater desire to have a body that looks toned and athletic." However, Grover warns that liposuction is not a quick fix for weight loss. "Liposuction is a surgical procedure that removes fat from specific areas of the body. It's not a weight-loss solution, and it's not a substitute for a healthy diet and exercise," he says. "If you're considering liposuction, it's important to do your research and find a reputable surgeon who can help you achieve your desired results." Dr. David Jack, a consultant plastic surgeon at the London Clinic, agrees that the athleisure trend has played a role in the rise of liposuction. He says: "I've definitely seen an increase in the number of patients coming to me for liposuction in recent years. I think this is partly due to the fact that people are more likely to wear gym clothes outside of the gym, which has made them more comfortable with the idea of showing off their bodies." However, Jack also stresses that liposuction is not a magic bullet. "It's important to have realistic expectations about what liposuction can achieve. It can't give you a perfect body, and it's not a substitute for a healthy lifestyle," he says. "If you're considering liposuction, it's important to do your research and find a reputable surgeon who can help you achieve your desired results. You should also be aware of the risks and complications associated with the procedure."

title: City sanguine on snap election call
text: Simon Jack Business editor The pound has gained 1% and although the stock market is down more than 2%, a lot of that happened before Theresa May called a snap election for 8 June. Still, market watchers are taking a keen interest in the moves because markets are likely to reward the greatest certainty. Currency traders, for example, like to know what sort of government will be in power, what economic direction it will travel in and what sort of trade deals it will seek. The pound has been particularly sensitive to Brexit, a vote to leave the EU, as many investors think a departure will shrink the economy and damage the country's international standing. Sterling fell more than 10% after the Brexit vote and has been fluctuating ever since. It is trading at $1.29, having risen from a low of $1.21 after the Brexit vote. The FTSE 100, the main index of blue-chip shares in London, has drifted in recent months, and has been dragged lower by weaker commodity prices, which have hit mining and oil stocks particularly hard. The FTSE 100 is trading at 7,350, having risen from a low of 6,850 after the Brexit vote. Investors like Jeremy Grantham, co-founder of fund manager GMO, are expecting the stock market to continue to fall. Last week, he said that the US stock market, and the FTSE 100, were "very dubiously placed". He warned that central banks will need to raise interest rates in the next few years, which will take the wind out of the sails of the recovery in the stock market. He said: "I don't think a recession is imminent, but I do think it is close." However, most economists expect the UK economy to continue to grow this year, although at a slower pace than in recent years. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) forecasts growth of 1.7% in the UK this year and 1.4% in 2018, compared with 2.2% in 2016. The markets expect a Conservative win because it is seen as the most stable outcome. The Conservatives are ahead in the polls and are likely to win the most seats. However, the pound and the stock market could still fall if the Conservatives fail to win a majority and have to form a coalition government with another party, such as the Liberal Democrats or the Scottish National Party. A hung parliament could also lead to a second referendum on Brexit, which would create further uncertainty and could damage the economy.

title: Foals: Oxford band go from squat parties to Albert Hall
text: By Greg Cochrane Newsbeat music reporter "There were two things we didn't want to do," recalls frontman Yannis Philappakis. "One was not do a record which was exactly like [2008's] Antidotes. The other was not to do one which was exactly the opposite. "We knew our sound had to evolve but we also didn't want to alienate the fans we had gained with Antidotes." Mission accomplished. Released in October 2010, Total Life Forever was a more polished, poppy and experimental affair than its predecessor, but it retained enough of Foals' raw energy and math-rock nous to please their existing fans. Total Life Forever debuted at number eight in the UK charts, and the band spent the next 18 months touring it relentlessly. By the time they got back from their final American date in October 2011, they had a dilemma. "We needed time off," says Philappakis. "We were totally burned out." So they took a break and went their separate ways. Philappakis went to study in Los Angeles, keyboardist Edwin Congreave moved to London, drummer Jack Bevan travelled Europe and guitarist Jimmy Smith stayed in Oxford. "I think it was really healthy for us," says Philappakis. "We'd been going non-stop for so long. We all needed a bit of space to do our own thing." A year later, they reconvened in Oxford to start work on their third album. "We went into it with a very different frame of mind," says Philappakis. "We weren't trying to write the next Antidotes or the next Total Life Forever. We just wanted to make a record that reflected where we were at that point in time." The result was Holy Fire, released in November 2013. It was a more mature and introspective record than its predecessors, but it still had plenty of the energy and excitement that had made Foals one of the most exciting bands in British rock. Holy Fire debuted at number two in the UK charts and was nominated for the Mercury Music Prize. The band toured it extensively throughout 2014, including a sold-out show at London's Alexandra Palace. In 2015, Foals released their fourth album, What Went Down. It was their most experimental and ambitious record to date, and it divided opinion among critics. Some praised it as a bold and innovative work, while others accused the band of losing their way. Despite the mixed reviews, What Went Down debuted at number one in the UK charts and was nominated for the Mercury Music Prize. The band toured it extensively throughout 2016, including a headline slot at the Reading and Leeds Festivals. In 2017, Foals released their fifth album, Everything Not Saved Will Be Lost - Part 1. It was a more experimental affair than its predecessor, and it incorporated elements of electronica and R&B. The album was met with critical acclaim, and it debuted at number two in the UK charts.
