title: Newtownabbey murder: police investigate drugs links
text: Police in Northern Ireland are investigating whether a murder in Newtownabbey on Tuesday evening was linked to drugs. The victim, named locally as Gary Coleman, 42, was shot several times outside his home in the Rathcoole area at around 7pm. Detective Chief Inspector John Caldwell said: "We are treating this as a murder investigation and our inquiries are ongoing. "We believe that the victim was known to his attacker and that this was not a random attack." Caldwell said police were "keeping an open mind" about the motive for the killing but that one line of inquiry was whether it was linked to drugs. "We are aware that Mr Coleman had previous convictions for drug offences and we are investigating whether this was a factor in his murder," he said. "We would appeal to anyone who has any information about this murder to contact us." The murder has shocked the local community, with many people expressing their condolences to Coleman's family. One resident, who did not want to be named, said: "This is a terrible tragedy. Gary was a well-known character in the area and he will be sadly missed." Another resident said: "This is a quiet area and we are all very shocked by what has happened. We just hope that the police catch the person responsible and bring him to justice." The murder is the latest in a series of violent incidents in the Newtownabbey area in recent months. In July, a man was shot in the leg in a paramilitary-style attack in the Rathcoole area. And in June, a man was stabbed to death in the nearby Monkstown area. Police have said they are concerned about the recent upsurge in violence and are working to identify the perpetrators and bring them to justice. Anyone with information about the murder of Gary Coleman is asked to contact the police on 101, quoting reference number 1342 of 23/08/22.

title: Doctors 'miss' underweight children, UCL study suggests
text: Doctors 'miss' underweight children, UCL study suggests Children who are underweight are being "missed" by doctors, a new study suggests. The research, published in the journal Pediatrics, found that nearly half of underweight children in the UK are not identified by their GP. This is despite the fact that underweight children are at increased risk of health problems, including stunted growth, delayed development, and weakened immune systems. The study, led by researchers at University College London (UCL), analyzed data from over 3,000 children aged 0-19 in the UK. They found that 5.4% of children were underweight, defined as having a body mass index (BMI) below the 5th percentile. However, only 27.6% of underweight children had been identified by their GP. This means that nearly half of underweight children are not receiving the care and support they need to improve their health. The researchers say that there are a number of reasons why doctors may miss underweight children. One reason is that underweight children may not be noticeably thin. Another reason is that doctors may not be routinely measuring children's weight and height. The researchers say that it is important for doctors to be aware of the signs and symptoms of underweight children. They also say that doctors should routinely measure children's weight and height. This will help to ensure that underweight children are identified and receive the care they need. The study also found that underweight children were more likely to be from disadvantaged backgrounds. This suggests that poverty may be a risk factor for underweight. The researchers say that further research is needed to explore the link between poverty and underweight. They also say that interventions are needed to improve the health of underweight children. These interventions could include providing financial support to families, improving access to healthy food, and increasing awareness of the importance of healthy eating.

title: UK banks 'prepared for Brexit and trade war fall-out'
text: UK banks 'prepared for Brexit and trade war fall-out' British banks are well-prepared to withstand the potential economic fallout from Brexit and a global trade war, according to a new report. The analysis by consultancy firm EY found that UK lenders have increased their capital buffers and reduced their exposure to risky assets in recent years. This has made them more resilient to financial shocks. The report also found that UK banks have been diversifying their sources of funding, making them less reliant on wholesale markets. This means that they are less likely to be affected by a downturn in the global economy. "UK banks have taken a number of steps to prepare for the potential impact of Brexit and a trade war," said EY's banking and capital markets leader, Omar Ali. "These measures have made them more resilient to financial shocks and better able to support the UK economy." The report comes as the UK prepares to leave the European Union on 29 March 2019. There is uncertainty about the terms of the UK's exit from the EU, and some businesses are concerned about the potential impact on the UK economy. However, the EY report suggests that UK banks are well-prepared for any potential economic shocks. The report found that UK banks have increased their capital buffers by 25% since 2014. This means that they have more money available to absorb losses in the event of a downturn. UK banks have also reduced their exposure to risky assets. The report found that the proportion of risky assets on UK banks' balance sheets has fallen from 30% to 20% since 2014. This means that UK banks are less likely to be affected by a fall in asset prices. In addition, UK banks have been diversifying their sources of funding. The report found that the proportion of wholesale funding on UK banks' balance sheets has fallen from 60% to 40% since 2014. This means that UK banks are less reliant on short-term funding, which can be more expensive and less stable. The EY report suggests that UK banks are well-prepared for any potential economic shocks. The report found that UK banks have increased their capital buffers, reduced their exposure to risky assets, and diversified their sources of funding. These measures have made them more resilient to financial shocks and better able to support the UK economy.

title: Flinstshire man awarded £3,750 after care package stopped
text: A Flintshire man has been awarded £3,750 after his care package was stopped without warning. The 65-year-old, who wishes to remain anonymous, was receiving a care package from Flintshire County Council which included help with washing, dressing, and cooking. However, in January 2023, the council stopped the care package without giving him any notice. The man was left struggling to cope and had to rely on help from friends and family. He complained to the council and the Local Government Ombudsman, who found that the council had failed to properly assess his needs before stopping his care package. The ombudsman ordered the council to pay the man £3,750 in compensation and to reinstate his care package. The man said he was "relieved" that the ombudsman had found in his favor. "I was really struggling to cope without my care package," he said. "I'm glad that the council has been ordered to pay me compensation and to reinstate my care package." A spokesperson for Flintshire County Council said: "We are sorry that Mr X's care package was stopped without proper notice. "We have now reinstated his care package and have paid him £3,750 in compensation. "We have also reviewed our procedures to ensure that this does not happen again." The Local Government Ombudsman said that the council had failed to follow its own policies and procedures when it stopped the man's care package. The ombudsman said: "The council should have carried out a proper assessment of Mr X's needs before stopping his care package. "The council also failed to give Mr X any notice that his care package was going to be stopped. "This caused Mr X a great deal of distress and inconvenience." The ombudsman ordered the council to pay the man £3,750 in compensation and to reinstate his care package. The council has now reinstated the man's care package and has paid him £3,750 in compensation.

title: Doctors said Herefordshire woman's bowel cancer was piles
text: A Herefordshire woman is urging people not to ignore symptoms of bowel cancer after doctors initially mistook hers for piles. Jackie Trow, from Ledbury, was diagnosed with stage three bowel cancer in February 2023, having initially gone to her GP in September 2022 with bleeding and changes to her bowel habits. However, she was told she had piles and was given cream. "I just thought, 'Oh well, I've got piles, I'll just crack on'," she said. But her symptoms did not improve and she returned to the GP in December 2022, when she was referred for further tests. These tests revealed a tumor in her bowel and she was diagnosed with cancer. Trow, 59, underwent surgery to remove the tumor in January 2023 and is now undergoing chemotherapy. She said she was "shocked" to be diagnosed with cancer and said she had no idea she was at risk. "I'm quite fit and healthy, I don't smoke, I don't drink, I eat healthily," she said. "I had no idea I was at risk of bowel cancer." Trow is now urging people not to ignore symptoms of bowel cancer and to seek medical advice as soon as possible. "If you have any changes in your bowel habits, or any bleeding, don't just ignore it," she said. "Go to your GP and get checked out. It could save your life." Dr. Matt Watkinson, a GP at Ledbury Medical Practice, said it is important to be aware of the symptoms of bowel cancer and to seek medical advice if you have any concerns. "Bowel cancer is the fourth most common cancer in the UK and it's important to be aware of the symptoms," he said. "These symptoms can include bleeding from the back passage, changes in bowel habits, abdominal pain, and unexplained weight loss. "If you have any of these symptoms, it's important to see your GP as soon as possible. Early diagnosis and treatment can improve your chances of survival."

title: Unhealthy food 'returning to school' warn caterers
text: Unhealthy Food 'Returning to School' Warn Caterers School caterers have raised concerns that unhealthy food is making a comeback in schools, undermining efforts to promote healthy eating habits among children. The warning comes as new research suggests that the proportion of schools offering unhealthy food options has increased in recent years. A survey conducted by the School Food Trust found that 43% of schools now offer sugary drinks, compared to 12% in 2013. The survey also revealed that 25% of schools offer crisps, and 42% offer chocolate bars. These findings contradict government guidelines, which recommend that schools should provide healthy and nutritious food options for their pupils. The catering industry has attributed the increase in unhealthy food offerings to a number of factors, including budget constraints and parental pressure. Some caterers argue that they are forced to sell unhealthy food to make ends meet, while others claim that parents demand access to such products. However, public health experts argue that schools have a responsibility to protect the health of their pupils. They emphasize that unhealthy food can contribute to a range of health problems, including obesity, tooth decay, and heart disease. "Schools should be places where children can learn about and access healthy food," said Dr. Susan Jebb, a nutrition and public health expert at the University of Oxford. "Offering unhealthy options undermines these efforts and sends the wrong message to children." The return of unhealthy food to schools has prompted calls for stricter regulations. Some experts are proposing a ban on the sale of sugary drinks and junk food in schools, while others believe that schools should be given more resources to provide healthier options. The government has stated that it is committed to improving the health of children and will explore a range of options to reduce the availability of unhealthy food in schools. In the meantime, caterers and parents are urged to work together to ensure that children have access to healthy and nutritious food. "It's important that we all play our part in creating a healthy school environment," said Barbara Crowther, chief executive of the School Food Trust. "Schools, caterers, and parents all have a role to fulfill."

title: Covid: UK must prepare for 'hard winter' of flu - expert
text: The UK must prepare itself for a "hard winter" of flu, with Covid-19 continuing to circulate, an expert has warned. Professor Peter Openshaw, a member of the New and Emerging Respiratory Virus Threats Advisory Group (Nervtag), said there was "no room for complacency". He said the UK's flu vaccine programme was one of the best in the world, but it was "not perfect". The NHS is urging people to get their flu jab as soon as possible to protect themselves from the virus. Eligible people in England can book their jab online or by calling 119. Prof Openshaw told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "I think we need to be thinking about the winter ahead as being a potentially difficult winter, because we've got flu coming back and we've still got Covid circulating. "I think flu could be quite severe this year. We haven't had much flu for the last couple of years because of all the other measures that we've had in place to try and control Covid. "But flu is still out there and it's likely to come back quite strongly this year." He said it was important to remember that flu can be a "very nasty disease" and can lead to hospitalisation and even death. "I would urge everybody to take up the offer of flu vaccination. It's the best way to protect yourself and your loved ones," he said. Dr Susan Hopkins, chief medical adviser at the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA), said the flu jab was "the best way to protect yourself and your loved ones". She said: "The flu vaccine is safe and effective. It's the best way to protect yourself and your loved ones from the virus. "I urge everyone who is eligible to get their flu jab as soon as possible." The flu vaccine is offered free to people at risk, including those aged 65 and over, pregnant women, and people with certain health conditions. The NHS is also offering a free Covid-19 booster jab to people aged 50 and over, and those with certain health conditions. People can book their Covid-19 booster jab online or by calling 119.

title: High heels row: Petition for work dress code law rejected
text: A petition calling for a law against mandatory high-heel dress codes in the workplace has been rejected by the UK government, despite receiving over 150,000 signatures. The petition, started by Nicola Thorp in 2016 after she was sent home from work for refusing to wear high heels, argued that such dress codes were discriminatory and caused physical pain. In its response, the government said that existing laws already provided sufficient protection against discrimination and that it did not believe a specific law on high heels was necessary. It also pointed out that employers were free to set their own dress codes, as long as they were applied fairly and did not discriminate against any particular group of employees. Thorp, who launched a campaign called "Time's Up on Heels" after her experience, said she was "deeply disappointed" by the government's decision. She argued that the existing laws on discrimination were not strong enough to protect women from being forced to wear high heels, and that a specific law was needed to make it clear that such dress codes were unacceptable. "This is a missed opportunity to send a clear message that women should not be discriminated against because of their choice of footwear," Thorp said. "It is time for the government to take action and ensure that women are not forced to choose between their dignity and their livelihood." The government's decision has also been criticized by trade unions and women's rights groups. The Trades Union Congress (TUC) said that the government was "out of touch" with the experiences of women in the workplace, while the Fawcett Society said that the decision was "a blow to women's equality." The issue of high-heel dress codes has been debated for many years, with some arguing that they are a form of sexism and discrimination, while others contend that they are a legitimate part of a professional dress code. A number of countries, including Canada and Australia, have already banned mandatory high-heel dress codes, while others, such as the UK and the US, are still considering the issue. In the UK, the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) has said that it is unlawful for employers to discriminate against employees on the basis of their sex, which could include forcing them to wear high heels. However, the EHRC has also said that employers are able to set dress codes, as long as they are applied fairly and do not discriminate against any particular group of employees.

title: Derek Bonnard: Cleveland officer 'branded criminal'
text: Derek Bonnard was a Cleveland police officer who was branded a criminal after he was convicted of stealing $200,000 from a drug dealer. Bonnard was a 12-year veteran of the force when he was arrested in 2012. He was accused of stealing the money during a drug raid. Bonnard claimed that he had found the money and that he had intended to turn it over to his superiors. However, prosecutors said that Bonnard had lied about finding the money and that he had actually stolen it. Bonnard was convicted of theft in 2013 and sentenced to three years in prison. He was also fired from the police force. Bonnard's conviction was a major embarrassment for the Cleveland Police Department. The department had been under fire for years for its use of excessive force and for its lack of accountability. Bonnard's conviction only served to further erode public trust in the department. In the years since his conviction, Bonnard has been trying to rebuild his life. He has started a new career as a truck driver and he is also working to get his criminal record expunged. Bonnard says that he is ashamed of what he did and that he regrets the pain that he caused his family and friends. He says that he is determined to make amends for his past mistakes and to become a productive member of society. Bonnard's story is a cautionary tale about the dangers of corruption. It is a reminder that even those who are entrusted with upholding the law can be tempted to break it. Bonnard's story is also a story of redemption. It is a reminder that even those who have made serious mistakes can turn their lives around.

title: South Korea warns North against satellite launch
text: South Korea warns North against satellite launch South Korea has warned North Korea against launching a satellite, saying it would be a violation of UN Security Council resolutions. The North has said it plans to launch a satellite between February 8 and 25, but the US and its allies believe it is a cover for a test of long-range missile technology. South Korea's foreign ministry spokesman Cho June-hyuck said on Tuesday that any launch would be "a clear violation" of the resolutions. "We strongly urge North Korea to refrain from taking any actions that could escalate tensions on the Korean Peninsula," he said. The US has also warned North Korea against the launch, saying it would be "a provocative act" that would violate UN Security Council resolutions. The UN Security Council has banned North Korea from conducting any ballistic missile or nuclear tests. North Korea has defended its plans to launch the satellite, saying it is for peaceful purposes. However, experts believe that the launch could be used to test technology that could be used to develop intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs). ICBMs are capable of carrying nuclear warheads and reaching targets thousands of miles away. The launch would be the North's first since it fired an intercontinental ballistic missile in November 2017. That launch was widely condemned by the international community, and the UN Security Council imposed new sanctions on North Korea in response. The US has also sent a number of warships to the region in a show of force. The launch would come at a time of heightened tensions between the US and North Korea. The two sides have been engaged in a war of words over North Korea's nuclear and missile programs. The US has also imposed a number of sanctions on North Korea in an effort to pressure the country to give up its nuclear weapons. title: Coronavirus: Vodafone and TalkTalk report surge in internet use
text: Vodafone and TalkTalk Report Surge in Internet Use Amidst Coronavirus Pandemic The ongoing coronavirus pandemic has led to a dramatic increase in internet usage as people work from home, study remotely, and engage in online entertainment. Leading telecommunications providers Vodafone and TalkTalk have reported a significant surge in internet traffic since the outbreak began. Vodafone, one of the world's largest mobile and broadband providers, said it has seen a 40% increase in mobile data usage and a 50% increase in fixed broadband traffic in the UK since the government implemented lockdown measures. The company also reported a 60% rise in video call traffic on its mobile network. TalkTalk, another major UK provider, echoed similar trends. The company said it has seen a 35% increase in broadband usage during peak hours, with average broadband traffic rising by 15%. It also reported a 100% increase in voice calls to its customer service team. The surge in internet use is largely attributed to the widespread adoption of remote working and virtual learning. With schools and offices closed, millions of people are relying on the internet to connect with colleagues, classmates, and loved ones. Online entertainment platforms have also seen a significant boost. Streaming services such as Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, and Disney+ have reported record-high viewership numbers. Social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram have also seen increased activity as people stay connected and share information. The increased internet traffic has put a strain on networks, but both Vodafone and TalkTalk have assured customers that they have sufficient capacity to meet the demand. Vodafone said it has invested heavily in its infrastructure in recent years, while TalkTalk has implemented a series of measures to optimise its network performance. However, the surge in usage has highlighted the importance of reliable and affordable broadband access for everyone. The government has pledged to invest in digital infrastructure to ensure that all citizens have access to high-speed internet, regardless of their location or income. As the pandemic continues, internet usage is expected to remain high. Both Vodafone and TalkTalk have said they are monitoring the situation closely and will continue to invest in their networks to meet the needs of their customers.

title: Coronavirus in South Africa: Misuse of Covid-19 funds 'frightening'
text: Coronavirus in South Africa: Misuse of Covid-19 Funds 'Frightening' A shocking report has revealed the widespread misuse of Covid-19 relief funds in South Africa, raising concerns about the erosion of public trust and the impact on the country's recovery efforts. The Special Investigating Unit (SIU), tasked with probing corruption allegations, found that billions of rand allocated to fight the pandemic were siphoned off through irregular tenders, inflated prices, and fraudulent claims. "The extent of the looting is frightening," said SIU head Andy Mothibi. "We have unearthed evidence of blatant disregard for proper procurement processes and gross overpricing, resulting in millions of rand being lost to corruption." One of the most egregious cases involved the procurement of personal protective equipment (PPE) at inflated prices. The SIU found that certain companies charged up to 500% more than the market rate for gloves, masks, and sanitizers. In another instance, a company was awarded a contract to supply food parcels to vulnerable households, but the parcels contained expired and rotten food. The misuse of funds has had a devastating impact on South Africa's response to the pandemic. Hospitals have been left short of essential supplies, while vulnerable communities have been denied critical aid. "This corruption has undermined the public's trust in government and eroded the credibility of our institutions," said Finance Minister Tito Mboweni. "We must take decisive action to recover these funds and hold those responsible accountable." President Cyril Ramaphosa has vowed to crack down on corruption and ensure that the stolen funds are returned. The SIU has already filed criminal charges against several individuals and companies, and further arrests are expected. However, experts warn that recovering the funds and restoring public trust will be a long and challenging process. "This is not just about money; it's about the integrity of our society," said independent anti-corruption activist Thuli Madonsela. "We must ensure that those who looted these funds are brought to justice and that we put in place strong mechanisms to prevent such abuses in the future." The misuse of Covid-19 funds has cast a dark shadow over South Africa's fight against the pandemic. The government must act decisively to address this crisis, rebuild trust, and ensure that every rand intended for fighting Covid-19 is used for its intended purpose.

title: Child's cerebral palsy book to help others understand her life
text: In the tapestry of life, every thread holds a unique story—a story that deserves to be shared. For nine-year-old Poppy Curl-Davies, her thread is woven with the challenges of cerebral palsy. Undeterred by the limitations imposed by her condition, Poppy has embarked on a remarkable journey to help others understand the complexities of her world. Through the pages of her self-penned book, "My Life with Cerebral Palsy," Poppy paints a vivid portrait of her daily experiences, from the joys of laughter to the frustrations of everyday tasks. Her words are an intimate glimpse into the mind of a child who sees the world from a different perspective. "My feet are like little boats that don't like to row," Poppy writes, describing her struggles with mobility. Yet, amidst the challenges, her spirit shines through, as she finds joy in the smallest of things. "I love to dance!" she proclaims, her words accompanied by a twirl of her wheelchair. "I can't move my legs like other people, but I can wiggle my hips and shake my shoulders." Poppy's book is more than just a personal narrative; it is a bridge between different worlds. It provides a window into the unique experiences of a child with cerebral palsy, breaking down barriers and fostering understanding. "I wanted to write this book," Poppy says, "so that other people can understand what it's like to live with cerebral palsy. I want them to know that I'm just like any other kid—I love to play, I love to learn, and I have dreams for the future." Poppy's journey is a testament to the transformative power of storytelling. Through her writing, she is not only sharing her own experiences but also empowering others to embrace their differences and celebrate the beauty of diversity. In a world where inclusion is often aspired to but rarely achieved, Poppy's book serves as a beacon of hope. It reminds us that every voice deserves to be heard and that every child, regardless of their abilities, has the potential to make a difference. Poppy's words are a clarion call for empathy, a reminder that true understanding can only come from listening to the stories of those who have lived them. Through her book, she invites us to embrace the richness of diversity and to create a society where every child feels valued, respected, and included.

title: Afghanistan war: Deadly Taliban attack 'destroys' hospital
text: Deadly Taliban Attack 'Destroys' Hospital in Afghanistan, Killing Dozens A brutal Taliban attack in Afghanistan has claimed dozens of lives and destroyed a provincial hospital, leaving the local community in shock and mourning. The assault targeted the hospital in the eastern province of Paktika, which was providing critical healthcare services to the war-torn region. According to health officials, at least 30 people, including women and children, were killed in the attack. Witnesses described scenes of chaos as the Taliban stormed the hospital, firing indiscriminately and setting it ablaze. "I heard a loud explosion, and then there was gunfire everywhere," said one survivor. "I saw people screaming and running for their lives." The attack comes amid escalating violence in Afghanistan, as the Taliban continues to make gains in the wake of the withdrawal of US and NATO forces. The militant group has been accused of committing numerous atrocities, including targeted killings of civilians. The United Nations condemned the attack on the hospital as a "war crime" and called for an immediate investigation. "The deliberate targeting of medical facilities is a violation of international humanitarian law," said a UN spokesperson. The destruction of the hospital is a devastating loss for the community, which relied on it for essential medical care. Health workers were said to be in a state of shock and disbelief, while patients and their families faced an uncertain future. "We have lost everything," said one doctor. "This was the only hospital in the area, and now it's gone. Our patients are suffering, and we have no way to help them." The attack has drawn widespread condemnation from the international community, with governments and aid agencies expressing their outrage and calling for accountability. The United States and the European Union have vowed to support the Afghan people and hold the Taliban accountable for their actions. However, the grim reality is that Afghanistan remains a country in turmoil, torn apart by decades of war and political instability. The Taliban's resurgence has plunged the country into a new era of uncertainty, with civilians bearing the brunt of the violence. The attack on the hospital in Paktika is a tragic reminder of the human cost of war and the urgent need for peace and reconciliation in Afghanistan.

title: Five Sisters Zoo fire: Glazier offers to help rebuild reptile house
text: A glazier has offered to help rebuild a reptile house at Five Sisters Zoo after it was destroyed in a fire. The blaze, which broke out on Sunday evening, killed dozens of animals, including snakes, lizards, and tortoises. Paul Kelly, who runs a glazing company in nearby West Calder, said he was "heartbroken" to hear about the fire. The zoo has launched an appeal to raise funds for the rebuilding of the reptile house. So far, over £100,000 has been raised, but the zoo says it will need much more to complete the project. title: BBC forgotten list 'sets precedent'
text: The BBC's decision to start publishing a list of "forgotten" programs has been hailed as a "positive step" by industry experts, who say it sets a precedent for other broadcasters to follow. The list, which was first published in March 2023, includes more than 1,000 programs that have been lost or destroyed over the years. It is the result of a collaboration between the BBC and the British Film Institute (BFI), and it is hoped that it will help to raise awareness of the importance of preserving our broadcasting heritage. The BBC's forgotten list includes a wide range of programs, from early documentaries and dramas to popular comedies and music shows. Some of the most notable titles on the list include: The Lost World (1951): A six-part serial starring Richard Attenborough and Vivien Leigh. The Quatermass Experiment (1953): A four-part serial starring Reginald Tate and John Robinson. Hancock's Half Hour (1954-1959): A popular comedy series starring Tony Hancock. The Avengers (1961-1969): A spy series starring Patrick Macnee and Diana Rigg. Monty Python's Flying Circus (1969-1974): A groundbreaking comedy series starring Graham Chapman, John Cleese, Terry Gilliam, Eric Idle, Terry Jones, and Michael Palin. The BBC's decision to publish the forgotten list has been welcomed by industry experts, who say it is a positive step towards preserving our broadcasting heritage. "This is a really important initiative," said Andrew Ryan, director of the BFI. "The BBC has a vast and valuable archive, and it is essential that we do everything we can to preserve it for future generations." "The forgotten list is a valuable resource for researchers and historians," said Dr. Matthew Sweet, a lecturer in film and television studies at Birkbeck, University of London. "It will help to raise awareness of the importance of preserving our broadcasting heritage, and it will also help to identify programs that may have been lost or destroyed." The BBC's forgotten list is a reminder of the fragility of our broadcasting heritage. It is essential that we do everything we can to preserve our cherished programs for future generations.

title: Obama London visit: Drones to be banned in the capital
text: Drones to be banned in the capital during Obama visit The use of drones will be banned in the capital during US President Barack Obama's visit to London next week, it has been announced. The Metropolitan Police said the ban was being imposed for "security reasons" and would be in place from 00:01 BST on Monday 23 April to 23:59 BST on Tuesday 24 April. The ban will apply to all drones, regardless of size or weight. Anyone caught flying a drone during the ban period could face prosecution. The Met said the ban was necessary to ensure the safety and security of the President and the public. "We are aware that drones are becoming increasingly popular, but their use in the capital during the President's visit could pose a significant security risk," a Met spokesman said. "We are therefore imposing a temporary ban on the use of drones in the capital during this time. We appreciate the cooperation of the public in this matter." The ban will be enforced by the Met's Counter Terrorism Command. Officers will be patrolling the capital and will be able to seize any drones that are being flown illegally. The ban is likely to cause disruption to some businesses and individuals who use drones for commercial or recreational purposes. However, the Met said the safety of the President and the public was paramount. "We understand that this ban may cause inconvenience to some people, but we believe it is necessary to ensure the safety of the President and the public," the spokesman said. "We would advise anyone who is planning to fly a drone in the capital during the ban period to reconsider their plans." The ban is the latest in a series of security measures that have been put in place for the President's visit. Other measures include road closures, increased police patrols and the deployment of armed officers. The President is due to arrive in London on Monday 23 April. title: US planning full Afghan pullout, Obama tells Karzai
text: US Planning Full Afghan Pullout, Obama Tells Karzai President Barack Obama has informed Afghan President Hamid Karzai that the US is planning a full withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan by the end of 2016. The move comes after more than 13 years of war in Afghanistan, which has cost the lives of thousands of US soldiers and Afghan civilians. In a phone call on Wednesday, Obama told Karzai that the US would continue to support Afghanistan financially and militarily, but that it was time for the Afghan government to take full responsibility for its own security. "The United States has been proud to stand with the Afghan people as they rebuild their country and chart a path towards self-reliance," Obama said in a statement. "But ultimately, it is up to the Afghan people to determine their own future." Karzai said he was "disappointed" by Obama's decision, but that he respected the US president's decision. "We have come a long way since 2001," Karzai said. "We have defeated the Taliban, established a new constitution, and built a new army and police force. But we still have a long way to go." The US-led invasion of Afghanistan began in 2001, following the September 11th terrorist attacks. The US overthrew the Taliban government, which was harboring al-Qaeda, the terrorist group responsible for the attacks. The US and its allies have been fighting the Taliban and other insurgent groups in Afghanistan ever since. The war has been costly, both in terms of human life and financial resources. The US has spent more than $1 trillion on the war in Afghanistan, and more than 2,400 US soldiers have been killed. Thousands of Afghan civilians have also been killed in the conflict. The US began to withdraw troops from Afghanistan in 2014, and the withdrawal process is scheduled to be completed by the end of 2016. The US will continue to provide financial and military support to Afghanistan after the withdrawal, but it is up to the Afghan government to take full responsibility for its own security. The decision to withdraw all US troops from Afghanistan is a significant development in the war. It is a sign that the US is confident that the Afghan government is capable of defending itself against the Taliban and other insurgent groups. However, the withdrawal of US troops also raises concerns about the future of Afghanistan. The Taliban has been gaining ground in recent months, and it is unclear whether the Afghan government will be able to defeat the insurgents without US support.

title: Labour rules out Royal Mail renationalisation pledge
text: Labour drops pledge to renationalise Royal Mail The Labour Party has dropped its pledge to renationalise Royal Mail, a move that has been met with criticism from some quarters. However, Labour leader Keir Starmer has now said that the party will not be pursuing this policy in the next election. Starmer said that the party had "listened to feedback" from businesses and the public, and that it had decided that renationalisation was not the best way to improve Royal Mail. The decision has been welcomed by business groups, who have argued that renationalisation would have been bad for the economy. However, it has been criticised by trade unions, who say that it will lead to job losses and worse services. The Communication Workers Union (CWU), which represents postal workers, said that it was "deeply disappointed" by Labour's decision. Labour's decision to drop its renationalisation pledge is a significant shift in policy. It remains to be seen whether the party's decision will have any impact on its popularity with voters. title: Dangerous dogs: PM urged not to treat pit bulls as 'collateral damage'
text: Animal welfare groups have urged the Prime Minister not to allow so-called "dangerous dogs" to become "collateral damage" in the government's plan to tackle violent crime. The plea comes as a consultation on proposed changes to the Dangerous Dogs Act 1991 closes on Friday. The government is considering extending the ban to cover more breeds, including the American Bully and Japanese Tosa. But campaigners say there is no evidence that breed-specific legislation is effective in reducing dog attacks. They argue that the focus should be on responsible ownership and education. The RSPCA said: "We urge the government to not allow the perception of certain breeds as 'dangerous' to become an excuse for inflicting severe and unnecessary penalties on these dogs." Dogs Trust called for a "modern, evidence-based approach" to dog control, arguing that "breed-specific legislation is not the answer." The Kennel Club said: "We are concerned that the proposed changes would be ineffective and unfair. We believe that the focus should be on responsible ownership and education, not on banning specific breeds." The British Veterinary Association (BVA) said: "We are concerned that the proposed changes would not be evidence-based and could have unintended consequences." The government has said that it is "committed to taking action to ensure that our communities are safe from dangerous dogs." But animal welfare groups say that the government's proposals are "misguided" and will not achieve the desired outcome. They are calling on the Prime Minister to reconsider the plans and to focus on measures that will genuinely reduce dog attacks, such as responsible ownership and education. The consultation on the proposed changes to the Dangerous Dogs Act 1991 closes on Friday. The government is expected to announce its decision in the coming months.

title: Analysis: What is behind Nissan UK's success?
text: Analysis: What is behind Nissan UK's success? Nissan UK has been a major player in the UK automotive industry for decades, and its success has been built on a number of factors. One of the key factors has been Nissan's commitment to manufacturing in the UK. The company has invested heavily in its Sunderland plant, which is now one of the most advanced car factories in Europe. This investment has allowed Nissan to produce high-quality cars at a competitive cost, which has helped to make them popular with UK consumers. Another factor has been Nissan's focus on innovation. The company has been at the forefront of developing new technologies, such as electric vehicles and autonomous driving. This has helped to keep Nissan ahead of the competition and has made its cars more appealing to consumers. In addition to its manufacturing and innovation strengths, Nissan has also benefited from a strong marketing strategy. The company has invested heavily in advertising and has been able to create a strong brand image. This has helped to make Nissan cars more recognizable and desirable to consumers. Finally, Nissan has been able to benefit from the UK government's support for the automotive industry. The government has provided financial assistance to Nissan in the past, and it has also worked to create a favorable regulatory environment for the company. This has helped to make it easier for Nissan to do business in the UK. As a result of these factors, Nissan UK has become one of the most successful car companies in the country. The company has a strong market share and is profitable. It is also a major employer in the UK, and it has helped to create a thriving automotive industry in the North East of England. However, Nissan UK's success is not guaranteed. The company faces a number of challenges, including Brexit, the rise of electric vehicles, and increased competition from other car manufacturers. In order to remain successful, Nissan will need to continue to invest in its UK operations and to adapt to the changing automotive landscape. One of the biggest challenges facing Nissan UK is Brexit. The UK's exit from the European Union could lead to tariffs on cars exported to the EU, which would make Nissan's cars more expensive. This could hurt sales and lead to job losses. Another challenge is the rise of electric vehicles. Electric vehicles are becoming increasingly popular, and Nissan will need to invest in developing and producing electric cars in order to remain competitive. This is a significant challenge, as electric cars are more expensive to produce than gasoline-powered cars. Finally, Nissan faces increased competition from other car manufacturers. Volkswagen, Toyota, and Hyundai are all major car manufacturers that are competing for market share in the UK. Nissan will need to continue to innovate and offer competitive prices in order to remain successful. Despite these challenges, Nissan UK has a strong foundation on which to build. The company has a strong brand, a loyal customer base, and a commitment to manufacturing in the UK. If Nissan can continue to invest in its UK operations and adapt to the changing automotive landscape, it should be able to remain successful for many years to come.

title: Derby staff and students given climate change anxiety therapy
text: Climate change is a pressing global issue that has far-reaching implications for our planet and its inhabitants. In recent years, there has been growing recognition of the psychological impact of climate change, particularly among young people. A study published in the journal Nature Climate Change found that over half of young people aged 16-25 surveyed in 10 countries reported feeling "very" or "extremely" worried about climate change. This anxiety can manifest in a variety of ways, including feelings of helplessness, hopelessness, and fear. In response to this growing concern, universities and colleges across the UK are starting to offer mental health support specifically tailored to students struggling with climate anxiety. title: Chagos Islanders lose court bid
text: Chagos Islanders Lose Court Bid to Return Home The Chagos Islanders have lost a legal battle to return to their ancestral homeland, which was forcibly evacuated by the British government in the 1960s. The Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that the Islanders do not have a legally enforceable right to return to the Chagos Archipelago, which is now a British Overseas Territory and home to a US military base. The Islanders, who were forcibly removed from their homes in the 1960s to make way for the base, have been fighting for decades to return home. They have argued that the eviction was illegal and that they have a right to compensation. However, the Supreme Court ruled that the British government acted lawfully in evicting the Islanders and that there is no legal basis for their return. The ruling is a blow to the Islanders, who have been hoping to return to their homeland for decades. It is also a setback for human rights activists, who have argued that the eviction of the Islanders was a violation of their rights. The British government has said that it will continue to provide support to the Islanders, but it has ruled out the possibility of their return. Background to the Chagos Archipelago The Chagos Archipelago is a group of islands in the Indian Ocean that was once part of the British colony of Mauritius. In 1965, the British government leased the archipelago to the US for use as a military base. The US military base on Diego Garcia, the largest island in the archipelago, is a key strategic asset for the US. It is used for surveillance, communications, and other military operations. The Chagos Islanders were forcibly removed from their homes in the 1960s to make way for the base. The British government has admitted that the eviction was wrong and has apologized for the suffering it caused. However, the British government has refused to allow the Islanders to return home, arguing that it would be too costly and disruptive. Reaction to the Supreme Court Ruling The Supreme Court ruling has been met with disappointment by the Chagos Islanders and their supporters. Olivier Bancoult, the leader of the Chagossians Welfare Association, said that the ruling was "a travesty of justice." "We have been fighting for our right to return home for decades, and now the Supreme Court has told us that we have no right at all," he said. Human rights activists have also criticized the ruling, arguing that it sets a dangerous precedent for the forced eviction of indigenous peoples. "This ruling is a setback for human rights around the world," said Amnesty International UK. "It sends a message that governments can forcibly evict indigenous peoples from their homes with impunity." The British government has welcomed the Supreme Court ruling, saying that it provides "legal certainty" on the issue of the Chagos Islanders. However, the government has also said that it will continue to provide support to the Islanders and that it is committed to finding a "just and fair" solution to their plight.

title: Derrick Murphy reports Norfolk County Council over recorded call
text: Derrick Murphy reports Norfolk County Council over recorded call A former foster carer has reported Norfolk County Council to the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) over a recorded phone call. The ICO is an independent body that regulates the use of personal data in the UK. A spokesperson for the ICO said it could not comment on individual cases. However, it said that it "takes all complaints seriously" and that it would "investigate any evidence of wrongdoing". Norfolk County Council said it had "a duty to record phone calls for quality assurance purposes" and that it was "satisfied" that it had done so lawfully. A spokesperson for the council said: "We have a duty to record phone calls for quality assurance purposes. title: Vietnam accuses China in seas dispute
text: Vietnam has accused China of violating its sovereignty after its survey ship entered disputed waters in the South China Sea. The Chinese vessel, Haiyang Dizhi 8, entered Vietnam's exclusive economic zone (EEZ) on Monday and has been conducting a survey since then, according to Vietnam's foreign ministry. Vietnam's foreign ministry has sent a diplomatic note to China, protesting the incursion and demanding that the vessel leave the area immediately. The incident comes amid heightened tensions between Vietnam and China over the South China Sea. China claims the majority of the sea, while Vietnam, along with Brunei, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Taiwan, also claim parts of it. The South China Sea is a vital waterway for trade and is believed to be rich in oil and gas reserves. In recent years, China has been building artificial islands in the sea and increasing its military presence there, raising concerns among other countries in the region. Vietnam has repeatedly condemned China's actions in the South China Sea and has called on the international community to support its position. In a statement on Tuesday, Vietnam's foreign ministry said that China's survey vessel "has been illegally conducting seismic surveys in Vietnam's exclusive economic zone and continental shelf." "This act constitutes a serious violation of Vietnam's sovereignty and sovereign rights over its maritime zones, as defined by the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea," the statement said. "Vietnam demands that China immediately cease the above-mentioned illegal activities, withdraw the Haiyang Dizhi 8 survey vessel from Vietnam's exclusive economic zone and continental shelf, and respect Vietnam's sovereignty and sovereign rights," the statement added. China has not yet commented on the incident.

title: Nintendo posts larger than expected loss despite Mario Kart
text: Nintendo has announced a larger-than-expected operating loss of 425 billion yen ($3.6 billion) for the fiscal year ended March 2023, despite the strong performance of its popular racing game Mario Kart 8 Deluxe. The loss was driven by a decline in sales of the Nintendo Switch console, which has been on the market for over six years, and a slowdown in demand for its games. Nintendo's net sales for the year fell by 5.6% to 1.6 trillion yen ($13.6 billion), while its operating profit plunged by 62.4% to 249 billion yen ($2.1 billion). The company sold 18.9 million Switch consoles during the fiscal year, down from 23 million in the previous year. Sales of Switch games also declined, with only 172 million units sold, compared to 235 million in the previous year. Despite the overall decline, Mario Kart 8 Deluxe continued to perform well, selling 11.8 million copies during the fiscal year, bringing its total sales to over 52 million units since its launch in 2017. Nintendo attributed the decline in sales to a number of factors, including the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on supply chains and consumer spending, as well as the aging of the Switch console. The company said it is working on new products and services to address the challenges it is facing and is confident in its long-term prospects. Analysts had expected Nintendo to post an operating loss of around 350 billion yen ($3 billion), so the actual loss was larger than anticipated. The loss is the first for Nintendo since the fiscal year ended March 2012, when it reported a loss of 20 billion yen ($170 million). title: USS John S McCain: Navy sacks officers over collision

title: Kevin Bennett killing: Three boys guilty of murder
text: Three boys have been found guilty of murdering Kevin Bennett, 17, in a park in Essex. The defendants, who were 14 and 15 at the time of the killing, admitted manslaughter but denied murder. A jury at Chelmsford Crown Court found them guilty of murder following a five-week trial. The court heard how Kevin was attacked in Colchester's High Woods Country Park on 14 July last year. He suffered multiple stab wounds and died at the scene. The three defendants, who cannot be named for legal reasons, were among a group of six or seven who chased Kevin and his friends. The court heard how the group was armed with knives and a machete. The jury was told that Kevin was stabbed in the back, chest and legs. He also suffered a fractured skull. The prosecution said that the defendants had intended to kill Kevin, while the defence argued that they had only intended to cause him serious harm. In a statement after the verdict, Kevin's family said they were "relieved" that the defendants had been found guilty of murder. They said: "We are relieved that the jury has reached a verdict of guilty. This has been an incredibly difficult time for us all, but we hope that this verdict will bring us some closure." Detective Chief Inspector Martin Pasmore, of the Kent and Essex Serious Crime Directorate, said: "This was a senseless and brutal attack on a young man who had his whole life ahead of him. "The defendants have shown no remorse for their actions and they deserve to spend a long time in prison." The three defendants will be sentenced at a later date. The trial heard how the defendants had been drinking and taking drugs on the day of the killing. They had also been involved in a number of fights in the park in the days leading up to the attack. The jury was told that the defendants had made threats to kill Kevin and his friends. In a statement, the Crown Prosecution Service said: "This was a tragic case in which a young man lost his life in a senseless and brutal attack. "The defendants have shown no remorse for their actions and they deserve to be punished for their crimes."

title: Mitsubishi Motors shares untraded in Japan due to sell orders
text: Mitsubishi Motors Shares Untraded in Japan Due to Sell Orders Shares of Mitsubishi Motors Corp. were halted from trading in Japan on Thursday due to a glut of sell orders, following reports that the automaker may face a fine of up to 1 billion euros ($1.1 billion) from the European Union. The European Commission is investigating allegations that Mitsubishi Motors used software to cheat on emissions tests for its diesel vehicles. The company has admitted to using the software and has already been fined by regulators in Japan and South Korea. The halt in trading came after Mitsubishi Motors' shares fell by more than 15% in early trading on Thursday. The company said it had requested the halt in order to prevent further volatility in its share price. The European Commission is expected to announce its decision on the fine later this month. If the fine is as large as reported, it would be a significant blow to Mitsubishi Motors, which has been struggling to recover from the emissions scandal. The company has already recalled more than 600,000 vehicles worldwide and has suspended sales of its diesel vehicles in Europe. The scandal has also damaged Mitsubishi Motors' reputation and has led to the resignation of its chairman and CEO. The halt in trading is likely to continue until the European Commission announces its decision on the fine. Mitsubishi Motors said it would update the market as soon as it had more information. The emissions scandal has had a significant impact on the Japanese auto industry. Toyota Motor Corp. and Honda Motor Co. have both been fined by regulators for using similar software to cheat on emissions tests. The scandal has also raised questions about the effectiveness of emissions regulations in Japan and Europe. Regulators in both regions are now reviewing their testing procedures and are considering new measures to prevent future cheating. The Mitsubishi Motors scandal is a reminder that the auto industry is facing increasing pressure to reduce emissions. Regulators around the world are cracking down on cheating and are demanding that automakers develop cleaner vehicles. The auto industry is also facing competition from new technologies, such as electric vehicles and autonomous vehicles. Automakers that fail to adapt to these changes may find themselves struggling to compete in the future.

title: Llangattock hydro power plan raises £270,000 in share offer
text: Llangattock Hydro Power Plant Raises £270,000 in Share Offer The Llangattock hydro power plant in the Brecon Beacons has raised £270,000 in a share offer, bringing the total raised to £1.1 million. The water will be diverted through a turbine to generate electricity. The electricity will then be fed into the National Grid. The plant is expected to have a lifespan of over 50 years. title: Labour's Kate Osamor resigns as shadow minister
text: Labour's Kate Osamor resigns as shadow minister amid bullying allegations Kate Osamor, the Labour MP for Edmonton, has resigned as shadow international development minister after she was accused of bullying a member of her staff. The allegations were made in a letter from the staff member to Labour's chief whip, Nick Brown. The letter, which has been seen by the BBC, alleges that Ms Osamor made "repeated and sustained" attempts to undermine and belittle the staff member. Ms Osamor has denied the allegations, but she has said she is standing down from her shadow cabinet role to "clear her name". In a statement, she said: "I am deeply disappointed to have to resign from my position as shadow international development minister. However, I believe that it is the right thing to do in the circumstances. "I want to make it clear that I absolutely deny the allegations that have been made against me. I have always behaved professionally and respectfully towards my staff. "I am confident that I will be able to clear my name and I look forward to returning to my shadow cabinet role as soon as possible." A Labour Party spokesman said: "The Labour Party takes all allegations of bullying very seriously. We are investigating the allegations that have been made against Kate Osamor and we will take appropriate action if necessary." Ms Osamor's resignation comes at a time when Labour is facing a number of allegations of bullying and harassment. In recent weeks, two Labour MPs have been suspended from the party over allegations of sexual harassment. The party has also been criticized for its handling of anti-Semitism complaints. Last week, the former Labour MP Luciana Berger quit the party, saying that she had been subjected to "relentless bullying, harassment and intimidation" by members and supporters of the party. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has said that he is "determined to root out" bullying and harassment from the party. He has also said that he is committed to ensuring that the party is a "safe and inclusive" place for all members. However, critics have accused Mr Corbyn of failing to take the issue of bullying seriously enough. They have also said that the party's complaints process is not fit for purpose. The latest allegations against Ms Osamor are likely to further damage Labour's reputation. The party is already facing calls to hold an independent inquiry into its handling of bullying and harassment complaints.

title: Gene therapy 'treats' Parkinson's disease
text: Gene Therapy Offers New Hope for Parkinson's Patients A groundbreaking gene therapy treatment has shown promising results in treating Parkinson's disease, offering new hope for patients who have long struggled with the debilitating effects of the condition. Parkinson's disease is a progressive neurological disorder that affects movement, balance, and coordination. It is caused by the loss of dopamine-producing cells in the brain, which is responsible for controlling movement. Symptoms of Parkinson's disease include tremor, rigidity, slowness of movement, and difficulty with balance. Traditional treatments for Parkinson's disease focus on managing symptoms and improving quality of life. However, gene therapy offers the potential to address the underlying cause of the disease by repairing or replacing damaged or lost brain cells. In a recent clinical trial, researchers used a gene therapy technique called adeno-associated viral (AAV) vector-mediated gene transfer to deliver a gene encoding for the dopamine transporter (DAT) protein into the striatum, a brain region affected in Parkinson's disease. The DAT protein is responsible for transporting dopamine into neurons, which allows the neurotransmitter to transmit signals between nerve cells. By introducing a functional DAT protein, the researchers hoped to restore dopamine signaling and improve motor function in Parkinson's patients. The results of the clinical trial were encouraging. Patients who received the gene therapy experienced significant improvements in motor function, including reduced tremor, increased mobility, and improved balance. The improvements were sustained for up to 3 years, suggesting a long-term benefit of the treatment. The researchers believe that gene therapy could become a valuable new tool for treating Parkinson's disease. By replacing lost or damaged dopamine-producing cells, the therapy has the potential to not only manage symptoms but also halt or slow down the progression of the disease. Further research is needed to optimize the gene therapy approach and assess its long-term safety and efficacy. However, the early success of this clinical trial provides a beacon of hope for Parkinson's patients and their families, suggesting that a potential cure for this life-changing condition may be within reach.

title: Don't weep for old economic targets
text: In the wake of last week's disappointing GDP figures, there have been calls for a return to the old economic targets of growth, inflation, and unemployment. However, such a move would be a mistake. The old economic targets were based on an outdated understanding of how the economy works. Growth is not the only measure of economic success, and inflation and unemployment are not always the best indicators of economic health. In fact, the old economic targets can sometimes be counterproductive. For example, a focus on growth can lead to unsustainable levels of debt and environmental degradation. A focus on inflation can lead to interest rate hikes that slow down economic growth. And a focus on unemployment can lead to policies that make it harder for people to find jobs. The new economic targets should focus on creating a more sustainable and equitable economy. This means focusing on measures such as: Well-being: This measure takes into account not only economic factors but also social and environmental factors. Job creation: This measure focuses on creating good-paying jobs that provide people with financial security. Wage growth: This measure focuses on increasing wages for all workers, not just those at the top. Productivity: This measure focuses on improving the efficiency of the economy so that we can produce more goods and services with fewer resources. Environmental sustainability: This measure focuses on reducing the economy's impact on the environment. These new economic targets are more in line with the challenges that we face today. They represent a shift away from the old, growth-at-all-costs mentality to a more sustainable and equitable approach to economic development. Of course, achieving these new economic targets will not be easy. It will require a fundamental shift in the way that we think about the economy. But it is a shift that is necessary if we want to create a more sustainable and equitable future for all. In the meantime, we should not weep for the old economic targets. They were based on an outdated understanding of how the economy works, and they are no longer relevant to the challenges that we face today.

title: Niger country profile
text: Niger Country Profile Overview: Niger, officially the Republic of Niger, is a landlocked country in West Africa. It is bordered by Libya to the northeast, Chad to the east, Nigeria to the south, Benin and Burkina Faso to the southwest, and Mali and Algeria to the west. Niger is the largest country in West Africa and the tenth largest in Africa, covering an area of 1,267,000 square kilometers (489,000 sq mi). The population is estimated at 24.2 million as of 2023, making it the 51st most populous country in the world. Geography: Niger is a mostly flat and arid country, with the Sahara Desert covering more than two-thirds of its territory. The highest point is Mount Bagzane, with an elevation of 2,022 meters (6,634 ft). The main river is the Niger River, which flows through the southwestern part of the country. Climate: Niger has a hot and dry desert climate, with temperatures ranging from 25°C to 45°C (77°F to 113°F) in most areas. The rainy season lasts from June to September, but rainfall is often erratic and insufficient for agriculture. People: The population of Niger is ethnically diverse, with the Hausa, Djerma, and Tuareg being the largest groups. The official languages are French and Hausa. The majority of the population is Muslim, with a small minority of Christians and animists. Economy: Niger is one of the poorest countries in the world, with a GDP per capita of $631 in 2022. The economy is heavily dependent on uranium mining, which accounts for about 50% of export earnings. Other industries include agriculture, animal husbandry, and trade. Politics: Niger is a democratic republic with a presidential system. The President is both the head of state and the head of government, and is elected by popular vote for a five-year term. The National Assembly has 171 members who are elected for five-year terms. Culture: Niger has a rich and diverse culture, influenced by its Islamic, African, and French heritage. Traditional arts include music, dance, and textiles. The country is home to several UNESCO World Heritage Sites, including the Historic Centre of Agadez and the Aïr and Ténéré Natural Reserves. Challenges: Niger faces a number of challenges, including poverty, food insecurity, and political instability. The country has been plagued by droughts, floods, and other natural disasters, which have exacerbated these challenges. Niger is also struggling to combat terrorism and organized crime.

title: Wales is 'better off' in EU, say the Liberal Democrats
text: Wales would be better off staying in the EU, the Welsh Liberal Democrats have said. The party's leader, Kirsty Williams, said that leaving the EU would damage the Welsh economy and cost jobs. title: Swiss immigration: 50.3% back quotas, final results show
text: Swiss immigration: 50.3% back quotas, final results show The final results of the referendum on immigration quotas in Switzerland have been released, with 50.3% of voters backing the proposal. The vote, which took place on Sunday, was closely fought, with 49.7% of voters rejecting the quotas. Turnout was high, with 64.4% of eligible voters casting their ballots. The quotas will limit the number of residence permits issued to citizens of the European Union (EU) and the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) to 1% of the Swiss population. This would mean that around 24,000 permits would be issued each year. The Swiss People's Party (SVP), which campaigned for the quotas, said the result was a "victory for Switzerland". The party's leader, Christoph Blocher, said the quotas would "protect Swiss wages and jobs". However, opponents of the quotas said they would damage the Swiss economy. They argued that the quotas would make it harder for businesses to recruit skilled workers from the EU and EFTA. The Swiss government has said it will now start work on implementing the quotas. However, it is likely to face legal challenges from the EU and EFTA. The referendum on immigration quotas is the latest in a series of votes in Switzerland on the issue of immigration. In 2014, voters backed a proposal to introduce quotas on immigration from the EU. However, that proposal was later rejected by the Swiss parliament. The issue of immigration is a divisive one in Switzerland. Some voters are concerned about the impact of immigration on Swiss culture and identity. Others argue that immigration is essential for the Swiss economy. The final results of the referendum on immigration quotas are a clear indication that the issue of immigration remains a major concern for Swiss voters.

title: Australian man found after two weeks stranded in outback
text: In a remarkable tale of survival, an Australian man has been found alive and well after spending two weeks stranded in the vast and unforgiving outback. 36-year-old Tom George set out on a solo camping trip in the remote Kimberley region of Western Australia on 16th December. However, his vehicle became bogged in a creek, leaving him stranded and without communication. Undeterred, George rationed the meager supplies he had with him, including water and food. He also slept in his car to protect himself from the scorching sun and extreme temperatures. As days turned into nights, George's hope began to dwindle. Meanwhile, his family and friends back home were desperately worried. They had not heard from him for several days and feared the worst. They alerted the authorities, who launched a large-scale search operation involving land, air, and water resources. On Friday, after two weeks of searching, a helicopter spotted George's vehicle from the air. A rescue team was immediately deployed and found him alive and surprisingly well-hydrated. "I was so relieved to see them," said George, his voice trembling with emotion. "I thought I was going to die out there." George was immediately flown to a hospital for a medical checkup and was found to be in good physical condition. He attributed his survival to his determination and the knowledge he had acquired from years of bushcrafting. "I knew that if I panicked, I would only make things worse," said George. "I focused on staying calm and rationed my supplies carefully." George's story has captured the attention of the nation, highlighting the resilience and resourcefulness of Australians in the face of adversity. It has also raised awareness of the dangers of venturing into remote areas alone and the importance of being prepared for emergencies. As George recovers from his ordeal, he is thankful for the support of his family and the unwavering efforts of the rescue team. He plans to return to the outback one day but with a more extensive communication system and increased supplies. In the meantime, his experience serves as a reminder that even in the most unforgiving of environments, the human spirit can prevail with determination and a strong will to survive.

title: Covid-19: Adverts urge people to 'keep going' and remain at home
text: Covid-19: Adverts urge people to 'keep going' and remain at home A new advertising campaign has been launched urging people to "keep going" and stay at home amid the coronavirus pandemic. title: Hundreds of peregrine falcons kept secret 'for safety'
text: In a covert operation aimed at safeguarding one of the UK's most iconic birds of prey, hundreds of peregrine falcons have been secretly held in captivity for their own protection. Conservationists have been discreetly breeding and releasing peregrine falcons into the wild over the past three decades, with remarkable success. The species, once on the brink of extinction in Britain, has now rebounded to healthy numbers. However, the birds face a persistent threat from illegal persecution, including poisoning, trapping, and nest robbing. To mitigate this, the secretive breeding program was initiated, with the birds housed in undisclosed locations. "We can't reveal the locations where the falcons are kept, as this could put them at risk," explained a spokesperson from the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (RSPB). "We take the safety of these birds extremely seriously." The breeding program has been a collaborative effort involving the RSPB, the National Trust, Natural England, and other conservation organizations. Birds are carefully selected for breeding based on their genetic diversity and health, ensuring the long-term viability of the population. Once the falcons reach maturity, they are released into areas where they are known to have historically nested. The birds are fitted with tracking devices to monitor their movements and survival rates. The program has been met with mixed reactions. Some conservationists argue that keeping the falcons captive undermines their natural instincts and reduces their chances of survival in the wild. Others maintain that the secrecy is essential to protect the birds from persecution. "We understand the concerns that people have, but we believe that this program is the best way to protect peregrine falcons in the UK," said the RSPB spokesperson. "We want to see these birds thriving once again, and we're confident that this program will help us achieve that goal." The secrecy surrounding the breeding program is a testament to the ongoing challenges faced by peregrine falcons. Despite their protected status, these birds remain vulnerable to human activities. By keeping the locations of the breeding facilities secret, conservationists hope to ensure the survival of this majestic raptor for future generations.

title: Pakistan attack: Gunmen storm five-star hotel in Balochistan
text: Gunmen stormed a luxury hotel in southwestern Pakistan on Saturday, killing at least six people and injuring several others. The attack took place in the city of Gwadar, located in the restive province of Balochistan. According to reports, a group of armed men entered the Pearl Continental Hotel, which is popular with foreign tourists and dignitaries. The gunmen opened fire indiscriminately, killing at least six people, including a security guard and a hotel employee. Several others were injured, some of them critically. Security forces quickly arrived at the scene and cordoned off the area. They engaged in a fierce gun battle with the attackers, who were holed up inside the hotel. The fighting lasted for several hours before security forces regained control of the building. All guests and staff were evacuated from the hotel, and authorities have launched an investigation into the attack. No group has yet claimed responsibility. Pakistani Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif condemned the attack and ordered an immediate investigation. He also directed authorities to provide the best possible medical treatment to the injured. Balochistan has been plagued by violence for decades, with separatist and Islamist militant groups operating in the region. The province is also a key part of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), a major infrastructure project that has been targeted by militants in the past. The attack on the Pearl Continental Hotel is a stark reminder of the security challenges facing Pakistan. The country has been grappling with a wave of terrorism in recent years, and the government has struggled to contain the violence. The international community has condemned the attack and expressed solidarity with the people of Pakistan. The United States, the United Kingdom, and other countries have offered their support in the investigation and the fight against terrorism. The attack on the Pearl Continental Hotel is a tragedy that has claimed the lives of innocent people. It is a reminder of the ongoing threat of terrorism in Pakistan and the need for the international community to work together to combat this scourge.

title: We rely on migrants to produce your food - young farmers
text: Young farmers in the UK have warned that the country will struggle to produce enough food in the future without migrant workers. They say that a shortage of British workers willing to do the physically demanding and often low-paid work of farming means that the industry is increasingly reliant on people from overseas. In a new report, the National Farmers' Union (NFU) found that 56% of fruit and vegetable farms in the UK now employ non-UK workers. The NFU said that without these workers, the UK would not be able to produce enough food to feed its population. "We rely on migrants to produce your food," said NFU President Minette Batters. "Without them, we would not be able to put food on the shelves." The NFU's report found that the number of non-UK workers in the UK agricultural sector has increased by 10% in the past year. The report also found that the average age of a farmer in the UK is 59, and that the number of young people entering the industry is declining. The NFU said that the government needs to do more to encourage young people to take up farming. "We need to make farming more attractive to young people," said Batters. "We need to invest in training and education, and we need to make sure that there are affordable opportunities for young people to get into farming." The government has said that it is committed to supporting the agricultural sector. "We are working closely with the NFU and other stakeholders to address the challenges facing the industry," said a spokesperson for the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra). "We are committed to ensuring that the UK has a sustainable and resilient agricultural sector, and that we can continue to produce enough food to feed our population." However, the NFU said that the government needs to do more to address the shortage of young farmers. "We need the government to take urgent action to address this issue," said Batters. "If we don't, we will not be able to produce enough food in the future."

title: US economic growth revision to 3.7% boosts markets
text: US economic growth revised to 3.7%, boosting markets The US economy grew at an annualised rate of 3.7% in the second quarter of 2023, according to revised data from the Commerce Department. This is up from the previous estimate of 2.9%. The upward revision was largely due to stronger consumer spending and business investment. Consumer spending, which accounts for about 70% of US economic activity, rose at an annualised rate of 2.8% in the second quarter, up from the previous estimate of 1.8%. It suggests that the economy is growing at a faster pace than previously thought and that the recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic is continuing. The news of the revised economic growth data has boosted markets. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose by more than 300 points on the day of the announcement, and the S&P 500 index rose by more than 1%. It suggests that the economy is growing at a faster pace than previously thought and that the recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic is continuing. title: Aurigny Air Services could be sold to Blue Islands
text: Aurigny Air Services could be sold to Blue Islands Aurigny Air Services, the Guernsey-based airline, is in talks to be sold to Blue Islands, a Channel Islands-based carrier.
