title: Restaurant insolvencies jump as diners stay at home
text: Restaurant Insolvencies Jump as Diners Stay at Home The hospitality industry has been one of the hardest hit sectors during the COVID-19 pandemic, with restaurant insolvencies surging as diners opt to stay home. Data from the Centre for Retail Research (CRR) shows that 88 restaurant chains, including Carluccio's, Gourmet Burger Kitchen, and Giraffe, have entered insolvency or administration since the start of the pandemic. This represents a 56% increase compared to the same period last year. The CRR attributes the surge in insolvencies to a combination of factors, including the government-imposed lockdowns, social distancing measures, and consumer reluctance to dine out. "The pandemic has had a devastating impact on the restaurant sector," said Professor Joshua Bamfield, director of the CRR. "With people unable to go out and eat, restaurants have been forced to close or operate at reduced capacity, leading to huge losses." The government's Eat Out to Help Out scheme, which subsidized dining out in August and September, provided some relief for the industry. However, with the scheme now ended and cases of COVID-19 rising again, restaurants are facing an uncertain future. "The outlook for the restaurant sector remains bleak," said Bamfield. "Unless there is a significant improvement in consumer confidence and a lifting of restrictions, we expect to see further insolvencies in the coming months." The surge in restaurant insolvencies is having a knock-on effect on the wider economy. The hospitality sector is one of the largest employers in the UK, accounting for over 3 million jobs. Restaurant closures are therefore likely to lead to job losses and reduced consumer spending. "The government needs to take urgent action to support the hospitality industry," said Kate Nicholls, chief executive of UKHospitality. "This includes extending the furlough scheme, providing financial assistance to struggling businesses, and reducing business rates." The government has announced a £1.5 billion support package for the hospitality sector, which includes grants for businesses that have been forced to close and a reduction in business rates. However, industry leaders say that more support is needed. "The government's support package is a welcome start, but it is not enough," said Nicholls. "We need to see more long-term measures to ensure that the hospitality industry can survive this crisis and emerge stronger on the other side."

title: Public sector hourly pay outstrips private sector pay
text: Public Sector Hourly Pay Outstrips Private Sector Pay New figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) have revealed that average hourly pay in the public sector has overtaken that in the private sector for the first time since records began in 2008. The ONS data shows that public sector employees earned an average of £26.58 per hour in August 2023, compared to £26.45 per hour in the private sector. This marks a significant change from the previous decade, when private sector pay consistently outpaced public sector pay. Several factors have contributed to this shift. Firstly, the government has implemented a series of pay rises for public sector workers in recent years, including teachers, nurses, and firefighters. This has helped to narrow the pay gap between the public and private sectors. Secondly, the cost of living crisis has disproportionately affected low-paid workers in the private sector, such as those in retail and hospitality. As a result, many private sector employers have struggled to recruit and retain staff, leading to upward pressure on wages. Thirdly, the public sector has been seen as a more secure and stable place to work during the current economic uncertainty. This has attracted workers from the private sector, further driving up public sector pay. The ONS data also shows that the pay gap between the public and private sectors is particularly pronounced in London and the South East of England. In these regions, public sector employees earn an average of £30.89 per hour, compared to £28.51 per hour in the private sector. The widening pay gap between the public and private sectors has raised concerns that it could lead to a brain drain from the public sector. However, the government has insisted that it is committed to paying public sector workers fairly. The Minister for the Cabinet Office, Michael Gove, said: "These figures show that we are delivering on our promise to pay public sector workers fairly. Their hard work and dedication deserve to be rewarded." The trade union Unison welcomed the news, but said that there was still more to be done. "This is a step in the right direction, but we need to see further pay rises for public sector workers to ensure that they are not left behind," said general secretary Christina McAnea. The widening pay gap between the public and private sectors is a significant development. It remains to be seen whether this trend will continue in the long term, but it is clear that the government's pay policy and the cost of living crisis have had a major impact on the relative pay of public and private sector workers.

title: Norilsk Nickel: Mining firm pays record $2bn fine over Arctic oil spill
text: Norilsk Nickel: Mining firm pays record $2bn fine over Arctic oil spill Russian mining giant Norilsk Nickel has been ordered to pay a record 146.2 billion roubles ($2bn; £1.5bn) in compensation for an Arctic oil spill last year. The world's largest nickel and palladium producer was found responsible for the leak of 21,000 tonnes of diesel fuel at its power plant in Norilsk, Siberia, in May 2020. The spill, one of the worst in Russian history, polluted rivers and lakes and killed thousands of fish. Norilsk Nickel initially tried to downplay the extent of the damage, but later admitted it had underestimated the scale of the spill. The company has now agreed to pay the compensation to the Russian government, which will use the money to clean up the environment and support local communities affected by the spill. The fine is the largest ever imposed on a Russian company for environmental damage. 'Unprecedented environmental disaster' The spill occurred when a storage tank at the power plant collapsed, releasing a huge amount of diesel fuel into nearby rivers and lakes. The fuel spread over an area of more than 350 square kilometres (135 square miles), contaminating water supplies and killing thousands of fish. The spill also caused significant damage to the local ecosystem, as the fuel polluted soil and vegetation. The Russian government declared a state of emergency in the region and launched a major clean-up operation. Norilsk Nickel has been heavily criticised for its handling of the spill. The company initially tried to downplay the extent of the damage, and it took several days for it to inform the authorities about the full scale of the leak. The company has since apologised for its actions and has pledged to invest in environmental protection measures. Compensation and clean-up The $2bn fine will be used to fund the clean-up of the environment and to support local communities affected by the spill. The Russian government has said that the money will be used to restore damaged ecosystems, to provide compensation to fishermen and other businesses that have been affected by the spill, and to improve infrastructure in the region. Norilsk Nickel has also committed to investing in environmental protection measures at its operations. The company has said it will spend $1.5bn over the next five years on environmental projects, including the construction of new wastewater treatment facilities and the upgrade of existing infrastructure. The Arctic oil spill was a major environmental disaster, but it has also led to a renewed focus on environmental protection in Russia. The government has pledged to increase its spending on environmental protection and to enforce environmental regulations more strictly.

title: Business bank: Industry's views
text: Business Bank: Industry's Views In the wake of the government's announcement of a new business bank, industry leaders have welcomed the move but also expressed concerns about its potential impact. The bank, which is set to receive £20 billion of government funding, is intended to provide loans to small and medium-sized businesses (SMEs) that are struggling to access finance from traditional lenders. The Federation of Small Businesses (FSB) has praised the government's commitment to supporting SMEs, but has urged the bank to ensure that it is accessible to all businesses, including those with a poor credit history. "SMEs are the backbone of the UK economy, and it is vital that they have access to the finance they need to grow and create jobs," said FSB chairman Mike Cherry. "The government's new bank has the potential to make a real difference, but it is essential that it is accessible to all businesses, regardless of their size or credit history." The British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) has also welcomed the new bank, but has expressed concerns about the potential for it to create an unlevel playing field between SMEs and larger businesses. "We are concerned that the new bank could create a two-tier system, with SMEs being able to access cheaper finance than larger businesses," said BCC director general Adam Marshall. "This could put larger businesses at a competitive disadvantage and stifle innovation." The CBI, which represents large businesses, has also expressed concerns about the potential for the new bank to lead to a reduction in lending from traditional lenders. "We urge the government to work with the banking sector to ensure that the new bank does not lead to a reduction in lending from traditional lenders," said CBI director general Carolyn Fairbairn. "SMEs need access to a diverse range of funding options, and it is important that the new bank does not crowd out competition." Despite these concerns, industry leaders generally agree that the new business bank is a positive step towards supporting SMEs. However, they believe that the government must carefully consider the potential impact on the wider banking sector and ensure that the bank is accessible to all businesses. In response to these concerns, the government has said that it is committed to ensuring that the new bank is accessible to all businesses and that it does not lead to a reduction in lending from traditional lenders. "The new bank will be a valuable addition to the UK's financial landscape, and it will play a vital role in supporting SMEs to grow and create jobs," said Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond. "We will work closely with the banking sector to ensure that the new bank does not lead to a reduction in lending from traditional lenders, and that it is accessible to all businesses, regardless of their size or credit history."

title: Ministers aim to 'rescue' Planning Bill by undoing changes
text: Ministers are preparing to undo changes made to the Planning Bill in an attempt to salvage the legislation after it was heavily criticized. Reaction from environmental groups has been mixed. Some groups, such as the Campaign to Protect Rural England, have welcomed the changes, but others, such as Greenpeace, have said that they do not go far enough. Local authorities have also expressed concerns about the bill. The Local Government Association has said that the bill would give developers too much power and would undermine local democracy. The public has also been critical of the bill. A recent poll by YouGov found that 57% of people oppose the bill, while only 28% support it. The government is facing a difficult task in trying to salvage the Planning Bill. The bill is unpopular with environmental groups, local authorities, and the public. The government will need to make significant concessions if it wants to get the bill through Parliament. If the bill is passed, it will have a major impact on the planning system in England. title: Cigarette packets wash up on Dorset's Chesil Beach
text: Cigarette packets wash up on Dorset's Chesil Beach Thousands of cigarette packets have washed up on Chesil Beach in Dorset, prompting a warning from the environmental charity the Marine Conservation Society (MCS). Members of the public reported finding the packets along the beach, which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The MCS said the packets were "a stark reminder" of the impact of littering on marine life. "Cigarette butts are the most common form of litter found on beaches," said MCS beachwatch officer Lizzie Prior. "They contain toxic chemicals that can harm marine life, and they can also be ingested by birds and other animals." Prior said the packets that had washed up on Chesil Beach were likely to have been washed out to sea by heavy rain. "When it rains, litter can be washed into our rivers and streams, and from there it can be carried out to sea," she said. "Chesil Beach is a very exposed beach, so it's not surprising that litter washes up here. But it's still a very sad sight to see so many cigarette packets littering the beach." The MCS is urging people to dispose of their cigarette butts responsibly. "If you're smoking on the beach, please don't just drop your cigarette butt on the sand," said Prior. "Put it in a bin, or take it home with you." The MCS is also calling for more to be done to reduce the number of cigarette butts that are littered. "We need to educate people about the impact of littering on marine life," said Prior. "We also need to make it easier for people to dispose of their cigarette butts responsibly." The MCS is working with local authorities and other organizations to install more cigarette butt bins on beaches. The charity is also running a campaign to raise awareness of the impact of littering on marine life. "We all need to do our bit to protect our oceans," said Prior. "By disposing of our litter responsibly, we can help to keep our beaches clean and safe for marine life."

title: Tata Sons names Natarajan Chandrasekaran new chairman
text: Tata Sons Appoints Natarajan Chandrasekaran as New Chairman Tata Sons, the holding company of the Tata Group, has announced the appointment of Natarajan Chandrasekaran as its new Chairman. Chandrasekaran, who is currently the Chairman of Tata Consultancy Services (TCS), will take over the reins from Ratan Tata, who has been holding the position on an interim basis since the departure of Cyrus Mistry in 2016. Chandrasekaran, 54, is a seasoned business leader with a proven track record of success. He joined TCS in 1987 as a software engineer and quickly rose through the ranks, becoming CEO in 2009. Under his leadership, TCS has grown into a global IT powerhouse with over 400,000 employees. In his new role, Chandrasekaran will be responsible for overseeing the operations of the Tata Group, which includes over 100 companies in various sectors such as automobiles, steel, and aviation. He will also be tasked with driving the group's growth and diversification strategy. Chandrasekaran's appointment comes at a time when the Tata Group is facing several challenges, including increasing competition and a slowing Indian economy. However, analysts are optimistic that his strong leadership skills and experience will help the group navigate these challenges and emerge stronger. In a statement, Ratan Tata said, "Natarajan Chandrasekaran has been an outstanding leader at TCS. His vision, passion, and commitment to excellence have been instrumental in making TCS what it is today. I am confident that he will bring the same qualities to his role as Chairman of Tata Sons." Chandrasekaran expressed his gratitude for the opportunity and said, "I am deeply honored and humbled to be entrusted with the responsibility of leading the Tata Group. I am committed to working with my colleagues to build on the strong legacy of our founders and create a sustainable and successful future for the group." Chandrasekaran's appointment is effective February 21, 2017. He is the first non-Tata family member to become Chairman of Tata Sons in over 50 years.

title: Rallies call for return of devolved assembly at Stormont
text: Rallies call for return of devolved assembly at Stormont Thousands of people have taken part in rallies in Belfast and Londonderry, calling for the return of the devolved assembly at Stormont. The assembly has been suspended since January 2017 due to a dispute between the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) and Sinn Féin over the Irish language and other issues. Speaking at the rally in Belfast, former DUP leader Peter Robinson said that the suspension of the assembly was "a disgrace" and that it was time for the parties to get back to work. "We need to find a way to work together," he said. "We need to find a way to compromise." Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald also spoke at the rally, saying that the people of Northern Ireland had "had enough" of the political deadlock. "We need to get back to Stormont and start working for the people," she said. The rallies come at a time when there is growing pressure on the DUP and Sinn Féin to reach an agreement. The British government has said that it is prepared to legislate to restore the assembly if the parties cannot reach an agreement by the end of the year. The Irish government has also said that it is prepared to take action if the parties cannot reach an agreement. The European Union has also expressed its concern about the ongoing political deadlock in Northern Ireland. In a statement, the EU Commission said that it was "essential" for the assembly to be restored as soon as possible. The rallies are a sign of the growing public frustration with the ongoing political deadlock. People are tired of the political games and they want to see the assembly restored so that it can start working for them again. It is now up to the DUP and Sinn Féin to show that they are listening to the people and that they are prepared to compromise. If they can do that, then there is hope that the assembly can be restored and that Northern Ireland can move forward.

title: Canada 'will not back down' over US metals tariffs
text: Canada's Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland has said her country "will not back down" in its dispute with the US over metals tariffs. Speaking at a news conference in Ottawa, Freeland said the tariffs were "unfair and unacceptable" and that Canada would "defend its interests vigorously." The US imposed tariffs of 25% on steel and 10% on aluminum from Canada, Mexico and the European Union in March, citing national security concerns. Canada has since retaliated with tariffs on $16.6 billion worth of US goods, including steel, aluminum and other products. Freeland said Canada was "disappointed" by the US decision to impose tariffs, but that it was "not surprised." "We have been clear from the beginning that we believe these tariffs are unfair and unacceptable," she said. "We will defend our interests vigorously." Freeland said Canada was "prepared to negotiate" with the US to resolve the dispute, but that it would not do so under the threat of tariffs. "We are not going to negotiate under duress," she said. "We are not going to back down." The US has said it is willing to negotiate with Canada, but that it will not remove the tariffs until Canada agrees to concessions on trade. The dispute between the two countries has raised concerns about the future of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). NAFTA is a trilateral trade agreement between the US, Canada and Mexico that has been in place since 1994. The US has threatened to withdraw from NAFTA if it cannot be renegotiated to its satisfaction. Freeland said Canada was "committed" to NAFTA, but that it was "also prepared" to walk away if the US withdrew. "We are not going to be bullied into a bad deal," she said. "We are prepared to walk away if necessary." The dispute between Canada and the US is the latest in a series of trade conflicts between the two countries. In recent months, the US has also imposed tariffs on Chinese goods, and has threatened to impose tariffs on cars from the EU. The trade conflicts have raised concerns about the global economy and have led to fears of a trade war.

title: West Wales health board cannot find dentist for 4,000

title: Spina bifida womb op baby back home in Essex
text: A baby girl who underwent pioneering surgery in the womb for spina bifida is back home in Essex with her family. The delicate operation, which was carried out at 25 weeks of pregnancy, was the first of its kind at St George's Hospital in Tooting, south London. Baby Willow's mother, Felicity, said she and her husband Chris were "over the moon" to have their little girl home. "She's doing really well," she said. "She's feeding well and she's just a happy little baby." Spina bifida is a birth defect that occurs when the spinal cord doesn't close properly during pregnancy. This can cause a range of problems, including paralysis, incontinence and learning difficulties. Traditional treatment for spina bifida involves surgery after the baby is born. However, this can be risky and can lead to further complications. The new surgery, known as fetoscopic myelomeningocele repair, is carried out while the baby is still in the womb. This means that the risks of surgery are reduced and the baby has a better chance of a normal life. Willow's surgery was carried out by a team of specialist doctors and nurses led by Professor Paolo De Coppi. The operation took four hours and involved making a small incision in Felicity's womb. A tiny camera was then inserted into the womb and the team used a laser to close the opening in Willow's spinal cord. The surgery was a success and Willow was born two months later by Caesarean section. She spent the first few weeks of her life in hospital but is now back home with her family. "We're just so grateful to the team at St George's for everything they've done," said Felicity. "They've given Willow the best possible start in life." Professor De Coppi said he was delighted with the outcome of the surgery. "This is a major breakthrough in the treatment of spina bifida," he said. "We're now able to offer families a new hope for their children." The surgery is still in its early stages and it is not yet clear how effective it will be in the long term. However, the early results are promising and it is hoped that it will become the standard treatment for spina bifida in the future.

title: Brexit: Job loss claim over 'deeply flawed' exit plan
text: Brexit: Job loss claim over 'deeply flawed' exit plan A leaked government document has revealed that the UK is set to lose up to 800,000 jobs in the wake of Brexit, a far higher figure than the government has previously admitted. The document, which was obtained by the BBC, also warns that the economy will be 2% smaller than it would have been if the UK had remained in the EU. The government has dismissed the claims in the document, saying that they are "deeply flawed" and that the UK will be better off outside the EU. However, the leak has raised fresh concerns about the economic impact of Brexit, which is already causing uncertainty and disruption for businesses. The leaked document is a report by the Department for Exiting the European Union (DExEU), which was commissioned by the Treasury. The report assesses the impact of a "no-deal" Brexit, in which the UK leaves the EU without a deal on future trading arrangements. The report finds that a no-deal Brexit would lead to a sharp fall in trade with the EU, which would in turn lead to job losses and a slowdown in economic growth. The report also warns that a no-deal Brexit would damage the UK's reputation as a reliable trading partner, which could make it harder for businesses to attract investment and grow. The government has dismissed the claims in the report, saying that they are "deeply flawed" and that the UK will be better off outside the EU. However, the leak has raised fresh concerns about the economic impact of Brexit, which is already causing uncertainty and disruption for businesses. The leaked document is the latest in a series of warnings about the economic impact of Brexit. In recent months, the Bank of England has warned that Brexit could lead to a recession, and the International Monetary Fund has said that the UK's economy will grow more slowly than the rest of the developed world in the coming years. The government has insisted that it is prepared for a no-deal Brexit, but businesses are increasingly concerned about the potential impact on their operations. A recent survey by the Confederation of British Industry found that two-thirds of businesses are not prepared for a no-deal Brexit. The leaked document is likely to add to the pressure on the government to reach a deal with the EU on future trading arrangements. However, it is unclear whether the EU is willing to make the concessions that the UK government is seeking. The UK is due to leave the EU on March 29, 2019. If a deal is not reached by then, the UK will leave without a deal, which could have a significant impact on the UK economy.

title: Youth unemployment doubled in East during Covid-19 pandemic
text: Youth unemployment in the East of England more than doubled during the Covid-19 pandemic, according to new figures. The number of 16 to 24-year-olds claiming unemployment benefits in the region rose by 126% between March 2020 and March 2021, from 12,895 to 29,250. This is the highest increase in youth unemployment of any region in England, and is significantly higher than the national average of 83%. The figures, from the Office for National Statistics (ONS), show that the East of England is now the region with the third highest rate of youth unemployment in England, after the North East and Yorkshire and the Humber. The rise in youth unemployment is likely to have been caused by a number of factors, including the closure of businesses during lockdown, the reduction in job vacancies, and the increase in competition for jobs. Young people are often the first to be laid off during an economic downturn, as they are often employed in low-paid, insecure jobs. They are also more likely to be working in sectors that have been particularly hard hit by the pandemic, such as hospitality, retail, and tourism. The rise in youth unemployment is a major concern, as it can have a significant impact on young people's long-term career prospects. Young people who are unemployed for a long period of time are more likely to be unemployed in the future, and they are also more likely to experience lower wages and job insecurity. The government has announced a number of measures to help young people into work, including the Kickstart scheme, which provides funding for employers to create new jobs for young people. However, it is unclear whether these measures will be enough to address the high levels of youth unemployment in the East of England. The ONS figures also show that the overall unemployment rate in the East of England has risen to 4.7%, up from 3.8% in March 2020. This is higher than the national average of 4.1%. The rise in unemployment is likely to have a significant impact on the local economy, as it will reduce consumer spending and investment. It is also likely to lead to an increase in poverty and inequality.

title: Allerdale and Copeland councils nuclear waste response
text: Allerdale and Copeland Councils Respond to Nuclear Waste Inquiry Allerdale and Copeland Borough Councils have submitted evidence to the House of Commons' Local Government Committee inquiry into nuclear waste management, which is examining the geological disposal of higher activity radioactive waste in the UK. The Councils stressed the importance of addressing the issue of nuclear waste disposal and welcomed the opportunity to contribute to the inquiry. The Councils' Concerns In their evidence, the Councils expressed a number of concerns about the proposed geological disposal facility (GDF) at Sellafield. Environmental impact: The Councils raised concerns about the potential environmental impact of the GDF, particularly on the Solway Firth and the wider area. They called for a full and independent environmental impact assessment to be carried out before any decisions are made. Economic impact: The Councils also expressed concerns about the economic impact of the GDF, arguing that it could have a negative impact on tourism and other industries in the area. They called for a detailed economic impact assessment to be carried out. Community engagement: The Councils stressed the importance of engaging with local communities and involving them in the decision-making process. They called for a comprehensive public consultation to be carried out before any decisions are made. The Councils' Recommendations The Councils made a number of recommendations to the Committee, including: Establish an independent body: The Councils recommended that an independent body be established to oversee the GDF project and provide assurance to the public. Carry out a full environmental impact assessment: The Councils called for a full and independent environmental impact assessment to be carried out before any decisions are made. Carry out a detailed economic impact assessment: The Councils called for a detailed economic impact assessment to be carried out, taking into account the potential impact on tourism and other industries. Engage with local communities: The Councils stressed the importance of engaging with local communities and involving them in the decision-making process. Consider alternative options: The Councils called for the Government to consider alternative options for nuclear waste disposal, such as reprocessing or recycling. Conclusion Allerdale and Copeland Borough Councils have submitted evidence to the House of Commons' Local Government Committee inquiry into nuclear waste management. The Councils have expressed a number of concerns about the proposed geological disposal facility at Sellafield and have made a number of recommendations to the Committee. The Committee is expected to publish its report later this year.

title: Covid: Portsmouth University threatens legal action amid New Theatre Royal plan
text: Portsmouth University has threatened legal action over plans to turn the historic New Theatre Royal into a live music venue. The university, which owns the Grade II-listed building, says the plans would "irreparably harm" its academic activities. The New Theatre Royal Trust, which is behind the plans, says it is "deeply disappointed" by the university's stance. The trust says the new venue would "bring significant cultural and economic benefits to the city". The university has given the trust until 5pm on Friday to withdraw its plans or face legal action. In a statement, the university said: "We have repeatedly expressed our concerns to the trust about the noise and disruption that a live music venue would cause to our students and staff. "The trust has failed to address these concerns and has refused to engage in any meaningful dialogue with us. "We have therefore been left with no choice but to take legal action to protect our interests." The New Theatre Royal Trust said it was "deeply disappointed" by the university's stance. In a statement, the trust said: "We believe that our plans for the New Theatre Royal would bring significant cultural and economic benefits to the city of Portsmouth. "We have been working closely with the university to address their concerns and we are confident that we can mitigate any potential impact on their activities. "We are therefore very disappointed that the university has decided to take legal action. We believe that this action is unnecessary and we will be vigorously defending our plans." The New Theatre Royal is one of Portsmouth's most iconic buildings. It was built in 1894 and has hosted a variety of performances over the years, including plays, musicals and concerts. The theatre has been closed since 2012 and the New Theatre Royal Trust is hoping to raise £25m to restore it and turn it into a live music venue. The trust has already secured £10m from the government's Levelling Up Fund and is hoping to raise the rest of the money from private donations. If the trust's plans are successful, the New Theatre Royal would become one of the largest live music venues in the south of England. It would have a capacity of 2,000 people and would host a variety of acts, including both local and international artists.

title: Lancashire councils push ahead for combined authority
text: Two Lancashire councils have agreed to push ahead with plans for a combined authority, despite the government's decision to reject their initial proposal. Lancashire County Council and Blackburn with Darwen Council have been working on the plans for several months, and they believe that a combined authority would give them more powers and resources to improve the lives of local people. The government initially rejected the councils' proposal, but they have now agreed to work with them to develop a new plan that meets the government's requirements. The councils are now working on a new proposal that they hope will be approved by the government. They are confident that a combined authority would be a positive step for Lancashire, and they are determined to make it happen. Council leaders said the creation of a combined authority would bring about "significant benefits" to the region. They said: "It would allow us to pool our resources and work together to improve transport, skills, housing and the economy. "It would also give us a stronger voice in government and allow us to speak up for Lancashire on the national stage." The councils are now working on a new proposal that they hope will be approved by the government. They are confident that a combined authority would be a positive step for Lancashire, and they are determined to make it happen. The government has said that it will consider any new proposals for combined authorities on a case-by-case basis. A spokesman for the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government said: "We are committed to working with local authorities to create combined authorities where there is a clear case for them. "We will consider any new proposals on a case-by-case basis, taking into account the specific circumstances of each area." If the government approves the councils' new proposal, a combined authority for Lancashire could be up and running by 2024. The councils believe that a combined authority would bring about a number of benefits for Lancashire, including: Improved transport links Increased investment in skills and training More affordable housing A stronger economy A stronger voice in government The councils are now urging the government to approve their new proposal, so that Lancashire can benefit from the advantages of a combined authority.

title: Oxford University summer school taster for Welsh students
text: Oxford University Summer School Taster for Welsh Students This summer, Oxford University is offering a unique opportunity for Welsh students to experience life at one of the world's leading universities. title: Facebook sorry for 'white supremacist ad'
text: Facebook apologises for publishing neo-Nazi advert Facebook has apologised for publishing an advert by a white supremacist group that was shared more than 2,200 times. The advert, which was shared on Tuesday, featured an image of a swastika and the words "White Pride World Wide". It was shared by a group called the "Nationalist Front". Facebook removed the advert and banned the group from its platform. It apologised for the error and said it was investigating how the advert was able to be published. "We are deeply sorry for the offence and pain this has caused. We have removed the ad and have banned the group responsible," a Facebook spokesperson said. "We have clear policies against hate speech and discrimination, and we are committed to removing this type of content from our platform. We are investigating how this ad was able to be published and will continue to work to improve our systems to prevent this from happening again." The incident has raised concerns about the spread of hate speech on social media. Critics have accused Facebook of not doing enough to remove this type of content. In response, Facebook has said that it is committed to fighting hate speech. It has increased its investment in human moderators and artificial intelligence to help identify and remove this type of content. However, the company has also faced criticism for its policies on free speech. Some people have argued that Facebook should not remove content that is offensive or hateful, even if it violates the company's policies. Facebook has said that it believes in freedom of expression, but it also has a responsibility to protect its users from hate speech and other harmful content. The incident has also raised questions about the role of social media companies in the spread of extremism. Critics have accused Facebook of providing a platform for hate groups and extremists. Facebook has said that it is committed to working with law enforcement and other organisations to fight extremism. It has also developed tools to help users identify and report hate speech and other harmful content. However, the company has also faced criticism for not doing enough to combat extremism. Some people have argued that Facebook should do more to take down extremist content and ban extremist groups from its platform. Facebook has said that it is constantly working to improve its systems to combat hate speech and extremism. It is also working with law enforcement and other organisations to help tackle these issues.

title: Michael Nyman composes Hillsborough memorial symphony
text: Michael Nyman has composed a new symphony to commemorate the 96 Liverpool fans who died in the Hillsborough disaster. The symphony, titled "96," will be performed by the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra and conducted by Vasily Petrenko at Liverpool's Philharmonic Hall on April 15, 2023, the 34th anniversary of the tragedy. Nyman said he was "honored" to have been asked to compose the symphony, adding that he hoped it would provide a "fitting tribute" to the victims and their families. "This is a very important piece for me," Nyman said. "It's a piece that I've been working on for a long time, and it's a piece that I'm very proud of." The symphony is in four movements, each of which is dedicated to a different aspect of the Hillsborough disaster. The first movement, "In Memoriam," is a slow and somber meditation on the victims. The second movement, "The Truth," is a more upbeat and celebratory movement that reflects the long campaign for justice for the victims. The third movement, "The Healing," is a peaceful and reflective movement that represents the healing process that the city of Liverpool has undergone since the disaster. The fourth movement, "The Future," is a hopeful and optimistic movement that looks to the future and the legacy of the Hillsborough victims. Nyman said he used a variety of musical styles in the symphony, including classical, electronic, and folk music. He also incorporated some of the chants and songs that were sung by Liverpool fans at Hillsborough. "I wanted to create a piece of music that was both beautiful and powerful," Nyman said. "I wanted to create a piece of music that would be a fitting tribute to the victims and their families, and a piece of music that would help to heal the wounds of the past." The Hillsborough disaster was one of the worst sporting disasters in British history. On April 15, 1989, 96 Liverpool fans were crushed to death in a overcrowded standing-room section of the Hillsborough Stadium in Sheffield. The disaster led to a long campaign for justice for the victims, which culminated in the publication of the Hillsborough Independent Panel report in 2012. The report found that the disaster was caused by a series of failures by the police and the stadium authorities. The Hillsborough Memorial Symphony is a powerful and moving tribute to the victims of the Hillsborough disaster. It is a piece of music that will help to keep their memory alive and to inspire future generations.

title: Conchata Ferrell: Two and a Half Men actress dies aged 77
text: Conchata Ferrell, who played Berta the housekeeper in the sitcom "Two and a Half Men," has died at the age of 77. Ferrell died on Tuesday at Sherman Oaks Hospital in Los Angeles after suffering a heart attack, according to a statement from her publicist. "We are deeply saddened by the loss of Conchata Ferrell," the statement said. "She brought joy to so many people with her performances. She will be greatly missed." Ferrell was born in Charleston, West Virginia, in 1943. She began her acting career in the early 1970s, appearing in small roles in films and television shows. She landed her breakout role in "Two and a Half Men" in 2003. Ferrell played Berta, the sarcastic and quick-witted housekeeper to Charlie Sheen's character, Charlie Harper. Ferrell's performance earned her two Primetime Emmy Award nominations for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Comedy Series. She also received a Golden Globe Award nomination for the role in 2005. "Two and a Half Men" ran for 12 seasons, ending in 2015. Ferrell appeared in all 262 episodes of the show. In addition to her work on "Two and a Half Men," Ferrell also appeared in films such as "Mystic Pizza" (1988), "Edward Scissorhands" (1990), and "Erin Brockovich" (2000). She also had recurring roles on television shows such as "L.A. Law" (1986-1994), "Grace Under Fire" (1993-1998), and "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" (1997-2003). Ferrell was known for her sharp wit and her ability to deliver comedic lines with perfect timing. She was also a beloved figure on the set of "Two and a Half Men." "Conchata was a beautiful human," said Jon Cryer, who played Alan Harper on the show. "She was funny, caring, and always had a smile on her face. She will be deeply missed." Ferrell's death has been met with an outpouring of grief from fans and colleagues alike. She is survived by her husband, Arnie Anderson, and her daughter, Samantha Anderson.

title: European protected status bid for Denbigh plum
text: Amidst the rolling hills of North Wales, a culinary treasure has garnered attention, prompting a bid for European protected status. The Denbigh plum, a unique and flavorful fruit, is at the heart of this endeavor. With its sweet, juicy flesh and distinctive aroma, the Denbigh plum has been a beloved favorite for centuries. Grown in the historic county of Denbighshire, its unique characteristics stem from the region's microclimate and the expertise of local growers. The bid for European Protected Geographical Indication (PGI) status aims to preserve and promote the authenticity of this exceptional fruit. By recognizing its origin and traditional production methods, PGI status will safeguard the Denbigh plum's reputation and prevent imitations. "This is a significant moment for the Denbigh plum," said John Jones, a local farmer and advocate for the bid. "It is a testament to the hard work and dedication of our growers and the unique qualities of this fruit." The PGI application highlights the specific growing conditions and traditional practices that contribute to the Denbigh plum's distinctive flavor profile. The plum trees flourish in the region's sheltered valleys, where they receive optimal sunlight and rainfall. The fruit is carefully handpicked when fully ripe, ensuring its sweetness and juiciness. "The Denbigh plum is not just a fruit," said Helen Jones, a local food historian. "It is part of our cultural heritage and culinary traditions. This bid is about protecting not only the fruit itself but also the way of life associated with it." The bid has garnered widespread support from local businesses, chefs, and consumers alike. Restaurants and cafes in the region feature the Denbigh plum in their dishes, showcasing its versatility and culinary appeal. The European Commission is currently evaluating the application. If successful, the Denbigh plum will join a prestigious group of products, such as Parma ham and Champagne, that have earned PGI status. This recognition would boost the economic profile of the region, attract food enthusiasts, and ensure the continued production of this exceptional fruit for generations to come. The Denbigh plum, a symbol of Welsh culinary excellence, stands poised to take its place among Europe's most celebrated delicacies. The bid for European protection status is a testament to the passion and dedication of those who have nurtured this fruit for centuries. As the evaluation process continues, the future of the Denbigh plum shines brightly, promising to delight taste buds for years to come.

title: John Lewis to pull 'Never knowingly undersold' pledge
text: John Lewis to pull 'Never knowingly undersold' pledge Department store chain John Lewis is to scrap its long-standing "Never knowingly undersold" pledge, which has been a cornerstone of its marketing strategy for nearly a century. The retailer said the move was necessary to reflect the changing retail landscape, which has seen the rise of online shopping and increased competition from discounters. John Lewis said it would continue to offer competitive prices, but would no longer match the prices of other retailers on a like-for-like basis. The decision has been met with mixed reactions from customers. Some have expressed disappointment, saying that the pledge was one of the things that made John Lewis unique. Others have said that the move is understandable, given the challenges facing the retail sector. John Lewis first introduced its "Never knowingly undersold" pledge in 1925. The pledge was designed to reassure customers that they were getting the best possible price on their purchases. However, in recent years, John Lewis has come under increasing pressure from online retailers, which can often offer lower prices due to their lower overheads. The retailer has also faced competition from discounters such as Aldi and Lidl, which have gained market share by offering lower-priced products. John Lewis said that the decision to scrap its "Never knowingly undersold" pledge was not taken lightly. "We know that our customers value our commitment to offering competitive prices," a spokesperson said. "However, we believe that this change is necessary to ensure that we can continue to offer the high-quality products and services that our customers expect." John Lewis said it would continue to offer a price match guarantee on certain products, but this would be on a case-by-case basis. The retailer also said that it would continue to invest in its online offering and its physical stores. "We are committed to providing our customers with the best possible shopping experience, both online and in-store," the spokesperson said. The decision by John Lewis to scrap its "Never knowingly undersold" pledge is a sign of the changing retail landscape. Consumers are increasingly shopping online and are more price-conscious than ever before. Retailers are having to adapt to these changes in order to survive.

title: Life Sciences Bridging Fund offers antibiotic 'lifeline'
text: Life Sciences Bridging Fund offers antibiotic 'lifeline' The government has announced a £100 million fund to support the development of new antibiotics to combat the rising threat of antimicrobial resistance (AMR). The Life Sciences Bridging Fund will provide grants to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to help them advance promising antibiotic candidates through clinical trials. AMR occurs when bacteria become resistant to the antibiotics used to treat them, making infections harder to treat and increasing the risk of serious illness and death. The World Health Organization (WHO) has identified AMR as one of the most urgent global health threats, with drug-resistant infections estimated to cause 700,000 deaths each year. In the UK, AMR is responsible for an estimated 5,000 deaths each year and costs the NHS billions of pounds. The Life Sciences Bridging Fund is part of the government's AMR Action Plan, which was launched in 2019. The plan aims to tackle AMR through a range of initiatives, including investing in research and development, improving surveillance, and promoting responsible antibiotic use. The fund is expected to support up to 15 projects, each of which will receive up to £10 million. The projects will be selected through a competitive process and will be assessed on their scientific merit, potential impact on AMR, and the ability of the SME to bring the product to market. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: "Antimicrobial resistance is one of the greatest threats to modern medicine, and it is vital that we take action now to develop new antibiotics. "The Life Sciences Bridging Fund will provide a much-needed lifeline to small businesses developing promising antibiotic candidates, helping them to bring new treatments to market and save lives." The fund will be managed by Innovate UK, the UK's innovation agency. Innovate UK's chief executive officer, Ian Campbell, said: "We are delighted to be working with the government to deliver this important fund. "The Life Sciences Bridging Fund will provide a vital source of support to SMEs developing new antibiotics, helping them to overcome the challenges of clinical trials and bring their products to market. "This investment will not only help to tackle the threat of AMR, but will also support the growth of the UK life sciences sector."

title: East Kent X-ray need sees Faversham injuries unit close
text: East Kent X-ray need sees Faversham injuries unit close An urgent need for X-ray facilities at the Kent and Canterbury Hospital has led to the temporary closure of the Faversham Minor Injuries Unit (MIU). East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust (EKH) took the difficult decision to close the MIU from October 31 to allow for the urgent installation of a new X-ray machine at the hospital in Canterbury. The trust said the closure was necessary to ensure the safety of patients and staff, as the existing X-ray machine at the Faversham MIU is no longer fit for purpose. "We understand that this closure will be disappointing for the local community," said Chris Streather, EKH's director of operations. "However, we want to assure the public that this is a temporary measure and that we are committed to reopening the MIU as soon as possible." The trust said it is exploring all options to minimize disruption to patients, including providing transport to the Kent and Canterbury Hospital for those who need X-rays. Patients with minor injuries are being advised to attend the Margate MIU, the Sheerness MIU, or the urgent treatment centre (UTC) at the William Harvey Hospital in Ashford. The trust said it is working closely with the South East Coast Ambulance Service (SECAmb) to ensure that patients are able to access the most appropriate care. "We apologize for any inconvenience this may cause," said Mr. Streather. "We would like to thank the public for their understanding and cooperation during this time." The trust said it will provide regular updates on the situation and will reopen the Faversham MIU as soon as possible.

title: Statute of limitations plan 'unhelpful'- Simon Coveney
text: The Irish government's plan to introduce a 30-year statute of limitations for historical institutional abuse has been described as "unhelpful" by Foreign Affairs Minister Simon Coveney. The proposed legislation would mean that victims of abuse in institutions run by the state, religious orders, or other organisations would have 30 years from the date of the abuse to take legal action. However, Coveney said that the plan would not help victims who were abused as children, as they would have already passed the 30-year time limit. "I think it's unhelpful to suggest that we're going to have a statute of limitations that will apply to everybody," Coveney said. "The reality is that for many people who were abused as children, the 30-year time limit will have already passed." Coveney said that the government was still considering its options on how to deal with historical institutional abuse. "We're not going to rush into anything," he said. "We want to get this right. We want to make sure that we have a system that is fair to victims and that also protects the rights of the accused." The government's plan has been criticized by victim support groups, who say that it will deny justice to many victims of abuse. "This is a betrayal of victims," said Maeve Lewis, chair of the Survivors of Child Abuse group. "The government is saying that it's not interested in helping people who were abused as children." The Irish government has been under pressure to introduce a statute of limitations for historical institutional abuse for a number of years. In 2019, the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child called on the government to introduce a statute of limitations that would not apply to child abuse cases. The government has said that it is committed to addressing the issue of historical institutional abuse. However, it has not yet said when it will introduce legislation to do so.

title: Kylie Minogue to play Glastonbury's legend slot

title: Elections 2021: Millions voting in bumper set of polls
text: Elections 2021: Millions Voting in Bumper Set of Polls Voters across the United Kingdom are heading to the polls today in a series of local and regional elections. Over 4,000 councillors will be elected in England, while voters in Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland will choose their representatives in devolved parliaments and assemblies. title: Syria air strikes: For and against UK action
text: Syria Air Strikes: Weighing the Arguments The UK government's decision to participate in air strikes against targets in Syria has ignited a heated debate, with proponents and opponents presenting compelling arguments. In Favor of UK Action: Humanitarian Intervention: Advocates argue that the air strikes are necessary to prevent further civilian casualties in Syria's ongoing civil war. The chemical weapons attack in Douma has been condemned as a war crime, and it is feared that the Assad regime could use such weapons again. International Responsibility: The UK has a moral obligation to protect civilians from mass atrocities, and air strikes can serve as a deterrent to further aggression. The use of chemical weapons violates international law and undermines the global order. Long-Term Stability: Proponents contend that air strikes can weaken the Assad regime and create space for a negotiated settlement to the conflict. By targeting military assets and infrastructure supporting the regime, the strikes can erode its power base. Against UK Action: Escalation of Conflict: Critics warn that air strikes could escalate the already fragile situation in Syria and lead to an unintended conflict with Russia, which supports the Assad regime. Limited Effectiveness: Sceptics argue that air strikes alone are unlikely to be sufficient to achieve their objectives. The Assad regime has shown resilience in the past and may adapt to the new attacks. Lack of Clear Strategy: Opponents criticize the UK government for failing to articulate a clear and coherent strategy for what it hopes to achieve with air strikes. They argue that without a broader diplomatic effort, the strikes may be counterproductive. Possible Civilian Casualties: Air strikes inevitably pose a risk of civilian casualties. Critics worry that the UK may inadvertently harm innocent lives while attempting to target the Assad regime. Conclusion: The decision of whether or not to participate in air strikes in Syria is complex. There are strong arguments to be made both for and against UK action. Ultimately, the government must weigh the potential benefits and risks carefully before making a decision. It is important to note that there is no consensus on the issue among experts or the public. The debate is likely to continue as the air strikes proceed and their consequences unfold.

title: Northern Ireland prison officer recruitment drive launched
text: Northern Ireland Prison Service (NIPS) has launched a recruitment drive in a bid to bolster its workforce. The organisation is looking to fill 100 frontline prison officer roles across its nine prisons in Northern Ireland. Those who are successful will be responsible for the safety and security of prisoners, as well as providing support and care. NIPS director general Ronnie Armour said: "Prison officers play a vital role in our society, and I am delighted to be able to launch this recruitment drive. "This is a fantastic opportunity for people to join a rewarding and challenging career, where they can make a real difference to the lives of others." Applicants must be aged 18 or over, have a good level of fitness and be able to work shifts. They must also be able to demonstrate good communication and interpersonal skills, as well as the ability to work independently and as part of a team. NIPS is particularly keen to encourage applications from women, people from minority ethnic backgrounds and those with disabilities. Armour added: "We are committed to building a workforce that is representative of the communities we serve. "We want people from all backgrounds to feel welcome and valued in NIPS, and we believe that this recruitment drive will help us to achieve that goal." Those who are interested in applying can visit the NIPS website for more information. The closing date for applications is 12 January 2023. Prisons in Northern Ireland have been facing a number of challenges in recent years, including overcrowding and a shortage of staff. In 2021, the Prison Officers' Association (POA) warned that the service was "on the brink of collapse" due to a lack of resources. The POA has welcomed the recruitment drive, but said that more needs to be done to address the long-term challenges facing the prison service. POA chairman Mark Lindsay said: "This recruitment drive is a welcome step, but it is only a short-term fix. "We need to see a long-term investment in the prison service, including more funding and more staff. "We also need to see a change in the way that prisons are run, with a focus on rehabilitation and reducing reoffending."

title: Sir Richard Branson abandons English Channel kitesurf attempt
text: Sir Richard Branson abandons English Channel kitesurf attempt Sir Richard Branson has abandoned his attempt to kitesurf across the English Channel after encountering strong winds and choppy seas. Branson and Pulido were both wearing wetsuits and helmets during their attempt. They were also using kitesurfing boards that were specially designed for the challenge. Despite the setback, Branson said he was still proud of what he had achieved. "I've never given up on a challenge before," he said. "But today, I had to listen to my body and to the advice of my team. I'm disappointed, but I'm also proud of what we've achieved." Branson's attempt to kitesurf across the English Channel was the latest in a series of challenges he has undertaken in recent years. In 2013, he became the oldest person to cross the Atlantic Ocean in a hot air balloon. In 2015, he became the first person to fly a commercial spacecraft into space. Branson is a well-known adventurer and philanthropist. He founded the Virgin Group, which includes Virgin Atlantic, Virgin Media, and Virgin Galactic. He is also the founder of the Branson Centre for Entrepreneurship, which supports young entrepreneurs. title: Amanda Knox: DNA evidence defended by Italian police
text: Italian police have defended the use of DNA evidence in the case of Amanda Knox, the American student who was convicted of murdering her roommate in Italy in 2007. Knox and her then-boyfriend, Raffaele Sollecito, were found guilty of killing Meredith Kercher in the Italian town of Perugia. They were both sentenced to 26 years in prison, but Knox was acquitted on appeal in 2011 and Sollecito in 2015. However, the case remains open in Italy, and prosecutors have continued to investigate the possibility that Knox and Sollecito were involved in the murder. In 2019, police announced that they had found new DNA evidence linking Knox to the crime scene. The evidence is a small amount of DNA that was found on the clasp of Kercher's bra. Police say that the DNA matches Knox's DNA profile. Knox has denied any involvement in the murder, and her lawyers have argued that the DNA evidence is unreliable. In a statement, Italian police defended the use of the DNA evidence. They said that the evidence was "consistent" with the other evidence in the case, and that it "supports the conclusion that Knox was present at the scene of the crime." The police also said that they had conducted a thorough investigation and that they were confident in the reliability of the DNA evidence. The case of Amanda Knox has been closely followed around the world. It has raised questions about the reliability of DNA evidence and the fairness of the Italian justice system. The new DNA evidence is likely to reignite the debate over Knox's guilt or innocence. It is also likely to put further pressure on the Italian authorities to bring the case to a close. In a statement, Knox's lawyers said that they were "disappointed" by the police's decision to continue to pursue the case. title: What Charles Manson and his followers did in California in 1969
text: In the heart of California's sun-kissed summers of 1969, a sinister shadow emerged, casting a pall of darkness over the idyllic landscape. Armed with knives and guns, they brutally slaughtered Tate, who was eight months pregnant, along with four others present. The victims, including celebrity hairstylist Jay Sebring and coffee heiress Abigail Folger, were stabbed and shot multiple times. The assailants scribbled "PIG" on the front door in Tate's blood. The following night, Manson's followers carried out another horrific attack, murdering Leno and Rosemary LaBianca in their home nearby. Again, the walls were adorned with chilling inscriptions, including "DEATH TO PIGS." Manson's motives remain shrouded in mystery. Some speculate that he sought revenge against the wealthy and famous, while others believe he was driven by a warped desire for chaos and notoriety. Regardless, the crimes he orchestrated left an indelible scar on society. The subsequent investigation unraveled a web of drug use, brainwashing, and violence that had characterized Manson's commune. title: Turner Prize exhibition opens to public
text: The Tate Britain museum in London has opened its doors to this year's Turner Prize exhibition, showcasing the works of the four shortlisted artists: Veronica Ryan, Heather Phillipson, Ingrid Pollard and Sin Wai Kin. Considered one of the most prestigious art awards in the United Kingdom, the Turner Prize is given to a British artist under the age of 50 for an outstanding exhibition or other presentation of their work. The award was established in 1984 by the Tate Gallery and is named after the 19th-century painter J.M.W. Turner. This year's exhibition features a diverse range of works, exploring themes such as identity, history, and the environment. Ryan's work, "Along a Spectrum," is a large-scale installation that uses light and sound to create an immersive experience that explores the fluidity of gender and sexuality. Phillipson's "RUPTURE NO 1: blowtorching the constricting corset of propriety" is a sculptural work that uses found objects and materials to explore themes of power and control. Pollard's work, "Reassemblage," is a series of photographs and installations that explore the history of black subjectivity in Britain. Kin's work, "A Wall is a Screen," is a multi-channel video installation that explores the relationship between technology and the human body. The Turner Prize exhibition is always highly anticipated, and this year's show is no exception. The works on display are thought-provoking and challenging, and they offer a unique insight into the work of some of the most exciting contemporary artists in the UK. The exhibition is open to the public until January 15, 2023. Admission is free. In addition to the main exhibition, the Tate Britain is also hosting a number of related events, including talks, workshops, and tours. For more information, please visit the Tate Britain website. The Turner Prize is one of the most prestigious art awards in the United Kingdom, and this year's exhibition is a must-see for anyone interested in contemporary art. The works on display are thought-provoking and challenging, and they offer a unique insight into the work of some of the most exciting contemporary artists in the UK.

title: Dreamland operator Sands Heritage has debts 'over £14m'
text: Operator of Dreamland Margate owes over £14m Sands Heritage, the operator of Dreamland in Margate, has debts of over £14m, according to a report by insolvency practitioners Duff & Phelps. The report, which was commissioned by the company's administrator FRP Advisory, found that Sands Heritage had liabilities of £14.2m as of 31 December 2021. This included £5.6m owed to creditors, £4.3m owed to HMRC, and £2.9m owed to Thanet District Council. The report also found that Sands Heritage had made a loss of £2.6m in 2021, and that its cashflow was "unsustainable". FRP Advisory was appointed as administrator to Sands Heritage in February 2022, after the company failed to repay a loan from Thanet District Council. The council had loaned Sands Heritage £1.5m in 2020 to help it through the COVID-19 pandemic. A spokesperson for FRP Advisory said: "We are currently working with Sands Heritage to explore all options for the future of the business. This includes seeking a sale of the company and its assets." Dreamland is a historic amusement park that first opened in 1880. It is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Margate, and it is home to a number of rides, attractions, and events. The news of Sands Heritage's debts has raised concerns about the future of Dreamland. However, FRP Advisory has said that it is committed to working with the company to find a solution that will allow it to continue operating. A spokesperson for Thanet District Council said: "We are aware of the financial challenges facing Sands Heritage. We are working with the administrator to explore all options for the future of the business, and we are committed to ensuring that Dreamland remains a key part of Margate's tourism offer." Despite its financial challenges, Sands Heritage has continued to operate Dreamland. The park is currently open to the public, and it is hosting a number of events throughout the summer.

title: 'Stansted 15' protesters' counter-terrorism convictions appealed
text: Stansted 15 Protesters Appeal Counter-Terrorism Convictions Fifteen protesters known as the "Stansted 15" are appealing their convictions for terrorism offenses related to a demonstration against the use of Stansted Airport for arms transportation. In March 2017, the group of British activists blocked access to the airport's runway in a protest against the alleged role it played in transporting weapons to Saudi Arabia and Bahrain, countries accused of human rights abuses. Following a high-profile trial, twelve of the protesters were found guilty of conspiracy to cause public nuisance and sentenced to prison terms ranging from three to six months. Three others were convicted of inciting others to engage in public nuisance and received suspended sentences. The protesters' lawyers have now filed an appeal, arguing that the convictions should be overturned on several grounds, including that: The trial judge misdirected the jury on the definition of public nuisance. The prosecution failed to prove that the protesters' actions were intended to cause disruption. The sentences imposed were excessive and disproportionate. The protesters' supporters maintain that their actions were justified as a form of legitimate protest against the arms trade. They argue that the use of terrorism charges against them was a heavy-handed attempt to criminalize dissent. The appeal hearing is expected to take place later this year. If successful, it could overturn the protesters' convictions and raise questions about the use of counter-terrorism legislation against non-violent demonstrators. Meanwhile, the Stansted 15 remain vocal about their opposition to arms exports and their belief in the right to protest peacefully. They have launched a campaign called "Stop the War Machine," which aims to raise awareness about the role of the UK in the international arms trade. The appeal of the Stansted 15's convictions has drawn attention to the ongoing debate over the balance between national security and the right to protest. It is a case that has the potential to set a significant precedent for future prosecutions of political demonstrations.
