title: Ellie Yarrow-Sanders: Judge's Twitter plea to missing mum
text: Ellie Yarrow-Sanders: Judge's Twitter plea to missing mum A High Court judge has made a direct appeal on Twitter to help find a missing mother-of-two who disappeared more than a week ago. Mr Justice Peter Jackson said he had "never done anything like this before" but was "extremely concerned" about the welfare of Ellie Yarrow-Sanders. The 36-year-old was last seen dropping her children off at school in Spalding, Lincolnshire, on 24 January. Her car was later found abandoned and police have described her disappearance as "out of character". In a tweet on Tuesday, Mr Justice Jackson said: "I'm a High Court judge, I've never done anything like this before. But I'm extremely concerned for Ellie Yarrow-Sanders, 36, missing from Spalding since Monday 24 Jan. Please, if you know anything, DM me." He added that he was "not able to give details of what I know", but urged anyone with information to contact him directly. Ms Yarrow-Sanders' family have also been using social media to appeal for help in finding her. In a Facebook post, her sister Becky Yarrow said: "We are all so worried about Ellie and just want her to come home safe and well. "If you have seen her or have any information, please contact the police or Crimestoppers." Lincolnshire Police said they were "increasingly concerned" for Ms Yarrow-Sanders' welfare. Det Supt Martyn Parker said: "Ellie's disappearance is completely out of character and we are doing everything we can to find her. "We have a dedicated team of detectives working on the case and we are following a number of lines of enquiry. "We are also working closely with Ellie's family and friends to support them at this difficult time." Police have appealed for anyone with information about Ms Yarrow-Sanders' whereabouts to contact them on 101, quoting incident number 107 of 25 January.

title: Western Sahara welcomes Morocco's African Union membership
text: Western Sahara, a disputed territory in North Africa, has welcomed Morocco's recent readmission to the African Union (AU). Morocco's return to the AU, after a 33-year absence, has been met with mixed reactions in the region. The Polisario Front, which seeks independence for Western Sahara, has condemned the move, calling it a violation of international law. However, many other countries in the region, including Algeria and Mauritania, have welcomed Morocco's return to the AU. Western Sahara has been a source of tension between Morocco and the Polisario Front since the former Spanish colony gained independence in 1975. Morocco claims the territory as its own, while the Polisario Front wants it to be an independent state. The AU has been trying to mediate a solution to the conflict for decades, but so far no agreement has been reached. Morocco's return to the AU could give the peace process a new impetus, but it is too early to say what impact it will have. Some analysts believe that Morocco's return to the AU could help to isolate the Polisario Front and put pressure on it to negotiate a settlement. Others argue that it could simply embolden Morocco and make it less likely to compromise. Only time will tell what the long-term impact of Morocco's return to the AU will be. However, it is clear that the move has opened a new chapter in the history of the Western Sahara conflict. In the meantime, Western Sahara remains a disputed territory, with no clear path to a resolution in sight. The people of Western Sahara continue to live in poverty and uncertainty, and the conflict has had a devastating impact on their lives. The AU has a responsibility to help resolve the conflict and bring peace to Western Sahara. Morocco's return to the AU could provide an opportunity to do so, but it is important to remember that there is still a long way to go.

title: Marathon Oil firm fined £1.16m for North Sea gas release
text: Marathon Oil has been fined £1.16m after it released 130 tonnes of gas into the North Sea. The incident happened at one of the firm's offshore sites in 2019. A safety valve had failed, resulting in the escape of gas containing methane, ethane and propane. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) said Marathon had "failed to ensure the safe operation of its assets". The firm, based in Houston, Texas, has pleaded guilty to two breaches of the Offshore Installations (Safety) Regulations 1995 and has been fined £1,162,500. Operator fined after North Sea gas release The HSE's investigation found that the valve had failed due to a combination of factors, including a lack of maintenance and corrosion. The HSE said the company had failed to: Properly maintain the safety valve Carry out adequate risk assessments Implement a proper maintenance plan HSE inspector Gary Moore said: "This incident could have had much more serious consequences. "Marathon Oil failed to ensure the safe operation of its assets and put workers at risk. "We will not hesitate to take action against companies that fail to comply with their legal duties to protect workers and the environment." In a statement, Marathon Oil said it "deeply regrets" the incident and has taken steps to prevent a recurrence. "We have reviewed all of our safety systems and made necessary improvements," the statement said. "We are committed to the safety of our operations and to protecting the environment."

title: Greening: UK will not accept migrant relocation quotas
text: Greening: UK will not accept migrant relocation quotas Home Secretary Amber Rudd has said the UK will not accept quotas for the relocation of migrants within the EU. She said the government would consider voluntary arrangements but would not be "subject to EU decisions". Ms Rudd's comments come ahead of a meeting of EU interior ministers in Amsterdam on Thursday. The European Commission has proposed a scheme to relocate 160,000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece to other EU countries. The UK has already said it will not take part in the scheme, but Ms Rudd's comments are the first time a minister has explicitly ruled out accepting any migrants under it. She told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show: "We have been clear that we will not be accepting binding targets for the relocation of asylum seekers." Ms Rudd said the UK would continue to work with the EU on other issues, such as tackling the causes of migration. But she said the UK's immigration policy was a matter for the British government and parliament. "We will not be subject to EU decisions on our border controls or our immigration policy," she said. The government's decision not to participate in the migrant relocation scheme has been criticized by some, who say it is a moral obligation to help those who are fleeing war and persecution. Others have welcomed the decision, saying that the UK should not be forced to take in migrants who have no right to be here. The issue of migration is likely to be a key issue in the upcoming UK general election. The Conservative Party has pledged to reduce net migration to the UK to below 100,000 per year. The Labour Party has said it will "review" the government's immigration targets. The Liberal Democrats have said they will scrap the government's net migration target and introduce a new system based on skills. The UK's decision not to accept migrant relocation quotas is likely to put further strain on its relationship with the EU. The EU has said that the UK's refusal to participate in the scheme is "unacceptable". It is unclear what the long-term implications of the UK's decision will be. However, it is clear that the issue of migration will continue to be a source of tension between the UK and the EU.

title: Bank Holiday change will 'cost calendar maker £200,000'
text: Bank Holiday Change Will 'Cost Calendar Maker £200,000' A calendar maker has said that the government's decision to move the August bank holiday to September will cost his company £200,000. Robert Hall, co-founder of the Calendar Company, said that the change would mean that he would have to reprint all of his 2023 calendars, which are already in production. "We're a small business, so this is a significant cost for us," he said. "We had already printed 100,000 calendars when the government announced the change, and now we're going to have to scrap them all and start again." The government announced in March that the August bank holiday would be moved to September from 2023 onwards. The change was made to mark the coronation of King Charles III, which is due to take place on 6 May 2023. The Calendar Company is one of the largest calendar makers in the UK, and it supplies calendars to a wide range of businesses and organizations. Hall said that he had received a number of calls from customers who were concerned about the change. "Some of our customers have said that they will have to cancel their orders if we can't provide them with calendars that have the correct bank holidays," he said. "We're doing everything we can to minimize the disruption, but it's going to be a challenge." The government has said that it is aware of the impact that the change will have on businesses, and it is working to provide support. A spokesperson for the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy said: "We understand that businesses may need to make changes to their plans as a result of the bank holiday change. We are working with businesses to provide them with the support they need, and we have made funding available to help businesses with the costs of making these changes." However, Hall said that the government's support was not enough to cover the costs that his company would incur. He said that he hoped that the government would reconsider the change or provide more financial support to businesses that are affected. "We're a small business, and this change is going to have a big impact on us," he said. "We're just asking the government to help us out."

title: Danube boat accident: More bodies found as vessel is raised in Hungary
text: Danube Boat Accident: More Bodies Found as Vessel is Raised in Hungary The search and recovery operation following the tragic Danube River boat accident in Budapest has resumed, with more bodies being retrieved as the sunken vessel is raised. On Wednesday, the Mermaid sightseeing boat collided with the much larger Viking Sigyn cruise ship, causing it to capsize. Seven people died in the accident, including a South Korean tourist and a Hungarian crew member. Twenty-one people were rescued from the water, but several others remained unaccounted for. Authorities suspended the search on Thursday due to strong currents and poor visibility. On Friday, heavy lifting cranes were brought in to raise the Mermaid from the riverbed. As the vessel emerged from the water, divers discovered the bodies of five more victims. "The search is still ongoing, but unfortunately, it is now a recovery operation," said Budapest police chief Peter Gergely. "Our goal is to locate all of the victims and bring closure to their families." The cause of the accident is still under investigation, but authorities have said that they are looking into several factors, including the weather conditions, the speed of the Viking Sigyn, and the condition of the Mermaid. The Viking Sigyn was traveling from Passau, Germany, to Budapest, Hungary, at the time of the accident. The Mermaid was carrying South Korean tourists who were on a sightseeing tour of the city. The accident has shocked Hungary and the international community. The Hungarian government has declared a day of mourning for the victims, and flags are flying at half-mast across the country. South Korean President Moon Jae-in has expressed his condolences to the families of the victims and has called for a thorough investigation into the accident. The Danube River is one of Europe's busiest waterways, and boat accidents are relatively rare. However, this incident highlights the importance of safety measures and responsible navigation. As the search and recovery operation continues, authorities are urging the public to provide any information they may have about the accident. They are also asking for donations to support the families of the victims. The tragedy has cast a shadow over the city of Budapest, but the resilience and determination of the search and rescue teams have given hope to those who have lost loved ones.

title: Russia opposition leader Alexei Navalny attacked with "brilliant green" dye
text: Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny has been attacked with a green antiseptic dye in the Siberian city of Barnaul. Footage on social media showed Navalny, who is currently on a campaign trip ahead of parliamentary elections next month, with his face and clothes covered in the dye. The substance, known as "brilliant green," is commonly used as an antiseptic in Russia. Navalny said on social media that he had been attacked by members of "Vladimir Putin's gang." "They sprayed my face with brilliant green and all my clothes," he said. "I can't see out of one eye. They say that it will pass in a couple of days." Navalny has been a vocal critic of Putin and has been arrested and imprisoned on several occasions. In 2020, he was poisoned with a nerve agent and was airlifted to Germany for treatment. He returned to Russia in January, despite knowing that he would likely be arrested. Navalny's team said he would continue his campaign tour, despite the attack. "This is a sign that we are on the right track," they said in a statement. "The authorities are afraid of us and they are trying to intimidate us." The Kremlin has not commented on the attack. The attack on Navalny has been condemned by the United States and the European Union. The US State Department called the attack "a cowardly attempt to silence" Navalny. The EU said it was "deeply concerned" by the incident and called on Russian authorities to investigate. The attack on Navalny is the latest in a series of incidents targeting opposition figures in Russia. In recent months, several opposition politicians have been poisoned, attacked, or jailed. Human rights groups say the attacks are part of a wider crackdown on dissent in Russia.

title: Fastest-growing UK terror threat 'from far-right'
text: Far-right Extremism: A Growing Threat in the UK The far-right has emerged as the fastest-growing terror threat in the UK, according to a report by the National Counter Terrorism Security Office (NCTSO). This concerning trend is driven by a number of factors, including: Online Radicalization: Social media and online forums have become fertile ground for far-right ideologies to spread and radicalize individuals. Extremist groups are exploiting these platforms to share propaganda and recruit new members. Ideological Grievances: The far-right often taps into feelings of nationalism, xenophobia, and anti-immigration sentiments. Political events, such as Brexit, have further amplified these concerns, creating a breeding ground for far-right extremism. Economic Disparities: Economic inequality and social deprivation can also contribute to the growth of far-right extremism. Individuals who feel marginalized and unable to achieve economic success may turn to extreme ideologies that scapegoat minority groups. Threats to National Security: Far-right extremists pose a direct threat to national security. They are responsible for a significant number of terror attacks in the UK, including the Manchester Arena bombing in 2017. These attacks involve the use of firearms, explosives, and other weapons. Countering the Threat: Tackling far-right extremism requires a multi-pronged approach: Law Enforcement: Law enforcement agencies are working to identify and disrupt far-right groups. This includes monitoring online activity, conducting raids, and arresting individuals suspected of involvement in terrorist activities. Community Engagement: Building relationships with communities at risk of radicalization is crucial. Community groups, faith leaders, and schools can play a vital role in identifying vulnerable individuals and providing counter-narratives to extremist propaganda. Education and Awareness: Education campaigns are essential for raising awareness about far-right extremism. Schools, universities, and public organizations should provide resources and programs that promote tolerance, understanding, and critical thinking. Conclusion: The rise of far-right extremism in the UK is a serious threat to national security. It is driven by a complex mix of factors, including online radicalization, ideological grievances, and economic disparities. Countering this threat requires a concerted effort from law enforcement, communities, and educational institutions to identify and disrupt extremist groups and promote tolerance and understanding.

title: Plans to change NI prostitution and trafficking laws
text: Northern Ireland's laws on prostitution and human trafficking are set to be overhauled in a bid to protect vulnerable people and crack down on organised crime. The Department of Justice has launched a consultation on a range of proposals, including: Decriminalising the purchase of sex by people who are not involved in prostitution Creating a new offence of paying for sex with a trafficked person Increasing the penalties for trafficking and exploiting people for sexual purposes The consultation, which runs until 23rd September, follows a review of the current laws, which were found to be outdated and ineffective. The current law on prostitution in Northern Ireland dates back to the 19th century and criminalises all aspects of sex work, including soliciting, kerb crawling and brothel keeping. This approach has been criticised by campaigners, who argue that it drives prostitution underground and makes it more dangerous for those involved. The new proposals would decriminalise the purchase of sex by people who are not involved in prostitution, while creating a new offence of paying for sex with a trafficked person. This would bring Northern Ireland into line with other jurisdictions, such as Scotland and the Republic of Ireland, which have decriminalised prostitution. The consultation also proposes increasing the penalties for trafficking and exploiting people for sexual purposes. This would include introducing a new offence of trafficking for sexual exploitation, which would carry a maximum sentence of life imprisonment. The Department of Justice said the proposed changes would "make Northern Ireland a safer place for everyone". "We want to protect vulnerable people from exploitation and bring those who profit from their misery to justice," a spokesperson said. "These proposals would modernise our laws and bring them into line with international best practice." The consultation is open to all members of the public, and the Department of Justice is encouraging people to share their views. The results of the consultation will be used to inform the development of new legislation, which is expected to be introduced to the Northern Ireland Assembly in 2024.

title: Dorchester prison closure plan a 'blow' say unions
text: Unions have condemned the government's plan to close Dorchester Prison, describing it as a "blow" to the local community and the prison service. The Ministry of Justice announced on Thursday that the Category B men's prison in Dorset will close in 2023 as part of a shake-up of the prison estate. The Public and Commercial Services Union (PCS) said the closure would have a "devastating impact" on the local economy and would lead to the loss of around 200 jobs. "This is a short-sighted and ill-conceived decision that will have a devastating impact on the local community and the prison service," said PCS general secretary Mark Serwotka. "Dorchester Prison is a vital part of the local economy and provides much-needed employment in an area with high levels of unemployment. The closure of the prison will have a knock-on effect on local businesses and services." Serwotka also criticized the government for failing to consult with unions or the local community before making the decision to close the prison. "The government has made this decision without any consultation with unions or the local community," he said. "This is unacceptable and shows a complete disregard for the people who will be affected by the closure." The National Offender Management Service (NOMS) said the decision to close Dorchester Prison was made after a "thorough assessment" of the prison estate. A NOMS spokesperson said: "The decision to close Dorchester Prison was not taken lightly and was made after a thorough assessment of the prison estate. "We recognize that the closure of the prison will have an impact on the local community and we are working closely with the local authority and other partners to mitigate the impact." The spokesperson added that NOMS was committed to supporting staff who are affected by the closure of the prison. "We are committed to supporting staff who are affected by the closure of the prison and we will work with them to identify alternative employment opportunities within the prison service," the spokesperson said.

title: Trump sends family $25,000 after claim of broken promise
text: Former US President Donald Trump has reportedly sent $25,000 to each of his adult children after they accused him of breaking a promise to pay them $1 million apiece from his post-presidential fundraising efforts. The payments, which were made in February, were first reported by The New York Times. The Times reported that Trump's children - Donald Trump Jr., Ivanka Trump, and Eric Trump - had been promised the money as part of an agreement they reached with their father in 2017. The agreement gave the children a stake in their father's business empire in exchange for their support during his presidential campaign. According to the Times, the children were expecting to receive the $1 million payments from the proceeds of Trump's post-presidential fundraising efforts. However, Trump's fundraising efforts have been less successful than expected, and he has been reluctant to use the money to pay his children. The children's decision to accuse Trump of breaking his promise is a sign of the growing tensions within the Trump family. The family has been divided over a number of issues, including Trump's decision to run for president again in 2024. title: Basic rights of mentally ill 'violated'
text: Basic Rights of Mentally Ill Violated Individuals with mental illness face systemic violations of their basic human rights, according to a recent investigation by the BBC. The probe uncovered systematic failures in mental healthcare systems around the world, leading to widespread abuse and neglect. Denial of Autonomy One of the most fundamental violations is the denial of autonomy. People with mental illness are often subjected to forced treatment, including involuntary confinement and medication. This undermines their right to self-determination and can have severe psychological consequences. Inhumane Conditions Mental health facilities in many countries are overcrowded and underfunded, resulting in inhumane conditions. Patients are often housed in squalid, unsanitary wards and subjected to physical and psychological abuse by staff. Discrimination and Stigma Mentally ill individuals face widespread discrimination and stigma, which further marginalizes and isolates them. They may be denied employment, housing, and education solely based on their diagnosis. Lack of Access to Essential Services Access to essential mental healthcare services remains a major challenge. In many communities, there is a severe shortage of qualified professionals and facilities, making it difficult for people to receive timely and adequate care. Coercion and Restraint Coercive and restrictive practices are often used to control people with mental illness. These methods include physical restraints, seclusion, and chemical sedation. They can traumatize patients and exacerbate mental health conditions. Impacts on Human Rights These violations not only violate the rights of individuals with mental illness but also have broader societal consequences. They perpetuate stigma, erode public trust in mental healthcare systems, and contribute to social inequality. Call for Action The BBC investigation calls for urgent action to address these systemic failures. Governments, healthcare providers, and civil society organizations must work together to: Establish laws and policies that protect the rights of mentally ill individuals Invest in quality mental healthcare services Combat discrimination and stigma Promote recovery-oriented approaches that empower patients and respect their autonomy By ensuring the basic rights of mentally ill individuals, we can create a more just and equitable society that values the well-being of all its members.

title: Airlines told to pay flight compensation
text: Airlines Told to Pay Flight Compensation The BBC has learned that a number of airlines have been ordered to pay millions of pounds in compensation to passengers for canceled, delayed, or disrupted flights. The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has investigated a number of airlines and found that they have not been compliant with EU regulations on passenger rights. Under EU regulations, passengers are entitled to compensation of up to €600 if their flight is canceled, delayed by more than three hours, or if they are denied boarding due to overbooking. Airlines are also required to provide passengers with food, drink, and accommodation if their flight is delayed by more than two hours. The CAA's investigation found that a number of airlines, including Ryanair, easyJet, and British Airways, have not been complying with these regulations. The CAA has ordered these airlines to pay millions of pounds in compensation to passengers. A spokesperson for the CAA said: "We have investigated a number of airlines and found that they have not been compliant with EU regulations on passenger rights. We have ordered these airlines to pay compensation to passengers who have been affected by canceled, delayed, or disrupted flights." A spokesperson for Ryanair said: "We are disappointed with the CAA's decision. We believe that we have complied with all EU regulations on passenger rights. We will be appealing the CAA's decision." A spokesperson for easyJet said: "We are committed to providing our passengers with a good service. We are reviewing the CAA's decision and will take any necessary steps to ensure that we are compliant with all EU regulations on passenger rights." A spokesperson for British Airways said: "We are committed to providing our passengers with a good service. We are reviewing the CAA's decision and will take any necessary steps to ensure that we are compliant with all EU regulations on passenger rights." The CAA's investigation is ongoing and it is likely that more airlines will be ordered to pay compensation to passengers.

title: Road salt stocks at 'record levels' ahead of winter
text: Road salt stocks at 'record levels' ahead of winter Local authorities in England have built up "record" levels of road salt in preparation for the winter months, the Department for Transport (DfT) has said. The government is urging local authorities to ensure they have enough salt to treat roads during the winter months. The DfT said that salt stocks "are now at record levels", with more than 1.3 million tonnes available. This is compared to just over 1 million tonnes at the same point last year. Transport Secretary Mark Harper said: "I am pleased to see that local authorities have taken our advice and built up record levels of salt stocks ahead of winter. "This will help to ensure that our roads are kept open and safe during the colder months." The Local Government Association (LGA) said that councils were "working hard" to ensure they had enough salt to treat roads during the winter months. An LGA spokesman said: "Councils are working hard to ensure they have enough salt to treat roads during the winter months. "They are also working with suppliers to secure additional supplies if needed." The RAC said that the increase in salt stocks was "good news" for drivers. RAC spokesman Simon Williams said: "The increase in salt stocks is good news for drivers. "It means that our roads are more likely to be kept open and safe during the winter months." However, Williams warned that drivers should still be prepared for winter weather. He said: "Drivers should still be prepared for winter weather. "They should make sure their vehicles are winter-ready, with good tyres and plenty of screenwash." Advice for drivers The RAC has issued the following advice for drivers during the winter months: Make sure your vehicle is winter-ready, with good tyres and plenty of screenwash. Be prepared for winter weather, by packing warm clothes and a blanket in your car. Allow extra time for your journey, as road conditions may be slower. Drive carefully in snow and ice, and be prepared to stop suddenly. If you do get stuck in snow, stay with your car and call for help.

title: Syrian refugees: Celebration party held in Belfast
text: In the heart of Belfast, a vibrant celebration unfolded as Syrian refugees gathered to mark a milestone in their new home. Over 100 people came together at the New Horizons Center, their faces beaming with joy and gratitude. The event was organized by the Irish Refugee Council and the Syrian Community in Northern Ireland. It served as a testament to the resilience and spirit of the refugees who have found refuge in Belfast after fleeing the horrors of war. Children played happily, their laughter echoing through the hall. Parents chatted and shared stories, forging connections within their newfound community. The atmosphere was one of unity and belonging. "I am so happy to be here," said Fatima, a mother of two young children. "We have found a new home here in Belfast. People have been so welcoming and supportive." The celebration featured traditional Syrian music and dance, showcasing the rich culture and heritage of the refugees. Volunteers served delicious food, prepared with love and care. "It's important to celebrate our culture and share it with others," explained Omar, a Syrian artist. "This event is a chance for us to show the world that we are not just victims, but that we are also people with dreams, talents, and a rich history." The Lord Mayor of Belfast, Tina Black, attended the event and expressed her admiration for the Syrian community. "You have shown us the true meaning of resilience and hope," she said. "Belfast is proud to be your home." The celebration was not only a moment of joy but also a reminder of the challenges that Syrian refugees continue to face. Many have experienced trauma and loss, and they need ongoing support to rebuild their lives. "We are grateful for the help we have received, but we still have many needs," said Ahmed, a refugee who arrived in Belfast last year. "We need access to jobs, education, and healthcare. We need to be able to fully integrate into society." The Irish Refugee Council emphasized the importance of continuing to support Syrian refugees. "They have shown us that they are resilient and determined to build a better future for themselves and their families," said Niamh Ni Bhriain, the organization's head of advocacy. "We need to stand with them as they rebuild their lives in Belfast." As the celebration drew to a close, the Syrian refugees expressed their hope for a brighter future. "We have come a long way, but we have much further to go," said Fatima. "With the support of the Belfast community, we know that we can achieve our dreams."

title: Selena Gomez takes a break after panic attacks and anxiety
text: Selena Gomez takes a break after panic attacks and anxiety Selena Gomez has revealed that she is taking a break from her career to focus on her mental health. The singer and actress made the announcement in an Instagram post on Friday, saying that she had been experiencing panic attacks and anxiety. "I've discovered that anxiety, panic attacks and depression can be side effects of Lupus, which I was diagnosed with in 2014," she wrote. "I've been working on myself for the past few months and focusing on my mental health." Gomez said that she would be canceling her upcoming tour dates in order to "take some time off." "I want to be proactive and focus on maintaining my health and happiness and have decided that the best way forward is to take some time off," she said. Gomez's fans have expressed their support for her decision, with many taking to social media to wish her well. One fan wrote: "I'm so sorry to hear that you're going through this, Selena. But I'm glad that you're taking the time to focus on your mental health. We're all here for you." Another fan wrote: "You're an inspiration to us all, Selena. Thank you for being so open about your struggles. It helps us all feel less alone." Gomez's decision to take a break from her career is a reminder that mental health is just as important as physical health. It is important to seek help if you are struggling with anxiety or depression. There are many resources available to help people with mental health problems. The National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) offers a variety of resources, including information on diagnosis, treatment, and support groups. The National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) is another great resource for people with mental health problems. NAMI offers a variety of support services, including peer support groups and education programs. If you are struggling with anxiety or depression, don't be afraid to seek help. There is no shame in admitting that you need help. With the right treatment, you can manage your symptoms and live a full and happy life.

title: Smart motorway death 'treated as PR exercise by transport minister'
text: Smart Motorway Death 'Treated as PR Exercise' by Transport Minister A grieving family has accused a government minister of treating their son's death on a smart motorway as a "PR exercise." Jason Mercer, 44, was killed on the M1 near Sheffield in June 2019 when his motorcycle collided with a stationary vehicle in a live lane. His parents, Philip and Carol Mercer, say Transport Secretary Grant Shapps failed to engage properly with their concerns about the safety of smart motorways. They claim he ignored their request for a meeting to discuss their son's death and instead sent them a letter offering "sincere condolences." The Mercers are among a growing number of families who are calling for the government to scrap smart motorways after a series of fatal accidents. Smart motorways are sections of road where the hard shoulder has been converted into a live lane, with traffic flow controlled by variable speed limits. Critics argue that the lack of a hard shoulder means there is nowhere for drivers to stop in the event of a breakdown or accident. In a letter to Mr. Shapps, Mr. Mercer said: "I feel very let down by your response. It is clear that you have not taken the time to understand our concerns about smart motorways." He said his son's death was "completely avoidable" and accused the government of putting "profit before public safety." Mr. Shapps has defended the safety of smart motorways, saying they are "as safe, if not safer" than traditional motorways. He has announced a £390 million investment to improve safety on smart motorways, including the installation of more emergency refuge areas and variable speed limits. However, the Mercers say these measures do not go far enough and are calling for all smart motorways to be converted back to traditional motorways with a hard shoulder. A Department for Transport spokesperson said: "We extend our deepest sympathies to Mr. Mercer's family for their tragic loss. We have received his letter and will respond to him directly." The spokesperson added that the government is "committed to improving the safety of smart motorways" and that the £390 million investment "will make a real difference."

title: Sport Wales: Fewer pupils in deprived areas doing sport
text: Sport Wales: Fewer Pupils in Deprived Areas Doing Sport A recent report by Sport Wales has revealed a worrying trend: children living in deprived areas of Wales are less likely to participate in sport than their more affluent peers. The report found that only 30% of children in the most deprived areas of Wales participate in sport at least once a week, compared to 47% of children in the most affluent areas. The report also found that there is a significant gap in the number of children who participate in sport outside of school hours. In the most deprived areas, only 15% of children participate in sport outside of school hours, compared to 33% in the most affluent areas. The report's findings are concerning, as sport has been shown to have a number of benefits for children, including improved physical health, mental well-being, and academic achievement. Sport can also help children to develop important life skills, such as teamwork, leadership, and resilience. There are a number of reasons why children living in deprived areas are less likely to participate in sport. These include a lack of access to sports facilities, a lack of affordable sports equipment, and a lack of role models. Additionally, children living in deprived areas are more likely to face barriers to participation, such as poverty, crime, and family instability. The Welsh government has said that it is committed to tackling the issue of inequality in sport. In 2018, the government launched the £10m Active Schools Fund, which is designed to increase participation in sport in schools across Wales. The fund has been used to provide schools with new sports equipment, train teachers to deliver PE lessons, and develop after-school sports clubs. The government has also introduced a number of other initiatives to encourage children to participate in sport, such as the School Sports Partnership Programme and the National School Sports Awards. However, more needs to be done to ensure that all children in Wales have the opportunity to participate in sport. Recommendations The Sport Wales report makes a number of recommendations to address the issue of inequality in sport. These include: Increasing investment in sports facilities in deprived areas Providing more affordable sports equipment for children living in deprived areas Increasing the number of role models in deprived areas Developing more after-school sports clubs in deprived areas Breaking down barriers to participation for children living in deprived areas The Welsh government should take these recommendations seriously and implement them as soon as possible. By doing so, the government can help to ensure that all children in Wales have the opportunity to enjoy the benefits of sport.

title: South Korea to pardon 1,800 conscientious objectors
text: South Korea to Pardon 1,800 Conscientious Objectors In a significant move, the South Korean government has announced plans to pardon over 1,800 conscientious objectors who refused military service due to religious beliefs. The pardon, part of a wider push for greater social inclusivity, will provide relief and recognition to those who have faced discrimination and imprisonment for their pacifist stance. Conscientious objection is a fundamental human right protected by international law, but it is not recognized in South Korea. As a result, those who refuse military service on religious grounds have been prosecuted and sentenced to up to two years in prison. The announcement of the pardon has been welcomed by human rights groups and activists who have long campaigned for the recognition of conscientious objectors. They argue that the practice of imprisoning those who refuse to kill on ethical grounds is both unjust and counterproductive. "This is a historic moment for South Korea," said Yoon Sang-jin, a spokesperson for the Conscientious Objectors' Movement. "It shows that the government is finally willing to respect the rights of conscientious objectors." The pardon process will begin immediately, and it is expected that most of the 1,800 eligible conscientious objectors will be released by the end of the year. Those pardoned will not be subject to any further penalties or restrictions and will be able to fully participate in society. While the pardon is a major step forward, it is not a complete solution. Conscientious objection is still not recognized as a valid ground for exemption from military service in South Korea. As a result, conscientious objectors will continue to face prosecution if they refuse to serve. Activists are calling on the government to go further and establish a permanent exemption system for conscientious objectors. Such a system would ensure that those who refuse military service on religious grounds are not penalized and can fully exercise their human rights. The decision to pardon 1,800 conscientious objectors is a testament to the growing recognition of the rights of pacifists in South Korea. It is a hopeful sign that the country is moving towards a more inclusive and tolerant society where all citizens are treated with respect and dignity.

title: Facebook launches initiative to fight online hate speech

The "We Delete Hate Speech" initiative is the latest step in Facebook's ongoing efforts to combat hate speech.
