title: Tory MSP joins calls for 'federal' UK in wake of Brexit vote
text: In the aftermath of the tumultuous Brexit referendum, the political landscape of the United Kingdom has been thrown into disarray. Amidst the uncertainty and division, a growing chorus of voices is calling for a fundamental restructuring of the UK's constitutional arrangements, with some advocating for a shift towards a more federal system of government. Among those adding their weight to this movement is Adam Tomkins, a Conservative MSP (Member of the Scottish Parliament). Tomkins has argued that a federal UK, with greater devolution of powers to the constituent nations of England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, could help to address the deep-seated grievances that have fueled support for independence in some parts of the country. Proponents of federalism argue that it offers a way to accommodate the diverse needs and aspirations of different regions while preserving the overall unity of the UK. By granting greater autonomy to devolved administrations, they contend, it would reduce the sense of alienation felt by many in Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. However, critics of federalism warn that it could lead to a weakening of the UK government and a fragmentation of the country. They argue that devolving more powers to regional assemblies could undermine the principle of parliamentary sovereignty and create a disjointed and inefficient system of governance. The debate over federalism is likely to intensify in the coming months and years as the UK navigates the uncharted waters of Brexit. The outcome of this debate will have a profound impact on the future shape of the United Kingdom, determining whether it remains a centralized state or embraces a more decentralized and federal model of governance. It is worth noting that the idea of a federal UK is not a new one. In the early 20th century, there were significant movements in Scotland and Wales advocating for greater autonomy. In recent years, the Scottish National Party (SNP) has made federalism a central plank of its platform, arguing that it would allow Scotland to remain part of the UK while having greater control over its own affairs. Whether or not the UK ultimately adopts a federal system of government remains to be seen. However, the growing momentum behind this idea suggests that it is a debate that is likely to continue for some time to come.

title: Sean Turner: 'Lost opportunities' in care, rules inquest
text: A coroner has concluded that there were "lost opportunities" to intervene in the care of a man who died following a cardiac arrest in a mental health unit. Sean Turner, 30, suffered from paranoid schizophrenia and had been admitted to the Royal Sussex County Hospital in Brighton in May 2021 after expressing suicidal thoughts. An inquest into his death heard that he had missed several appointments with mental health services in the months leading up to his admission. The inquest also heard that Mr. Turner had been prescribed a number of medications, including antipsychotics and antidepressants. However, there was no evidence that he had taken any of these medications as prescribed. On the day of his death, Mr. Turner was found unresponsive in his room at the hospital. He was taken to the intensive care unit, where he died the following day. A post-mortem examination found that Mr. Turner had died from a cardiac arrest caused by a combination of factors, including obesity, sleep apnea, and the effects of drug use. The inquest heard that Mr. Turner had a history of drug and alcohol misuse. He had also been diagnosed with epilepsy and had learning disabilities. The coroner concluded that there had been a number of "lost opportunities" to intervene in Mr. Turner's care. He said that there had been a lack of communication between different services involved in his care, and that this had led to delays in him receiving appropriate treatment. The coroner also said that there was a need for better training for staff working in mental health units in how to manage patients with complex needs. He made a number of recommendations to improve the care of patients with mental health problems, including: Improved communication between different services involved in a patient's care Earlier intervention for patients with complex needs Better training for staff working in mental health units The coroner also recommended that the government review the current system of care for people with mental health problems.

title: Police outline security for G8 summit in Fermanagh
text: Police outline security for G8 summit in Fermanagh Police in Northern Ireland have outlined the security operation for the G8 summit in Fermanagh next month. The summit, which will bring together leaders from the world's eight most powerful countries, will be held at the Lough Erne Resort in Enniskillen from June 17-18. Assistant Chief Constable Alan Todd said the security operation would be "significant" but that it was important to strike a balance between protecting the summit and minimizing disruption to the local community. "We want to make sure that the summit is safe and secure, but we also want to make sure that it is a success for the people of Fermanagh and Northern Ireland," he said. The security operation will involve a number of measures, including: Road closures and traffic diversions around the Lough Erne Resort Increased police patrols in the area A security cordon around the resort Air and water patrols ACC Todd said the police would be working closely with the security services and other agencies to ensure the safety of the summit. "We have a proven track record of delivering safe and secure events in Northern Ireland, and we are confident that we will do so again for the G8 summit," he said. The G8 summit is expected to attract a large number of protesters, and the police have said they will be prepared for any potential demonstrations. ACC Todd said the police would respect the right to protest, but that they would not tolerate any violence or disorder. "We will work with the organizers of any protests to ensure that they are safe and peaceful," he said. The security operation for the G8 summit has been welcomed by local businesses and community groups. Fermanagh and Omagh District Council Chairman Thomas O'Reilly said the summit was a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity" for the area. "We are confident that the police will do everything they can to ensure that the summit is a success," he said.

title: Philippines president pledges Manila bus siege inquiry
text: Philippines President Pledges Manila Bus Siege Inquiry Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has vowed to conduct a thorough investigation into the deadly bus siege in Manila that claimed the lives of at least 25 people. Speaking to reporters at the scene of the incident, Marcos expressed his condolences to the families of the victims and condemned the attack. "This is a cowardly and senseless act of violence that has no place in our society," Marcos said. "We will leave no stone unturned in our efforts to bring the perpetrators to justice." The siege began on Monday when a former policeman, identified as Rolando Mendoza, boarded a public bus in the Manila suburb of Pasay. Mendoza then took all the passengers hostage, demanding the reinstatement of his job in the police force. Authorities responded to the incident and attempted to negotiate with Mendoza. However, after several hours of unsuccessful negotiations, police stormed the bus, ending the siege. Mendoza and 24 hostages were killed in the operation. Marcos said that the investigation into the siege would focus on several key areas, including the police response to the incident, the motive behind the attack, and the screening process for police officers. "We need to determine if there were any lapses or deficiencies in our response that could have contributed to the loss of life," Marcos said. "We also need to understand why Mendoza carried out this attack and whether there are any underlying issues within the police force that need to be addressed." Marcos said that the results of the investigation would be made public and that he would take any necessary action to prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future. "We owe it to the victims and their families to ensure that this does not happen again," Marcos said. "We will work tirelessly to make sure that justice is served and that the safety of our citizens is protected." The bus siege has shocked the Philippines and raised concerns about the security situation in the country. Marcos has promised to take all necessary steps to address these concerns and ensure the safety of the public.

title: Trump wiretap claims: Senator makes subpoena threat to FBI
text: In a dramatic escalation of the clash between the Trump administration and Congress, Senator Lindsey Graham has threatened to subpoena the FBI over the President's claims that his phones were wiretapped by former President Barack Obama. Graham, a Republican who chairs the Senate Judiciary Committee, said he would issue the subpoena if the FBI did not provide his panel with documents and testimony related to the wiretapping allegations. "We're going to subpoena the FBI if we don't get the information we need," Graham told reporters on Capitol Hill. "We're not going to stand for this." The FBI has denied the President's claims, and there is no evidence to support them. But Trump has continued to repeat the allegations, and he has accused the FBI of being biased against him. Graham's threat is a significant development, as it marks the first time that a Republican lawmaker has publicly threatened to subpoena the FBI over the wiretapping allegations. It is also a sign of the growing frustration among some Republicans with the Trump administration's handling of the Russia investigation. Trump has repeatedly attacked the FBI, and he has called for the firing of FBI Director James Comey. Comey has been leading the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election, and he has been critical of Trump's handling of the probe. Graham's threat is likely to put further pressure on the FBI to provide Congress with more information about the wiretapping allegations. It could also lead to a showdown between the FBI and Congress, as the FBI has indicated that it is not willing to provide Congress with all of the information it has related to the investigation. The wiretapping allegations are just one of a number of issues that are causing tension between the Trump administration and Congress. Congress is also investigating the Trump administration's ties to Russia, and it is looking into the President's business dealings. The Trump administration has been accused of stonewalling Congress's investigations, and it has refused to provide Congress with some of the documents and testimony that it has requested. The clash between the Trump administration and Congress is likely to continue for the foreseeable future. It is unclear how the conflict will be resolved, but it is clear that the two branches of government are on a collision course.

title: Trump lawyer 'pressed Oval Office to release gold dealer'
text: Revelations in the House January 6 Committee's final report allege that former President Donald Trump's lawyer, John Eastman, pressured senior White House staff in the waning days of his administration to release a gold dealer who was arrested with $2 million in gold bars. According to the report released on December 20, 2022, Eastman made multiple calls to the White House Counsel's Office, urging the release of the dealer, who was identified as Nicolas Goureau. Goureau was arrested by the FBI on January 6, 2021, on suspicion of smuggling gold from Guinea to the United States. The report states that Eastman argued that Goureau's release was necessary to secure evidence related to alleged election fraud. This was a strategy pursued by Trump and his allies to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election. However, senior White House staff, including Pat Cipollone, declined to intervene in the case, citing concerns about the legality of such a move. The Department of Justice also opposed the release of Goureau, arguing that he posed a flight risk and was involved in criminal activity. The report's findings raise questions about the extent to which Trump and his allies were willing to go to undermine the rule of law in the aftermath of the 2020 election. It also suggests that Eastman may have been involved in a broader effort to use the Justice Department to advance Trump's personal and political interests. In addition to the allegations regarding Goureau, the January 6 Committee report also detailed Eastman's efforts to pressure then-Vice President Mike Pence to overturn the election results. Eastman argued that Pence had the authority to reject electoral votes from states where Trump alleged widespread fraud, but Pence ultimately declined to do so. The committee's report is a comprehensive account of the events leading up to and including the January 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. The report has been praised by some for its thoroughness and damning conclusions, while others have criticized it for its partisan nature. The Justice Department is currently investigating Eastman's actions, as well as those of other Trump allies who were involved in efforts to overturn the election results. It is unclear whether Eastman will face criminal charges, but the report's findings may provide the basis for further legal action.

title: Brexit worker issues 'could shut offshore platforms'
text: Brexit worker issues 'could shut offshore platforms' amid fears thousands of jobs could be lost due to new rules. The oil and gas industry has warned that new immigration rules could lead to the closure of offshore platforms in the UK, with the loss of thousands of jobs. Under the new rules, which came into effect on 1 January 2021, EU citizens who want to work in the UK need to have a job offer that pays a minimum salary of £25,600 and have a certain level of English language proficiency. The industry says that these requirements will make it difficult to recruit and retain the skilled workers it needs, particularly in remote locations such as offshore platforms. A survey by industry body Oil & Gas UK found that 80% of companies are concerned about the impact of the new rules on their ability to operate. One company, which operates a number of offshore platforms in the North Sea, said that it could be forced to close one of its platforms if it is unable to recruit enough skilled workers. The company said that it needs to recruit around 100 new workers each year, but that it is now struggling to fill these vacancies. "The new immigration rules are making it very difficult for us to recruit the skilled workers we need," said a spokesman for the company. "We are particularly concerned about the impact of the new rules on our ability to operate our offshore platforms, which are essential to the UK's energy security." The government has said that it is aware of the concerns of the oil and gas industry and is working to address them. A spokesman for the Home Office said: "We are working with the oil and gas industry to ensure that they have access to the skilled workers they need." "We have already made a number of changes to the immigration rules to help the industry, including reducing the minimum salary requirement for skilled workers in shortage occupations." However, the industry says that more needs to be done. "The government needs to do more to address the concerns of the oil and gas industry," said Mike Tholen, the CEO of Oil & Gas UK. "The new immigration rules are a serious threat to the UK's energy security and the government needs to take action to ensure that the industry has access to the skilled workers it needs."

title: Plea to park safely to help guide dogs and their owners
text: Plea to park safely to help guide dogs and their owners Guide dogs provide invaluable assistance to people with sight loss, helping them navigate the world safely and confidently. However, inconsiderate parking can create significant obstacles for these dogs and their owners. When parking, it's crucial to leave enough space for guide dogs to pass safely. This means avoiding parking too close to dropped kerbs, pedestrian crossings, and any areas where guide dogs need to manoeuvre. Blocking dropped kerbs forces guide dogs and their owners to navigate busy roads without the protection of a tactile surface. Similarly, parking near pedestrian crossings prevents them from using the audible signals that help them cross safely. In addition to leaving adequate space, it's important to avoid parking on pavements. Guide dogs rely on pavements as their safe zone, as they can confidently walk along them without fear of obstacles. Parking on pavements forces them into the road, exposing them to traffic and other hazards. Parking safely not only benefits guide dogs and their owners but also contributes to a more inclusive society. By creating a more accessible environment, we can ensure that people with sight loss can participate fully in community life. Guide dogs and their owners often have a specific routine, and inconsiderate parking can disrupt this routine and cause stress and anxiety. For example, if a guide dog and its owner are used to crossing at a particular pedestrian crossing but a car is parked too close, they may have to go a long way out of their way to find another crossing point. There are a number of simple things drivers can do to help guide dogs and their owners: Leave enough space for guide dogs to pass safely at dropped kerbs, pedestrian crossings, and pavements. Avoid parking on pavements. Be aware of guide dogs and their owners when you are driving. Give them plenty of space and time to cross the road. By following these simple guidelines, drivers can make a significant difference to the lives of guide dogs and their owners. It's a small gesture that can make a big impact.

title: Suicide in men 'highest since 2001'
text: Suicide in Men 'Highest Since 2001' Suicide rates among men in England and Wales have reached their highest level since 2001, new figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) show. There were 5,691 suicides registered in 2021, up from 5,239 in 2020. This represents a rate of 16.6 deaths per 100,000 men, compared to 4.9 per 100,000 women. The increase in male suicides follows a long-term trend that has seen rates rise since the early 1980s. In 2001, the rate was 15.5 deaths per 100,000 men. The ONS figures show that suicide is the leading cause of death for men under the age of 50. In 2021, there were 1,635 suicides among men aged 20-49, a rate of 24.9 deaths per 100,000. The reasons for the rise in male suicide rates are complex and not fully understood. However, some factors that have been linked to suicide include: Mental health problems, such as depression and anxiety Substance abuse Financial difficulties Relationship problems Work-related stress The ONS figures also show that suicide rates vary significantly across different parts of England and Wales. The highest rates are in the North East of England, where there were 20.9 deaths per 100,000 men in 2021. The lowest rates are in the South East, where there were 12.7 deaths per 100,000 men. Experts have called for more to be done to prevent suicide among men. This includes investing in mental health services, providing support for people with financial difficulties, and raising awareness of the issue. Tom Madders, head of campaigns at the mental health charity Mind, said: "These figures are a stark reminder that suicide remains a major issue in our society. We need to do more to support men who are struggling with their mental health and to create a society where they feel comfortable seeking help." If you are struggling with suicidal thoughts, there is help available. You can call the Samaritans on 116 123 or email them at jo@samaritans.org.

title: Android for wearables coming, says Google software boss
text: Android for wearables coming, says Google software boss Google's software boss has said that Android will be coming to wearables. Speaking at the Code/Mobile conference in Half Moon Bay, California, Sundar Pichai said that Android is "the best platform" for wearables because it is "open and flexible." "We think Android is the best platform for wearables because it's open and flexible," Pichai said. "We're working with a number of partners to bring Android to a range of wearable devices." Pichai did not provide any specific details about which wearables Android will be coming to, or when. However, he said that Google is "excited about the potential of wearables" and that the company believes that they will "play a major role in the future of computing." The news that Android is coming to wearables is not surprising. Google has been working on a version of Android for wearables for some time, and the company has already released a number of developer tools for the platform. However, Pichai's comments are the first time that Google has publicly confirmed that Android will be coming to wearables. The move by Google to bring Android to wearables is a significant one. Android is the most popular mobile operating system in the world, and its arrival on wearables will give Google a major advantage in the market. Wearables are a rapidly growing market, and they are expected to become even more popular in the coming years. By bringing Android to wearables, Google is positioning itself to be a major player in this market. The news of Android's arrival on wearables is also good news for consumers. Android is a powerful and versatile operating system, and it will give consumers a wide range of choices when it comes to wearables. Consumers will be able to choose from a variety of Android-powered wearables, including watches, glasses, and fitness trackers. They will also be able to choose from a wide range of apps and services that are designed for wearables. The arrival of Android on wearables is a major development in the wearable computing market. It is a sign that Google is committed to this market, and it is a sign that wearables are becoming more mainstream.

title: Woman hatches ducks from Waitrose eggs
text: A woman from Devon has successfully hatched six ducklings from eggs she bought at her local Waitrose supermarket. Becky Goldsmith, from Topsham, decided to try hatching eggs after seeing a video online. She bought 12 duck eggs from Waitrose and put them in an incubator. To her surprise, six of the eggs hatched and she now has six healthy ducklings. Becky said: "I was really surprised when they hatched. I didn't think they would because they were from the supermarket. "But they're all doing really well now. They're eating and drinking and they're starting to grow feathers." Becky has named the ducklings after characters from the Winnie the Pooh stories. She said: "I've called them Pooh, Piglet, Eeyore, Tigger, Rabbit and Owl. "They're all really cute and I'm really enjoying looking after them." Becky is now planning to keep the ducklings until they are old enough to be released into the wild. She said: "I'm going to keep them for a few months until they're big enough to look after themselves. "Then I'll release them into a local pond." A Waitrose spokesperson said: "We're delighted to hear that Becky has been able to hatch ducklings from our eggs. "We sell a wide range of fresh eggs, including duck eggs, and we're always happy to hear from our customers about their experiences with our products." Experts say that it is possible to hatch ducklings from supermarket eggs, but it is not always successful. They say that the eggs need to be fresh and fertile, and they need to be incubated at the correct temperature and humidity. If the eggs are not incubated correctly, the ducklings may not hatch or they may be born with deformities.

title: Asian markets rally on Covid-19 vaccine hopes
text: Asian markets rallied on Monday on growing optimism over progress in the development of a Covid-19 vaccine. The positive sentiment was boosted by news that Moderna's vaccine candidate had shown promising results in early-stage human trials. The US biotech firm said its vaccine produced antibodies in all 45 volunteers who were given two doses, and that no serious side effects were reported. The news sent Moderna's shares soaring by more than 25% in pre-market trading. It also lifted other stocks in the healthcare sector, with shares in Pfizer and BioNTech, which are also developing a vaccine, rising by more than 5%. The positive sentiment spread to Asian markets, with the Nikkei 225 in Japan closing up 1.7%, the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong rising 1.5%, and the Shanghai Composite Index in China gaining 1.2%. Analysts said the news about Moderna's vaccine was a major boost for investors, who have been looking for positive news on the Covid-19 front. "The Moderna news is a very positive development," said Vishnu Varathan, head of economics and strategy at Mizuho Bank. "It gives investors hope that a vaccine could be available sooner rather than later." However, analysts also cautioned that it was still too early to tell whether Moderna's vaccine would be effective and safe in the long term. "We need to see the results of larger trials before we can be sure that the vaccine is effective," said Stephen Innes, chief market strategist at AxiCorp. "But the news from Moderna is definitely a step in the right direction." The rally in Asian markets also came on the back of positive economic data from China. The country's official manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) rose to 50.6 in May, up from 50.1 in April. This was the first time the PMI had risen above 50 since December 2019, indicating that the Chinese economy is starting to recover from the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The positive economic data from China also helped to boost investor sentiment in other Asian markets. "The PMI data from China is another sign that the global economy is starting to recover," said Varathan. "This is good news for Asian markets, which are heavily dependent on trade with China." Overall, the positive news on the Covid-19 vaccine front and the improving economic data from China helped to boost investor sentiment in Asian markets on Monday. However, analysts cautioned that it was still too early to say whether the rally would be sustained in the long term.

title: Government appoints new Doncaster Council chief
text: The government has appointed a new chief executive for Doncaster Council, it has been announced. Jo Miller, the current chief executive of North Lincolnshire Council, will take up the post in Doncaster in the new year. She replaces Damian Allen, who left the council in July after just 18 months in the role. Ms Miller has more than 25 years' experience in local government, and has held senior positions at a number of councils, including Leeds City Council and Wakefield Council. She said she was "delighted" to have been appointed to the role, and said she was "looking forward to working with the council and the community to make a real difference to the lives of people in Doncaster". "I am passionate about public service and believe that local government has a vital role to play in improving the lives of people and communities," she said. "I am committed to working with the council and the community to deliver the best possible services for Doncaster." The appointment of Ms Miller has been welcomed by Doncaster Council leader, Ros Jones. She said: "I am delighted to welcome Jo to Doncaster. She has a wealth of experience in local government and a proven track record of success. "I am confident that she will be an excellent asset to the council and the community, and I look forward to working with her to make Doncaster a better place to live, work and visit." Ms Miller's appointment comes at a time when Doncaster Council is facing a number of challenges, including budget cuts and a high level of deprivation. But she said she was confident that the council could overcome these challenges and deliver a better future for Doncaster. "I am aware of the challenges facing Doncaster Council, but I am confident that we can overcome them and deliver a better future for the borough," she said. "I am committed to working with the council and the community to make Doncaster a place where everyone can thrive."

title: Selfridges to offer clothing rental in environmental push
text: Selfridges to Offer Clothing Rental in Environmental Push In a major move to promote sustainable fashion, luxury department store Selfridges is launching a clothing rental service. The initiative, called "The Rental," will offer customers the opportunity to borrow designer pieces for a monthly fee, rather than buying them outright. The move comes amid growing concerns about the environmental impact of the fashion industry. The production and disposal of clothing generates significant amounts of greenhouse gases, water pollution, and waste. By encouraging customers to rent rather than buy, Selfridges hopes to reduce its environmental footprint. The Rental will feature a curated collection of over 500 pieces from various luxury brands, including Victoria Beckham, Stella McCartney, and Alexander McQueen. Customers can rent items for a period of four, eight, or twelve weeks, and can choose to have them delivered to their homes or picked up in-store. To ensure the longevity of the rented garments, Selfridges has partnered with leading clothing care company Oxwash. Oxwash uses eco-friendly cleaning methods and repairs items as needed to keep them in pristine condition. Selfridges' decision to offer a clothing rental service is part of a broader strategy to promote sustainable practices. The department store has already implemented a number of initiatives, including banning single-use plastics, reducing energy consumption, and supporting ethical suppliers. The launch of The Rental has been welcomed by environmental groups. "This is a positive step towards making the fashion industry more sustainable," said Sarah Kent, head of campaigns at Greenpeace UK. "By offering clothing rental, Selfridges is making it easier for consumers to reduce their environmental impact." Customers have also expressed enthusiasm for the new service. "I'm really excited about The Rental," said Sarah Jones, a Selfridges customer. "It's a great way to access designer fashion without breaking the bank or harming the environment." The Rental is expected to be a major success for Selfridges. The department store believes that the service will appeal to a wide range of customers, including those who are looking to reduce their environmental impact, those who want to experiment with different styles, and those who are looking for a more affordable way to access designer fashion.

title: Nine Journalists killed since 2006 - Dinesh
text: Nine Journalists Killed Since 2006 - Dinesh Dinesh Kumar Upadhyay, a freelance journalist from Madhya Pradesh, India, was brutally murdered on January 24, 2023. He became the ninth journalist killed in the country since 2006, highlighting the dangerous and often deadly climate for journalists in India. Dinesh's life was tragically cut short at the age of 44. He was known for his fearless reporting on corruption, crime, and social issues in his home state. His murder shocked his family, colleagues, and the entire journalistic community. The motive behind Dinesh's murder remains unclear, but it is widely believed that his work as a journalist played a role. He had been facing threats and intimidation for years and had recently filed a complaint with the police about the harassment he was experiencing. Dinesh's murder is a stark reminder of the risks journalists face when they dare to speak truth to power. Journalists in India operate in an atmosphere of fear, where physical attacks, threats, and legal harassment are not uncommon. Since 2006, the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) has documented the murders of nine journalists in India: 2006: Chandrasekaran Balasubramaniam, Tamil Nadu 2007: Sai Reddy, Andhra Pradesh 2010: Jagendra Singh, Uttar Pradesh 2012: Rajesh Verma, Chhattisgarh 2013: Akhilesh Pratap Singh, Bihar 2015: Gauri Lankesh, Karnataka 2017: Shantanu Bhowmick, Tripura 2018: Shubham Mani Tripathi, Uttar Pradesh 2023: Dinesh Kumar Upadhyay, Madhya Pradesh The CPJ believes that these journalists were killed because of their work, making India one of the deadliest countries in the world for journalists. The killings of journalists in India have a chilling effect on freedom of expression. Journalists are afraid to report on sensitive issues or challenge powerful figures for fear of retaliation. This undermines democracy and the public's right to know. The Indian government has a responsibility to ensure the safety of journalists and to hold those responsible for their murders accountable. If the government fails to take action, the killings of journalists will continue, silencing voices and stifling dissent.

title: More than 60,000 waiting to join Scouts amid 'volunteer shortage'
text: Amidst a surge in youth enrollment, the iconic youth organization, the Scouts, grapples with a concerning shortage of adult volunteers, leaving over 60,000 young individuals eager to join but unable to do so. The Scouts, renowned for fostering leadership, teamwork, and outdoor adventure, has seen a surge in applications. However, the organization's ability to accommodate these aspiring Scouts is severely hindered by the lack of adult volunteers to lead and supervise groups. "We have a real crisis on our hands," said Matt Hyde, the Scouts' chief executive. "The demand for Scouting is soaring, but we simply don't have enough adults to make it happen." The volunteer shortage stems from a variety of factors, including societal changes, increased demands on time, and a lack of awareness about the benefits of volunteering with the Scouts. "People are busier than ever these days, and it can be hard to find the time to volunteer," said Hyde. "But the Scouts is an incredibly rewarding experience, both for the young people and for the adults who support them." Compounding the challenge is a decline in traditional recruitment methods. Once upon a time, many adults would learn about Scouting through their children or by attending local events. However, with the rise of social media and other digital distractions, it has become more difficult to reach potential volunteers. The lack of adult volunteers is not only preventing young people from joining the Scouts but also impacting existing groups. With fewer adults to lead and supervise activities, some units have been forced to reduce their programs or even close down. "It's heart-wrenching to see young people so eager to join the Scouts but not being able to because we don't have the adults to support them," said Hyde. "We need people to step forward and help us give these young people the chance to experience all that the Scouts has to offer." The Scouts is appealing for adults from all walks of life to consider volunteering. No prior Scouting experience is necessary, and flexible volunteering options are available to accommodate busy schedules. "Volunteering with the Scouts is a fantastic way to make a real difference in the lives of young people," said Hyde. "It's an opportunity to inspire, support, and nurture the next generation of leaders." With over 60,000 young people waiting to join the Scouts, the organization is urging adults to consider volunteering and help bridge the gap. By supporting the Scouts, adults can empower young people with essential life skills and foster a brighter future for the entire community.

title: Johnson and Corbyn poisonous, says Welsh Lib Dem MP
text: The toxic political atmosphere in Westminster is damaging democratic debate and deterring people from entering politics, a Welsh MP has said. Liberal Democrat Jane Dodds said the personal attacks and "demonisation" of political opponents by Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn had made it "increasingly difficult" to have constructive discussions about the issues facing the country. "People are being put off from entering politics because they don't want to subject themselves to the level of abuse that is now commonplace," she said. "This is a very worrying trend and it is something that we need to address urgently." Dodds, who is the MP for Brecon and Radnorshire, said the "nastiness" of the political debate was "damaging our democracy" and "making it harder for people to make informed decisions about who to vote for". "We need to find a way to have more respectful and constructive debates about the issues that matter to people," she said. "We need to find a way to disagree without being disagreeable." Dodds' comments come after a series of bitter exchanges between Johnson and Corbyn in the House of Commons. In one memorable incident, Johnson accused Corbyn of being a "chicken" for refusing to call a general election. Corbyn retorted by calling Johnson a "coward" for hiding from scrutiny. The two leaders have also traded insults on social media, with Johnson calling Corbyn a "Marxist" and Corbyn calling Johnson a "liar". The Liberal Democrats have long called for a more civil and respectful tone in political debate. In 2017, the party launched a campaign called "Stop the Smears" which aimed to tackle the spread of misinformation and personal attacks in politics. Dodds said the campaign was "more relevant than ever" in the current political climate. "We need to find a way to restore trust in our political system," she said. "We need to find a way to have more respectful and constructive debates about the issues that matter to people. "We need to find a way to disagree without being disagreeable."

title: Ai Weiwei show at Royal Academy to house heaviest sculpture
text: Ai Weiwei's daring exhibition at the Royal Academy of Arts, London, has pushed the boundaries of sculpture by housing one of the heaviest ever created. Weighing an astonishing 15 tonnes, the monumental "Snake Ceiling" is a testament to the artist's relentless exploration of power, history, and social justice. Crafted from stainless steel, the serpentine structure hangs suspended from the ceiling, its coils slithering through the grand galleries like a celestial serpent. Its immense weight necessitates reinforced beams and bespoke engineering solutions, highlighting the awe-inspiring feat of architectural collaboration that brought it to life. Weiwei meticulously handcrafted the individual components of the snake, assembling them with exquisite precision. The result is a seamless, undulating form that defies gravity, inviting viewers to contemplate the interplay between the physical and the intangible. The snake has been a recurring motif in Weiwei's work, often symbolizing authority, repression, and the struggle for freedom. In "Snake Ceiling," the artist draws parallels between the serpentine form and the sinuous trajectory of history, where progress is often accompanied by setbacks and resilience. The exhibition, titled "History of Bombs," delves into the destructive power of warfare and the human cost of conflict. Weiwei's iconic "Forever Bicycles" installation, featuring thousands of recycled bicycles hanging from the ceiling, evokes the fragility of life and the collective spirit of resistance. Another highlight is "Bang," a massive explosion depicted using 2000 porcelain tiles. The work epitomizes Weiwei's critique of the commodification of suffering and the tendency to distance ourselves from the horrors that unfold in distant lands. Through his bold and provocative sculptures, Weiwei challenges conventional notions of art and engages with pressing social and political issues. His work forces us to confront uncomfortable truths and question the intricate web of power structures that shape our world. The Royal Academy exhibition provides a unique opportunity to witness the transformative power of Ai Weiwei's art firsthand. His monumental "Snake Ceiling" is a breathtaking testament to the artist's ingenuity, technical prowess, and unwavering commitment to using art as a catalyst for change.

title: Two Door Cinema Club's Lady Gaga remix 'total surprise'
text: Two Door Cinema Club's remix of Lady Gaga's "Babylon" is a surprising and infectious departure from the original. The Northern Irish trio's signature blend of indie pop and electronica transforms Gaga's brooding anthem into an effervescent dancefloor banger. The remix opens with a flurry of synthesized arpeggios, setting the stage for Gaga's ethereal vocals. However, as the track progresses, Two Door Cinema Club's influence becomes increasingly apparent. The drums become more pronounced, propelling the song forward with an irresistible groove. The synths take on a more playful tone, adding layers of shimmering textures that dance around Gaga's voice. One of the most striking aspects of the remix is the way it highlights Gaga's vocal prowess. Stripped of the original's bombastic production, her voice shines through with a raw power that is both vulnerable and commanding. Two Door Cinema Club's production provides a perfect backdrop for Gaga's vocals, allowing them to soar and soar. The remix also features a subtle but effective rework of the song's lyrics. Gaga's original line "I'm living in a world that's made of glass" becomes "I'm living in a world that's made of dreams." This slight change shifts the song's focus from one of despair to one of hope and possibility. Overall, Two Door Cinema Club's remix of "Babylon" is a triumph. It takes a beloved song and reinvents it in a way that is both faithful to the original and uniquely their own. The remix is a testament to Two Door Cinema Club's versatility as musicians and their ability to create music that is both infectious and thought-provoking. The remix has been met with widespread critical acclaim. Rolling Stone called it "a dancefloor-ready banger that will have you moving all night long." Pitchfork praised the remix's "playful and infectious" production, while The Guardian said it was "a stunning reinterpretation of Gaga's classic." Two Door Cinema Club's remix of "Babylon" is a total surprise, but it is also a total triumph. It is a testament to the band's creativity and their ability to create music that is both catchy and meaningful.

title: New evidence could solve 1990 Oxfordshire taxi murder
text: New evidence could solve 1990 Oxfordshire taxi murder Detectives investigating the unsolved murder of a taxi driver in Oxfordshire in 1990 are appealing for information after new evidence came to light. John Terry, 34, was found dead in his cab in Benson, south Oxfordshire, on 31 August 1990. He had been stabbed multiple times. The murder weapon has never been found, and despite extensive inquiries, no-one has ever been charged with his killing. However, Thames Valley Police said new forensic techniques had been used to examine Mr. Terry's clothing, and that had led to significant developments in the case. The force said it had identified a partial DNA profile that did not belong to Mr. Terry or his family. Det Ch Insp Stuart Bosley, who is leading the investigation, said this was a "significant development" in the case. He said: "This is one of the most important pieces of evidence we have obtained in this case. "We are now working to establish the identity of the person to whom this DNA belongs." Det Ch Insp Bosley said the profile was "very unique" and that it was likely to belong to the killer. He said: "We are confident that this DNA will lead us to the person responsible for John Terry's murder." The police said they were also appealing for anyone who may have seen Mr. Terry's cab in the Benson area on the night of his murder to come forward. Det Ch Insp Bosley said: "We believe that there are people out there who may have information that could help us solve this case. "We are asking them to come forward and speak to us." Mr. Terry's family said they were "delighted" that the police were making progress in the case. In a statement, they said: "We have never given up hope that John's killer would be caught. "This news gives us hope that we will finally get justice for John." Anyone with information about the case is asked to contact Thames Valley Police on 101, quoting reference number 43220381071.

title: Pinewood marks first year in Wales
text: Pinewood marks first year in Wales, creating more than 600 jobs and investing over £100 million Pinewood Group celebrates its first anniversary in Wales, marking a successful year of growth and investment in the region. Since establishing a presence in Cardiff in 2022, Pinewood has created over 600 jobs and invested more than £100 million in the area. The company's investment has been instrumental in the development of Wales' creative industries sector, supporting local businesses and attracting major productions to the region. Pinewood's world-class facilities and expertise have been utilised by numerous high-profile projects, including the upcoming BBC drama "Stonehouse". "Our first year in Wales has exceeded our expectations," said Pinewood Group CEO Paul Golding. "The region has a wealth of talent, a supportive business environment, and a growing reputation as a hub for film and television production. We are proud to be part of this thriving industry and look forward to continuing our investment and growth in Wales." The Welsh Government has welcomed Pinewood's decision to establish a base in Cardiff, recognising the significant economic and cultural benefits it brings to the region. "Pinewood's investment is a major boost to the Welsh economy and our creative industries sector," said Welsh Economy Minister Vaughan Gething. "The company's presence has created hundreds of jobs and attracted major productions to Wales, showcasing our world-class facilities and talent to a global audience." Pinewood's commitment to Wales extends beyond its investment in physical infrastructure. The company is also actively engaged in supporting local businesses and nurturing emerging talent. Through its Pinewood Studios Wales Academy, the company provides training and development opportunities to aspiring filmmakers and professionals in the region. "Our academy is a vital part of our investment in Wales," said Pinewood Studios Wales Managing Director Jason Hardisty. "We are committed to developing the next generation of filmmakers and ensuring that Wales has a sustainable and thriving creative industries sector for years to come." As Pinewood looks ahead to its second year in Wales, the company remains optimistic about the future of the region's creative industries. The company plans to continue investing in its facilities and workforce, while also exploring new opportunities for growth and collaboration with local businesses and partners. "We believe that Wales has the potential to become a major player in the global film and television industry," said Golding. "Pinewood is committed to working with the Welsh Government, local businesses, and the talented people of Wales to make this a reality."

title: Brittan widow attacks Met over abuse claims handling
text: A British widow has criticized the Metropolitan Police's handling of her husband's abuse claims, saying the force failed to investigate properly and protect him. Carl Beech, a former serviceman, was found dead in his cell in 2021 while awaiting trial for fraud. He had made a series of allegations of abuse against senior political and military figures, but these were later found to be false. His wife, Laura Beech, said she had repeatedly raised concerns about her husband's mental health with the police, but they had not taken her seriously. She said she had also been harassed and intimidated by police officers. "I feel like I've been let down by the police," she said. "They should have been protecting my husband, but they didn't. They treated him like a criminal, and they treated me like a nuisance." The Met has said it is "deeply sorry" for the way Mrs. Beech was treated. It said it has since changed its procedures for dealing with victims of abuse. However, Mrs. Beech said she does not believe that the Met has gone far enough. She said she wants to see a full public inquiry into the force's handling of her husband's case. "I want to know why the police didn't investigate my husband's allegations properly," she said. "I want to know why they harassed and intimidated me. And I want to know what the Met is going to do to make sure that this never happens again." The Met has said it is "cooperating fully" with the Independent Office for Police Conduct, which is investigating the force's handling of the Beech case. The Beech case has raised serious questions about the Met's handling of abuse allegations. It has also highlighted the importance of providing support to victims of abuse. Mrs. Beech's story is a reminder that victims of abuse often face significant challenges in getting their voices heard. It is also a reminder that the police have a duty to protect victims of abuse, and to investigate allegations of abuse thoroughly.

title: CWU says Royal Mail workers 'certain' to back strike
text: Royal Mail workers are "certain" to back strike action in a row over pay, the Communication Workers Union (CWU) has said. The union's general secretary, Dave Ward, said members were "angry" and "determined" to take action after Royal Mail offered a 2% pay rise, which it said was "the best it can afford". The CWU is demanding a 10% pay increase, arguing that workers deserve a "fair share" of the company's profits. Royal Mail has said it is "disappointed" by the union's decision to ballot for strike action, and that it believes its pay offer is "fair and affordable". The strike ballot will open on 24 August and close on 14 September. If members vote in favour of strike action, it could take place as early as the end of September. In a statement, Ward said: "Royal Mail workers are angry. They are determined to take action to defend their livelihoods and their futures. "Royal Mail has made huge profits while our members have been struggling to make ends meet. We are demanding a fair share of the company's success." Royal Mail said in a statement: "We are disappointed that the CWU has decided to ballot for industrial action. We believe our pay offer is fair and affordable, and we are committed to continuing our discussions with the union." The strike ballot comes at a time of growing industrial unrest in the UK, with workers in a number of sectors, including rail, health and education, taking action or threatening to do so over pay and conditions. The TUC has said that the cost-of-living crisis is "pushing workers to the brink", and that the government needs to do more to support them. The government has said that it understands the challenges that workers are facing, but that it is "committed to taking responsible action to help people with the cost of living". The strike ballot by Royal Mail workers is likely to be closely watched by other unions and employers, as it could set a precedent for pay settlements in other sectors.

title: London Stock Exchange resumes trading after glitch
text: London Stock Exchange Resumes Trading After Glitch The London Stock Exchange (LSE) has resumed trading after a technical glitch forced it to suspend operations for several hours. The issue, which affected the exchange's trading platform, emerged shortly after the market opened on Tuesday morning. As a result, no trading could take place, causing significant disruption for investors and brokers. The LSE quickly responded to the situation, launching an investigation into the cause of the glitch. In the meantime, trading was suspended on both the main market and the AIM alternative investment market. The issue was eventually resolved, and trading resumed at 10:45 BST. The LSE said in a statement that it "sincerely apologizes for the inconvenience caused to our members and other market participants." The glitch is the latest in a series of technical issues that have plagued the LSE in recent years. In 2019, the exchange suffered a major outage that halted trading for more than six hours. The incident led to a sharp decline in the LSE's share price and raised questions about the resilience of its systems. The LSE has since invested heavily in upgrading its infrastructure and improving its resilience to technical glitches. However, the latest issue highlights the challenges that exchanges face in maintaining smooth and reliable operations in an increasingly complex and interconnected market environment. The suspension of trading on the LSE had a ripple effect across the global financial markets. Investors were left unable to trade UK stocks, while brokers faced difficulties executing orders. The incident also raised concerns about the vulnerability of financial exchanges to cyberattacks and other disruptions. The LSE is one of the world's largest stock exchanges, with a market capitalization of over £3 trillion. It is also a major hub for international finance, with many of the world's largest companies listed on its markets. The glitch is likely to raise questions about the LSE's ability to compete with other global exchanges, such as the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq. Investors may be hesitant to trade on the LSE if they are concerned about the risk of future technical disruptions. The LSE is expected to release a full report on the causes of the glitch in due course. The exchange is also likely to face increased scrutiny from regulators and other stakeholders as it seeks to restore confidence in its operations.

title: Covid-19: Ministers urged to ban 'reckless' evictions over rent arrears
text: Ministers are being urged to introduce a ban on "reckless" evictions over rent arrears that have accrued during the Covid-19 pandemic. A cross-party group of MPs and peers is calling for the government to act now to prevent a wave of homelessness as the country emerges from lockdown. In a letter to Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick, the group warns that many tenants have built up significant rent arrears due to job losses and reduced incomes during the pandemic. They say that without government intervention, these tenants could face eviction from their homes, even if they are making efforts to repay their debt. The letter is signed by Labour's shadow housing secretary, Thangam Debbonaire, the Lib Dems' housing spokesperson, Daisy Cooper, and the Green Party's housing spokesperson, Caroline Lucas. It is also backed by a number of Conservative MPs, including Bob Blackman, Crispin Blunt, and Sir Peter Bottomley. The group says that the government must act now to prevent a "public health disaster" as well as a homelessness crisis. They are calling for a ban on evictions for rent arrears that have accrued during the pandemic, as well as financial support for tenants who are struggling to pay their rent. The government has already introduced a number of measures to help tenants during the pandemic, including a ban on evictions for non-payment of rent until the end of March 2021 and a £435 million hardship fund for tenants who are struggling to pay their rent. However, the group of MPs and peers say that these measures do not go far enough and that more needs to be done to prevent a wave of homelessness. They warn that the government's current approach is "reckless" and that it will lead to a "public health disaster" as well as a homelessness crisis. The government has said that it is "committed to protecting renters" and that it will "continue to monitor the situation closely". However, the group of MPs and peers say that the government needs to act now to prevent a homelessness crisis. They say that the government must introduce a ban on evictions for rent arrears that have accrued during the pandemic, as well as financial support for tenants who are struggling to pay their rent.

title: Israel 'thwarts Hezbollah infiltration from Lebanon'
text: Israeli forces thwarted an attempted infiltration by Hezbollah militants from Lebanon into northern Israel on Saturday, the military said. The incident occurred near the town of Metula, where Israeli troops detected a group of armed men crossing the border fence. The troops opened fire, killing one of the militants and wounding another. The remaining militants fled back into Lebanon. The Israeli military said that the militants were carrying weapons and explosives, and that they were likely planning to carry out an attack in Israel. "This incident is a clear violation of Israeli sovereignty," said Lieutenant Colonel Jonathan Conricus, a spokesman for the Israeli military. "We will not tolerate any attempts to infiltrate our borders or to harm our citizens." Hezbollah is a Lebanese Shiite militant group that is backed by Iran. The group has fought several wars with Israel, and it is considered to be one of the most powerful non-state armed groups in the world. The attempted infiltration comes at a time of heightened tensions between Israel and Lebanon. In recent months, there have been several incidents of cross-border fire between the two countries. The Israeli military has been on high alert since the beginning of the year, after a series of rocket attacks on Israel from Lebanon. The Israeli military has responded to these attacks by carrying out airstrikes on Hezbollah targets in Lebanon. The Lebanese government has condemned the Israeli airstrikes, and it has called on the United Nations to intervene. The United Nations has called for a ceasefire between Israel and Lebanon, but both sides have so far refused to comply. The situation between Israel and Lebanon remains tense, and there is a risk of further escalation. The Israeli military is on high alert, and it is prepared to respond to any threats from Hezbollah.

title: Apple Irish tax case appeal heard by EU court
text: The European Court of Justice (ECJ) has begun hearing an appeal by Apple against an order by the European Commission that it pay €13 billion (£11.6bn) in back taxes to the Irish government. The case centers around a 2016 ruling by the European Commission that Apple had received illegal state aid from Ireland, which allowed it to pay far less tax than other companies. The Commission said that the tax arrangement between Apple and Ireland gave the company an unfair advantage over its competitors. Apple has appealed the ruling, arguing that it did not receive any special treatment from the Irish government and that the tax arrangement was in line with Irish law. The Irish government has also appealed the ruling, arguing that it did not give Apple any special treatment and that the tax arrangement was not illegal. The ECJ hearing is expected to last two days. A ruling is not expected for several months. If the ECJ upholds the Commission's ruling, it will be a major blow to Apple. The company could be forced to pay the €13 billion in back taxes, plus interest. It could also damage Apple's reputation and make it more difficult for the company to do business in Europe. If the ECJ overturns the Commission's ruling, it will be a victory for Apple and the Irish government. It will also set a precedent for other cases involving state aid and taxation. The Apple case is one of several high-profile cases that the European Commission has brought against multinational companies in recent years. The Commission has accused companies such as Amazon, Google, and Starbucks of receiving illegal state aid. The Commission's crackdown on tax avoidance by multinational companies has been welcomed by some, who argue that it is unfair for companies to pay less tax than other businesses. However, others have criticized the Commission's approach, arguing that it is damaging the competitiveness of European companies. The outcome of the Apple case will be closely watched by companies, governments, and tax experts around the world. It could have a significant impact on the way that multinational companies are taxed in Europe.

title: Greater Manchester PC Nicola Hughes' cortege met by applause
text: Greater Manchester PC Nicola Hughes' cortege met by applause Mourners have lined the streets to pay their respects to Police Constable Nicola Hughes, who was killed in a gun and grenade attack last week. The cortege left Manchester Royal Infirmary at 10:30 BST on Wednesday and travelled to Manchester Cathedral, where a funeral service was held. Members of the public stood in silence as the hearse passed by, some wiping away tears. Others applauded as the coffin, draped in a Union flag, entered the cathedral. PC Hughes, 23, was shot dead in a gun and grenade attack in Hattersley, Greater Manchester, on Friday. She was responding to reports of a burglary when she and a colleague, PC Fiona Bone, were attacked. PC Bone, 32, was also killed in the attack. The cortege was led by a mounted police escort, followed by officers from Greater Manchester Police, other police forces and the emergency services. The hearse was followed by PC Hughes' family and friends, including her parents, Malcolm and Susan Hughes. The service at Manchester Cathedral was attended by around 1,000 people, including the Prime Minister, David Cameron, and the Home Secretary, Theresa May. The service was led by the Bishop of Manchester, the Right Reverend David Walker. In his sermon, Bishop Walker said that PC Hughes was a "heroine" who had "died in the line of duty". He said: "She was a young woman who had her whole life ahead of her. She had only been a police officer for two years, but she had already made a difference." Bishop Walker said that PC Hughes' death was a "tragedy" but that she would "never be forgotten". He said: "She will always be remembered as a brave and selfless police officer who gave her life to protect others." At the end of the service, the congregation sang the hymn "The Lord's My Shepherd". The cortege then left the cathedral and travelled to Southern Cemetery, where PC Hughes was buried. The cemetery was packed with mourners, who stood in silence as the coffin was lowered into the grave. PC Hughes' family and friends then released white balloons into the sky. The balloons floated up into the air, carrying with them the love and respect of everyone who had gathered to say goodbye to a brave and selfless police officer.

title: Saga shares close flat on debut
text: Saga shares close flat on debut Shares in Saga closed flat on their first day of trading on the London Stock Exchange on Thursday. The over-50s specialist closed at 185 pence per share, the same price at which they were sold to investors in the company's initial public offering (IPO). The IPO raised £550m for Saga, which is using the money to reduce its debt and invest in its business. The company has been struggling in recent years, with profits falling and its share price tumbling. However, Saga's new management team, led by chief executive Euan Sutherland, is confident that the company can be turned around. Sutherland has a track record of success in the retail sector, having previously worked at Argos and Dixons Carphone. He has already made a number of changes at Saga, including simplifying the company's product range and improving its customer service. Sutherland is also investing in new technology, such as a new online platform that will make it easier for customers to buy Saga products and services. Analysts are cautiously optimistic about Saga's prospects. They believe that the company has a strong brand and a loyal customer base. However, they also warn that the company faces a number of challenges, including the rising cost of insurance and the increasing popularity of online travel agents. Saga's shares are likely to remain volatile in the short term. However, if Sutherland can successfully turn the company around, then the shares could have significant upside potential. In a statement, Sutherland said: "I am delighted that Saga has successfully listed on the London Stock Exchange. This is a major milestone for the company and a testament to the hard work of our employees. "We have a clear plan to turn Saga around and I am confident that we can create a successful future for the company and our shareholders."

title: Alex Salmond hails green energy work by Scots and Norwegians
text: Scottish First Minister Alex Salmond has hailed the work of Scots and Norwegians in developing green energy. He was speaking at the opening of a new wind farm in Scotland, which is a joint venture between Scottish and Norwegian companies. The wind farm is part of a growing number of renewable energy projects in Scotland, which is aiming to become a world leader in the sector. Mr Salmond said that the work of Scots and Norwegians in developing green energy was "a shining example" of how international cooperation could help to tackle climate change. He said: "This wind farm is a testament to the hard work and dedication of Scots and Norwegians. It is a symbol of our shared commitment to tackling climate change and building a cleaner, greener future for our planet." The wind farm is located in the Highlands of Scotland, and will generate enough electricity to power 12,000 homes. It is the largest wind farm in Scotland, and one of the largest in the UK. The project was developed by ScottishPower Renewables and Statoil, and was built by a consortium of Scottish and Norwegian companies. Mr Salmond said that the wind farm was a "major milestone" in Scotland's transition to a low-carbon economy. He said: "This wind farm is a major milestone in our journey to becoming a world leader in renewable energy. It is a symbol of our commitment to tackling climate change and building a cleaner, greener future for our planet." The Norwegian Prime Minister, Erna Solberg, also attended the opening of the wind farm. She said: "This wind farm is a testament to the strong cooperation between Scotland and Norway. It is a symbol of our shared commitment to tackling climate change and building a more sustainable future for our planet." The Scottish Government has set a target of generating 100% of its electricity from renewable sources by 2020. The wind farm is a major step towards achieving this target, and is expected to help Scotland to reduce its carbon emissions by 2 million tonnes per year.

title: Razzies: Christian comedy film gets top golden raspberry
text: In a ceremony held to honor the worst of the worst in film, a Christian comedy has taken home the top prize. "The Chosen" won the Razzie Award for Worst Picture, as well as Worst Director for Dallas Jenkins, Worst Screenplay for Jenkins and Tyler Thompson, and Worst Supporting Actress for Lea Thompson. The film, which tells the story of Jesus Christ, has been criticized for its low production values, wooden acting, and heavy-handed religious message. Despite its critical panning, "The Chosen" has been a commercial success, grossing over $100 million worldwide. The Razzies, which are awarded annually by the Golden Raspberry Foundation, have a long history of recognizing the worst films of the year. Past winners include such cinematic disasters as "Showgirls," "Battlefield Earth," and "The Room." "The Chosen" is the first Christian film to win the Razzie for Worst Picture. This has led to some controversy, with some critics accusing the Razzie voters of being biased against religious films. However, the Razzie Foundation has defended its decision, saying that "The Chosen" was simply the worst film of the year, regardless of its religious content. "We don't care what your beliefs are," said Razzie founder John Wilson. "If your movie sucks, we're going to give you a Razzie." The Razzie Awards have always been a controversial event, but they have also become a cult favorite among film fans. Many people enjoy watching the ceremony to see which films will win and to revel in the sheer awfulness of some of the nominees. Whether you love them or hate them, the Razzies are a unique part of film culture. They remind us that even the worst films can have their own strange appeal.

title: London tower block 'mouldy and damp' after cladding removed
text: In a shocking exposé, residents of a London tower block have revealed the appalling living conditions they have been forced to endure after cladding was removed from their building. The 12-story block in Elephant and Castle has been plagued by mold, damp, and leaks since the cladding was removed as part of fire safety works following the Grenfell Tower disaster. Residents say they have been living in these conditions for months, with no end in sight. One resident, who asked not to be named, said: "The mold is everywhere. It's on the walls, the ceilings, the furniture. It's making us all ill. We're constantly coughing and sneezing, and our eyes are always watering." Another resident said: "The damp is so bad that our clothes are always wet. We can't even dry them on the radiators because they're too cold. We're having to use dehumidifiers, but they're not making much difference." The residents say they have complained to the building's management company, but they have been met with indifference. "They just don't care," said one resident. "They keep telling us that they're working on it, but nothing ever happens. We're at our wits' end." The conditions in the tower block are a stark reminder of the Grenfell Tower disaster, in which 72 people died. The fire was caused by flammable cladding that was installed on the building. Following the Grenfell Tower fire, the government ordered that all tower blocks over 18 meters tall must have their cladding removed. However, the removal of the cladding has left many buildings exposed to the elements, leading to widespread problems with mold and damp. The residents of the tower block in Elephant and Castle are calling on the government to take action to address the issue of mold and damp in tower blocks. They say that they are living in inhumane conditions and that their health is being put at risk. A spokesperson for the building's management company said: "We are aware of the issues that residents have been experiencing with mold and damp. We are working to address these issues as quickly as possible." The spokesperson added that the company is carrying out a survey of all the flats in the tower block to assess the extent of the problem. The company is also working with a contractor to carry out repairs.

title: US finds against Bombardier in Boeing dispute
text: US Finds Against Bombardier in Boeing Dispute The United States has ruled against Canadian aircraft manufacturer Bombardier in a long-running trade dispute with Boeing. The dispute centered around allegations from Boeing that Bombardier had received illegal subsidies from the Canadian government, giving it an unfair advantage in the market. The US Department of Commerce has imposed preliminary anti-subsidy duties of nearly 220% on Bombardier's C Series aircraft, which is designed to compete with Boeing's 737 MAX jetliner. The department also found that Bombardier had received unfair pricing benefits from the Canadian government, resulting in dumping margins of 79.41%. The decision is a major blow to Bombardier, which has been struggling financially for several years. The company has already announced plans to scale back production of the C Series and has been seeking partnerships with other companies to help fund its operations. The Canadian government has condemned the US decision, calling it "unjustified" and "protectionist." The government has vowed to continue defending Bombardier and the Canadian aerospace industry. Boeing has welcomed the decision, saying it "reaffirms" the company's position that Bombardier has been unfairly subsidized. Boeing has also said it is "disappointed" that Bombardier has not been held accountable for its actions. The US decision is likely to have a significant impact on the global aircraft industry. Bombardier is one of the world's largest producers of commercial aircraft, and its C Series is considered to be one of the most advanced and fuel-efficient aircraft in its class. The US decision could make it more difficult for Bombardier to compete with Boeing and other aircraft manufacturers. It could also lead to higher prices for C Series aircraft, making it less competitive in the market. The dispute between Boeing and Bombardier has been going on for several years. In 2017, Boeing filed a petition with the US government, alleging that Bombardier had received illegal subsidies from the Canadian government. The US government launched an investigation, which resulted in the preliminary anti-subsidy duties announced this week. The dispute has also been taken to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
