title: Swansea City's Brendan Rodgers climbs Kilimanjaro
text: Swansea City manager Brendan Rodgers climbs Mount Kilimanjaro Swansea City manager Brendan Rodgers has reached the summit of Mount Kilimanjaro, the highest mountain in Africa. The 50-year-old climbed the 5,895-meter (19,341-foot) peak with a group of friends and family, including his wife Susan and son Anton. Rodgers said he had always wanted to climb Kilimanjaro and was determined to do it before he turned 50. "It was an incredible experience," he said. "It was tough at times, but it was worth it." Rodgers said the highlight of the climb was reaching the summit and seeing the sunrise over the African plains. "It was an amazing feeling," he said. "It's something I'll never forget." Rodgers is the second Premier League manager to climb Kilimanjaro, after former Manchester United boss Sir Alex Ferguson. Ferguson climbed the mountain in 2009 and said it was "one of the most rewarding experiences" of his life. Rodgers said he was inspired by Ferguson's climb and was determined to follow in his footsteps. "I've always admired Sir Alex Ferguson," he said. "He's a great leader and a great man." "I'm glad I was able to follow in his footsteps and climb Kilimanjaro." Rodgers' climb was part of a fundraising effort for the Brendan Rodgers Foundation, which supports young people in Swansea. The foundation has raised over £1 million since it was launched in 2013. Rodgers said he was grateful for the support of everyone who donated to the foundation. "I'm so grateful for the support of everyone who donated to the foundation," he said. "Your donations will make a real difference to the lives of young people in Swansea." Rodgers' climb of Kilimanjaro was a great achievement for the Swansea City manager. It was a tough challenge, but he showed great determination and resilience to reach the summit. His climb has also raised a lot of money for a great cause. The Brendan Rodgers Foundation will use the money to support young people in Swansea, and make a real difference to their lives.

title: Colour-coded school performance ratings revealed in Wales
text: Colour-coded school performance ratings revealed in Wales Schools in Wales have been given colour-coded performance ratings for the first time, under a new system designed to provide parents and the public with more information about how well schools are performing. The ratings, which range from green (excellent) to red (unsatisfactory), are based on a range of factors, including pupil attainment, progress and attendance. The ratings were published by the Welsh Government on Thursday, and they show that the majority of schools in Wales are performing well. Around two-thirds of schools were rated green or yellow (good), while just over 10% were rated red. The ratings are designed to help parents make informed choices about which school to send their children to, and to help schools identify areas where they need to improve. Education Minister Kirsty Williams said: "These ratings will provide parents and the public with clear and accessible information about how well schools are performing. "They will also help schools to identify areas where they need to improve, and to target their resources accordingly." The ratings have been welcomed by some, but others have expressed concerns about the potential for them to be used to create a league table of schools. The Welsh Government has said that it does not intend to create a league table, and that the ratings should be used to support schools, not to rank them. However, some critics have argued that the ratings could still be used to create a de facto league table, and that this could lead to schools being unfairly compared to each other. The Welsh Government has said that it will monitor the use of the ratings and will take steps to prevent them from being used to create a league table. The ratings are part of a wider package of reforms to the school system in Wales. Other reforms include the introduction of a new curriculum, and changes to the way that teachers are trained and paid. The Welsh Government believes that these reforms will help to improve standards in schools and to ensure that all pupils have the opportunity to succeed.

title: Coronavirus: Coping with behavioural issues during lockdown
text: Coronavirus: Coping with behavioural issues during lockdown The coronavirus lockdown has been a challenging time for everyone, but it can be especially difficult for those with behavioural issues. Children and adults with autism, ADHD, or other developmental disorders may find it hard to cope with the changes in their routine and the lack of social interaction. Here are some tips for coping with behavioural issues during lockdown: Establish a routine and stick to it as much as possible. This will help your child or adult feel more secure and reduce anxiety. Create a structured day with plenty of activities. This will help to keep your child or adult occupied and prevent boredom. Involve your child or adult in household chores. This will give them a sense of purpose and responsibility. Make time for physical activity. Exercise can help to reduce stress and improve mood. Take breaks throughout the day to relax and de-stress. This will help to prevent burnout. Be patient and understanding. It is important to remember that everyone is coping with the lockdown in their own way. Seek professional help if needed. If you are struggling to cope with behavioural issues, do not hesitate to seek professional help. Here are some specific tips for coping with behavioural issues in children with autism: Use visual aids to help your child understand the changes in their routine. Create a social story to explain the lockdown and what it means for your child. Provide your child with plenty of sensory input. This can help to calm and regulate them. Be patient and understanding. It is important to remember that children with autism may need more time to adjust to the changes. Here are some specific tips for coping with behavioural issues in adults with ADHD: Create a structured day with plenty of breaks. Use a timer to help you stay on task. Take regular breaks to move around and get some fresh air. Find ways to manage your stress. This could include exercise, yoga, or meditation. Be patient and understanding. It is important to remember that adults with ADHD may need more time to adjust to the changes. The coronavirus lockdown is a challenging time for everyone, but it is especially important to be patient and understanding with those who have behavioural issues. By following these tips, you can help your child or adult cope with the changes and maintain their well-being.

title: Abdul Fattah al-Sisi: Egyptian president may rule until 2034
text: Egypt's President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi could potentially remain in power until 2034 after the passing of constitutional amendments in a referendum. The changes, which were approved by 88.83% of voters, have sparked concerns about the country's democratic future. Al-Sisi, who came to power in a 2013 military coup, has faced criticism for his crackdown on dissent and his authoritarian rule. The new amendments have raised fears that he will further consolidate his power and stifle opposition. One of the most significant changes introduced by the amendments is the extension of the presidential term from four to six years. This means that al-Sisi could potentially serve two more terms in office, taking him to 2034. The amendments also give the president the power to appoint the heads of the judiciary and the public prosecutor. This could potentially give al-Sisi control over the entire justice system, further undermining the independence of the judiciary. In addition, the amendments create a new upper house of parliament, the Senate. The Senate will have the power to approve or reject legislation passed by the lower house, the House of Representatives. However, the Senate will be dominated by al-Sisi's supporters, giving him effective control over the legislative process. The amendments also include a number of other provisions that could further strengthen al-Sisi's grip on power. For example, they give the president the power to declare a state of emergency without the approval of parliament. They also allow the president to issue decrees that have the force of law, bypassing the need for parliamentary approval. The passing of the constitutional amendments has been condemned by human rights groups and opposition politicians. They argue that the amendments will further entrench authoritarian rule in Egypt and undermine the country's democratic institutions. The international community has also expressed concern about the amendments. The United States has said that it is "concerned about the implications of the constitutional amendments for Egypt's democratic development." The European Union has also said that it is "monitoring the situation closely." Al-Sisi's supporters argue that the amendments are necessary to provide stability and security in Egypt. They say that the country is facing a number of challenges, including terrorism and economic instability, and that a strong leader is needed to guide the country through these difficult times. However, critics argue that the amendments will only serve to further suppress dissent and stifle opposition. They say that Egypt needs a democratic system that allows for the free expression of ideas and the peaceful transfer of power.

title: NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde sends obese to Weight Watchers
text: NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde is sending obese patients to Weight Watchers as part of a bid to reduce the number of people in the region who are overweight or obese. The health board has partnered with the weight loss company to offer a free 12-week programme to patients who have a body mass index (BMI) of 30 or more. The programme will include weekly weigh-ins, group support and access to online resources. NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde said the move was part of its commitment to tackling obesity, which is a major public health issue. The health board said that obesity costs the NHS in Scotland an estimated £600m a year. Dr Gregor Smith, NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde's director of public health, said: "Obesity is a major public health challenge and we are committed to doing everything we can to tackle it. "This new partnership with Weight Watchers will provide our patients with the support they need to lose weight and improve their health." Weight Watchers said it was delighted to be working with NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde. The company's UK managing director, Fiona Campbell, said: "We are committed to helping people lose weight and live healthier lives. "This partnership with NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde will allow us to reach even more people who are struggling with their weight." The programme is open to patients who are over 18 and have a BMI of 30 or more. Patients can refer themselves to the programme or be referred by their GP. The programme will be evaluated to assess its effectiveness in helping patients to lose weight and improve their health. NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde is one of the largest health boards in Scotland, providing services to a population of over 1.2 million people. The health board has a number of initiatives in place to tackle obesity, including a weight management service and a healthy weight programme for children.

title: Grenfell Tower fire: Downing Street criticises council over aborted meeting
text: Downing Street has criticised Kensington and Chelsea Council over its decision to cancel a meeting due to be held on Tuesday, which had been scheduled to discuss the Grenfell Tower fire. The meeting had been arranged by the Communities Secretary, James Brokenshire, and was intended to bring together residents' groups, the council, and central government representatives. However, the council announced it was calling off the meeting due to security concerns, after consultation with the police. A Number 10 spokesperson said: "We regret that Kensington and Chelsea Council has taken this decision at such short notice and without prior discussion with the government." The spokesperson added that the government believed it was "vital" for the meeting to go ahead, and that "residents need to have their voices heard". The Grenfell Tower fire, which claimed the lives of at least 80 people in June, has raised questions about the council's handling of the disaster, and its relationship with residents. The council has been accused of failing to listen to residents' concerns about the safety of the tower, and of not doing enough to help those affected by the fire. The decision to cancel the meeting has further angered residents, who say they are being denied the opportunity to have their say about the fire. One resident, who did not want to be named, said: "This is a kick in the teeth. We have been waiting for months for this meeting, and now it's been cancelled at the last minute. It's clear that the council doesn't want to listen to us." The council said it had taken the decision to cancel the meeting after receiving advice from the police that there was a "credible threat" to the safety of those attending. The council said it understood that this would be "disappointing" for residents, but that it had to put their safety first. The government has said that it will continue to work with the council to ensure that residents' voices are heard, and that those affected by the fire get the support they need.

title: Margaret Thatcher's criticism of Brixton riot response revealed
text: Margaret Thatcher's Criticism of Brixton Riot Response Revealed Newly released documents have shed light on Margaret Thatcher's harsh criticism of the police response to the Brixton riots of 1981. The riots, which began on April 10th, 1981, were sparked by the fatal shooting of a black man, Cherry Groce, by a police officer during a traffic stop. Four days of rioting followed, resulting in 297 police officers and 111 civilians being injured, and significant damage to property. In the aftermath of the riots, Thatcher expressed deep dissatisfaction with the police's handling of the situation. Cabinet papers released under the 30-year rule show that she accused the police of "total lack of control" and "gross incompetence." In a letter to Home Secretary Willie Whitelaw, Thatcher wrote: "I must say that I think the police lost control of the situation, and there was a serious lack of co-ordination between the different forces involved... As a result, the public lost confidence in the police and there was a serious breakdown in law and order." Thatcher's criticism extended beyond the immediate response to the riots. She expressed concern that the police had failed to engage with the black community in Brixton before the violence erupted. "It is clear that there is a serious problem of police-community relations, particularly in Brixton," Thatcher wrote. "The police must do more to reach out to the black community and earn their trust. Otherwise, there will be further trouble in the future." She also called for a review of police training and tactics to ensure that officers were better prepared to deal with riots and other public order incidents. Thatcher's criticism of the police response to the Brixton riots added to the tensions between her government and the Metropolitan Police. The riots had already prompted a major inquiry into police powers, which ultimately led to the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984. The release of the cabinet papers provides fresh insights into Thatcher's views on law and order, police accountability, and race relations. They also highlight the ongoing challenges of policing diverse communities and maintaining trust between the police and the public.

title: Flood-hit Tewkesbury farmer 'unable to plant crops'
text: A farmer whose land was ravaged by flooding two years ago says he is still unable to plant crops because the Environment Agency has not repaired a flood defence. Andrew Frowen, who runs an organic farm near Tewkesbury in Gloucestershire, says he has lost £100,000 in income since the River Severn burst its banks in February 2020. The Environment Agency says it is working to repair the flood defence, but Mr Frowen says the work is taking too long. "It's been two years since the floods and I'm still unable to plant crops on a significant proportion of my land," he said. "The Environment Agency has a duty to protect people and property from flooding, but they are failing in that duty." The Environment Agency said: "We are working to repair the flood defence as quickly as possible, but it is a complex and challenging project. "We understand the frustration of those affected by flooding, and we are doing everything we can to help them." Mr Frowen is not the only farmer who has been affected by the flooding.  соседний фермер, Джон Смит, сказал, что он также потерял большой доход из-за наводнения. "Я потерял около 50 000 фунтов стерлингов дохода, - сказал он. - Это огромная сумма денег для небольшого фермера, такого как я". Смит сказал, что правительство должно сделать больше для помощи фермерам, пострадавшим от наводнения. "Правительство должно инвестировать в противопаводковую защиту, - сказал он. - Оно также должно предоставить финансовую помощь фермерам, пострадавшим от наводнения". Ожидается, что ремонтные работы на дамбе будут завершены в конце этого года. Однако фермеры, пострадавшие от наводнения, говорят, что этого недостаточно. "Они должны сделать больше, чтобы защитить нас от будущих наводнений", - сказал Фровен.

title: Preston Bus Station: £1 bid set to be declined
text: Preston Bus Station: £1 bid set to be declined Preston City Council has said it is set to reject a £1 bid for the city's iconic bus station. The authority said the offer, from the Preston Bus Station Action Group, was "not viable" and would not allow the building to be brought back into use. The group had said it wanted to buy the bus station for £1 and turn it into a community hub. But the council said it had received other bids for the site, which it would now consider. The bus station closed in 2020 after being deemed unsafe. It has since been earmarked for demolition as part of the city's £200m Tithebarn regeneration project. The Preston Bus Station Action Group, which has more than 4,000 members, has been campaigning to save the building. It had hoped to buy the bus station for £1 and turn it into a community hub, with a market, food stalls and performance spaces. The group said it was "disappointed" by the council's decision to reject its bid. "We believe our bid was viable and would have allowed the bus station to be brought back into use," said a spokesperson. "We are now considering our options and will continue to campaign to save the bus station." The council said it had received a number of bids for the site, which it would now consider. "We are committed to finding a viable solution for the bus station site that will benefit the city," said a spokesperson. "We will now consider the bids we have received and make a decision in due course." The bus station was designed by Keith Ingham and opened in 1969. It is considered one of the most important examples of Brutalist architecture in the UK. The building has been the subject of much debate in recent years, with some people calling for it to be demolished and others arguing that it should be preserved. The council has said that it will make a decision on the future of the bus station "in due course".

title: EU immigration - the Croatian solution?
text: EU Immigration - The Croatian Solution? Croatia's accession to the European Union in 2013 marked a significant turning point for the country. As a new member state, Croatia became subject to EU freedom of movement rules, allowing its citizens to travel and work freely within the bloc. In the years that followed, Croatia experienced a substantial outflow of its population. According to the country's Central Bureau of Statistics, over 300,000 Croatian citizens emigrated between 2013 and 2018, mainly to Germany, Austria, and Ireland. This mass exodus has had a profound impact on Croatia's economy and society. In an effort to stem the tide of emigration, the Croatian government has implemented a range of measures, including increasing public investment, providing tax breaks to businesses, and improving infrastructure. However, these efforts have had limited success. In recent years, the Croatian government has begun to look to the EU for solutions to its emigration problem. One potential solution that has been explored is the Croatian solution. The Croatian solution is a proposal by the Croatian government to grant all Croatian citizens who have emigrated to the EU the right to return to Croatia and settle there permanently. This would give Croatian citizens the same rights as other EU citizens, who can move freely within the bloc and settle in any member state. The Croatian solution has been met with mixed reactions. Some experts believe that it could help to stem the flow of emigration from Croatia, while others argue that it could create a brain drain and deprive the country of skilled workers and professionals. The Croatian government is currently in negotiations with the EU over the Croatian solution. If successful, it would be a significant development in EU immigration policy and could have implications for other member states facing similar challenges. The Croatian Experience Croatia's experience with EU immigration is a complex one. The country has benefited from the free movement of workers, which has helped to boost its economy and fill labor shortages. However, it has also experienced a significant outflow of its population, which has had a negative impact on its economy and society. The Croatian solution is an attempt to address this issue and keep more Croatian citizens in the country. However, it remains to be seen whether this solution will be successful. Only time will tell whether the Croatian solution will stem the flow of emigration from Croatia and help to revitalize its economy and society.

title: Uber agrees to 20 years of privacy audits to settle FTC charges
text: Uber has agreed to 20 years of privacy audits and other measures to settle charges by the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) that it misled consumers about how it shared their data with third parties. The FTC alleged that Uber's privacy practices violated a 2016 consent order that required the ride-hailing company to get users' explicit consent before sharing their data with third parties. The agency also alleged that Uber made false claims about the security of its app and failed to take reasonable steps to protect users' personal information. Uber has agreed to pay $20 million to settle the charges. The company also agreed to: Obtain consumers' explicit consent before sharing their data with third parties. Implement a comprehensive privacy program that includes regular audits and employee training. Appoint a privacy officer responsible for overseeing the company's privacy practices. Submit quarterly reports to the FTC on its compliance with the consent order. The FTC's action against Uber is part of a broader crackdown on companies that misuse consumers' personal information. The agency has recently taken action against Facebook, Google, and other tech giants for privacy violations. Uber's settlement with the FTC is a significant victory for consumer privacy advocates. It sends a strong message that companies must be transparent about how they collect and use consumers' personal information and that they will be held accountable for any violations of the law. "This settlement is a major victory for consumers," said FTC Chairman Joe Simons. "Uber deceived consumers about how it was using their data, and it failed to take reasonable steps to protect their privacy. This settlement will help ensure that Uber treats consumers' personal information fairly and that it complies with the law." Uber's privacy practices have been under scrutiny for several years. In 2017, the company disclosed that a hacker had stolen the personal information of 57 million Uber users and drivers. The company was also criticized for its use of surge pricing, which increases the cost of rides during periods of high demand. Uber's new privacy measures are designed to address these concerns. The company has promised to be more transparent about how it collects and uses consumers' personal information, and it has implemented a number of new security measures to protect users' data. Uber's settlement with the FTC is a positive step forward for the company. It is a sign that Uber is taking its privacy obligations seriously and that it is committed to protecting consumers' personal information.

title: Venezuela's Maduro 'optimistic' as crisis talks resume
text: Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has expressed optimism as talks between the government and opposition resume in Mexico City. The negotiations, which had been suspended for over a year, aim to resolve the country's political crisis and pave the way for free and fair elections. Speaking at a televised event, Maduro said he was "very optimistic" about the talks and hoped they would lead to "a peaceful solution" to the crisis. "We are here to dialogue, to negotiate, to reach agreements that will allow us to live in peace and democracy," he said. The opposition, led by Juan Guaidó, has welcomed the resumption of talks but has also expressed skepticism about Maduro's intentions. "We are going to these negotiations with a clear objective: to achieve free and fair elections," Guaidó said in a statement. "We are not going to accept any false promises or delays." The talks are being facilitated by Norway and have been endorsed by the international community. The United States, which has recognized Guaidó as the legitimate president of Venezuela, has said it supports the talks and hopes they will lead to a "peaceful and democratic solution" to the crisis. The European Union has also welcomed the resumption of talks and has urged both sides to engage in "constructive dialogue." The Venezuelan crisis began in 2015 when the opposition won a majority in the National Assembly. Maduro's government responded by stripping the Assembly of its powers and jailing opposition leaders. The crisis escalated in 2019 when Guaidó declared himself interim president. The United States and dozens of other countries recognized Guaidó as the legitimate president, but Maduro has retained control of the military and government institutions. The Venezuelan economy has been devastated by the crisis, with hyperinflation and shortages of food and medicine. Millions of Venezuelans have fled the country in recent years. The talks in Mexico City are seen as a potential breakthrough in the crisis. However, it remains to be seen whether the two sides can reach an agreement that will lead to free and fair elections and a peaceful resolution to the crisis.

title: Benefit sanctions force people to sleep rough, claims charity
text: Benefit sanctions are a form of punishment for people who fail to meet the conditions of their welfare payments. These conditions can include attending job interviews, taking part in workfare schemes, or providing evidence that they are actively looking for work. If someone fails to meet these conditions, their benefits can be stopped or reduced. In recent years, the use of benefit sanctions has increased significantly. In 2010, there were just over 300,000 benefit sanctions issued. By 2018, that number had risen to over 1.6 million. This increase has led to growing concerns about the impact of benefit sanctions on people's lives. One of the most concerning impacts of benefit sanctions is that they can force people to sleep rough. A study by the charity Crisis found that over a quarter of people who had been sanctioned had slept rough at some point in the past year. This is because benefit sanctions can leave people with no money to pay for food or accommodation. In addition to the risk of homelessness, benefit sanctions can also have a range of other negative consequences. These can include increased poverty, mental health problems, and social isolation. Critics of benefit sanctions argue that they are a cruel and ineffective way to get people into work. They point out that many people who are sanctioned are already looking for work, but they are unable to find a job due to factors such as a lack of skills or experience. They also argue that benefit sanctions can make it more difficult for people to find work, as they can lead to people losing their homes and their support networks. The government has defended the use of benefit sanctions, arguing that they are necessary to encourage people to look for work and to reduce the cost of the welfare system. However, the evidence suggests that benefit sanctions are not effective in getting people into work and that they can have a range of negative consequences for people's lives. In conclusion, benefit sanctions are a form of punishment for people who fail to meet the conditions of their welfare payments. While the government argues that they are necessary to encourage people to look for work and to reduce the cost of the welfare system, the evidence suggests that benefit sanctions are not effective in getting people into work and that they can have a range of negative consequences for people's lives.

title: G8 summit: exclusion zone extended in County Fermanagh
text: G8 summit: exclusion zone extended in County Fermanagh The exclusion zone around the Lough Erne Resort, where the G8 summit is being held, has been extended to include the village of Kesh. The move comes after police said they had received "credible information" of a potential threat to the summit. The exclusion zone now extends for a radius of 10 miles around the resort, and includes the main road between Enniskillen and Omagh. Police have set up roadblocks on all roads leading into the exclusion zone, and are stopping and searching vehicles. They have also advised people to avoid the area if possible. The G8 summit is being held at the Lough Erne Resort from Monday 17 June to Tuesday 18 June. World leaders, including US President Barack Obama, UK Prime Minister David Cameron and Russian President Vladimir Putin, will be attending the summit. The summit is expected to focus on a range of issues, including the global economy, climate change and the Syrian civil war. The extension of the exclusion zone has been met with mixed reactions from local residents. Some have welcomed the move, saying it will help to keep the summit safe. Others have expressed concern about the impact it will have on their lives. One resident, who lives in Kesh, said: "I'm worried about how I'm going to get to work. "The main road is closed, so I'll have to take a long detour." Another resident said: "I'm not sure why they need to extend the exclusion zone so far. "It's going to cause a lot of inconvenience for people." The Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) has said it understands the concerns of local residents, but that the extension of the exclusion zone is necessary to ensure the safety of the summit. A PSNI spokesperson said: "We have received credible information of a potential threat to the summit. "As a result, we have taken the decision to extend the exclusion zone to include the village of Kesh. "We understand that this will cause some inconvenience to local residents, but we would ask for their understanding and cooperation."

title: Tom Ballard: 'Silhouettes' spotted in missing climber search
text: Climber Tom Ballard: 'Silhouettes' spotted during search operation Authorities searching for missing British climber Tom Ballard on Nanga Parbat, often referred to as "Killer Mountain," have spotted silhouettes that could potentially be the 30-year-old and his climbing partner, Daniele Nardi. The pair disappeared on February 24 while attempting to scale the 8,126-meter (26,660-foot) peak in Pakistan's Gilgit-Baltistan region. Their last communication was a text message sent by Nardi at 5:30 a.m. Pakistani time on February 23, claiming to have reached an altitude of 6,300 meters (20,670 feet). Helicopter crews using thermal imaging equipment have identified several silhouettes, but none have yet been confirmed to be those of Ballard and Nardi. Ballard's mother, Alison Hargreaves, who was the first British woman to summit Mount Everest, has expressed cautious optimism about the potential sighting. "We urge everyone to remain calm and respectful of the search and rescue operation," Hargreaves said in a statement. A team of Pakistani high-altitude climbers led by Muhammad Ali Sadpara is currently ascending the mountain to search for the missing climbers. The team is equipped with oxygen tanks and food supplies to enable them to remain at high altitude for as long as possible. The search operation has been hampered by poor weather conditions, including high winds and snowfall. However, authorities are determined to continue their efforts until all possible leads have been exhausted. "We have been working day and night since we received the distress call," said Pakistan's Alpine Club secretary, Karrar Haidri. "We are doing everything we can to find Tom and Daniele, but we need to be realistic about the challenges we face." Nardi, 42, is an experienced climber with a successful track record of high-altitude ascents. He has previously attempted to summit Nanga Parbat twice before, in 2016 and 2017. Ballard, who is the son of renowned climber Alison Hargreaves and renowned Pakistani mountaineer Muhammad Ali Sadpara, has emerged as one of Britain's most promising young climbers. He became the first person to free climb the north face of the Eiger in the Swiss Alps in 2018. The search operation for Ballard and Nardi is ongoing, and authorities remain hopeful of finding them alive.

title: Toppled Pontfadog Oak in Chirk moved off house
text: Toppled Pontfadog Oak in Chirk moved off house A 1,000-year-old oak tree that toppled onto a house in Chirk, Wrexham, has been carefully lifted off the property and transported to a nearby field. The Pontfadog Oak, which is thought to be one of the oldest trees in Britain, fell during Storm Eunice in February, causing significant damage to the house it landed on. Specialist contractors were brought in to remove the tree, which was lifted off the house using a crane and transported to a field near to where it originally stood. The tree, which has a trunk diameter of 6ft (1.8m), is now being assessed by experts to determine whether it can be replanted. Denbighshire council's lead member for highways, waste and the environment, Councillor Brian Jones, said: "This was a very delicate operation, and we are grateful to the contractors for their expertise in removing the tree safely. "We are now working with experts to assess the tree's condition and determine whether it can be replanted. We are hopeful that we can save this iconic tree and give it a new lease of life." The Pontfadog Oak is a sessile oak (Quercus petraea), which is native to Britain and Ireland. It is one of the longest-living trees in the UK, with some specimens known to have reached 1,000 years old. The tree is a popular tourist attraction and has been featured in a number of books and articles. It is also a Site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) and is protected by law. The tree's owner, who does not wish to be named, said: "I am very relieved that the tree has been removed from my house. It was a very stressful time, and I am grateful to everyone who has helped to make this happen. "I am hopeful that the tree can be replanted and that it can continue to be enjoyed by future generations."

title: Ex-Gaddafi Tuareg fighters boost Mali rebels
text: Ex-Gaddafi Tuareg fighters boost Mali rebels ByBBC News, Bamako* Tuareg fighters who fought for Libya's late leader Muammar Gaddafi are joining up with the Tuareg-led rebel group in northern Mali, the Movement for the National Liberation of Azawad (MNLA). The MNLA is fighting for the independence of the vast desert region of Azawad, which it declared independent in April. The government in Bamako has rejected the declaration of independence and is preparing a military offensive to retake the region. The MNLA is made up of Tuareg fighters who fought for Gaddafi in the Libyan civil war. After Gaddafi was overthrown and killed in October 2011, many of these fighters returned to Mali and joined the MNLA. The MNLA is also being joined by Tuareg fighters from Niger and Burkina Faso. The influx of experienced fighters has boosted the MNLA's military capabilities. The group has been able to capture several towns in northern Mali, including the regional capital, Gao. The government in Bamako is concerned about the growing strength of the MNLA. The government has accused the MNLA of receiving support from al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM). AQIM is a terrorist group that operates in the Sahel region of North Africa. The government has also accused the MNLA of carrying out human rights abuses, including summary executions and torture. The MNLA has denied these accusations. The MNLA says it is fighting for the rights of the Tuareg people, who have been marginalized by the government in Bamako. The Tuareg are a nomadic people who have traditionally lived in the Sahara desert. They have been fighting for independence for decades. The MNLA is the latest in a series of Tuareg rebel groups to fight for independence. In the 1960s and 1970s, the Tuareg fought a war against the government in Bamako. The war ended in a peace agreement in 1991. However, the peace agreement was not fully implemented and the Tuareg continued to feel marginalized. In 2007, the Tuareg launched a new rebellion. The rebellion was crushed by the government in 2009. The MNLA is the latest incarnation of the Tuareg rebellion. The group is determined to fight for the independence of Azawad. The government in Bamako is determined to crush the rebellion. The conflict in northern Mali is likely to continue for some time to come.

title: Covid-19: Angry calls and threats over Chesterfield FC vaccines
text: Angry calls and threats have been made to footballers at Chesterfield FC who have been encouraging people to get vaccinated against Covid-19. The club's players and manager released a video urging people to get the jab, but some have since been subjected to abuse. title: Theresa May offers some Brexit answers

title: Street advertising boards to be banned in Edinburgh
text: Street Advertising Boards to Be Banned in Edinburgh In a move towards enhancing the city's visual aesthetics and reducing clutter, Edinburgh is set to become the first city in the UK to ban street advertising boards. The decision, approved by the city council, aims to create a more cohesive and visually appealing urban environment. Street advertising boards have long been a fixture in our cities, but their proliferation has raised concerns about their impact on the aesthetic value of public spaces. Critics argue that these boards create visual pollution, distracting from the beauty of historic buildings and natural landmarks. Edinburgh, renowned for its stunning architecture and picturesque streets, has been particularly affected by advertising clutter. The council's decision to ban them is seen as a positive step towards preserving the city's unique character. The ban will apply to all street advertising boards, including billboards, posters, and sandwich boards. Exceptions will be made for certain public information signs, such as those for bus stops and road safety. The ban is expected to come into effect in 2024, allowing businesses and advertisers time to adapt. The council will work with businesses to explore alternative advertising methods, such as digital displays and online platforms. The decision has been welcomed by heritage groups and conservationists. Historic Environment Scotland, which is responsible for protecting Scotland's built heritage, has praised the council for taking action to preserve Edinburgh's unique streetscape. The ban is also seen as a step towards reducing the environmental impact of advertising. Street advertising boards often use non-recyclable materials and contribute to litter. While the ban may have some impact on businesses that rely on street advertising, the council believes that the benefits to the city as a whole will outweigh any potential drawbacks. By removing street advertising boards, Edinburgh aims to create a more welcoming and visually appealing environment for residents and visitors alike. The ban is seen as a bold step towards shaping a more sustainable and aesthetically pleasing city. The decision to ban street advertising boards in Edinburgh has sparked a wider debate about the role of advertising in our public spaces. As other cities consider similar measures, Edinburgh's example may pave the way for a more balanced approach to urban advertising that respects the visual integrity of our cities.

title: Friends and enemies in the North
text: Nestled amidst the rugged landscapes of the North, where the winds whisper secrets and the rivers carve their paths, lies a tapestry of complex relationships. Friendships forged in the crucible of shared experiences twine alongside rivalries that simmer beneath the surface. In the quaint village of Willow Creek, the bonds between Emma and Sarah have weathered the storms of life. Childhood playmates transformed into steadfast confidants, they share laughter, secrets, and unwavering support. Their friendship, a beacon of stability amidst the ever-changing world, has become an unbreakable pillar in their lives. Yet, just across the river lies the brooding figure of Ethan, Emma's former lover. A bitter breakup has soured his heart, leaving a trail of resentment and wounded pride. Now, he watches Emma and Sarah's bond with a venomous gaze, his once-warm feelings replaced by a deep-seated animosity. As fate would have it, Willow Creek is not immune to the machinations of enemies. The arrival of the enigmatic stranger, Mark, sends ripples through the community. His charm and charisma initially win over hearts, but beneath the surface lurks a darker agenda. He seeks to divide and conquer, exploiting the vulnerabilities and grudges that fester within the village. Mark's machinations ignite old rivalries and sow seeds of suspicion. The once-peaceful community fractures into factions, each clinging to their own twisted truths. Emma and Sarah find themselves caught in the crossfire, their friendship threatened by the encroaching darkness. As tensions rise, the lines between friend and foe blur. Alliances shift, and former adversaries are forced to confront the consequences of their actions. The village becomes a battleground, where old wounds are reopened and new ones are inflicted. In the end, it is the bonds of friendship that prove unyielding. Emma and Sarah's unwavering loyalty to each other provides a beacon of hope amidst the chaos. They stand together, their friendship a testament to the resilience of the human spirit, even in the face of relentless adversity. And so, the tapestry of relationships in the North continues to be woven, an intricate web of love, hate, and everything in between. As the winds howl and the rivers flow, the friendships and enmities that define Willow Creek will forever be etched into its history.

title: Aberdeen lockdown: 'It feels never ending'
text: In the granite city of Aberdeen, the weight of lockdown has settled heavily upon its inhabitants, their spirits dampened by the relentless march of time. The once-bustling streets now stand eerily vacant, their vibrancy replaced by a profound sense of emptiness. "It feels never ending," sighs local resident Sarah MacDonald. "We're stuck in this limbo, not knowing when or if things will ever go back to normal." The lockdown, imposed to curb a surge in COVID-19 cases, has ground life in Aberdeen to a halt. Businesses shuttered, schools deserted, and social gatherings banned, the city has been transformed into a ghost town. "It's a strange feeling," says David Henderson, owner of a local coffee shop. "I used to love the buzz of people coming and going, but now it's like the city's holding its breath." The extended isolation has taken its toll on the city's mental health. Anxiety and depression have spiked, with residents reporting feelings of loneliness and despair. "I feel like I'm losing my mind," confides one woman, who prefers to remain anonymous. "I just want to see people again." The economic impact has been equally devastating. Many businesses have been forced to close, leaving workers unemployed and uncertain about the future. "I'm worried about how I'm going to pay the rent," says James Scott, a bartender. "I've been out of work for weeks now, and my savings are running out." Despite the challenges, there are pockets of resilience and determination emerging. Community groups have sprung up, offering support to those in need. Virtual gatherings have become a lifeline for people craving connection. "We can't let this lockdown break us," says community organizer Jane Chalmers. "We have to find ways to stay strong and support each other." As the days turn into weeks, the people of Aberdeen cling to the hope that this lockdown will not last forever. They long for the day when they can once again embrace the city they love, when the streets will be filled with laughter and the weight of isolation will finally lift. But until that day arrives, the city remains in a state of suspended animation, waiting patiently for the end of this interminable nightmare.

title: 'Save the Waverley' paddle steamer appeal launched
text: Save the Waverley: Appeal Launched for Historic Paddle Steamer The Waverley, the world's last seagoing paddle steamer, is facing an uncertain future. To save this iconic vessel, a fundraising appeal has been launched to raise £2.3 million. Built in 1947, the Waverley has sailed for over 70 years, connecting communities and offering visitors a glimpse of maritime history. However, the rising costs of maintenance and operation have put the steamer's future in jeopardy. To ensure the Waverley's continued operation, the Paddle Steamer Preservation Society (PSPS) has launched an urgent appeal for donations. The funds raised will be used to cover essential repairs and upgrades, including boiler replacements and hull repairs. "The Waverley is an irreplaceable part of our maritime heritage," said PSPS chairman John Slater. "She provides a unique and unforgettable experience for passengers and brings joy to everyone who sees her." The Waverley is a vital link between communities on the Scottish coast and islands. It offers scenic cruises, day trips, and special events, creating lasting memories for visitors. Saving the Waverley is not just about preserving a historical artifact. It is about safeguarding a cultural icon that brings people together and supports local tourism. "The Waverley is more than just a boat," said Scottish Tourism Minister Ivan McKee. "She is a symbol of our country's rich maritime history and a vital part of our visitor experience." The PSPS has already secured £1 million of match funding from the Scottish Government, but it needs to raise the remaining £1.3 million through public donations. Various fundraising initiatives are planned, including online crowdfunding, merchandise sales, and a major raffle. Every donation, no matter how small, will make a difference in saving the Waverley. "We are confident that the public will rally around to support this iconic vessel," said PSPS fundraising manager Karen Henderson. "Together, we can ensure that the Waverley continues to sail for generations to come." To support the 'Save the Waverley' appeal, visit the PSPS website at www.waverleyexcursion.co.uk.

title: 'Financial tsunami' forced police officers to retire
text: Amidst the economic turmoil that swept the globe in 2008, countless individuals and industries bore the brunt of the financial tsunami's devastating impact. Among those affected were the very people sworn to protect and serve our communities: police officers. As governments grappled with severe budget cuts and financial constraints, many police departments across the country were forced to make difficult decisions. Faced with dwindling resources and a shrinking revenue stream, they had no choice but to implement cost-saving measures that would ultimately lead to the premature retirement of experienced and dedicated officers. The consequences of these retirements were far-reaching. With fewer officers on the force, response times to emergencies and investigations slowed down. The loss of valuable experience and expertise also hindered the ability of police departments to effectively address complex crimes and community issues. Furthermore, the forced retirements had a significant impact on the morale of the remaining officers. Many felt betrayed and disillusioned by the lack of support from the very institutions they had served with distinction. The feeling of being undervalued and dispensable weighed heavily on the minds of those who continued to don the badge. In addition to the operational challenges, the mass retirements also affected the overall safety and well-being of communities. With fewer officers patrolling the streets, criminals became more brazen in their activities. The absence of a visible police presence emboldened offenders and led to an increase in crime rates in some areas. Recognizing the severity of the situation, some police departments implemented innovative strategies to mitigate the impact of the retirements. These included: Offering early retirement packages with incentives to encourage experienced officers to stay on the force longer. Exploring partnerships with other law enforcement agencies to share resources and personnel. Initiating recruitment campaigns to attract and hire qualified candidates to fill the void left by retiring officers. While these measures helped to alleviate some of the pressure, they could not fully compensate for the loss of so many experienced and dedicated officers. The financial tsunami had left an indelible mark on police departments across the country, and its consequences would continue to be felt for years to come. In the aftermath of the crisis, there was a growing recognition of the importance of investing in public safety and providing adequate support for law enforcement agencies. The lesson learned from the 'financial tsunami' was that underfunding and undermining the police force could have severe and long-lasting repercussions for society as a whole.

title: Wisbech murder: Dzilva Butiene 'relied' on man who killed her
text: In the aftermath of the tragic murder of Dzilva Butiene in Wisbech, Cambridgeshire, the trial at Peterborough Crown Court has revealed the chilling details surrounding her untimely death. The victim, a vulnerable woman in her 60s, was brutally killed in her own home on January 12, 2023. The prosecution presented evidence indicating that Dzilva Butiene had developed a dependency on the defendant, Jonas Mikalauskas, a Lithuanian national who had been staying at her residence for several weeks. While initially, it was believed that Mikalauskas had played a protective role in Butiene's life, the trial has painted a different picture. According to the prosecution, Mikalauskas took advantage of Butiene's vulnerability, exploiting her need for companionship and financial assistance. He allegedly controlled her bank accounts, withdrew large sums of money without her knowledge, and isolated her from her friends and family. On the fateful night of the murder, the court heard that a violent argument erupted between the two. Mikalauskas subjected Butiene to a sustained and brutal attack, causing multiple injuries to her head and body. Her frail body was discovered by police officers who had been called to the scene following a report of a disturbance. During the trial, evidence was presented suggesting that Mikalauskas had a history of violence and aggression. Witnesses testified to his volatile temper and his tendency to lash out when things did not go his way. The prosecution argued that Mikalauskas's actions were deliberate and motivated by greed and a desire to exert control over Butiene. They emphasized the extent to which the victim had relied on the defendant, only to be met with violence and betrayal. The jury has now retired to consider their verdict. If convicted of murder, Mikalauskas faces a mandatory life sentence. The trial has highlighted the dangers faced by vulnerable people who may fall prey to those who seek to exploit them. It serves as a reminder of the importance of reaching out to those in need and ensuring that they have access to support and protection.

title: Covid lockdown: 'My closed hair salons cost me £1,000 a day'
text: In the face of the ongoing Covid lockdown, the beauty industry has been left reeling, with hair salons being forced to close their doors. For many salon owners, the financial implications have been severe, with some losing thousands of pounds each day. One such salon owner is Emma, who runs a hair salon in London. Prior to the lockdown, her salon was thriving, with a steady stream of clients booking appointments. However, since the lockdown was imposed, her business has come to a standstill. "It's been devastating," she told the BBC. "I'm losing around £1,000 a day. I've had to furlough my staff, and I'm worried that I won't be able to afford to reopen when the lockdown is lifted." Emma is not alone in her struggles. According to the National Hair and Beauty Federation, the hair and beauty industry is losing an estimated £1.5 billion a month as a result of the lockdown. The closure of hair salons has had a significant impact on the mental health of many people. For some, regular hair appointments are an essential part of their self-care routine. Being unable to get their hair cut or styled can lead to feelings of stress, anxiety, and depression. "For many people, their hair is a big part of their identity," said Emma. "When they can't get it cut or styled, it can really affect their confidence." In addition to the financial and emotional impact, the closure of hair salons has also had a knock-on effect on other businesses. For example, many hair salons also sell products such as shampoos, conditioners, and styling tools. When salons are closed, these businesses lose out on potential sales. The government has announced a number of support measures for businesses affected by the lockdown, including grants and loans. However, many salon owners say that these measures are not enough to cover their losses. "The government needs to do more to help businesses like mine," said Emma. "We're facing an uncertain future, and we need to know that we're going to be able to survive."

title: Fishlake floods: Stranded residents helped by community heroes
text: Fishlake Floods: Community Heroes Rally to Aid Stranded Residents As torrential rainfall relentlessly battered Fishlake, South Yorkshire, on Thursday evening, the River Don burst its banks, inundating homes and leaving residents stranded. In the face of adversity, the community rallied together, with ordinary individuals stepping up as heroes to support their neighbors in need. Among them was 24-year-old Tom Hughes, a local builder, who used his van to ferry stranded residents to safety. "I saw people in distress, and I knew I had to do something," he said. "I took as many people as I could, even those with limited mobility." Another local resident, Maria Wilson, 56, opened her home to those who had been forced to evacuate. "We had plenty of space, and we couldn't bear the thought of people being out in the cold and wet," she explained. "We offered them warm clothes, food, and a place to rest." As the floodwaters rose, emergency services struggled to reach the worst-affected areas. But the community stepped into the breach, forming human chains to rescue residents from flooded homes and move them to higher ground. Local businesses also played a crucial role in the relief effort. The Fishlake Inn provided hot meals to the stranded residents, while the local Co-op donated food and other essential supplies to those in need. "The community spirit has been incredible," said local councilor John Burrows. "People have gone above and beyond to help their neighbors. It's heartwarming to see how everyone has pulled together in these difficult times." As the floodwaters gradually receded, the community continued to support the clean-up effort. Volunteers from the local church and other community groups helped remove debris from homes and businesses. The Fishlake floods have left a devastating impact on the community, but they have also brought out the best in people. The heroic actions of ordinary individuals and the outpouring of support from all quarters have been a beacon of light amidst the darkness. As the recovery process continues, the community of Fishlake will undoubtedly draw strength from the bonds that have been forged during this challenging time. The floods may have separated their homes, but they have brought their hearts and spirits closer together.

title: Little Mix's Jesy Nelson praised for 'inspiring' documentary Odd One Out
text: Little Mix's Jesy Nelson hailed for 'inspiring' documentary 'Odd One Out' Little Mix star Jesy Nelson has been praised for her "raw" and "inspiring" documentary "Odd One Out", which explores her experiences with cyberbullying and body image issues. In the documentary, which aired on BBC Three on Thursday, Nelson opens up about her struggles with online abuse, which began when she first joined Little Mix in 2011. She reveals how the relentless trolling left her feeling depressed and suicidal. Nelson also speaks out about the impact of body image pressures on her mental health. She discusses how she was constantly comparing herself to other members of the band and feeling like she wasn't good enough. The documentary has been widely praised by critics and viewers alike, with many commending Nelson for her bravery in speaking out about such difficult issues. "Odd One Out" has been praised as a powerful and necessary documentary that shines a light on the devastating effects of cyberbullying and body image pressures. It has also been credited with helping to raise awareness of these issues and encouraging people to seek help if they are struggling. In a statement released after the documentary aired, Nelson said she was "overwhelmed" by the positive response it had received. "I'm so grateful to everyone who has watched and shared their stories with me," she said. "It's so important to talk about these issues and break the stigma surrounding mental health." Little Mix's Leigh-Anne Pinnock said she was "so proud" of Nelson for making the documentary. "She's such an inspiration," Pinnock said. "She's using her platform to help others and that's what makes her a true role model." Jade Thirlwall, another member of Little Mix, said she was "heartbroken" by what Nelson had gone through. "But I'm also so inspired by her strength and resilience," Thirlwall said. "She's an incredible woman and I'm so proud to call her my friend." "Odd One Out" has been nominated for several awards, including a National Television Award for Best Authored Documentary. It is available to watch on BBC Three and BBC iPlayer.

title: Burger King remove 'racist' chopsticks ad
text: Burger King has removed an advertisement for its new 'Oriental' burger after it was branded "racist" by viewers. The advert, which was posted on Facebook, featured a woman using chopsticks to eat the burger. Many people criticised the advert, saying that it was stereotypical and perpetuated harmful stereotypes about Asian people. Burger King has since apologised for the advert and said that it was "unacceptable". The company has also removed the advert from its social media channels. The advert has sparked a debate about the use of cultural stereotypes in advertising. Some people believe that it is acceptable to use stereotypes in advertising if they are done in a humorous or light-hearted way. Others believe that stereotypes are always harmful, as they can reinforce negative stereotypes about particular groups of people. The Burger King advert is not the first time that a company has been accused of using racist advertising. In recent years, there have been a number of high-profile cases of companies using racist imagery or language in their advertising. These cases have led to calls for greater diversity in the advertising industry. Some people believe that the advertising industry is too white and male, and that this lack of diversity contributes to the creation of racist advertising. Others believe that the advertising industry is not intentionally racist, but that it simply reflects the racist attitudes that exist in society. They argue that the only way to change the advertising industry is to change society as a whole. The debate about the use of cultural stereotypes in advertising is likely to continue for some time. However, the Burger King advert has highlighted the importance of being sensitive to the potential impact of advertising on different groups of people. In a statement, Burger King said: "We apologise for the insensitive and inappropriate advertisement that we posted on our Facebook page. We have removed the advertisement and we sincerely regret any offence that it may have caused." The advertising watchdog, the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA), has said that it is investigating the advert. The ASA has the power to ban advertising that it considers to be offensive or misleading.

title: Social mobility: Poorer children 'making less progress'
text: Social mobility in the United Kingdom has stalled, with children from poorer backgrounds making less progress than their wealthier peers, according to a new report. The study, by the Sutton Trust, found that the gap between the richest and poorest pupils has widened in recent years, with children from the poorest families now 18 months behind their wealthier classmates by the age of 16. The report also found that children from poorer backgrounds are less likely to go to university, and those who do are more likely to drop out. They are also less likely to get good jobs and earn high salaries. The Sutton Trust's chief executive, Sir Peter Lampl, said the findings were "deeply concerning". "Social mobility is not just about giving everyone the same chances in life," he said. "It's about giving everyone the opportunity to reach their full potential. And that's not happening at the moment." The report's findings echo those of a number of other recent studies, which have all found that social mobility in the UK has stalled or even declined in recent years. One of the key factors behind this decline is the rising cost of living, which has made it increasingly difficult for families on low incomes to make ends meet. This has led to a number of families being forced to cut back on essential spending, such as food and heating, which can have a negative impact on children's education and development. The government has introduced a number of policies in recent years aimed at improving social mobility, such as the pupil premium, which gives extra funding to schools with high numbers of pupils from disadvantaged backgrounds. However, these policies have not been fully successful in addressing the underlying causes of social inequality. Experts say that more needs to be done to improve social mobility in the UK, including investing in early years education, providing better support for families on low incomes, and tackling the underlying causes of poverty and disadvantage. "We need to create a level playing field for all children, regardless of their background," said Sir Peter Lampl. "That means giving them the same opportunities to succeed, and that means tackling the underlying causes of poverty and disadvantage."

title: Coronavirus: Trump’s disinfectant and sunlight claims fact-checked
text: Coronavirus: Trump’s Disinfectant and Sunlight Claims Fact-Checked In a recent press conference, US President Donald Trump made several unproven and potentially dangerous claims about the treatment of coronavirus. He suggested that injecting disinfectant into the body could be an effective way to kill the virus, and also that sunlight could cure the disease. These claims have been widely condemned by medical experts, who have warned that they are both ineffective and potentially harmful. Disinfectant Injecting disinfectant into the body is not a safe or effective way to treat coronavirus. Disinfectants are designed to kill bacteria and viruses on surfaces, but they are not safe to inject into the human body. In fact, injecting disinfectant can cause serious health problems, including tissue damage, organ failure, and even death. The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has issued a warning against using disinfectants to treat coronavirus, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has also stated that there is no evidence to support the use of disinfectants to treat or prevent the virus. Sunlight Sunlight does not cure coronavirus. While exposure to sunlight can help to boost the immune system, there is no evidence to suggest that it can cure the virus. In fact, excessive exposure to sunlight can actually damage the skin and increase the risk of skin cancer. The CDC recommends that people avoid prolonged exposure to sunlight, and that they wear sunscreen and protective clothing when they are outdoors. Trump’s Claims Trump’s claims about the treatment of coronavirus are not supported by scientific evidence. In fact, they are potentially dangerous, and could lead people to take harmful actions. It is important to rely on information from credible sources, such as the CDC, FDA, and World Health Organization, when seeking information about coronavirus. These organizations have a wealth of knowledge and expertise, and they can provide accurate and reliable information about the virus and its treatment. Conclusion Trump’s claims about the treatment of coronavirus are not supported by scientific evidence. It is important to rely on information from credible sources, such as the CDC, FDA, and World Health Organization, when seeking information about coronavirus.

title: Male depression 'set to increase'
text: Male Depression Set to Increase Depression is a serious mental illness that can have a devastating impact on an individual's life. While it can affect anyone, regardless of age, gender, or background, research suggests that men may be at an increased risk of experiencing depression. According to a recent study published in the journal JAMA Psychiatry, the prevalence of depression among men is expected to rise by 20% in the next decade. Led by researchers from Harvard University, the study analyzed data from over 3 million men and found that the risk of depression increased with age, from 4.2% in men aged 18-24 to 7.5% in men aged 65 and over. The reasons for the increasing prevalence of depression in men are not fully understood, but several factors may contribute to this trend. One possible explanation is that men are less likely to seek help for mental health issues due to social stigma and cultural norms that discourage them from expressing their emotions. Another factor is the changing nature of work and family life. Men are increasingly facing pressures to succeed professionally and financially, while also balancing family responsibilities. This can lead to stress, anxiety, and feelings of inadequacy, which can increase the risk of depression. Furthermore, men are more likely to engage in risky behaviors, such as substance abuse and violence, which can further contribute to mental health problems. The consequences of depression can be severe. It can lead to decreased productivity at work, strained relationships, and physical illnesses. In severe cases, depression can lead to suicide. It is important to raise awareness about depression and encourage men to seek help if they are experiencing symptoms. Signs and symptoms of depression include: Persistent sadness or emptiness Loss of interest in activities that were once enjoyable Changes in appetite or weight Difficulty sleeping or staying asleep Fatigue or loss of energy Difficulty concentrating or making decisions Feelings of worthlessness or guilt Thoughts of death or suicide If you or someone you know is experiencing these symptoms, it is important to seek professional help. There are effective treatments available for depression, such as psychotherapy, medication, and lifestyle changes. By breaking down the stigma and providing access to support, we can help men to overcome depression and lead fulfilling lives.

title: Princess Beatrice marries Edoardo Mapelli Mozzi in private Windsor ceremony
text: In a private ceremony held at The Royal Chapel of All Saints in Windsor Great Park, Princess Beatrice of York and Edoardo Mapelli Mozzi exchanged vows, uniting in matrimony on July 17, 2020. The intimate ceremony, conducted by the Reverend Canon Paul Wright, was attended by a select group of the couple's closest family and friends, adhering to social distancing guidelines amidst the ongoing pandemic. Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, Beatrice's grandparents, graced the occasion with their presence, along with Beatrice's parents, Prince Andrew, Duke of York, and Sarah, Duchess of York. Edoardo's parents, Nikki Shale and Alessandro Mapelli Mozzi, also witnessed the union. Beatrice, the elder daughter of Prince Andrew and Sarah Ferguson, looked radiant in a vintage Norman Hartnell gown, originally owned by the Queen. The elegant dress featured an ivory taffeta skirt and bodice adorned with intricate beading and diamanté details. She paired the gown with the Queen Mary diamond fringe tiara, borrowed from her grandmother. Edoardo, an Italian property developer, looked dapper in a bespoke tailcoat by Huntsman. The couple exchanged vows amidst a setting of floral arrangements designed by Rob Van Helden. Beatrice's bouquet, a cascade of trailing jasmine, myrtle, and sweet peas, symbolized happiness, love, and fertility. Following the ceremony, the newlyweds emerged from the chapel, sharing a kiss on the steps. They then proceeded to a small reception held in the gardens of the Royal Lodge, the residence of Beatrice's parents. The celebration included a champagne toast and a cutting of the wedding cake, a traditional fruitcake adorned with white icing and fresh flowers. In a statement released after the ceremony, Beatrice and Edoardo expressed their joy and gratitude. "We are delighted to share our wedding day with you all. We are both so excited to embark on this new chapter in our lives together and can't wait to see what the future holds for us," they said. The royal wedding, though scaled down due to the pandemic, was a testament to the enduring bonds of love and family. It marked a joyful occasion for the British royal family, bringing together members in a celebration of unity and happiness.

title: African swine fever: Australia expels Vietnamese woman over pork haul
text: Australian authorities have deported a Vietnamese woman who attempted to smuggle pork products into the country, amid concerns over African swine fever (ASF). The woman, who arrived in Australia from Vietnam on a tourist visa, was found to be carrying 18 kilograms of pork in her luggage. The pork was vacuum-sealed and hidden in various bags. ASF is a highly contagious viral disease that affects pigs and wild boar. It is not harmful to humans, but it can cause significant economic losses to the pig industry. title: Taio Cruz quits TikTok after 'suicidal thoughts'
text: Taio Cruz Quits TikTok After 'Suicidal Thoughts' Singer Taio Cruz has announced his departure from TikTok, citing concerns about the app's impact on his mental health. In a candid video posted to Instagram, Cruz revealed that he had been experiencing suicidal thoughts as a result of using the platform. "I've been struggling with suicidal thoughts and I've realized it's because of TikTok," he said. Cruz explained that the constant need to create and post content had become overwhelming and had led to feelings of anxiety and depression. "I felt like I was always chasing the next hit of dopamine, the next like or comment," he said. "It was like an addiction." The singer expressed concern about the potential impact of TikTok on young people, particularly those who are vulnerable to mental health issues. "I'm worried about the kids who are growing up with this app," he said. "It's creating a culture of comparison and perfectionism that is unhealthy." Cruz's announcement has sparked a debate about the potential risks of social media use. Some critics have argued that the constant pressure to create and share content can lead to mental health issues, while others have defended TikTok, claiming that it can be a positive platform for self-expression and community building. TikTok has responded to Cruz's concerns by saying that it is committed to creating a safe and supportive environment for its users. The company has introduced a number of features aimed at promoting mental well-being, such as the ability to limit screen time and filter out harmful content. However, some experts believe that more needs to be done to address the potential mental health risks of social media. Dr. Henrietta Bowden-Jones, a consultant psychiatrist, said: "Social media can be a double-edged sword. It can provide support and connection, but it can also be a source of stress and anxiety." Bowden-Jones recommended that people use social media in moderation and be aware of the potential risks. "If you start to feel overwhelmed or anxious, it's important to take a step back and disconnect," she said. Cruz's decision to quit TikTok is a reminder of the importance of mental health and the need for social media platforms to do more to protect their users. As the popularity of social media continues to grow, it is essential that we continue to explore and address its potential impact on our mental well-being.
