title: Stoke-on-Trent hotel for homeless secures housing for rough sleepers
text: In a heartening development, a hotel in Stoke-on-Trent that had been temporarily housing homeless people during the pandemic has now secured permanent housing for over 20 rough sleepers. The initiative, spearheaded by the city council and local charities, has been hailed as a lifeline for those who had previously been living on the streets. The project began in March 2020 when the Britannia Hotel agreed to provide accommodation for rough sleepers during the initial Covid-19 lockdown. The hotel's 100 rooms became a sanctuary for those who had nowhere else to go, offering them a safe and warm place to stay with regular meals and access to support services. The success of the initiative led the city council to extend the partnership with the Britannia Hotel. In addition, funding was secured from the government's Rough Sleeping Accommodation Programme (RSAP) to provide longer-term accommodation for the hotel's residents. Working in collaboration with local charities, the council has now found permanent housing for 22 former rough sleepers who had been staying at the hotel. These individuals have been placed in a variety of accommodation, including council-owned properties, supported housing, and private rented accommodation. The council's cabinet member for housing and regeneration, Councillor Abi Brown, expressed her delight at the positive outcomes achieved through the project. "This is fantastic news," she said. "We are committed to ending homelessness in Stoke-on-Trent, and this project has played a vital role in helping us to achieve that goal." She added: "It is heartening to see that so many people who have been experiencing homelessness have been able to secure permanent housing. This will make a real difference to their lives, providing them with the stability and support they need to rebuild their lives." One of the former rough sleepers who has now found permanent accommodation is 45-year-old John Smith. John had been living on the streets for several years before he was offered a room at the Britannia Hotel. "It was a lifeline for me," said John. "I had nowhere else to go, and I was struggling to survive. The hotel gave me a safe place to stay and support to get my life back on track." John has now been placed in a supported housing scheme where he is receiving help with his mental health and addiction issues. He is also working with a job coach to find employment. "I am so grateful for the help I have received," said John. "I am now in a much better place, and I am looking forward to the future." The success of the Stoke-on-Trent project demonstrates the positive impact that can be achieved when local authorities, charities, and the private sector work together to tackle homelessness. It is hoped that the model can be replicated in other areas to help end the scourge of rough sleeping on our streets.

title: Box ticking: Dubious benefits of midges and ticks explored
text: Box Ticking: Dubious Benefits of Midges and Ticks Explored Despite their often-pesky reputation, midges and ticks play essential roles in various ecosystems. However, their perceived benefits often fail to outweigh the negative impacts they can have on human health and well-being. Midges: A Deceptive Nitrogen Fixer Midges are commonly credited for their contribution to nitrogen fixation in wetlands. However, their role is often overstated and varies widely based on environmental conditions. In some cases, midges may actually contribute to nitrogen release, exacerbating nutrient pollution in sensitive ecosystems. Moreover, their presence can be a nuisance to humans. Their bites are known to cause itchy rashes and skin irritation, and they can be a deterrent to outdoor activities. In some areas, swarms of midges have even led to economic losses in tourism and recreation. Ticks: Disease Vectors with Unproven Medicinal Benefits Ticks are notorious for transmitting diseases to both humans and animals. Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, and Rocky Mountain spotted fever are just a few of the serious conditions they can cause. In the United States alone, tick-borne diseases are estimated to affect over 300,000 people annually. Despite this, there have been claims that certain tick species can have medicinal benefits. However, scientific evidence for these claims is often lacking. While some studies have shown that tick saliva contains compounds with anti-inflammatory properties, the therapeutic value of these compounds is highly questionable. Even if tick saliva does contain beneficial compounds, the risk of contracting serious diseases from tick bites far outweighs any potential health benefits. Limited Ecological Benefits While midges and ticks may serve as food sources for certain animals, their overall ecological importance is often exaggerated. Some bird species, such as swallows and flycatchers, do feed on midges, but these birds have other sources of nutrition as well. Ticks, on the other hand, are primarily parasites that feed on the blood of animals. While they may contribute to host population regulation in some cases, their role is often minimal. Additionally, the diseases they transmit can have devastating effects on wildlife populations. Weighing the Risks and Benefits It is essential to weigh the potential benefits of midges and ticks against their risks to human health and well-being. While these insects may play minor ecological roles, they also pose significant risks to humans and animals. Exaggerating their benefits to justify their presence can be misleading and dangerous. Public health measures should prioritize controlling tick and midge populations to minimize disease risk and improve the quality of life for people living in affected areas.

title: Eurozone manufacturing growth remains 'meagre'
text: Eurozone Manufacturing Growth Remains 'Meagre' The Eurozone's manufacturing sector continued to show signs of weakness in February, as growth remained "meagre," according to a closely-watched survey. The IHS Markit Eurozone Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 50.1 in February, from 50.9 in January. A reading above 50 indicates growth, while below 50 denotes contraction. Chris Williamson, chief business economist at IHS Markit, said the "meagre" growth in February was largely driven by the ongoing impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. "Eurozone manufacturing output rose at the weakest pace for three months in February as supply chain disruptions and capacity constraints continued to hamper production," Williamson said. "The Omicron wave of the COVID-19 pandemic also weighed on activity, particularly in the consumer-facing sectors." The survey showed that new orders fell for the first time in three months, while production growth slowed to a three-month low. "The drop in new orders is a particular concern, as it suggests that the current weakness in manufacturing output could persist in the near term," Williamson said. The survey also found that inflationary pressures remained high, with input costs rising at the fastest pace in six months. "Companies report that supply chain constraints continue to be a major problem, leading to longer lead times and higher prices," Williamson said. Despite the challenges, Williamson said that there were some positive signs in the survey. "The rate of job creation remained robust, and there was evidence of a slight easing in supply chain constraints," he said. "However, with the war in Ukraine creating additional uncertainty, it is too early to say whether these positive signs will be sustained." The Eurozone economy has been hit hard by the COVID-19 pandemic and the ongoing supply chain disruptions. The war in Ukraine has added to the uncertainty surrounding the economic outlook. The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to raise interest rates for the first time in more than a decade later this year in an effort to combat rising inflation. However, the bank is also mindful of the risks to economic growth. The latest PMI survey suggests that the Eurozone economy is facing a number of challenges, and that growth is likely to remain subdued in the near term.

title: Benefit sanctions can cause severe hardship, say MPs
text: Benefit Sanctions Can Cause Severe Hardship, Say MPs The House of Commons Work and Pensions Committee has published a report on the use of benefit sanctions, finding that they can cause severe hardship for claimants. The report found that sanctions are often imposed for minor or unintentional errors, and that they can lead to people losing their homes, going hungry, and getting into debt. The committee also found that the sanctions system is not always fair, and that it can discriminate against certain groups of people, such as those with mental health problems or disabilities. The report makes a number of recommendations to the government, including: Abolishing the use of sanctions for minor or unintentional errors Introducing a more flexible approach to sanctions, which takes into account individual circumstances Providing more support for claimants who are facing hardship as a result of sanctions The government has said that it will consider the committee's recommendations. The report's findings are based on evidence from a wide range of sources, including claimants, charities, and experts. The committee also visited a number of food banks and homeless shelters to see the impact of sanctions firsthand. The report is a damning indictment of the government's use of benefit sanctions. It is clear that sanctions are causing severe hardship for many claimants, and that the government needs to take action to reform the system. Case Study: Sarah Sarah is a single mother of two young children. She has been claiming benefits for the past year after losing her job. In January, Sarah received a letter from the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) informing her that she had been sanctioned for failing to attend a job interview. Sarah had not received the letter inviting her to the interview, and she had no idea that she was supposed to attend. Sarah appealed the decision, but her appeal was unsuccessful. She was told that she would lose her benefits for three months. Sarah was devastated. She had no way to pay her rent or buy food for her children. She was forced to rely on food banks and the generosity of friends and family. Sarah's experience is not unique. Thousands of people across the UK are being sanctioned for minor or unintentional errors. The sanctions system is broken, and it is causing severe hardship for many claimants.

title: Stain-shedding coating gets tough
text: Stain-shedding Coating Gets Tough Scientists have developed a new stain-shedding coating inspired by the slippery surface of pitcher plants. The coating is durable and can be applied to a variety of surfaces, making them resistant to stains from coffee, red wine, and even permanent markers. The coating is made from a polymer called polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS), which is commonly used in contact lenses and medical implants. The PDMS is coated with a layer of fluorinated molecules, which are known for their water- and oil-repellent properties. The resulting coating is both hydrophobic and oleophobic, meaning that it repels both water and oil. This makes it highly resistant to stains, as most stains are either water-based or oil-based. To test the coating's durability, the researchers applied it to a variety of surfaces, including glass, metal, plastic, and fabric. The coated surfaces were then exposed to a variety of stains, including coffee, red wine, and permanent markers. The coating was found to be effective at repelling all of the stains, even after multiple applications. The researchers also tested the coating's durability by scratching it with a razor blade. The coating was able to withstand the scratching without losing its stain-repellent properties. The new coating has a wide range of potential applications, including in the food and beverage industry, the healthcare industry, and the textile industry. It could be used to create stain-resistant clothing, tablecloths, and other fabrics. It could also be used to create stain-resistant surfaces in kitchens, bathrooms, and hospitals. The researchers believe that the new coating could have a significant impact on the way we clean and protect our belongings. They are currently working to develop a commercial version of the coating that can be easily applied to a variety of surfaces. In addition to its stain-repellent properties, the coating is also transparent, flexible, and non-toxic. This makes it ideal for a variety of applications where a clear, durable coating is required. The researchers believe that the new coating could revolutionize the way we protect our belongings from stains. They are excited to see how the coating can be used to create new products and improve existing ones.

During that time, streamers will refrain from streaming on Twitch, as a way of sending a message to the company. Twitch has said that it is committed to creating a safe and inclusive environment for its streamers and viewers. "We do not tolerate any form of abuse on our platform," a Twitch spokesperson said. "We are constantly working to improve our policies and procedures to ensure that Twitch is a place where everyone feels safe and respected." However, streamers have said that Twitch's actions have not gone far enough. "Twitch needs to do more than just issue statements," said another streamer, who goes by the name Pokimane. "They need to take concrete steps to address the underlying culture of abuse on the platform." The blackout is expected to be a major test for Twitch. If it is successful, it could force the company to take more aggressive action to address the issue of abuse on its platform. However, it is also possible that the blackout will have little impact on Twitch. The company has a large and loyal user base, and it is not clear how many streamers will be willing to participate in the blackout. Regardless of its impact, the blackout is a clear sign that streamers are fed up with the way that Twitch has handled the issue of abuse on its platform. title: Sir Keir Starmer: Labour has 'duty' to tackle anti-Semitism
text: Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer has said his party has a "duty" to tackle anti-Semitism, following a damning report into the issue. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) found that the party was responsible for unlawful acts of harassment and discrimination. Sir Keir apologized for the hurt caused and said the party would "change and improve." He said: "We have a duty to tackle anti-Semitism wherever it occurs, and to do so robustly and urgently." The EHRC report found that the Labour Party had a "culture of deference" to former leader Jeremy Corbyn, who has been accused of tolerating anti-Semitism. The report also found that the party had failed to deal with complaints of anti-Semitism promptly and effectively. Sir Keir said that he accepted the findings of the report and that the party would implement all of its recommendations. He said: "I am determined to build a Labour Party that is welcoming and inclusive for all." The EHRC report is the latest in a series of setbacks for the Labour Party, which has been embroiled in a long-running row over anti-Semitism. In 2019, the party was suspended from the international body that represents social democratic parties. And in 2020, the former Labour MP Luciana Berger quit the party, accusing it of being "institutionally anti-Semitic." Sir Keir's apology and commitment to tackling anti-Semitism has been welcomed by some Jewish groups. The Jewish Labour Movement said: "We welcome Sir Keir Starmer's unequivocal apology and commitment to tackling anti-Semitism in the Labour Party." But other groups have said that the party needs to do more to demonstrate that it is serious about tackling the issue. The Campaign Against Antisemitism said: "Sir Keir Starmer's apology is a welcome first step, but it must be followed by real action to root out the anti-Semitism that has taken hold in the Labour Party." The Labour Party is now facing a legal challenge over its handling of anti-Semitism. A group of Jewish former Labour MPs and party members is suing the party, alleging that it has failed to tackle anti-Semitism effectively. The case is due to be heard in the High Court later this year.

title: Should we lose civil liberties for national security?
text: In the aftermath of terrorist attacks and other national crises, it's tempting to trade away some personal freedoms in the name of safety. But does sacrificing civil liberties truly enhance national security? Proponents of such measures argue that increased surveillance, restrictions on political speech, and the suspension of due process are necessary to prevent future attacks. They point to the Patriot Act, passed after the 9/11 attacks, as an example of successful legislation that has helped thwart potential threats. However, critics contend that such measures can have unintended consequences. Mass surveillance can stifle dissent and create a climate of fear. By chilling free speech, governments can prevent individuals from speaking out against oppressive policies or expressing unpopular opinions. Furthermore, the suspension of due process can lead to wrongful convictions and erode trust in the justice system. When individuals are detained indefinitely without charge or access to legal counsel, the fundamental right to a fair trial is compromised. It is also worth considering the potential long-term effects of eroding civil liberties. Once lost, these freedoms can be difficult to regain. The slippery slope argument suggests that once one liberty is sacrificed, the door is opened to further encroachments on personal rights. For example, the Espionage Act of 1917, which criminalized anti-war speech during World War I, was later used to suppress political dissent. Similarly, the Smith Act of 1940, which targeted communists and other radicals, was later used to prosecute civil rights activists. Moreover, the balance between security and liberty is a delicate one. While it is certainly important to protect citizens from harm, excessive sacrifices of civil liberties can undermine the very values that make a society free and democratic. As former President Franklin D. Roosevelt once said, "In times of national emergency, the public must beware of the danger of hysterical demands for legislation to curb the rights of American citizens." It is essential to find a balance that does not compromise the basic freedoms that underpin a democratic society. This means implementing effective security measures while safeguarding civil liberties. Instead of eroding personal rights, governments should focus on addressing the root causes of terrorism, such as poverty, inequality, and social injustice. By investing in education, opportunity, and diplomacy, we can create a more just and peaceful world that is less susceptible to the lure of extremism. Ultimately, the question of whether we should lose civil liberties for national security is a complex one with no easy answers. It requires a careful weighing of the potential risks and benefits and a recognition that the preservation of both security and liberty are essential for a thriving society.

title: Covid-19: Open prison Hollesley Bay has 'quarter of inmates' infected
text: Covid-19: Open prison Hollesley Bay has 'quarter of inmates' infected A quarter of inmates at an open prison in Suffolk have tested positive for Covid-19, the BBC understands. Hollesley Bay prison, near Woodbridge, holds about 100 male prisoners in open conditions. The Prison Service said 25 prisoners and seven staff have tested positive. They are all in self-isolation. It is understood about 25 prisoners have tested positive in the past week and the first case was reported on 22 December. The open prison system allows inmates to work and take part in education outside the prison walls during the day, but they must return to their cells at night. Inmates can also apply to go on temporary release to visit family or friends, or to attend medical appointments. One prison source told the BBC they believe the outbreak began with an inmate who had been on temporary release and attended a large family event. The Prison Service said the prison was working closely with Public Health England to manage the outbreak. "All appropriate measures are being taken to prevent the spread of the virus," it said. "This includes enhanced cleaning regimes, the provision of PPE and social distancing measures." The prison service has already taken steps to limit the spread of the virus, including reducing the number of prisoners who can go out to work or take part in education. It has also stopped all visits to the prison and is not allowing any new prisoners to be admitted. The outbreak at Hollesley Bay is the latest in a series of Covid-19 outbreaks in prisons in England and Wales. In October, more than 100 prisoners at HMP Berwyn in Wrexham tested positive for Covid-19. And in November, more than 50 prisoners at HMP Oakwood in Featherstone, Staffordshire, tested positive for the virus. The Prison Service said it was committed to protecting the health and safety of staff and prisoners. "We are working closely with Public Health England to manage the outbreak at Hollesley Bay and are taking all necessary steps to prevent the spread of the virus," it said.

title: TSB chaos: 'We are on our knees,' says boss
text: TSB customers are still struggling to access their accounts, a week after the bank's IT meltdown. The bank's chief executive, Paul Pester, has apologised for the chaos, saying: "We are on our knees." More than 1.9 million customers have been affected by the problems, which began on April 23. TSB has said that it is working to resolve the issues as quickly as possible, but it is not yet clear when customers will be able to access their accounts again. In the meantime, TSB has set up a £300 million fund to help customers who have been affected by the problems. The bank has also said that it will not charge any fees or interest on overdrafts or credit cards for customers who have been affected by the IT meltdown. However, many customers are still angry and frustrated about the situation. Some have said that they have been unable to pay their bills or access their savings. Others have said that they have lost out on important payments, such as mortgage repayments. TSB has said that it understands the frustration of its customers and that it is doing everything it can to resolve the issues. However, it is not yet clear when customers will be able to access their accounts again. In the meantime, TSB has advised customers to keep checking its website for updates. The bank has also said that it will be contacting customers directly to let them know when their accounts are back up and running. TSB is not the only bank to have experienced IT problems in recent months. In February, Lloyds Bank customers were unable to access their accounts for several hours due to an IT outage. In March, RBS customers were unable to use their cards or withdraw cash for several hours due to an IT problem. These incidents have raised concerns about the resilience of the UK banking system. The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has said that it is investigating the TSB IT meltdown. The FCA has also said that it is working with other banks to ensure that they have robust IT systems in place.

title: How Perrie from Little Mix is helping me learn to love my freckles
text: Perrie Edwards, a member of the iconic girl group Little Mix, has become an unexpected role model for me in terms of self-love and body acceptance. Her unapologetic embrace of her freckles has inspired me to challenge societal beauty standards and appreciate the unique features that make me who I am. I had spent so many years hiding behind a mask, and now I was finally ready to show the world who I truly was. The reaction I received was overwhelmingly positive. Friends and strangers alike complimented me on my freckles, telling me how they made me look unique and beautiful. Embracing my freckles has been a transformative experience. It has not only boosted my self-esteem but has also given me a newfound sense of authenticity. I no longer feel the need to conform to unrealistic beauty ideals. I am proud of who I am, both inside and out. Perrie's influence extends beyond just her freckles. Seeing her use her platform to challenge body shaming and promote self-love has inspired me to do the same. In an industry that often objectifies women, Perrie is a refreshing and much-needed voice. title: Meningitis death girl Izzy Gentry 'not given a chance'
text: A young woman who died of meningitis was "not given a chance" by a healthcare system that failed her, her heartbroken father has said. Izzy Gentry, 20, died in hospital on June 14 after falling ill just days earlier with a headache and vomiting. Her father, Darren Gentry, said she had been seen by a GP on the day she was taken to hospital, but was sent home with paracetamol. He said the doctor had failed to spot the tell-tale signs of meningitis, such as a rash and stiff neck, and had not carried out a blood test. "She was not given a chance," Mr Gentry said. "If she had been seen by a doctor who knew what to look for, she would still be here today." Izzy, from Carlton, Nottinghamshire, was a student at Nottingham Trent University. She had been out with friends on June 12 when she started to feel unwell. She went home and went to bed, but woke up the next morning with a headache and vomiting. Her parents took her to the GP, who diagnosed her with a virus and sent her home with paracetamol. But her condition worsened and she was taken to hospital on June 14. She was diagnosed with meningitis and died later that day. Mr Gentry said he was "furious" that his daughter had not been given the care she needed. "The doctor who saw her should have known better," he said. "He should have carried out a blood test and he should have spotted the signs of meningitis. "If he had, she would still be here today." A spokesman for the NHS said: "We are deeply saddened by the death of Izzy Gentry and our thoughts are with her family and friends at this difficult time. "We are investigating the circumstances of her death and we will be working with the family to understand what happened." Meningitis is a serious bacterial infection of the membranes that line the brain and spinal cord. It can be fatal if not treated quickly. The symptoms of meningitis can include: A headache Vomiting A stiff neck A rash Confusion Drowsiness If you think someone has meningitis, it is important to seek medical help immediately.

title: Queen stars launch 'moving' exhibition
text: Queen stars launch 'moving' exhibition Queen stars Brian May and Roger Taylor have launched a new exhibition celebrating the band's history. The exhibition, called "Queen: The Studio Experience," opened at the O2 in London on Tuesday and features over 500 items from the band's archive. These include handwritten lyrics, stage costumes, and rare recordings. The exhibition also features a recreation of the band's iconic recording studio, where visitors can hear the band's biggest hits and watch footage of them in action. May and Taylor said they were "thrilled" to be able to share the exhibition with fans. "It's a very moving exhibition," said May. "It's a chance for people to see the band's history and how we worked together." "It's a very special experience," added Taylor. "I think people will really enjoy it." The exhibition has been praised by critics, with The Guardian calling it "a must-see for any Queen fan." The Telegraph said the exhibition was "a fitting tribute to one of the greatest bands of all time." "Queen: The Studio Experience" will run at the O2 until September 2023. Tickets are on sale now. Queen's history Queen were formed in London in 1970. The band consisted of Freddie Mercury (lead vocals and piano), Brian May (lead guitar and vocals), Roger Taylor (drums and vocals), and John Deacon (bass guitar). Queen released their debut album in 1973 and went on to become one of the most successful bands of all time. The band has sold over 300 million albums worldwide and has won numerous awards, including four Grammy Awards. Queen's biggest hits include "Bohemian Rhapsody," "We Will Rock You," and "We Are the Champions." Freddie Mercury died of AIDS in 1991. John Deacon retired from the band in 1997. May and Taylor have continued to tour and record as Queen, with Adam Lambert on lead vocals. Queen's legacy Queen are considered one of the greatest bands of all time. The band's music has been praised for its originality, complexity, and emotional power. Queen have influenced countless other bands and their music continues to be enjoyed by fans around the world. The "Queen: The Studio Experience" exhibition is a unique opportunity to learn more about one of the most iconic bands in history.

title: UK tax evasion action hunt identifies 100 individuals
text: UK Tax Evasion Action Hunt Identifies 100 Individuals A major tax evasion crackdown by HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) has identified 100 individuals suspected of hiding millions of pounds offshore. The operation, codenamed "Project Lantana," involved investigators working with international tax authorities to uncover complex financial structures used to conceal wealth abroad. The individuals under investigation are believed to have hidden assets in countries such as Switzerland, Monaco, and the British Virgin Islands. HMRC said the suspected tax evasion amounts to hundreds of millions of pounds. The agency has frozen assets, seized property, and launched criminal investigations. "This is a significant blow to tax evasion in the UK," said HMRC Director General Jim Harra. "We will not tolerate those who hide their wealth offshore to avoid paying their fair share of tax." The investigation was sparked by the Panama Papers leak in 2016, which revealed how wealthy individuals and companies used offshore companies to avoid taxes. HMRC has since invested heavily in new technology and data analysis capabilities to identify and pursue suspected tax evaders. The individuals under investigation come from a variety of backgrounds, including business owners, celebrities, and high-net-worth individuals. They are accused of using offshore structures to hide income, assets, and profits from HMRC. HMRC said it is working closely with the National Crime Agency and other law enforcement partners to tackle tax evasion. The agency has also called on the public to report any suspected tax fraud. "Tax evasion is a serious crime that deprives vital public services of funding," said Harra. "We urge anyone with information about tax fraud to come forward." The operation is part of HMRC's ongoing efforts to crack down on tax evasion and avoidance. In recent years, the agency has recovered billions of pounds in unpaid taxes. The government has also introduced a number of measures to deter tax evasion, including the introduction of a "strict liability" offense for failing to declare offshore income. However, tax evasion remains a problem in the UK. The Tax Justice Network estimates that the UK loses around £35 billion a year to tax evasion. HMRC's crackdown on tax evasion is a welcome step towards tackling this problem. However, it is clear that more needs to be done to close the loopholes that allow individuals to hide their wealth offshore.

text: How did it go so wrong for Govia Thameslink? title: Portland homes evacuated as sirens sound for first time
text: Residents in Portland, Oregon, have been evacuated from their homes as sirens sounded for the first time in decades, warning of an imminent threat to the city. The sirens, which were installed in the 1950s to warn of an air raid, were activated just before 7am on Wednesday morning. City officials have urged people in the affected areas to take shelter immediately. The exact nature of the threat is not yet known, but local media are reporting that there is a large fire in the city's industrial district. The fire is said to be spreading rapidly, and there are concerns that it could spread to residential areas. Portland Fire & Rescue is currently battling the blaze, and has requested assistance from neighboring fire departments. The extent of the damage is not yet known, but the fire is believed to have caused significant damage to several buildings. The evacuation order is currently in effect for the following areas: The Pearl District The Old Town Chinatown The Lloyd District The Central Eastside Industrial District Residents in these areas are advised to leave their homes immediately and seek shelter in a safe location. The city has set up several emergency shelters, which can be found at the following locations: The Oregon Convention Center The Moda Center The Portland Expo Center The city is urging residents to stay informed about the situation by monitoring local news and social media. The city's website also has up-to-date information on the fire and evacuation order. The activation of the sirens is a rare event in Portland. The last time the sirens were sounded was in 1980, when there was a major earthquake in the Pacific Northwest. The city has been preparing for the possibility of a major disaster for several years. In 2016, the city adopted a new emergency management plan, which includes a provision for sounding the sirens in the event of an imminent threat. The city is also working to improve its communication systems, so that residents can be quickly notified of any emergencies. The city is urging residents to sign up for the city's emergency alert system, which can be found at the city's website.

title: Are these north Wales hills sitting on a gold mine?
text: Nestled amidst the breathtaking landscape of north Wales, the rugged hills of Bwlchgwyn and Cefn Mawr have long held a tantalizing secret - the potential to harbor vast reserves of gold. Recent exploration by mining company Alba Mineral Resources has ignited excitement among geologists and investors alike, raising the tantalizing prospect that these hills could be sitting on a gold mine. Historical records hint at the presence of gold in the area dating back to Roman times. However, it was not until the 19th century that serious exploration began. In the 1860s, a gold rush gripped the region, attracting miners from far and wide. While some small-scale mining operations did uncover some gold, the veins proved to be narrow and inconsistent, leading to the eventual decline of the rush. Fast forward to the present day, and Alba Mineral Resources has embarked on a renewed exploration campaign using cutting-edge technology. Their focus is on a potentially large gold deposit that lies deep beneath the hills, known as the Bwlchgwyn Gold Project. Through extensive drilling and core sampling, Alba has identified several gold-bearing zones. The most significant of these is the Central Zone, which has shown consistently high gold grades over a substantial area. Further drilling is underway to delineate the full extent of this zone and to estimate the potential size and value of the deposit. "The results we've seen so far are very encouraging," said Alba's exploration manager, Dr. Mark Jones. "We're excited about the potential of this project to deliver a significant new gold resource for Wales." The company's exploration activities have sparked interest from the wider mining industry and the financial community. Investors are keen to get involved in what could potentially be a lucrative investment opportunity. However, it is important to note that exploration is still ongoing, and there is no guarantee that the Bwlchgwyn Gold Project will ultimately prove to be economically viable. Further drilling and analysis are required to fully understand the size and quality of the deposit. Furthermore, the project would require significant investment and infrastructure to develop. Environmental considerations and local community engagement will also be key factors in determining the future of the project. Despite these uncertainties, the potential rewards of the Bwlchgwyn Gold Project are undeniably tantalizing. If Alba's exploration efforts prove successful, it could transform the area, bringing economic benefits and creating new jobs. It could also establish north Wales as a significant player in the global gold mining industry.

title: India mango farmers angry at dump plan
text: In the verdant heart of India's mango-producing belt, a storm of anger is brewing among farmers over the government's plans to dump thousands of tonnes of imported Alphonso mangoes. The move, intended to ease dwindling domestic supplies and cool soaring prices, has sent shockwaves through a community that relies heavily on the fruit for their livelihoods. Farmers fear the influx of foreign mangoes will flood the market, driving down prices and potentially ruining their businesses. "This is a death knell for mango farmers," said Sanjay Jadhav, a farmer from the western state of Maharashtra. "Why import mangoes when our own farmers are struggling?" The government's decision stems from a shortfall in domestic production this year due to unfavourable weather conditions. To address the gap, it granted permission to import 20,000 tonnes of Alphonso mangoes from the neighbouring country of Pakistan. However, farmers argue that the imported mangoes will not only harm their livelihoods but also compromise the reputation of Indian Alphonso mangoes, renowned worldwide for their sweet and juicy flavour. "Pakistan produces different varieties of Alphonso mangoes," said Satish Patwari, a farmer from the Alphonso-growing district of Ratnagiri. "Mixing them with our own mangoes will damage the brand and reduce consumer confidence." The farmers' concerns are echoed by industry experts, who warn that the import plan could disrupt the delicate balance of the mango market. "The government should have explored alternative options, such as increasing domestic production or importing from other countries with similar mango varieties," said Parag Parikh, an agricultural economist. The government, for its part, insists that the import move is a temporary measure to ensure adequate supply and prevent price spikes. It has promised to provide compensation to farmers affected by the decision. But for the mango farmers of India, the government's assurances ring hollow. They demand a reversal of the import decision and a long-term plan to support domestic mango production. "We are not asking for handouts," said Jadhav. "We want the government to create a supportive environment where mango farmers can thrive and continue to produce the best mangoes in the world." As the mango season approaches its peak, the battle between India's mango farmers and the government continues to simmer, threatening the livelihoods of thousands and the reputation of an iconic fruit.

title: Ari Fuld killing: $1m raised for family by crowdfunders
text: In a remarkable display of global solidarity, over $1 million has been raised for the family of Ari Fuld, an Israeli-American father of four who was brutally murdered in a terrorist attack in the West Bank on Sunday. The outpouring of support has been driven by a crowdfunding campaign launched by Fuld's friends in the US, which has seen donations pour in from around the world. Fuld, a 45-year-old dual US-Israeli citizen, was stabbed to death while driving his car near the Jewish settlement of Efrat. The attack was claimed by the Palestinian militant group Hamas, which hailed Fuld's killing as a "heroic operation" against Israeli settlers. The crowdfunding campaign, hosted on the GoFundMe platform, was set up by Fuld's close friend, Rabbi Yaakov Menken. The initial goal was to raise $500,000 to support Fuld's wife and four young children, but that target was quickly surpassed. As of Tuesday morning, the campaign had raised over $1.1 million, with donations coming from more than 14,000 people from 50 countries. In a statement posted on the GoFundMe page, Rabbi Menken thanked the global community for their "overwhelming outpouring of love and support." He said that the money raised would help Fuld's family "during this incredibly difficult time" and allow them to focus on rebuilding their lives. "Ari was a true hero who dedicated his life to protecting Israel and its people," Rabbi Menken wrote. "His legacy will live on through the countless lives he touched and the impact he had on the world." The killing of Ari Fuld has been widely condemned by world leaders, including US President Donald Trump and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Trump called the attack a "horrific act of terrorism" and vowed to stand with Israel in the fight against terrorism. Netanyahu vowed to "bring the despicable murderers to justice" and said that Fuld's death would not be in vain. The crowdfunding campaign for Ari Fuld's family has been praised as a powerful example of how people from around the world can come together in the face of tragedy. It is a testament to the deep bonds of friendship and solidarity that unite people across borders and religious divides.

title: Google Android phone shipments increase by 886%
text: Google Android Phone Shipments Surge by 886% Google's Android operating system has seen a remarkable surge in popularity, with shipments of Android-powered smartphones increasing by 886% year-over-year in the second quarter of 2023. This exponential growth has cemented Android's position as the dominant force in the mobile phone market. According to data from market research firm Canalys, Android's market share reached an astounding 87% in Q2, a significant increase from its 75% share in the same period last year. This surge has been driven by a combination of factors, including the growing popularity of budget-friendly Android devices and the expansion of the Android ecosystem. The rapid growth of Android shipments has been particularly noticeable in emerging markets, where the demand for affordable smartphones is high. Android phones have become increasingly accessible to a broader range of consumers, thanks to the availability of low-cost models and the flexibility of the Android platform. In addition, Google's efforts to enhance the Android experience have played a significant role in its success. Regular software updates, improved security features, and a wide selection of apps and services have made Android devices more appealing to users. The dominance of Android has also been bolstered by the rise of Chinese smartphone manufacturers. Companies like Huawei, Xiaomi, and OPPO have been aggressively pushing their Android-powered devices into the global market, challenging established players like Apple and Samsung. The growth of Android shipments has had a significant impact on the smartphone industry. It has led to increased competition, lower prices for consumers, and a wider range of devices to choose from. Furthermore, Android's dominance has spurred innovation in the mobile ecosystem, with developers creating new apps and services specifically designed for the platform. As Android continues to gain ground, it is expected to further reshape the smartphone market. The platform's affordability, flexibility, and growing ecosystem position it well to maintain its leadership position for the foreseeable future.

title: Covid in Scotland: Hundreds hit with Covid fines over new year
text: Hundreds of people across Scotland have been fined for breaching Covid-19 regulations over the New Year period. Police Scotland said on Monday that 300 fixed penalty notices were issued between December 31 and January 2. The force said the majority of fines were for house parties, with others issued for large gatherings in public places. Assistant Chief Constable Alan Speirs said: "Our approach throughout the pandemic has been to engage with the public, explain the regulations and encourage compliance. "However, we will not hesitate to use enforcement where necessary to protect public health." The Scottish government has urged people to follow the rules in place to help stop the spread of the virus. First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said: "The vast majority of people in Scotland are following the rules and doing everything they can to help suppress the virus. "But it is clear that a small minority are not and their actions are putting others at risk. "We have repeatedly asked people to follow the rules and we have given them plenty of time to do so. "But we will not hesitate to take action against those who continue to flout the rules and put others at risk." The Scottish government has introduced a number of measures to help stop the spread of the virus, including a ban on gatherings of more than six people from different households. People are also being urged to stay at home as much as possible and to work from home if they can. The Scottish government has also introduced a number of financial support measures to help businesses and individuals affected by the pandemic. These measures include grants for businesses, loans for individuals and a temporary increase in Universal Credit payments. The Scottish government has said that it will continue to review the situation and will make changes to the regulations as necessary. The Scottish government has also urged people to get vaccinated against Covid-19. The vaccine is free and available to everyone over the age of 12. The Scottish government has said that the vaccine is the best way to protect yourself and others from the virus.

title: Covid: Wales-wide lockdown questioned by Tories
text: The Welsh government's decision to impose a Wales-wide lockdown has been criticised by the Welsh Conservatives, who have called for a more targeted approach. First Minister Mark Drakeford announced on Friday that Wales would enter a 17-day "firebreak" lockdown from 6pm on Friday 23 October, amid rising Covid-19 cases. The lockdown will see schools, non-essential shops and hospitality businesses close, and people will be advised to stay at home as much as possible. But Welsh Conservative leader Paul Davies said the lockdown was a "blunt instrument" that would "do more harm than good". He said the government should have considered a more targeted approach, such as localised lockdowns in areas with high levels of Covid-19 cases. "The Welsh government has once again taken the easy option of a blanket lockdown, rather than taking a more targeted approach," Mr Davies said. "This lockdown will have a devastating impact on our economy and will cause untold damage to our businesses and livelihoods. "The Welsh government needs to think again and come up with a more proportionate response to the current situation." The Welsh government has defended its decision to impose a lockdown, saying it is necessary to prevent the NHS from being overwhelmed. Health Minister Vaughan Gething said the lockdown was "not an easy decision" but that it was "the right decision". "We know that a lockdown will have a significant impact on people's lives, but we believe that it is necessary to protect the NHS and save lives," Mr Gething said. "We are asking everyone in Wales to play their part and follow the rules of the lockdown. "By working together, we can get through this difficult time." The lockdown in Wales will be reviewed after 17 days.

title: Uber sells self-driving cars to focus on profits
text: In a surprising move, transportation giant Uber has announced the sale of its self-driving car unit to Aurora Innovation, a leading autonomous vehicle technology company. This decision marks a significant shift in Uber's strategy as it pivots its focus towards profitability and core ride-hailing services. Uber's self-driving car program has been in development for several years, with a substantial investment of time and resources. However, despite early promises and successful demonstration projects, the company has faced challenges in bringing its autonomous vehicles to commercial operation. The technical and regulatory hurdles proved more complex and time-consuming than initially anticipated. Moreover, Uber's self-driving car ambitions have faced financial constraints. The unit has consistently operated at a loss, and recent market conditions have made it difficult for the company to justify continued investment in a venture that is not yet generating revenue. By selling its self-driving car unit, Uber is acknowledging the challenges involved in bringing autonomous vehicles to market. Instead, it will focus on its core ride-hailing business, which has proven to be a profitable and growing segment. Uber's decision to prioritize profitability is not unexpected in the current economic climate. The company has recently made several cost-cutting moves, including layoffs and the sale of non-core assets. By divesting its self-driving car unit, Uber can free up capital and resources to invest in its core business and improve its financial performance. Aurora Innovation, the buyer of Uber's self-driving car unit, is a well-funded and experienced player in the autonomous vehicle industry. The company has a strong track record in developing and testing self-driving technologies and has partnerships with major automakers such as Toyota and Hyundai. The acquisition of Uber's self-driving car unit will boost Aurora Innovation's capabilities and accelerate its progress towards commercializing autonomous vehicles. Aurora will gain access to Uber's extensive data, software, and hardware, as well as a team of experienced engineers and scientists. While Uber's decision to sell its self-driving car unit may disappoint some, it is a pragmatic move that reflects the challenges and uncertainties of the autonomous vehicle industry. Uber's prioritization of profitability and focus on its core ride-hailing business will ensure its long-term sustainability and success.
