title: Llandeilo bypass delayed until 2025 by Welsh Government
text: The £120m Llandeilo bypass has been delayed by two years and is now not expected to open until 2025, the Welsh Government has announced. The road scheme, which aims to ease congestion in the Carmarthenshire town, was originally due to be completed in 2023. But the project has been hit by a number of delays, including the discovery of archaeological remains and the need for additional environmental assessments. The Welsh Government said it was "disappointed" by the delay, but insisted that the bypass was still "essential" to improving the area's infrastructure. "The Llandeilo bypass is an essential project that will improve journey times, reduce congestion and provide better access to the town centre," said a Welsh Government spokesperson. "We are disappointed that the project has been delayed, but we are committed to delivering it as soon as possible." The delay has been met with disappointment by local businesses and residents, who have been calling for the bypass for many years. "This is a huge blow to Llandeilo," said David Jenkins, who runs a local shop. "The bypass is essential to the town's future. It will reduce congestion, improve air quality and make it easier for people to get to and from the town centre." "I'm very disappointed by the delay," said local resident Mary Jones. "I've been waiting for the bypass for years. It's a shame that we have to wait even longer." The Welsh Government said it was working with the contractor to minimize further delays. "We are working closely with the contractor to ensure that the project is completed as quickly as possible," said the spokesperson. "We understand the frustration that this delay will cause, but we ask people to bear with us. The bypass is an important investment in Llandeilo and the surrounding area. It will make a real difference to the lives of local people." The Llandeilo bypass is part of the Welsh Government's wider investment in infrastructure in the region. Other projects include the £1bn M4 relief road around Newport and the £500m A487 improvement scheme between Swansea and Carmarthen. The Welsh Government said it was committed to improving transport links in Wales and that the Llandeilo bypass was an important part of that strategy.

title: Culture shock for Stormont's youngest MLA, Megan Fearon
text: Megan Fearon, the youngest MLA in Stormont, has spoken of the culture shock she experienced when she first entered the Northern Ireland Assembly. The 25-year-old Alliance Party MLA said she was surprised by the "adversarial" nature of politics at Stormont. "I was used to a much more collaborative approach in my previous role," she said. "But here, it's very much about scoring points off each other. It can be quite off-putting." Fearon also said she was surprised by the lack of diversity in the Assembly. "I'm one of only a handful of women MLAs," she said. "And there are very few people from ethnic minority backgrounds. It's not representative of the society we live in." Fearon said she believes that Stormont needs to change if it is to be more effective. "We need to find a way to work together more collaboratively," she said. "And we need to make the Assembly more representative of the people we represent." Fearon's comments come as the Assembly is facing a number of challenges, including the ongoing Brexit negotiations and the recent collapse of the power-sharing government. It is unclear whether Fearon's call for change will be heeded by her fellow MLAs. However, her comments highlight the challenges facing Stormont and the need for reform. Here are some additional details about Megan Fearon's background and political views: Fearon is a graduate of Queen's University Belfast, where she studied politics and international relations. She was elected to the Assembly in 2017, representing the constituency of Newry and Armagh. Fearon is a member of the Alliance Party, which is a centrist party that supports Irish reunification. She is a strong advocate for social justice and equality, and has spoken out on issues such as abortion rights and same-sex marriage. Fearon is seen as a rising star in the Alliance Party, and is tipped as a potential future leader of the party.

title: Venezuela opposition wins EU's top human rights prize
text: Venezuela Opposition Wins EU's Top Human Rights Prize The European Union (EU) has awarded its prestigious Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought to the Venezuelan opposition, recognising their "courageous and tireless efforts" against President Nicolás Maduro's authoritarian regime. The prize was accepted on behalf of the opposition by Juan Guaidó, the self-proclaimed interim president of Venezuela, who has been a vocal critic of Maduro. In a statement, the EU Parliament said: "The opposition has consistently defended democracy, the rule of law and human rights." "Despite the regime's repression and persecution, they have remained steadfast in their commitment to a peaceful and democratic solution to the crisis in Venezuela." The opposition has been fighting for years against Maduro's regime, which has been accused of widespread human rights abuses, including arbitrary arrests, torture, and extrajudicial killings. The Sakharov Prize, named after the Soviet dissident Andrei Sakharov, is awarded annually to individuals or organisations that have made an exceptional contribution to the promotion of human rights and democracy. Past winners include Nelson Mandela, Aung San Suu Kyi, and Malala Yousafzai. The EU's award to the Venezuelan opposition is a significant recognition of their struggle and a clear message of support from the international community. The opposition has welcomed the award, saying it is a "recognition of the courage and determination of the Venezuelan people." "We will not rest until we have achieved our goal of a free and democratic Venezuela," said Guaidó. The Maduro regime has dismissed the award as "interference" in Venezuela's internal affairs. The EU's decision to award the Sakharov Prize to the Venezuelan opposition is likely to further strain relations between the bloc and Maduro's regime. The EU has already imposed sanctions on Venezuela, and has called for the release of political prisoners and the restoration of democracy. The Maduro regime has accused the EU of supporting the opposition's "coup attempt" and of trying to undermine his government. Despite the challenges they face, the Venezuelan opposition remains committed to its goal of a free and democratic country. The EU's Sakharov Prize is a powerful symbol of support for their struggle and a reminder that the international community stands with them.

title: Q&A: What now for staff at clinical waste firm HES?
text: Q&A: What now for staff at clinical waste firm HES? Following the liquidation of healthcare waste management firm Healthcare Environmental Services (HES), employees are facing an uncertain future. Here's a Q&A on the latest developments: What happened to HES? HES was placed into liquidation on 28 February 2023, after experiencing financial difficulties. The company, which operated across the UK, had been facing challenges for several months. What does liquidation mean? Liquidation is a legal process that involves winding up a company's affairs. An official liquidator is appointed to oversee the process, which typically includes selling off the company's assets and distributing the proceeds to creditors. What happens to employees when a company goes into liquidation? Employees who are made redundant due to liquidation may be entitled to certain payments, including redundancy pay, unpaid wages, and holiday pay. They may also be able to claim benefits from the government. What are the prospects for HES employees? The prospects for HES employees are unclear at this stage. The liquidator is currently assessing the company's financial situation and will need to sell off its assets to generate funds for creditors. It's possible that some employees may be retained if a buyer is found for the business. What should HES employees do? HES employees should contact Jobcentre Plus to register as unemployed and explore job search options. They should also check their contracts to determine their entitlements and consult with legal professionals if necessary. What is the government doing to support HES employees? The government has announced that it will provide support to HES employees through the Jobcentre Plus Rapid Response Service. This service offers guidance and support to help people find new jobs or retrain. What are the unions saying? The unions representing HES employees have expressed concern about the impact of the liquidation on their members. They are calling for the government and the liquidator to provide support and ensure that workers are treated fairly. Additional Information Employees can find more information on their rights and entitlements at the government website: www.gov.uk/redundancy The insolvency practitioner handling HES's liquidation is FRP Advisory LLP. The National Association of Waste Disposal Officers (NAWDO) is providing support to HES employees. HES employees should stay informed through updates from the liquidator and their union representatives.

title: Royals race America's Cup yachts around NZ harbour
text: Royals race America's Cup yachts around NZ harbour Auckland, New Zealand - Members of the British royal family took to the waters of Auckland's Waitematā Harbour on Wednesday, racing each other on America's Cup yachts. The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and their children, Prince George and Princess Charlotte, joined the crew of the INEOS Team UK boat, while the Earl and Countess of Wessex raced on board the Emirates Team New Zealand yacht. The two teams competed in a short race around the harbor, with INEOS Team UK emerging victorious. Afterward, the royals met with members of both teams and thanked them for their hospitality. The Duke of Cambridge, who is a keen sailor, said that he had a "fantastic time" racing on the America's Cup yacht. "It was an incredible experience to be able to race on these boats, and I'm very grateful to both teams for giving us the opportunity," he said. The Duchess of Cambridge said that she was "proud" of her husband and children for taking part in the race. "It was a great day out for the whole family," she said. The Earl and Countess of Wessex also enjoyed their time on the water, with the Countess saying that she was "amazed" by the speed of the boats. "It was a once-in-a-lifetime experience," she said. The America's Cup is the oldest international sporting trophy, and is awarded to the winner of a series of yacht races. The 36th America's Cup is being held in Auckland, New Zealand, from March 6 to 21, 2021. The INEOS Team UK and the Emirates Team New Zealand are two of the favorites to win the America's Cup. INEOS Team UK is led by Sir Ben Ainslie, who is one of the most successful sailors in history. Emirates Team New Zealand is the defending champion, having won the America's Cup in 2017. The race between the two royal teams was a friendly competition, but it also served as a reminder of the intense rivalry between the two countries in the America's Cup.

title: Storm Callum: Amber weather alert issued for Wales
text: Storm Callum: Amber weather alert issued for Wales The Met Office has issued an amber weather warning for Wales as Storm Callum is set to bring heavy rain and strong winds to the country. title: Private schools extend lead in entrants to university
text: Private schools have further extended their lead in terms of university entrants, with nearly a quarter (23.4%) of all pupils accepted onto degree courses in 2022, compared to just 14.6% in 2019. This widening gap highlights the ongoing advantages enjoyed by those from more affluent backgrounds when it comes to accessing higher education. The figures, released by the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS), show that the proportion of private school pupils accepted into university has increased by 1.8 percentage points since 2019, while the proportion of state school pupils has fallen by 0.6 percentage points. This means that private school pupils are now more than twice as likely to go to university as state school pupils. The gap is particularly pronounced in the most selective universities, with 43.5% of private school pupils accepted into Russell Group universities in 2022, compared to just 18.9% of state school pupils. This means that private school pupils are now more than twice as likely to go to a Russell Group university as state school pupils. There are a number of factors that contribute to this gap, including: Funding: Private schools have significantly more funding than state schools, which allows them to provide smaller class sizes, better facilities, and more extracurricular activities. This can give private school pupils a significant advantage in terms of academic achievement. Selection: Private schools are able to select their pupils, which means that they can admit pupils who are more likely to succeed academically. This can also contribute to the gap in university entrance rates. Culture: Private schools often have a culture of academic achievement, which can motivate pupils to work harder and achieve better grades. This can also contribute to the gap in university entrance rates. The widening gap in university entrance rates is a concern, as it means that pupils from less affluent backgrounds are less likely to have the opportunity to access higher education. This can have a significant impact on their future life chances. There are a number of things that can be done to address this gap, including: Increasing funding for state schools: State schools need to be given more funding so that they can provide the same quality of education as private schools. This would help to level the playing field for pupils from all backgrounds. Reforming school admissions: The school admissions system needs to be reformed so that it is fairer to pupils from all backgrounds. This could involve abolishing private school selection or introducing a system of quotas for state school pupils in selective schools. Changing the culture of schools: Schools need to change their culture so that they value academic achievement for all pupils, regardless of their background. This could involve setting higher expectations for all pupils and providing more support for pupils who are struggling. By addressing the factors that contribute to the gap in university entrance rates, we can help to create a more level playing field for pupils from all backgrounds and ensure that everyone has the opportunity to succeed in higher education.

title: Groupe Eurotunnel bid to run French ports
text: Groupe Eurotunnel Eyes French Port Expansion Groupe Eurotunnel, the operator of the Channel Tunnel, has submitted a bid to acquire a long-term concession to manage a cluster of French ports in the English Channel region. The bid, which is for a 50-year concession, includes the ports of Calais, Boulogne-sur-Mer, and Dunkerque. If successful, Groupe Eurotunnel would become the largest port operator in Northern France, with an annual traffic volume of approximately 25 million passengers and 6 million tonnes of freight. The company believes that the acquisition would allow it to optimize operations, improve efficiency, and enhance services for customers. The French government has launched a tender process for the concession, which is expected to close in the coming months. Groupe Eurotunnel faces competition from several other international port operators, including DP World, PSA International, and Bolloré Ports. The acquisition of the French ports would be a major strategic move for Groupe Eurotunnel, which has been seeking to diversify its revenue streams and expand its presence in the European port market. The company currently operates ports in the United Kingdom, Dover, and Folkestone, and has been exploring opportunities to expand its operations in France for several years. Analysts believe that the French ports offer significant growth potential, particularly in the areas of freight and logistics. The ports are well-positioned to serve the growing trade between the United Kingdom and the European continent, and they have the potential to develop into major hubs for the distribution of goods. Groupe Eurotunnel has a strong track record in port management and operations, and it is well-respected in the industry. The company has a proven ability to deliver high-quality services and to innovate in order to improve efficiency and customer satisfaction. The French government is expected to announce the outcome of the tender process in the coming months. If Groupe Eurotunnel is successful in its bid, it will have the opportunity to make a significant investment in the French ports and to transform them into major gateways for trade and tourism. The acquisition of the French ports would be a major boost for Groupe Eurotunnel, and it would allow the company to further solidify its position as a leading player in the European transport sector.

title: Coronavirus: Ecuador sees massive surge in deaths in April
text: Ecuador has seen a massive surge in deaths in April, with the country's official death toll from the coronavirus pandemic more than doubling in the space of a month. According to the country's health ministry, there were 3,095 confirmed deaths from Covid-19 as of 30 April - up from 1,424 at the end of March. The vast majority of the deaths have been in the coastal province of Guayas, which includes the city of Guayaquil. The province has been the epicentre of the outbreak in Ecuador, and has accounted for more than half of the country's total deaths. The surge in deaths has overwhelmed the healthcare system in Guayas, with hospitals struggling to cope with the influx of patients. Many people have died at home or in the streets, as they were unable to get access to medical care. The Ecuadorian government has imposed a nationwide lockdown in an attempt to contain the virus, but the measures have been difficult to enforce in Guayas. The province is home to many poor and informal workers, who have been unable to stay home and lose income. The government has also been criticised for its handling of the crisis, with many accusing it of being slow to react to the outbreak. The surge in deaths in Ecuador is a reminder of the devastating impact that the coronavirus pandemic can have. It is also a warning to other countries that are still struggling to contain the virus. Analysis The surge in deaths in Ecuador is a major concern, and it is likely to put a strain on the country's healthcare system. The government is facing a difficult challenge in trying to contain the virus, as it is difficult to enforce lockdown measures in a poor and densely populated country. The international community should provide assistance to Ecuador, as it is struggling to cope with the crisis. This assistance could include financial aid, medical supplies, and technical expertise. It is also important to learn from the mistakes that have been made in Ecuador. Other countries should take steps to ensure that they have a robust healthcare system in place, and that they are prepared to respond to a major outbreak of the virus.

title: Historic annual mop fair returns to Cirencester market place
text: Amidst the bustling streets of Cirencester, Gloucestershire, the historic Mop Fair makes its long-awaited return, bringing with it a vibrant tapestry of tradition, entertainment, and community spirit. This annual extravaganza, dating back to the 17th century, is a testament to the town's rich past as a wool-trading center. The fair's origins lie in the hiring of farm laborers, known as "mops," who would congregate in the market square to seek employment. Over time, Mop Fair has evolved into a much-loved festival that celebrates Cirencester's heritage and offers a plethora of attractions for visitors of all ages. The heart of the fair remains the lively market stalls, where traders from far and wide showcase their wares, from handmade crafts to delectable local produce. But there's much more to Mop Fair than just shopping. The streets are alive with the sound of music, with live performances taking place on multiple stages throughout the day. Traditional fairground rides, such as the iconic carousel and helter-skelter, add an element of nostalgia and childhood wonder. A highlight of the fair is the grand parade, which winds its way through the town center on the Saturday afternoon. Local groups, marching bands, and colorful floats participate in this vibrant procession, showcasing the diversity and creativity of Cirencester's community. In the evenings, the fair transforms into a magical nighttime spectacle. The market square is illuminated by twinkling lights, and the rides take on a surreal glow. Live music continues late into the night, providing a soundtrack for the revelry and merriments. Mop Fair is more than just a fair; it's a celebration of community and a reminder of Cirencester's rich history. It's a chance for locals and visitors alike to come together, enjoy the entertainment, and embrace the spirit of this time-honored tradition. As the sun sets on Mop Fair, the memories created will linger long after the rides have stopped and the stalls have closed. It's a testament to the enduring power of tradition and the importance of preserving our cultural heritage.

title: Covid-19: Facebook rejects businessman's jab advert
text: Covid-19: Facebook rejects businessman's jab advert Facebook has rejected an advert from a businessman offering cash to encourage people to get vaccinated against COVID-19. Ben Francis, the chief executive of Gymshark, said he was "disappointed" that the advert was not allowed to run, and offered to pay for a billboard campaign instead. The social media giant said its policy prohibited ads "that promote the sale or use of vaccines". It comes as the government launches a new campaign to encourage people to get vaccinated. Mr Francis, whose sportswear company has 1.2 million followers on Facebook, said he had offered £10 to anyone who showed proof of having had the vaccine. He said he was "frustrated" that Facebook would not allow him to run the advert, and said it was "not in the spirit of helping the UK out of this mess". A Facebook spokesperson said: "Our policy prohibits ads that promote the sale or use of vaccines, including ads that offer financial incentives for people to get vaccinated. "We understand that people are passionate about getting vaccinated, but we need to ensure that our platform is not used to promote the sale or use of vaccines. "We will continue to review our policies and make updates as necessary." The government has launched a new campaign to encourage people to get vaccinated, with the slogan "Every vaccination gives us hope". The campaign includes TV, radio and online adverts, and will see famous faces such as Sir Captain Tom Moore, Dolly Parton and Michael Sheen encouraging people to get jabbed. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: "I am delighted that so many people have already come forward to get their vaccine. "But we need to do more to encourage those who haven't yet been vaccinated to do so. "This new campaign will help us to reach more people and give them the information they need to make an informed decision about getting vaccinated." The government has set a target of vaccinating all adults by the end of July.

title: Newcastle cancer patients helped on road to recovery
text: Newcastle cancer patients helped on road to recovery People in Newcastle battling cancer are getting help with their recovery through a new service that tackles transport challenges. The service, provided by Macmillan Cancer Support and the British Red Cross, helps patients get to and from hospital for treatment, as well as to other appointments and activities that support their recovery. Cancer treatment can often cause side effects that make it difficult to travel, such as fatigue, nausea, and pain. The service provides a range of support, including: Transport to and from hospital appointments Transport to other appointments, such as support groups and counseling Help with planning and coordinating travel Assistance with getting on and off public transport The service is available to people who are receiving cancer treatment at the Freeman Hospital in Newcastle. It is funded by Macmillan Cancer Support and the British Red Cross, and is delivered in partnership with local transport providers. Since the service launched in April 2023, it has helped over 100 people with cancer in Newcastle. One person who has benefited from the service is 65-year-old John Smith. John was diagnosed with lung cancer in 2022 and has been receiving treatment at the Freeman Hospital. "The transport service has been a lifeline for me," said John. "I live on my own and don't have any family nearby, so getting to and from hospital appointments was a real challenge. The service has taken away that stress and allowed me to focus on my recovery." Another person who has benefited from the service is 42-year-old Sarah Jones. Sarah was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2021 and has been receiving treatment at the Freeman Hospital. "The transport service has been a huge help to me," said Sarah. "I have young children and I need to be able to get to and from hospital appointments without having to worry about how I'm going to get there. The service has given me peace of mind and allowed me to focus on getting better." The Macmillan Cancer Support and British Red Cross transport service is a vital service for people with cancer in Newcastle. It provides practical support that helps people with cancer to access the treatment and support they need to recover. If you are receiving cancer treatment at the Freeman Hospital in Newcastle and would like to access the transport service, please contact the Macmillan Cancer Support team on 0191 213 7323.

title: Redcar SSI: Two men killed in explosion near gas pipes at former steelworks site
text: Two men have died following an explosion near gas pipes at the former steelworks site in Redcar, north-east England. Cleveland Police said the incident happened at about 11:15 BST on Tuesday off the Trunk Road, near the former SSI steelworks. The area, which includes the former Redcar Bulk Terminal, has been cordoned off and the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) has been informed. The identities of the men have not yet been released. Two other men were injured in the blast, which happened close to a site owned by demolition firm TWMA. A spokesperson for TWMA Group said: "This tragic incident occurred during the decommissioning of the former Redcar Bulk Terminal, which TWMA were contracted to undertake. "Our primary focus at this time is on supporting those involved, the families of those who have sadly lost their lives, the injured and our employees." Chief Superintendent Sharon Cooney, of Cleveland Police, said: "This is an extremely tragic incident and our thoughts are with the families and friends of the men who have lost their lives. "We are working with our partners to establish what happened and to support those affected." The former SSI steelworks, which closed in 2015, has been the subject of several redevelopment plans in recent years. In 2020, it was announced that the site would be used for a new "green" steel plant, but these plans have since been put on hold. The site is owned by the SSI UK Property Company, which is part of the Thai steel company Sahaviriya Steel Industries (SSI). A spokesperson for Sahaviriya Steel Industries said: "We are deeply saddened by the tragic incident that occurred at the former SSI UK steelworks site in Redcar. "Our thoughts and condolences are with the families and friends of the victims. "We are committed to working with the authorities to investigate this incident thoroughly and to ensure that all necessary safety measures are in place."

title: Da Vinci's art is star of Swansea's revamped Glynn Vivian gallery
text: Nestled amidst the bustling streets of Swansea, the newly revamped Glynn Vivian Art Gallery has unveiled an exhibition that will captivate art enthusiasts and casual observers alike: "Leonardo da Vinci: A Life in Drawing." This extraordinary showcase brings together a collection of exquisite drawings by the Italian master, offering a glimpse into the mind of one of history's greatest geniuses. At the heart of the exhibition is the magnificent "Benois Madonna," a captivating study of the Virgin Mary with the Christ Child. Created around 1480, this drawing showcases da Vinci's mastery of chiaroscuro, the interplay of light and shadow, which creates a sense of depth and realism that is both awe-inspiring and intimate. Another highlight is the "Head of Grotesque Man," a striking portrait of a jester with an enigmatic expression. With his exaggerated features and piercing gaze, this drawing reveals da Vinci's fascination with human physiognomy and his ability to capture the complexities of the human condition. The exhibition also features a selection of preparatory sketches for da Vinci's iconic masterpiece, the "Mona Lisa." These drawings provide valuable insights into the artist's meticulous planning process and his quest for perfection. Visitors can trace the evolution of the painting from its initial conception to its final execution, gaining a deeper appreciation for da Vinci's artistic brilliance. Beyond the famous works, the exhibition also showcases a range of lesser-known drawings that illuminate da Vinci's diverse interests and pursuits. From anatomical studies to landscapes, these sketches reveal the breadth of his genius and his insatiable curiosity about the natural world. The Glynn Vivian Art Gallery has created a stunning and immersive experience for visitors. The exhibition is thoughtfully curated, with each drawing carefully placed to create a narrative that guides visitors through da Vinci's artistic journey. The gallery space is spacious and well-lit, allowing visitors to fully appreciate the details and nuances of each work. "Leonardo da Vinci: A Life in Drawing" is an unmissable opportunity to encounter the genius of one of the most influential artists in history. Whether you are an art connoisseur or simply curious about the Renaissance, this exhibition will inspire, intrigue, and leave a lasting impression.

title: Small pearl-bordered fritillary butterfly numbers boost
text: The small pearl-bordered fritillary butterfly is a rare and threatened species that has seen a significant boost in numbers thanks to conservation efforts. The butterfly, which is found in damp meadows and marshes, has suffered from habitat loss and fragmentation, as well as changes in land management practices. As a result, its numbers have declined significantly in recent decades. However, thanks to the work of conservationists, the small pearl-bordered fritillary is now making a comeback. In the UK, the Butterfly Conservation charity has been working with landowners and farmers to create and restore habitats for the butterfly. This has included planting wildflowers, managing grazing and mowing practices, and reducing the use of pesticides. As a result of these efforts, the small pearl-bordered fritillary is now starting to recolonise areas where it was once extinct. In 2022, the butterfly was recorded in 10 new sites in the UK, the highest number of new records in a single year since the charity began monitoring the species in 1976. Dr Richard Fox, head of science at Butterfly Conservation, said: "This is fantastic news for the small pearl-bordered fritillary. It shows that with the right conservation efforts, we can help to bring even the rarest species back from the brink of extinction." The small pearl-bordered fritillary is a beautiful and important species. It plays a vital role in the ecosystem, pollinating plants and providing food for other animals. Its recovery is a testament to the power of conservation and the importance of working together to protect our wildlife. Here are some tips on how you can help the small pearl-bordered fritillary: - Create a wildlife-friendly garden by planting wildflowers and reducing the use of pesticides. - Support organisations that are working to protect the butterfly, such as Butterfly Conservation. - Visit meadows and marshes where the butterfly is known to occur and report any sightings to Butterfly Conservation.

title: Caerphilly and Blaenau Gwent social services merger rejected
text: Caerphilly and Blaenau Gwent social services merger rejected Plans to merge the social services departments of Caerphilly and Blaenau Gwent councils have been rejected by the Welsh Government. The merger was proposed as a way to save money and improve services, but the government said it had not been convinced that it would be in the best interests of the people of the two counties. The decision is a blow to the councils, which had been working on the merger for several years. They had argued that the merger would lead to a more efficient and effective social services department, and that it would save money that could be used to improve services. However, the government said it had not been convinced that the merger would achieve the desired outcomes. It said that there was no clear evidence that the merger would lead to significant savings, and that it could actually lead to a worse service for the people of the two counties. The government also said that it was concerned about the impact of the merger on the staff of the two councils. It said that the merger could lead to job losses and that it could also make it more difficult for staff to provide a high-quality service. The decision to reject the merger has been welcomed by some people, but it has also been criticized by others. Those who support the decision say that it is the right one for the people of the two counties, and that it will protect vital services. Those who criticize the decision say that it is a missed opportunity to improve services and that it will lead to a worse service for the people of the two counties. title: Egypt explosion: Tourists on bus injured near Giza pyramids
text: Tourists were injured in a bus explosion near Egypt's iconic Giza pyramids on Saturday, the health ministry has said. Two people were killed and at least 12 others were injured on the bus, which was carrying tourists from South Africa. The blast occurred as the bus was travelling along the road leading to the pyramids, officials said. Egypt's interior ministry said the explosion was caused by a homemade bomb placed under the bus, adding that it had begun an investigation into the incident. No group has yet claimed responsibility for the attack. The health ministry said the injured tourists were taken to nearby hospitals for treatment. Most of them are said to be in a stable condition. The Giza pyramids are one of Egypt's most popular tourist destinations. Millions of people visit the ancient structures each year. The explosion comes as Egypt's tourism industry is struggling to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic, which caused a sharp decline in visitor numbers. The country is hoping to boost its tourism revenue by promoting new tourist attractions, such as the Grand Egyptian Museum, which is set to open later this year. The attack is a reminder of the security challenges that Egypt faces. The country has been battling an insurgency in the Sinai Peninsula for years. In recent months, there have also been several attacks on Coptic Christian churches in the country. The UK Foreign Office has advised British nationals to avoid the area around the Giza pyramids. It has also advised against all but essential travel to Egypt. The explosion has been condemned by world leaders. UN Secretary-General António Guterres said he was "deeply saddened" by the news of the attack. He called for those responsible to be brought to justice. US President Joe Biden said the attack was "a cowardly act of violence against innocent civilians." He said the US stands with Egypt in its fight against terrorism. The Egyptian government has vowed to bring those responsible for the attack to justice. President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi said the attack would not deter Egypt from continuing to fight terrorism. The explosion is a major blow to Egypt's tourism industry. It is likely to deter tourists from visiting the country, which could have a significant impact on the economy.

title: NI 100: BBC News NI marks a milestone in Irish history
text: Marking the 100th anniversary of Northern Ireland's foundation, BBC News NI will present extensive multi-platform coverage throughout 2021, reflecting on the region's complex century. The centerpiece of the coverage will be a landmark documentary series, "NI 100," which will explore the key moments, themes, and personalities that have shaped Northern Ireland since its inception. The series will feature contributions from a range of historians, politicians, and cultural figures, offering diverse perspectives on the region's journey. "NI 100" will delve into the events that led to the creation of Northern Ireland in 1921, examining the political and social factors that influenced the partition of Ireland. It will also explore the turbulent decades of conflict known as the Troubles, which left an enduring mark on the region. In addition to the documentary series, BBC News NI will produce a range of other programming to mark the anniversary. This will include dedicated news specials, current affairs programs, and features focusing on the impact of the past century on different aspects of Northern Irish society. BBC News NI's online platforms will provide comprehensive coverage, including interactive timelines, archival footage, and original content from across the region. The BBC's Irish language service, BBC Gaeilge, will also offer a dedicated range of programming to mark the anniversary. The BBC's commitment to reflecting the full complexity of Northern Ireland's history is reflected in the diversity of voices and perspectives featured in its coverage. The aim is to provide a balanced and nuanced understanding of the events and experiences that have shaped the region over the past century. The NI 100 programming will not only commemorate the past but also look to the future, exploring the hopes and aspirations of the people of Northern Ireland as they navigate the challenges and opportunities of the 21st century. By engaging with a wide range of perspectives and providing in-depth analysis, BBC News NI aims to foster a greater understanding of Northern Ireland's history and its contemporary context, contributing to a more informed and inclusive dialogue about the region's future.

title: Ancrum Old Bridge rediscovered beneath the River Teviot
text: Nestled amidst the picturesque Scottish Borders, the River Teviot has long hidden a secret beneath its tranquil waters. Ancrum Old Bridge, a centuries-old structure, has lain submerged for decades, its existence fading into the annals of history. However, thanks to the tireless efforts of local historians and archaeologists, this lost relic has been rediscovered, offering a glimpse into the region's rich past. The bridge's origins can be traced back to the 16th century, when it served as a vital crossing point for travelers and goods. Constructed of massive stone blocks, it spanned the river with a single, graceful arch. Over the centuries, the bridge bore witness to countless events, from the passage of armies to the bustling trade that flourished along the river. However, in the mid-19th century, tragedy struck. A devastating flood ravaged the area, sweeping away the bridge and burying it beneath layers of silt and debris. For over a century, it remained concealed, its existence known only through local folklore and faded records. In recent years, a renewed interest in the bridge's fate emerged. Local historian John Foreman, driven by a deep fascination with the region's past, began searching for clues to its whereabouts. Through meticulous research and collaboration with archaeologists, he gradually pieced together the puzzle of the lost bridge. Armed with sonar equipment and a team of volunteers, Foreman embarked on a series of underwater surveys. To their astonishment, they discovered the bridge's remains lying intact beneath the riverbed. The stone arch, remarkably well-preserved, testified to the bridge's enduring resilience. The rediscovery of Ancrum Old Bridge has sparked great excitement among historians and heritage enthusiasts. It provides tangible evidence of the region's vibrant past and offers a window into the lives of those who crossed it centuries ago. Plans are now underway to excavate the bridge and restore it to its former glory, creating a unique historical attraction that will further enrich the cultural heritage of the Scottish Borders. As the waters of the River Teviot gently flow over the rediscovered bridge, they carry with them the echoes of history. Ancrum Old Bridge, once lost to time, has now re-emerged as a testament to the indomitable spirit of the past and the enduring power of human connection.

title: Amphibian that buries head in sand named after Donald Trump
text: In a peculiar twist of nomenclature, a newly discovered species of amphibian has been named after former US President Donald Trump. The creature, a burrowing frog native to Panama, has earned the scientific moniker "Atelopus trumpi" due to a striking resemblance between its head and the former leader's distinctive hairstyle. Scientists at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute stumbled upon the frog during an expedition in the remote rainforests of western Panama. Its unusual appearance, characterized by a bulbous head and a prominent orange crest, immediately caught their attention. As they observed the frog's behavior, they noticed a peculiar habit: when threatened, it would bury its head in the sand, leaving only its eyes and nostrils exposed. This defensive mechanism, known as "concealing crypsis," is common among amphibians and reptiles. However, the frog's distinctive head shape and habit of burying its head in the sand were so reminiscent of Donald Trump's appearance and his signature hand gesture that the scientists couldn't resist bestowing the presidential namesake upon it. "We wanted to highlight the importance of amphibians and conservation, and we thought naming this species after a well-known figure would draw attention to their plight," explained Dr. Brian Gratwicke, one of the scientists involved in the discovery. The newly named "Atelopus trumpi" is a small, terrestrial frog that measures about 3 centimeters in length. It has a dark brown back with bright orange markings on its limbs and head. Its natural habitat is the rainforest streams of western Panama, where it feeds on insects and other small invertebrates. While the frog's scientific name may elicit some chuckles, the scientists hope that it will serve as a reminder of the importance of amphibian conservation. Amphibians are facing numerous threats, including habitat loss, climate change, and pollution. The naming of "Atelopus trumpi" is a playful way to raise awareness about these threats and the need to protect these delicate creatures. So, next time you hear about Donald Trump, remember that he has an amphibian namesake – a small, burrowing frog that spends its days buried in the sands of Panama. It's a quirky and unexpected connection between the worlds of politics and nature, a testament to the diversity and wonder of the natural world.

title: 'Diabetes burnout': The mental-health impact of diagnosis
text: Diabetes burnout is a real and common phenomenon that can affect people with diabetes of all ages and types. It is a state of emotional, physical, and mental exhaustion that can make it difficult to manage your diabetes effectively. There are many factors that can contribute to diabetes burnout, including: The daily demands of managing diabetes, such as monitoring your blood sugar, taking medication, and following a healthy diet The emotional stress of living with a chronic condition The social stigma associated with diabetes The financial burden of diabetes Diabetes burnout can lead to a number of problems, including: Poor blood sugar control Increased risk of complications Depression and anxiety Difficulty sleeping Weight gain Loss of interest in activities you once enjoyed If you are experiencing diabetes burnout, it is important to seek help. There are a number of resources available to help you manage your diabetes and improve your mental health. Here are some tips for coping with diabetes burnout: Talk to your doctor or a mental health professional about how you are feeling. Join a support group for people with diabetes. Find a diabetes educator who can help you learn more about managing your diabetes. Make small changes to your diabetes management plan that can make it easier to follow. Take breaks from diabetes management when you need them. Focus on the positive aspects of your life and the things that you can control. Diabetes burnout is a serious condition, but it can be managed. With the right help and support, you can learn to cope with diabetes burnout and live a full and healthy life. Here are some additional tips for preventing diabetes burnout: Set realistic goals for yourself. Don't try to do everything at once. Ask for help from family and friends. Take time for yourself to relax and de-stress. Remember that you are not alone. If you are experiencing diabetes burnout, please know that you are not alone. There is help available. Talk to your doctor or a mental health professional about how you are feeling.

title: Reality Check: How are English councils spending your taxes?
text: Reality Check: How are English councils spending your taxes? Every year, local authorities in England receive billions of pounds from taxpayers to provide essential services such as education, social care and waste collection. But how efficiently is this money being spent? A recent study by the Local Government Association (LGA) found that English councils spent a total of £108 billion in 2021/22. Of this, the largest proportion (35%) was spent on education, followed by social care (23%) and highways maintenance (10%). However, there were significant variations in spending between different councils. For example, the London Borough of Kensington and Chelsea spent £1,800 per person on social care, while the Isle of Wight Council spent just £800. The LGA's study also found that councils are facing increasing financial pressures. In 2021/22, they received £15 billion less in government funding than they did in 2010/11. This has led to cuts in services and increased council tax bills. So, what can be done to improve the efficiency of council spending? The LGA has called for the government to provide more funding to local authorities. It has also suggested that councils should be given more freedom to raise their own revenue. Some councils are already taking steps to improve their efficiency. For example, the London Borough of Sutton has introduced a "digital first" approach, which has reduced the cost of providing services by 20%. The LGA's study provides a valuable insight into how English councils are spending their money. It is clear that there is room for improvement, but councils are also facing significant financial challenges. The government needs to work with councils to find ways to improve efficiency and ensure that essential services are protected. Here are some tips for how you can find out how your local council is spending your taxes: Check your council's website. Most councils publish their budgets and financial statements online. Attend your local council meetings. This is a good way to hear from councilors and officers about how your money is being spent. Contact your local council directly. You can usually find contact details on your council's website. By being informed about how your council is spending your taxes, you can hold them to account and help to ensure that your money is being used wisely.

title: Football and dementia: Alan Jarvis inquest to explore heading link
text: Former footballer Alan Jarvis died at the age of 44 due to a brain condition. An inquest has determined that the cause of death was a fatal neurodegenerative disease caused by repeated heading of footballs. Alan Jarvis played for various English football clubs, including Norwich City, Luton Town, and Cambridge United. He underwent a post-mortem examination which revealed he had Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE). CTE is a progressive degenerative brain disease that is linked to repetitive head trauma. The inquest heard that Jarvis had been experiencing a range of symptoms, including memory loss, aggression, confusion, mood swings, and depression. His wife, Donna Jarvis, stated that these symptoms began while he was still playing football. She said that he had been "a different man" after heading the ball. The coroner, Claire Welch, concluded that Jarvis' death was a direct result of heading footballs. She said that the evidence showed that he had sustained multiple head injuries during his career as a professional footballer. These injuries had led to the development of CTE, which ultimately caused his death. The inquest is the first time that a coroner in England has directly linked heading footballs to the death of a former player. The findings of the inquest are likely to put pressure on football authorities to take action to reduce the risks of head injuries in the sport. The Professional Footballers' Association (PFA) said the inquest was a "landmark moment" in the understanding of the risks of heading footballs. The PFA called for football authorities to introduce new rules to limit the number of headers that players are allowed to make in training and matches. The Football Association (FA) said it was "deeply saddened" by Jarvis' death and that it was committed to taking action to reduce the risks of head injuries in football. The FA said it was working with other football organisations to develop new rules and guidelines to protect players. The inquest into Alan Jarvis' death has highlighted the serious risks of head injuries in football. It is now up to football authorities to take action to reduce these risks and to ensure that the sport is safe for all players.

title: Schools need support not blame from Ofsted, says head
text: Ofsted's latest report on the state of education in England has been met with mixed reactions. Some have welcomed the report's findings, which highlight the need for urgent improvement in many schools. Others have criticized the report for being too negative and for failing to recognize the progress that has been made in recent years. One of the most controversial aspects of the report is its focus on the role of headteachers. The report finds that many headteachers are not doing enough to improve the quality of teaching and learning in their schools. This has led to calls for Ofsted to take a tougher stance on underperforming headteachers. However, some headteachers have argued that they need more support from Ofsted, not more blame. They say that Ofsted's current inspection regime is too focused on short-term targets and does not take into account the challenges that schools face. They also say that Ofsted's inspectors are often too quick to criticize headteachers without offering any constructive feedback. One headteacher who has spoken out against Ofsted is Sally Coates, the headteacher of St Anne's Primary School in London. Coates says that Ofsted's inspections are "damaging" and that they do not help schools to improve. She says that Ofsted should focus on providing support to schools, rather than on blaming headteachers. "Ofsted needs to change its approach," said Coates. "It needs to stop blaming headteachers and start working with them to improve the quality of education in our schools." Coates's views are echoed by many other headteachers. A recent survey by the National Association of Head Teachers (NAHT) found that 70% of headteachers believe that Ofsted's inspections are not helpful. The NAHT is calling for Ofsted to reform its inspection regime and to focus on providing support to schools. The debate about the role of Ofsted is likely to continue for some time. However, it is clear that many headteachers believe that they need more support from Ofsted, not more blame. If Ofsted is to be effective in improving the quality of education in England, it will need to listen to the concerns of headteachers and work with them to find solutions to the challenges that schools face.

title: Estate agents urged to tell buyers about air pollution
text: Estate agents urged to tell buyers about air pollution Estate agents are being urged to tell buyers about air pollution levels near properties they are selling. The call comes from the Royal College of Physicians (RCP), which says that air pollution is a "major public health emergency" that is linked to a range of health problems, including heart disease, stroke, lung cancer, and dementia. The RCP says that estate agents have a duty to inform buyers about potential risks to their health, and that this includes air pollution. "Estate agents have a responsibility to make sure that buyers are aware of all the relevant information about a property before they make a decision," said Professor Stephen Holgate, chairman of the RCP's working group on air pollution. "This includes information about air pollution levels in the area, and the potential health risks associated with exposure to air pollution." The RCP's call comes after a study by the University of Birmingham found that people who live in areas with high levels of air pollution are more likely to develop dementia. The study found that people who lived in areas with the highest levels of air pollution were 40% more likely to develop dementia than those who lived in areas with the lowest levels of air pollution. The RCP says that the study's findings are "concerning" and that they highlight the need for estate agents to inform buyers about air pollution levels. "Air pollution is a serious public health problem, and it is important that buyers are aware of the risks associated with exposure to air pollution," said Professor Holgate. "Estate agents have a duty to make sure that buyers are aware of all the relevant information about a property before they make a decision, and this includes information about air pollution levels." The RCP is calling on the government to introduce new regulations that would require estate agents to tell buyers about air pollution levels. The RCP also wants the government to provide more support for local authorities to tackle air pollution. "Air pollution is a major public health emergency, and we need to take urgent action to reduce exposure to air pollution," said Professor Holgate. "Estate agents have a role to play in this by informing buyers about air pollution levels and by supporting local authorities in their efforts to tackle air pollution."

title: John Boyega says father was stopped by police on way from church
text: John Boyega, the 'Star Wars' actor, has revealed that his father was stopped by police for driving while black on his way home from church. Boyega, 27, said his father was pulled over by police in London in 2018. He said the incident left his father "traumatized" and "humiliated." "My dad was driving back from church and he was pulled over by the police," Boyega told GQ magazine. "He was driving a nice car and he was dressed smartly. He had just come from church. "The police officer asked him where he was going and he said he was coming from church. The police officer then asked him for his ID and he gave it to him. "The police officer then asked him to step out of the car and he did. The police officer then searched him and his car. "My dad was humiliated. He was traumatized. He felt like he was being treated like a criminal. He didn't do anything wrong. He was just driving home from church." Boyega said the incident made him realize that racism is still a problem in the UK. "It's not just about police brutality," he said. "It's about the everyday racism that black people face. "We're constantly being stopped and searched. We're constantly being followed around shops. We're constantly being treated like we're criminals. "It's not right. It's not fair. It's not just. "We need to do more to fight racism. We need to do more to educate people about racism. We need to do more to hold the police accountable for their actions." Boyega's comments come amid growing concerns about racial profiling by the police in the UK. A report by the Equality and Human Rights Commission in 2019 found that black people in the UK are more likely to be stopped and searched by the police than white people. The report also found that black people are more likely to be arrested and charged than white people. Boyega's father's experience is a reminder that racism is still a problem in the UK. It is a problem that needs to be addressed.

title: Covid-19: Fewest firms planning job cuts since pandemic began
text: The number of UK firms planning to make redundancies has fallen to its lowest level since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, a survey suggests. The latest quarterly Recruitment and Employment Confederation (REC) and KPMG report found that 18% of companies are considering cutting jobs in the coming months, down from 22% in the previous quarter. The survey also found that the number of permanent placements made by recruiters rose by 22% in the three months to September, the fastest pace of growth since before the pandemic. The findings suggest that the UK labor market is continuing to recover from the impact of the pandemic, but that some businesses are still facing challenges. The REC's chief executive, Neil Carberry, said: "The labor market remains tight, with employers continuing to struggle to fill roles. This is good news for jobseekers, but it is also a challenge for businesses. "The fall in the number of firms planning redundancies is a welcome sign, but it is important to remember that many businesses are still struggling. The government needs to do more to support businesses and help them to create jobs." The KPMG UK head of employers, Claire Kennedy, said: "The UK labor market is showing signs of recovery, but there are still challenges ahead. The rise in the number of permanent placements is a positive sign, but the number of firms planning redundancies remains high. "The government needs to continue to support businesses and help them to create jobs. This will be essential for ensuring that the UK economy recovers from the impact of the pandemic." The REC and KPMG report is based on a survey of 600 employers in the UK. The survey was conducted in September 2021. Key findings: 18% of companies are considering cutting jobs in the coming months, down from 22% in the previous quarter. The number of permanent placements made by recruiters rose by 22% in the three months to September, the fastest pace of growth since before the pandemic. The government needs to do more to support businesses and help them to create jobs.

title: Criggion museum bid for ex-WW2 and Cold War centre
text: Criggion Museum Bid for Ex-WW2 and Cold War Centre A museum in Wales is bidding to take over an abandoned ex-World War Two and Cold War centre. Criggion Museum in Powys has submitted an ambitious bid to the Ministry of Defence to acquire the former RAF base at Llanbedr, near Harlech. The museum is aiming to transform the site into a major visitor attraction, showcasing the history of the base and its role in both conflicts. The proposal includes plans for a new exhibition centre, a research facility, and a visitor centre. If successful, the bid would be a major boost for the museum, which currently houses a collection of over 20,000 artefacts from the two wars. The acquisition of the Llanbedr site would provide the museum with much-needed space to expand its collection and create a world-class visitor experience. The Llanbedr base was first established in 1940 as a training ground for RAF pilots during World War Two. It later became home to the No. 207 Squadron, which flew reconnaissance missions over Europe. The base was also used as a staging post for aircraft flying to and from the Mediterranean and the Far East. After the war, the base was used by the Royal Observer Corps, which monitored aircraft movements during the Cold War. It was finally closed in 1995. The Ministry of Defence has confirmed that it is considering the museum's bid. A decision is expected later this year. If successful, the museum will work with local partners to develop the site into a major tourist destination. The project is expected to create new jobs and boost the local economy. The museum's bid has been welcomed by local politicians and businesses. Arfon Jones, MS for Arfon, said: "This is a fantastic opportunity to create a world-class visitor attraction in North Wales. The museum's bid has my full support." Geraint Evans, owner of the Plas Tan-Yr-Allt Hotel in Llanbedr, said: "The museum's plans are very exciting. This would be a major boost for the local economy and would attract visitors from all over the world." The museum's bid is part of a wider effort to preserve and promote the history of Wales' role in the two world wars. In recent years, there has been a growing interest in the country's military heritage, with a number of new museums and memorials being opened.

title: Covid-19: Guernsey sets reclaiming support threshold at £50k
text: Covid-19: Guernsey sets reclaiming support threshold at £50k The States of Guernsey has agreed to reclaim Covid-19 financial support from businesses with profits over £50,000. It follows criticism that some businesses were claiming support they did not need. The income support scheme, which paid businesses a percentage of lost earnings during the pandemic, has now closed. The States said it had "reluctantly" made the decision after "careful consideration". It added that it was "currently reviewing" other Covid-19 financial support schemes to ensure "equitable support for businesses". The States said that businesses with taxable income over £50,000 in 2019 and 2020 would have to repay any grant funding they received from the business disruption loan guarantee, co-funded payroll and income support schemes. Businesses will have to submit an online form to the States by 30 September to declare their profits. Loans under the business disruption loan guarantee scheme will be converted to loans at commercial interest rates, the States said. Deputy Mark Helyar, president of the Committee for Economic Development, said the States had been "very clear from the outset that support was not available to those businesses which were able to trade profitably". "The States has provided significant financial support to our businesses throughout the pandemic to support jobs and livelihoods," he said. "In order to meet the value for money and fairness principles that apply to public funds, it is right that we reclaim this support where businesses have not incurred financial hardship as a result of Covid-19." The Guernsey Chamber of Commerce said it was "disappointed" with the decision. "We believe that the States could find a better way to claw back this money," said chief executive Elaine Gray. "We have made suggestions and other jurisdictions have set other thresholds so we are slightly disappointed with that." However, the Institute of Directors (IoD) in Guernsey said it "appreciated" the States' decision. "The IoD has always maintained that those businesses which do not need financial support should not take it," said chairman Peter Mills. "We therefore appreciate the States' decision to reclaim grants from those businesses with profits of over £50,000 in 2019 and 2020." Additional information The income support scheme paid businesses up to 80% of their lost earnings during the pandemic. The business disruption loan guarantee scheme provided loans of up to £500,000 to businesses affected by the pandemic. The co-funded payroll scheme paid businesses 60% of the salaries of furloughed staff during the pandemic.

title: Microbreweries 'the way forward' after 11 open in year
text: Microbreweries: The Way Forward After 11 Open in Year The microbrewing industry in the UK is booming, with 11 new breweries opening in the past year alone. This surge in popularity is being driven by a growing demand for craft beer, as consumers become increasingly interested in local, independent, and high-quality beverages. Microbreweries are typically small-scale operations that produce limited quantities of beer, often using traditional brewing methods. They are often passionate about their craft, and they take pride in creating unique and flavorful beers that reflect their local heritage and brewing styles. The growth of the microbrewing industry is good news for consumers, as it provides them with a wider choice of beers to enjoy. It is also good news for the economy, as it creates jobs and supports local businesses. However, the microbrewing industry is not without its challenges. One of the biggest challenges is competition from large, multinational brewing companies. These companies have vast resources and marketing budgets, which can make it difficult for microbreweries to compete. Another challenge is the cost of production. Microbreweries often have to pay more for ingredients and equipment than large breweries. This can make it difficult for them to keep their prices competitive. Despite these challenges, the microbrewing industry is well-positioned for continued growth. Consumers are increasingly interested in craft beer, and they are willing to pay a premium for it. This provides microbreweries with a strong foundation for success. In order to continue to grow, microbreweries need to focus on producing high-quality beer, building strong relationships with their customers, and marketing their products effectively. They also need to be aware of the challenges they face and be prepared to adapt to the changing market. If they can do these things, microbreweries will be well-positioned to continue to thrive in the years to come. Here are some of the key factors that are driving the growth of the microbrewing industry: Growing demand for craft beer: Consumers are increasingly interested in local, independent, and high-quality beverages. This is driving demand for craft beer, which is often seen as being more flavorful and innovative than mass-produced beer. Increased availability of microbrewed beer: Microbrewed beer is now more widely available than ever before. It is sold in bars, restaurants, and bottle shops across the UK. This makes it easy for consumers to find and try new craft beers. Government support: The government has been supportive of the microbrewing industry, providing grants and loans to help businesses get started. This support has helped to create a favorable environment for microbreweries to grow and thrive. The future of the microbrewing industry looks bright. As demand for craft beer continues to grow, microbreweries will be well-positioned to continue to grow and thrive.

title: Bovis says it will fix home faults by end of 2017
text: Bovis says it will fix home faults by end of 2017 Housebuilder Bovis Homes has said it will fix all outstanding faults in its homes by the end of the year. The company was fined £10.6m earlier this month after admitting its homes were "defective". Bovis said it had now written to all 2,662 customers who had bought homes from it since the start of 2016. It said it had identified 2,045 properties with 9,379 faults, and that 3,668 of these faults had already been fixed. Bovis said it had set up a new team of staff to deal with the repairs, and that it was working with independent building inspectors to ensure the work was carried out to a high standard. The company said it was "confident" that it would be able to fix all of the remaining faults by the end of the year. However, some homeowners have expressed doubts about whether Bovis will be able to meet this deadline. One homeowner, who wished to remain anonymous, told the BBC that she had been waiting for repairs to her home for over a year. She said: "I'm very sceptical about whether Bovis will be able to fix all of the faults by the end of the year. "I've been waiting for repairs for over a year now, and I've had no communication from Bovis for months." Bovis said it understood that some homeowners were frustrated, but it insisted that it was committed to fixing all of the outstanding faults. A spokesman for the company said: "We are very sorry for the inconvenience and distress that we have caused our customers. "We are working hard to put things right, and we are confident that we will be able to fix all of the remaining faults by the end of the year." The Consumer Rights Act 2015 gives homeowners the right to a repair, replacement or refund if they find faults with their new home within six years of moving in. If a developer refuses to fix the faults, homeowners can take them to court.

title: Boston Tapes: Ex-IRA man loses fight over secret tapes
text: Former IRA commander Gerry Adams has lost his legal battle to prevent the release of secret tapes thought to contain conversations about his alleged role in the murder of Jean McConville. The tapes were made by an unknown source during a series of interviews in the early 2000s with former IRA members Dolours Price and Brendan Hughes. Price, a leading member of a known IRA "unofficial" unit called "The Unknowns," turned herself in to the authorities and confessed to her role in the 1972 abduction and murder of the widowed mother-of-10 shortly before she died of cancer in 2013. Hughes was also a leading member of the IRA, and he was sentenced to twelve years in prison in 1981 as one of the masterminds behind the bombing of a British Army base in Warrenpoint, County Down. He died following a short illness in 2008. Adams has always denied any involvement in the murder of Jean McConville, and his lawyers argued that the tapes should not be released as they had been obtained illegally. However, the Supreme Court ruled that the public interest in hearing the tapes outweighed any privacy concerns, and they will now be released to the Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI). Adams has said that he will not listen to the tapes, but he has vowed to continue to fight to clear his name. He said that the tapes were "a fabrication" and that he was the victim of a "witch hunt" by the British government and media. "I have nothing to hide," he said. "I am innocent of any wrongdoing, and I will not let these tapes be used to rewrite history." The PSNI has welcomed the Supreme Court's decision, and said that it will now review the tapes and decide whether they contain any evidence that could lead to criminal charges being brought against Adams. title: Google faces French court claim over market dominance
text: Google Faces French Court Claim Over Market Dominance Google is facing a legal challenge in France over allegations that it has abused its dominant position in the online advertising market. The lawsuit, filed by French competition authority Autorité de la concurrence, accuses the tech giant of favoring its own advertising services over those of rivals. The complaint alleges that Google's practices have stifled competition and harmed both consumers and businesses. Investigators claim that Google's exclusive deals with certain websites and its control over the auction process for online ads have given it an unfair advantage. The French competition watchdog is seeking a fine of up to 10% of Google's global revenue, which would amount to billions of euros. The authority has also ordered Google to change its practices within two months or face further penalties. Google has denied the allegations and vowed to defend itself vigorously in court. The company argues that its practices are fair and competitive and that it does not favor its own services. The lawsuit is a significant development in the ongoing scrutiny of Google's market power in Europe. Regulators in several countries have launched investigations into the company's practices, and Google has already faced fines in the European Union and the United States. The French case is particularly significant because it focuses specifically on the online advertising market. This market is hugely important for Google, which generates the vast majority of its revenue from advertising. If Google is found guilty of abusing its dominant position in the French market, it could set a precedent for further action in other countries. It could also lead to significant changes in the way Google operates its advertising business. The outcome of the case will be closely watched by businesses and regulators around the world. It could have a major impact on the future of online advertising and the competitive landscape of the tech sector.

title: Brexit law 'constitutionally insensitive' to Welsh Government
text: The UK Supreme Court has ruled that the UK government acted "unconstitutionally" when it passed legislation that affected the powers of the Welsh Government without its consent. The case, brought by the Welsh Government, challenged the UK government's decision to impose a new tax on Welsh businesses without consulting with the Welsh Government. The Welsh Government argued that this was a breach of the devolution settlement, which gives Wales the power to make its own laws on certain matters. The Supreme Court agreed with the Welsh Government, ruling that the UK government had acted "unconstitutionally" by failing to consult with the Welsh Government before passing the legislation. The court said that this was a "serious breach" of the devolution settlement and that it had "undermined the constitutional position of the Welsh Government". The ruling is a significant victory for the Welsh Government and it will have implications for the future of devolution in the UK. It is clear that the UK government cannot simply impose its will on the devolved governments without their consent. The ruling is also a blow to the UK government's Brexit plans. The UK government has said that it wants to "take back control" from the EU and that it will be able to do this by passing new laws that will apply throughout the UK. However, the Supreme Court's ruling suggests that the UK government will not be able to do this without the consent of the devolved governments. The ruling has been welcomed by the Welsh Government. First Minister Mark Drakeford said that it was a "landmark victory" for the Welsh Government and that it would "strengthen the devolution settlement". The UK government has said that it is "disappointed" by the ruling. A government spokesperson said that the government "respects the decision of the court" but that it "does not accept the characterisation of the legislation as unconstitutional". The ruling is likely to have a significant impact on the UK government's Brexit plans. It is clear that the UK government will not be able to simply impose its will on the devolved governments without their consent. This could make it more difficult for the UK government to pass new laws that will apply throughout the UK.

title: Brexit: Pound and shares jump on optimism over talks
text: The pound and UK shares have jumped amid optimism over Brexit trade talks between the UK and EU. But he said he was "confident" that a deal could be reached by the end of October, when the UK is due to leave the EU. title: Health expert raises Cwmfelinfach waste site concern

title: Russia bans Azerbaijani tomatoes over 'pesticide concerns'
text: Russia has banned imports of tomatoes from Azerbaijan due to concerns over the use of pesticides, the country's agricultural watchdog said on Friday. The ban, which took effect immediately, applies to all fresh and processed tomatoes from Azerbaijan, the Federal Service for Veterinary and Phytosanitary Surveillance (Rosselkhoznadzor) said in a statement. Rosselkhoznadzor said its decision was based on the results of laboratory tests, which found high levels of pesticides in Azerbaijani tomatoes. The agency said the levels of pesticides exceeded the maximum residue levels (MRLs) established by the Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU), of which both Russia and Azerbaijan are members. The EAEU has established MRLs for a wide range of pesticides, which are based on scientific evidence and international standards. MRLs are the maximum concentration of a pesticide residue that is legally allowed in or on food or feed when pesticides are used according to good agricultural practices. Rosselkhoznadzor said it had repeatedly notified the Azerbaijani authorities of its concerns about the use of pesticides in tomatoes, but that no corrective action had been taken. The agency said it had therefore decided to impose the ban to protect Russian consumers from potential health risks. The ban on Azerbaijani tomatoes is likely to have a significant impact on the country's tomato industry. Azerbaijan is one of the largest producers of tomatoes in the region, and Russia is one of its main export markets. In 2021, Azerbaijan exported over 100,000 tonnes of tomatoes to Russia, according to data from the Azerbaijani State Customs Committee. The ban could cost Azerbaijani tomato growers millions of dollars in lost revenue. The Azerbaijani government has not yet commented on the ban. However, it is likely to challenge the decision, arguing that its tomatoes meet the required safety standards. The ban on Azerbaijani tomatoes is the latest in a series of trade disputes between Russia and its neighbors. In recent years, Russia has banned imports of a variety of products from Ukraine, Belarus, and other countries, citing concerns over quality and safety. These disputes have raised concerns about Russia's commitment to free trade and its use of trade restrictions as a political tool.
