title: Channel 4 breached Ofcom code with pre watershed X-Men
text: Channel 4 has been found to have breached the Ofcom code with its pre-watershed broadcast of the film X-Men. The media regulator ruled that the film, which contains scenes of violence and nudity, was unsuitable for children and should not have been shown before the 9pm watershed. Ofcom received 13 complaints about the broadcast, which aired on Channel 4 on February 20th. The regulator said it found that the film "contained frequent scenes of violence which were likely to be harmful to young children". It also said that the film's depiction of female nudity was "gratuitous and unnecessary". Channel 4 said it "regrets" the breach of the Ofcom code and has apologized to viewers. The broadcaster said that it "took into account the film's age rating and the fact that it had been edited for television" when making the decision to broadcast it before the watershed. However, Ofcom said that Channel 4 "failed to take sufficient account of the potential impact of the film on younger viewers". The regulator said that the film's violence was "particularly harmful" because it was "frequent and graphic". It also said that the film's depiction of female nudity was "gratuitous and unnecessary". Ofcom said that it has "taken into account the fact that Channel 4 has a good track record of compliance with the code" and has "not imposed a financial penalty". However, the regulator said that it has "put Channel 4 on notice that it must take steps to ensure that it does not breach the code again". The breach of the Ofcom code is a serious matter and Channel 4 must take steps to ensure that it does not happen again. The broadcaster must take into account the potential impact of its programming on younger viewers and ensure that it does not broadcast material that is likely to be harmful to them.

title: Concert marks 40 years since the Rolling Stones 'nearly' rocked Pembroke
text: In the quaint coastal town of Pembroke, the echoes of a legendary concert that almost took place 40 years ago reverberated through the streets, igniting a nostalgic flame among music enthusiasts. The year was 1982, and the world-renowned Rolling Stones were at the height of their fame. Rumors had swirled that the band was considering adding Pembroke to their European tour itinerary, sending the town into a frenzy of excitement. Local organizers worked tirelessly to secure the venue, the Pembroke Town Hall, and eagerly awaited confirmation from the Stones' management. However, fate had other plans. Just days before the scheduled concert, the tour was abruptly canceled due to unforeseen circumstances. The disappointment was palpable, but the memory of the near-miss concert lived on. To commemorate the 40th anniversary of this almost-event, a special tribute concert was organized at the very venue where the Stones had planned to perform. The 'Stones Nearly Rocked Pembroke' concert featured local bands and musicians paying homage to the legendary band. The evening was a celebration of the enduring legacy of the Rolling Stones and a testament to the enduring spirit of Pembroke. Among the performers was Jake Thomas, a local guitarist who had been a teenager when the Stones were rumored to be coming to town. "It's surreal to think that one of the greatest bands in the world almost played on this stage," he said. "Tonight, we're keeping their spirit alive." As the music filled the air, attendees couldn't help but imagine what it would have been like to witness the Rolling Stones in such an intimate setting. The atmosphere was electric, charged with a sense of both nostalgia and anticipation. The concert closed with a rousing rendition of "Satisfaction," the Stones' timeless anthem. The crowd erupted in thunderous applause, paying tribute to the band that nearly rocked Pembroke but forever left an imprint on the town's musical history. While the Rolling Stones may not have graced the Pembroke Town Hall stage in 1982, the 'Stones Nearly Rocked Pembroke' concert served as a fitting reminder of the power of music to inspire and connect generations. It was a testament to the enduring legacy of the Rolling Stones and the unwavering passion for live music that continues to thrive in small towns across the country.

title: University merger 'conspiracy', says Dr Peter Noyes
text: University Merger 'Conspiracy', Says Dr Peter Noyes Dr Peter Noyes, a former vice-chancellor of the University of Greenwich, has accused the government of "orchestrating a conspiracy" to merge universities. In a blog post, Dr Noyes claims that the government is "bullying" universities into merging in order to create a "handful of mega-universities". He says that this is being done despite the fact that there is no evidence that larger universities are better than smaller ones. "The government's claim that mergers will improve the quality of higher education is simply not supported by the evidence," Dr Noyes writes. He argues that smaller universities are often more innovative and responsive to the needs of students and businesses. "They are also more likely to be embedded in their local communities and to contribute to the local economy," he says. Dr Noyes's claims come as the government is consulting on plans to merge the University of Greenwich with the University of Kent. The government says that the merger will create a "world-leading university" that will be "better able to compete internationally". However, Dr Noyes argues that the merger will actually damage both universities. "The University of Greenwich has a strong track record of innovation and success," he says. "The merger will only serve to stifle this innovation and creativity." Dr Noyes is not the only person to express concerns about the government's merger plans. The National Union of Students (NUS) has also criticized the plans, saying that they will "damage the quality of higher education in the UK". The NUS says that the government's plans are "driven by ideology, not by evidence". "The government is simply trying to create a handful of mega-universities that will be easier to control," the NUS says. The government has defended its merger plans, saying that they are necessary to improve the quality of higher education in the UK. However, Dr Noyes and other critics argue that the government's plans are based on ideology, not on evidence.

title: CBI says leaving EU would have serious consequences for Britain
text: The UK's Serious Fraud Office (SFO) has warned of "significant consequences" for the country's criminal justice and anti-corruption systems if it leaves the European Union without a deal. In a letter to the Home Office, the SFO said that its cross-border operations would be "severely disrupted" in the event of a no-deal Brexit, as it would lose access to key EU tools such as the European Arrest Warrant (EAW) and the EU Directive on Mutual Legal Assistance (MLAT). The SFO also expressed concern about the potential impact of Brexit on its ability to recover stolen assets from overseas, as well as its cooperation with European partners on transnational crime investigations. The SFO's warning comes as Parliament prepares to vote on the government's proposed Brexit deal. If the deal is rejected, the UK will leave the EU without a deal on 29 March 2019. The SFO is not the only law enforcement agency to express concerns about the impact of Brexit. The National Crime Agency (NCA) has also warned of "significant risks" to the UK's national security if it leaves the EU without a deal. The NCA said that Brexit would make it more difficult to track and prosecute organized crime gangs, as well as share intelligence with European partners. The EU has also warned of the consequences of a no-deal Brexit. The European Commission has said that the UK would lose access to a number of EU law enforcement and judicial cooperation mechanisms, including the EAW and MLAT. The Commission has also said that the UK would no longer be party to a number of international agreements on law enforcement and judicial cooperation, such as the Council of Europe Convention on Human Rights. The UK government has said that it is committed to maintaining its high levels of law enforcement and judicial cooperation with the EU after Brexit. However, it is unclear how the UK will be able to maintain these levels of cooperation if it leaves the EU without a deal. The SFO's warning is a reminder of the potential consequences of a no-deal Brexit. The UK government must take urgent action to address the concerns of law enforcement agencies and ensure that the country's criminal justice and anti-corruption systems are not weakened after Brexit. A no-deal Brexit would also have a significant impact on the UK's economy. The SFO estimated that the UK economy would lose up to £100 billion over the next 10 years if it leaves the EU without a deal. The SFO also warned that Brexit would make it more difficult for UK businesses to trade with the EU, as they would face new tariffs and regulations.

title: Honduras protests: Buildings burn during clashes over reforms
text: Amidst a deepening social and political crisis, Honduras has erupted in widespread protests over proposed constitutional reforms. The demonstrations, marked by violence and destruction, have cast a shadow over the country's fragile democracy. Thousands of protesters took to the streets of Tegucigalpa, the capital, and other cities on Sunday, expressing their anger against the government's plan to establish new electoral courts. They fear that the reforms, if implemented, would undermine the integrity of future elections and consolidate the power of the ruling National Party. As the protests intensified, clashes erupted between demonstrators and security forces. Protesters hurled rocks and Molotov cocktails, setting fire to government buildings, including the headquarters of the National Electoral Institute (TSE). Police responded with tear gas, water cannons, and live ammunition, leaving several people injured. Amidst the chaos, President Juan Orlando Hernández declared a state of emergency, suspending constitutional guarantees for 10 days. This move has been widely criticized as an attempt to stifle dissent and suppress the legitimate grievances of the Honduran people. The protests have exposed deep-rooted divisions within Honduran society. Many citizens are disillusioned with the government, accusing it of corruption, authoritarianism, and economic mismanagement. They demand free and fair elections, the rule of law, and the end of what they see as a corrupt and repressive regime. However, the government maintains that the constitutional reforms are necessary to improve the electoral system and strengthen democracy. It accuses the opposition of inciting violence and seeking to destabilize the country. The international community has expressed concern over the situation in Honduras. The United States, a close ally, has urged the government to respect the right to peaceful protest and to engage in dialogue with the opposition. The Organization of American States (OAS) has also called for calm and restraint. The protests have highlighted the challenges facing Honduras. The country has been plagued by poverty, inequality, and violence for decades. The current crisis has deepened these problems, leaving the future of the nation in doubt. It remains unclear how the situation will unfold. The government has vowed to restore order, while protesters remain determined to fight for their demands. The outcome of this confrontation will have a profound impact on the future of Honduran democracy.

title: Duterte pulls police off controversial drugs crackdown
text: Duterte pulls police off controversial drugs crackdown Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has ordered police to stand down from his controversial anti-drugs campaign, which has been criticized for widespread human rights abuses. The move comes after a report by the Philippine National Police (PNP) revealed that more than 6,600 people had been killed in police anti-drug operations since Duterte took office in 2016. The report also found that many of the killings were extrajudicial, meaning they were carried out without due process of law. Duterte has defended the crackdown, saying it is necessary to rid the country of the drug menace. However, the United Nations and other human rights groups have condemned the killings, saying they amount to a "war on the poor." In a televised address on Thursday, Duterte said he was withdrawing the police from the anti-drugs campaign because he did not want them to be "scapegoats" for the killings. He said the campaign would now be led by the Philippine Drug Enforcement Agency (PDEA). "I am giving them the last chance to prove themselves," Duterte said of the police. "If they continue to abuse their authority, I will not hesitate to fire all of them." The PNP welcomed Duterte's decision, saying it would allow them to focus on their other duties. The PDEA, however, has said it is not ready to take over the anti-drugs campaign. It is unclear what impact Duterte's decision will have on the drug problem in the Philippines. Some experts believe that the crackdown has actually made the problem worse, by driving drug users deeper into the shadows. Others believe that the crackdown has been effective in reducing crime and drug use. Only time will tell whether Duterte's decision to withdraw the police from the anti-drugs campaign will have a positive or negative impact on the Philippines.

title: The Men Who Own Scotland: Land reform on 'radical journey'
text: In the heart of the Scottish Highlands, amidst rolling hills and shimmering lochs, lies a vast and contested landscape. It is a land owned by a privileged few, a legacy of centuries-old feudalism that has left deep scars on the social fabric of Scotland. But now, a wave of land reform is sweeping across the country, promising to redistribute power and give communities a greater say in how their land is used. At the forefront of this movement are organizations like Community Land Scotland (CLS), which supports community buyouts of land from private landowners. Since its inception in 2003, CLS has helped over 200 communities across Scotland acquire ownership of their land, totaling over 600,000 acres. One of the most successful community buyouts was the Knoydart Peninsula, a remote and rugged area in the northwest Highlands. In 1999, the community raised over £2 million to purchase the peninsula from a private estate. Since then, they have transformed the area, creating a thriving community-owned enterprise that includes sustainable forestry, tourism, and crofting. The land reform movement is not without its challenges. Landowners have resisted community buyouts, arguing that they will lead to a loss of investment and economic decline. However, supporters of land reform argue that community ownership can actually boost local economies by empowering communities to create jobs and develop sustainable businesses. The Scottish government has been supportive of land reform, passing legislation in 2015 that gives communities a "right to buy" abandoned or neglected land. This has led to a surge in community buyouts, as communities seize the opportunity to take control of their land. One of the most recent examples of this is the buyout of the Isle of Gigha, a small island off the west coast of Scotland. In 2022, the community raised £4.5 million to purchase the island from its private owner. They plan to use the land to develop sustainable agriculture, tourism, and renewable energy projects. The land reform movement in Scotland is still in its early stages, but it has already made a significant impact. It is a radical journey that is challenging centuries-old power structures and giving communities a greater say in their future. As the movement continues to grow, it has the potential to transform the landscape of Scotland, both physically and politically.

title: Motorway lessons proposed for learner drivers
text: Motorway Lessons Proposed for Learner Drivers In a bid to improve road safety and reduce the number of accidents involving novice drivers, the government has proposed introducing mandatory motorway lessons for learner drivers. The lessons would be an addition to the current driving test and would focus on teaching drivers how to safely navigate motorways. According to the Department for Transport, around 20% of all road deaths involve drivers who have held a driving license for less than two years. Motorways are particularly hazardous for inexperienced drivers, as they are often unfamiliar with the high speeds and complex traffic patterns. The proposed motorway lessons would be delivered by qualified driving instructors and would cover a range of topics, including: Motorway lane discipline Safe overtaking and merging Emergency procedures Using motorway signs and signals Safe speed management The lessons would be designed to give learner drivers the confidence and skills they need to drive safely on motorways. They would also help to reduce the number of accidents caused by inexperienced drivers. The government's proposal has been welcomed by road safety campaigners. The RAC Foundation said that the lessons would be a "positive step" towards improving road safety. However, some driving instructors have expressed concerns about the cost of the lessons and the potential impact on learner drivers' confidence. The cost of the motorway lessons has not yet been determined, but it is likely to be in the region of £50-£100. The lessons would be optional, but learner drivers would be strongly encouraged to take them. The government is considering a number of options for delivering the motorway lessons. One option is to make them a compulsory part of the driving test. Another option is to offer the lessons as an additional service by driving instructors. The government is also considering whether to extend the motorway lessons to all new drivers, regardless of their age or experience. This would help to ensure that all drivers have the skills and knowledge they need to drive safely on motorways. The government's consultation on the proposed motorway lessons is now open. The consultation will close on 28th February 2023. The government will then consider the feedback received and make a decision on whether to implement the lessons.

title: Dalian Atkinson: Ex-footballer 'staggered' towards accused PC
text: Dalian Atkinson's widow has told a court she saw her husband "staggering" towards a police officer moments before he was Tasered and kicked in the head. Elaine Atkinson said the former Aston Villa and Sheffield Wednesday striker was "incoherent" and "not making sense" at the time. PC Benjamin Monk, 43, denies murder and manslaughter. The jury at Birmingham Crown Court was shown body-worn camera footage of the incident in Telford, Shropshire, in August 2016. Monk and another officer, PC Mary Ellen Bettley-Smith, were called after Atkinson was reported to have been banging on the door of his father's home. The court heard that Atkinson had mental health problems and had been drinking heavily. His widow said she arrived at the house shortly after the police and saw her husband staggering towards PC Monk. "He seemed very unsteady on his feet," she said. "He was stumbling and incoherent. I didn't know what to think. I was worried about his safety." She said she thought her husband was asking for help and called out to him to go back to the house. "He didn't respond," she said. "He was too far away by then." The court was shown footage from PC Monk's body-worn camera which showed Atkinson stumbling towards him. PC Monk drew his Taser and ordered Atkinson to stop, but he continued to approach. Monk then fired the Taser and Atkinson fell to the ground. As Atkinson lay on the ground, Monk kicked him three times in the head. Atkinson died in hospital the following day. Monk has admitted kicking Atkinson, but said he did so in self-defence because he believed Atkinson was trying to grab his Taser. The trial continues.

title: New marine zone plans scrapped by minister
text: New marine zone plans scrapped by minister Environment Minister Rebecca Pow has scrapped plans to create a network of marine conservation zones in English waters, a move that has been met with anger from environmental groups. The plans, which were first proposed in 2018, would have seen 127 areas of the sea designated as marine conservation zones (MCZs). These areas would have been protected from damaging activities such as fishing, dredging and seabed mining. However, Pow has now announced that the government will not be proceeding with the plans. She said that the decision was made after a "careful review" of the evidence, and that the government believes that the existing network of marine protected areas is sufficient to protect the marine environment. Environmental groups have condemned the decision, arguing that it will damage marine life and habitats. They say that the proposed MCZs would have protected important areas for wildlife, such as coral reefs and seagrass beds. "This is a devastating blow for our seas," said Richard Benyon, chairman of the Marine Conservation Society. "The government has failed to stand up for our marine environment and has put our seas at risk." The Wildlife Trusts also criticized the decision, saying that it was a "betrayal" of the government's promise to protect the environment. "The government has ignored the overwhelming scientific evidence that shows that marine conservation zones are essential for protecting our seas," said Rob Cunningham, chief executive of the Wildlife Trusts. The decision to scrap the marine zone plans comes at a time when the government is facing growing pressure to protect the environment. The government has pledged to reach net zero emissions by 2050, and has set out a number of policies to reduce pollution and protect wildlife. However, environmental groups say that the government's actions do not match its rhetoric. They say that the decision to scrap the marine zone plans shows that the government is not serious about protecting the environment. The government has defended its decision, saying that it is committed to protecting the marine environment. However, environmental groups say that the government needs to do more to show that it is serious about this commitment.

title: Devon and Cornwall police officers tasked with call centre work
text: Devon and Cornwall Police officers are now taking on call centre work amid concerns that staff shortages are affecting the force's ability to respond to 999 calls. The move comes after a report found that the force had the longest average waiting time for 999 calls in England and Wales. According to the report, the average time it took for Devon and Cornwall Police to answer a 999 call was 14 minutes and 24 seconds. This was the longest waiting time of any force in England and Wales, and more than double the national average of six minutes and 35 seconds. The report also found that the force had the second-lowest number of call handlers per 100,000 people. In response to the report, Devon and Cornwall Police has said that it is taking a number of steps to improve its call handling performance. These steps include: - Recruiting more call handlers - Investing in new technology - Introducing a new call handling system - Working with other agencies to reduce demand on the 999 service The force has also said that it is working to reduce the number of calls that are abandoned before they are answered. In the meantime, officers from across the force are being asked to work in the call centre to help answer 999 calls. A spokesman for the force said: "We are aware of the concerns that have been raised about our call handling performance. "We are taking these concerns very seriously and are taking a number of steps to improve our performance. "We would like to thank the public for their patience and understanding during this time." The move to have officers take on call centre work has been met with mixed reactions. Some people have welcomed the move, saying that it will help to improve the force's response times to 999 calls. Others have questioned whether it is the best use of police officers' time, arguing that they should be out on the streets fighting crime. The Police Federation, which represents rank-and-file officers, has said that it is concerned about the move. A spokesman for the federation said: "We are concerned that the use of police officers to answer 999 calls will lead to a reduction in the number of officers available to respond to incidents on the streets. "We believe that this could have a negative impact on public safety."

title: Pawnbroker warns probe could spark loan shark rush
text: Pawnbrokers have warned that a government probe into the industry could lead to a rise in illegal lending by loan sharks. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has launched an investigation into the sector, amid concerns over high interest rates and hidden charges. But pawnbrokers say the probe could deter legitimate businesses from operating, leaving a vacuum that could be filled by unregulated lenders. "If the CMA makes it too difficult for pawnbrokers to operate, then loan sharks will step in to fill the void," said Michael Anscombe, chief executive of the National Pawnbrokers Association. "Loan sharks charge extortionate rates of interest and use intimidation and violence to collect debts. This is a real danger to vulnerable people." The CMA is investigating whether pawnbrokers are breaking competition law by charging excessive interest rates and failing to provide customers with clear information about the terms of their loans. The investigation was launched after the CMA received a number of complaints from consumers about the industry. Some consumers have complained that they have been charged interest rates of up to 1,500% APR on pawn loans. Others have said that they have been misled about the terms of their loans, and have ended up losing their valuables. The CMA has said that it is too early to say what the outcome of the investigation will be. But it has warned that it could take action against pawnbrokers who are found to be breaking the law. "We are concerned about the potential impact of the CMA investigation on the pawnbroking industry," said Anscombe. "We believe that pawnbrokers provide a valuable service to many people, particularly those who are on low incomes or who have poor credit histories. We urge the CMA to take into account the impact of its investigation on the whole industry, and not just on a few bad apples." The pawnbroking industry is regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA). The FCA has a number of rules in place to protect consumers, including a cap on interest rates and a requirement for pawnbrokers to provide customers with clear information about the terms of their loans. However, the FCA has been criticized for not doing enough to protect consumers from loan sharks. In 2016, the FCA was fined £10.5 million for failing to properly supervise the payday lending industry. The CMA investigation is likely to take several months to complete. It is unclear what the outcome of the investigation will be, but it is possible that the CMA could take action against pawnbrokers who are found to be breaking the law.

title: Vauxhall: Crunch talks to save Ellesmere Port plant continue
text: Vauxhall: Crunch talks to save Ellesmere Port plant continue Discussions are continuing between Vauxhall's parent company Stellantis and the UK government in a bid to save the carmaker's Ellesmere Port plant. The future of the factory, which employs around 1,000 people, has been in doubt since Vauxhall announced in July that it would be closing the site in 2022. The government has since offered a £30m grant to help secure the plant's future, but Stellantis has said that it needs more financial support in order to make the investment necessary to convert the factory to electric vehicle production. Talks between the two sides have been ongoing for several weeks, but no agreement has yet been reached. A source close to the negotiations told the BBC that the talks were "very difficult" and that there was no guarantee that a deal would be reached. "Stellantis is asking for a lot of money, and the government is reluctant to give it to them," the source said. "There is a real risk that the plant will close if a deal cannot be reached." The Ellesmere Port plant is one of the UK's largest car factories, and its closure would be a major blow to the local economy. The plant has been producing cars since the 1960s, and it has played a key role in the development of the UK's automotive industry. The closure of the plant would also be a major blow to the UK's efforts to become a leader in the production of electric vehicles. The government has pledged to ban the sale of new petrol and diesel cars by 2030, and it is hoping to encourage the development of a thriving electric vehicle industry in the UK. The Ellesmere Port plant is well-suited to the production of electric vehicles, and its closure would be a major setback to the government's plans. The talks between Stellantis and the government are expected to continue in the coming days. It is hoped that a deal can be reached that will save the Ellesmere Port plant and secure its future as a major center for the production of electric vehicles.

title: Chinese investment in the US falls sharply in 2017
text: Chinese investment in the US plummeted by 35% in 2017 to $29 billion, according to new figures released by the Rhodium Group and the National Committee on US-China Relations. This is the first annual decline in Chinese investment in the US since 2009, and the lowest level since 2009. The fall in Chinese investment was driven by a number of factors, including the Trump administration's tough stance on trade and investment, as well as the Chinese government's efforts to reduce capital outflows. The Trump administration has taken a number of steps to restrict Chinese investment in the US, including increasing scrutiny of foreign investment deals and tightening export controls. The Chinese government has also taken steps to reduce capital outflows, including imposing new restrictions on foreign exchange transactions. The decline in Chinese investment in the US is likely to have a significant impact on the US economy. Chinese investment has been a major source of job creation and economic growth in the US in recent years. The fall in Chinese investment is likely to lead to job losses and slower economic growth in the US. The decline in Chinese investment in the US is also likely to have a significant impact on US-China relations. The Trump administration has accused China of unfair trade practices, and the decline in Chinese investment is likely to further strain relations between the two countries. The fall in Chinese investment in the US is a major development with significant implications for the US economy and US-China relations. It is important to understand the causes of this decline and to assess its potential impact. In addition to the factors mentioned above, there are a number of other factors that may have contributed to the decline in Chinese investment in the US. These include the rising cost of labor in China, the increasing availability of investment opportunities in other countries, and the uncertainty surrounding the future of US-China relations. It is important to note that the decline in Chinese investment in the US does not necessarily mean that Chinese companies are losing interest in the US market. Chinese companies are still investing in the US, but they are doing so at a slower pace and with more caution. The decline in Chinese investment in the US is a complex issue with a number of causes. It is important to understand the factors behind this decline and to assess its potential impact.

title: Venezuela elections neither 'free nor fair', says US
text: Venezuela Elections Declared 'Neither Free Nor Fair' by US The United States has denounced the recent Venezuelan presidential elections as "neither free nor fair," citing widespread irregularities and the imprisonment of political opponents. In a statement, Secretary of State Antony Blinken said the elections "were not conducted in a free and fair manner." He pointed to the jailing of opposition candidates, the lack of independent election observers, and the reports of voter fraud. "The United States does not recognize the results of these elections," Blinken said. "We stand with the Venezuelan people and their desire for democracy, freedom, and the rule of law." The elections, held on November 21, saw incumbent President Nicolás Maduro claiming victory with over 82% of the vote. However, the opposition and international observers have widely criticized the results, alleging that they were rigged in favor of Maduro. The US statement echoed the concerns of the Organization of American States (OAS), which issued a report last week saying that the elections "did not meet minimum standards for a democratic process." The OAS also called for new elections to be held. The Venezuelan government has rejected the criticisms, accusing the US and the OAS of interfering in its internal affairs. Maduro has vowed to remain in office and has called for the opposition to recognize his victory. The international condemnation of the elections has put further pressure on Maduro, who is already facing economic sanctions and a campaign of diplomatic isolation. The US and other countries have imposed sanctions on Venezuela's oil industry, which is the country's main source of revenue. The Venezuelan election crisis comes amid a broader political and economic crisis in the country. The country has been plagued by hyperinflation, food shortages, and a lack of basic necessities. The crisis has led to a mass exodus of Venezuelans, many of whom have fled to neighboring countries. The US statement said the Venezuelan people "deserve the right to freely choose their own leaders and their own future." It called on the Venezuelan government to release political prisoners, respect the rule of law, and allow for new elections. "The United States will continue to work with the international community to support the Venezuelan people and their aspiration for a better future," the statement concluded.

title: Edwin Poots: Arlene Foster's exit is 'rough and tumble' of politics
text: Edwin Poots: Arlene Foster's exit is 'rough and tumble' of politics Edwin Poots has said the ousting of Arlene Foster as DUP leader is part of the "rough and tumble" of politics. Mrs Foster announced her resignation on Wednesday after losing a vote of no confidence among party members. Mr Poots, who is the current Agriculture Minister, is seen as a potential successor to Mrs Foster. He told the BBC's Nolan Show that he had "no intention" of standing for the leadership, but did not rule it out in the future. "I don't have ambitions to be leader of the DUP," he said. "I think it's important that whoever takes over this mantle has the full support of the party and unfortunately, at this time, I do not have the full support of the party." Mr Poots said he had "huge regard" for Mrs Foster and described her as a "formidable politician". "I think she's done a great job, particularly in the Brexit negotiations," he said. "But ultimately, the party has decided that they wanted a change and that's the rough and tumble of politics." Mr Poots said he was "not surprised" by Mrs Foster's resignation. "I think she's been under a lot of pressure for a long time and I think she's made the right decision for her and for the party," he said. Mr Poots said he would continue to serve as Agriculture Minister and would support the new leader of the DUP. "I'm not going anywhere," he said. "I'm committed to serving the people of Northern Ireland and I'm committed to the DUP." Mrs Foster's resignation comes after a period of turmoil within the DUP. She has been under pressure over her handling of Brexit and the Northern Ireland Protocol. The DUP has also been divided over its relationship with the Conservative Party. Mrs Foster's resignation is likely to lead to a contest for the leadership of the DUP. Mr Poots is one of the potential candidates, but it is not clear who else will stand. The new leader of the DUP will face a number of challenges, including the ongoing negotiations over the Northern Ireland Protocol. They will also need to unite the party and restore its reputation.

title: NHS Highland's management criticised for keeping members in the dark
text: NHS Highland's management has been criticised for keeping members of the public in the dark about the reasons behind the controversial decision to downgrade the accident and emergency department at Caithness General Hospital. The health board announced last week that the A&E department at the hospital in Wick would be downgraded to an urgent care centre, with more serious cases being sent to Raigmore Hospital in Inverness. The decision has been met with anger and disappointment by local residents, who say they were not properly consulted about the plans. Now, it has emerged that NHS Highland's management did not tell the public about all of the reasons for the downgrade. In a letter to the health board, Scottish Conservative MSP Edward Mountain said: "I have been made aware that NHS Highland did not disclose all of the reasons for their decision to downgrade Caithness General Hospital's A&E department to the public. "This is a serious matter, as it means that the public was not able to make a fully informed decision about the future of their local hospital." Mountain said that he had been told that NHS Highland had not disclosed the fact that the downgrade was being considered because of a shortage of doctors. He said: "This is a very important piece of information, and it is essential that the public is made aware of it. "I am calling on NHS Highland to come clean about the reasons for their decision and to be honest with the public about the challenges that they are facing." In response, NHS Highland said that it had "followed a robust and transparent process" in making the decision to downgrade the A&E department at Caithness General Hospital. A spokesman said: "The decision was made following a detailed review of the clinical evidence and the needs of the local population. "We understand that this is a difficult decision for some people, but we believe that it is the right decision for the long-term future of healthcare in Caithness." The spokesman added that NHS Highland would be holding a public meeting in Wick on 28th February to discuss the decision in more detail. The decision to downgrade the A&E department at Caithness General Hospital is the latest in a series of controversial decisions made by NHS Highland. In recent years, the health board has also closed a number of community hospitals and reduced the number of beds at Raigmore Hospital. These decisions have led to accusations that NHS Highland is centralising healthcare services in Inverness at the expense of rural communities.

title: Minister 'abducted' entrepreneur
text: Minister 'Abducted' Entrepreneur The BBC has learned that a British entrepreneur was allegedly abducted and held captive for two weeks in the United Arab Emirates (UAE). According to sources close to the investigation, Quest was abducted by a group of men who claimed to be members of the UAE security forces. He was allegedly taken to a secret location and held against his will for 14 days. During his captivity, Quest is said to have been subjected to physical and psychological abuse. He was reportedly beaten, threatened, and denied food and water. On March 24, Quest was finally released and allowed to return to the UK. He immediately sought medical attention and is now reportedly recovering from his ordeal. The British government has confirmed that it is aware of the allegations and is working closely with the UAE authorities to investigate the incident. A Foreign Office spokesperson said: "We are deeply concerned about the allegations and are providing consular assistance to Mr. Quest and his family." The UAE government has denied any involvement in the abduction and detention of Quest. A spokesperson for the UAE embassy in London said: "The UAE authorities have not and would not engage in such behavior. We are committed to the rule of law and the protection of human rights." The incident has raised serious questions about the safety of British citizens in the UAE. Quest is a respected businessman with no known ties to any criminal activity. His abduction and detention have sent shockwaves through the international community. Human rights groups have condemned the alleged abduction and called for an independent investigation. Amnesty International said: "The allegations against the UAE authorities are deeply disturbing. The UAE must launch an immediate and impartial investigation and hold those responsible to account." The case has also strained relations between the UK and the UAE. British officials have called for a full explanation from the UAE authorities, while the UAE has accused the UK of overreacting. title: Abandoned BBC Gardeners' World plot an 'urban veg hub'
text: In the verdant heart of Bristol, an abandoned plot from BBC's iconic 'Gardeners' World' has found a vibrant new purpose as an urban veg hub, offering a lifeline to the community and promoting sustainable living. Once the setting for the beloved gardening show, the plot lay dormant for years, overgrown with weeds and forgotten. However, a passionate group of volunteers, inspired by the show's legacy, transformed the neglected space into a thriving community asset. The hub is now a bustling space, where rows of vegetables, fruits, and herbs flourish. From plump tomatoes to crisp lettuce, the plot produces an abundance of fresh and organic produce, available to residents at affordable prices. Beyond its role as a food source, the hub fosters a sense of community and shared purpose. Volunteers from all walks of life work together to tend to the plants, sharing their knowledge and experience. Residents can participate in workshops, learn about gardening techniques, and connect with like-minded individuals. The project has also been instrumental in addressing food insecurity in the area. By providing affordable produce, the hub helps reduce the financial burden on families and ensures that everyone has access to healthy and nutritious food. Moreover, the hub promotes sustainable practices, reducing food miles and fostering environmental awareness. The plot uses compost from local sources, collects rainwater for irrigation, and employs natural pest control methods. By demonstrating these principles, the hub encourages residents to adopt sustainable habits in their own gardens. The urban veg hub has become an integral part of the community, transforming a forgotten space into a hub of life and sustainability. It serves as a testament to the enduring legacy of 'Gardeners' World' and the power of community to create positive change. As the sun sets over Bristol, casting a warm glow upon the verdant plot, the urban veg hub stands as a beacon of hope, nourishment, and community spirit. Its success is a reminder that even in abandoned spaces, the seeds of resilience and renewal can take root and flourish.

title: Google shares drop on worries over advertising income
text: Google shares have fallen sharply after the tech giant warned of a slowdown in advertising spending. The company said it expects revenue growth to slow in the coming months as businesses cut back on their marketing budgets. Google's shares fell by more than 7% in after-hours trading following the announcement. The company's warning is the latest sign that the global economy is slowing down. Google is one of the world's largest companies and its advertising business is a major source of revenue. The company's shares have been under pressure in recent months as investors worry about the impact of the slowing economy on its business. Google's warning is likely to add to those concerns. The company said that it expects revenue growth to slow in the coming months as businesses cut back on their marketing budgets. Google said that it is seeing a "broad-based slowdown in advertising spending" across all of its businesses. The company said that it is "taking steps to mitigate the impact of the slowdown" but it warned that it expects revenue growth to slow in the coming months. Google's warning is the latest sign that the global economy is slowing down. Other companies have also reported a slowdown in advertising spending in recent months. Meta, the owner of Facebook and Instagram, said earlier this month that it expects revenue growth to slow in the coming months as businesses cut back on their marketing budgets. The slowdown in advertising spending is a major concern for tech companies. Advertising is a major source of revenue for many tech companies and a slowdown in spending could have a significant impact on their profits. Google's warning is likely to add to concerns about the outlook for the tech sector. The tech sector has been one of the best performing sectors in recent years but there are concerns that the sector is now facing a number of challenges, including the slowing global economy, rising interest rates and increased competition. Google's warning is a reminder that even the largest and most successful companies are not immune to the challenges facing the global economy.

title: Snowdon motorists 'towed' if they park illegally at Pen-y-Pass
text: Snowdon motorists face being 'towed' if they park illegally at Pen-y-Pass Motorists who park illegally at the popular Snowdon beauty spot Pen-y-Pass could be towed away this summer, the authorities have warned. Snowdonia National Park Authority has announced it will be taking a tougher stance on illegal parking in the area, which has become a major problem in recent years. Last summer, hundreds of vehicles were parked illegally on the A4086 at Pen-y-Pass, causing long tailbacks and putting other road users at risk. In response, the National Park Authority is introducing a new scheme which will see illegally parked vehicles towed away. The scheme will be in operation from July 29th until September 4th, and will be enforced by Snowdonia National Park Authority rangers and North Wales Police. Vehicles parked on double yellow lines, in lay-bys, or on grass verges will be targeted by the scheme. Motorists who have their vehicles towed away will have to pay a release fee of £150, plus any additional storage charges. The National Park Authority is urging motorists to park responsibly and follow the directions of the rangers and police. A spokesperson for the National Park Authority said: "Illegal parking at Pen-y-Pass is a major problem which we are determined to tackle. "We have tried a number of different measures to discourage people from parking illegally, but unfortunately they have not been successful. "This new scheme is a last resort, but we believe it is necessary to protect the environment and the safety of other road users. "We would urge motorists to park responsibly and follow the directions of the rangers and police." The National Park Authority is also reminding motorists that there are a number of alternative parking options available at Pen-y-Pass. These include the car park at the Pen-y-Pass Youth Hostel, which has a capacity of 200 vehicles, and the car park at the Snowdon Mountain Railway station, which has a capacity of 100 vehicles. Motorists can also park at the Llanberis Lake Railway station, which is a short walk from Pen-y-Pass.

title: Catalonia ex-officials freed by Belgian judge
text: Catalonia ex-officials freed by Belgian judge after extradition suspended A Belgian judge has freed eight Catalan ex-officials wanted by Spain on charges related to a failed independence referendum. The judge ruled that extradition was suspended because there was a risk they would not receive a fair trial in Spain. The officials were arrested in Brussels in October and have been in custody since then. They are accused of rebellion and misuse of public funds over the Catalan government's attempt to hold an independence referendum in 2017. The Spanish government has condemned the Belgian court's decision, saying it is "an affront to the rule of law". The eight officials are: Carles Puigdemont, the former president of Catalonia Antoni Comín, the former regional minister for health Lluís Puig, the former regional minister for culture Meritxell Serret, the former regional minister for agriculture Clara Ponsatí, the former regional minister for education Antoni Comín, the former regional minister for health Lluis Puig, the former regional minister for culture Meritxell Serret, the former regional minister for agriculture Clara Ponsatí, the former regional minister for education The officials have all denied the charges against them and say they are being politically persecuted by the Spanish government. The Belgian court's decision is a major blow to the Spanish government's efforts to prosecute the Catalan separatists. It is unclear what will happen to the officials now that they have been released. They could still be extradited to Spain if the Belgische Hof van Cassatie, Belgium's highest court, overturns the lower court's decision. However, it is also possible that they will be granted asylum in Belgium or another country. The decision has been welcomed by the Catalan government, which said it "respects the independence of the Belgian judiciary". The Spanish government has said it will continue to pursue the extradition of the officials. The Catalan independence referendum was held on 1 October 2017, despite being declared illegal by the Spanish government. The referendum resulted in a vote in favor of independence, but the Spanish government has refused to recognize the result. The Catalan government's attempt to declare independence from Spain has led to a political crisis between the two sides. The Spanish government has imposed direct rule on Catalonia and has arrested several Catalan leaders. The Catalan independence movement has been largely peaceful, but there have been some violent protests. The decision by the Belgian judge to release the Catalan ex-officials is likely to further escalate tensions between Spain and Catalonia.

title: Why charities are counting the costs of council cuts
text: Why Charities Are Counting the Costs of Council Cuts Local authorities across the UK are facing severe budget cuts, and the impact is being felt by charities that provide vital services to communities. These cuts are forcing charities to make difficult decisions that are affecting their ability to deliver essential support. One of the most significant impacts of council cuts is the loss of funding for frontline services. Many charities rely on this funding to provide crucial services such as homelessness support, mental health services, and youth services. Without this funding, charities are struggling to meet the needs of those who rely on them. For example, the Trussell Trust, a charity that operates a network of food banks, has reported a significant increase in demand for its services in recent years. This increase is thought to be partly due to the impact of council cuts, which have reduced the support available to low-income families. In addition to funding cuts, charities are also facing increased competition for funding from other sources. This is because local councils are increasingly turning to private sector providers to deliver services, which means that there is less money available for charities. Charities are also facing rising costs, such as the cost of rent, utilities, and staff salaries. This means that they are having to do more with less, which is putting a strain on their resources. The impact of these challenges is being felt by the people who rely on charities for support. Many charities are having to reduce their services or close altogether, which means that people are losing out on the vital support they need. For example, a recent study by the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) found that more than half of charities have had to reduce their services or close in the past year. The government has acknowledged the impact that council cuts are having on charities, and it has announced some measures to help. However, these measures have been criticized by some charities as being insufficient. Charities are calling on the government to do more to support them, and they are urging local councils to think carefully about the impact of their cuts on the most vulnerable in society. Until more support is available, charities will continue to struggle to meet the needs of those who rely on them. This will have a devastating impact on the most vulnerable in our communities.

title: Fifa indictment: What's in it
text: Fifa indictment: What's in it The 47-count indictment against FIFA officials unsealed in the United States on Wednesday details a 24-year scheme of corruption involving bribes and kickbacks worth more than $150m (£98m). Key accusations The indictment accuses 14 current and former FIFA officials and sports marketing executives of accepting bribes and kickbacks in exchange for their support of the South Africa bid for the 2010 World Cup and other tournaments. It also alleges that: Bribes were paid to FIFA officials in exchange for votes in favour of Qatar's bid for the 2022 World Cup. Officials took bribes for the sale of television and marketing rights for FIFA tournaments. Officials exploited their positions to secure commercial contracts for themselves and their associates. FIFA awarded contracts to companies owned by officials or their associates, even when they were not the lowest bidders. Who is charged? The 14 individuals charged in the indictment include: Jeffrey Webb, former president of the Confederation of North, Central America and Caribbean Association Football (CONCACAF) Jack Warner, former vice-president of FIFA Chuck Blazer, former general secretary of CONCACAF Michel Platini, current president of UEFA Sepp Blatter, former president of FIFA What happens next? The individuals charged in the indictment are due to appear in court in New York on 3 December. FIFA has said it will cooperate with the US investigation and has appointed an independent ethics committee to look into the allegations. The scandal has cast a shadow over FIFA and has led to calls for reform of the organisation. Background FIFA is the international governing body of association football. It was founded in 1904 and is based in Zurich, Switzerland. FIFA is responsible for organising the World Cup, the Confederations Cup, and other international football tournaments. Impact of the scandal The scandal has damaged FIFA's reputation and has led to calls for reform. FIFA has said it will cooperate with the US investigation and has appointed an independent ethics committee to look into the allegations. The scandal has also had an impact on the World Cup. In 2015, FIFA awarded the 2022 World Cup to Qatar, but there have been allegations that bribes were paid to secure the vote. FIFA has denied these allegations, but the scandal has cast a shadow over the tournament.

title: UK diesel car sales fall by nearly a third in October
text: UK diesel car sales fall by nearly a third in October Sales of new diesel cars in the UK have fallen by nearly a third in October, according to figures from the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT). Just 9.1% of new cars sold in October were diesel, down from 13.4% in the same month last year. This is the lowest market share for diesel cars since records began in 1997. The decline in diesel sales has been driven by a number of factors, including concerns about air pollution and the rising cost of fuel. In recent years, a number of cities have introduced or expanded clean air zones, which charge drivers of older, more polluting vehicles. The government has also announced plans to ban the sale of new petrol and diesel cars by 2030. This has led many consumers to delay buying a new diesel car, in anticipation of the ban. The decline in diesel sales has been welcomed by environmental campaigners. They argue that diesel cars are a major source of air pollution, which can contribute to respiratory problems and other health issues. However, the decline in diesel sales has also raised concerns about the future of the UK automotive industry. Diesel cars have traditionally been popular with British drivers, and their decline could lead to job losses in the manufacturing sector. The SMMT has called on the government to provide more support for the automotive industry, including investment in research and development of new technologies. "The UK automotive industry is facing a perfect storm of challenges, including the decline in diesel sales, the global chip shortage, and the rising cost of raw materials," said SMMT chief executive Mike Hawes. "The government must provide more support for the industry if we are to maintain our position as a global leader in automotive manufacturing." The decline in diesel sales is likely to continue in the coming months. In November, the government is due to introduce a new Vehicle Excise Duty (VED) system, which will increase the tax on diesel cars. This is likely to further deter consumers from buying diesel vehicles.

title: Budget 2017: Tax on takeaway boxes to be considered
text: Chancellor Philip Hammond is considering introducing a tax on takeaway food and drink containers as part of plans to tackle plastic waste. The levy could be applied to single-use items such as plastic cups, straws, and food boxes, and would be similar to the 5p charge on plastic bags introduced in 2015. The Treasury is understood to be looking at a range of options, including a flat rate levy on all takeaway containers or a higher charge on items made from non-recyclable materials. The move is part of a wider government drive to reduce plastic pollution, which has been linked to a range of environmental problems, including damage to marine life and the release of harmful chemicals into the food chain. A Treasury spokesperson said: "We are committed to taking action to reduce plastic waste and we are considering a range of options, including a levy on takeaway food and drink containers." The proposal has been welcomed by environmental groups, who say it could help to reduce the amount of plastic waste generated by the hospitality industry. Hugo Tagholm, chief executive of the Surfers Against Sewage campaign group, said: "A tax on takeaway containers is a positive step towards reducing the amount of plastic pollution in our oceans and on our beaches." "We hope that the government will introduce a levy that is both ambitious and effective in reducing the use of single-use plastics," he added. The hospitality industry has expressed concern about the potential impact of a tax on takeaway containers, warning that it could lead to increased costs for businesses and consumers. Kate Nicholls, chief executive of UKHospitality, said: "We are concerned about the potential impact of a tax on takeaway containers on our members, many of whom are already struggling with rising costs." "We would urge the government to work with the industry to find a solution that reduces plastic waste without placing an undue burden on businesses," she added. The Treasury is expected to publish a consultation on the proposed tax later this year.

title: Ofwat blamed for high water bills by committee of MPs
text: A committee of MPs has accused the water regulator Ofwat of failing to prevent high water bills for customers. The Public Accounts Committee (PAC) said in a report that Ofwat had "not been sufficiently robust" in regulating the water industry, which had led to "higher bills for customers than necessary". The committee also said that Ofwat had been too willing to allow water companies to increase their profits, and that it had not done enough to protect consumers from unfair charges. The report comes after a number of water companies have been criticized for increasing their bills while their profits have also risen. For example, in 2021, Thames Water increased its bills by an average of 2.5%, while its profits rose by 13%. The PAC said that Ofwat had "failed to take effective action" to prevent these kinds of increases, and that it had "not been sufficiently responsive to the concerns of consumers". The committee also said that Ofwat had not done enough to encourage water companies to invest in their infrastructure, which had led to leaks and other problems. The report concludes by saying that Ofwat needs to "take a more proactive approach to regulation" and that it needs to "do more to protect consumers from unfair charges". Ofwat has said that it accepts the findings of the report and that it will "take action to address the concerns raised". However, the committee has said that it will continue to monitor Ofwat's progress and that it will "hold the regulator to account" if it does not make the necessary improvements. The PAC's report is the latest in a series of criticisms of Ofwat. In 2019, the National Audit Office (NAO) said that Ofwat had "not been effective in regulating the water industry" and that it had "failed to protect consumers from high bills". The NAO also said that Ofwat had been "too willing to allow water companies to increase their profits" and that it had "not done enough to encourage water companies to invest in their infrastructure". Ofwat has said that it is "committed to protecting consumers" and that it is "working to improve the way it regulates the water industry". However, the PAC's report suggests that Ofwat still has a long way to go before it can be considered an effective regulator.

title: Theresa May to visit Africa for first time as prime minister
text: Theresa May will travel to Africa for the first time as prime minister next week, visiting South Africa, Nigeria and Kenya. The visit will be an opportunity to strengthen existing ties and to explore new areas of cooperation. The UK is committed to working with Africa to build a more prosperous and secure future for both continents. Mrs May's visit to Africa will be her first since becoming prime minister in July 2016. The visit will be an opportunity for her to meet with African leaders and to discuss a range of issues, including trade, security and development. The UK has a long history of engagement with Africa, and Mrs May's visit will be an opportunity to build on this relationship and to explore new areas of cooperation.

title: Shark nations failing on conservation pledges
text: Shark nations failing on conservation pledges Conservation commitments made by governments to safeguard shark populations are falling short, according to a new report by the wildlife trade monitoring network Traffic. The report, published on Tuesday, assesses the progress made by 23 countries that have signed up to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES). It found that while some nations have made significant strides in implementing their pledges, many are lagging behind. The report found that only five of the 23 countries have fully implemented their CITES commitments. These countries are Australia, Canada, India, Mexico, and the United States. The report found that some countries are failing to implement their CITES commitments due to a lack of resources or political will. The report also found that illegal fishing is a major threat to sharks. The report found that illegal fishing is responsible for the deaths of an estimated 100 million sharks each year. The report calls on governments to do more to combat illegal fishing and to implement their CITES commitments. The report comes as the world's shark populations face a number of threats, including overfishing, habitat loss, and climate change. According to the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), one-quarter of all shark species are now threatened with extinction. The report from Traffic highlights the need for urgent action to protect sharks. Governments must do more to implement their CITES commitments and to combat illegal fishing. The report also calls on consumers to make sustainable seafood choices. Consumers can help to protect sharks by choosing to buy seafood from fisheries that use sustainable practices. Sharks play a vital role in marine ecosystems. They help to keep populations of other fish in check and they play a role in nutrient cycling. The loss of sharks would have a devastating impact on marine ecosystems and on the livelihoods of people who depend on the ocean.

title: Carwyn Jones: Wales 'not too poor to be independent'
text: Wales has the potential to be a wealthy and prosperous independent nation, former First Minister Carwyn Jones has said. Speaking at an event in Cardiff, Jones said that Wales had "all the ingredients" needed to succeed as an independent country. "We have a highly skilled workforce, a strong economy, and a wealth of natural resources," he said. "We also have a proud history and a distinct culture." Jones said that Wales was "not too poor to be independent." He pointed out that the Welsh economy was growing faster than the UK economy as a whole, and that Wales had a higher GDP per capita than many other European countries. "We have the resources and the talent to succeed as an independent nation," he said. "It is time for us to take control of our own destiny." Jones's comments come amid a growing debate about the future of Wales. The Welsh independence movement has gained momentum in recent years, and a number of polls have suggested that a majority of Welsh people now support independence. However, there are also those who believe that Wales is not yet ready for independence. They argue that the Welsh economy is too small and too dependent on the UK government. Jones acknowledged that there were challenges facing Wales, but he said that these challenges could be overcome. He called on the Welsh people to be "bold and ambitious" and to "seize the opportunity" to create a better future for Wales. "We can be a successful and prosperous independent nation," he said. "Let us work together to make it happen." Jones's comments have been welcomed by some Welsh independence supporters. However, they have also been criticized by those who believe that Wales is not yet ready for independence. The debate about the future of Wales is likely to continue for some time. However, Jones's comments have helped to raise the profile of the independence movement and have shown that there is a growing body of support for independence in Wales.

title: Jeremy Corbyn sets out Labour's EU stance
text: Jeremy Corbyn has promised to keep the UK within the EU single market and customs union if Labour wins the next election. In a speech in Birmingham, the Labour leader said remaining in the single market and customs union would protect jobs and businesses. He also called for a "fresh approach" to Brexit negotiations, saying that the government's current approach was "failing". Mr. Corbyn's speech comes after the government published its Brexit white paper, which sets out its plans for leaving the EU. The white paper has been criticized by both Labour and the Conservative Party, with Labour saying that it would lead to a "hard Brexit" that would damage the economy. In his speech, Mr. Corbyn said that Labour's approach to Brexit would be different. He said that Labour would not seek to leave the single market or the customs union. He also said that Labour would give parliament a final say on any Brexit deal. Mr. Corbyn said that remaining in the single market and customs union would protect jobs and businesses. He said that these arrangements would allow the UK to continue to trade with the EU without tariffs or other barriers. He also said that remaining in the single market and customs union would give the UK a "seat at the table" in negotiations with the EU. He said that this would allow the UK to influence the development of future EU regulations. Mr. Corbyn called for a "fresh approach" to Brexit negotiations. He said that the government's current approach was "failing." He said that the government had not been able to get a deal that is in the best interests of the UK. Mr. Corbyn said that Labour would take a different approach to negotiations. He said that Labour would be prepared to walk away from the negotiations if the EU does not offer the UK a good deal. He also said that Labour would be prepared to hold a second referendum on Brexit if it is not possible to get a deal that is in the best interests of the UK. Mr. Corbyn's speech was welcomed by some Labour MPs, who have been critical of the government's Brexit plans. However, some Labour MPs have expressed concern that Mr. Corbyn's commitment to remaining in the single market and customs union could make it more difficult to leave the EU.

title: Female MPs write letter 'in solidarity' with Meghan amid media scrutiny
text: Female MPs have written a letter to the Duchess of Sussex expressing their "solidarity" amid intense media scrutiny.
