title: EA games web server hacked to host phishing website now fixed
text: EA Games Web Server Breach: Phishing Website Removed Electronic Arts (EA), a leading video game publisher, has confirmed that its web server was recently compromised by hackers. The breach allowed the attackers to host a phishing website on EA's servers, designed to steal personal and financial information from users. According to EA, the phishing website was hosted on a subdomain of the EA Help website. It was disguised as a legitimate EA login page and prompted users to enter their EA account credentials, including their username, password, and security questions. The breach was first discovered by security researcher Chad Seaman, who reported it to EA on Monday. EA immediately took down the phishing website and launched an investigation into the incident. "We are aware of a recent attempt to phish EA players through a fake website," EA said in a statement. "This website was not hosted on EA's servers, but it was able to spoof EA's login page." "We have taken down the phishing website and are continuing to investigate the incident. We recommend that players be cautious when entering their personal information online, and only use official EA websites and channels." It is unclear at this time how many users may have been affected by the phishing scam. EA has advised users to change their EA account passwords immediately and be wary of any suspicious emails or websites that claim to be from EA. The breach is a reminder of the importance of online security and the need for users to be vigilant when entering personal information online. It is also a reminder for companies to invest in robust security measures to protect their data and their customers' privacy. EA has not disclosed any further details about the breach, including how the hackers gained access to its web server or what measures it is taking to prevent similar incidents in the future. The incident comes at a sensitive time for EA, which is currently in the process of releasing its highly anticipated new game, Battlefield 2042. The company has faced criticism in recent years for its aggressive monetization practices and its handling of player feedback. The phishing scam is likely to damage EA's reputation further and could potentially affect sales of Battlefield 2042. title: WW2's 'Spitfire Women': Eleanor Wadsworth, one of last female pilots, dies
text: Eleanor Wadsworth, One of the Last Female Spitfire Pilots of World War II, Dies Eleanor Wadsworth, one of the last surviving female pilots who flew Spitfires during World War II, has passed away at the age of 100. Wadsworth, who hailed from Ulverston, Cumbria, joined the Air Transport Auxiliary (ATA) in 1943. The ATA was responsible for ferrying aircraft from factories to operational units, a vital role in supporting the war effort. Despite facing prejudice and skepticism as a woman in a male-dominated field, Wadsworth proved to be an exceptional pilot. She flew over 900 aircraft during her time with the ATA, including Spitfires, Hurricanes, and Wellingtons. Her fearless spirit and unwavering determination earned her the admiration of her colleagues. "She was one of the finest and most courageous pilots I ever flew with," said John Hemingway, a fellow ATA pilot. After the war, Wadsworth continued to fly, working as an instructor and test pilot. She also became an advocate for women in aviation, sharing her experiences and encouraging others to pursue their dreams. In 2018, she was awarded the MBE for her services to aviation. At the ceremony, she met Prince Charles, who praised her as an "inspiration to us all." Eleanor Wadsworth's passing marks the end of an era. She was one of the pioneers who paved the way for women in aviation, demonstrating that they could excel in even the most challenging of fields. Her legacy lives on in the countless women who have followed in her footsteps, inspired by her courage, determination, and unwavering passion for flying. In a tribute to her life, the RAF said: "Eleanor was a remarkable woman who made a significant contribution to our country during and after the war. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her." Eleanor Wadsworth's memory will continue to inspire generations of aviators to come, reminding us of the indomitable spirit that can overcome any obstacle.

title: Northamptonshire 1930 'blazing car murder': Nine families shortlisted
text: In a chilling twist to the unsolved "blazing car murder" of 1930, which left the body of an unidentified woman charred beyond recognition, Northamptonshire Police have shortlisted nine families as potential relatives of the victim. The case, which has haunted detectives for decades, took a dramatic turn when a breakthrough in DNA analysis allowed investigators to create a genetic profile of the victim. This profile was then cross-referenced with genetic databases, leading to the identification of nine families with a potential familial connection. Families from across the country, including the West Midlands, Lancashire, and London, have been contacted by police and asked to provide DNA samples for comparison. Investigators believe that the victim may have had links to these areas, as her belongings contained items suggesting she had traveled extensively. "This is a significant development in a case that has remained a mystery for almost a century," said Detective Superintendent Shaun O'Keefe, who is leading the investigation. "We believe that these nine families could hold the key to unlocking the identity of this unknown woman and finally bringing closure to her family." The victim's body was discovered on January 18, 1930, inside a burnt-out car parked in a field near the village of Islip. The blaze had been so intense that her body was left unrecognizable, and her identity has remained a tantalizing enigma ever since. Over the years, there have been numerous theories about the victim's identity, including that she was a runaway teenager, a victim of foul play, or even a spy. However, despite extensive investigations, her true identity has remained elusive. The families who have been shortlisted are now anxiously awaiting the results of the DNA comparisons. They have been told that there is no guarantee that the victim is their relative, but they remain hopeful that this breakthrough could finally provide them with answers after years of uncertainty. "We have been living with this mystery for so long," said one family member who wished to remain anonymous. title: Fonseka political prisoner - former CJ
text: In the annals of Sri Lankan history, the saga of Sarath Fonseka, the former Chief of Defence Staff and one-time political prisoner, remains a tale of intrigue, conflict, and societal upheaval. Fonseka's rise to prominence came during the final stages of the Sri Lankan Civil War, where he played a pivotal role in defeating the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) in 2009. As a venerated military figure, he enjoyed widespread public support and was hailed as a war hero. However, his political aspirations would soon set him on a collision course with the government. In 2010, Fonseka challenged incumbent President Mahinda Rajapaksa in the presidential election. The campaign was fiercely contested, with allegations of voter fraud and intimidation. After a narrow defeat, Fonseka found himself the target of political persecution. He was arrested on fabricated charges of conspiring against the government and sentenced to two and a half years in prison. Fonseka's imprisonment sparked international condemnation and raised concerns about the state of democracy in Sri Lanka. The former war hero became a symbol of political oppression, with his supporters organizing protests and demanding his release. After serving his sentence, Fonseka was released in 2012, but he remained under restrictions and surveillance. Following the electoral defeat of Rajapaksa in 2015, Fonseka's political fortunes took a turn. He was elected to parliament in 2016 and joined the government of President Maithripala Sirisena. However, his tenure was marked by controversy, with allegations of corruption and a strained relationship with the ruling party. Fonseka's legacy remains a complex and contested one. His military accomplishments are undeniable, yet his political actions have been divisive. His arrest and imprisonment cast a shadow over Sri Lanka's post-war transition and raised questions about the government's commitment to democratic principles. Today, Fonseka is a vocal critic of the Rajapaksa regime, which has returned to power. He remains a symbol of both the triumph and the tribulations of a nation grappling with its past and present. The story of Sarath Fonseka is a reminder of the often-fragile nature of democracy and the price paid by those who dare to challenge the powerful.

title: Amazonian groups sue French supermarket chain over deforestation
text: Amazonian Groups Sue French Supermarket Chain over Deforestation Indigenous groups from the Amazon rainforest have filed a lawsuit against a French supermarket chain, accusing it of contributing to deforestation in the region. The lawsuit, filed with the French courts, alleges that the supermarket chain has been sourcing products from suppliers linked to the destruction of the Amazon rainforest. The lawsuit was filed by the Coordination of Indigenous Organizations of the Brazilian Amazon (COIAB) and the Amazon Environmental Research Institute (IPAM). The groups claim that the supermarket chain has been sourcing products such as beef, soy, and palm oil from suppliers who have cleared large areas of rainforest to make way for agriculture. The lawsuit alleges that the supermarket chain has failed to take adequate steps to ensure that its products are not contributing to deforestation. The groups claim that the supermarket chain has not conducted proper due diligence on its suppliers and has not taken steps to reduce the risk of sourcing products from deforested areas. The lawsuit is seeking an injunction to prevent the supermarket chain from sourcing products from suppliers linked to deforestation. The groups are also seeking damages for the environmental damage caused by the deforestation. The lawsuit is the latest in a series of legal actions brought against companies accused of contributing to deforestation in the Amazon rainforest. In recent years, a number of companies have been sued by investors, environmental groups, and indigenous communities. The Amazon rainforest is one of the most important ecosystems on Earth. It is home to an estimated 10% of the world's known species and plays a vital role in regulating the global climate. However, the rainforest is under threat from deforestation, which is driven by the demand for commodities such as beef, soy, and palm oil. Deforestation is a major problem in the Amazon rainforest. In 2020, an area of rainforest the size of Portugal was cleared. This deforestation is having a devastating impact on the environment and on the indigenous communities who live in the rainforest. The lawsuit against the supermarket chain is an important step towards holding companies accountable for their role in deforestation. The lawsuit could set a precedent for future legal actions against companies that are linked to deforestation.

title: Chinese police uncover huge fake jellyfish 'scam'
text: In a shocking bust, Chinese authorities have uncovered a massive counterfeit jellyfish operation, seizing over 160 tons of artificial jellyfish destined for dinner tables around the country. The operation, which spanned multiple provinces, involved the production and sale of fake jellyfish made from a mixture of industrial gelatin, salt, and alum, posing serious health risks to unsuspecting consumers. Jellyfish, a popular delicacy in China, is harvested from the ocean or farmed in coastal areas. However, the high demand and lucrative prices have led to a surge in counterfeiting, with fraudulent products flooding the market. The fake jellyfish were manufactured in clandestine workshops, where cheap ingredients were combined to create a semblance of the real thing. The artificial jellyfish were then sold to restaurants and seafood markets, often mixed in with genuine jellyfish to maximize profits. The scam was exposed following a tip-off to police in the eastern city of Taizhou, Zhejiang Province. A preliminary investigation revealed a network of suppliers, manufacturers, and distributors involved in the illicit trade. Raids conducted across several provinces uncovered numerous production facilities, where hundreds of workers were busy manufacturing the fake jellyfish. Tons of raw materials and finished products were confiscated, along with equipment used in the production process. Police arrested over 50 suspects, including the alleged mastermind behind the operation. The suspects face charges ranging from fraud to producing and selling harmful food products. The seizure of the fake jellyfish is a major victory for food safety regulators in China, who have been cracking down on counterfeit and adulterated food products in recent years. The case has also highlighted the need for increased vigilance in the seafood industry, where counterfeiting remains a persistent problem. Experts warn that consuming fake jellyfish can have severe consequences for health. Industrial gelatin, a primary component in the counterfeit products, is not intended for human consumption and can contain toxic substances. Alum, another ingredient used in the fake jellyfish, can cause gastrointestinal problems and kidney damage. Consumers are urged to be wary of suspiciously low prices for jellyfish and to purchase seafood from reputable sources. Restaurants and seafood markets should also be vigilant and ensure that their suppliers are legitimate. The authorities are continuing to investigate the case and have vowed to prosecute all those involved in the counterfeit jellyfish operation to the fullest extent of the law.

title: Cahuzac scandal: Ministers publish wealth details
text: Cahuzac scandal: Ministers publish wealth details Amid growing pressure following the Cahuzac scandal, French ministers have published details of their wealth as part of a new transparency drive. title: How financial crisis in Europe affects the UK's economy
text: How Financial Crisis in Europe Affects the UK's Economy The financial crisis that has gripped Europe in recent years has had a significant impact on the UK's economy. The UK is closely linked to the European economy, and so the economic problems in Europe have had a knock-on effect on the UK. One of the main ways that the European financial crisis has affected the UK is through trade. The UK is a major exporter to the European Union, and so when the European economy slows down, the demand for UK goods and services decreases. This has led to a decline in UK exports, which has in turn had a negative impact on the UK's GDP. In addition to the decline in exports, the European financial crisis has also led to a decrease in investment in the UK. Investors are less likely to invest in the UK when the European economy is in turmoil, and this has led to a decline in business investment. This has in turn led to a slowdown in the UK's economic growth. The European financial crisis has also had an impact on the UK's financial sector. The UK's financial sector is heavily exposed to the European economy, and so the problems in Europe have led to increased risk aversion among UK banks. This has made it more difficult for UK businesses to access credit, which has in turn had a negative impact on economic growth. The European financial crisis is a complex issue with a wide range of implications for the UK economy. The UK government has taken a number of steps to mitigate the impact of the crisis, but it is clear that the crisis will continue to have a negative impact on the UK economy for some time to come. What does this mean for the UK economy? The European financial crisis has had a number of negative consequences for the UK economy. title: Covid: Minister rules out vaccine passports in UK
text: Covid: Minister rules out vaccine passports in UK The UK government has ruled out introducing vaccine passports for domestic use, following a review of their potential benefits and risks. Health Minister Sajid Javid said on Monday that the government had "carefully considered" the use of vaccine passports, but had concluded that they "are not a proportionate way" to tackle the spread of Covid-19. He said that the government was "confident" that the current measures in place, such as the vaccination programme and the NHS Covid Pass, were sufficient to "manage the risks" of the virus. The decision comes after a six-week consultation on the potential use of vaccine passports, which received more than 150,000 responses. The consultation found that there was "no consensus" on the use of vaccine passports, with some people supporting their use and others strongly opposed. The government also considered the potential impact of vaccine passports on civil liberties and the economy, and concluded that they would "have a significant and disproportionate impact on certain groups in society". The government's decision has been welcomed by some, who argue that vaccine passports are discriminatory and could lead to a "two-tier" society. However, others have expressed disappointment, arguing that vaccine passports could be an effective way to reduce the spread of the virus and protect the NHS. The government has said that it will continue to monitor the situation and will "not hesitate" to introduce vaccine passports if they become necessary in the future. In the meantime, the government is urging people to get vaccinated and to follow the current Covid-19 restrictions. Analysis: The government's decision not to introduce vaccine passports is a significant development in the UK's response to the Covid-19 pandemic. It reflects the government's view that the current measures in place are sufficient to manage the risks of the virus, and that vaccine passports would be disproportionate and discriminatory. The decision is likely to be welcomed by some, but it may also lead to disappointment from others who believe that vaccine passports could be an effective way to reduce the spread of the virus. The government has said that it will continue to monitor the situation and will not hesitate to introduce vaccine passports if they become necessary in the future.

title: Trade talks 'must include healthcare'
text: Trade talks 'must include healthcare' Trade deals should not be negotiated without addressing the impact on healthcare systems, a leading health charity has warned. Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) said it was "deeply concerned" about the secrecy surrounding trade talks, which it said could "undermine access to affordable medicines". The charity is calling for trade deals to be transparent and to include clear safeguards to protect public health. It comes as the UK government prepares to negotiate a trade deal with the US. The US has been pushing for changes to the NHS that could lead to higher drug prices and reduced access to healthcare. MSF said it was "essential" that the UK government resisted these demands and put the protection of the NHS first. "Trade deals can have a huge impact on our health, but they are often negotiated in secret, with little or no input from the public," said Rachel Kiddell-Monroe, MSF's UK director. "We are deeply concerned that trade talks could undermine access to affordable medicines and other essential healthcare services. We are calling for trade deals to be transparent and to include clear safeguards to protect public health." MSF's concerns are echoed by other health organisations. The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that trade deals can lead to "higher prices, reduced access to medicines, and weakened health systems". The European Public Health Alliance (EPHA) has also called for trade deals to be transparent and to include safeguards to protect public health. "Trade deals are not just about economics. They can have a profound impact on our health and well-being," said EPHA director Johanna Hanefeld. "We need to make sure that trade deals are negotiated in the interests of public health, not just the interests of big business." The UK government has said it is committed to protecting the NHS in trade talks. However, it has also said that it is willing to consider changes to the NHS if they are "in the best interests of the UK". MSF said it was "essential" that the UK government resisted US demands to change the NHS. "The NHS is one of the UK's most cherished institutions. It provides high-quality healthcare to all, regardless of their ability to pay," said Kiddell-Monroe. "We must not allow trade deals to undermine the NHS and its commitment to universal healthcare."

title: Loughborough University student died from drugs mix
text: A Loughborough University student has died after taking a fatal combination of drugs, an inquest has heard. Megan Pollitt, 19, was found unresponsive in her flat on 10 November 2021. Paramedics were called but were unable to revive her. An inquest into her death at Loughborough Coroners' Court heard that Ms Pollitt had taken a combination of cocaine, ketamine and alcohol. The medical cause of death was given as mixed drug toxicity. The inquest heard that Ms Pollitt had been out with friends on the evening of 9 November. She returned to her flat in the early hours of the morning and took the drugs. Her flatmates found her unresponsive later that day and called for help. The inquest heard that Ms Pollitt had a history of mental health problems and had been taking medication for depression and anxiety. She had also been drinking alcohol and taking recreational drugs in the months leading up to her death. The coroner concluded that Ms Pollitt's death was a tragic accident. He said that she had taken a combination of drugs that were known to be dangerous and that she had not been aware of the risks. He urged students to be aware of the dangers of taking drugs and to seek help if they are struggling with mental health problems. Ms Pollitt's family said in a statement that they were "heartbroken" by her death. They said: "Megan was a beautiful, intelligent and caring young woman who had her whole life ahead of her. "We are devastated that she has been taken from us so suddenly and tragically. "We would urge other young people to be aware of the dangers of taking drugs and to seek help if they are struggling with mental health problems." Loughborough University said in a statement that it was "deeply saddened" by Ms Pollitt's death. The university said: "We offer our deepest condolences to Megan's family and friends at this difficult time. "We are committed to providing support to our students and staff and we have a range of services in place to help those who are struggling with mental health problems or substance misuse." The university said that it would be reviewing its drug and alcohol policies in light of Ms Pollitt's death.

title: Lowest ever winter deaths recorded
text: The number of deaths in England during the winter months has fallen to its lowest level on record, according to new figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS). Between December 2022 and March 2023, there were 113,600 deaths in England, which is 15.6% lower than the average number of deaths during the same period over the last five years. The ONS said that the decrease in winter deaths is likely to be due to a number of factors, including the success of the Covid-19 vaccination program and the mild winter weather. Dr. Julie Stanborough, head of mortality analysis at the ONS, said: "The decrease in winter deaths is good news and is likely to be due to a number of factors, including the success of the Covid-19 vaccination program and the mild winter weather. "However, it is important to note that the number of deaths in England is still higher than it was before the pandemic, and we are still seeing excess deaths among people aged 65 and over." The ONS figures also show that the number of deaths from Covid-19 in England during the winter months fell by 86% compared to the previous year. This is likely to be due to the success of the vaccination program, which has reduced the number of people who are becoming seriously ill from the virus. The decrease in winter deaths is a positive sign, but it is important to remember that the number of deaths in England is still higher than it was before the pandemic. We need to continue to take steps to protect ourselves and others from Covid-19, including getting vaccinated and boosted, and following public health advice. Here are some tips for staying healthy during the winter months: Get vaccinated and boosted against Covid-19. Wash your hands frequently with soap and water. Avoid touching your face. Cover your mouth and nose when you cough or sneeze. Stay home if you are feeling unwell. Get regular exercise. Eat a healthy diet. Get enough sleep. By following these tips, we can all help to reduce the risk of getting sick and dying during the winter months.

title: Brexit: Plaid Cymru wants pro-remain parties to work together
text: Plaid Cymru has called for pro-Remain parties to work together ahead of local government elections in Wales. title: Amazon told to answer Deliveroo deal concerns in five days
text: Amazon has been given five days to address competition concerns over its proposed deal to buy food delivery service Deliveroo. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) said its initial probe had raised issues about the tie-up, which it fears could lead to higher prices, less choice, and reduced innovation in the sector. The CMA said it had "reasonable grounds for believing that the merger may result in a substantial lessening of competition." It has now launched a Phase 2 investigation, which will give Amazon and Deliveroo the chance to respond to the concerns. The CMA said its concerns center on the following areas: The combined market share of Amazon and Deliveroo: Amazon is already a major player in the online grocery market, while Deliveroo is one of the UK's leading food delivery services. The CMA is worried that the tie-up could give the combined company too much control over the market, leading to higher prices for consumers. The potential for Amazon to use its data to gain an unfair advantage: Amazon has vast amounts of data on its customers' shopping habits. The CMA is concerned that it could use this data to give Deliveroo an unfair advantage over its rivals, for example, by offering exclusive discounts or promotions to Amazon Prime members. The impact on innovation: The CMA is concerned that the tie-up could stifle innovation in the food delivery sector. Amazon and Deliveroo are both large companies with a strong track record of innovation. However, the CMA is worried that the deal could lead to less competition and less investment in new products and services. The CMA has given Amazon and Deliveroo five working days to submit their responses to these concerns. The companies will then have the opportunity to make further representations before the CMA makes a final decision on whether to block the deal. If the CMA does decide to block the deal, it would be a major setback for Amazon's ambitions in the UK grocery market. It would also be a blow to Deliveroo, which is currently facing intense competition from Uber Eats and other rivals. The CMA's investigation is expected to conclude by the end of the year.

title: China quake: Rescue teams blast roads amid aftershocks
text: Amid the devastation wrought by Monday's deadly earthquake in China, rescue teams are working tirelessly to reach survivors trapped under the rubble. As aftershocks continue to rattle the region, complicating their efforts, teams are employing a range of techniques, including blasting roads to clear the way for heavy machinery. The 6.8-magnitude quake struck Sichuan province on Monday, killing at least 93 people and injuring hundreds more. The epicenter was in Luding County, a mountainous area home to about 130,000 people. Rescue teams from across the country have been deployed to the affected area, and they are using a variety of equipment to search for survivors. This includes backhoes, excavators, and cranes, as well as search and rescue dogs. In some cases, teams are having to blast roads to clear the way for their vehicles. This is a dangerous operation, as the aftershocks could cause further landslides or building collapses. However, it is necessary to reach the areas where people are trapped. One team that has been using this technique is from the China Earthquake Administration. They have been working in the town of Moxi, which was heavily damaged in the quake. "We have to be very careful when we blast the roads," said team leader Wang Wei. "The aftershocks could cause the rocks to fall on us. But we have to do it to reach the people who are trapped." The team has been using explosives to clear a road that leads to a collapsed building. They are hoping to reach a group of people who are believed to be trapped inside. "We know that there are people trapped in there," said Wang. "We can hear their voices. We are doing everything we can to reach them." The rescue efforts are being hampered by the aftershocks, which are continuing to shake the region. This is making it difficult for teams to work safely and is also causing further damage to buildings. However, the rescue teams are determined to continue their search for survivors. They are working around the clock, and they are not giving up hope. "We will not rest until we have found everyone who is trapped," said Wang.

title: Spalding shooting: Three members of family killed
text: Three members of a family have been shot dead in a suspected murder-suicide in the Lincolnshire town of Spalding. Police were called to a house in the town's Priory Road at around 9.15am on Friday, 20 May, following reports of a firearms incident. Inside, officers found the bodies of three people - a man and two women. A fourth person - a woman - was found injured at the scene and was taken to hospital, where she remains in a critical condition. title: The spying game: China's global network
text: In the shadowy realm of international espionage, China has emerged as a formidable player. Its sprawling global network of spies operates with stealth and precision, seeking to gather intelligence, influence foreign governments, and advance its own geopolitical agenda. China's intelligence apparatus is vast and well-resourced. The Ministry of State Security (MSS) is responsible for internal and external intelligence operations, while the People's Liberation Army (PLA) has a significant intelligence arm known as the General Staff Department. These agencies employ a wide range of methods, from traditional human intelligence to sophisticated cyberwarfare techniques. China's spying network extends far beyond its borders. It has been accused of operating covert operations in over 100 countries, targeting foreign governments, businesses, and dissidents. In the United States, for example, the FBI has investigated numerous cases of Chinese espionage, including the hacking of government computer systems and the theft of trade secrets. One of the key tactics employed by China's spies is the use of "honeypots" – individuals who are recruited to provide information or access to sensitive targets. These honeypots can be found in a variety of settings, from academic institutions to diplomatic functions. They are often well-educated and well-connected, making them ideal for gathering information on political, economic, and military matters. China's spying activities have raised concerns among Western governments, who see it as a threat to their national security. In 2018, the United States expelled dozens of Chinese diplomats suspected of spying, and the European Union has also expressed concerns about China's intelligence operations. However, China has defended its spying activities as necessary for protecting its national interests. It argues that other countries, including the United States, also engage in espionage, and that its own activities are no more aggressive or intrusive. The spying game between China and other countries is likely to continue for the foreseeable future. As China's global power and influence grows, so too will the need for it to maintain a robust intelligence network. Western governments will need to remain vigilant and develop effective counterintelligence measures to protect their own national security while also seeking to engage with China in a constructive and cooperative manner.

title: Egypt arrests: UN condemns detention of human rights advocates
text: The United Nations has condemned the detention of human rights advocates in Egypt, calling for their immediate release. Three prominent activists were arrested on 29 November 2022, during a raid on the Egyptian Commission for Rights and Freedoms (ECRF), a leading human rights organization. The activists, ECRF director Mohamed Zaree, researcher Haytham Mohamedain, and lawyer Abdelrahman Tarek, were taken to an unknown location and have since been held incommunicado. The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Volker Türk, expressed deep concern about the arrests and called for the activists' immediate release. "The detention of human rights defenders in Egypt is a deeply troubling development," Türk said. "These individuals are playing a vital role in promoting and protecting human rights in the country, and their work should be supported, not criminalized." The UN Human Rights Office (OHCHR) said that the arrests appear to be part of a broader crackdown on civil society in Egypt. "We have received reports of numerous other human rights defenders being subjected to arbitrary arrests, detention, and harassment in recent months," said OHCHR spokesperson Jeremy Laurence. "These actions are a violation of Egypt's international obligations and must stop." The Egyptian government has not commented publicly on the arrests of the three ECRF activists. However, the government has a history of cracking down on dissent and human rights activism. In recent years, the Egyptian government has imprisoned dozens of human rights activists, journalists, and political dissidents. Many of these individuals have been held for months or even years without charge or trial. The crackdown on dissent has been particularly severe since the 2013 military coup that brought President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi to power. Sisi has overseen a wide-ranging crackdown on civil society, media, and political opposition. The international community has repeatedly condemned the Egyptian government's crackdown on dissent. In 2021, the UN Human Rights Council passed a resolution calling on Egypt to release all political prisoners and to respect the rights of human rights defenders. However, the Egyptian government has ignored the international community's calls for reform. The arrests of the three ECRF activists are a further indication that the government is not willing to tolerate any form of dissent.

title: Paddy Armstrong in offer to help Guildford Four inquest
text: Paddy Armstrong, who spent 15 years in prison for the Guildford pub bombings, is offering to help the inquest into the deaths of his three co-accused. Paul Hill, Gerry Conlon, and Carole Richardson died by suicide after their convictions for the 1974 IRA attack were quashed in 1989. The inquest into the deaths of the "Guildford Four" is due to begin in Woking, Surrey, on 2 January. The group was wrongly convicted of the IRA bombings of two pubs in Guildford, Surrey, in 1974, in which five people died and 65 were injured. Mr Armstrong, who was 21 when he was convicted, served 15 years in prison, along with the other three. After their convictions were quashed, the Court of Appeal said the police had lied and fabricated evidence against them. Mr Armstrong, speaking to the BBC, said: "I am offering my support to the inquest because I believe it is important to find out the truth about what happened to Paul, Gerry and Carole. "I believe that all four of our convictions were fabricated and I want to help prevent other families going through the same ordeal that my family and the families of Paul, Gerry and Carole have been through." Mr Armstrong said he had been approached by the coroner's office and asked if he would be willing to give evidence at the inquest. He said he had agreed to do so and would be giving evidence about his own experience of being wrongly convicted and imprisoned. title: RNLI 'float' advice after 18 deaths off Welsh coast
text: RNLI ‘Float’ Advice After 18 Deaths Off Welsh Coast Following the tragic loss of 18 lives in the Bristol Channel in recent weeks, the RNLI has issued an urgent reminder about the importance of wearing a life jacket or buoyancy aid when on or near the water. The warning comes as the organization released statistics showing that there have been 18 accidental drownings in the Welsh coastal region this year, compared to 10 in the same period last year. The RNLI's 'Float to Live' campaign aims to raise awareness of the risks associated with cold water shock and the importance of staying afloat in the event of an accident. Cold water shock is a sudden and potentially fatal involuntary gasp for air caused by the body's reaction to being immersed in cold water. It can lead to drowning even in shallow water. The RNLI's Water Safety Lead, Chris Cousens, said: "We cannot stress enough how vital it is to wear a life jacket or buoyancy aid when on or near the water, especially during the colder months. Cold water shock is a real and serious risk, and it can affect anyone, regardless of their swimming ability." The RNLI recommends that anyone going on or near the water should: Wear a life jacket or buoyancy aid that is the correct size and fit. Tell someone where you are going and when you expect to be back. Check the weather forecast and tide times before you set off. Carry a means of communication, such as a mobile phone in a waterproof case. Cousens added: "We urge everyone to take heed of our advice and to always put safety first. By following these simple steps, we can all help to reduce the risk of drowning and save lives." The RNLI also offers free Float to Live leaflets and resources for anyone who wants to learn more about water safety. These can be downloaded from the RNLI website or obtained from RNLI lifeboat stations. Remember, if you see someone in trouble in the water, call 999 or 112 immediately.

title: Venezuela political prisoners 'revolt' at Caracas jail
text: Venezuela Political Prisoners 'Revolt' at Caracas Jail At least 14 political prisoners have taken control of a wing of a jail in the Venezuelan capital Caracas, demanding their immediate release. The prisoners, who were detained during anti-government protests in recent years, seized control of a corridor in the El Helicoide jail on Monday. They have barricaded themselves inside and are refusing to leave until their demands are met. The prisoners are demanding the release of all political prisoners in Venezuela, as well as an end to the persecution of dissent. They are also calling for an independent investigation into the deaths of several political prisoners in recent years. The Venezuelan government has not yet commented on the situation, but security forces have been deployed around the jail. The political prisoners' revolt is the latest sign of growing unrest in Venezuela, which is facing a severe economic and political crisis. The country has been plagued by shortages of food and medicine, and inflation has soared to over 1 million percent. The government of President Nicolás Maduro has been accused of corruption and human rights abuses, and there have been widespread protests against his rule. The prisoners' revolt comes just days after the United Nations released a report accusing the Venezuelan government of committing crimes against humanity. The report found that the government had carried out arbitrary detentions, torture, and extrajudicial killings. The UN report has put further pressure on the Maduro government, which is already facing sanctions from the United States and other countries. It is unclear how the prisoners' revolt will end, but it is a sign of the growing desperation and anger among Venezuelans. The prisoners' demands are unlikely to be met by the government, which has shown no willingness to compromise. This could lead to a prolonged standoff, or even a violent confrontation.

title: Justene Reece: Police failed to link stalking reports before death
text: Justine Reece, 21, was stalked and harassed by a man she had previously dated, David O'Dowd, for months before her death. Despite reporting O'Dowd's behavior to the police on multiple occasions, officers failed to link the reports together and take appropriate action. Justine's family has said that they believe that if the police had taken her reports more seriously, she would still be alive today. O'Dowd was eventually arrested and charged with Justine's murder, but he was found not guilty by reason of insanity. Justine's case has highlighted the need for police to take stalking and harassment more seriously and to improve their response to reports of such crimes. In the wake of Justine's death, her family has set up a foundation in her name to raise awareness of stalking and harassment and to support victims of these crimes. The foundation's website states that "Justine's legacy will be to ensure that no other family has to suffer the pain and loss that we have." Justine's case is not an isolated one. In the UK, there are an estimated 1.5 million stalking victims each year. Stalking can have a devastating impact on victims' lives, causing them to feel scared, anxious, and isolated. In many cases, stalking victims are reluctant to report their experiences to the police, fearing that they will not be taken seriously or that their reports will not be acted upon. However, it is important to remember that stalking is a crime and that victims should report it to the police. The police have a duty to investigate reports of stalking and to take appropriate action to protect victims. If you are being stalked, there are a number of things you can do to protect yourself: Keep a record of all incidents of stalking, including dates, times, and details of what happened. Report the stalking to the police. Tell your friends and family about what is happening. Get a restraining order against the stalker. Consider getting a panic alarm or personal safety device.

title: Aldi overtakes Co-op to become UK's fifth largest grocer
text: Aldi overtakes Co-op to become UK's fifth largest grocer German discounter Aldi has overtaken The Co-op to become the UK's fifth largest grocer, according to the latest market share figures. Aldi's market share has grown to 9.3%, up from 8.9% a year ago, while The Co-op's has fallen to 6.3%, down from 6.6%. The figures, from Kantar Worldpanel, show that Aldi is now the fastest-growing grocer in the UK, with sales up by 18.7% over the past year. The Co-op's sales have fallen by 1.1% over the same period. Aldi's success is being driven by its low prices and its focus on own-brand products. The discounter has been expanding rapidly in recent years, opening new stores and increasing its range of products. The Co-op, on the other hand, has been struggling to compete with the discounters. The grocer has been losing market share for several years and has recently closed a number of stores. The change in market share between Aldi and The Co-op is a significant development in the UK grocery market. It shows that the discounters are continuing to grow in popularity, while the traditional grocers are struggling to compete. Aldi's success is also a sign of the growing importance of value for money for UK consumers. Shoppers are increasingly looking for ways to save money on their grocery bills, and Aldi's low prices are proving to be attractive. The Co-op's decline is a concern for the grocer. The Co-op is a major employer in the UK and it plays an important role in many local communities. However, the grocer needs to find a way to compete with the discounters if it wants to survive. One possible way for The Co-op to compete with the discounters would be to focus on its own-brand products. The Co-op has a strong range of own-brand products, which are often of good quality and competitively priced. Another option for The Co-op would be to offer more convenience to shoppers. The Co-op has a large network of stores, many of which are located in convenient locations. The grocer could focus on offering more services to shoppers, such as online shopping and home delivery. It remains to be seen whether The Co-op can find a way to compete with the discounters. However, the grocer's decline is a reminder of the challenges facing traditional grocers in the UK.

title: UK gets 24-hour esports gaming channel on TV
text: The United Kingdom is set to become the first country in the world to have a 24-hour esports gaming channel on TV. The new channel, called eGGNetwork, will be available on Freeview, Sky, and Virgin Media from August 1st. It will feature a mix of live esports tournaments, highlights, and interviews with top players. The channel is being launched by a consortium of investors led by esports company Fnatic. Fnatic's chief executive officer, Sam Mathews, said that the channel would be "a game-changer for esports in the UK." "We believe that esports has the potential to be as popular as traditional sports, and we're confident that eGGNetwork will help to make that happen," he said. The channel's content will be produced by a team of experienced esports journalists and broadcasters. The team will be led by former Sky Sports presenter Rachel Stringer. Stringer said that she was "excited" to be part of the team that is launching eGGNetwork. "Esports is a rapidly growing industry, and I believe that eGGNetwork has the potential to be a major player in the market," she said. The channel's launch has been welcomed by the UK esports community. "This is a huge step forward for esports in the UK," said Sean "Seany" O'Brien, the captain of the UK's national esports team. "eGGNetwork will give esports fans in the UK a dedicated channel where they can watch their favorite games and players," he said. The channel is also expected to attract viewers from around the world. "The UK has a strong esports scene, and eGGNetwork will be a great way for people from all over the world to watch the best UK players in action," said Duncan "Thorin" Shields, a leading esports commentator. eGGNetwork is the latest in a series of investments in esports by traditional media companies. In recent months, ESPN, NBCUniversal, and Turner have all launched esports channels or divisions. The growing interest in esports from traditional media companies is a sign of the growing popularity of the industry. Esports is now a global phenomenon, with millions of fans around the world. eGGNetwork is set to launch at a time when the UK esports scene is also growing rapidly. The UK is now home to some of the best esports teams and players in the world. The launch of eGGNetwork is a major milestone for the UK esports community. The channel will give esports fans in the UK a dedicated place to watch their favorite games and players. It will also help to raise the profile of esports in the UK and around the world.

title: Inca success in Peruvian Andes 'thanks to llama dung'
text: Inca Success in Peruvian Andes 'Thanks to Llama Dung' In the unforgiving environment of the Peruvian Andes, the Incas flourished for centuries thanks in part to their clever use of llama dung. This remarkable civilization built vast cities, developed a complex agricultural system, and created stunning works of art, all while relying on the humble llama for survival. Llama dung served as a vital fuel source for the Incas. The high altitude and harsh conditions made it difficult to find firewood, but llama dung burned cleanly and efficiently. It was used to cook food, warm homes, and light public spaces. The Incas even developed a specialized type of stove, known as a "fogón," that was designed to burn llama dung optimally. But llama dung's value extended far beyond fuel. The Incas discovered that it was also an excellent fertilizer. When mixed with soil, llama dung provided essential nutrients for crops. This allowed the Incas to cultivate a wide variety of plants at high altitudes, where farming would otherwise have been impossible. Inca farmers used llama dung to build raised fields, known as "andenes." These elevated platforms created a microclimate that was more conducive to plant growth. By terracing the slopes of the Andes, the Incas were able to maximize agricultural productivity and feed their growing population. Llama dung also played a role in Inca construction. The Incas used it to make mortar, which was used to build walls, temples, and palaces. The dung was mixed with clay and other materials to create a strong and durable adhesive. This enabled the Incas to build impressive structures that have withstood the test of time. In addition to its practical applications, llama dung also had cultural significance for the Incas. It was used in religious ceremonies and festivals. The smoke from burning llama dung was believed to have purifying properties. It was also used to create ceremonial fires, which were used to communicate with the gods. The Inca civilization is a testament to the ingenuity and adaptability of human societies. By harnessing the unique properties of llama dung, the Incas were able to thrive in a challenging environment. Their success serves as a reminder of the importance of sustainable practices and the potential for innovation in even the most unlikely of sources.

title: Ethiopia Tigray crisis: Fear of mass starvation
text: In the war-torn Tigray region of Ethiopia, the haunting specter of mass starvation looms large. The conflict has ravaged the region, leaving its people teetering on the brink of a humanitarian catastrophe. Food supplies have dwindled to alarming levels, and access to basic necessities like clean water and healthcare has been severely compromised. Fields lie fallow, and livestock has been decimated, leaving countless families destitute and facing unimaginable hardship. The United Nations has repeatedly warned of the dire situation, estimating that over 5 million people in Tigray are in urgent need of food assistance. However, aid deliveries have been repeatedly blocked by warring parties, exacerbating the suffering of civilians. The plight of the people of Tigray is particularly harrowing. Many have been displaced from their homes, seeking refuge in overcrowded camps where disease and malnutrition run rampant. Children are bearing the brunt of the crisis, with stunted growth and an increased vulnerability to preventable diseases. International aid agencies are working tirelessly to provide life-saving assistance, but their efforts are severely hampered by the ongoing conflict. Humanitarian corridors have been repeatedly violated, and aid workers have been targeted, putting their own lives at risk. The consequences of mass starvation in Tigray would be devastating. It would not only result in the loss of countless lives but also destabilize the entire region. The World Food Program has warned that if aid is not delivered urgently, the Tigray crisis could become one of the worst famines in recent history. The international community must act now to avert this impending catastrophe. Pressure must be exerted on the warring parties to allow unfettered access for humanitarian assistance. Aid agencies must be given the necessary protection to safely deliver life-saving supplies to those in desperate need. The people of Tigray cannot be abandoned to their fate. Their lives and the future of their region hang in the balance. Immediate and decisive action is required to prevent a tragedy of unimaginable proportions. The world must not stand idly by while the specter of mass starvation haunts the people of this war-ravaged land.

title: Saudi Arabia profile - overview
text: Saudi Arabia: A Land of Contrasts Saudi Arabia, the birthplace of Islam and custodian of its holiest sites, is a land of ancient traditions and modern ambitions. Spanning a vast and arid desert landscape, the kingdom is an enigma, a land of paradoxes and contradictions. With its vast oil reserves and an authoritarian monarchy, Saudi Arabia is a wealthy nation and a major player on the world stage. Yet, it also faces significant social and economic challenges, including high youth unemployment and a strict adherence to Islamic law. Geography and Population: Saudi Arabia occupies the vast Arabian Peninsula, bordered by Jordan and Iraq to the north, Kuwait to the northeast, Qatar, Bahrain, and the United Arab Emirates to the east, Yemen to the south, and Oman to the southeast. With a land area of over 2 million square kilometers, it is the largest country in the Middle East and the fifth largest in the world. The population of Saudi Arabia is estimated to be around 36 million, including a large expatriate workforce. The majority of the population are Muslims, with a small Christian minority. The official language is Arabic, and the capital city is Riyadh. History and Politics: Saudi Arabia was founded in 1932 by King Abdulaziz Ibn Saud, who unified the various tribes of the Arabian Peninsula under a single monarchy. The kingdom has been ruled by the House of Saud ever since. Saudi Arabia is an absolute monarchy, with the king wielding ultimate authority over all aspects of government and society. The king is advised by a Council of Ministers, appointed by him. There is no elected parliament or political parties. Economy: Saudi Arabia has one of the largest and most diversified economies in the Middle East. However, it is heavily dependent on oil, which accounts for the majority of its exports and government revenue. In recent years, the government has implemented reforms to reduce its reliance on oil and promote economic diversification. These include investments in renewable energy, tourism, and other non-oil sectors. Culture and Society: Saudi Arabia is a deeply conservative society, shaped by Islamic law and tradition. Women face significant restrictions, including legal limitations on their movement, education, and employment. However, there have been some signs of social liberalization in recent years. In 2018, women were granted the right to drive, and there have been increased efforts to promote female empowerment. Challenges and Future Outlook: Saudi Arabia faces a number of challenges, including high youth unemployment, income inequality, and environmental degradation. The country also faces geopolitical risks, including the ongoing conflict in Yemen and tensions with Iran. The future of Saudi Arabia depends on its ability to address these challenges and adapt to a changing global economy. The kingdom's ambitious Vision 2030 plan aims to diversify the economy, create new jobs, and improve the quality of life for its citizens. The success of this plan will shape the destiny of Saudi Arabia for decades to come.

title: Pangbourne sprays to kill oak processionary caterpillar 'dangerous'
text: Pangbourne sprays to kill oak processionary caterpillar 'dangerous' Residents in Pangbourne have been warned not to touch a dangerous spray being used to kill oak processionary caterpillars in the area. The caterpillars, which can cause skin rashes and respiratory problems, have been found in trees in the village and the council has begun spraying to eradicate them. However, the spray, which contains the insecticide deltamethrin, can also be harmful to humans and animals if it is ingested or inhaled. Pangbourne Parish Council has warned residents to keep children and pets away from the sprayed areas and to wear protective clothing if they have to go near them. The council has also advised residents to wash any clothes that have come into contact with the spray and to seek medical attention if they experience any symptoms such as skin irritation, nausea, or vomiting. Deltamethrin is a synthetic pyrethroid insecticide that is commonly used to control pests in agriculture and public health. It is also used in some household products, such as flea and tick treatments for pets. Deltamethrin can cause a range of health problems in humans, including skin irritation, eye irritation, respiratory problems, and neurological problems. In severe cases, it can be fatal. The World Health Organization (WHO) has classified deltamethrin as a moderately hazardous pesticide. However, the UK's Health and Safety Executive (HSE) has concluded that deltamethrin is safe to use when used according to the instructions on the product label. The HSE advises users to wear protective clothing and equipment when using deltamethrin, to avoid contact with skin and eyes, and to wash their hands thoroughly after use. The council has said that it is using the spray in accordance with the HSE's guidelines and that it is taking all necessary precautions to protect the public. However, some residents have expressed concerns about the use of the spray, particularly in areas where children and pets are likely to be present. The council has said that it will continue to monitor the situation and will take further action if necessary to protect the public. In the meantime, residents are advised to follow the council's advice and to avoid contact with the sprayed areas.

title: Kurdish PKK rebels 'begin leaving Turkey' after truce
text: Kurdish PKK rebels begin leaving Turkey after truce Kurdish PKK rebels have begun to withdraw from Turkey under a historic peace deal aimed at ending decades of bloodshed. The first group of around 200 fighters crossed into northern Iraq on Wednesday, under the supervision of international monitors. The move is part of a deal agreed in March between the Turkish government and the PKK, which has been fighting for greater autonomy for Turkey's Kurdish population. The PKK has agreed to withdraw all its fighters from Turkey by the end of the year, and to disarm. In return, the Turkish government has agreed to grant Kurds greater cultural and political rights. The withdrawal is a major step forward in the peace process, but it is not without its risks. The PKK has a long history of breaking ceasefires, and there are fears that the withdrawal could lead to renewed violence. However, both the Turkish government and the PKK are committed to the peace process, and they are confident that it can succeed. The withdrawal is being overseen by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), the Turkish government, and international monitors. The monitors are from the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE). The OSCE monitors will be responsible for verifying that the PKK fighters are withdrawing from Turkey and that they are disarming. They will also be responsible for monitoring the security situation in the areas from which the PKK fighters are withdrawing. The withdrawal is expected to take several months to complete. Once it is complete, the PKK will have withdrawn all of its fighters from Turkey for the first time in more than 30 years. The peace process between the Turkish government and the PKK has been ongoing for several years. It has been a difficult process, but it has made significant progress in recent months. The withdrawal of the PKK fighters from Turkey is a major step forward in the peace process, and it is a sign that both sides are committed to finding a peaceful solution to the conflict.

title: Christians persecuted by Islamists, says Prince Charles
text: Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, has spoken out about the persecution of Christians by Islamists, calling it a "great tragedy" that must be stopped. In a speech at the Church of England's General Synod, Charles said that the persecution of Christians is "a matter of great concern to me" and that he is "deeply worried" about the situation. He said that Christians are being "driven out of their homes, their businesses, and their countries" and that they are being "killed, tortured, and raped." Charles said that the persecution of Christians is "a crime against humanity" and that it must be stopped. He called on the international community to "do more to protect Christians from persecution" and to "stand up for religious freedom." Charles's speech comes amid growing concern about the persecution of Christians around the world. According to a report by the Pew Research Center, Christians are the most persecuted religious group in the world, with more than 245 million Christians experiencing persecution in 2017. The report found that Christians are persecuted in more than 150 countries, with the worst persecution occurring in North Korea, Afghanistan, and Somalia. The persecution of Christians has been condemned by Pope Francis, who has called it a "genocide." In a speech in 2018, Francis said that the persecution of Christians is "a tragedy of immense proportions" and that it is "a crime against humanity." He called on the international community to "do more to protect Christians from persecution" and to "stand up for religious freedom." The persecution of Christians is a serious problem that must be addressed. The international community must do more to protect Christians from persecution and to stand up for religious freedom.

title: Warrior women of Eigg and other tales from Small Isles
text: In the mystical realm of the Small Isles, off the west coast of Scotland, a tapestry of tales unfolds, where warrior women and legendary figures dance through the mists of time. Among these captivating narratives, the saga of the fierce women of Eigg stands tall. According to ancient Gaelic lore, the Isle of Eigg was once home to a formidable band of female warriors known as the "Daughters of Eigg." These warrior women, led by the legendary Scaithach, were renowned for their exceptional skills in combat and their unwavering courage. In one tale, the Daughters of Eigg faced an invading force from the Isle of Skye. With bows and arrows in hand, they defended their homeland with fierce determination. Their arrows flew with deadly precision, raining upon the enemy from the hillsides. The invaders, overwhelmed by the women's tenacity, were forced to retreat. Another tale tells of how Scaithach trained the young Celtic hero Cú Chulainn in the arts of warfare. The Daughters of Eigg imparted upon him the secrets of swordsmanship, archery, and the deadly "sling bullet." Under their tutelage, Cú Chulainn became one of the greatest warriors in Irish mythology. The legacy of the warrior women of Eigg lives on in the island's folklore and archaeological record. The remains of an ancient fort, perched on a rugged clifftop, are believed to have been the stronghold of Scaithach and her formidable daughters. Beyond Eigg, the other Small Isles hold their own enchanting stories. On the Isle of Muck, the legend of "The Red Lady of Muck" persists. She is said to haunt the island's ancient ruins, a spectral figure guarding hidden treasures and secrets. On the Isle of Rùm, tales of a giant race of people, known as the "Fomorians," are still whispered among locals. These mythical beings are said to have ruled the island in prehistoric times, leaving behind enigmatic stone structures and legends of their immense strength. As the sun sets over the Small Isles, casting long shadows across the landscape, the echoes of warrior women, legendary figures, and otherworldly tales continue to reverberate. These islands hold within their embrace a rich seam of history, myth, and folklore, inviting us to delve into a world where the boundaries between reality and imagination blur.

title: Evan Lloyd Evans jailed after 'appalling' horses case
text: Evan Lloyd Evans, 39, of Glandyfi, near Machynlleth, Powys, admitted 15 offences relating to the poor treatment of animals. Evans had been warned previously about the poor condition of the animals, and an RSPCA inspector found horses in "appalling" condition during a visit in March 2021. Evans was sentenced to 16 weeks in prison and was banned from keeping equines for life. The RSPCA said 18 horses were removed from the land, with five needing immediate veterinary treatment. Prosecutor Helen Tench said witnesses described the condition of the land as "a quagmire". She said Evans had been given advice from vets and the RSPCA on how to improve the horses' condition but had failed to act on it. "The photographs show the appalling condition that these horses were kept in," Ms Tench said. "They were standing in deep mud and their hooves were overgrown." Defending, Nia Lloyd said her client had not intended to cause the animals suffering. She said he had taken on more horses than he could cope with and had been struggling to pay for their feed and care. "He is not a cruel man and he is deeply remorseful for any suffering caused," Ms Lloyd said. Sentencing, Judge Timothy Petts said the case was "a sorry tale of neglect". He said Evans had "failed abjectly" to meet the needs of the animals in his care. "It's clear you were totally out of your depth," Judge Petts said. "You were keeping far too many horses and were simply unable to cope." The judge said the prison sentence and ban on keeping horses were necessary to protect animals from further suffering. Speaking after the case, RSPCA inspector Keith Hogben said: "This is one of the worst cases of neglect I have ever seen. "The horses were in appalling condition and were suffering unnecessarily. "We are pleased that Evans has been banned from keeping horses for life and hope that this sends out a clear message that animal cruelty will not be tolerated."

title: Euro 2016: Wales' Belarusian fan travels from New York
text: In the heart of Lyon, amidst the vibrant tapestry of Euro 2016, an unlikely figure emerged from the crowd, his passion for football transcending borders and oceans. Aliaksandr Hleb, a Belarusian native residing in New York, had embarked on an extraordinary journey to witness his beloved Wales take on Slovakia in the group stages. Hleb's love for Wales began during his time as a player for Arsenal, where he developed close friendships with Welsh stalwarts such as Aaron Ramsey and Gareth Bale. Inspired by their unwavering spirit and camaraderie, he adopted the Welsh cause as his own. Despite the vast distance, Hleb's determination to experience the thrill of Euro 2016 firsthand was unwavering. He booked flights, arranged accommodation, and meticulously planned his itinerary. As the day of the match approached, he boarded a transatlantic flight, his heart pounding with anticipation. Upon arriving in Lyon, Hleb immersed himself in the electric atmosphere surrounding the stadium. He donned his Wales jersey, proudly displaying his adopted nation's colors. As he made his way to his seat, he was greeted with warm smiles and words of encouragement from fellow Welsh fans. The match itself was a rollercoaster of emotions. Wales took an early lead, only to concede an equalizer shortly after. Hleb's nerves frayed as the tension mounted. But in the dying minutes of the match, Hal Robson-Kanu struck a magnificent goal to secure a memorable victory for Wales. Hleb erupted in jubilation, his voice hoarse from cheering. He hugged the strangers around him, sharing in their collective joy. At that moment, he felt an unbreakable bond with the Welsh people and their resilient spirit. After the match, Hleb had the opportunity to meet some of his Welsh heroes, including Ramsey and Bale. They thanked him for his unwavering support and shared their thoughts on the tournament. Hleb left the stadium that night with a heart filled with gratitude and memories that would last a lifetime. Hleb's journey to Euro 2016 was not merely about supporting a football team. It was a testament to the power of passion, friendship, and the indomitable spirit of human connection. His story serves as a reminder that despite differences in nationality, language, or distance, the love of sport can unite people from all walks of life.

title: Rural communities being ignored and underrated, say peers
text: Amidst the bustling metropolises and technological advancements, rural communities often find themselves overlooked and undervalued. Yet, the vital role they play in shaping our society and economy cannot be understated. A recent report from the House of Lords has highlighted the urgent need to address the growing disparity between urban and rural areas. Rural communities face unique challenges that are often overlooked by policymakers. The decline of traditional industries, such as farming and mining, has led to economic stagnation in many regions. Lack of access to essential services, including healthcare, education, and transportation, further compounds the challenges faced by rural residents. The report emphasizes that the neglect of rural communities has profound consequences not only for those living in these areas but for the nation as a whole. Rural areas provide vital ecosystem services, such as clean air and water, that benefit everyone. They also serve as important centers for food production, tourism, and cultural heritage. Furthermore, rural communities play a crucial role in maintaining social cohesion and stability. The close-knit nature of these communities fosters strong bonds and a sense of belonging, which are essential for a thriving society. Ignoring the needs of rural communities not only undermines their well-being but also weakens the fabric of our nation. The report calls for a comprehensive approach to tackling the challenges facing rural communities. This includes investing in infrastructure, such as broadband internet and transportation networks, to improve connectivity and economic opportunities. It also emphasizes the need for tailored support for businesses and industries that are specific to rural areas. Moreover, the report highlights the importance of empowering rural communities to have a voice in decision-making that affects them. This can be achieved through greater representation in government and local authorities, as well as the establishment of community-led organizations that can advocate for their needs. By recognizing the value of rural communities and addressing the challenges they face, we can create a more balanced and prosperous society. The neglect of rural areas is a national issue that requires urgent attention. It is time for policymakers and all stakeholders to prioritize the needs of these communities and ensure that they are given the opportunities they deserve to thrive and contribute to the well-being of our nation.

title: Tories would scrap stamp duty on £250,000 homes
text: The Conservative Party has pledged to scrap stamp duty on all homes worth up to £250,000 in England and Northern Ireland if it wins the next general election. The policy, which would come into effect from April 2025, is designed to help first-time buyers and those moving up the property ladder. Stamp duty is a tax on the purchase of property in England and Northern Ireland. The amount of tax you pay depends on the value of the property and whether you are a first-time buyer. First-time buyers currently pay no stamp duty on properties up to £300,000, and 5% on the portion of the property price between £300,000 and £500,000. Under the Conservative Party's proposals, first-time buyers would pay no stamp duty on properties up to £250,000, and 5% on the portion of the property price between £250,000 and £500,000. This would mean that first-time buyers would save up to £2,500 on the purchase of a £250,000 home. The Conservative Party has also pledged to increase the threshold at which people start paying stamp duty on their main home from £125,000 to £250,000. This would mean that people would not have to pay any stamp duty on the first £250,000 of their home's value, regardless of whether they were a first-time buyer or not. The Conservative Party says that its stamp duty cuts would help to boost the housing market and make it easier for people to buy a home. The policy has been welcomed by the property industry, but critics have argued that it will benefit wealthy homeowners more than first-time buyers. The Liberal Democrats have pledged to scrap stamp duty for first-time buyers on all homes under £500,000, while Labour has pledged to scrap stamp duty for all first-time buyers on homes under £250,000. The next general election is due to be held in 2024.

title: Protests against train fare rises held at more than 100 stations
text: In a widespread display of discontent, protesters took to over 100 railway stations across the United Kingdom on Saturday to voice their opposition to impending train fare increases. The demonstrations, organized by the pressure group Action for Rail, were intended to send a clear message to the government and train operating companies that the proposed fare hikes are unacceptable. The protests, which saw participation from commuters, trade unions, and political organizations, were marked by a lively atmosphere. At London's Euston station, hundreds of demonstrators gathered, waving placards and chanting slogans such as "Stop the fare rises" and "Rail for all, not just the rich." Similar scenes unfolded at stations in Manchester, Birmingham, Glasgow, and Edinburgh, among others. The planned fare increases, which are expected to take effect in March, have been widely criticized for placing an undue burden on commuters already struggling with the rising cost of living. Action for Rail estimates that the average commuter will face an increase of £100 per year, a figure that many find excessive. "These fare increases are a disgrace," declared Sarah, a commuter from Leeds. "The government and train companies are out of touch with the reality of people's lives. We can't afford these hikes, and we're not going to stand for them." The protests have received support from several Labour Party politicians, including leader Keir Starmer, who has pledged to freeze fares if elected. The government, however, has defended the increases, arguing that they are necessary to maintain and improve rail services. "We understand that people are facing financial pressures, but these fare rises are essential to ensure we have a safe and reliable railway system," said a spokesperson for the Department for Transport. Despite the government's stance, protesters remain determined to fight the fare increases. Action for Rail has vowed to continue organizing demonstrations and campaigning for affordable rail travel. "We won't give up," said Mark, a spokesperson for the group. "These fare rises are unfair, and we're going to keep fighting until they're scrapped." The protests have sparked a wider debate about the future of rail travel in the UK. Many argue that the current system, which is heavily reliant on fare revenue, is unsustainable and needs to be reformed. Alternative funding models, such as a tax on road use or increased government subsidies, have been proposed. As the government prepares to implement the fare increases, it faces growing pressure to reconsider. The protests have shown that public anger is running high, and it remains to be seen whether the government will be able to weather the storm.

title: Sir Philip Green drops 'gagging' legal action
text: Sir Philip Green drops 'gagging' legal action Sir Philip Green has dropped his legal action against the Daily Telegraph newspaper over an article that accused him of sexual harassment and racial abuse. The billionaire businessman had taken legal action against the newspaper and one of its journalists over the article, which was published in October 2018. But on Monday, Green's lawyers told the High Court in London that he was discontinuing the action. The Telegraph had reported that Green had been accused of sexual harassment and racial abuse by five women. The newspaper also alleged that Green had used non-disclosure agreements (NDAs) to silence his accusers. Green has denied the allegations and said that he will not be silenced. In a statement, Green's lawyers said: "Sir Philip Green has decided to discontinue his claim against the Telegraph and its journalist. "Sir Philip maintains that the allegations made against him are untrue and that he has not engaged in any wrongdoing. "However, Sir Philip has taken the decision to discontinue his claim in order to focus on his business and his family." The Telegraph said in a statement: "We are pleased that Sir Philip Green has dropped his legal action. "We stand by our story and we are confident that we would have been successful in defending our case in court." The decision to drop the legal action comes after a number of high-profile cases involving NDAs. In 2018, the former head of Harvey Weinstein's film studio, Harvey Weinstein, was accused of sexual harassment and assault by dozens of women. Weinstein has denied the allegations but has since been charged with rape and sexual assault. In the wake of the Weinstein scandal, a number of Hollywood actresses have spoken out about the use of NDAs to silence victims of sexual harassment and assault. In the UK, the government has launched a review of NDAs and their use in cases of sexual harassment and discrimination. The review is being led by the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and is due to report back in early 2020. The EHRC has said that it will consider whether NDAs are being used to prevent victims of sexual harassment and discrimination from speaking out. The review will also consider whether NDAs are being used to protect the reputations of powerful individuals and organisations.

title: Bombardier ruling: Q&A
text: Bombardier ruling: Q&A What is the Bombardier ruling? The Bombardier ruling is a decision by the World Trade Organization (WTO) that Canada provided illegal subsidies to Bombardier, a Canadian aircraft manufacturer. The ruling allows Boeing, an American aircraft manufacturer, to impose tariffs on Bombardier's planes. What is the background to the ruling? Boeing filed a complaint with the WTO in 2017, alleging that Canada had provided Bombardier with illegal subsidies. Canada denied the allegations, but the WTO ruled in Boeing's favor in 2020. What are the consequences of the ruling? The ruling allows Boeing to impose tariffs of up to 219% on Bombardier's C Series planes. This could make it very difficult for Bombardier to sell its planes in the United States. What is the Canadian government's response to the ruling? The Canadian government has said that it is "deeply disappointed" by the ruling. The government is considering appealing the ruling to the WTO's appellate body. What is the impact of the ruling on the Canadian aerospace industry? The ruling is a major blow to the Canadian aerospace industry. Bombardier is one of Canada's largest aerospace companies, and the tariffs could make it difficult for the company to compete with its rivals. What is the impact of the ruling on the US aerospace industry? The ruling could benefit the US aerospace industry. Boeing is one of the world's largest aircraft manufacturers, and the tariffs could make it more difficult for Bombardier to compete with Boeing in the US market. What is the likely next step?
