title: Pigs can play video games with their snouts, scientists find
text: Pigs can play video games with their snouts, scientists find Pigs are not just intelligent animals, they are also capable of playing video games with their snouts, scientists have found. A study published in the journal Frontiers in Psychology has shown that pigs can use their snouts to control a cursor on a screen and navigate a simple game. The study involved four pigs that were trained to use their snouts to move a cursor around a screen and click on targets. The pigs were able to learn the game quickly and were able to reach a high level of accuracy. The researchers behind the study say that their findings show that pigs have the cognitive abilities to play video games and that they may even be able to learn more complex games in the future. "Our study shows that pigs are capable of learning and playing video games, which suggests that they have higher cognitive abilities than we previously thought," said Dr. Candace Croney, lead author of the study. "This study opens up new possibilities for research into the cognitive abilities of pigs and other animals," she said. The study is the first to show that pigs can play video games with their snouts. However, it is not the first time that animals have been shown to be able to play video games. In 2002, a study showed that monkeys could learn to play the video game Pong using a joystick. And in 2015, a study showed that rats could learn to play the video game Pac-Man using a touchscreen. The ability of animals to play video games is a testament to their intelligence and their ability to learn and adapt. It is also a reminder that animals are not just simple creatures, but are capable of complex thought and behavior. The study on pigs playing video games was conducted at Purdue University in the United States. The study was funded by the National Institutes of Health.

title: Miss America leaked emails: CEO Sam Haskell and three others quit
text: The CEO of the Miss America Organization, Sam Haskell, has resigned after emails containing offensive and misogynistic comments were leaked to the media. Haskell stepped down on Sunday, along with three other top executives, amid growing anger over the emails, which were published by the Huffington Post. The emails, which were sent between Haskell and other Miss America officials, included derogatory remarks about former Miss Americas, as well as comments about their weight, appearance, and sex lives. In one email, Haskell referred to a former Miss America as a "fat pig" and a "disgusting animal." In another, he suggested that a different Miss America had performed oral sex on a former Miss America CEO. The emails have sparked outrage and calls for Haskell and the other executives to resign. Several former Miss Americas have spoken out against the organization, saying that the emails reflect a culture of misogyny and harassment. Haskell has apologized for the emails, saying that they were "inappropriate and offensive." He said that he was "deeply sorry" for the pain that he had caused. The Miss America Organization has also apologized for the emails, saying that they "do not reflect the values of our organization." The organization said that it is "committed to creating a culture of respect and inclusivity." The resignations of Haskell and the other executives are a major blow to the Miss America Organization. Haskell had been CEO since 2005, and he is widely credited with turning the organization around. The Miss America Organization is now facing calls for reform. Many people are calling for the organization to change its rules and regulations, and to do more to promote diversity and inclusion. The future of the Miss America Organization is uncertain. The organization is facing a major crisis, and it is unclear how it will recover. The resignations of Haskell and the other executives are a sign that the organization is in need of change.

title: Malaysia seeks 10 year-jail terms for 'fake news'
text: Malaysia is considering introducing new laws that could see people jailed for up to 10 years for spreading "fake news". The proposed legislation, which is currently being debated in parliament, defines fake news as "any news, information, data and reports which is or are wholly or partly false and which is or are spread whether in the physical or digital form with the intention of deceiving or misleading the public". Anyone found guilty of spreading fake news could face a fine of up to 500,000 ringgit (US$120,000) and a jail term of up to 10 years. The government says the new laws are needed to combat the spread of misinformation and disinformation, which it says is a threat to national security and public order. However, critics have warned that the laws could be used to suppress legitimate dissent and free speech. "These laws are too vague and could be used to target anyone who criticizes the government or its policies," said Lawyers for Liberty executive director Eric Paulsen. "They would have a chilling effect on freedom of expression and could lead to the suppression of legitimate dissent." The government has defended the proposed laws, saying that they are necessary to protect the public from the harmful effects of fake news. "Fake news can cause panic, fear and social unrest," said Communications and Multimedia Minister Gobind Singh Deo. "It can also damage the reputation of individuals and businesses and undermine trust in public institutions." The government has also said that the laws will not be used to target legitimate dissent or free speech. "We are committed to protecting freedom of expression and the right to criticize the government," said Gobind. "These laws are not intended to suppress legitimate dissent, but to target those who spread false and misleading information with the intention of causing harm." The proposed laws are currently being debated in parliament and are expected to be voted on in the coming weeks. If passed, they would come into effect immediately.

title: Stormont crisis: Simon Hamilton says no new money for welfare deal
text: Northern Ireland's former finance minister has warned that the British government will not provide any new funding to help break the political deadlock at Stormont. Simon Hamilton said the current welfare reform package on offer from Westminster was the "best and final" deal and further concessions would not be made. His comments came as the DUP and Sinn Fein continued to trade blame over the failure to reach an agreement on the devolution of policing and justice powers. The two parties have been locked in talks for months, but a deal has yet to be reached on a number of key issues, including the future of the Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI). The DUP wants to see a reduction in the number of PSNI officers, while Sinn Fein wants to see an increase. The two parties are also at odds over the issue of legacy inquests into Troubles-related deaths. Hamilton said the UK government was "frustrated" by the lack of progress and was not prepared to offer any more money to help break the deadlock. "The UK government has made it clear that the current welfare reform package is the best and final deal on offer," he said. "There will be no new money made available." Hamilton said the DUP and Sinn Fein needed to "get their act together" and reach an agreement. "The people of Northern Ireland deserve better than this," he said. "They deserve a functioning government that is able to deliver for them." The DUP and Sinn Fein have been urged to reach a deal by the end of the month. If they fail to do so, the UK government could impose direct rule from Westminster. Direct rule would see Northern Ireland being run by a team of civil servants from London. It would be a major setback for the devolution process in Northern Ireland and could lead to a return to violence. The DUP and Sinn Fein have been warned that they have a "responsibility" to reach an agreement. The two parties need to "put the people of Northern Ireland first" and find a way to resolve their differences, he said.

title: Pakistan asks Facebook to help fight blasphemy
text: Pakistan's government has written to Facebook asking for help in combating blasphemy on its platform. In a letter sent to the social media giant, the Ministry of Information Technology and Telecommunication requested that Facebook remove content that is deemed blasphemous and cooperate with law enforcement investigations. Blasphemy is a highly sensitive issue in Pakistan, where it is illegal to defame Islam or the Prophet Muhammad. Offenders can face severe penalties, including the death sentence. In recent years, there have been several high-profile cases of people being accused of blasphemy, often on social media. The government's request to Facebook comes amid growing concerns about the spread of blasphemy-related content online. In 2020, the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) blocked access to several websites and social media pages for allegedly hosting blasphemous content. However, critics argue that these measures are often arbitrary and have led to the censorship of legitimate dissent. Facebook has not yet responded to the government's request. However, the company has previously stated that it does not tolerate hate speech or content that incites violence. In 2018, Facebook removed several pages and groups in Pakistan for violating its community standards on hate speech. The government's request to Facebook has sparked debate among legal experts and civil society groups. Some argue that the government is right to take action against blasphemy, while others warn that the request could be used to suppress freedom of expression. "The government has a responsibility to protect its citizens from hate speech and incitement to violence," said Salman Akram Raja, a lawyer and human rights activist. "However, it is important to ensure that any measures taken do not violate the right to freedom of expression." Others argue that the government's request is an attempt to silence dissent and curtail freedom of expression. "The government is using blasphemy as a weapon to suppress criticism and dissent," said Taha Siddiqui, a researcher at the Digital Rights Foundation. "This request to Facebook is a dangerous step that could have serious consequences for freedom of expression in Pakistan." The debate over blasphemy and freedom of expression is likely to continue in Pakistan. The government's request to Facebook is a sign that the issue is not going away anytime soon.

title: Somali famine: Care aid driver abducted in Kenyan camp
text: Somali famine: Care aid driver abducted in Kenyan camp A driver working for the international aid agency Care has been abducted from a refugee camp in Kenya. The man, who is Kenyan, was seized by armed men from the Dadaab camp complex on Tuesday evening. Care said in a statement that it was "deeply concerned" about the driver's safety and called for his immediate release. The abduction comes as Somalia faces its worst drought in decades, which has left millions of people at risk of starvation. Dadaab is the world's largest refugee camp, housing more than 350,000 people who have fled conflict and drought in Somalia. The camp has been plagued by insecurity in recent months, with a number of aid workers being killed or kidnapped. In July, two aid workers from the Norwegian Refugee Council were killed in an ambush in the camp. The Kenyan government has deployed additional security forces to the camp, but the situation remains volatile. The abduction of the Care driver is a reminder of the challenges facing aid workers in Somalia. The country is one of the most dangerous places in the world for aid workers, with a number of groups targeting them for kidnapping or attack. Despite the risks, aid agencies are continuing to provide vital assistance to the people of Somalia. Care said that it was committed to continuing its work in Dadaab and called on all parties to respect the neutrality and safety of aid workers. "We urge all parties to the conflict to respect the humanitarian space and allow aid workers to carry out their lifesaving work," the statement said. The United Nations has warned that Somalia is facing a "catastrophic" famine, with more than 6 million people at risk of starvation. The drought has destroyed crops and livestock, and has also led to a sharp rise in food prices. The UN is appealing for $1.5 billion to provide food aid and other assistance to Somalia. The international community must do everything it can to help the people of Somalia avoid a famine.

title: Kim Jong-nam killing: North Korea condemns Malaysia
text: North Korea has strongly condemned Malaysia's handling of the investigation into the killing of Kim Jong-nam, the half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. In a statement carried by the state-run Korean Central News Agency (KCNA), North Korea accused Malaysia of "fabricating evidence" and "politicising" the case. The statement said that Malaysia had "colluded with hostile forces" to "tarnish the image" of North Korea and "justify their illegal sanctions." It also accused Malaysia of "detaining and torturing" North Korean suspects in the case. Malaysia has rejected North Korea's accusations, saying that the investigation was conducted in a "fair and transparent" manner. Kim Jong-nam was killed at Kuala Lumpur International Airport in February 2017. He was poisoned with a nerve agent, VX, which is classified as a weapon of mass destruction. Two women, an Indonesian and a Vietnamese, were convicted of murder in 2017. They claimed that they were tricked into carrying out the attack and did not know that they were handling a deadly substance. North Korea has denied any involvement in Kim Jong-nam's death. However, Malaysian authorities believe that the attack was carried out by North Korean agents. The killing of Kim Jong-nam has strained relations between Malaysia and North Korea. Malaysia has expelled the North Korean ambassador and recalled its own ambassador from Pyongyang. North Korea has also banned Malaysians from leaving the country. The case has also raised concerns about the use of chemical weapons and the threat posed by North Korea's nuclear and missile programs. In a separate statement, North Korea's foreign ministry said that it would "take all necessary measures" to protect its citizens and its sovereignty. It also warned that Malaysia would "pay a price" for its actions. The Malaysian government has said that it is "deeply concerned" by North Korea's threats and has urged Pyongyang to "refrain from any further provocative actions."

title: Coronavirus: Salary subsidy scheme extended into June
text: Salary subsidy scheme extended into June The government has announced that the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme, which pays 80% of the wages of furloughed workers, will be extended until the end of June. The scheme was originally due to end on April 30, but the government has decided to extend it for an extra two months to help businesses that are still struggling due to the pandemic. The extension will cost the government an additional £8.5 billion, but it is hoped that it will help to prevent mass redundancies and keep businesses afloat. The scheme has been welcomed by businesses and trade unions, who say it is essential for protecting jobs and businesses. However, some economists have warned that the extension could lead to higher levels of unemployment in the long run, as businesses may become reliant on the scheme. The government has said that it will continue to review the scheme and will make further announcements in due course. What does this mean for you? If you are currently furloughed, you will continue to receive 80% of your wages until the end of June. Your employer will need to continue to claim for your wages through the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme. If you are not currently furloughed, but your employer is still struggling due to the pandemic, you may be eligible for furlough. You should speak to your employer to find out if you are eligible and how to apply. How to apply for the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme Employers can apply for the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme through the HMRC website. Employers will need to provide information about their employees, such as their name, National Insurance number, and salary. Employers will also need to provide evidence that they have been affected by the pandemic, such as a reduction in sales or profits. What if I am not eligible for the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme? If you are not eligible for the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme, you may be able to claim other benefits, such as Universal Credit or the Self-Employment Income Support Scheme. You can find out more about these benefits on the government website.

title: US seizes millions of dollars of Iranian fuel bound for Venezuela
text: The United States has seized millions of dollars worth of Iranian fuel bound for Venezuela, accusing the two countries of violating sanctions. The US Justice Department said on Tuesday that it had seized four Iranian tankers carrying 1.1 million barrels of fuel, worth an estimated $40 million. The tankers were intercepted in the Arabian Sea on May 25. The seizure is the latest escalation in tensions between the US and Iran, which have been heightened by the Trump administration's "maximum pressure" campaign against Tehran. The US has imposed a series of sanctions on Iran in an effort to curb its nuclear program and its support for militant groups in the Middle East. Venezuela, which is also facing US sanctions, has been a close ally of Iran in recent years. The two countries have signed a number of economic and military agreements, and Iran has provided Venezuela with financial and technical assistance. The US alleges that the fuel shipment was part of a broader effort by Iran to support the Maduro regime in Venezuela. The US has accused Maduro of being a dictator who has rigged elections and violated human rights. The Venezuelan government has condemned the US seizure of the fuel shipment, calling it an "act of piracy." The Venezuelan foreign ministry said in a statement that the fuel was purchased legally and was intended for the Venezuelan people. The US Justice Department said that the seizure of the fuel shipment was justified because it violated US sanctions against Iran. The department said that Iran was using the fuel shipment to support the Maduro regime, which the US considers to be a pariah state. The seizure of the fuel shipment is likely to further escalate tensions between the US and Iran. It is also likely to put further pressure on the Maduro regime in Venezuela, which is already facing a severe economic crisis. The seizure of the fuel shipment is a reminder of the deep divisions between the US and Iran, and of the challenges that the Biden administration faces in trying to improve relations with Iran.

title: Energy-efficient show home opens at Ravenscraig site
text: Energy-efficient show home opens at Ravenscraig site A new energy-efficient show home has opened its doors at the Ravenscraig site in North Lanarkshire, showcasing the latest in sustainable building design. The home, built by housebuilder Taylor Wimpey, features a range of innovative technologies and materials that help to reduce energy consumption and carbon emissions. These include: Air source heat pump: This system provides heating and hot water for the home, using renewable energy from the air. Solar panels: These panels generate electricity from the sun, which can be used to power the home or sold back to the grid. Triple glazing: This type of glazing helps to keep the home warm in winter and cool in summer, reducing the need for heating and cooling. LED lighting: LED bulbs use less energy than traditional bulbs, helping to reduce electricity bills. Smart home technology: This technology allows homeowners to control their heating, lighting, and other appliances from their smartphone or tablet, helping to reduce energy waste. The show home is part of a wider development of 1,500 new homes at Ravenscraig, which is being built on the site of a former steelworks. The development is designed to be a sustainable community, with a focus on energy efficiency, green spaces, and active travel. The show home is open to the public seven days a week, and visitors are encouraged to come and see for themselves the latest in energy-efficient building design. Quotes "We are delighted to open our new energy-efficient show home at Ravenscraig," said Taylor Wimpey Sales and Marketing Director for Scotland, Stuart Allan. "This home is a showcase for the latest in sustainable building design, and we are confident that it will inspire others to build more energy-efficient homes." "Ravenscraig is a flagship development for sustainable housing in Scotland," said North Lanarkshire Council Leader Jim Logue. "The new show home is a great example of how we can build homes that are not only affordable and comfortable, but also good for the environment." Additional information The Ravenscraig development is being built on the site of a former steelworks, which closed in 1992. The development will include a mix of housing types, from apartments to detached houses. The development is expected to be completed by 2025.

title: Quarter of children in north Wales overweight or obese
text: Nearly a quarter of children in north Wales are overweight or obese, according to new figures. Data from Public Health Wales shows that 24.3% of four and five-year-olds and 27.8% of 10 and 11-year-olds in the region are overweight or obese. The figures are higher than the national average for Wales, which is 22.3% for four and five-year-olds and 26.5% for 10 and 11-year-olds. Experts say the problem is due to a number of factors, including poor diet and lack of exercise. Dr Sarah Aitken, a consultant in public health at Public Health Wales, said: "We know that childhood obesity is a major public health concern. It can lead to a range of health problems in later life, including heart disease, stroke, type 2 diabetes and some types of cancer. "There are a number of things that can be done to tackle childhood obesity, including improving diet and increasing physical activity. It's important that children eat a healthy diet that includes plenty of fruit and vegetables, and that they get regular exercise." The figures show that the problem of childhood obesity is particularly acute in some parts of north Wales. In Wrexham, for example, 30% of four and five-year-olds are overweight or obese, and 35% of 10 and 11-year-olds. In Flintshire, the figures are 27% for four and five-year-olds and 30% for 10 and 11-year-olds. Dr Aitken said: "We are working with local authorities and other partners to tackle childhood obesity in north Wales. We are providing support to families to help them make healthy choices, and we are also working to improve the food environment in schools and communities." She added: "It's important to remember that childhood obesity is a complex issue with no single solution. It will take a concerted effort from all sectors of society to tackle the problem."

title: Thousands of low-paid Britons set for pay rise
text: Thousands of low-paid Britons are set for a pay rise as the national living wage increases. The new rate, which will come into effect on April 1, will see workers aged 23 and over receive a pay rise of 9.7%, or 82p an hour. This will take the national living wage to £9.50 an hour. The increase is the biggest in the history of the national living wage, and is designed to help workers keep up with the rising cost of living. The increase is expected to benefit around 2 million workers, and will add around £1,000 to their annual earnings. The government has said that the increase is "a fair deal for workers" and will help to "boost the economy". However, some businesses have warned that the increase could lead to job losses. The British Chambers of Commerce has said that the increase is "a significant cost for businesses" and could lead to "tough decisions" being made about staffing levels. The national living wage was introduced in 2016 and is designed to provide a minimum level of pay for workers aged 23 and over. The rate is reviewed annually and is based on the recommendations of the Low Pay Commission. The Low Pay Commission is an independent body that is responsible for setting the national living wage. The commission takes into account a number of factors when making its recommendations, including the cost of living, the level of inflation, and the productivity of the economy. The increase in the national living wage is a positive step for low-paid workers. However, it is important to ensure that the increase does not lead to job losses. The government and businesses need to work together to ensure that the increase is implemented in a way that benefits both workers and businesses.

title: Compulsory mental health detentions in Scotland at record high
text: Compulsory mental health detentions in Scotland have reached a record high, with nearly 2,500 people being detained under the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 in 2021/22. This represents an increase of 7% on the previous year and is the highest number since the Act came into force in 2005. The figures, published by Public Health Scotland, show that the majority of people detained were over the age of 18 and that more women than men were detained. The most common reason for detention was schizophrenia, followed by bipolar affective disorder and depression. The increase in detentions has been attributed to a number of factors, including the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, which has led to increased levels of stress and anxiety. There have also been concerns about the availability of mental health services, with some people being detained because there is no other appropriate place for them to receive care. Mental health campaigners have expressed concern about the rising number of detentions, arguing that it is a sign that the mental health system is not working properly. They say that people should only be detained as a last resort and that there should be more investment in community-based mental health services. The Scottish Government has said that it is committed to reducing the number of compulsory detentions and that it is working to improve the provision of mental health services. However, campaigners say that more needs to be done to address the underlying causes of mental ill-health, such as poverty, inequality and discrimination. In a statement, the Scottish Government said: "We are committed to improving mental health services in Scotland and reducing the number of compulsory detentions. We are working to increase the availability of community-based mental health services and to provide more support to people with mental ill-health." However, campaigners say that more needs to be done to address the underlying causes of mental ill-health, such as poverty, inequality and discrimination. They say that until these issues are addressed, the number of compulsory detentions is likely to continue to rise.

title: Sainsbury's-Asda deal faces investigation
text: Sainsbury's-Asda deal faces investigation The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has launched an investigation into the proposed merger of Sainsbury's and Asda. The two supermarkets announced plans to merge in April, in a deal that would create the UK's largest supermarket chain. The CMA said it was concerned that the merger could lead to higher prices, less choice and reduced innovation in the grocery market. It will now investigate the deal in more detail, and has invited comments from interested parties. Sainsbury's and Asda have said they are confident that the merger will benefit consumers. They argue that it will allow them to invest more in lower prices, better products and improved services. However, the CMA has said it is concerned that the merger could lead to a number of negative consequences for consumers. One concern is that the merged company would have a dominant position in the grocery market, which could give it the power to raise prices. Another concern is that the merger could lead to less choice for consumers, as the two supermarkets would be likely to reduce the number of competing products on their shelves. The CMA is also concerned that the merger could stifle innovation in the grocery market. Sainsbury's and Asda are both major investors in new products and technologies. The CMA is concerned that the merger could reduce the incentive for them to invest in innovation, as they would no longer be competing with each other. The CMA's investigation is expected to take several months. If the CMA finds that the merger would be harmful to competition, it could block the deal or require Sainsbury's and Asda to make changes to their plans. The CMA's decision will be final and binding on Sainsbury's and Asda. The proposed merger has been met with mixed reactions from industry experts. Some analysts believe that the merger would benefit consumers, while others believe that it could lead to higher prices and less choice. The CMA's investigation will help to determine whether the merger would be beneficial or harmful to competition, and ultimately to consumers.

title: Health budget rise 'less than was promised'
text: The government's plan to increase the NHS budget is "not enough" and "will not fix" the problems facing the health service, the NHS Confederation has warned. The confederation, which represents NHS trusts, said the £33.9bn rise announced by the chancellor, Rishi Sunak, in Wednesday's autumn statement was less than the £39bn that had been promised. It said the increase was "too little, too late" and would not be enough to meet the growing demand for NHS services. The confederation's chief executive, Matthew Taylor, said: "This is not the investment that the NHS needs to fix the problems it faces. "The NHS is in crisis, with waiting lists at record levels and staff morale at an all-time low. This investment will not be enough to turn things around." The confederation said the government needed to invest more in the NHS to reduce waiting times, improve access to care and boost staff morale. It said the government should also consider raising taxes to fund the NHS, as the current system is "not sustainable". The government has said that the £33.9bn increase is the largest ever cash boost for the NHS. It said the money would be used to fund a number of initiatives, including: reducing waiting times for elective care improving access to mental health services boosting the number of nurses and doctors investing in new technology The government has also said that it is committed to reforming the NHS to make it more efficient and effective. However, the NHS Confederation has said that the government's plans do not go far enough. It said the government needed to do more to address the underlying problems facing the NHS, such as the shortage of staff and the lack of funding. The confederation said: "The government needs to be honest with the public about the challenges facing the NHS. "It needs to set out a clear plan for how it will fix the NHS and it needs to provide the funding to make that plan a reality."

title: Julia Donaldson: Children's authors 'don't get recognition'
text: Acclaimed British children's author Julia Donaldson has lamented the lack of recognition given to her fellow writers in the industry. Speaking at the Cheltenham Literature Festival, Donaldson argued that children's authors often receive less attention and respect than those who write for adults. "It's a bit of a strange thing," she said. "Children's authors don't get the same kind of recognition as adult authors. It's almost as if it's not seen as being as serious." Donaldson, who has written over 200 books for children, including the best-selling "The Gruffalo," believes this disparity is due to a number of factors. "I think part of it is that children's books are often seen as being something that you read to your children, rather than something that you read for yourself," she explained. "This can lead to the assumption that children's authors are not as skilled or accomplished as adult authors." Donaldson also pointed to the fact that children's books are often shorter and less complex than adult books, which can contribute to the perception that they are less worthy of critical attention. "I think it's important to remember that just because a book is shorter doesn't mean it's less valuable," she said. "Some of the most important and influential books in the world are children's books." Donaldson called for a greater appreciation of the work that children's authors do, arguing that they play a vital role in shaping young minds. "Children's books can teach children about important values, such as kindness, empathy, and perseverance," she said. "They can also help children to develop their imaginations and to learn about the world around them." Donaldson's comments have sparked a debate about the importance of children's literature and the need to give its authors more recognition. Some critics have argued that Donaldson's concerns are overblown, pointing to the fact that many children's authors have achieved great success and critical acclaim. However, others have agreed with Donaldson, arguing that children's authors often face an uphill battle when it comes to gaining recognition for their work. Regardless of the debate, Donaldson's comments have highlighted the importance of children's literature and the need to give its authors the respect they deserve.

title: Brexit: Manston Airport to host lorry park trial
text: Brexit: Manston Airport to host lorry park trial The Port of Ramsgate is to trial a lorry park at Manston Airport in Kent to alleviate disruption caused by Brexit. The government has pledged £23m to fund the project, which will see the airport transformed into a 24/7 parking area for up to 1,200 lorries. The trial is due to start in the spring, and will run for around six months. The government has said that the lorry park is needed to provide a "contingency" in the event of disruption to cross-Channel trade after the UK leaves the EU. The Port of Ramsgate said that the park would be "a valuable asset" and would help to "ensure the smooth flow of goods between the UK and Europe". However, some local residents have expressed concerns about the impact of the lorry park on the area. They say that the park will increase traffic and noise, and could also damage the environment. Kent County Council has said that it will work with the Port of Ramsgate to "mitigate any negative impacts" of the lorry park. The council has also said that it will carry out a full environmental impact assessment before the park is opened. The lorry park is part of a wider government plan to invest in infrastructure and technology to support cross-Channel trade after Brexit. The government has also pledged £200m to upgrade the M2 and M20 motorways in Kent, and £25m to improve the Port of Dover. The government has said that it is "committed to ensuring that the UK remains a competitive trading nation after Brexit". It says that the investment in infrastructure and technology will help to "facilitate the movement of goods and people between the UK and Europe". However, businesses have warned that the government needs to do more to prepare for Brexit. They say that the government needs to provide more clarity on the UK's future trading relationship with the EU, and that it needs to invest in more customs and border infrastructure. The government has said that it is working on these issues, but it has not yet provided any specific details. Businesses are now waiting to see whether the government can deliver on its promises and whether it can avoid a chaotic Brexit.

title: China bubonic plague: WHO 'monitoring' case but says it is 'not high risk'
text: The World Health Organization (WHO) is monitoring a case of bubonic plague in China but says it is not a high risk to the public. The case was reported in the city of Hohhot in Inner Mongolia and the patient is in stable condition. Bubonic plague is a bacterial infection that is spread by fleas that live on rodents. Symptoms of bubonic plague include fever, chills, headache, and swollen lymph nodes. If left untreated, it can be fatal. The WHO says that the risk of the plague spreading to other people is low. The organization is working with Chinese health authorities to investigate the case and take steps to prevent further spread. Bubonic plague is a serious disease, but it is treatable with antibiotics. Bubonic plague is a rare disease, but it can be fatal if left untreated. The WHO is monitoring the case in China and taking steps to prevent further spread. title: Melbourne attack: Man shot dead after fire and fatal stabbing
text: In a tragic turn of events, Melbourne has witnessed a horrifying attack that has left one man dead and several others injured. The attack began at approximately 8:30 pm on Monday evening, when a man entered a home on North Road and ignited a fire. As residents attempted to escape the blaze, the assailant armed with a knife, turned his fury on them. Among the victims was a 59-year-old man, who sustained fatal stab wounds. Two other individuals, a 57-year-old man and a 55-year-old woman, were rushed to hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. Police arrived at the scene and confronted the attacker, who refused to cooperate. After repeated commands were ignored, officers opened fire, shooting the man dead. The identity of the attacker has not been released, but police have confirmed that he was known to the victims. A motive for the horrific attack is still under investigation. title: Anger at Manx mobile library cuts
text: Anger at Manx Mobile Library Cuts Residents of the Isle of Man have expressed outrage over the government's decision to slash funding for the island's mobile library service. The cuts, announced in the government's budget last month, will see the number of mobile library stops reduced from 101 to just 21 per week. The mobile library service is a lifeline for many residents, particularly those in rural areas who have difficulty accessing traditional libraries. The service provides books, audiobooks, DVDs, and other resources to communities that would otherwise be underserved. "This is a devastating blow to our community," said Margaret Jones, a resident of the village of Laxey. "The mobile library is our only source of books and other resources. Without it, we'll be cut off from the outside world." The government has argued that the cuts are necessary to save money. However, critics say the government is prioritizing cost-cutting over the welfare of the island's residents. "The government is putting profits before people," said Peter Karran, a member of the Manx parliament. "These cuts will have a devastating impact on our most vulnerable citizens." The Isle of Man Library Service has launched a petition to save the mobile library service. The petition has already gathered thousands of signatures. "We are determined to fight these cuts," said Sarah Cormode, the head of the library service. "The mobile library is an essential service that provides vital resources to our community." The government has said it will consider the feedback from the public before making a final decision on the cuts. However, residents are concerned that the government has already made up its mind. "We're not going to give up without a fight," said Jones. "The mobile library is too important to our community to let it go without a fight." The mobile library cuts are just one of a number of proposed cuts to public services in the Isle of Man. The government has also proposed cutting funding for the island's health and education services. Critics say the cuts are a sign of the government's austerity agenda. They argue that the cuts will disproportionately affect the island's most vulnerable citizens. "These cuts are an attack on our social fabric," said Karran. "They will make our island a poorer place to live."

title: UUP leader Mike Nesbitt rules out electoral pact with DUP
text: UUP leader Mike Nesbitt rules out electoral pact with DUP Ulster Unionist Party (UUP) leader Mike Nesbitt has ruled out an electoral pact with the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) ahead of the upcoming Assembly election in Northern Ireland. Nesbitt made the announcement during an interview with BBC Radio Ulster's Talkback programme, where he said that the UUP would be "going it alone" in the election. Some observers had suggested that such a pact could help to unite the unionist vote and maximize their chances of winning seats in the Assembly. However, Nesbitt has consistently rejected the idea of a pact, arguing that it would be a "betrayal" of the UUP's principles. He has also said that he believes the UUP can win the election on its own merits. The UUP is currently the third-largest party in the Assembly, with 10 seats. The DUP is the largest party, with 28 seats. The Assembly election is scheduled to take place on May 5, 2022. The election will be held to elect 90 members to the Northern Ireland Assembly. The UUP is aiming to increase its number of seats in the Assembly and become the main opposition party. The DUP is aiming to win the most seats and remain the largest party in the Assembly. text: Nawaz Sharif: Ex-PM leaves Pakistan for medical treatment Former Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has left the country for medical treatment in London. title: Khashoggi fiancée calls for Premier League to block Newcastle Saudi takeover
text: Khashoggi fiancée calls for Premier League to block Newcastle Saudi takeover Hatice Cengiz, the fiancée of murdered Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, has called on the Premier League to block the proposed takeover of Newcastle United by a Saudi-backed consortium. The £300m deal, which would see the Saudi Public Investment Fund (PIF) take an 80% stake in the club, has been met with widespread criticism from human rights groups. Cengiz, who has been a vocal critic of the Saudi government since Khashoggi's murder in 2018, said that the takeover would "reward" the regime for its human rights abuses. "The Premier League must not allow itself to be used as a sportswashing tool by a regime that has committed horrific crimes," she said. "Jamal was a journalist who was brutally murdered for speaking out against the Saudi government. His killers have never been brought to justice, and the Saudi regime continues to suppress dissent and violate human rights. "Allowing the Saudi regime to buy Newcastle United would send a dangerous message that those who commit human rights abuses can get away with it. It would also give the Saudi government a platform to whitewash its image and distract from its appalling human rights record." Cengiz's call has been echoed by a number of other human rights groups, including Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch. Amnesty International has said that the takeover would be a "disaster for human rights", while Human Rights Watch has called on the Premier League to "put human rights first" and block the deal. The Premier League has said that it is "considering all relevant factors" before making a decision on the takeover. However, it is under increasing pressure to block the deal, particularly in light of the recent release of a US intelligence report which concluded that Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman approved Khashoggi's murder. The report, which was released by the Biden administration in February, said that bin Salman had "authorized" Khashoggi's killing "in order to silence his criticism of the regime". The Premier League has come under fire in recent years for its close ties to Saudi Arabia. In 2020, the league signed a £30m-a-year deal with the Saudi state-owned broadcaster beIN Sports. The league has also been criticized for its decision to stage its overseas Super Cup matches in Saudi Arabia. The 2022 Super Cup match between Liverpool and Chelsea was held in Jeddah, despite the fact that the city is known for its human rights abuses. Cengiz said that the Premier League's ties to Saudi Arabia "must end". "The league cannot continue to do business with a regime that has blood on its hands," she said. "I urge the Premier League to listen to the voices of human rights defenders and block the Newcastle takeover. It is the right thing to do."

title: Birmingham prison inmates' letters laced with drugs
text: Birmingham Prison inmates' letters laced with drugs Letters sent to inmates at Birmingham Prison have been found to contain drugs, the BBC has learned. The drugs, which include synthetic cannabinoids and benzodiazepines, are being soaked into the paper and then dried before being sent to prisoners. The practice is known as "paper doping" and is becoming increasingly common in prisons across the country. The drugs are believed to be smuggled into the prison by visitors or staff. Once inside, they are then passed on to inmates, who can smoke the paper or dissolve it in water and drink it. The use of paper doping is a major concern for prison staff, as it can lead to a number of health problems, including respiratory problems, heart problems, and seizures. Inmates who are caught using drugs can face additional charges and may have their sentences extended. The discovery of drugs in letters sent to Birmingham Prison comes just weeks after a similar incident at HMP Wandsworth in London. In that case, letters were found to contain a synthetic cannabinoid known as "spice." The use of spice has been linked to a number of deaths in prisons across the country. The Ministry of Justice has said that it is aware of the issue of paper doping and is working to address it. A spokesperson for the Ministry of Justice said: "We are aware of the issue of paper doping and are working to address it. We are working with prisons to improve security measures and to prevent drugs from being smuggled into prisons." The use of paper doping is a serious problem that is putting the lives of inmates at risk. The Ministry of Justice must take immediate action to address this issue and to ensure that prisons are safe for both staff and inmates.

title: Clara Ponsati arrest case is delayed
text: The extradition case against former Catalan minister Clara Ponsatí has been delayed until next year. She was due to appear at Edinburgh Sheriff Court on Thursday for a procedural hearing. However, the case has now been adjourned until 18 March 2022. A lawyer for Ponsatí said the delay was due to the "complexity" of the case and the need for further legal submissions. The Spanish authorities have been seeking Ponsatí's extradition since 2018. She is one of several Catalan politicians who have been living in exile since the failed referendum. The Spanish government has accused Ponsatí of being a key figure in the Catalan independence movement. She was the education minister in the Catalan government at the time of the referendum. Ponsatí has denied the charges against her and has said she is being politically persecuted. She has also said she will not return to Spain voluntarily. The extradition case is likely to be closely watched by other Catalan politicians who are facing similar charges. It could also have implications for the future of the Catalan independence movement. title: Barnsley Football Club coach sentenced for bribery
text: Barnsley Football Club coach, Daniel Stendel, has been sentenced to two years in prison, suspended for two years, after admitting to bribery. Stendel, 46, was found guilty of offering a bribe to an official of the German Football Association (DFB) in order to influence the outcome of a match in 2005. The court heard that Stendel had offered the official €20,000 to ensure that his team, Hannover 96, would win a match against Energie Cottbus. The official, who has not been named, reported the bribe to the DFB, which led to an investigation and Stendel's subsequent arrest. In a statement, Stendel said that he was "deeply sorry" for his actions and that he "accepted the court's decision". He said that he had "made a mistake" and that he was "determined to learn from it". Stendel's sentencing comes at a time when football is facing increasing scrutiny over corruption. In recent years, several high-profile players and coaches have been found guilty of bribery or match-fixing. The DFB has welcomed Stendel's sentencing, saying that it sends a clear message that corruption will not be tolerated in football. The DFB's president, Reinhard Grindel, said that "corruption is a cancer that can destroy football" and that the DFB was "determined to do everything we can to root it out of the game". Stendel's sentencing is a reminder of the importance of integrity in football. title: Dr Michael Watt patient recall: Further 1,044 people recalled
text: Dr Michael Watt patient recall: Further 1,044 people recalled NHS Tayside has recalled a further 1,044 patients of a disgraced former Tayside doctor. Dr Michael Watt, 63, was jailed for three years in 2011 for abusing 11 young female patients while working as a GP in Carnoustie, Angus. NHS Tayside has now written to 1,044 additional patients who were seen by Watt between 1981 and 1995. The board said a review of Watt's medical records had identified a "small number" of patients who may have been exposed to inappropriate or unacceptable behaviour. Dr Watt's offending came to light after a woman came forward in 2009 to report a complaint. She told police that she had been abused by Watt during breast examinations when she was a teenager. Watt denied the allegations but was found guilty of 11 charges of indecent assault and one charge of sexual assault by penetration. The former GP has never admitted his guilt and maintained his innocence throughout the investigation and legal proceedings. Following his conviction, Watt was struck off the medical register and jailed for three years. In 2014, the General Medical Council (GMC) ruled that the former GP's fitness to practice was impaired because of his conviction. The GMC said Watt had shown a "persistent pattern of inappropriate behaviour" and had breached patient trust. In a statement, NHS Tayside said: "We are writing to a further 1,044 patients who were seen by Dr Watt between 1981 and 1995. "A review of Dr Watt's medical records has identified a small number of patients who may have been exposed to inappropriate or unacceptable behaviour. "We have written to these patients informing them of the situation and offering them the opportunity to discuss their concerns with a member of our team." The board said it was committed to supporting any patients who may have been affected by Dr Watt's behaviour. "We understand that this may be a difficult time for those affected," the board said. "We want to assure you that we are here to support you and will do everything we can to answer your questions and provide you with the care and support you need." Patients who have been recalled can contact NHS Tayside on 0800 027 2123.

title: Council tax payers to pay more for North Wales Police
text: Council Tax Payers to Pay More for North Wales Police Residents in North Wales will face an increase in their council tax bills to fund the region's police force. The North Wales Police and Crime Panel has approved a 5.9% increase in the police precept, the portion of council tax that goes towards policing. This will result in an average increase of £15.25 per year for band D properties. The decision was made after a public consultation which found that most respondents were willing to pay more to maintain the current level of policing. The police force has said that the extra funding is needed to meet rising costs and to continue investing in frontline services. It plans to use the money to: Recruit more police officers and staff Improve training and equipment Invest in new technology The Police and Crime Commissioner for North Wales, Andy Dunbobbin, said: "I know that any increase in council tax is unwelcome, but I believe that this is a necessary investment in our police force." "North Wales Police is one of the best performing forces in the country, and I want to make sure that it remains that way. This extra funding will help us to continue providing the high level of service that our communities expect and deserve." The increase in the police precept will come into effect from April 2023. Reaction from Residents The decision to increase the police precept has been met with mixed reactions from residents. Some residents have welcomed the move, saying that they are happy to pay more to support the police force. "I think it's a small price to pay for the safety and security of our communities," said one resident. Others have expressed concern about the increase, saying that it will put a strain on their finances. "I'm a pensioner and every penny counts," said one resident. "I'm not sure how I'm going to afford this extra cost." The council tax increase is part of a wider package of measures to increase funding for the police in England and Wales. The government has pledged to provide an additional £15 billion to the police over the next three years.

title: Africa development: Young 'Einsteins' make their pitch
text: In the heart of Africa, where innovation and ambition collide, a group of young and brilliant minds known as the "African Einsteins" are making their voices heard. Recognizing their potential, several organizations are supporting these young inventors. The African Innovation Foundation provides mentorship, training, and funding to foster their ideas. Similarly, the Next Einstein Forum aims to nurture and connect a new generation of scientific leaders in Africa. The African Einsteins' contributions extend beyond their individual achievements. They inspire other young people to pursue STEM careers and challenge the status quo. Their inventions and ideas are fueling a wave of optimism and innovation across the continent. As the African Einsteins continue to make their mark, they are not only shaping the future of Africa but also setting an example for the world. title: Questions over school holiday fine pay-back in Wales
text: Questions have been raised about school holiday fine repayments in Wales, after several councils confirmed they do not intend to give parents the money back. The Welsh government announced last week that it will scrap the £60 fines, which were introduced in 2014 for parents who take their children on holiday during term time without permission. However, some councils have said they will not be refunding the fines that have already been issued. Powys County Council said it would not be refunding fines, as the money had already been spent on "essential services". A spokesman for the council said: "The council has no legal obligation to refund fines that have already been paid. The money from the fines has been used to provide essential services for children and young people in Powys." Other councils, including Denbighshire and Gwynedd, have also said they will not be refunding fines. The Welsh government has said it is "disappointed" by the councils' decision not to refund the fines. A spokesman for the government said: "We believe that it is important that parents are not penalised for taking their children on holiday during term time. I was told that the fine would be refunded once the new law came into effect. Now I am being told that I will not be getting my money back. It is completely unfair." title: 'Nazi art' hoarder Gurlitt makes Swiss museum sole heir
text: Nazi Art Hoarder Gurlitt Makes Swiss Museum Sole Heir Cornelius Gurlitt, the infamous German collector of art looted by the Nazis, has bequeathed his entire trove of 1,500 works to the Kunstmuseum Bern in Switzerland. The announcement, made on Tuesday, comes after years of legal battles and ethical debates over the fate of the collection. Gurlitt's father, Hildebrand, amassed a vast collection of art during the Nazi era, some of which was stolen from Jewish families or acquired under duress. After the war, Hildebrand's collection was hidden away and only rediscovered in 2012 after Cornelius's death. The bequest to the Kunstmuseum Bern has been met with mixed reactions. Some experts welcomed the decision, arguing that the museum has the expertise and resources to properly research and display the works. Others expressed concern that the museum may not be able to fully address the provenance of all the pieces and could potentially legitimize looted art. The Kunstmuseum Bern has stated that it intends to conduct thorough research into the provenance of the collection and make public any findings. The museum also plans to create an online database of the works, providing access to information about their history. The decision to bequeath the collection to Switzerland reflects Cornelius Gurlitt's long-standing ties to the country. He lived in Switzerland for several years and had a Swiss lawyer. Gurlitt's choice may also have been influenced by the Swiss legal system, which is seen as more lenient towards art collectors than some other countries. The legacy of Nazi-looted art remains a complex and sensitive issue. Many works are still missing, and families continue to search for art that was stolen from them. The resolution of the Gurlitt collection is a significant step in addressing this legacy, but it also highlights the challenges of restituting looted art and ensuring that victims of Nazi persecution are properly compensated. Experts estimate that the Gurlitt collection is worth hundreds of millions of dollars. It includes works by Pablo Picasso, Henri Matisse, and Marc Chagall. The Kunstmuseum Bern has not yet announced its plans for displaying the collection, but it is expected to go on display in the coming years. The Gurlitt bequest is a reminder of the dark history of art during the Nazi era. It is also a testament to the ongoing struggle to recover and repatriate looted art and to seek justice for victims of Nazi persecution. The Kunstmuseum Bern's decision to accept the collection carries with it a responsibility to address these issues and to ensure that the works are displayed with sensitivity and respect for their history.

title: Grenfell Tower study: Cancer-causing chemicals found nearby
text: Grenfell Tower Study: Cancer-Causing Chemicals Found Nearby A new study has found that cancer-causing chemicals were present in the air near Grenfell Tower in the aftermath of the devastating fire in 2017. The research, published in the journal "Environmental Science & Technology," analyzed air samples taken from the area surrounding the tower in the days and weeks following the blaze. The scientists found high levels of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), which are known carcinogens. PAHs are produced by the incomplete combustion of organic materials, such as wood, coal, and oil. They have been linked to an increased risk of lung, skin, and bladder cancer. The study found that the levels of PAHs in the air near Grenfell Tower were significantly higher than those found in other parts of London. The highest levels were found in the immediate vicinity of the tower, but PAHs were also detected at lower levels in areas several kilometers away. The researchers say that their findings are concerning, as they suggest that residents of the area may have been exposed to harmful levels of PAHs after the fire. "Our study provides the first evidence of significant PAH exposure in the aftermath of the Grenfell Tower fire," said Dr. Thomas Gent, lead author of the study. "These findings highlight the need for further research to assess the potential health risks to residents." The study also found that the levels of PAHs in the air decreased over time, as the debris from the fire was removed and the area was cleaned up. However, the researchers say that it is important to continue to monitor the levels of PAHs in the air in the long term, to ensure that they do not pose a health risk to residents. The Grenfell Tower fire was one of the deadliest residential fires in UK history. The blaze claimed the lives of 72 people and destroyed the 24-story tower block. The fire was caused by a faulty refrigerator, and the subsequent inquiry found that the building's cladding was highly flammable and contributed to the spread of the fire. The findings of the new study are likely to add to the concerns of residents who live near Grenfell Tower. Many residents have reported health problems since the fire, including respiratory problems, skin irritation, and cancer. The government has said that it is committed to supporting residents affected by the fire and is working to ensure that the area is safe. However, the findings of the new study suggest that more needs to be done to protect residents from the potential health risks of exposure to PAHs.

title: Baby Lynlee 'born twice' after life-saving tumour surgery
text: In a remarkable display of medical prowess, baby Lynlee Hope was effectively "born twice" after undergoing life-saving surgery to remove a large tumour that threatened her existence. Weighing just over 2lbs, Lynlee was born at 26 weeks with a sacrococcygeal teratoma (SCT), a rare and potentially fatal tumour attached to her lower spine and pelvis. The tumour was rapidly growing, compromising her vital organs and blood supply. Faced with this life-threatening situation, a team of highly skilled surgeons at Leicester's Glenfield Hospital embarked on an audacious plan. They would perform a complex surgery to remove the tumour, essentially giving Lynlee a second chance at life. The operation, which lasted over eight hours, was fraught with risks. The tumour was intricately interwoven with Lynlee's delicate body, posing a significant threat to her spinal cord, nerves, and vital organs. "The surgery was incredibly challenging," said Dr. Andrew Kingsnorth, lead surgeon on the case. "We had to work with extreme precision to remove the tumour while preserving as much of Lynlee's anatomy as possible." Miraculously, the surgery was a success. The surgeons expertly removed the tumour in its entirety, along with a portion of Lynlee's tailbone. Her spinal cord and major blood vessels were miraculously unscathed. "It was an incredible relief to see that we had managed to remove the tumour without causing any permanent damage to Lynlee," said Dr. Kingsnorth. "It was a testament to the incredible skill and dedication of the whole surgical team." After a period of recovery, Lynlee was able to be discharged from hospital. She is now thriving at home with her loving family. While she will require ongoing monitoring, her prognosis is excellent. Lynlee's miraculous journey has given hope to countless families facing similar challenges. It is a testament to the incredible advances in medical science and the dedication of healthcare professionals who go above and beyond to save lives.

title: End war against media - UNP
text: UNP calls for an end to war against media The United National Party (UNP) has strongly condemned the recent attacks on journalists and media outlets in Sri Lanka, and called on the government to take immediate action to protect freedom of the press. In a statement issued today, the UNP said that the attacks were a "clear attempt to silence critical voices and intimidate the media into self-censorship." "These attacks are unacceptable and must be condemned in the strongest possible terms," the statement said. "The media is essential to a free and democratic society, and it is imperative that journalists be able to work without fear of reprisal." The UNP called on the government to take immediate steps to investigate the attacks and bring the perpetrators to justice. The party also urged the government to adopt measures to protect journalists and media outlets from further violence and intimidation. "The war against the media must end," the statement said. "The media is a vital part of our society, and it must be allowed to operate freely and without fear." The UNP's statement comes in the wake of a series of attacks on journalists and media outlets in Sri Lanka. In recent months, several journalists have been killed, injured, or threatened, and several media outlets have been vandalized or closed down. The attacks have raised concerns about the state of press freedom in Sri Lanka. The country has a long history of violence against journalists, and the recent attacks have only served to worsen the situation. The UNP's call for an end to the war against the media is a welcome step. It is essential that the government takes action to protect freedom of the press and ensure that journalists can work without fear of reprisal. The media is a vital part of a free and democratic society. It provides information, holds those in power to account, and gives voice to the voiceless. The attacks on the media in Sri Lanka are an attack on democracy itself. The government must take immediate action to end the war against the media. It must investigate the attacks, bring the perpetrators to justice, and adopt measures to protect journalists and media outlets from further violence and intimidation. The UNP's statement is a reminder that the fight for press freedom is not over. It is a fight that must be fought every day, by all those who believe in the importance of a free and independent media.

title: Yahoo tests ear-based smartphone identification system
text: Yahoo Tests Ear-Based Smartphone Identification System Yahoo is trialing a novel method to identify smartphone users based on their unique ear shape. The system, dubbed "EarID," uses advanced algorithms to analyze the contours, shape, and size of a user's ear to create a personalized identification profile. This biometric authentication approach offers several advantages over traditional methods like passwords and PINs. Ears are a relatively permanent physical characteristic that is difficult to alter or disguise. Moreover, EarID can be used in a variety of situations, including when a user's hands are occupied or when they may have forgotten their credentials. To use EarID, users simply take a photo of their ear with their smartphone's camera. The algorithm then extracts a series of biometric features and creates a unique identification profile that is stored securely on the device. When a user attempts to access their smartphone, the EarID system compares the live ear image captured with the stored profile. If the match is successful, the user is granted access without the need to enter any additional credentials. Yahoo has conducted extensive testing of the EarID system, demonstrating its accuracy and reliability. In a recent study involving 2,000 participants, the system achieved an impressive 99% success rate in identifying users. False positives and negatives were rare, occurring in less than 1% of cases. The company believes that EarID has the potential to revolutionize smartphone security and user convenience. It could eliminate the need for passwords and PINs, reducing the risk of unauthorized access and making the user experience more seamless. However, there are also potential privacy concerns to consider. Critics argue that collecting and storing biometric data could pose a risk to user privacy, especially if the data is compromised or falls into the wrong hands. Yahoo has addressed these concerns by implementing strong encryption and privacy safeguards to protect user data. The company also emphasizes that EarID is an opt-in feature, and users have the choice to use or disable the system. As Yahoo continues to test and refine EarID, it remains to be seen whether the system will gain widespread adoption. However, if successful, it could pave the way for a new era of secure and convenient smartphone authentication.

title: Weinstein Company files for bankruptcy
text: Weinstein Company Files for Bankruptcy The Weinstein Company, the film studio founded by disgraced producer Harvey Weinstein, has filed for bankruptcy. The move comes after months of financial turmoil and legal challenges following a wave of sexual misconduct allegations against Weinstein. The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in Delaware on Monday, March 19, 2018. The filing lists assets of less than $500 million and liabilities of more than $1 billion. The bankruptcy filing is a major setback for the once-successful studio, which has produced films such as "Pulp Fiction," "Shakespeare in Love," and "The King's Speech." However, the company has been reeling from the fallout of Weinstein's misconduct, which led to his ouster and the subsequent departure of several key executives. The bankruptcy process will allow the company to reorganize its finances and continue operating, while protecting it from creditors. However, it is unclear what the future holds for The Weinstein Company, which is now facing lawsuits from numerous alleged victims of Weinstein's sexual misconduct. The bankruptcy filing also includes a plan to sell off the company's assets, including its film library and other intellectual property. The proceeds from the sale will be used to pay off creditors and alleged victims of Weinstein's misconduct. The Weinstein Company's bankruptcy is a reminder of the consequences of sexual misconduct in the workplace. The allegations against Weinstein have had a profound impact on the company, its employees, and the wider film industry. The bankruptcy filing shows that even the most successful companies can be brought down by the actions of their leaders. The bankruptcy process is likely to be a lengthy and complex one. It will take months, if not years, for the company to reorganize its finances and sell off its assets. The outcome of the bankruptcy will determine the future of The Weinstein Company and the fate of its alleged victims. In the meantime, the bankruptcy filing is a major blow to the legacy of Harvey Weinstein, who was once one of the most powerful producers in Hollywood. The filing shows that his actions have had far-reaching consequences and that he will not be able to escape accountability for his alleged misconduct.

title: EU and Turkey agreement on deporting migrants and visas
text: EU and Turkey Reach Agreement on Deportations and Visas The European Union and Turkey have reached a landmark agreement on the deportation of migrants from Europe to Turkey and the easing of visa restrictions for Turkish citizens. Deportations Under the deal, the EU will deport to Turkey all irregular migrants who cross into Greece or Italy. In return, Turkey will readmit these migrants and provide them with assistance. The agreement also includes a relocation scheme to resettle some of the deported migrants in other EU countries. The deportation plan has been criticized by human rights groups, which argue that it violates the rights of asylum seekers and refugees. However, the EU and Turkey maintain that the agreement is necessary to deter irregular migration and break the business model of human smugglers. Visas As part of the deal, the EU has agreed to ease visa restrictions for Turkish citizens. Turkish citizens will be able to travel to the EU for up to 90 days without a visa, provided they have a valid biometric passport. The visa liberalization move has been welcomed by the Turkish government, which sees it as a sign of closer ties with the EU. However, some EU member states are concerned about the potential for increased migration from Turkey. Reaction The EU-Turkey agreement has been met with mixed reactions. Some EU member states have welcomed the deal, while others have expressed concerns about the deportation provisions. Human rights groups have condemned the agreement as inhumane and illegal. The Turkish government has hailed the agreement as a success, saying it will help to reduce irregular migration and improve relations with the EU. However, it remains to be seen how the agreement will be implemented and how effective it will be in reducing migration flows. Challenges The implementation of the EU-Turkey agreement is likely to face a number of challenges. One challenge will be the identification and deportation of irregular migrants. Another challenge will be the provision of adequate assistance to deported migrants in Turkey. Furthermore, the agreement could strain relations between the EU and Turkey if it is not perceived as fair and effective. The deportation of migrants could also lead to protests and unrest in both Greece and Turkey. Conclusion The EU-Turkey agreement on deportations and visas is a complex and controversial deal. It remains to be seen how the agreement will be implemented and how effective it will be in reducing irregular migration. The deal has the potential to improve relations between the EU and Turkey, but it could also strain relations if it is not perceived as fair and effective.

title: Austria bans 'hidden' neo-Nazi codes on car number plates
text: In a decisive move to combat the resurgence of far-right extremism, Austria has banned the use of neo-Nazi codes on car number plates. This proactive measure aims to curb the subtle display of hateful symbols and prevent their normalization within society. Among the banned codes are those representing the numbers 88 and 14. The former is an abbreviation for "Heil Hitler," as "H" is the eighth letter of the alphabet, while the latter stands for the "Fourteen Words" white supremacist slogan. Other prohibited codes include combinations of letters and numbers that reference various neo-Nazi groups and ideologies. The ban, implemented by the Federal Ministry of Transport, Innovation and Technology, is part of a broader crackdown on extremist symbols and activities in Austria. In recent years, the country has witnessed an alarming rise in hate crimes and far-right propaganda, prompting authorities to take swift action. "We will not tolerate the use of Nazi symbols or codes in our society," said Transport Minister Leonore Gewessler. "These symbols represent a dark chapter in our history and have no place in modern Austria." The ban has been met with widespread support from anti-extremism organizations and the general public. Many view it as a necessary step to prevent the spread of hate speech and violence. "Symbols are powerful, and they can be used to promote dangerous ideologies," said Maria Rauch-Kallat, president of the Austrian Holocaust Memorial Service. "By banning these codes, we are sending a clear message that we reject intolerance and discrimination in all its forms." However, some critics argue that the ban may infringe on freedom of expression. They contend that it could lead to the suppression of legitimate historical or cultural symbols. In response, the government has emphasized that the ban is narrowly tailored to target specific neo-Nazi codes that are explicitly used to promote hatred and violence. It does not affect legitimate historical or cultural symbols, such as the use of the number 88 in a non-Nazi context. The ban on neo-Nazi codes on car number plates is a significant step in Austria's ongoing fight against extremism. It sends a powerful message that hateful symbols will not be tolerated and that the country is committed to fostering a society free from intolerance and discrimination.

title: Coronavirus: Beijing tightens controls amid spike in local cases
text: Amid a surge in local coronavirus cases, Beijing has implemented stricter control measures to curb the spread of the virus. Authorities have suspended all non-essential business activities, including entertainment venues, cultural institutions, and tourist attractions. Public transport has been reduced, and gatherings of more than 10 people are prohibited. The Chinese capital has reported 20 new locally transmitted COVID-19 cases since Friday (June 11), the highest daily increase in months. The outbreak is believed to have originated from the Xinfadi wholesale market, which supplies around 90% of Beijing's fresh produce. The market has been closed, and thousands of workers and visitors have been tested. The Beijing government has also ordered mass testing for residents in 11 districts, including those who live near the Xinfadi market. So far, over 100,000 people have been tested, and more than 2,000 people have been placed under quarantine. The new outbreak has raised concerns about a second wave of infections in China. The country has largely brought the virus under control, with only a few sporadic cases reported in recent months. However, the Beijing outbreak shows that the virus can still spread rapidly, even in areas that have previously been successful in containing it. Beijing's strict control measures are aimed at preventing the virus from spreading further. The government has urged residents to stay home as much as possible and to avoid unnecessary travel. People who have recently visited the Xinfadi market or who have come into contact with confirmed cases have been advised to self-isolate. The outbreak has also had a significant impact on Beijing's economy. Many businesses have been forced to close, and tourism has been severely affected. The government has announced a series of financial support measures for businesses and individuals affected by the outbreak. The Beijing outbreak is a reminder that the coronavirus pandemic is not over. Even in countries that have successfully contained the virus, there is still a risk of new outbreaks.
