title: Steel pensions: Decision deadline 'cannot be extended'
text: Steel pensions: Decision deadline 'cannot be extended' The government has said it will not extend the deadline for steelworkers to make a decision on their pensions. The deadline for members of the British Steel Pension Scheme (BSPS) to decide whether to transfer their pension to another scheme or stay in the current scheme is 28 September. The government said it "recognises the challenges" faced by steelworkers, but it is "not possible" to extend the deadline. The decision comes after the government was urged to extend the deadline by the steelworkers' union, Community. Community said that the deadline was "unfair" and that many steelworkers were still waiting for information about their pensions. The union also said that the government had not done enough to help steelworkers understand the options available to them. However, the government said that it had "provided extensive support" to steelworkers, including setting up a dedicated helpline and providing information online. The government also said that it had "engaged with Community and other stakeholders throughout the process". The BSPS is a defined benefit pension scheme, which means that members are guaranteed a certain level of income in retirement. However, the scheme has been in deficit for a number of years, and the government has said that it is not sustainable in its current form. The government has offered steelworkers a choice of two options: Transfer their pension to a new scheme, which would be run by an insurance company. Stay in the current scheme, which would be restructured to make it more sustainable. The government has said that both options are "fair and affordable". However, Community has said that the government's offer is "not good enough" and that it will continue to campaign for a better deal for steelworkers. The deadline for steelworkers to make a decision on their pensions is 28 September.

title: Japan whaling ban welcomed in Australia and New Zealand
text: Japan whaling ban welcomed in Australia and New Zealand The Australian and New Zealand governments have welcomed Japan's decision to end commercial whaling in the Southern Ocean. The decision was announced by Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida at the International Whaling Commission (IWC) meeting in Panama City. Australia's Environment Minister Sussan Ley said the decision was a "significant step forward" for whale conservation. "This is a victory for whales and for all those who have campaigned for their protection," she said. New Zealand's Foreign Minister Nanaia Mahuta said the decision was a "positive outcome" for the whales and for the region. "We have long called for an end to commercial whaling in the Southern Ocean, and we are pleased that Japan has finally agreed to stop," she said. The IWC has been trying to ban commercial whaling since 1986, but Japan has continued to hunt whales under a loophole that allows for "scientific research". However, Japan has faced increasing international pressure to end its whaling program, and the IWC has been considering a proposal to close the loophole. Japan's decision to end commercial whaling is a significant victory for whale conservationists. It is estimated that around 10,000 whales have been killed by Japanese whalers in the Southern Ocean since 1986. The decision is also a boost for the Australian and New Zealand governments, which have been working for many years to end commercial whaling in the region. The Australian and New Zealand governments have both committed to providing financial assistance to Japan to help it transition to non-lethal whale research. The decision is also a victory for the whales themselves. Whales are highly intelligent and social animals, and they play an important role in the marine ecosystem. The end of commercial whaling in the Southern Ocean will help to protect these magnificent creatures and ensure that they can continue to thrive in the region.

title: HIE takes control of CairnGorm Mountain
text: HIE takes control of CairnGorm Mountain CairnGorm Mountain, one of Scotland's most popular tourist destinations, has been taken over by Highlands and Islands Enterprise (HIE), the Scottish government's economic and community development agency. HIE has acquired the mountain and its associated infrastructure, including the funicular railway, from CairnGorm Mountain Ltd, the previous owner. The move comes after the company was placed into administration in October 2022. HIE said it is committed to reopening the mountain for visitors as soon as possible. It is also working with stakeholders to develop a long-term plan for the sustainable development of CairnGorm. The acquisition of CairnGorm Mountain is a significant step for HIE, which has been working closely with the Scottish government and other partners to support the economic and social development of the area. HIE's chief executive, Charlotte Wright, said: "CairnGorm Mountain is a unique and iconic asset for the Highlands and Islands. We are committed to working with stakeholders to ensure that it is reopened for visitors as soon as possible and that it has a sustainable future." The Scottish government's Rural Affairs Minister, Mairi Gougeon, said: "CairnGorm Mountain is a vital part of the Highlands and Islands economy. I am pleased that HIE has taken over the mountain and is working to reopen it for visitors. This is a positive step for the area and I look forward to working with HIE to ensure that CairnGorm has a sustainable future." CairnGorm Mountain is located in the Cairngorms National Park, which is home to some of Scotland's most stunning scenery. The mountain is a popular destination for skiers, snowboarders, hikers, and mountain bikers. The funicular railway, which opened in 2001, takes visitors to the Ptarmigan Station, which is located near the summit of the mountain. The station offers stunning views of the surrounding countryside. HIE said it is working with stakeholders to develop a long-term plan for the sustainable development of CairnGorm. This will include looking at ways to improve the visitor experience, protect the environment, and support the local economy. HIE is also working with the Scottish government to secure funding for the reopening of the mountain. The Scottish government has committed to providing £10 million to support the reopening of CairnGorm. HIE said it is confident that CairnGorm Mountain can be reopened for visitors in the near future. The agency is working with stakeholders to develop a plan that will ensure that the mountain has a sustainable future.

title: AMs' report highlights gaps in muscular dystrophy care
text: Muscular Dystrophy UK: Report finds 'gaps' in care for people with muscular dystrophy A new report by the charity Muscular Dystrophy UK has found "significant gaps" in the care provided to people with muscular dystrophy (MD). The report, which surveyed over 1,000 people with MD and their families, found that many people are not receiving the care and support they need. Some of the key findings of the report include: Delays in diagnosis: Many people with MD experience delays in diagnosis, which can lead to a delay in accessing appropriate care and support. Lack of access to specialist care: Many people with MD do not have access to specialist care, which can lead to a lack of understanding of their condition and its management. Inadequate support for families: Many families of people with MD do not receive adequate support, which can lead to significant stress and financial hardship. The report also found that people with MD are more likely to experience mental health problems, such as anxiety and depression. The report concludes that there is a need for a "step change" in the care provided to people with MD. It calls for a number of improvements, including: Earlier diagnosis: The report calls for earlier diagnosis of MD, so that people can access appropriate care and support as soon as possible. Increased access to specialist care: The report calls for increased access to specialist care for people with MD, so that they can receive the best possible care and support. Improved support for families: The report calls for improved support for families of people with MD, so that they can cope with the challenges of caring for a loved one with MD. The report also calls for more research into MD, so that we can better understand the condition and develop new treatments. Muscular Dystrophy UK is a charity that provides support and information to people with MD and their families. The charity also campaigns for improved care and services for people with MD. Chief executive of Muscular Dystrophy UK, Catherine Woodhead, said: "This report shows that there are significant gaps in the care provided to people with muscular dystrophy. This is unacceptable. People with MD deserve to have access to the best possible care, and we will continue to campaign for improvements."

title: Mitsubishi Motors: How did it falsify its fuel economy data?
text: Mitsubishi Motors: How did it falsify its fuel economy data? In 2016, Mitsubishi Motors admitted to falsifying fuel economy data on four of its minicar models, resulting in a major scandal that tarnished the company's reputation and shook the Japanese auto industry. An investigation revealed a widespread pattern of deception, with employees instructed to manipulate test results to meet government targets for fuel efficiency. How it happened Mitsubishi's fuel economy deception involved two main methods: Engine idling: During fuel economy tests, the vehicles were put into a special "economy mode" that idled the engine more frequently, resulting in artificially inflated fuel efficiency readings. Weight reduction: The vehicles were tested with less weight than specified in the regulations, further improving fuel economy results. These practices were not limited to a few rogue employees but were reportedly sanctioned at high levels within the company. Employees were allegedly pressured to meet ambitious fuel economy targets, leading to a culture of cutting corners and falsifying data. The consequences The scandal had devastating consequences for Mitsubishi Motors: Financial losses: The company incurred billions of dollars in fines, compensation payments, and lost sales. Loss of trust: Mitsubishi's reputation was severely damaged, leading to a loss of consumer confidence and a drop in sales. Criminal charges: Several Mitsubishi executives were arrested and charged with falsifying data, resulting in prison sentences. Aftermath and reforms The Mitsubishi scandal prompted a major overhaul of the company's corporate culture and regulatory oversight in the Japanese auto industry. Mitsubishi implemented stricter internal controls, enhanced employee training, and appointed an independent auditor to monitor fuel economy testing. Government agencies also strengthened regulations and increased oversight of fuel economy tests. The Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association (JAMA) introduced new guidelines for fuel economy testing, including stricter vehicle weighing requirements and more realistic driving conditions. Lessons learned The Mitsubishi scandal highlighted the importance of ethical conduct, transparency, and regulatory compliance in the automotive industry. It demonstrated the risks of cutting corners to meet performance targets and the devastating consequences that can result from manipulating data. The scandal also underscored the need for strong corporate governance and independent oversight to prevent such misconduct from occurring in the future. By implementing comprehensive reforms and strengthening regulations, the industry has taken steps to restore trust and ensure the accuracy and integrity of fuel economy data.

title: NHS: Reform message was screwed up - health minister

title: Boeing 787 Dreamliner: NTSB details battery fire
text: Boeing 787 Dreamliner: NTSB Details Battery Fire The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) has released a new report on the battery fire that caused a Boeing 787 Dreamliner to make an emergency landing in Boston in 2013. The report concludes that the fire was caused by a design flaw in the battery's charging system. The NTSB found that the battery's charging system was not able to regulate the voltage properly, which caused the battery to overheat and catch fire. The report also found that Boeing had not adequately tested the charging system before the plane was put into service. The NTSB's findings are consistent with those of an earlier investigation by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA). In 2014, the FAA ordered all Boeing 787 Dreamliners to be grounded until the battery problem was fixed. Boeing has since redesigned the battery charging system and the planes have been returned to service. The NTSB's report is a reminder of the importance of thorough testing and oversight in the aviation industry. The battery fire on the Boeing 787 Dreamliner could have had catastrophic consequences if it had not been detected and extinguished quickly. The NTSB's report also highlights the need for continued research into battery technology. Lithium-ion batteries are used in a wide range of electronic devices, including laptops, cell phones, and electric cars. As the demand for these devices grows, so too does the need for safe and reliable battery technology. The NTSB's report on the Boeing 787 Dreamliner battery fire is a valuable contribution to the safety of the aviation industry. The report's findings will help to prevent similar accidents from happening in the future. Additional Information from the NTSB Report The battery fire on the Boeing 787 Dreamliner occurred on January 7, 2013. The plane was carrying 182 passengers and crew members. The plane made an emergency landing at Logan International Airport in Boston. No one was injured in the incident. The NTSB's investigation into the battery fire took two years to complete. The NTSB made a number of recommendations to Boeing and the FAA as a result of its investigation.

title: Flat-dwelling children exposed to neighbours' smoke too
text: Flat-dwelling children exposed to neighbours' smoke too When it comes to protecting children from the dangers of secondhand smoke, most parents focus on keeping their own homes smoke-free. But new research suggests that children who live in flats may also be exposed to harmful levels of smoke from neighbouring apartments. The study, published in the journal Pediatrics, found that children who lived in flats were exposed to higher levels of secondhand smoke than those who lived in houses. The researchers believe that this is because smoke can easily seep through the walls and floors of flats, even if the neighbouring apartment is smoke-free. "Our findings suggest that children who live in flats may be at increased risk for exposure to secondhand smoke," said study author Dr. Jonathan Winickoff, a professor of pediatrics at Harvard Medical School. "This is a concern because secondhand smoke exposure has been linked to a number of health problems in children, including respiratory problems, asthma, and sudden infant death syndrome." The study included over 1,000 children between the ages of 6 and 17. The researchers measured the levels of cotinine, a chemical that is produced when nicotine is broken down in the body, in the children's urine. Cotinine levels are a measure of secondhand smoke exposure. The researchers found that children who lived in flats had higher levels of cotinine in their urine than those who lived in houses. The difference in cotinine levels was even greater for children who lived in flats with smokers in the neighbouring apartment. "Our findings suggest that children who live in flats may need to take additional steps to protect themselves from secondhand smoke exposure," said Winickoff. "This could include using air purifiers, closing windows and doors, and avoiding spending time in areas where smoking is allowed." The study is the first to examine the exposure of flat-dwelling children to secondhand smoke from neighbouring apartments. The findings suggest that this is a significant problem that could have a negative impact on the health of children. "Our findings highlight the need for more research on the health effects of secondhand smoke exposure in flat-dwelling children," said Winickoff. "We also need to develop and implement policies to protect these children from secondhand smoke exposure."

title: Romania protests: Thousands hold fresh rallies after clashes
text: Thousands of people have taken to the streets of Bucharest and other Romanian cities to protest for a second day, following violent clashes with police the night before. The demonstrations were sparked by a government decree to decriminalize some forms of corruption, which critics say would allow corrupt politicians to escape justice. On Tuesday night, police used tear gas and water cannon to disperse protesters in Bucharest, injuring dozens of people. Interior Minister Carmen Dan has defended the police's actions, saying that they were necessary to maintain order. However, the violence has only served to further anger protesters, who have vowed to continue demonstrating until the government withdraws the decree. On Wednesday, protesters gathered in Victory Square in central Bucharest, holding Romanian flags and chanting slogans such as "Thieves!" and "Resign!". Similar protests were held in other cities, including Cluj-Napoca, Timisoara, and Iasi. The Romanian government has come under increasing pressure to resign in recent months, following a series of corruption scandals. In October, Prime Minister Sorin Grindeanu was forced to resign after just six months in office, following mass protests against his government's austerity measures. The current government, led by Mihai Tudose, has also been rocked by corruption scandals. In December, the justice minister was forced to resign after being accused of taking bribes. The protests in Romania are the latest in a wave of anti-corruption demonstrations that have swept across Eastern Europe in recent years. In 2015, mass protests in Bulgaria forced the government to resign. And in 2016, similar protests in Slovakia led to the resignation of Prime Minister Robert Fico. The protests in Romania are a sign that people in Eastern Europe are increasingly fed up with corruption and are demanding change.

title: Eurotunnel accused of overcharging train companies
text: The Eurotunnel, the underwater rail link between Britain and France, has been accused of overcharging train companies by up to £30m a year. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has launched an investigation into the company's pricing practices, following a complaint from the Rail Delivery Group (RDG), which represents train operators. The RDG alleges that Eurotunnel has been charging excessive tolls for trains using the tunnel, which has led to higher fares for passengers. Eurotunnel has denied the allegations, saying that its prices are "fair and reasonable". However, the CMA has said that it has "reasonable grounds" to believe that Eurotunnel may have infringed competition law. The investigation will now look at whether Eurotunnel has abused its dominant position in the market and whether it has charged excessive prices. The CMA has the power to impose fines of up to 10% of a company's annual turnover if it finds that it has infringed competition law. The Eurotunnel is a vital link between Britain and Europe, and it is used by millions of passengers and freight trains every year. The CMA's investigation could have a significant impact on the cost of travel between the two countries. The Eurotunnel was privatized in 1995 and is now owned by a consortium of investors. The company has a monopoly on the rail link between Britain and France, and it sets the tolls that train operators must pay to use the tunnel. The RDG has long complained that Eurotunnel's tolls are too high, and it has welcomed the CMA's investigation. The CMA's investigation is expected to take several months to complete.

title: Greta Thunberg: New beetle named after climate activist
text: Greta Thunberg: New beetle named after climate activist A newly discovered species of beetle has been named after Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg in recognition of her tireless efforts to raise awareness about the climate crisis. The insect, known as Nelloptodes gretae, is a tiny, flightless beetle found in the rainforests of Kenya. It belongs to the family of ground beetles, which are known for their hard exoskeletons and ability to thrive in diverse habitats. The discovery and naming of the beetle was made by a team of researchers from the Natural History Museum in London and the University of Turku in Finland. They chose the name "gretae" to honor Thunberg's unwavering commitment to protecting the planet. Lead researcher Dr. Martin Brendell said, "We were inspired by Greta's passion and determination in speaking out about the urgent need to address climate change. By naming this beetle after her, we hope to recognize her important work and inspire others to follow in her footsteps." The Nelloptodes gretae beetle is a small, black insect with a distinctive pattern of ridges and grooves on its back. It measures just a few millimeters in length and is adapted to living in the leaf litter of rainforest floors. While the beetle may not be particularly conspicuous or charismatic, Dr. Brendell emphasizes its importance as part of the rainforest ecosystem. "Ground beetles play a crucial role in nutrient cycling and soil health, and they serve as a food source for other animals," he explained. Thunberg has expressed gratitude for the honor, saying, "It's amazing to think that a beetle has been named after me. I hope it reminds people that even the smallest creatures are affected by climate change, and that we all have a responsibility to protect our planet." The naming of the beetle after Thunberg also highlights the growing recognition of the role that young people are playing in the fight against climate change. Thunberg's activism has inspired countless individuals, young and old, to speak out and demand action. By naming a beetle after her, the researchers hope to inspire future generations of scientists, conservationists, and activists to continue Thunberg's legacy of environmental stewardship. They believe that the beetle's name will serve as a reminder that even small actions can make a big difference in the fight against climate change.

title: Portishead-Bristol line restoration gets funding boost
text: Portishead-Bristol line restoration gets funding boost The restoration of the Portishead-Bristol line has received a significant funding boost, bringing the long-awaited project closer to reality. The Department for Transport has awarded £20 million to Network Rail to progress the scheme, which aims to reinstate passenger services between Portishead and Bristol Temple Meads. The funding will cover the development of detailed plans and the start of construction work. The Portishead-Bristol line was closed in 1964 as part of the Beeching Axe, a widespread reduction in Britain's railway network. Since then, there have been numerous attempts to reopen the line, but these have failed to secure the necessary funding. The restoration project has been welcomed by local communities and businesses, who believe it will improve connectivity and boost the local economy. The line is expected to carry up to 4,000 passengers per day and create approximately 1,000 jobs during construction. Transport Secretary Mark Harper said: "This funding boost is a major step forward in delivering the Portishead-Bristol line restoration. It will improve transport links for local communities and businesses, while also creating new jobs and supporting economic growth." The project involves the construction of a new 6.5-mile section of railway between Portishead and Pill, as well as the refurbishment of existing track and stations. The line will be electrified, enabling the use of electric trains. Network Rail's Western region managing director, Mark Langman, said: "We are delighted to have secured this funding, which will allow us to progress the restoration of the Portishead-Bristol line. This is a complex and challenging project, but we are committed to delivering it for the benefit of the local community and the wider region." The restoration project is scheduled to be completed by 2025. Once operational, the line will provide a vital link between Portishead and Bristol, reducing journey times and providing increased access to jobs, education, and leisure opportunities. The Portishead-Bristol line restoration is one of a number of rail projects that have received funding from the government in recent months. This includes the electrification of the Midland Main Line and the construction of a new high-speed rail line between London and Birmingham. The government's investment in rail infrastructure is part of its wider commitment to improving transport links and supporting economic growth throughout the country.

title: Colombian government to negotiate with striking farmers
text: Colombian Government to Negotiate with Striking Farmers The Colombian government has agreed to negotiate with striking farmers who have taken to the streets in protest over low crop prices and other grievances. They are demanding government action to address their concerns, including higher prices for their products, lower input costs, and increased access to credit. The government has said that it is committed to resolving the strike peacefully and that it will work with the farmers to find a solution that meets their needs while also protecting the interests of the broader economy. The strike has had a significant impact on the Colombian economy. The blockades have disrupted the flow of goods and services, and have caused shortages of some products. The strike has also led to job losses and increased prices for consumers. The Colombian government has faced criticism for its handling of the strike. Some critics have said that the government was too slow to react to the farmers' demands, and that it could have done more to prevent the strike from escalating. Others have criticized the government for using excessive force against the protesters. In one incident, police fired tear gas at a group of protesters, injuring several people. title: Nuclear Posture Review: US wants smaller nukes to counter Russia
text: Nuclear Posture Review: US Wants Smaller Nukes to Counter Russia The Biden administration's Nuclear Posture Review (NPR), unveiled on Thursday, outlines a shift in US nuclear policy towards smaller, lower-yield weapons designed to deter potential adversaries like Russia. The review acknowledges the evolving nature of nuclear threats and emphasizes the need to modernize the US nuclear arsenal. Key among the changes proposed by the NPR is the development of a new sea-launched nuclear cruise missile, the SLCM-N, with a smaller warhead than existing cruise missiles. This move is seen as a direct response to Russia's development of similar weapons, which could potentially be used against US allies and partners. The NPR also calls for continued modernization of the US nuclear triad, which includes land-based intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs), submarine-launched ballistic missiles (SLBMs), and strategic bombers. The administration plans to invest in new ICBMs, extend the service life of SLBMs, and purchase new heavy bombers to maintain a credible nuclear deterrent. However, the NPR also recognizes the importance of arms control and non-proliferation. The administration remains committed to the New START treaty, which limits the number of deployed strategic nuclear weapons, and is seeking to engage with Russia on a new framework for nuclear arms control. The NPR's emphasis on smaller, lower-yield weapons is a departure from previous US nuclear policy, which focused on larger, more powerful weapons. However, the administration believes that these smaller weapons provide a more credible deterrent against Russian aggression, particularly in the wake of the invasion of Ukraine. Critics of the NPR argue that smaller nuclear weapons could make their use more likely, as they may be seen as less destructive and therefore more acceptable. They also question the need for a new nuclear cruise missile, arguing that existing weapons are already sufficient. Despite these concerns, the NPR is likely to be welcomed by US allies and partners who have long been concerned about the threat posed by Russia's nuclear arsenal. The review's emphasis on deterrence and arms control also sends a positive signal to other nuclear powers, such as China and North Korea. The NPR represents a significant shift in US nuclear policy and could have far-reaching implications for the future of nuclear deterrence. It remains to be seen whether the administration's plans will be successful in countering Russia's nuclear threat and maintaining stability in a dangerous and uncertain world.

title: Egypt court upholds Muslim Brotherhood death sentences
text: Egypt Court Upholds Muslim Brotherhood Death Sentences An Egyptian court has upheld death sentences against 12 members of the banned Muslim Brotherhood, including its former leader Mohamed Badie, over deadly violence in 2013. The court also sentenced 28 other Brotherhood members to life in prison and acquitted 37. All the defendants were accused of inciting violence and murdering nine police officers in a clash with security forces following the military's ouster of Islamist President Mohamed Morsi. Rights groups condemned the verdicts, calling them a "travesty of justice" and urging Egypt to halt all death sentences. The Muslim Brotherhood, Egypt's largest Islamist movement, was designated a terrorist organization by the government in 2013 after Morsi was removed from power. The group has been the target of a sweeping crackdown by the authorities, with thousands of its members arrested and imprisoned. Wednesday's verdict came after a highly criticized trial that lasted nearly six years. The defendants were held in pretrial detention for over four years before the trial began. They were denied access to lawyers during interrogations and were allegedly subjected to torture and ill-treatment. During the trial, the prosecution relied heavily on confessions, which human rights advocates say were likely coerced under duress. The defense team also argued that the evidence against the defendants was fabricated and that the violence in 2013 was largely provoked by security forces. The verdicts have drawn international condemnation, with many observers seeing them as part of the Egyptian government's wider crackdown on dissent. Human Rights Watch called the trial "grossly unfair" and said it "demonstrates the Egyptian government's contempt for the rule of law." The Egyptian government has defended its handling of the case, saying that the defendants were given a fair trial and that the verdicts were based on evidence. However, it has faced accusations of silencing political opposition and violating human rights. The verdicts are a blow to the Muslim Brotherhood, which has been struggling to rebuild its organization after the 2013 crackdown. The group's credibility has been damaged by allegations of violence and extremism, and it has faced increasing opposition from both within and outside Egypt. The verdicts are also likely to further polarize Egyptian society and fuel instability in the country. Many Egyptians see the Muslim Brotherhood as a legitimate political force, while others view it as a dangerous extremist organization. The government's crackdown has only exacerbated these divisions.

title: NSA 'tracking' hundreds of millions of mobile phones
text: NSA Accused of Tracking Hundreds of Millions of Mobile Phones A new report has revealed that the US National Security Agency (NSA) has been tracking the location data of hundreds of millions of mobile phones around the world. The report, from the privacy advocacy group Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF), is based on a leaked NSA document that describes a program called "COBALT." COBALT allows the NSA to collect and store the location data of any mobile phone that connects to a cellular network. The EFF estimates that COBALT has been collecting location data from over 200 million mobile phones in 70 countries. The data includes the phone's location, the time and date of each location fix, and the identity of the phone's owner. The NSA claims that COBALT is used to track terrorists and other national security threats. However, the EFF argues that the program is a violation of the privacy of ordinary citizens. "The NSA is collecting vast amounts of data on the location of hundreds of millions of people around the world," said Nate Cardozo, a senior staff attorney at the EFF. "This is a clear violation of our privacy rights." The EFF has filed a lawsuit against the NSA, challenging the legality of COBALT. The lawsuit is currently pending in federal court. The revelations about COBALT have raised concerns about the extent of the NSA's surveillance activities. In recent years, the NSA has been accused of spying on Americans without a warrant, collecting data from phone calls and emails, and hacking into the computer systems of foreign governments. The NSA has defended its surveillance programs, arguing that they are necessary to protect national security. However, critics argue that the NSA has gone too far and that its surveillance activities are a threat to our civil liberties. The debate over the NSA's surveillance activities is likely to continue for years to come. However, the revelations about COBALT have made it clear that the NSA is collecting vast amounts of data on the location of ordinary citizens. This is a serious threat to our privacy rights, and it is important to challenge the NSA's surveillance programs.

title: Coronavirus pandemic 'costing councils £30m a month'
text: Coronavirus pandemic 'costing councils £30m a month' Local authorities in the UK are facing a financial crisis due to the coronavirus pandemic, with new figures revealing that they are losing £30 million a month in income. The Local Government Association (LGA) said that councils are seeing a sharp decline in income from areas such as parking, leisure centres and business rates. At the same time, they are facing increased costs as they provide essential services such as social care and waste collection. The LGA is calling on the government to provide additional financial support to councils to help them cope with the crisis. "The coronavirus pandemic is having a devastating impact on local government finances," said LGA chairman James Jamieson. "Councils are losing millions of pounds in income at a time when they are facing increased costs. This is putting essential services at risk." The LGA's figures show that councils are losing around £10 million a month in income from parking, £6 million from leisure centres and £5 million from business rates. They are also facing increased costs of around £9 million a month for social care and £4 million for waste collection. The LGA said that the government has provided some financial support to councils, but it is not enough to cover their losses. "The government needs to step up and provide additional financial support to councils," said Jamieson. "Without this support, councils will be forced to cut essential services or raise council tax." The government said that it is aware of the financial pressures facing councils and that it is considering what further support can be provided. "We are committed to supporting local government through this challenging time," said a government spokesman. "We have already provided £3.2 billion of additional funding to councils and we are considering what further support can be provided." The LGA said that it is important for the government to provide additional financial support to councils as soon as possible. "Councils need this support now to ensure that they can continue to provide essential services to their communities," said Jamieson.

title: St Helier Hospital cuts: Fun day protest against plans
text: Protesters gathered at St Helier Hospital for a fun day to voice their opposition to controversial plans to downgrade services. Campaigner Chris Le Masurier said the government needed to listen to the people and keep services at St Helier. "This hospital is at the heart of our community," he said. "It's a place where people come for help when they need it most. We cannot let the government take that away from us." Fellow campaigner Sarah Mallett said the fun day was a way to show the government that the people of Jersey would not give up fighting to save the hospital. "We're here to send a message that we're not going to let them get away with this," she said. "We're going to fight for our hospital, for our community, and for our future." title: M4 relief road judicial review rejected

title: Scottish government offers help to job loss BAE workers
